For this dish, I have added big long green and red chillies that is spicy but sweet.Â  Â The brinjals are sweet when cooked, only little seasoning is needed.Â  This dish takes only about 4 minutes to cook, aromatic, appetisingly good with rice. Nice vegetable dish.Â Ingredients1-2 medium size brinjals - cut wedgessome salt, oil and cornstarchÂ some sliced red carrots [for colour]1-2 long green and red chillies - seeded and cut wedges1 big onion - peeled and sliced2-3 cloves garlic - slicedSeasoningsome light soy sauce to tasteMix brinjals with some salt, oil and cornstarch.Â  Toss and mix well. Set aside.Heat some oil in a non stick wok, add in brinjals and carrots.Â  Spread out in a single layer if possible.Â  Fry until slightly charred [about 2 minutes].Â  Push aside add in garlic to fry until aromatic.Stir in chillies and onions Continue to fry, then add in some light soy sauce for extra flavour and water.Â  Toss well.Dish up to taste.

title: HAND KNEAD RAISIN BREAD LOAF
text: Can say it has been a long, long while I did not hand knead my bread dough from stretch, think ever since I was using the electric mixer.Â  But now, I may have to knead with my hands as my electric mixer for 3 decades is 'out of order'.Back to this recipe, is adapted fromÂ Che Nom Roti Benggali RecipeÂ with some modifications. Of course, her bread looks good [soft and chewy].Â  Â Mine is not bad too but I need to practise my hand kneading to get to her standard if possible.Ingredients[1 Pullman loaf]350 gmÂ bread flour + 1-2 tbsp wheat bran1 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt50-70 ml water or more if dough is too dry1 tbsp magarine1-2 tbsp raisins150 ml lukewarm water1.5-2 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp sugarAdd yeast to lukewarm water in a cup, add in sugar.Â  Stir well and leave for 2-3 minutes until frothy.Mix bread flour, wheat bran, sugar, salt in a mixing bowl.Â  Add in yeast mixture and extra water gradually to knead into a soft dough.Remove from bowl and knead on a smooth table top for about 5-10 minutes.Â Â Add in magarine and continue to knead until smooth, not sticky and pliable.Â Â Add in raisins, knead to incorporate into dough.Shape into a round ball, cover to proof for 20-30 minutes or double in size.Punch down dough to release trapped air, roll and shape into a Swiss roll dough.Place on a Pullman tin lined with parchment paper.Â  Cover to proof until double in size [about 1 hour].Bake in a preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 35-40 minutes.Remove from tin to cool on wire rack before slicing to serve.

title: EZ TO COOK PURPLE EGGPLANTS
text: Many people will scrape away the purple skin of eggplant when frying as the bright purple colour will turned brown when one does not know how to prevent discolourisation.Â  There is one simple way that can help to retain its vibrant purple colour.Â  Try the method below [no boiling, steaming or deep-frying] and you will be happy to cook eggplants for your family for its benefits.Â Benefits of eating eggplants:Â  a great source of vitamins and minerals, helps digestion, improves heart health, prevents cancer, increase brain function and prevents anemia.Ingredients2 medium size eggplants - washed and cut wedgessome chopped spring onions1 tbsp oil1 tsp sesame seed oil [optional]Seasoning Sauce2-3 garlic - chopped1 red chilli - sliced or chopped2-3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp sugar3 tbsp waterCut eggplants, add some salt, cornstarch and oil [this will prevent oxidation that discolourised them].Â  Toss well and set aside.Combined sauce ingredients.Heat a non stick wok, add oil.Â  Pan fry the eggplants [1] in a single layer until light brown and soft.Â Â Pour in the seasoning sauce.Â  Stir fry to mix well until eggplants are cooked through.Add chopped spring onions.Â  Stir and dish up to serve.

title: STEAMED PAUS - PANDAN TAOYONG FILLING
text: Making paus is not difficult if you have the perseverance and patience to try until you succeed.Â  It may not be smooth sailing but it is worth giving it a try.Â  Stick to a sure can [fail proof] pau skin recipe and you are sure to create indefinite varieties of paus with various fillings [sweet or savoury] and in various shapes.Sweet pau fillings are easily available from the stores which makes pau making at home less tedious.Â  You can even try preparing any pau filling that you are confident with.The pau filling which I used here is from the store, the sweetness and taste is acceptable to me.Â  You can used less filling if the paste is too sweet.Â  Personally,Â  for home consumption, I prefer paus with a thicker skin with less filling.Ingredients Pau Skin Dough[makes about 20 paus]500 gm pau flour1 tsp instant yeast1 tsp sugar270 ml lukewarm water or slightly more [add gradually]Pau Filling250-300 gm Pandan Taoyong Paste - store bought [can used any store bought sweet paste of your choice]Combined sugar with some water in a cup or bowl.Â  Sprinkle in yeast and leave for 1 minute or so.Â  Stir until dissolved.Â  It should be smooth and silky.Gradually pour into flour, mix into a rough dough.Â  Gradually add in remaining water and knead until dough is soft, smooth and pliable.Â Â Shape into a ball, dust with some flour to prevent sticking to hand.Â  Place in the mixing bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough, then roll into round.Â  Divide into 20 equal portions and roll into balls.Â  Flatten each one in circle. Flatten the edges, place filling [about less than a tablespoon] in the centre, gather the edges together to seal to make a round pau or pleat the edges into a pau shape.Place on parchment paper and steaming tray.Â  Proof for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Finish doing the rest.Â  Place steaming tray over rapidly boiling.Â  Cover to steam for 12 minutes.Â  Off heat, leave in steamer and remove paus only after 2-3 minutes.Cool on wire rack or serve immediately.

title: PUMPKIN KUIH EE IN GULA MERAH SYRUP
text: August 3, 2020 marks half year of the Chinese lunar calendar.Â  Some Chinese families will prepare Kuih Ee as offerings to the deities or ancestors.Â  I do not follow this procedure, it is not a must for my family but with some extra free time, I did it.Anyway, with all the ingredients available here is a recipe which I like to share.Â  For the syrup, I used a small bit of Penang local ginger [popularly known as Air Itam ginger] and Gula Merah.Â  The syrup is aromatic and sweetness is acceptable as a dessert. I also add some chopped red dates.Â  As for the rice balls, I used glutinous rice flour, pumpkin puree, water and some white sugar.Â Â Ingredients[serves 4-5]150 gm pumpkin puree150 gm glutinous rice flour1 tbsp fine sugara few tbsp water600 ml water or more [depends on the sweetness you prefer]100 gm gula merah1 small knob of ginger - rinsed and lightly bruised6 red dates - deseeded and choppedSteamed sliced pumpkin for 20 minutes over high heat or until soft.Â  Mash into puree while still hot with 1 tbsp fine sugar [optional].Â  Leave to cool.Bring water to boil with ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in sugar, continue to boil until sugar dissolves.Â  Tastes to adjust bearing in mind that red dates will add sweetness to the syrup. Add in red dates, continue to boil until soft.Â  Off heat, leave to cool completely.Â  Tip: can prepare earlier before preparing the rice balls.In a big bowl, mix glutinous rice flour gradually to pumpkin puree then knead into a smooth pliable dough.Â  Add some water gradually if dough is too dry.Â  Leave to rest for 20-30 minutes before shaping into round balls.Bring a pot of water to rolling boil, drop in rice balls in batches.Â  The rice balls will float to the surface when cooked.Â  Remove with a serrated ladle and drop them into a bowl of cool water, then dish up using the serrated ladle.Add to prepare syrup.Serve.

title: TELUR MASAK BALADO
text: This is probably the first time that I cooked hard boiled eggs in this 'elaborate' way, having to blend the sauce ingredients.Â  But the end result is worth the attempt.Â  According to the source recipe, this dish is rather spicy 'pedas in Bahasa Malaysia'.Â  I did reduce the amount of fresh chillies used and the spiciness is acceptable.Â Â For reference, I had googled for the meaning of 'Balado'.It is a type of hot and spicy mixture found in Minang cuisine of West Sumatra, Indonesia.Â  It is a chilli sauce usually mixed and stir fried together with its main ingredients.Â  Alternatiive names stated as 'Sambal Goreng' or 'Sambal Lado'.The sauce is of thick consistency, aromatic, tastes spicy, savoury, sweet and sourish. Addition of kaffir leaves adds fragrance to this dish.Â  It is appetising to savour with rice.Â  I also discovered that this sauceÂ  [sambal] can be used to cooked fried chicken, too.Recipe adapted fromÂ  Che Nom ResipiÂ with modificationsIngredients6 hard-boiled eggs - shelled and lightly poked with a forksome chilli powder and tumeric powder to fry eggs [optional]some kaffir leaves [whole and shredded]1 piece assam keping [assam gelugor] - rinsed1 tomato - chopped4 tbsp coconut powder mixed with 125 ml water [can used fresh coconut milk]3 tbsp cooking oilsalt, sugar and chicken stock granules to tasteSauce Ingredients [blended]3-4 red chillies [more spicy - used up to 8]Â 3-4 small red chillies3 shallots3 garlic1/2 red onion - peeled and choppedUsing a non stick wok, add oil and some chilli powder and tumeric powder [if using], fry hard boiled eggs until golden brown or a little crispy.Â  Remove and set aside.Using the same oil and wok, saute blended paste with some salt and sugar over low heat until oil separates.Â  Add some water if it is too dry.Add in chopped tomatoes and assam keping, continue to fry until oil separates.Â  Add in a portion of coconut milk, some kaffir leaves and fried eggs.Â  Continue to fry before adding the balance coconut milk.Seasoned sauce and cook till sauce is of thick consistency.Dish up to serve.Â  Garnish with some shredded kaffir leaves.

title: COLOURFUL STIR FRY TOFU PUFFS
text: A homey, colourful stir fry tofu puff dish that is tasty and delicious.Â  Very economical to prepare at home for the family.Â  It is a very healthy dish too, with all the colourful ingredients.The tofu puffs absorbed the simple seasoning sauce [light soy sauce, oyster sauce] and the aroma is enhanced with the addition of sesame seed oil.A dish which can be served with rice or porridge.Â  It would be great to use the recipe to fry noodles like rice vermicelli [beehoon], glass noodles [tanghoon] and any noodles of your choice.Ingredients[serves 2-3]100 gm tofu puffs - soaked in hot boiling water, cooled and squeeze out the water - cut halve diagonally1 small piece black fungus - soaked to plumb up, break into pieces1/2 green capsicum - seeded and cut wedges1 red chilli - seeded and cut wedges1 onion - peeled and cut into piecessome shredded carrots and chopped ginger1/2 cup water1 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, oyster sauce, tomato sauce, cooking wine1 tsp sugardash of pepper and salt to taste1 tsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp water [combined]Â Prepare the ingredients.Â  Heat up wok, add in oil.Â  Saute chopped ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in tofu puffs, black fungus and carrots.Â  Stir fry for a minute before adding the seasoning.Add in water, bring to boil and let it simmer for a minute for the puffs to absorb the flavours.Add in onions and chillies.Â  Give it a good stir and thicken with cornstarch water.Â  Add a little more water if it is too dry.Mix well and dish up to serve.

title: POTATO OMELETTE
text: One-minute omelette, so called by the chef who shared this recipe on you-tube video, who has also generously shared another omelette recipeÂ Egg Omelette With Tofu.Â  Both are quick cook recipes so suitable for busy people who cooks at home.I had prepared this a few times and finally sharing it here.Â  Hope is of use to novice and busy cooks when we run short of ideas on what to cook.The shredded potatoes are soft and moist and the omelette is fragrant with the lovely crispy edges.Â  You can fine tune the seasoning according to your preference.This recipe adapted fromÂ OE CooksÂ with modifications.Ingredients2 medium size potatoes - peeled and shredded3 eggsÂ some chopped spring onionssalt and pepper to tastePeel and shred the potatoes in a bowl.Â  Season with salt and pepper to taste.Lightly beat eggs in another bowl.Â  Add in chopped spring onions.Heat some oil in a wok, stir fry potatoes until soft.Â  Pour in beaten eggs, spread out mixture and pan fry until the base is cooked.Â Â Flip over to fry the other side until golden brown and cooked through [if you are skillful otherwise, slide the omelette onto a big plate then invert back to the wok to continue frying until the edges are crispy, omelette is cooked.Slide omelette onto serving platter, sliced to serve hot orÂ  serve whole.

title: PAN FRIED EGGPLANT WITH FRAGRANT SAUCE
text: Another vegetable dish quite similar in preparation as this recipeÂ Stir Fry Brinjal and Lady's Fingers.Â  Once you master the tip on preparing the eggplants or brinjals, you should be able to cook up a variety of dishes with this vegetable.By coating the eggplants with salt, cornstarch and oil, it will prevent them turning brown and oxidation.Â  After frying the eggplants retain a nice, bright purple color.You can choose to fry the eggplant till soft or just tender with a bite in this quick cook style by pan frying them.Â  You can flavour it with any flavours of your choice be it spicy, savoury, sweet and sour.Â  A versatile flavour dish you can create easily.Ingredients2 medium size brinjal - cut long strip wedges [or according toÂ  own preference]some salt, cornstarch and oil to coat vegetablessome chopped spring onions1-2 tbsp oilSeasoning [combine in a bowl]3-4 cloves garlic - peeled and choppedsome chopped red chillies or small red chillies1 tsp sugar2 tbsp each light soy sauce1 tbsp each of oyster sauce and cooking winesome dark soy sauce for colour1 tsp sesame seed oil3 tbsp waterPrepare the vegetables as stated above.Â  Quickly sprinkle some salt and cornstarch.Â  Add a few drops of oil.Â  Shake and mix until the vegetables are coated with the salt, cornstarch and oil.Â  You can prepare this immediately after cutting the eggplants.Heat a non stick wok with some oil, add in eggplants to fry on a single layer until lightly brown, then quickly stir fry over high heat for several minutes.Â Â Pour in the seasoning and continue to fry until well mixed and vegetables look soft and shiny.Dish up to serve immediately.

title: CHAI KUIH [STEAMED YAM BEAN DUMPLINGS]
text: Irresistible traditional Steamed Vegetable Dumplings using a unique translucent wrapper to wrap the simply delicious fried jicama.Â  The wrapper is made from wheat starch and tapioca flour, is chewy when steamed.Â  Many may be a little cautious about the fat content in this kuih yet can't resist having a bite if the dainty kuih.My first posting on this kuih was in 2014 [Steamed Chai Kuih].Â  It is a lovely recipe where the wrapper stays soft and chewy when cooled and even after a day.Â  The wrapper recipe here gives the same results.Â  The recipe portion is smaller than the first [makes about 25 pieces].Â  Perhaps, for beginners, you can choose to follow this recipe.Â Â The filling can be prepared a day earlier.Â Yambean Filling-Ingredients and Preparation250 gm yambean/sengkuang - after skinned and shredded50-100 gm carrot - peeled and shredded2 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed and chopped coarsely1/2 tbsp chopped garlic1 tbsp oil100 gm minced meat [optional] - I omitSeasoning1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp pepper1/4 tsp salt1 tsp sugar [I omit]2 tbsp water [if necessary]Heat up oil, saute chopped garlic until fragrant. Add in dried prawns . Stir fry then add in shredded vegetables. Stir to mix well.Â Add seasoning and water [if necessary]. Continue to stir fry until vegetables are softened [cover with lid] over medium low heat and aromatic.Dish up to cool. This filling can be prepared in advance and refrigerate until required.Ingredients for Dumpling Skin100 gm wheat starch [tang mien fun] + 2 tbsp wheat starch100 gm tapioca flour1/2 tsp salt400 ml boiling water3-4 tbsp cooking oilÂ Combine wheat flour, tapioca flour and salt in a mixing bowl.Â  Pour in boiling water and stir immediately to mix well.Â  Cover and leave aside for 10 minutes.Add in oil and knead into a smooth dough [this takes some time].Â  Cover and rest for 5 minutes.Divide dough into smaller portions. Flatten with a roller into a thin dough, cut into rounds with a 4-5 inch round cutter or lid of a container.Â  Flatten each piece before wrapping up the filling.Â  Seal well.Â  You can wrap up dough in rounds, oval or half moon shapes with pleats according to your preference. Please referÂ hereÂ for illustration on how to wrap the kuih.Arrange dumplings onto a greased steaming tray, steam for 7-8 minutes on high heat.Â  I steamed for 10-15 minutes using a 2 tier aluminium steamer.Remove, brush with fried garlic oil while still hot.Â  Serve with sweet chilli sauce.

title: STIR FRY BRINJAL AND LADY'S FINGERS
text: A lovely stir-fry vegetable dish with brinjals/eggplant and Lady's fingers.Â  Many would think that brinjals takes some time to soften when cooking them and some would choose to deep fry them to retain its bright purplish colour.For this dish, just with stir frying method, the purplish colour stays, the brinjals are soft and the Lady's fingers are bright green and crunchy.Â Â Fried with the fermented black beans and aromatics, this isÂ  a yummy vegetable that goes well with rice and porridge.Â  Try serving it with hard-boiled salted eggs and sambal belacan, wow! It is an appetising meal for me.When I shared this picture to my friend, he does not believe that the brinjals can be soft and the skin purplish in colour.Â  He said the Lady's fingers would be soft and soggy before the brinjals are cooked.I loved the nice greenish colour and crunchy Lady's fingers.Â  More so is the purplish colour, soft and sweetness of the brinjals.Â  The vegetables blend so well with the savoury seasonings.Ingredients1 medium-large brinjal - cut wedges [depends on preference]4-5 Lady's fingers - cut into 1 inch sections1 red chilli - cut ringssome choppedÂ  ginger and garlic1 heaped tbsp fermented black beans [tau see] - rinse and drainsome salt, cornstarch and oil to coat vegetablesSeasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce, oyster sauce and cooking winePrepare the vegetables as stated above.Â  Quickly sprinkle some salt and cornstarch.Â  Add a few drops of oil.Â  Shake and mix until the vegetables are coated with the salt, cornstarch and oil.Heat a non stick wok with some oil, put in the cut vegetables and quickly stir fry over high heat for several minutes.Â  Push aside, add in the aromatics and chillies, continue to fry the vegetables.Â  Pour in the seasoning.Give it a good stir and sprinkle some water.Stir fry for a second and dish up to serve.

title: AWESOME EGG OMELETTE WITH TOFU
text: A simple and easy to prepare omelette filled with loads of satisfaction and benefits.Tofu is much healthier than meat, an excellent source of protein, fiber, vitamins and minerals without the saturated fat and cholesterol in meat.Â Â Eggs are rich sources of selenium, vitamin D, B6, B12 and minerals such as zinc, iron and copper.Â  Is a source of fat soluble vitamins A, D, E, K and lecithin.Just these 2 main ingredients may fulfil your body's needs of the above.This is a light dish suitable for the young and old.Â  Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.Â  It has a nice aroma and fragrance of the fried eggs like other omelettes.I made this omelette using a 18 cm width non stick pan.Ingredients[makes a 6-7 inch wide and 1 inch thick omelette]2 large eggs [can use 3 if you like]1 piece tofu - cut into cubessome chopped spring onionsSeasoningsalt and pepper to tastesome cooking wine1 tsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp waterPat dry tofu.Â  Cut into cubes.Â  Place on a plate, drain off excess water before adding to eggs.Place seasoning ingredients in a bowl.Â  Break in eggs, lightly beat and mix with seasoning.Add in tofu pieces and some chopped spring onions.Heat a non stick pan with some oil, pour in all the mixture, slightly shake the mixture to level it for even cooking.Â  Cover with level and leave to fry over medium heat until the edges are firm and crispy.When the egg mixture in the centre is almost cooked, lightly loosen the omelette.Â  Flip it onto a flat plate, then slide it back to the pan to fry until omelette is cooked through and golden brown.Â  Sprinkle some chopped spring onions.Remove onto a serving plate.Â  garnish with extra chopped spring onions.

title: BITTERGOURD OMELETTE
text: A very simple omelette but wow is amazing. It tastes better than what I expected.Â  Bittergourd is supposed to be bitter but it isn't.Blanching it before mixing with the beaten egg, speeds up the frying process and gives it a nice bright green colour.Â  A quick cook dish that goes well with rice and porridge.Â Â Just 3 eggs and half a medium size bittergourd, it makes a 8-9 inch size omelette depending on the thickness of the fried omelette.Â  I wonder if you have tried frying omelette this way, read the steps below, no harm trying.Ingredients[makes an 8-9 inch omelette]3 medium eggsÂ 1/2 a medium size bittergourd - seeded and cut in 4 quarters lengthwisesalt, pepper and cooking wine to taste1 tsp cornstarch mix with 2 tsp wateroil for fryingBring some water to boil in a pan with some salt.Â  Quickly blanch the bittergourd until it turns bright green.Â  Remove into a bowl of cold water.Â  Drain and cut into small cubes.Break up eggs into a bowl, add in bittergourd and seasoning to taste together with cornstarch mix.Â  Light beat up the ingredients. Mix well.Heat some oil in a non stick pan, pour in 1/3 to 1/2 of the mixture.Â  Quickly stir fry to almost firm.Â  Dish out and mix with the remaining egg mixture.Using the same pan, heat up some oil, pour in the mixture, swirl the mixture into a round.Â  Leave to fry until almost cooked.Â  Flip over to fry the other side until the omelette is done.Â  [If it is difficult to flip it, slip the omelette onto a round plate, then flip by inverting it into the pan].Dish up onto a plate, serve whole or cut into pieces.

title: INDIAN CURRY EGGS WITH OKRA
text: It is curry time again.Â  Just this curry is enough for a satisfyingÂ  meal with rice.Â  I have been looking through some Indian curry recipes and realised that it has the least seasoning.Â  Many only uses just salt.Â  The reason probably is that Indian curries use many types of cooking aromatics [such as shallots, onions, tomatoes, ginger, garlic and peppers etc.] and spices [such as cloves, coriander, cinnamon, cumin, cardamon etc].Â  Lots of shallots, onions and tomatoes are used which give the curry its flavours.Â The curries are tasty, aromatic and flavourful. Looks to be a healthy dish.Â  Great!!!The curry paste ingredients is enough to cook about 7-8 eggs if not using Okra.Recipe adapted fromÂ Spice EatsIngredients[serves 3-4]10-12 Lady's fingers3-4 hard boiled eggs - shelled1 red chilli - cut1 green chilli - cuta few stalks coriander leaves - chopped3-4 tbsp cooking oil1 tsp salt to taste250 ml waterSpices & Aromatics3 cardamons3-4 cloves1 piece cinnamon1 tsp each of ginger and garlic pasteCurry Paste [Blended]3 small green chillies [can used 2-3 dried red chillies]100 gm shallots2 tomatoes - blendedDry Spice Powders2 tsp coriander powder2 tsp chilli powder1/4 tsp tumeric powder1 tsp cumin powder1 tsp fennel powder1/2 tsp garam masala powderPrepare the curry ingredients as above.Fry eggs in a non stick wok with oil and 1/4 tsp tumeric powder and 1 tsp chilli powder.Â  Fry until golden brown.Â  Remove.Using the same oil, spices until aromatic then add inÂ  onions paste.Â  Fry for 1-2 minutes over medium heat, then add in tomatoes, continue to fry for several minutes.Â  Add in ginger, garlic paste.Â  Continue to fry until oil separates and paste is thick.Â  Add in the dry spice powders and salt, continue to fry for 5-6 minutes.Add in 250 ml water,Â  bring to boil, then add in the fried eggs and lady's fingers.Â  Bring to boil, add in chillies, then cover to cook until vegetables are cooked.Lastly, stir in the chopped coriander leaves.Dish up to serve.

title: RED BRAISED FRIED TOFU
text: This is a simple vegetarian dish with firm tofu as the main ingredient.Â  Yet, it is tasty and delicious to serve with rice.Â  Savoury, sweet in taste and aromatic.Â  A dish that you can choose to add to your meal whenever you think of going meatless.Â  Suitable for the young and old.Â Â Studies show that regularly eating tofu can provide lower total cholesterol and triglyceride levels.Â  It is healthier than meat as soy provides an excellent source of protein, fiber, vitamins and minerals, minus the saturated fats.Â Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]2 pieces firm tofu - sprinkle some fine salt over tofu pieces, leave for 15 minutes.Â  Press lightly to release some water, then cut each piece into 6 pieces1 red chilli - seeded and cut into pieces1 green chilli - seeded and cut into piecessome soaked black fungus - cut stripssome chopped ginger and garlic1-2 tbsp fine dried soy gluten [optional]1 tbsp rock sugarSeasoning1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, mushroom sauce and sweet soy sauce*1/2 tsp dark soy sauce for colour* can replace by adding some sugarsalt to tastedash of peppersesame seed oilPrepare the ingredientsÂ  as listed.Â  Heat a non stick wok with some oil enough to fry the tofu pieces.Â  Slowly put in the tofu pieces to fry over medium high heat until golden brown on both sides.Â  Dish up, set aside.Remove excess oil, add in rock sugar to caramelise over medium heat.Â  [This process results inÂ  nutty sweet flavour and brown colour].Â  Return the fried tofu to wok once the rock sugar has caramelised.Â  Swirl the wok to coat the tofu pieces with the caramel.Add in the remaining ingredients except the chillies and seasoning.Â  Stir fry to mix the ingredients well.Add in seasoning, chillies and water.Â  Bring to boil, then braise for 1-2 minutes until water is reduced.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Dish up to serve with rice.

title: EZ CARAMEL KAYA
text: This recipe was from a friend.Â  She explained it is very easy to prepare and I give it a go as my preserves is soon finishing.Â  I have being making caramel kaya withÂ this recipeÂ which uses 5 eggs and half of portion of this coconut milk of this recipe.Â  So if you are looking for a caramel kaya with less coconut milk then you can refer toÂ this recipe.From this recipe below, I was able to make 4-5 tubs [150 gm each].Â  Since the process of kaya making is about the same, why not prepare a bigger portion in one go.Ingredients[makes about 4 tubs x 150 gm]6 eggs [AA size]200 gm + 100 gm sugar500 ml thick coconut milk5-6 blades screw pine [pandan] leaves - washed and knottedIngredients for Caramel KayaÂ BeatenÂ  EggsPreparing CaramelBeat the eggs in a large bowl, then strained into another bowl.Â  Set aside.Place 100 gm sugar in a heavy base pan [I used a copper wok].Â  Cook caramel over medium low heat.Â  Stirring continuously until golden brown in colour and sugar has dissolved.Â  Off heat.Â  Remove from stove.Gradually pour in the coconut milk, stirring while you pour in the coconut milk.Â  Add in the remaining sugar and pandan leaves.Â  Continue to stir until the mixture is well mixed.Â Â Remove from heat and leave to cool down for about 2 minutes before gradually adding in the beaten eggs.Â  Stir to mix well before returning to cook over low heat.Turn heat to low, place pan over it and continue to stir the mixture for about 15 minutes until paste is of runny consistency.Â  Paste will thicken slightly when cooled down.Â  NOTE: it is necessary to stir continuously here to prevent batter becoming lumpy.Store in plastic or glass tubs.Â  Refrigerate.Stirring caramel with sugar, coconut milk and pandan leaves

title: STEAMED EGGPLANT WITH FRIED MUI CHOY
text: This recipe is an extended post from my previous posting onÂ EZ Vegetarian Fried Mui Choy.Â  I have used half of the mui choy dish to steam these eggplant.[EZ Vegetarian Fried Mui Choy]It is very easy, simple once you have got the Mui Choy dish ready.Â  As the dish is tasty enough, you can used it to steam with other ingredientsÂ  such as minced meat or tofu or perhaps to use it to fry another vegetable 'Kailan'.Â Â Steaming the eggplant takes only 10-12 minutes and the dish is ready to serve.The savoury taste of the mui choy blends well with the natural sweetness of the eggplants.Â  Great meatless dish.I like it served with rice or porridge.Recipe adapted from Bo Bo Vegan You-tube Video with slight modificationsIngredients[serves 3]400 gm eggplant - washed and cut wedges1 tbsp salt5 cups watersome oil, cornstarch and dash of salt [optional]1/2 portion of the Mui Choy Recipe [EZ Vegetarian Fried Mui Choy]some chopped Chinese celery or coriander [optional]Â Wash and cut eggplants into bite size cubes or wedges [own preference].Â  Soak them in salt water for 15 minutes. Drain in colander.Â  This is to preserve the bright purple colour of the eggplant after steaming.Â  Mix with some oil,Â  cornstarch and salt if using.Prepare a steaming plate.Â  Arrange eggplant on plate, top with fried mui choy.Steamed over medium high heat for 12 minutes.Â  Removed and garnish with chopped coriander or Chinese celery.Serve.

title: EZ VEGETARIAN FRIED MUI CHOY
text: This fried mui choy was actually prepared as a steaming ingredient for another dish with eggplants.Â  But I thought it could be served as it is too with porridge or rice.Â  So I am sharing it as a separate post for future reference.Â  For this portion, I can used it to steam eggplant or with minced meat.Steamed Eggplant with Fried Mui ChoyPreserved Vegetables [Mui Choy æ¢…ä¹¾èœ]Recipe adapted from Bo Bo Vegan You-tube Video with slight modificationsIngredients150 gm salty mui choy - soaked in water with some salt for 30 minutes and rinsed under running water before cutting into small piecessome chopped ginger and garlic1 red chilli - cut small pieces1/2 cup water or moreSeasoningsugar to tastesome light soy sauceÂ dash of pepperRinse then soak mui choy in water with some salt for 30 minutes.Â  Rinse 2-3 times in a large bowl of water to ensure the sand are removed.Â  Squeezed dry and cut.Heat up a wok, add oil saute ginger and garlic [omit garlic if serving dish for religious reason] over medium heat until aromatic.Â  Â Add red chilli, continue to fry.Add mui choy and seasoning, continue to fry for 1-2 minutes.Â  Add water, bring to boil.Â  Lower heat to simmer for 2-3 minutes [not until dry if you prefer the vegetables with some liquid sauce].Dish up to serve with porridge or rice or for steaming with other ingredients such as eggplants or minced meat if prefered.

title: STIR FRIED BRINJALS WITH OKRA
text: MCO is now on Phase 4 and home-makers are cracking their heads as to what to cook for the families.Â  Some would have ran short of ideas on what to cook and for those who have been buying takeaway food would probably be tired of having to think of which food outlet to go, concerned about food hygiene and social distancing [the queue etc] and to sum the costs of living.As such, to deal with the new normal, we have to consider making changes to our way of living and decide if it is high time we should do some cooking at home.Â  No worries, check out some simple recipes here [from my collection of recipes].Â  It may be of help to you if you are looking for easy, simple, quick cook and healthy recipes to prepare for your family and yourself.It is a better and healthier option to prepare our own nutritious meals at home.This stir fried vegetable dish is one of the many simple, healthy dishes from my collection.Â  If you love your vegetables to be crunchy, do not overcooked them.Â  Aromatic platter of vegetables is here for you.Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 medium size brinjal [eggplant] - washed and sliced [see picture]6 Lady's fingers - washed and cut slantwisesome sliced carrots1 sprig curry leavessome cut green and red chillies1 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed and choppedsome chopped garlicSeasoning1 tbsp each of soy sauce, oyster sauce and cooking winesome salt and chicken stock granules to tastesome waterHeat wok, add about 1 tablespoon of oil, saute chopped garlic until aromatic.Â  Add in chopped dried prawns, stir fry until fragrant.Add in brinjals, continue to stir fry over high heat, cover to cook for 2-3 minutes until brinjals are a little softÂ  before adding the remaining ingredients.Â  Give it a good stir, add in seasoning and some water.Â  Cover to cook for a minute until the vegetables are soft.Dish up to serve.

title: EZ BANANA BREAD
text: On one of the days of Phase 3 Malaysia's MCO to curb Covid19 infection, I bought some bananas which look greenish yellow.Â  Hoping that they would be ripe and turn yellow in a day or two for consumption but they didn't.Â  Instead the skin turned greyish, greenish and yellowish.Â  I was thinking of discarding them, but before I did that, I peeled one and discovered that they are already ripe and edible.Â  It is impossible to finish the lot of them and afraid that they may be spoiled the next day, I decided to make banana bread.Â Â I came across this recipe from Brian's CuisineÂ which suits me well.Â  The bananas need to be frozen for 24 hours before using.Â  Great, I went ahead to get it done for the next day's baking.This is my opinion - awesome banana bread loaf.Â  The steps are so easy to follow, just mixing the ingredients without the need of a mixer, yet the result is satisfactory.Â  This recipe is a keeper and in future, I need not worry if I have leftover bananas at home.The banana bread is soft, moist and the sweetness is just nice for me.Â Ingredients350 gm banana flesh - peeled and freezed100 gm castor sugar70 gm brown sugar2 large eggs [about 110 gm]-lightly beaten55 ml unsalted melted butter220 gm plain flour - sifted with baking soda1 tsp baking soda1/4 tsp saltPeel the bananas to get 350 gm of the flesh.Â  Cut into sections and store them in a zipper bag.Â  Leave in freezer for at least a day before using.The next day, thaw the frozen bananas for at least 2 hours, mash into puree.Â  Set aside and get ready the remaining ingredients.In a large mixing bowl, put in mashed bananas, add in both sugars.Â  Mix well until sugar dissolves.Â  Add in beaten eggs and salt.Â  Continue to mix well with a hand whisk.Pour in melted butter.Â  Mix well.Add egg mixture into sifted flour.Â  Combine ingredients by folding lightly until the flour is not visible [Do Not Over-mix batter].Pour into a greased baking tin [I used an aluminium foil tray of size 12cm x 20cm x 5cm].Â  Tap tray a few times to release trapped air.Bake in a preheated oven at 180 for 47-50 minutes.Â  Test with a skewer before removing from oven.Â  Leave to cool in a wire rack for 20-30 minutes before dislodging bread.Slice and serve.

title: TANGY DISH WITH EGGS AND RICE
text: MCO, no regular outdoor exercises and activities.Â  It is important to stay home, stay safe and stay healthy.Â  My friends say must eat more protein food to boost our immune system to fight Covid19.Â  Much ideas have been shared but isÂ  it possible to follow, hmmm......Nope, I cannot, best is to do with what is available in the kitchen and pantry.Â  Most crucial during this time is not to waste FOOD.This One Dish Meal to me is satiable.Â  The tangy tastes makes this platter appetising.Â  Â If you can't go meatless, it is not a problem to add some minced meat or prawns to this dish.Ingredients[serves 2-3]2-3 eggs - keep whole or lightly beaten200 gm cabbage - cut small pieces1-2 tomatoes - cut small pieces50 gm red carrots - peeled and cut small pieces15 gm black fungus [bok nee] - soakedsome chopped gingersome chopped spring onions1 cup water1 tbsp cornstarch + water for thickeningSeasoning [combined]3 tbsp tomato sauce2 tbsp spicy sweet chilli sauce1 tbsp vinegar1/2 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp saltHeat up a wok, add some oil, saute ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in cabbage and carrots, continue to fry for a minute before adding the black fungus and tomatoes.Add in the seasoning, continue to stir until all the ingredients are well mixed.Â  Pour in water, bring to boil.Â  Thicken with cornstarch water.Â Taste to adjust seasoning before putting in the eggs.Â  Let the eggs firm up.Â  Add in chopped spring onions.Prepare 2-3 plates of rice.Scoop fried ingredients over rice.Â  Serve immediately.

title: GINGER AND EGG FRIED RICE
text: Ginger and Egg Fried for MCO lunch.Â  Friends, all talking about food, food and food.Â  Third phase of MCO and all are running out of ideas on what to cook for the family.Â  Instead of stressing myself out, I will look for simple dishes with minimum number of ingredients and its availability.Â  During MCO, I would not go marketing daily. Best to stay home, stay safe.I have posted a fried rice with ginger recipeÂ here.Â  It is one of my favourite fried rice but this recipe needs more ingredients.Â  So I sourced for an alternative, simpler recipe.This is it.Â  Simple yet tasty, aromatic, most important can fill the hungry stomach.Ingredients[serves 2-3]3 bowls cooked rice [preferably overnight rice]2-3 inch piece ginger [used good quality ginger if possible]3 eggs - lightly beatenSeasoningsalt to tastedash of msgÂ Grated ginger and squeeze out the ginger.Â  You can choose not to, it is alright.Heat up a non-stick wok, add in the rice.Â  Toss the rice until light.Add in 2 tablespoon of oil, eggs and seasoning to taste.Â  Continue to stir fry the rice over medium heat until eggs are cooked and rice is light.Â Drizzle in the ginger juice.Â  Continue to fry until rice is light.Dish up to serve.

title: STEAMED PUMPKIN RICE WITH MUSHROOMS
text: Another tasty and yummy One Dish Meal during Malaysian MCO, 'Steamed Pumpkin Rice with Mushrooms'.Â  The original recipe is for vegetarians but I have modified it a little with addition of some minced meat and dried prawns.Â  I did that because it is for my family and just to avoid my hubby asking why there is no dried prawns in the rice.Â Â Â If you wish to go meatless, just omit the dried prawns and minced meat.Â  It is as yummy-licious.Â  The rice is light,Â  fluffy, whereas the pumpkin is naturally sweet and blends well with the mushrooms that tastes savoury.Â  The rice is extra fragrant with the fried shallots.Â  Tastes good.Recipe adapted from Irene Yong's You-tubeÂ Video [with modifications] -Â å—ç“œé¦™è‡ç‡œé£¯|Pumpkin & Shiitake Stewed RiceI am happy that this rice turned out yummy and I was able to share a portion with my neighbour [a widower] during MCO as he has to get his meals from the food stalls.Ingredients[serves 3-4]2 cups rice - wash and drain [I used the plastic rice cup]2 cups waterÂ 300-350 gm pumpkin - skinned and cut small chunks3 dried shiitake mushrooms - soaked and cut strips30 gm or 1 tbsp dried prawns [omit if vegetarian]50-70 gm minced meat [omit is vegetarian]4-5 shallots - peeled and sliced thinlyÂ 1 tbsp chopped ginger3 tbsp cooking oilsome chopped Chinese celery and some cut small red chilliesSeasoning1 tbsp light soy sauce [good quality]1 tsp salt1/2 tsp white pepper1 tsp dark soy sauceUsing a non stick fry pan, fry shallots in oil until golden brown and crispy.Â  Dish up and set aside.Add in mushrooms and ginger to fry pan, fry until aromatic.Â  Add in dried prawns and minced meat if using.Â  Continue to fry until meat turns white.Â  Add in seasoning and pumpkin.Â  Stir fry to mix for a minute.Add in the rice and dark soy sauce [if using],Â  stir fry to mix the ingredients.Â  Add in fried shallots, stir to combine with the rice.Dish up into a steaming tray, spread out evenly and pour in water.Â  Bring fried ingredients to cook by steaming in a steamer for 35-40 minutes over medium high heat.If not steaming, cook in a rice cooker as normal.Â  Fluff up rice when cooked.Â  Garnish with chopped Chinese celery and cut chillies.Dish up to serve.

title: VEGETARIAN BRAISED EGGPLANT [HOONG SIAO EGGPLANT]
text: Malaysian MCO 'Stay At Home'.Â  Everybody keeps saying 'Don't Go Out Unless Necessary'.Â  Yes, it is time to eat simple and healthy if possible.Â  So when I go out for marketing about once a week, I will buy some vegetables that I can keep well for at least a few days.Eggplant or brinjals is one of them, apart from others like cabbage [Chinese or round], bittergourd, long beans, cucumbers and pumpkin etc. I do get some leafy vegetables which I will cook first as they may not keep for too long.I bought these eggplant about 1 week ago and is still good.I prepared this simple dish and it is just awesome.Â  As this dish goes with a soup for a meal, I cooked it with a bit more gravy.The eggplant are cut into big sections and halved.Â  Pan fried to brown on both sides and almost cooked. Just add in the mixed braising sauce and garnish with some cut red chillies for some oomph if you want to spice it up a little.Recipe adapted from a Vegetarian Cookbook from a Buddhist Temple [with modifications]Ingredients[serves 3]2 eggplant or brinjals [400 gm] - cut into 2-3 inch sections and halved [cut just before cooking so do not have to soak in water]some chopped Chinese celery and red chillies [optional]3/4 cup water1 tsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp water [mixed]Braising Sauce Ingredients [combined]1 inch piece ginger - chopped1 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp sugar1/4 tsp saltÂ 1/4 tsp vegetarian mushroom stock granulesdash of pepper1 tsp sesame seed oilÂ Pan fry eggplant with some oil to brown on both sides.Â  Cover for 1 minute over medium high heat to speed up cooking].Remove lid, pour in combined sauce and add in water.Bring to boil, cover to cook for a minute until sauce is reduced a little and eggplant is soft.Â  Stir in cornstarch water to thicken the sauce.Dish up to serve, garnish with some chopped Chinese celery and red chillies.Â  Sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds if preferred.

title: BRAISED SPAGHETTI ORIENTAL STYLE
text: Day 11 of MCO, prepared this braised spaghetti for dinner.Â  What more can I ask?Â  Â To me, it is more than satisfactory meal to feed 3 household members.Â  Â If cannot get meat or chicken from the wet market due to long queues, make it vegetarian.Â Â Â Unbelievable!!! Surprisingly yummy spaghetti fried this way.Â  The original recipe is a vegetarian fried spaghetti but I have added some meat strips, here.Â  Initially, it is not meant to be shared in this blog but as it was so good, I thought it would be good to record it here for my future reference.This fried spaghetti with the addition of some cornstarch water as thickening makes the pasta smooth, moist and coated with the thick gravy.Â  Great, love it especially when you do not require to meat.Â  It can be vegetarian.Recipe adapted fromÂ Irene Yong's You-tubeÂ [Shiitake Braised Spaghetti] with some modificationsIngredients[serves 3-4]350 gm spaghetti [Angel Hair] - cook as per instructions2-3 Ernygii mushrooms - cut thick strips2-3 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips1-2 firm beancurd - fried and cut thick strips [for vegetarian] - if vegetariansome meat strips - optionalsome chopped ginger and garlic100 gm cabbage - shredded [according to preference]1-2 stalks mustard [choi sum] - wash and cut sections100 gm carrots - peeled, sliced and cut strips1 cup water2 tbsp cooking wineSeasoning Ingredients [combined]1-2 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce [Vegetarian mushroom stir fry sauce]2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp vegetarian mushroom stock granules1 tsp salt to taste1/2 tsp pepper to taste1 tsp sesame seed oil1 tbsp cornstarch + 1 cup water for thickeningFry mushrooms in oil until aromatic.Â  Push aside.Â  Add in ginger and garlic.Â  Fry until golden brown.Â  Add in meat [if using]. If not add fried firm beancurd strips.Add in carrots, cabbage and stir fry to mix well.Â  Add in water and seasoning ingredients.Â  Stir to mix well.Bring to boil, add in blanched spaghetti.Â  Lower heat, toss to mix well, taste to fine tune seasoning.Add in mustard leaves, toss well over medium heat until vegetables are cooked.Â  Stir in thickening.Â  Mix well.Dish up to serve. Garnish with chopped coriander if you have some.

title: ZUCCHINI ERYNGII MUSHROOM SALAD
text: Another simple salad which I prepared during MCO.Â  Healthy, light and refreshing salad with simple ingredients.Â  Appetising for the current humid and warm weather.Recipe adapted from a Vegetarian Cookbook given by a Buddhist Association [slightly modified].Â  My appreciation to the association for sharing this cookbook.Ingredients2 Zucchini - shredded1 packet Eryngii [250gm] - blanched in hot water and cut shreds1 carrot - peeled and shreddedsome chopped coriandersome toasted sesame seedsSalad Sauce Ingredients [combined]3 tbsp Apple Cider Vinegar or any of your choice2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp sesame seed oil1 tsp salt to taste1/2 tsp 5 spice powder1/2 tsp mushroom stock granulesÂ Prepare the ingredients as stated.Â  Place in a large bowl, mix to combine.Â  Pour in salad sauce.Mix well, add in toasted sesame seeds.Serve immediately.

title: FRIED TOFU AND BLACK FUNGUS
text: What more can I ask for a dish like this during Malaysia's MCO [movement control order], a government's effort to control the Covid19 pandemic?Â  I am more than happy and satisifed with this dish.Home-cooked with simple ingredients and seasoning but it is definitely healthy, awesome and fuss free.Â Â If you happen to run short of ideas on what to cook for your family during this 'Stay At Home' time, this could be of help.Â  The fried tofu absorbs the sauce which tastes savoury sweet.Â  The tastes can be fine tune according to the quantity you are cooking.Â  It doesn't costs much but the returns is satisfactory.Â Â This is enough to serve 3 and you can increased the sauce ingredients if you like more gravy to spread over plain white rice.Recipe adapted from a Vegetarian Food Cookbook from a Buddhist Association with modificationsIngredients[serves 3]2 pieces tofu - cut each into 6 portionsa handful of black fungus [bok nee] - soaked and rinsedsome chopped red chilliessome chopped coriander leavessome chopped gingerSauce Ingredients1 tbsp vegetarian mushroom sauce1 tbsp good quality light soy sauce [tastes sweet and savoury]dash of pepper1/2 tsp sesame seed oil1/2 bowl watersome cornstarch water for thickeningCut each tofu piece into 6 pieces.  Pat dry with kitchen paper towel.  Pan fry in a non stick pan until golden brown on both sides.Add in chopped ginger, black fungus and red chillies.Â  Stir to combine ingredients well and until ginger is aromatic.Add in the the seasoning ingredients and water.Give it a good stir, then bring to boil until bubbly.Â  Thicken with cornstarch water.Throw in some chopped coriander.Â  Dish up to serve.

title: VEGETARIAN FRIED RICE WITH CAI CHOY
text: This is a vegetarian fried rice with Sichuan Vegetables 'Zai Choy' and other ingredients [carrots, cucumber or zucchini, fresh Ernygii mushrooms].Â When I first came across this recipe [I think from you-tube video], I was quite skeptical that this could be a tasty fried rice. Out of curiosity, I went ahead to try.Â  It surprises me, turns out to be nice with a mix of savoury and sweet taste.Â  Crunchy diced zucchini and Sichuan vegetables, sweetness from the fresh mushrooms and fragrance of the ginger and sesame seed oil could be reason for this tasty fried rice.Ingredients[serves 2]3 bowls cooked white rice [left overnight]100 gm carrots - peeled and cut small cubes100 gm Sichuan vegetable [zai choy] - cut small cubes and rinsed several times [do not soak]100 gm zucchini - cut small cubes2 stems Ernygii mushrooms - cut small cubes1 tbsp chopped ginger2 tbsp cooking oilSeasoning1 tsp mushroom stock granules1/4 tsp pepper1/2 tsp salt2 tsp sesame seed oilsome dark soy sauce [optional]Dry fry fresh mushrooms in a non stick wok until aromatic.Â  Add in cooking oil together with ginger.Â  Stir fry until aromatic.Add in Sichuan vegetables and carrots.Â  Stir fry to mix well.Add in the rice,Â  stir fry over medium heat to mix well all the ingredients.Â  Then add in seasoning [except sesame oil].Â  Taste to fine tune the seasoning.Â Â Lastly add in the zucchini, continue to fry until the rice grains are light.Â  Drizzle in sesame seed oil before dishing up to serve.Garnish with some chopped coriander leaves or Chinese celery [kin chye].Â  Serve with cut chillies for extra 'oomph'.

title: STIR FRY OKRA WITH ERYNGII MUSHROOMS
text: This is a lovely vegetarian dish.Â  Light and healthy, quick stir fry vegetables.Â  If you like the Okra a bit crunchy, do not fry for too longer.Â  Once the Okra turns bright greenish in colour, it is done.Â  The fresh mushrooms are crunchy and sweet.Â  Blend well with the cai por that is salty in taste.Ingredients200 gm ladies' fingers - wash, drain and cut slantwise slices2 stems Eryngii mushrooms - halved lengthwise and sliced1/2red carrot - peeled and cut slicessome chopped red chillies1 tbsp minced preserved vegetables [cai por]some chopped gingerSeasoning1/2 tsp mushroom stock granulesdash of peppersalt to tasteAdd 1/2 tablespoon oil to a non stick wok, add in chopped ginger to fry until aromatic.Â  Add in cai por and mushrooms together [I added cai por and mushrooms at the same time as I do not want the cai por pieces 'jumping' out of the wok].Â Fry till aromatic, then add in carrots and ladies fingers.Â  Â Stir fry to mix well, cover with lid and allow the steam to cook the vegetables.Remove lid when okra turns bright greenish, add in seasoning, chopped chillies and drizzle in some water.Bring to boil.Â  Dish up to serve.

title: CNY 2020 - MELT IN MOUTH SALTED EGG COOKIES
text: All said nice - this Melt in mouth salted egg cookies.Â  A friend, who does not fancy eating cookies, keeps saying these are nice cookies.Â  Reminded me to give him some if I do bake this again.Â  He said these cookies are not too sweet or salty but crispy, light and aromatic.Â  To him is, very addictive cookies.He did not that these are salted egg cookies.Recipe adapted from Iwen Baking Youtube videoIngredients[makes 85-100 pieces depending on size of cutter]4 salted egg yolks - steamed 10-15 minutes, mash while still hot. Set aside120 gm unsalted butter40 gm castor sugar20 gm icing sugar1/4 tsp salt180 gm plain flour20 gm cornflour1/4 tsp baking powderEgg Glaze [mix and strain]1 egg yolk + 1 tbsp watersome toasted white sesame seedsCream butter,Â  sugars and salt until creamy and light.Add in dry ingredients and mashed egg yolks.Light mix ingredients with a spatula into a soft dough.Wrap dough with parchment or greased proof paper in a rectangular block.Â  Chill dough for 30 minutes.Remove, unwrap dough.Â  Place dough in between 2 plastic sheets.Â  Roll flat into 1/2 cm thick piece.Â  Use a cookie cutter [I used 2 cm width pineapple tart mould] to cut out cookies.Place on baking tray lined with parchment paper, leave some space in between cookie dough.Lightly brush egg glaze, sprinkle some sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 15-18 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing.

title: CNY 2020 - JELLY MOULD PINEAPPLE TARTS
text: I made 3 batches of pineapple tarts with this recipe as I wanted to make different design tarts using the plastic jelly mould.Â  Â I believe many homemakers would have this type of jelly moulds in their kitchen.Â  Â Can make use of it to shape the pineapple tarts.Â  Kids love to try them looking at the different designs.Tarts taste better after a few days.Ingredients250 gm unsalted butter50 icing sugar2 egg yolks350 gm superfine flour40 gm cornstarch300 gm Pineapple Jam [store bought] - depends on the size of mould useEgg Glaze [mix and sieve]1 egg yolk + 1 tbsp waterShape pineapple filing into small round balls [5 gm each]. Set aside or chill in fridge until required.Use an electric mixer to cream butter, sugar and add in egg yolk until light and fluffy.Â  Fold in flour mixture, mix into a soft dough or just combined [do not over work dough].Divide dough into small portions enough to wrap filling, seal and roll into round ball.Â  Press into a small tartlet mould.Â  Dislodge from mould and place tart on a lined baking tray.Bake at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, remove from oven.Lightly brush egg glaze over tarts.Â  Do not apply too much egg glaze.Return to oven and bake for another 10 minutes or until golden in colour.Remove from oven, cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: CNY 2020 - COFFEE BUTTER COOKIES
text: One of my favourite cookies for 2020 - Coffee flavour butter cookies.Â  These cookies are nice, so aromatic.Â  Love the coffee aroma.Â  Great to enjoy these cookies with a cup of hot beverage.Â Â Â I did not use emulco coffee but instead mix the below instant coffeeÂ  with 1 sachet of Cafe 21 2-in instant coffee.Recipe adapted fromÂ Kathrine Kwa's Youtube VideoÂ [slightly modified]Ingredients[makes 120 pieces]250 gm salted butter [good quality butter]130 gm icing sugar1 egg yolkMix TogetherÂ  Coffee Paste1 tbsp instant coffee powder with hot water1 tsp emulco coffeeÂ  OR1 tbsp instant coffee powder [any brand that you prefer] with hot water1 sachet 2 in 1 coffee mix [I used Cafe 21 brand]Dry Ingredients [sieve together]270 gm plain flour60 gm cornflour30 gm custard powderCream butter and icing sugar until creamy and light.Â  Add in egg yolk, continue to beat until fluffy.Add in coffee mixture, mix well.Â  Fold in sifted flour in batches until well combined.Â  Chill in fridge until required.Press dough into rosette design on a lined baking tray.Â  Top with a small piece of red cherries.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 20 minutes.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtight containers.Â Spanish Instant Coffee [Hacendado Brand]

title: CNY 2020 - BUTTER COOKIES
text: This butter cookie dough is easy to handle, design stays after baking.Â  It is crispy, not overly sweet and buttery if you use good quality butter.I won't mind using this recipe again when looking at the lovely shapes.Â  Just probably have to improve my skill of pressing out the dough, hehehe!Recipe adapted fromÂ Maxu Cupcake KitchenÂ [slightly modified].Â  The portion here 3 times the original recipeIngredients[makes 140 pieces]250 gm butter [room temperature]150 gm icing sugar2 large eggs3 tsp vanilla essence435 gm plain flour - siftedCream butter with icing sugar until creamy.Add in eggs and vanilla essence.Â  Continue to beat until creamy and light.Fold in sifted flour in batches.Â  Mix well until well combined.Â  If not baking right away, chill in fridge.Put dough in small portion into piping bag with rosette design.Â  Press onto baking tray lined with parchment paper.Â  Top with a small bit of red cherries.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes depending on your own or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in air-tight containers.

title: CNY 2020 - GREEN PEAS COOKIES
text: When making these cookies, I told myself probably I won't share this post because it is too tedious with the rolling of the dough.Â  The dough is crumbly and very time consuming. Later, I changed my mind when I ate it after several days andÂ  also my friend's tip.Â  The cookies tasted good, has a nice aroma of the green peas, quite addictive if you know how to enjoy it.Â  Don't pop it into your mouth in one go, may choke, give it a bite or two.Â  You will enjoy it.Â  Â Â My friend gave me the idea to roll the dough in between plastic sheets, use a 2 cm wide cookie cutter to cut, then a funnel stem to create the small circle in the centre.Â  I saw and tried hers, it is nice.Store bought Ground Green Peas PowderRecipe adapted fromÂ MyKitchen 101Â [slightly modified]Ingredients[makes 120 pieces]420 gm green pea powder300 gm plain flour130 gm icing sugar1/4 tsp salt210 gm vegetable oil [or more if you find the dough too crumbly]Egg Glaze [mix and sieve]1 egg yolk + 1 tbsp waterSift plain flour, icing sugar and salt in a large bowl.Sift [1] again when adding to green pea powder.Â  Mix well.Gradually add in vegetable oil, mix until well combined.Take out 1/2 tablespoon dough press until firm, then shape gently into a ball.Â  Arrange dough balls slightly apart on a lined baking tray.Â Lightly press the dough ball with a funnel stem to create the small circles.Brush top lightly with egg glaze once [over brushing will result in top looking too dark].Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 20 minutes.Remove from oven, set aside to cool completely before storing in air-tight containers.Â  Cookies taste better after several days.Took the picture during CNY at my mother in-law's house in a hurry,Â doesn't look good but tastes good

title: CNY 2020 - KUIH BANGKIT
text: This is a not 'melt-in' mouth kuih bangkit recipe but it is a recipe which is worth keeping.Â  This recipe uses whole eggs which is quite different from other recipes which uses all egg yolks.These kuih bangkit are light, crispy and not as fragile my earlier recipe onÂ Kuih Bangkit.Â  They are aromatic and tasty, do not break apart easily while handling.Â  IÂ  believe you may not find this recipe elsewhere as it is shared to me by a lady who used to bake kuih bangkit for sale and giving up this trade for good due to age.Ingredients[makes 3-4 medium size bottles]500 gm tapioca flour500 gm Arrowroot flour [Ah Lulu flour]200 gm cornflour5-6 screwpine [pandan] leaves - washed and wipe dry, cut into half300 gm icing sugar5 large eggs [AA size] - whole eggs300 ml thick coconut milk1 tbsp butter -Â  room temperatureStep 1 - PhotosPlace flour and pandan leaves in a wok.Â  In low heat, fry the until all the flour is light and the pandan leaves turned crispy [stir lightly as the flour will be very light].Â Â  Cool, discard the leaves and scoop the flour into a big sieve.Â  Lightly sift the flour into a big deep bowl.Â Â  Transfer sifted flour in a plastic bag until required.Â Â  The flour must be cooled thoroughly.Â  This step can be done days ahead.Cream eggs, then add in icing sugar until light and creamy.Â  Make sure the sugar is totally dissolved.Gradually add in the coconut milk to mix.Â  Slowly add in the flour and butter and then creamed the mixture well.Â  [You may needÂ  to reserve some extra coconut milk for use when the dough is too dry].Knead until the dough does not stick to the hand.Â Â Cover the dough with a dampÂ cloth, rest for at least 30 minutes.Â Â  You can use this time to line your baking tray with parchment paper, extra fried flour for dusting and a little pink colouring for decoration.Dust the wooden moulds with some tapioca flour [fry more for dusting], pinch off some dough and press it into the moulds one by one, thenÂ cut offÂ any excess using a thin sharp knife.Â Â Knock outÂ and arrange the cookies onto the Â baking tray.Â  This cookie does not expand but will be very fragile after baking.Bake in a preheated oven @ 180 degrees C for about 12-15 minutes or until it's slight brown at the base.Cool completely on a wire rack before storing them in a cookie jar.Notes: Kuih Bangkit tastes good after resting and keeps well in airtight containers for months.

title: CNY 2020 - CHOC CHIPS OATMEAL COOKIES
text: December 2019 and January 2020 was indeed a very busy period for me with much to do to the extent of delaying posting of the recipes which I tried till now.Â  With the long list of things to handle, I still have to bake some cookies for my elders' families forÂ Chinese New Year. So from now, with the last of schedule done, I will have to catch up with the recipe postings.Â Â These cookies are moist, not too sweet but crunchy and it looks a little dark as I used Jaggery sugar instead of brown sugar [original recipe].Â  Anyway, I happened to like these cookies and sharing it here for future reference.Ingredients[makes 160 cookies]350 gm butter [room temperature]180 gm Jaggery sugar60 gm castor sugar1 tsp salt3 eggs3 tsp vanilla essence560 gm plain flour100 gm regular oats2 tsp baking soda1/2 tsp cinnamon powder200 gm chocolate chipsCream butter with sugars, salt until light and creamy.Â  Add in eggs one at a time and vanilla essence. until well blended.Â  Scrap down.Combine all the dry ingredients in a large bowl.Â  Fold into cream mixture.Â  Mixed well and chill cookie dough in fridge for 30 minutes or until required.Use a spoon to scoop the dough into small portions.Â  Lightly roll into balls.Â  Place dough on a baking tray lined with parchment paper.Â  Leave some space in between as cookies will spread out a little.Bake in a preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 20 minutes.Remove to cool on tray before storing in airtight container.

title: STIR FRY FRIED BEANCURD WITH CUCUMBER
text: Supposed to be a meatless, vegetarian dish but since I have some prawns lying in the fridge, I just add them in.Â  If cooking vegetarian meal, leave the prawns out.A rather tasty, spicy delicious dish, simple and healthy.Â  Great to serve with rice.Ingredients2 pieces firm beancurd [taukwa] - cut cubes1 medium size cucumber - seeded and cut cubes50 gm prawns - shelled [optional]1 heaped tablespoon fried vegetarian sambalsome salt to tasteFry prawns with some oil until firm.Â  Add in the fried taukwa, cucumber and sambal.Â  Add more if you like it more spicy.Stir fry to mix well.Â  Drizzle in some water so that the flavours are well absorbed.Â  Bring to boil.Dish up to serve immediately.

title: STIR FRY CELERY WITH MUSHROOMS
text: Just back from overseas trip, missed my meatless dishes.Â  Out of over 30 main meals during the trip, there was only one meatless meal which I really enjoyed.Â  It was a vegetarian food buffet treat, a wide range of dishes and desserts.Â  The foodÂ  was delicious.Â  We were all smiles and satisfied for that.Â  Sounds crazy, most people would go for the fresh seafood, yummy duck, pork and chicken dishes given a choice.Â Back to this stir fry celery with king oyster mushrooms.Â  It is a quick stir fry vegetable dish.Â  The celery is crunchy and the mushrooms are sweet.Â  I loved the celery crunchy and would not over fried them.Ingredients3 stalks of celery - cut slantwise1 red chilli - sliced1/2 red carrot - peeled and sliced100 gm king oyster mushrooms - sliced2-3 dried mushrooms - soaked and slicedSeasoning1/2 tsp mushroom stock granules1/2 tsp saltdash of pepper1/2 tsp sesame seed oilsome cornstarch water for thickeningPan fry sliced mushrooms and ginger without oil until aromatic.Â  Add in some oil.Â  Continue to fry for a few seconds.Add in carrots, stir fry for several minutes.Â  Add some water and seasoning.Â  Bring to a rolling boil, then add in celery and red chillies.Â  Stir fry to mix well.Â Â Thicken with some cornstarch water.Â  Drizzle in sesame seed oil.Dish up to serve immediately.

title: BRAISED TOFU PUFFS WITH DONG QUAI
text: Simple, homey dish that is nutritious and healthy for the family.Â  This dish is easy to prepare but tastes good with just a good quality soy sauce seasoning.Â  Extra flavours with the used of Dong Quai and wolfberries.The flavourful sauce definitely goes well with steaming hot rice.Ingredients[serves 2]1-2 tbsp minced meat100 gm tofu puffs - cut into halvesa few florets of soaked black fungus2 slices Dong Quai1 tbsp wolfberries [kei chee]a handful of garlic - peeled and keep whole1-2 slices gingerSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp cooking wine1 tsp sesame seed oilSaute ginger and garlic with some oil until fragrant.Add in minced meat, fry until meat turns white.Add in Dong Quai, black fungus and tofu puffs.Â  Give it a good stir to mix well.Add in seasoning, stir to mix before adding some water.Â  Bring to boil until tofu puffs are soft and gravy reduced to slightly thick.Add in wolfberries, drizzle in sesame seed oil. Mix well.Dish up to serve.

title: STEAMED PAUS-BAMBOO SHOOTS MUI CHOY FILLINGS
text: Please refer to my post on 'Fresh Bamboo Shoots Pork Rib Soup'Â about my fresh bamboo shoot story.  These paus with bamboo shoots and mui choy filling is Awesome!!!.  The pau skin is light and fluffy.  The slightly sweet skin blends well with the savoury taste and flavour of the filling.  The bamboo shoots are crunchy though blanched, fried and steamed.Â You would not stop with just ONE but I had no choice because I need to share some with my mom, sister and other family members.Â  No worries, I will try to get some fresh bamboo shoots from my cousin in Taiping during my next visit end of November.Â Bamboo Shoots Mui Choy Pau FillingRecipe adapted from Coco Kong's Cookbook [modified]Ingredients For Bamboo Shoots Mui Choy Fillings180 gm minced meat160 gm fresh bamboo shoots - blanched, drained and chopped100 gm mui choy - rinsed well, soaked for 5 minutes, drained and chopped1 tsp chopped ginger and shallots150 ml watersome toasted sesame seeds [optional]Seasoning1 tbsp each sugar, cooking wine and light soy sauce1 tsp mushroom stock granules1/2 tsp white powder1 tbsp cornflour + 50 ml waterHeat wok with 1/2 tablespoon oil, saute ginger andÂ  shallots, add minced meat. Stir fry to mix well or until meat turned white.Â Â Add seasoning andÂ bamboo shoots. Stir fry for awhile.Add inÂ  mui choy, stir to mix well, then add 100 ml water.Â  Let it boils and cook for 5-10 minutesÂ  Stir fry to mix well, fry until water is almost dry.Stir in cornstarch water to thicken. Add in chopped spring onions and sesame seeds. Dish up and leave to cool before using.Â  Can prepare and refrigerate until required.Ingredients for Pau Skin[makes 16 medium size paus]400 gm pau flour2 tsp yeast60 gm icing sugar240-250 ml water [this depends on the 'age' of flour]1/4 tsp vinegar1 tsp vegetable shorteningCombined flour, sugar, yeast in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water to form a rough dough.Â  Knead until well mixed, then add in shortening.Â  Continue to knead untilÂ  smooth and pliable.Â Â Shape into a ball, dust with some flour to prevent sticking to hand.Â  Place in mixing bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough, then roll into round.Â  Divide into 16 equal portions, each to roll into balls.Â  Flatten each one in circle. Flatten the edges, place filling [about 1 heaped tablespoon] in the centre, gather the edges together to seal to make a round pau or pleat the edges into a pau shape.Place on parchment paper and steaming tray.Â  Proof for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Finish doing the rest.Â  Place steaming tray over rapidly boiling.Â  Cover to steam for 12 minutes.Â  Off heat and remove paus after 2-3 minutes.Cool on wire rack or serve immediately.Â  ENJOY!!

title: HOONG SEOW TOFU
text: One additional simple and healthy dish for the family.Â  Main ingredient is tofu and good quality light soy sauce.TofuÂ is a good plant source of protein, iron and calcium especially for vegan or many people who are cutting down on intake of meat.Â  It contains numerous or all nine essential amino acids. Other minerals are manganese, selenium and phosphorous andÂ a good source of magnesium, copper, zinc and vitamin B1.TofuÂ is considered a superfood andÂ a healthier substitute to eating fish.Â Best of all, the price is affordable for all.Ingredients2 blocks tofu - cut 1/2 inch thick slices1 stalk spring onions - cut sections [keep some for garnishing]2 dried mushrooms - soaked and sliced [optional]several slices of ginger1 red chilli - slicedSeasoning3 tbsp light soy sauce1/4 tsp mushroom stock granules1 tbsp cooking winePan fry tofu slices in a non stick pan until brown on both sides.Â  Push aside, saute ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in spring onions, mushrooms and red chillies.Â  Continue to fry until aromatic.Mix will fried tofu.Â  Pour in seasoning.Bring to bubbly boil, add in enough water to cover the tofu pieces.Â  Braise until water is slightly reduced or thick.Add in remaining spring onions.Â  Stir to mix, dish up to serve.

title: STIR FRY TOFU PUFFS AND BEANCURD STICKS
text: Simple healthy dish with soya ingredients like tofu puffs and dried beancurd sticks.Â  Much easier if you can get the wet fuchok [no soaking is needed].Â Preparation and cooking is easy, too.Ingredients50 gm dried beancurd stick [fuchuk] - soak in water to soften, drained and set aside10 tofu puffs - keep whole, make a small slit on one side - rinsed until running tap watersome shredded carrots and chopped spring onion1 tbsp soya kelp [Okara]some chopped spring onionsa few slices of gingerSeasoning1/2 tsp mushroom stock granules1 tsp light soy saucesalt and pepper to taste1 tsp sesame seed oilÂ Saute ginger slice with some oil until aromatic, add in soya kelp, fry until slight golden.Â  Add in tofu puffs, continue to fry for a while, then add in fuchuk and carrots.Stir fry ingredients lightly to mix well, add in some water and seasoning.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Thicken with some cornstarch water, add in sesame seed oil.Â Â Dish up to serve.Â  Garnish with chopped spring onions.

title: VEGETARIAN PUMPKIN CURRY
text: Awesome, delicious pumpkin curry that is so easy to prepare if ready blended curry mix.I bought ready mixed fresh curry paste ingredients at the wet market.Â  Very cheap, only RM 1.20 enough to cook about 1 Kg pumpkin.Â  In Penang, this kind of curry paste is available.Â  Just need to ask for curry paste to cook mutton.Ingredients1 kg pumpkin - skinned and cut bite size piecesReady mixed curry paste1-2 sprigs of curry leaves1 yellow onion - peeled and sliced thinly100 ml coconut milk3 tbsp cooking oilSeasoningsalt and sugar to tasteAdd oil to a non-stick pan, stir fry onions and curry leaves until aromatic.Â  Add in curry paste, continue to fry until oil separates and fragrant.Add in the pumpkin, continue to fry for 1-2 minutes.Â  Add in some water, enough to cover the pumpkin pieces.Â  Bring to boil and simmer until pumpkin is tender but not soft.Add in coconut milk and seasoning to taste.Dish up to serve with steaming hot rice.

title: HEALTHY VEGETARIAN STOCK
text: A very healthy vegetarian stock that is easy to prepare and has many uses.Â  Can be used as stock or soup for noodles and sauce for fried food such as firm beancurd or tofu or blanched vegetables like broccoli and cauliflower.The stock can be seasoned with curry powder, white or black pepper, savoury or sweet sour according to own preference.Ingredients3 medium size potatoes [with skin] - washed and sliced 1/2 cm thick1 large yellow onions - peeled and cut chunky pieces2-3 tomatoes - cut chunky piecessome coarsely chopped garlic2 pieces bay leaves1 liter waterSeasoningsalt and pepper to tastePan fry the sliced potatoes until slight brown and aromatic.Â  Add in onions, garlic and tomatoes.Continue to fry until all ingredients are aromatic.Â  Pour in water.Â  Bring to boil and simmer until all ingredients are tender and soft.Â  Add seasoning to taste.Off heat, blend until creamy and smooth with a hand blender or cool before blending.Store in individual containers, freeze them if not using immediately.

title: FRIED TOFU WITH OKRA
text: Simple ingredients but do not underestimate the taste and goodness of this dish.Â Â A meatless dish that is tastes awesome, not too overwhelming in taste.Â  Both the fried tofu and okra are smooth, soft and tender, suitable for all ages.Okra aka Lady's Fingers is rich in nutrients, contains antioxidants.Â  May lower heart disease risk, anticancer properties, lower blood sugar and helps to relieve constipation problems.Recipe adapted fromÂ Irene's You-tube videoÂ with modificationsIngredients2 pieces soft tofu - cut thick slices and pan-fried250 gm Okra [lady's fingers] - washed and sliced1 red chilli - slicedsome chopped gingerSeasoning1 heaped tbsp fermented soy bean paste [taucheong]1 tsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp mushroom stock granulesdash of pepperPan fry tofu pieces until golden brown.Â  Dish up.Using the same pan, add in some oil, saute chopped ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in taucheong, continue to fry for awhile.Â  Mix in fried tofu pieces.Â  Â Add in 150 ml water.Bring to boil, add in sliced Okra and red chilli,Â  Lightly stir fry to mix the ingredients.Â  Cover to cook the Okra until bright green in colour and tender.Add in seasoning.Â  Mix well.Â Dish up to serve.

title: GARFIELD [SALTED MUNGBEAN] FIGURINE MOONCAKES [å…¬ä»”é¥¼]
text: Came across this recipe on You-tube.Â  Tried it and my opinionÂ  is, this recipe is a keeper.The dough is soft and easy to handle.Â  The mooncakes taste perfect with the salted mungbean paste filling.Â  You can smell the nice aroma of the mooncakes while airing them.I have made a double portion of this recipe and managed to get about 50 pieces figurine mooncakes [Garfield design].Just Baked Mooncakes Before AiringThese mooncakes are without egg glaze after airingThese figurine mooncakes are soft, aromatic and the sweetness is acceptable.Â  Nice mooncakes.Recipe adapted from Kathrine Kwa You-tube Figurine Mooncake [çŒªä»”é¥¼#å…¬ä»”é¥¼ Piggy Mooncakes] - slightly modifiedIngredients[makes 25 Garfield Figurine Mooncakes]240 gm golden syrup75 ml peanut oil1/2 tbsp alkaline water300 gm plain flour â€“ siftedAny doll mooncake molds of your choiceMooncake Filling200 gm Salted Mungbean PasteCombine golden syrup, peanut oil and alkaline water in a mixing bowl. Mix until the ingredients blends well. Set aside for 3 hours [I left mine overnight].Add sifted flour to syrup mixture lightly until well combined [do not knead the dough]. Leave for several hours [I left mine overnight].Divide dough into small portions according to the size of the mold used. Roll into round shape and dust lightly with flour [if necessary].Â  Flatten, place a teaspoon paste in centre.Â  Roll in round and press it into mooncake mold. Tap to dislodge dough from the mold. Arrange on baking tray lined with parchment paper.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C [middle shelf] for 15-20 minutes [this is without glazing with beaten egg].Â  Â Remove to cool on wire rack for 15 minutes.Return to oven and bake at 180 degrees C for 15 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack then store in container to air them for 1-2 days. The mooncakes will be soft after airing.

title: STEAMED PAUS - LOH HAN VEGETABLES
text: Awesome steamed paus with Loh Han Vegetable Filling.Â  This is a vegetarian pau recipe.The pau skin is awesome, pliable dough and easy to handle and pleat when well kneaded.Â  The skin is soft, smooth and fluffy light.Â  The sweetness of it blends well with the savoury taste of the mixed vegetable filling.For this paus, I have triedÂ  to steam them from cold water after shaping with leaving to rest using my multi-purpose cooker/steamer.Â  The result is so satisfactory.Â  For this portion, I was able to steam all of it in one go.Â Ingredients for Pau Skin[makes 8 medium size paus]200 gm pau flour1 tsp yeast30 gm icing sugar120-130 ml water [this depends on the 'age' of flour]1 tsp vegetable shorteninga drop of green pandan paste or colouringCombined flour, sugar, yeast and colouring in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water to form a rough dough.Â  Knead until well mixed, then add in shortening.Â  Continue to knead untilÂ  smooth and pliable.Â Â Shape into a ball, dust with some flour to prevent sticking to hand.Â  Place in mixing bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough, then roll into round.Â  Divide into 8 equal portions, each to roll into balls.Â  Flatten each one in circle. Flatten the edges, place filling in the centre, gather the edges together or pleat the edges to seal into a pau shape.Place on parchment paper and steaming tray.Finish doing the rest.Â  Place steaming tray over water in the multi-purpose cooker pot.Â  Cover, turn to high heat.Â  When water boils, continue to steam for 20 minutes.Â  Off heat and remove paus after 2-3 minutes.Cool on wire rack or serve immediately.Â  ENJOY!!Recipe adapted from Coco Kong's CookbookIngredients For Vegetable Fillings150 gm Napa Cabbage or Chinese Cabbage - washed and finely shredded3 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut into thin strips40 gm red carrot - peeled and shredded1 small piece woodear fungus - soaked and finely shredded2 piece fried beancurd skin or foo pei [soaked and shredded]30-40 gm glass noodles - soaked and cut into sections]Seasoning2 tsp each of salt, mushroom seasoning and sugar [can reduced to 1 tsp, taste to adjust seasoning]1/2 tsp white or black pepper powder2 tsp cornflour with 100 ml waterHeat wok with 1/2 tablespoon oil, add in the ingredients and seasoning.Â  Stir fry to mix well or until limp.Â  Stir in cornstarch water to thicken.Â  Dish up and leave to cool before using.Â  Can prepare and refrigerate until required.

title: 2019 - FIGURINE SESAME MOONCAKES
text: This figurine mooncake recipe uses more oil with the same portion of flour compared to others.Â  The syrup used is slightly less.The dough is a little greasy but easy to handle and mould as it is soft and less gluten if you do not over-mix.Â  These mooncakes are without egg glaze suitable for vegetarians.Â  I have added some toasted sesame seeds to the dough.I have increased the portion to 1.5 [in bracket] as I wanted to finish off my packet of low protein flour.Ingredients[makes 24 & 36 small size mooncake mould]180 ml golden syrup [270 ml]90 ml peanut oil [130 ml]1 tsp alkaline water [1 1/2 tsp]2 tbsp toasted sesame seeds300 gm plain flour [450 gm]Combine golden syrup, peanut oil and alkaline water in a mixing bowl.Â  Stir with a wooden spatula until well blended.Â  Mix in the sesame seeds.Sift flour and fold in 2/3 of it into syrup mixture using the cutting method lightly.Â  Add in the remaining and fold until no sign of white flour.Â  Cover and leave to rest for an hour or more.Divide into small portion sufficient to fill the size of the mould used.Roll each portion into rounds and press onto mould.Â  Knock out dough and place on baking tray lined with parchment paper.Bake in a preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 12 minutes.Â  Remove to cool for 10 minutes.Â  Returned cooled mooncakes to oven and bake for another 12 minutes or until nicely golden brown.Remove to cool and leave mooncakes to air for several days before serving.Â  Store in mooncake containers.

title: 2019 FIGURINE MOONCAKES [ANGKU DESIGN]
