text: For several years, I have been making figurine mooncakes rather than the 'big' ones or snowskin mooncakes because my family members prefer Koong Cai Paeng [plain figurine mooncakes].Â  Their preference makes it easier for me, hehehe!This year, I looked up some you-tube videos [not many] and I noticed that the recipes are about the same.Â  It is the skill is mixing the dough, baking them that makes the mooncakes turn out difference.Â  Before serving, the most important step is the resting of themÂ  for several days after baking.Â  They are extra fragrant and soft.This recipe is adapted from 3C KitchenÂ [here]Â with some modificationsIngredients[makes 24-medium size Angku mould]200 ml golden syrup70 ml peanut oil1 tsp alkaline water1/2 tsp baking soda - gives a nice darker colour360 gm low protein flourCombine golden syrup, peanut oil, alkaline water and baking soda in a mixing bowl.Â  Stir with a wooden spatula until well blended.Sift flour and fold in 2/3 of it into syrup mixture using the cutting method lightly.Â  Add in the remaining and fold until no sign of white flour.Â  Cover and leave to rest for an hour or more.Divide into small portion sufficient to fill the size of the mould used.Roll each portion into rounds and press onto mould.Â  Knock out dough and place on baking tray lined with parchment paper.Bake in a preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 10 minutes.Â  Remove to cool for 10 minutes.Â  Returned cooled mooncakes to oven and bake for another 5 minutes or until nicely golden brown.Remove to cool and leave mooncakes to air for several days before serving.Â  Store in mooncake containers.

title: STIR FRY EGGPLANT WITH GLASS NOODLES
text: Surprisingly good dish that can be eaten with rice or just as a fried noodle dish.Â  If serving as noodles, just add more glass noodles and water.The addition of curry leaves, adds extra fragrance and aroma to this dish.Â  The eggplant is soft and sweet, goes well with the savoury taste of the noodles.Â  The addition of crispy fried soya kelp provides a different texture to this dish.Â  Awesome.Ingredient[serves 2]1 medium eggplant [brinjal] - sliced wedges50 gm carrots - cut strips or shredded1 red chilli - sliced1-2 sprigs curry leaves1/2 tbsp chopped ginger3 tbsp fried crispy soya kelp50 gm glass noodles - soak in water for 5 minutes, drained150 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp each fermented soya bean [taucheong], oyster sauce and light soya sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp salt to tasteÂ dash of pepper and mushroom stock granulesSoak slicedÂ  eggplant in water until required.Heat 1 tbsp oil in wok, saute ginger and curry leaves until aromatic.Â Â Add in eggplant and carrots.Â  Stir fry to mix well, then add in seasoning and water.Â  Stir fry and bring to boil.Â Â Add in glass noodles and red chillies.Â  Stir fry until water is almost dry but noodles are moist.Â  Add in soya kelp.Â  Mix well.Dish up to serve.Â  Garnish with remaining soya kelp.Serve with rice or enjoy as a noodle dish.

title: STIR FRY TOFU WITH MUSHROOMS
text: This savoury tofu dish recipe is from Irene YongÂ [you-tube]Â Â which is easy to prepare yet delicious and healthy.Â  Thanks to Irene for sharing her recipes onÂ  vegetarian dishes.Meatless dish, though but it is rich in protein from the tofu and mushrooms as it contain substantial nutrients, enzymes, vitamins.Â  Mushrooms are excellent sources of antioxidants and selenium.A delicious vegetarian dish, great with rice or porridge.Â  The vegetables [carrots and capsicum] are sweet while the tofu absorbs the flavours of the seasoning.Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]2 pieces tofu - cut 1/2 inch thick slices - fried golden brown3-4 dried mushrooms - soaked and clut thick strips1 green capsicum - seeded and cut thick strips1 red chilli - seeded and cut thick strips50 gm red carrot - peeled and slicedsome chopped gingerSeasoning1 tbsp each oyster sauce, light soy sauce and cooking winedash of pepper, mushroom stock granulesÂ and salt to taste100 ml water1 tsp cornflour + 1 tbsp water for thickeningUsing the same wok from frying the tofu, remove excess oil.Â  Saute ginger and mushrooms until aromatic.Â  Add in carrots.Â  Stir to mix well.Add in fried tofu, seasoning and water.Â  Bring to boil for a few minutes.Add in chillies and capsicum.Â  Stir to mix well.Thicken with cornstarch water.Â  Drizzle in some sesame seed oil.Dish up to serve.

title: STIR FRY LOUFFA WITH EU CHAR KOAY
text: A very simple vegetarian dish with only 2 main ingredients, yet it is tasty and delicious.Â  The Chinese crueller pieces are crispy with its savoury taste which blends well with sweet taste of the fried louffa [petola].Â  An awesome combination and a quick cook dish.Â  Certain parts of the cruellers are still crispy when you enjoy this dish right away.Ingredients1 medium size louffa - green hard skin scraped - cut into wedges1 Chinese crueller [Eu Char Koay] - cut into small sections1 red chilli - seeded and cut into piecessome chopped gingersome water1/2 tsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp water [for thickening]Seasoning1/4 tsp mushroom stock granulesdash of pepperÂ salt to tastePan fry cruellers in a non stick pan [without oil] over low medium heat until crispy.Â  Dish up, set aside.Using the same pan, add in 1 tsp oil to saute ginger until fragrant.Â  Add in the louffa and red chillies.Â  Fry over high heat until louffa is soft, add in some water and seasoning to taste.Add in fried cruellers, stir to mix well and thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up to serve.

title: VEGETARIAN BRAISED SOYA PUFFS WITH SESAME OIL
text: Fragrant braised soya puffs with mushrooms and black fungus in soy sauce is as yummy though meatless.Â  All the ingredients are tasty and flavourful. With the use of sesame seed oil to cook is a great choice as it gives this dish the extra fragrance and aroma.IngredientsÂ [serves 2-3]100 gm fried tofu puffs - halved3 piece fried hollow soya puffs - halved3 dried mushrooms - soaked and halveda handful of soaked black fungus1 tbsp chopped ginger1 tbsp sesame seed oilSeasoning1 tbsp each of vegetarian oyster sauce and light soy sauce1/2 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp mushrooms granules1/4 tsp salt to tastedash of pepperÂ Heat wok, add in sesame oil.Â  Saute ginger and mushrooms until fragrant before adding the remaining ingredients.Â  Stir to mix well.Add in seasoning, stir for a minute before adding some water to braise.Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Bring to boil until water is reduced but still moist.Dish up to serve.

title: AWESOME VEGETARIAN FRIED RICE VERMICELLI
text: This vegetarian fried noodles is easy to prepare yet awesome.Â  With the addition of crushed vegetarian 'salted fish' [kiam hoo] makes it even more appetising.Â  You would not miss meat but will love this meatless noodles.The sweetness comes from the cabbages and carrot.Â  Great to serve it with cut small red chillies and lime juice, it is really yummy.Â The crispy golden flakes on top the noodles are vegetarian salted fish [kiam hoo] which is made from foo peh [beancurd sheets].Â  Ready made ones are available in most vegetarian food ingredients stores.Fried Vegetarian Salted FishIngredients[serves 2-3]150 gm rice vermicelli [beehoon]6 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips1/2 bowl of soaked black fungus [bok nee] - cut strips100 gm red carrot - peeled and shredded150 gm cabbage - cut strips1 stalk Chinese celery - cut small sections1 tbsp chopped gingersome fried vegetarian salted fish [kiam hoo] - crushed2 tbsp cooking oilcut small red chillies mix with some lime juiceSeasoning1 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1 tsp salt1 tsp mushroom stock granules1/2 tsp pepper1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tbsp darkÂ  soy sauce1 tsp sesame seed oilÂ Bring water to boil in a wok, blanched beehoon for several minutes until soft [about 1 minute].Â  Â Drain in a colander.Â  Set aside.Using a clean wok, fry mushrooms and ginger in oil until aromatic.Â  Add in cabbage, carrots and black fungus.Â  Stir fry to mix, add in seasoning [except light and dark soy sauce and sesame oil].Â  Stir to mix well, add in some water.Place blanched beehoon in wok, add in remaining seasoning.Â  Toss ingredients well and fry until water is almost dry.Lastly, add in celery.Â  Mix and dish up on serving platter.Sprinkle crushed vegetarian kiam hoo over noodles.Â  Serve with cut chillies.

title: STIR FRY ERNGYII MUSHROOMS WITH CAPSICUM
text: This is a tasty, delicious meatless stir fry dish.Â  Light dish and easy to prepare that goes well, great with rice.Â The main ingredients of this dish are:Erngyii Mushrroms [Sin Pao Ku] - high in antioxidants that helps protect cell damage and fiber helps boost satiety, improve insulin function and curb appetiteSea Kelp [Hai Tai] - natural source of vitamins A, B1 & B2, C, D and E as well as minerals like zinc, magnesium, iron, potassium, copper and ironCapsicum - a good soure of dietary fiber and rich in Vitamins A, B6, C, E and folateÂ With this dish, you probably wouldn't miss meat when you are thinking of going on meatless diet.Ingredients250 gm Erngyii mushrooms - tear into strips1 green capsicum - seeded and cut strips1 red chill - seeded and cut strips1 piece firm beancurd - cut thick strips and fried to golden brown1 small piece of sea kelp [hai tai] - rinsed and cut thin stripsÂ some chopped gingerSeasoning1 tbsp each oyster sauce and light soy sauce1/4 tsp salt to tastedash of pepper1 tsp sesame oilsome cornstarch water for thickeningÂ Pan fry firm beancurd strips until golden brown.Â  Push aside. Add in ginger and mushrooms, stir fry until ingredients are fragrant.Â  Mix well with fried beancurd.Add in sea kelp and red chilli, together with seasoning.Stir fry to mix well, add in some water.Â  Bring to boil, then add in capsicum.Â  Mix well and thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up to serve.

title: 5 SPICE EMBRYO RICE CHANG [RICE DUMPLINGS]
text: When comes the timeÂ  for making rice dumplings [chang] for Duan Wu Jie, it is common to hear people advising not to eat too much of the rice dumplings made with glutinous rice.Â  There are some of my friends who love eating changs but due to health reasons, they opted to make rice dumplings using Brown Rice, oatmeal etc.So far, I have not made such rich dumplings because my family members and relatives still prefers the traditional Kiam Bak Chang made of glutinous rice.Â  Even my mom, a diabetic did not refrain herself for it.Recently, I have started eating Embryo Rice and I was curious to try making a healthier version of Kiam Bak Chang with this rice.Â  Below is my attempt.Â  Instead of using Brown Rice [needs soaking] and oatmeal, here I used Embryo Rice [no need soaking] and glutinous rice.Â  The dumpling looks like this.Â  The rice is not crumbly and tastes awesome without the 'sinful' feel when you dig in.Ingredients - Dumpling Filling20 pieces dried mushrooms - rinsed, soaked and drained - keep whole20 dried chestnuts - soak with 1/2 tsp alkaline water with some water for 15 minutes. Â Blanch with boiling water for 15 minutes then boil for 15 minutes. Â Drain and set aside5 salted egg yolks - steamed with some sesame oil - quartered2 tbsp each of oil, chopped garlic and sliced shallots [I used 8 shallots and 4 pips garlic]400 gm fatty pork belly - cut into 20 big pieces5 tbsp waterSeasoning for Meat2 tsp each of Chinese 5 spice powder, sugar, oyster sauce and dark soy sauce1 tsp pepper1 1/2 tsp saltHeat oil and fry chopped garlic and shallots until aromatic and brown.Â  Dish up 1/2 of it, set aside for frying rice.Add in pork belly, stir fry until meat pieces are firm.Â  Add in seasoning and continue to fry until aromatic, then add dried mushrooms and chestnuts.Â  Add in water, fry for 5 minutes or until all the ingredients are well coated with seasoning and water almost dry.Â  Cool before dishing up, separating the main ingredients [pork belly, mushrooms and chestnuts in a container.Â  Â Set aside for later use.Â  This filling can be prepared a day earlier.Ingredients - Rice[makes about 20 dumplings]500 gm glutinous rice - soaked for 4 hours or overnight and drained500 gm Embryo rice - washed and drained [no need to soak]2 tbsp each of oil2 tsp each 5 spice powder and salt1 tbsp dark soy sauce and 1 tbspÂ light soy sauce1 tsp pepper50 gm dried prawns - rinsed and drained100 gm prepared peanuts [can prepare days ahead and freezed]Wash peanuts and soak it in salty water for several hours.Â  Drained and transfer to a freezer bag.Â  Freeze in refrigerator until required.Heat up oil, saute dried prawns for a few seconds, add in the fried shallots set aside earlier from frying the fillings above.Add in the glutinous rice, stir fry for several minutes before adding the Embryo rice, peanuts and seasoning.Â  [off heat while adding ingredients].Â  Stir fry to mix well the seasoning and rice.Â Turn on the fire and fry for 5 minutes or until the rice is well mixed with the seasoning and looks clear with a nice soy sauce colour.Dish up and leave aside.Wrapping Dumplingsabout 40 pieces of Â bamboo leaves - soaked in hot water until soft, then wash by wiping each pieces, then wipe dry, set asidehemp strings enough to tie 20 dumplingsUsing Â 2 pieces of bamboo leaves to fold into a cone. Scoop some rice into the cone [I used about 1 tablespoon], place 1 piece pork belly, chestnuts, salted egg yolk and mushroom. Â Cover with about 1 - 1 1/2 tbsp rice [depending on the size of chang you wish to make].Â Press the rice firm, cover it with the extended ends of bamboo leaves and form into a pyramid [chang] shape. Â Tie and secure it with the hemp string.Finish doing the same for the rest of ingredients. Â Trim the edges of the bamboo leaves and excess strings.Â Place the changs in a big pot. Â Pour water Â enough to cover them. Â Bring to boil and cook for about 3 1/2 hours or until the rice dumplings are cooked. Â Add more boiling water should the to water is reduced below the changs.Remove from water and hang dumplings to dry before storing them or serve warm.Notes: Some benefits of Embryo Rice - contains selenium said to prevent cataract, helps to remove body toxin and absorption of nutrients

title: SPINACH OMELETTE
text: Never underestimate the outcome of a simple recipe. A simple omelette recipe could turned out to be an awesome dish that you would enjoy and say it is a keeper.Â Â This spinach [Pui Ling] omelette is what I meant as an example.Â  I have prepared this several times and love it very much.Â  Get snap up quickly.Â You can get to eat spinach minus the 'bitter/metallic' flavour with this omelette.Drizzling some light soy sauce before dishing up the omelette gives it extra fragrance and taste.Ingredients[makes 1 big omelette]3 stalks [medium size] spinach - rinsed wellsome chopped garlic1 large egg + 1 large egg2 tbsp plain flour1 tsp saltdash of peppersome light soy sauceBring some water to boil in a wok, blanch spinach for several seconds or until the spinach is limp.Â  Removed, rinsed with cold water.Â  Squeezed out excess water, chopped.Place flour, salt and pepper in a bowl.Â  Mix well and add in 1 egg.Â  Lightly beat into a smooth batter.Â  Add in chopped spinach and garlic.Â  Mix well.Heat a non stick wok with some oil, pour in the mixture, spread out evenly.Â  Leave to fry.Â  Meanwhile, lightly beat another egg in the bowl.Fry until firm and golden brown.Â  Flip over and pour in the extra egg, spread evenly and leave to fry for awhile before flipping over to fry until both sides are golden in colour.Drizzle light soy sauce along the edges before dishing up to serve.

title: FRIED PEPPERS WITH BEANCURD
text: These days when you meet with health conscious people, most would suggest or advise that we need to cut down on all meat intake, even seafood because the world is getting more and more polluted.There is no guarantee that our daily food intake is free of chemicals, safe or healthy, no matter how careful we are with our selection.Â  To make it simpler, just eat a balanced diet in moderation and lead a healthy lifestyle. At least, to follow these 4 steps.1. Eat in moderation a balanced diet;2. Drink more water;3. Exercise regularly;4. Sleep early and rise early.How many of us can follow these steps?Â  Can you?Â  Give it some thoughts.Back to this recipe, inspired fromÂ Irene Yong's Youtube VideoÂ with modificationsCan substitute red chillies with red capsicum.Â  This is aÂ  tasty meatless dish, savoury and sweet in taste that goes well with rice or porridge.Â  Try going meatless more often and discover for yourself if you miss meat, hehehe!Ingredients2 pieces firm beancurd - halved and cutÂ  into 1 cm thick pieces1 green capsicum - seeded and cut into piecessome sliced red carrots1 red chilli - seeded and cut into pieces1 tbsp fermented black beans [tao see] - rinsed and drained1 tbsp chopped ginger50-70 ml waterSeasoning [combined]2 tbsp sweet chilli sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce [good quality ones]1 tbsp cooking wine1 tsp sesame oildash of pepper1/2 tbsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp water [mixed]Pan fry beancurd pieces until golden brown.Â  Push aside.Add in chopped ginger, fry until aromatic.Â  Mix well with fried beancurd before adding carrots, chillies and capsicum.Add in fermented black beans, stir fry for awhile.Pour in seasoning, mix well and add in water.Bring to boil for awhile.Â  Thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up to serve.

title: CRISPY CURRY OKARA
text: A very simple dish that is suitableÂ  for vegetarians and non-vegetarians.Great to serve with rice or eaten as a snack.Â  The okara and peanuts are crispy.Â  Fried with curry leaves and seasoned with curry powder, salt, sugar and vegetarian stock granules, the taste is perfect.What is Okara? - Okara, is a miracle food thatâ€™s low in fat and high in calcium, protein and dietary fiber.  It is usually white or yellowish, a by-product of black soybean tofu.What is Okara good for? - Okara is the leftover pulp from soybeans after they are filtered to make soy milk and tofu. ... In addition to savory dishes like unohana, okara can be utilized as a versatile nutritious and diet-friendly addition to baked goods.Ingredients50 gm Okara [soy bean dregs/dried glutten crisps]100 gm peanuts - roasted10 gm curry leaves - rinsed and pat drySeasoning [combined]1 1/2 tsp curry powder1/2 tsp each of salt and icing sugar1/4 tsp vegetarian stock granulesRoast or deep fry peanuts until golden and crispy.Â  Set aside.Pan fry or deep fry curry leaves and Okara until golden over low medium heat [drain, removed excess oil].Â Â Using the same pan without heat, combined all the ingredients, mix well.Â  Dish up to serve or set aside to cool before storing in air tight container.

title: SWEET SOUR LOTUS ROOTS
text: I was quite skeptical if this is going to be tasty dish as there is only 1 main ingredient [lotus roots] which I would normally use to make soup or stir fry with some other ingredients likeÂ this.This turns out to be appetising as it tasted sweet and sour, looks good.Â  The lotus roots are crunchy and crispy.Â  Moreover, it is a quick stir fry dish.Â  Great option to cook lotus roots this way.Recipe adapted fromÂ here.Â Â Ingredients2 sections lotus roots - scrap the skin, cut cubessome chopped spring onionssome toasted sesame seedsSeasoning [combined]2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce15 - 30 ml white vinegar2 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp salt1 tsp cornstarch + 50 ml waterCube lotus roots and soak in water with a few drops of vinegar to prevent de-colourisation.Â  Drain just before frying.Heat a non stick wok with some oil, add in lotus roots and stir fry for about 1 minute.Pour on theÂ  sauce, continue to stir fry until bubbly, thicken with cornstarch water.Dish out, garnish with spring onions and toasted sesame seeds.

title: STIR FRY ENOKI MUSHROOMS WITH SNOW PEAS
text: Busy days, simple meals but healthy.Â  An easy to prepare dish that can be served with rice or as a noodle dish.If serving with rice, just reduced the amount of glass noodles add more snow peas.Â  You can also use Holland peas and red carrots.Â  It is alright.The mushroom and snow peas texture is crunchy and tasty sweet.Â Â Ingredients200 gm Enoki mushrooms - removed the root portion150 gm snow peas or Holland peas - cut long strips1 red chilli - cut stripschopped ginger and garlica small bunch glass noodles - soak and drainSeasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce and oyster saucedash of pepper and salt1/4 tsp mushroom stock granulesÂ Remove the root portion of mushrooms, lightly rinse under running water.Â  Drain in colander.Soak glass noodles for 5-10 minutes.Â  Drain.Heat oil in a non stick pan, saute ginger and garlic until aromatic.Â  Add in snow peas and red chillies.Â  Stir to mix well, add in some water then glass noodles.Stir for a minute before adding in mushrooms and seasoning.Â  Continue to stir until the water is almost dry but moist.Dish up to serve.Â  Garnish with some crispy fried glutten.

title: POTATO PANCAKES
text: Savoury Pancakes are my favorite option to serve for breakfast or lunch over the weekends.Â  Usually, I will chooseÂ  the ones which are easy, simple and quick to prepare and ingredients are readily available in my kitchen.This potato pancake is a great choice as I can prepare the portion just enough to serve.The pancakes are crispy at the edges, the potato and carrots are tender [not totally crispy] at the centre because I prefer a thicker pancake.Â  A thinner one will be crispy in the centre, too.Ingredients[makes 4 pieces, serves 2]2 medium size potatoes - peeled and shredded1/2 red carrotÂ  - peeled and shredded1 stalk spring onions - cut strips3 - 4 tbsp plain flourSeasoningsome salt, pepper, 5 spice powder and mushroom stock granulesPlace shredded ingredients [except spring onions] in a big bowl.Â  Add in seasoning, mix well and taste to fine tune.Â  Add in plain flour, mix well before adding spring onions.Mix into a thick batter but not dry.Heat a non stick pan with some oil.Â  Scoop 1/4 portion of the mixture onto pan.Â  Spread out evenly.Â  Fry until the edges are crispy.Â  Sprinkle some sesame seed on top before flipping over to fry the other side.Fry until golden and cooked through.Â  Dish up to serve whole with chilli sauce or mayonnaise or cut into pieces.

title: STIR FRIED TOFU WITH SZECHUAN VEGETABLE [CAI CHOY]
text: This is a lovely vegetarian dish which is tasty, delicious to serve with rice and porridge.Â  I have prepared this twice, then only decided to share it here.Â  It is an easy and simple dish for the family, economical too.Awesome dish, the mustard stems are crunchy and tasty, not salty, while the fried tofu absorbs the flavours well.Â  Enjoy it!Fully agree with the chefÂ Irene YongÂ the taste is surprisingly good!Â  Below is the description she generously shared about mustard stems [Szechuan Vegetables/Cai Choy]:"Preserved Mustard Stem" has a crisp texture, delicious flavor, rich nutrition, a special flavor, special sour taste and savory taste, crisp and refreshing, rich in protein, carotene, dietary fiber, minerals, etc. and 17 kinds of free amino acids such as glutamic acid, aspartic acid and propionic acid."Honestly, I am not aware of this.  Recipe adapted fromÂ Irene Yong's RecipeÂ with modificationsIngredients1 piece tofu - cut into thick slices and fried100 gm Szechuan vegetablesÂ [æ¦¨èœ] - cut strips and soaked for 5 minutes, rinsed and drainedSome shredded ginger, red carrot and red chilliSome shredded wood ear fungus [can omit]Seasoningoyster sauce, light soy sauce, pepper to tastesome sesame seed oilsome cornstarch water for thickeningPan fry tofu slices in a non stick wok until crispy at the edges and golden brown.  Dish up.Using the same wok, saute ginger until aromatic before adding in the remaining ingredients.Stir fry well for several seconds.  Add in fried tofu, seasoning and some water.  Bring to boil.Thicken with cornstarch water, drizzle in some sesame oil and pepper.Dish up to serve.

title: SPICY FRIED FRESH BEANCURD STICKS [FU CHOK]
text: Another lovely stir fried fresh fu chok dish which I learnt fromÂ Â Irene YongÂ after trying some of her recipes using Fu Chok aka Yuba.Â  This dish is a spicy version but I like it, delicious and appetising.Â  It is a nice dish suitable for the young and old.As shared by Irene:Â "Yuba" contains a large amount of protein, together with vitamins B, C and mineral elements such as calcium, iron, zinc and copper.  These are believed to help in prevention of Alzheimer's disease, lowers cholesterol and blood lipids, prevents arteriosclerosis and promotes blood, cycle and delay aging".Recipe adapted fromÂ Irene Yong's RecipesÂ with modificationsIngredients250 gm fresh fu chok*1 small green capsicum - seeded and cut thick stripssome shredded red carrotsome chopped ginger and garlic1-2 small red chillies - cut small pieces1 star anisesome cornstarch water for thickeningSeasoning1 tbsp each vegetarian oyster sauce and light soy sauce1/4 tsp mushroom stock granulessalt and pepper to tastesome sesame seed oilÂ * can used dried fu chok, soaked till soft and cut into sectionsHeat some oil in a non stick wok, saute chopped ginger, garlic and star anise until aromatic.Â  Add in red chillies [can use dried chillies].Â  Stir fry until ginger and garlic are golden.Add in fuchok and red carrot.Â  Stir fry for a minute to mixÂ  well before adding in the seasoning.Â  Â Stir ingredient well before adding capsicum and some dark soy sauce for colour.Add in some water, bring to boil, stir in cornstarch water to thicken.Â  Drizzle in some sesame seed oil.Dish up to serve.

title: RICE AND VEGE PANCAKE
text: Have leftover rice to clear off but not enough to make a plate of fried rice?Â  Â No worry, this recipe may be able to solve the problem. Mix a batter with it together with some shredded vegetables and eggs.Â  You get to enjoy some lovely rice/vege pancakes for breakfast or light lunch.Â  I believe kids would love it too with some mayonnaise.Recipe inspired from thisÂ youtubeÂ video.Â  Slightly modified the recipe as I have added some French beans and seasoning.Ingredients[makes about 5-6 pieces]2-3 eggsabout 1 small bowl cooked rice1 tbsp plain flour1/2 tsp saltÂ 1/4 - 1/2 tsp chicken granulesdash of pepper50 gm shredded red carrot6-8 French beans - thinly sliced1 stalk spring onions - choppedsome sweet chilli sauce and mayonnaiseBreak eggs in a big bowl, add in cooked rice.Â  Mix to coat with eggs.Add in plain flour, salt, pepper and stock granules.Â  Mix well.Add in carrots, French beans and spring onions.Â  Mix into a batter.Heat a non stick pan or skillet over medium heat.Â  Add in some oil.Â  Scoop a small ladle of batter onto pan, spread out evenly into a round shape.Â  Cover and fry until the edges are a little brown and firm.Â  Flip over to fry the other side until edges are brown or crispy.Dish up on serving plate.Â  Finish frying the remaining batter.Serve pancakes with mayonnaise and chilli sauce.

title: TASTY FRIED YELLOW NOODLES WITH TOMATOES
text: This is a Chinese grandmother style home-cooked fried yellow noodles.Â  Not my grandma or mum.Â  My family style fried yellow noodles is without tomatoes or mushrooms.Â  We used prawns, meat slices and a must have ingredient is crispy fried shallots popularly known for this noodle 'Hokkien Char'.Â  Â It is awesome.This means that we can fry yellow noodles according to this recipe either with prawns, meat, tomatoes and mushrooms and serve it with sambal belacan or cut chillies.Ingredients[serves 2 ]200 gm yellow noodles - rinsed with tap water in a colander2 stalks of chai sim or bok choy - cut1-2 tomatoes - cut wedges2-3 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut50 gm meat slices1 big onion - peeled and slicedsome waterSeasoning2 tbsp oyster sauce1/2 tbsp light soy sauce to tastedash of msg and pepper to tasteMarinate meat slices with some soy sauce, water and cornstarch.Â  Set aside.Heat 1-2 tbsp oil in a non stick wok, fry mushrooms until aromatic.Â  Add in meat slices, continue to stir fry until meat turns white.Add in onions and tomatoes.Â  Stir fry to mix all the ingredients before adding water and seasoning.Â  Bring to boil.Place yellow noodles on top, cover with lid and leave to cook for 1-2 minutes or until water is reduced [most important step is to cover lid to braise noodles].Remove lid, stir to mix noodles with ingredients, add in vegetables.Fry until vegetables are cooked.Dish up to serve.

title: STEAMED RICE CAKE [HUAT KUIH]
text: I have been making numerous steamed paus/buns for ancestor veneration, thought I should steamed some rice cakes [huat kuih] for a change.Â  At times, I do worry that my huat kuihs [fatt gao] would not smile because I received feedbacks that their attempts to steam huat kuihs failed.Â  But I believe it needs practice and some trial and error to get smiling, soft and spongy huat kuihs.This time, I am happy with this recipe as kuihs did smile when I removed the lid.Â  The texture is soft and spongy, colour is nice and not too sweet.Ingredients[makes 14 cakes - depends on the size of the paper cases you use]100 gm superfine flour100 gm rice flour1 tbsp custard powder1 tsp baking powder1.5 tsp instant yeast80 gm gula merah [Jaggery sugar]20 gm castor sugar180 ml watersome papercasesPlace sugar and water in a saucepan.Â  Heat up over low fire, stir to dissolve the sugar [not necessary to bring to boil].Â  Strain and cool.Combine the remaining ingredients [sifted] and yeast.Â  Gradually, stir in the cooled syrup water in one direction until the batter is smooth and runny thick consistency.Arrange paper cases over plastic or steel cups in a steaming tray. Pour in the batter until 70-80% full.Â  Cover to rest for 15 minutes.Meanwhile, bring water to boil in steamer over high heat.Â  Steam kuihs for 15-20 minutes.Â  Off heat, remove lid and cool on wire rack.Â  Can steam huat kuihs in greased ceramic cups, too.

title: STIR FRY CAULIFLOWER WITH TOMATOES
text: This is one of my simply [cin cai in Hokkien dialect] cooked dishes with whatever ingredients I have in my fridge waiting to clear off.Â  That's why there aren't any step by step pictures as I do not have intention to post it here.But just it turned out to be tasty and good with rice, I thought maybe can put up here for record/reference purpose.The cauliflower is soft but still crunchy, blends well with the sourish sweetness of the tomatoes.Â  The fried fresh fu chok [my favourite food ingredient for vegetarian dishes] tastes good when it absorbs the sourish sweet flavours of the tomatoes and seasoning.I will not state the quantity of the ingredients for this dish here as it is supposed to be 'cincai cooked'.Â  So you can just do your combination according to own preference.Ingredientscauliflower - washed and cut into floretstomatoes [with or without skin removed] - cut wedgessome fried fu chok [beancurd sheet/skin] - cut sectionssome sliced carrotssome chopped gingerBring some water to boil, blanch cauliflower and carrots for 1 minute or so.Â  Drain and set aside.Heat oil in wok, saute ginger until aromatic then add in tomatoes.Â  Stir fry until tomatoes are soft.Â  Add in blanched vegetables, fu chok and some water.Stir fry to mix, add salt and vegetarian seasoning to taste. Thicken with some cornstarch water if preferred.Drizzle in sesame seed oil and dash of pepper. Mix well and dish up to serve.

title: STIR FRY GLASS NOODLES WITH FRESH KING OYSTER MUSHROOMS
text: This noodle dish is inspired from Irene Yong's You-tube videoÂ Vegan Sauteed Shark's Fin.Â  I just added more glass noodles.Â A meatless, simple stir fry glass noodles that is tasty and delicious.Â  Serve with some cut chillies in soy sauce makes a satisfying meal.Ingredients100 gm glass noodles - soaked for 10-15 minutes3 pieces King oyster mushrooms - rinsed, removed the head and tear the stems into strips [keep the head for other dishes or slice into thin strips]80 gm wet foo peh - cut strips [I used 1 packet ready fried foo peh]50 gm red carrots - peeled and shredded1-2 tbsp oilsome chopped gingersome chopped Chinese celery for garnishingSeasoningmushroom stock granules or vegetarian stock granulesvegetarian oyster saucesalt to tastesesame seed oilFry mushrooms in wok without oil until fragrant [water will ooze out from the mushrooms, then dries up].Â  Push aside, add in oil, saute ginger until aromatic.Add in foo peh, carrots and seasoning.Â  Stir fry to mix well and add in water to cover ingredients.Â  Bring to boil.Add in glass noodles, continue to stir fry lightly until the water dries up and the noodles are moist.Â  Drizzle in some sesame seed oil and add in cut celery.Dish up.Â  Serve immediately.

title: STIR FRY SENGKUANG WITH DRIED GLUTTEN CRISPS
text: Meatless dishes can be as delicious and tasty without meat.Â  Just like this dish.Â  It is meatless yet the taste is awesome with ingredients like fresh, young sengkuang [crispy and juicy], dried mushrooms and dried glutten crisps.Â  Looks good to with addition of French beans and red carrots.Â The seasoning is only salt and mushroom stock granules. If not strictly vegetarian, can use chicken stock granules, too. Awesome stir fry sengkuang that is healthy and tasty.Ingredients1.2 kg sengkuang - peeled and finely shredded150 gm French beans - thinly sliced1 red carrot - peeled and finely shredded6 dried mushrooms - soaked and finely shredded50 gm dried glutten crisps - lightly brownedsome chopped gingerSeasoningsalt and mushroom stock granules to tasteHeat 2-3 tbsp oil in wok, saute ginger until aromatic. Add in dried mushrooms, fry until fragrant.Add in sengkuang and carrot.Â  Continue to stir fry until the vegetables are soft [the water comes from the freshness of the vegetables, naturally sweet in taste].Add in French beans, continue to fry until the beans turns bright green in colour.Â  Add seasoning to taste and fried glutten crisps.Stir to mix well and dish up to serve [hot or warm].

title: CANTONESE MIXED STIR FRY VEGETABLES
text: This is another tasty, delicious meatless vegetable stir fry dish withÂ an assortment of ingredients.Â  Again thanks toÂ Irene Yong's Youtube recipeÂ and the nutritional information about lotus roots."Lotus Root" - rich in starch, protein, vitamin B + C, fat, carbohydrates and calcium, phosphorus, iron and other mineralsaccording to Chinese medicine, believes that lotus root is a winter tonic health food that is edible with medicinal valuea food good for our internal organs, strong bones and muscles, nourishing Yin and blood.it helps to excrete waste and toxins in the body.It is a lovely combination of ingredients and I especially love the crunchy lotus root slices areÂ tender, sweet and crispy.Â  A dish worth trying is you a looking for meatless dish to try.Ingredients200 g lotus roots - scrape the skin and slice thinly50 g black fungus - soaked and break into pieces150 g red carrots - peeled and sliced1 red capsicum - seeded and cut triangle shape150 gm sweet peas - cut halfsome chopped gingersome watersome sesame seed oil1-2 tbsp cooking oilSeasoning [combined]dash of mushroom granulesdash of pepper and salt to tastesome cornstarch water for thickeningSoak sliced lotus roots in water with a few drops of vinegar [prevents decolorisation].  Drain before blanching.Bring a some water to boil, blanch black fungus, followed by carrots and lotus roots for 1-2 minutes.  Drain in a colander.Heat a non stick wok, add oil, saute ginger until aromatic.  Add in the blanched ingredients, stir lightly to mix.  Add in seasoning, red capsicum and sweet peas. Pour in some water.Stir fry to mix well, thicken with cornstarch water and drizzle in sesame seed oil.Dish up to serve.

title: BRAISED MUSHROOMS WITH FRESH FU CHOK
text: This recipe is adapted fromÂ Irene Yong's YoutubeÂ video.Â  She has numerous meatless dishes.Â Â Â If you wish to go for meatless meals, it is worth trying some of her recipes.Â Â I have picked a few to prepare as Ching Ming food offerings to my late father in-law at the Kek Lok Si Columbarium.Â  At KLS columbarium, we can only offer meatless food as KLS is a Buddhist temple.Anyway, back to this dish, it is simple and easy to prepare yet it is surprisingly tasty and delicious as the chef has commented.Â  Suitable for the old and young and highly nutritious.Â  Fresh fuchok is aka 'yuba' which means -Â Tofu skin,Â Â bean curd skin, bean curd sheet, or bean curd robes, is a food product made from soybeans'.Â  Can substitute fuchok with dried ones [soak before use].Irene has generously shared some valuable information about this ingredient. "Yuba" - contains a variety of minerals, supplements calciumprevents osteoporosis caused by calcium deficiency, enhances bone developmentregular consumption is beneficial to the brain, prevent Alzheimer's diseaseprevents hardening of the blood vessels, protects the heart, lowers the blood cholesterol level, prevents hyperlipidemia and arteriosclerosis.It has the effect of clearing away heat and moistening the lungs, relieving cough and eliminating phlegm, and is suitable for everyone to eat.glutamic acid in yuba is 2 to 5 times higher than that of other legumes or animal foods, and glutamate plays an important role in brain activityyuba has a good brain function and helps prevent senile dementia diseaseIngredients100 g fresh fu chok [yuba] - cut sections30 gm dried mushrooms - soaked and halved150 g red carrots - peeled and sliced1 green capsicum - seeded and cut shapessome chopped ginger1-2 tbsp cooking oilsome sesame seed oil1-2 tbsp waterSeasoning [combined]2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1/2 tbsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp vinegardash of mushroom granulesdash of pepper and salt to tastesome cornstarch water for thickeningBring a some water to boil, blanch mushrooms, followed by carrots and fu chok for 1-2 minutes.  Drain in a colander.Heat a non stick wok, add oil, saute ginger until aromatic.  Add in the blanched ingredients, stir lightly to mix.  Add in seasoning, green capsicum and water.Stir fry to mix well, thicken with cornstarch water and drizzle in sesame seed oil.Dish up to serve.

title: STIR FRIED SPINACH [PUI LING - è èœ]
text: I used to fry this leafy green, spinach aka Pui Ling [è èœ], sometimes with dried prawns, anchovies, chopped garlic and fermented beancurd [foo yee].This time, I followed a recipe from Irene Yong's Youtube] which is easy and simple.  Just with 2 ingredients, yet the result is awesome.Irene has advised to not to discard the root stems but to retain about 1 cm near the root is most nutritious part.  It should be preserved and fried together with the stems and leaves.  You can get to taste the sweetness of spinach.I followed her tips and it is true, the vegetable is sweet, soft and smooth without the bitter taste.  Boiling the greens before frying reduce the 'oxalic acid'.  According to Irene, oxalic acid hinders the body's absorption of calcium and iron.Ingredients300 gm spinach - cut into appropriate lengths2-3 pips garlic - chopped1 tbsp cooking oilSeasoningsalt, mushroom stock granules and pepper to tasteRinse vegetable under running tap water then soak in a basin of clean water for 10 minutes.  Rinse well.  Cut off the roots but leave at least 1 cm of the section before the stems.  Cut in sections preferred.Bring a pot of water to boil, add in a little oil and a pinch of salt.  Blanch cut vegetables in hot water for a while.  Remove and drain on a colander.Heat a non stick wok with some oil, add a pinch of salt, saute garlic until aromatic.  Add in blanched spinach, stir over high heat and add in seasoning.Dish up to serve. Enjoy.!!!

title: STEAMED PAUS - GULA MELAKA COCONUT FILLING
text: This is quite a different steamed pau skin recipe which I tried.Â  The pau skin turned out to be smooth,Â  spongy, soft and chewy.  Lovely fluffy pau skin which is low in sugar and fats compared to other recipes which I have been using.Â Â If you enjoy eating steamed paus but afraid of the sugar and fats in the pau skin, this is a good recipe to use.Â  The texture is good and great with this Gula Melaka Coconut filling.Gula Melaka Coconut Filling recipe inspired fromÂ MyKitchen101en.Â  Though I did not follow exactly the portion but this filling is nice.Â  It is fragrant, tastes good and not too sweet.Â Ingredients For Gula Melaka Coconut Filling200 gm freshly grated white coconutÂ 110 gmÂ palm sugar/gula melaka - chopped25 gm Jaggery sugar or gula merah80 ml hot water2-3 blades pandan leaves - washed and tie into a knotslaked cornstarch [1.5 tsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp water]For the Filling - Place palm sugar, gula merah and pandan leaves in a saucepan.Â  Add in hot water, bring to boil over medium low heat until sugar dissolves.Strain into a clean non stick pan/wok.Â  Bring to boil and stir in cornstarch water.Â  Add in grated white coconut.Stir to mix well, fry until the coconut is almost dry but moist and leave the pan clean.Dish out to cool.Ingredients[makes 16 paus]300 gm pau flour1/2 tbsp icing sugar1 tsp instant yeast150-170 ml water1/2 tbsp shorteningFor Skin - combine all ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water to mix into a rough dough [may not need to use all the water].Â Add in shortening, continue to knead until dough is soft and smooth.Â  Shape into a round ball, leave in bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down, roll into a long log or ball, then divide into 16 equal portions or more according to own preference.Â  Shape each portion into a ball.Flatten each ball and wrap 1-2 tsp gula melaka coconut filling, seal the edges well into a pleated or round pau.Â  Place on a piece of parchment paper in a steaming tray.Â  Finish making the rest.Cover and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Steaming over high heat for 10-12 minutes.Off heat, remove to cool on wire rack before storing or serve immediately.

title: STIR FRY TASTY TOFU PUFFS
text: This dish is a rather quick stir fry dish, savoury and sweet in taste.Â Â A meatless dish, good to spread over a plate of steaming hot plain rice as One Dish Meal.Â  Particularly love the dried chillies, spicy hot and appetising.Â  The tofu puffs absorb the flavours of the seasoning, makes it tasty.Ingredients[serves 2]100 - 150 gm tofu puffs - cut half diagonally1 small green capsicum - cut wedges1 small red capsicu, - cut wedges [ I used 1 red chilli]2 dried red chillies - soaked and cut small sectionssome slice ginger and garlic1 stalk spring onions - cut sections1 tsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp water100 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp each sweet chilli sauce, oyster sauce, light soy sauce and sugar1 tsp stock granules1/2 tsp each salt and dark soy sauceHeat a non stick wok with some oil, pan fry the tofu puffs until slightly charred.Â  Dish up.Using the same wok with some oil, saute ginger, garlic and spring onions until aromatic.Add in the seasoning, stir to mix, add in water.Bring to boil, add in the fried tofu puffs.Â  Stir to mix well and let itÂ  braise for awhile.Lastly, add in the chillies/capsicum.Â  Mix well and thicken with cornstarch water.Â  Drizzle inÂ some sesame seed oil.Dish up to serve.

title: FRIED FIRM BEANCURD WITH FRAGRANT SAUCE
text: These days [especially after the Chinese New Year], I have been going more for meatless dishes.Â  Trying to be a 'flexitarian'.Â "The term "flexitarian" has been coined to describe someone who eats mostly plant-based foods, but occasionally eats meat, poultry and fish. That kind of healthy eating is central to the Mediterranean diet â€” which limits red meat and emphasizes fruits, vegetables, legumes, whole grains and healthy fats â€” and has been shown to reduce your risk of heart disease and other chronic conditions. Why not work on your flexibility and start reaping some healthy benefits?"Â  Excerpts fromÂ "Mayo Clinic - Healthy Eating/Meatless Meals].Hope I can keep it up. "Meatless meals are built around beans, lentils, vegetables and whole grains. These plant-based proteins tend to be less expensive and offer more health benefits than meat."Â Â How true?Â  MustÂ  give it a try.....This dish is simple just with firm beancurd [my favorite food ingredient] and a tasty, sweet, sourish sauce.Â  The sauce can be used for frying eggplants or fresh beancurd sticks [foo chuk] too.Â  One can use her own creativity or feel free to add any other ingredients deems fit....I believe it would be nice, too.Â Â Ingredients[serves 3]3 pieces firm beancurd [taukwa] - quarteredsome chopped garlic [omit for full time vegetarians]some chopped spring onions [omit for full time vegetarians]**some toasted sesame seeds** can substitute with Chinese celery or coriander leavesSeasoning Sauce [combined]1 tbsp each of tomato puree, black vinegar, light soy sauce and sugar1 tsp cornstarch + 3 tbsp waterHeat oil in a non stick wok, fry beancurd pieces until golden or crispy at the edges.Â  Dish up, set aside.Â  Remove excess oil.Using the same wok, fry chopped garlic until aromatic with some oil, pour in seasoning sauce, add in fried beancurd.Stir to mix well, thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up, garnish with sesame seeds, spring onions or coriander leaves.Serve.

title: HOME STYLE WAT TAN HOR
text: Have you tried preparing Cantonese Wat Tan Hor using Kailan instead of Choy Sum?Â  For me, yes, ever since I prepared this Thai noodleÂ [Rad Nah [Thai Flat Noodles in Gravy], I have been switching these 2 vegetables whenever I cook flat rice noodles.Â  Love the crunchy, bright green leaves in the gravy. Simply delicious eventhough there are no prawns. It is good, my husband has got used to it, neverÂ  ask why I am not using Choy Sum for the gravy when cookingÂ  this noodle 'Char Hor Fun' in Hokkien dialect.This a simple and easy to prepare noodle dish.Â  If you think a plate of this you eat at the stall isn't enough to fill your stomach, why not make this at home?Â  Awesome.Â  You can also serve this meat/vegetable gravy over plain rice as a One Dish Meal.Ingredients[serves 3]600 gm flat rice noodles - loosen up with a pair of chopsticks200 gm lean pork - sliceda bunch of kailan - washed and break into piecessome sliced cut carrots1 tbsp chopped garlic3 bowls water2-3 eggs - lightly beaten2 tbsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp water [thickening]Seasoning2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp salt1/2 tsp msg or chicken stock granules1/4 tsp pepperSoak kailan in water with a pinch of bicarbonate soda for 10 minutes.Â  Rinse, drain and break into pieces.Marinate meat slices with some light soy sauce, dash of pepper and some cornstarch.Heat a non stick wok with a teaspoon of oil [need little oil as the flat noodles are oily],Â  add in noodles, spread out evenly so that the noodles will be a little charred [fragrance] or has the so called 'wok hei'.Â  Seasoned with 1 tablespoon of oyster sauce.Â  Stir fry to mix well, dish up on serving platter.Using the same wok, add in 1 tablespoon of oil, saute garlic until aromatic.Â  Add in meat slices.Â  Fry until it turns white.Â  Add in water.Bring to boil, add seasoning to taste, boil for 1-2 minutes.Add in kailan and carrots.Â  Stir to mix well, thicken with cornstarch water.Lower heat, pour in eggs.Â  Need not stir the gravy.Â  Off heat.Scoop over fried noodles.Â  Serve immediately with cut chillies or sambal belacan.ENJOY!!!

title: RYE FLOUR BREAD LOAF
text: Bread is my family's staple food for the first meal [breakfast]Â  of our day.Â  Though I have baked numerous types of bread loaves, I need to stick to just one or two recipes for convenience.Â Â Lately, I tried this recipe and find it good too.Â  The bread texture is soft, spongy and chewy.Â  Tastes good with much less sweetness compared to store bought ones.Â  Served with butter and homemade preserves with a cup of hot beverage is awesome meal to us.Ingredients[makes 2 loaves x 550 gm or 24 slices of 1.5 cm width]500 gm bread flour30 gm wheat germ50 gm rye flour100 gm plain flour1 tsp salt3 tbsp jaggery sugar or castor sugar6 tsp instant yeast420 ml water [+-]50 gm butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter and water] on slow speed to combine.Â  Add in water gradually as you may need less than 420 ml. Â  Continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed [Kenwood mixer - speed 3] when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky [leaves the bowl clean]Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 2 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a long rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â  Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tins.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour or rise over the rim of the baking tin].Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 35 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack.

title: FRIED YELLOW NOODLES WITH CHIVES
text: One comfort food for a quick simple meal over the weekend.Â  Fried yellow noodles top with a thick soup of mixed ingredients.Â  Tasty and delicious served with a spoonful of precooked tom yam chilli paste if you prefer noodles spicy.Ingredients[serves 2]300 to 350 gm fresh yellow noodlesa small bunch of chives - cut sections100 gm beansprouts - tailed2-3 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips50 gm carrots - cut strips100 gm minced or sliced meatÂ a few slices ginger - cut strips250 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp chicken stock granulesÂ dash of pepper1 tbsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp waterMarinate meat with some light soy sauce, pepper and sesame seed oil.Â Â Heat a little oil in wok, saute chopped garlic until fragrant, add in yellow noodles and some dark soy sauce [for colour].Â  Stir fry untilÂ  well combined and aromatic.Â  Dish up onto serving platter.Using the same wok, add in some oil, saute ginger strips and mushrooms until aromatic.Â  Add in meat to fry until it turns white and firm.Add in carrots, stir fry to mix before adding water.Â  Bring to boil and add in seasoning.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.When water boils, add in beansprouts and chive.Â  Stir to mix well.Â  Thicken with cornstarch water.Bring to boil and scoop gravy over fried noodles.Serve immediately with cut chillies or sambal belacan or cooked tomyam paste.

title: STIR FRY TOFU PUFFS WITH BLACK FUNGUS
text: This is aÂ vegetarian dish which I will be preparingÂ  for Chinese New Year meal.Â  As in previous years, there is a need to cookvegetarian dishes for my hubbyâ€™s siblings when they come visiting.Â  More and more of his siblings and relativesare on vegan meals.Â  Some are forreligious reasons while others are for their love of vegetarian dishes.ThisÂ  can beÂ  â€˜cin caiâ€™ cooked dish as you can adjust theseasoning according to the portion of tofu puffs you wish to cook.Â  It tastes a bit of a â€˜hotâ€™ with the dried redchillies and ginger but definitely appetizing serving it with rice.Ingredients200 gm tofu puffs [taupok] â€“ halvedSome red and green chillies or capsicums â€“ cut wedges1 bowlÂ  soakedblack fungus 30 gm red carrot â€“ peeled and slicedSome chopped ginger4-5 dried chillies â€“ soaked and cut small piecesÂ½ tbsp cooking oilSeasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce and oyster sauceÂ½ tsp salt1 tsp sugarÂ½ tbsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp waterBring some water to boil, blanched black fungus for 1minute.Â  Drain and set aside.Heat oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© gingerÂ  and dried chillies until aromatic.Add in tofu puffs and carrots.Â  Stir to mix well.Â  Add in seasoning ingredients and black fungus.Stir fry for another minute, add some water to bring outthe flavours.Add in chillies, stir to mix well then thicken withcornstarch water.Dish up to serve.

title: CNY 2019 - PINEAPPLE TARTS [TARTLET SHAPE]
text: I started shaping the pineapple tarts in a rose shape. Halfway through, I remembered that I wanted to try using the small tartlet mould to shape the tarts.So here, you will see some rose and tartlet shapes of the pineapple tarts.  Using the tartlet mould saves much of my  time.These are all so lovely.  The pastry is buttery, soft and aromatic with the nice pineapple jam inside.Ingredients[makes 75 pieces]Filling Â - 250-300 gm pineapple jam-roll into small balls1 egg yolk mix with 1 tbsp water for glazingsmall paper cup casesPastry Ingredients250 gm soft butter50 gm icing sugar1 egg yolk1 tsp vanilla essence1/2 tsp salt360 gm plain flour + 2 tbsp custard powderShape pineapple filing into small round balls [5 gm each]. Set aside or chill in fridge until required.Use an electric mixer to cream butter, sugar and then add in egg yolk and essence. Continue to beat until light and fluffy.Â  Fold in flour mixture, mix into a soft dough or just combined [do not over work dough].Divide dough into small portions enough to wrap filling, seal and roll into round ball.Â  Press into a small tartlet mould.Â  Place tart inverted [bigger surface as base] on a lined baking tray.Use a plastic peg to create a criss cross pattern.Â  Apply egg glaze.Bake at 180 degrees C for 20 minutes or until golden in colour.Remove from oven, cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: CNY 2019 - GERMAN COOKIES [KB DESIGN]
text: This is a test attempt, shaping German Cookies using plastic Kuih Bangkit mould.Â  I was quite tired of making the usual shape German Cookies [rolling into rounds and press with a fork to create the design].Â  With the KB mould, no harm giving it a try.Â  So long as the dough does not stick to the mould, can consider it successful.Â  Even if it sticks, dusting you hand with some flour will solve the problem.I like the designs, looks cute and attractive.Â  These cookies are crispy, light and buttery.Â  Guess many would not know they are German Cookies.Ingredients[makes 140 pieces]250 gm butter - room temperature80 gm icing sugarÂ - sifted250 gm potato starch150 gm plain flourÂ - siftedÂ Red cherry bitsÂ Beat butter and icing sugar till fluffy and light in color.Sift in potato starch together with plain flour.Â  Fold flour mixture into cream.Â  Mix into a soft dough.Â  Â Transfer to a container and chill for 30 minutes.Lightly dust hand with flour, pinch a small bit of the dough, roll into round and press into plastic kuih bangkit mould [choose the design you prefer].Â  Lightly knock the mould to dislodge dough. Place cookies in the baking tray line with parchment paper.Â  Top with cut red cherries.Bake at preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 15-20 minutes depending on the size of your cookies or until slightly golden.Remove from oven, leave to cool completely on Â a wire rack and store in airtight container.

title: CNY 2019 - BUTTER COOKIES
text: This is the second batch of butter cookies which I baked for the coming Chinese New Year.Â  The first post onÂ Butter CookiesÂ is just a small portion which makes about 60 pieces.Â  It isn't enough to share.The recipe here is adapted fromÂ Kathrine Kwa [Youtube] recipeÂ with modifications.Â  Afraid that the original recipe yields not enough pieces to share, I roughly increased the portion to one and half.These butter cookies are aromatic, buttery, crispy and not overly sweet.Â  Suits my taste bud and yours if you like the not too sweet butter cookies.Â  Lovely cookies.Ingredients[makes 150 pieces]270 gm salted butter120 gm icing sugar1 egg [size AA]1/2 tsp salt330 gm plain flour + 75 gm cornflour â€“ sifted40 ml milkÂ some chopped red cherries - toppingCream butter, sugar and salt until light and fluffy.Â  Beat in eggs until well blended.Sift the dry ingredients together.Fold [2] into [1], alternating with milk.Â  Mix into a dough. Transfer to a container and chill for 30 minutes.Scoop in small portions into a piping bag with star nozzle.Â  Pipe star rosettes onto a lined baking tray.Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 15 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: CNY 2019 - YUAN PAO PINEAPPLE TARTS
text: Cheesy flavour 'yuan pao' pineapple tarts for this CNY.Â  Sure prosper with the nice, auspicious shaped pineapple tarts, hehehe!.Like other pineapple tarts recipes, this recipe is also a keeper.Â  The tarts are lovely, soft, buttery and with the 'fragile' texture.Â  Loves the new shape that I made and happy with the store bought pineapple jam that is not too sweet.Â  Blends well with the not too sweet pastry.Â Ingredients[makes 80 pieces]Filling Â - 250-300 gm pineapple jam-roll into small balls1 egg yolk mix with 1 tbsp water for glazingsmall paper cup casesPastry Ingredients240 gm soft butter20 gm icing sugar1 egg yolk1 tsp vanilla essence320 gm plain flour + 40 gm cornflour + 40 gm cheese powderShape pineapple filing into small round balls [5 gm each]. Â Set aside or chill in fridge until required.Use an electric mixer to blend butter, sugar and add in egg yolk and essence.Â  Cream until light.Â  Fold in flour mixture, mix into a soft dough or just combined [do not over work dough].Divide dough into small portions enough to wrap filling, seal and roll into round ball.Â  Place in a small paper case.Use a plastic peg to create a criss-cross design.Place on a baking tray.Â  Apply egg glaze.Bake at 180 degrees C for 20 minutes or until golden in colour.Remove from oven, cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: CNY 2019 - BUTTER COOKIES
text: One of my sister in-law only likes plain Butter Cookies.Â  So these butter cookies are for her and hope she would enjoy these too, instead of my otherÂ My Family Butter CookiesÂ which to her is Awesome.Â Â I have tried this eggless butter cookies, it is great.Â  Crispy and buttery.Â  This recipe is a keeper.Â  Perhaps, I need to bake a double portion next time.Recipe adapted fromÂ Little Duck's KitchenÂ with modificationsIngredients[makes 60 pieces]220 gm unsalted butter55 gm icing sugar175 gm superfine flour + 3 tbsp cornflour + 2 tbsp milk powder â€“ sifted1/2 tsp saltsome chopped red cherries - toppingCream butter, sugar and salt until light and fluffy.Sift the dry ingredients together.Fold [2] into [1].Â  Mix into a dough. Transfer to a container and chill for 30 minutes.Scoop into small portions in a piping bag with star nozzle.Â  Pipe star rosettes onto a lined baking tray.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 20 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: CNY 2019 - OREO GERMAN COOKIES
text: A friend bought too much of the potato starch and not in the mood of baking cookies.Â  She gave me a portion.Â  So as not to waste it,Â  I baked another variety of German Cookies with addition of Oreo.Â  I believe it should be good as Oreo itself is yummy-licious.Similar with German Cookies of other flavours, this is another variation.Â  These cookies are crispy. crunchy and buttery.Â  Great to snack on.Â  If it isn't for Chinese New Year, I would probably make them slightly bigger in size.Recipe adapted fromÂ Little Duck's KitchenÂ with modificationsIngredients[makes 125 pieces]250 gm butter - room temperature90-100 gm icing sugarÂ - sifted240 gm potato starch160 gm plain flourÂ - siftedÂ 60 gm Oreo cookies - crushedBeat butter and icing sugar till fluffy and lighter in color.Sift in potato starch together with plain flour.Â  Fold flour mixture into cream.Â  Mix wellÂ  then add in crushed Oreo.Â  Mix into a soft dough.Â  Â Transfer to a container and chill for 30 minutes.Pinch about 10 gm dough, roll into round and press it with a fork to make design and placeÂ  in the baking tray line with parchment paper.Bake at preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 20 minutes depending on the size of your cookies.Remove from oven, leave to cool completely on Â a wire rack and store in airtight container.

title: CNY 2019 - SALTED EGG YOLKS COOKIES
text: A recipe which I have bookmarked to try some time back.Â  Looks good when I prepared the dough.Â  Do not omit the salt because just with the salted egg yolks, the saltiness is not sufficient to bring out the aroma.This is a lovely savoury, sweet and fragrant cookie.Â  This recipe is a keeper if you are in for this kind of cookies. I definitely going to bake another batch because this portion is not enough to share.Very addictive and is a 'fragile' kind of cookies to handle with care.Â  Awesome.Recipe adapted from Cheh Cheh of Messy WitchenÂ with modificationsIngredients[makes 105 pieces]250 gm plain flour +Â 20 gm cornflour - sifted1/4 tsp baking powder +Â 1/8 tsp bicarbonate of soda3-4 salted duck egg yolks - mashed170 gm butter - room temperature80 gm icing sugar - sifted1/2 tsp saltEgg Glaze - Lightly beaten1 egg +Â pinch of saltGarnishing - Black and white toasted sesame seedsSeparate the eggs.  Steam the egg yolks until cooked.  Use a fork to mash the yolks and set aside.Sift together the dry ingredients and add in mashed egg yolks.Â  Mix well.Â  Set aside.Using a stand mixer cream butter, sugar and salt until light and fluffy.Â With low speed, fold in sifted dry ingredients and in batches.Â  Beat until just combined into a soft dough.Transfer to a air-tight container and place in the fridge for about 30 minutes.Pinch dough of about 10 gm, roll into rounds, place cookies on baking tray lined with parchment paper, press to flatten.Â  Brush with egg glaze and sprinkle some sesame seeds on top.Bake in a preheated oven at 170 degrees C for about 15 minutes or until golden brown.Â Cool cookies completely before storing in air tight containers.

title: MY UPGRADED DAILY HOME MADE BREAD LOAF
text: Unlimited knowledge to acquire irrespective of time and age. I was happy with My Daily Home Baked Wholemeal Bread LoafÂ since 3-4 years ago.Â  My hubby has not complained or got tired of having the same bread for breakfast for years.Â Recently, I went to get some baking ingredients from another store.Â  I discovered that they supply wheat germ and rye flour at a very much cheaper price than the regular store I used to get my baking stuff.Â  I have been adding wheat bran to my bread which I find to be good enough.Â  Now I discovered that with wheat germ with rye flour, my bread is soft, spongy and the texture is compact but not dry.Â  Very nice texture, super soft, fluffy and moist bread. Â Served with butter, my home-made preserves and a slice of cheddar cheese, it's awesome.Â  Finish it off with a cup of hot beverage is a good meal to start the day.This recipe is for 2 loaves which is enough for four days for my family of three.Ingredients[makes 2 loaves x 600 gm or 24 slices of 1.5 cm width]500 gm bread flour50 gm wheat germ50 gm rye flour100 gm plain flour1 tsp salt3 tbsp jaggery sugar6 tsp instant yeast400 ml water [+-]50 gm butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter and water] on slow speed to combine.Â  Add in water gradually as you may need less than 400 ml. Â  Continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed [Kenwood mixer - speed 3] when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 2 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a long rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â  Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tins.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour or rise over the rim of the baking tin].Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 35 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack.

title: CNY 2019 - CRANBERRIES GERMAN COOKIES
text: Again, it is time to bake Chinese New Year cookies.Â  Last year this time was a very busy and tiring period when my mother in-law was in hospital for operation.Â  Time was not enough then to get the necessary things and routine done as I was juggling from home to hospital and work.There are several cookies which I have intended to try but all set aside due to shortage of time and the worries over my in-law's condition.Now, with things back to normal, I supposed there shall be enough time for me to get going to bake the various cookies.German Cookies, I have baked several but I think I have not tried one with dried cranberries.Â  This is it, crispy, crunchy with a soft bite of the cranberry bits.Recipe adapted fromÂ Little Duck's KitchenÂ with modificationsIngredients[makes 110 pieces]250 gm butter - room temperature100 gm icing sugarÂ - sifted250 gm potato starch180 gm plain flourÂ - siftedÂ 50 gm dried cranberries - choppedÂ Beat butter and icing sugar till fluffy and lighter in color.Sift in potato starch, plain flour and mix with dried cranberries.Â  Â Fold flour mixture into cream.Â  Mix well into a soft dough.Â  Chill for 30 minutes.Pinch about 10 gm dough, roll into round and press it with a fork to make design and placeÂ  in the baking tray line with parchment paper.Bake at preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 13-15 minutes depending on the size of your cookies.Remove from oven, leave to cool completely on Â a wire rack and store in airtight container.

title: CNY 2019 - HIGHLY ADDICTIVE PINEAPPLE TARTS
text: Ingredients:Â (yield about 97pcs)Â Â  (A)Â  Â 250g salted butter (I used SCS, my aunt used tin type Golden Churn)Â Â  50g castor sugar (see tips)Â Â  1 tsp condensed milkÂ Â  1Â tsp vanilla extractÂ Â  (B)Â  Â 1 eggÂ Â  (C)Â  Â 350g plain flourÂ Â Â  50g milk powderÂ  Â Filling: +/- 780g pineapple paste (roll into balls of 1 level tsp each)Â Â  Egg glaze: 1 egg yolk mix with 1 to 2 tsp water (sifted)Â Â Â Â Method:Sift (C) together 3 times (my aunt specially mentioned must sieve 3 times but being lazy I only sieve 1 time: P).Beat (A) till creamy.Add (B) mix well.Use the lowest speed of the mixer to fold in (C) in 3 batches then use a rubber spatula to scrape the bowl and fold in any remaining flour (do not over mix).Wrap dough with cling wrap and chill for 30 mins to firm it up. Take Â½ level tbsp of dough, roll into ball, lightly flatten and wrap with one pineapple ball. (Suggest keeping half of the dough in fridge while wrapping).Arrange on lined baking tray or use small paper case to hold it.Bake in preheated oven at 180C for about 8-10 mins, upper middle rack. Take out from oven, apply egg wash and return to oven to bake for another 5-6 mins till cooked.Tips:Only start to bake the first tray while you are almost complete wrapping for the second tray. When applying egg wash for the first tray, pop the second tray into oven. When the second tray is done for the first round of baking, return first tray to oven after egg wash is done.I made my own castor sugar by blending fine sugar in a blender.I try Singlong brand of pineapple paste this year. It is sweet and sour type and fibrous which I like. I do not need to add any lemon juice to adjust the sweetness. Instead, I rub in little unsalted butter. This is another â€œsecret ingredientâ€ to make store-bought pineapple paste taste better.The baking temperature and time will also affect the texture. If you like the pastry more firm and crispy, bake it at higher temperature (180/190C), if you like it soft bake it at lower temperature.Â Â Â Â Â (Recipe source: Aunt ofÂ Angel of Cook.Bake.Love)Auntâ€™s Pineapple Tart

title: SWEET POTATO LEMONGRASS TANG YUAN
text: This Winter Solstice, I made a daring change from the usual.Â  Instead of preparing the much use to colourful pulut rice balls in ginger sugar syrupÂ [Kuih Ee], I cooked the glutinous rice balls in lemongrass/pandan sweet soup with orange sweet potatoes.Â  I made the rice balls with only one colour [pandan green] instead of the colourful ones below.It is lucky my mother in-law did not object and perhaps could not because she likes them with the sweet potatoes [her favourite tuber] and the not too sweet syrup soup.Â Recipe adapted from Feminine Magazine No. 570Ingredients30 gm wheat starch mixed with 40 ml boiling water120 ml pandan juice ** + 30 gm castor sugar150 gm glutinous rice flour1-2 tsp oil [I omit]** extracted from blending 6 blades screwpine leaves with 120 ml water [keep excess if dough is too dry]. Add a drop of green colouring if prefered.Sugar Syrup Soup400 gm orange sweet potatoes - peeled, cut big cubes or diamond shape2-3 stalks lemongrass2-3 blades pandan leaves100-120 gm sugar or rock sugar5 bowls waterÂ Dissolve sugar in warm pandan juice.Stir 40 ml hot water into wheat starch.Â  Mixed.Add to glutinous rice flour, mixed then gradually add in the pandan liquid and oil.Â  Knead into a soft smooth dough.Â  Add a little more water if it is too dry.Â  Rest dough for at least 30-60 minutes before rolling into balls.To make the syrup, boil pandan leaves with lemongrass until fragrant.Â  Add in sweet potatoes.Â  Continue to boil until soft, add sugar to taste.Â  Set aside.Bring a pot of water to boil to cook rice balls.Â  Remove with a serrated ladle when the rice balls float up.Â  Transfer to sweet potato soup.Serve warm or hot.

title: STEAMED PAUS - PALM SUGAR FILLING
text: My husband's friend gave him some palm sugar [gula melaka] from Melaka.Â  The palm sugar is not very sweet but is soft and easy to chopped into small pieces.I used them to make these paus.Â  Fluffy paus with an easy gula melaka filling.Â  I believe this recipe is good for a novice in pau making.Â Ingredients[makes 12 paus]200 gm pau flour1 tbsp icing sugar1 tsp instant yeast1/2 tsp double action baking powder1/4 tsp white vinegar1 tbsp golden syrup100-120 ml water1/2 tbsp shorteningIngredients For Filling50 gm palm sugar/gula melaka - choppedsome diced glazed cherries for decorationFor Skin - combine all ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water/vinegar to mix into a rough dough [may not need to use all the water].Â Add in shortening, continue to knead until dough is soft and smooth.Â  Shape into a round ball, leave in bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down, roll into a ball, then divide into 10 equal portions or more according to own preference.Â  Shape each portion into a ball.Flatten each ball and wrap 1 tsp gula melaka filling, seal the edges well into a pleated or round pau.Â  Place on a piece of parchment paper in a steaming tray [I used my electric steamer].Â  Finish making the rest.Cover and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Steaming over high heat for 10-12 minutes.Off heat, remove to cool on wire rack before storing or serve immediately.

title: STEAMED PAUS - YAM FILLINGS
text: As I mentioned in my earlier posting on paus, really crazy over making paus these days.Â  Probably, discovered that it is not difficult so long as I don't expect the paus to be perfect/flawless in shape, texture and tastes.This time is steamed paus with yam fillings.Â  I managed to get very good quality yam to make the paste.Â  The yam paste is not too sweet, smooth and nice.Â  The pau skin texture isÂ  chewy, soft and fluffy.Â  Glad that I made these and can serve them for breakfast when I run short of bread.Shared some with my neighbour [a widower and a stroke patient], staying with a son but most times alone in the house.Â  Hope he enjoys them.Ingredients[makes 10 paus]250 gm pau flour1 tbsp wheat germ [or wheat bran]50 gm icing sugar1 tsp instant yeast1 tsp double action baking powder1/4 tsp white vinegar150 ml water20 gm shorteningIngredients For Filling200 gm yam puree60 gm sugar to taste [add more if you like the paste sweet]a pinch of salt1 tbsp coconut powder100 ml water1 tbsp butterFor Filling - cut yam into thin slices and steam until soft, then mash while still hot.Â  Mix mashed yam and all remaining ingredients [except sugar and butter] in a mixing bowl.Â  Sieve through a wire mash to get a smooth paste.Â  Stir paste in a non stick pan together with sugar andÂ  butter until the paste is thick and leaves the pan clean.Â  Cool and store in a container.Â  Chill in fridgeÂ  until required.For Skin - combine flour, baking powder, wheat germ, sugar, yeast and vinegar in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water to mix into a rough dough [may not need to use all the water].Â Add in shortening, continue to knead until dough is soft and smooth.Â  Shape into a round ball, leave in bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down, roll into a ball, then divide into 8, 10 or 12 equal portions according to own preference.Â  Shape each portion into a ball.Flatten each ball and wrap enough filling, seal the edges well into a pleated or round pau.Â  Place on a piece of parchment paper in a steaming tray [I used my electric steamer].Â  Finish making the rest.Cover and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Steaming over high heat for 10-12 minutes.Off heat, remove to cool on wire rack before storing or serve immediately.

title: STEAMED PAUS - PUMPKIN FILLINGS
text: Another easy to make and pliable pau skin dough recipe.Â  The dough is soft, smooth and pliable that is easy to pleat.Â  After steaming the pau skin is soft and fluffy.Â  The filling is smooth and not too sweet.Â  Lovely and nice home made paus.Â  Great, I could send some to my mum for her breakfast or afternoon snack.Â  She must be very happy.I have made the paus in 2 different shapes, just for fun, hehehe!Â  No worries, just do what you like according to you own creativity.Ingredients[makes 10 paus]250 gm pau flour1 tbsp chia seeds40 gm icing sugar1 tsp instant yeast1 tsp double action baking powder1/4 tsp white vinegar150 ml water20 gm shorteningIngredients For Filling200 gm pumpkin puree50 gm sugar1 tbsp butterFor Filling - steam cut pumpkin until soft, then mashed.Â  Mix mashed pumpkin and sugar in a mixing bowl.Â  Sieve through a wire mash to get a smooth paste.Â  Stir paste in a non stick pan together with butter until the paste is thick and leaves the pan clean.Â  Cool and store in a container.Â  Chill in fridgeÂ  until required.For Skin - combine flour, baking powder, chia seeds, sugar, yeast and vinegar in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water to mix into a rough dough [may not need to use all the water].Â Add in shortening, continue to knead until dough is soft and smooth.Â  Shape into a round ball, leave in bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down, roll into a ball, then divide into 8, 10 or 12 equal portions according to own preference.Â  Shape each portion into a ball.Flatten each ball and wrap enough filling, seal the edges well into a pleated or round pau.Â  Place on a piece of parchment paper in a steaming tray [I used my electric steamer].Â  Finish making the rest.Cover and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Steaming over high heat for 10-12 minutes.Off heat, remove to cool on wire rack before storing or serve immediately.

title: STEAMED PAUS - PURPLE SWEET POTATO FILLINGS
text: Realised that yummy paus need not have to look good.Â  I was at the temple for 9 days for vegetarian meals and they served various types of paus daily [hundreds of them], all made in their own kitchen by helpers, some who have never made paus before.Â  Yet, the paus turned out to be yummy eventhough they don't look perfect.Â  The size and shapes are not flawless but the skin is soft and fluffy.I told myself, should try their way, don't expect the paus to look flawless.Â  So long as the pau skin is soft and fluffy with any edible, tasty fillings, it should be awesome. The pau making craze came back and I have been using this pau skin dough recipe to make paus with various fillings from savoury to sweet [yambean dried prawns, peanuts/sesame, peanuts/sesame/meat floss/pumpkin/sweet potato etc].These are good, though the shapes do not look attractive.Â  The filling is not too sweet and the sweet potato flavour is noticeable.Â  I am happy with them.Â  The pictures do not look good either because I made these paus on a gloomy afternoon.Ingredients[makes 10 paus]250 gm pau flour1 tbsp wheat bran [optional]40 gm icing sugar2 tsp instant yeast120-150 ml water20 gm shorteningIngredients For Filling200 gm purple sweet potato - steamed/mashed50 gm sugar200 ml water1 tbsp butterFor Filling - mix mashed sweet potato, sugar and water in a mixing bowl.Â  Sieve through a wire mash to get a smooth paste.Â  Stir paste in a non stick pan together with butter until the paste is thick and leaves the pan clean.Â  Cool and store in a container.Â  Chill in fridgeÂ  until required.For Skin - combine flour, wheat bran, sugar, yeast in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water to mix into a rough dough [may not need to use all the water].Â  But I used more maybe because I added wheat bran.Add in shortening, continue to knead until dough is soft and smooth.Â  Shape into a round ball, leave in bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down, roll into a ball, then divide into 8, 10 or 12 equal portions according to own preference.Â  Shape each portion into a ball.Flatten each ball and wrap enough filling, seal the edges well into a pleated or round pau.Â  Place on a piece of parchment paper in a steaming tray [I used my electric steamer].Â  Finish making the rest.Cover and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Steaming over high heat for 10-12 minutes.Off heat, remove to cool on wire rack before storing or serve immediately.

title: FRIED TOFU WITH CHIVES
text: Glad that I tried this simple dish.Â  Just 2 ingredients and a simple dipping sauce, it is surprisingly satisfying dish.Â  I can eat lots of this alone.Recipe adapted from cook show on you-tube [a Chinese version]. I hope I got it right but if I am wrong, it is still alright because I did enjoy this dish.Â  If you love tofu and enjoy eating chives, do give this a try.Ingredients[serves 2]2 blocks tofu [best to get the traditional tofu] - cut into 1/2 inch thick slicesa bunch of chives - cut small bitssalt to taste50 ml boiling waterCut tofu, set aside.Cut chives, place is a serving bowl.Deep fry tofu pieces in batches until golden brown and edges are crispy.Â  Dish up on serving plate.Bring water to boil, pour over cut chives.Â  Add in salt to taste.To serve, dip fried tofu pieces in chives.

title: SWEET POTATOES WITH SAGO DESSERT
text: I learned a new way of preparing this sweet potato sago sweet dessert.Â  For this recipe the sago pearls are boiled to almost transparent before adding the sweet potatoes to cook.The dessert soup is smooth and the pearl sago are not visible especially with the purple sweet potatoes where the colour darkens the soup.Ingredients[makes 4-5 bowls]1 medium size orange sweet potato - peeled, cut chunky pieces1 medium size purple sweet potato - peeled, cut chunky pieces3 tbsp sago - rinsed and drained800 ml water60 gm jaggery sugar or brown sugarBring water to boil in a pot.Â  Stir in the sago.Â  Stir constantly to prevent sticking together.When sago is almost transparent, add in the sweet potatoes to cook.Bring to boil and simmer until sweet potatoes are soft.Â  Add in sugar to taste.Serve warm or hot.

title: STIR FRY OYSTER MUSHROOMS WITH LONG  BEANS
text: Eat more vege, drink more water, exercise often to stay healthy.Â  Yes, another point 'do not over stress'.Â  These are the very common spoken phrases that you often get to hear from friends when one complained about the 3 'highs' - blood pressure, blood glucose, cholesterol etc.Â  Â Some even tell you not to overeat, hehehe!It is easier said than done.
