Needs discipline.Â Â This a simple, tasty vegetarian dish which may help you to eat more vegetables and it's meatless.Â  Not too bad for a start with this dish.Ingredients100 gm long beans - washed and cut into sections50 gm carrots - sliced200 gm fresh oyster mushrooms - cut thick pieces3-4 dried mushrooms - soaked and slicedÂ some shredded ginger1 red chilli - seeded and cut stripsSome spring onions - cut sectionsSeasoning [combined]1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, oyster sauce and wine1/4 tsp pepper1/4 tsp salt to taste1 tsp sesame seed oil1 tsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp waterPan fry dried mushrooms and oyster mushrooms until aromatic.Â  Dish up.Heat up a non stick pan with 1/2 tbsp oil, fry long beans and carrots until long beans turn bright greenish colour.Â  Â  Dish up.Â Using the same pan, add a little oil, saute ginger until aromatic.Â  Returned all the fried ingredients into pan.Â  Stir to mix well.Add seasoning and some water.Â  Add more water if you like to have some gravy for this dish.Â  Bring to boil to cook the ingredients.Â  Add spring onions and stir in thickening.Dish up to serve.

title: YAMBEAN DRIED SHRIMP PAUS
text: I had this recipe book on 'Paus' by Coco Kong.Â  Have been selecting and trying them but seems its unending as there are over 30 pau recipes ranging from sweet to savoury tastes, vegetables to meat fillings etc. Can't remember how many I have tried to make.Â  Afraid that I may failed in my attempts when I first started, I tried the easy ones first.Â  So far, so good and there are some that I have repeated making them [peach longevity paus, butter custard paus, mui choy lotus paste paus etc] because they are good.Â Â ClickÂ hereÂ for the details.Having some yam bean in the kitchen and dried shrimps in my fridge, this time I tried this yambean dried shrimp paus.The pau skin is soft and fluffy.Â  Dough is easy to kneadÂ  and handle, pleating is notÂ  a problem.Â  The original recipe states that this portion can make 12 paus but I made only 9 because I want to make bigger ones to enjoy thicker pau skin.The filling is tasty with the dried shrimps but feel free to add some minced meat or black fungus if you like.Â  Just fry them together.Â  If you have leftover filling, you can eat it with rice, no problem since it is a vegetable.Recipe adapted from 'Paus' by Coco Kong with modifications.Ingredients250 gm pau flour40 gm icing sugar2 tsp instant yeast120-150 ml water20 gm shorteningIngredients For Yambean Filling300 gm yambean/sengkuang-peeled and shredded50 gm carrots - peeled and shredded2 tbsp dried shrimp - rinsed several times, drained1 piece soaked black fungus - shredded [optional]120 ml water1 tsp pepper1 tsp salt1 tsp msgFilling - Heat a non stick wok with some oil, saute dried prawns until fragrant, then add in the remaining ingredients and seasoning.Â  Stir fry well until yambeans are soft, sprinkle some cornstarch.Â  Mix well.Â  Dish up to cool.For Skin - combine flour, sugar, yeast in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually add in water to mix into a rough dough [may not need to use all the water].Add in shortening, continue to knead until dough is soft and smooth.Â  Shape into a round ball, leave in bowl, cover to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down, roll into a ball, then divide into 8, 10 or 12 equal portions according to own preference.Â  Shape each portion into a ball.Flatten each ball and wrap enough filling, seal the edges well into a pleated or round pau.Â  Place on a piece of parchment paper in a steaming tray [I used my electric steamer].Â  Finish making the rest.Cover and leave to proof for 30 minutes or until double in size.Steaming over high heat for 10-12 minutes.Off heat, remove to cool on wire rack before storing or serve immediately.

title: QUICK AND EASY BLACK PEPPER SAUCE RECIPE
text: My previous post is a recipe on how to prepare an Easy Oriental Sauce for chicken or pork chops.Â Â Here is another recipe on how to prepare an Easy Black Pepper Sauce for fried chicken or pork chops.Â There are many variations to this classic sauce that is simple and more close to home.Â  You know what you have added into the sauce compared to store bought ones.Â  You can make variations to adjust the spiciness, saltiness and sweetness of the sauce according to your preference.Ingredients4 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp light soya sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce [for colour]1 tsp sugar1 tsp chicken stock granules or 1/2 tsp msg1/2 tbsp ground black pepper1/2 tbsp ground white pepper100 ml water2 tsp cornstarch mixed with 2 tbsp waterMixed all the ingredients [except cornstarch water] in a non stick pan.Stir the mixture and bring to boil, simmer over medium low heat until sugar dissolves.Thicken the sauce with cornstarch mix.Serve with chicken or pork chops or cool sauce before storing in glass containers for later use.Â  Refrigerate if not using immediately.

title: EASY ORIENTAL SAUCE RECIPE
text: This is an Oriental Sauce for Chicken Chop that is easy for you to prepare ahead of meal time.Â  The sauce is suitable also for pork chops and also as a dipping sauce for fried firm beancurdÂ  with addition of some toasted sesame seeds or ground peanuts.This sauce comes in handy when you wish to fry meats but cannot decide what sauce to serve with it.There are many variations to this slightly sweet and sour sauce.Â  You can also add in some fresh red chillies for extra flavour, big onions, tomatoes and sliced cucumbers.Ingredients4 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp sweet chilli sauce1 tbsp A1 sauce1 tbsp Worcester sauce4 tbsp water1/2 tsp salt1 tsp sugarCombine all the ingredients in a non stick saucepan.Bring to boil for several, adjust seasoning to your preference.Off heat, serve with cooked chicken or pork chops or leave to cool before storing in glass container and chilli in fridge if not for immediate use.

title: SPROUT SALAD WITH SPICY PALM SUGAR DRESSING
text: A lovely beansprout salad.Â  Light, tasty and appetising salad with blanched beansprouts, crispy and crunchy anchovies/dried prawns, good with rice. If you like a tangy taste salad dressing, just add juices of 3 calamansi limes.This dressing is savoury, sweet, aromatic from the lemongrass and garlic.Â  The spiciness is from the chilli padi [you can reduce the portion which is what I did].Â Â For this dressing recipe, it goes well when roasted together with baby potatoes.Â  Brown sugar can be used instead of palm sugar. You can also toss in fried salted fish.Â  If you find it troublesome to fry the anchovies, you can use ready fried ones from the stalls.Ingredients[serves 2-3]200 gm beansprouts - tailed, washed and blanched lightly6 cherry tomatoes - cut half2 tbsp fried dried prawns2 tbsp crispy fried anchovies2 chilli padi - sliced4 pips garlic - chopped2 stalks lemongrass - finely slicedsome chopped coriander leavesDressing50 gm palm sugar + 50 ml water2-3 tbsp fish sauceJuices of 3 calamansi limes [optional]Dissolve palm sugar by boiling it with water, then add in fish sauce.Â  Boil to a syrupy consistency.Â  Set aside to cool.Blanch beansprouts lightly, drained in a colander.Toss beansprouts, tomatoes and chopped coriander in a bowl.Dressing - mix well chopped garlic, lemongrass and chilli padi with palm sugar syrup in a bowl.Drizzle over [3], add in fried anchovies and dried prawns.Â  Toss lightly and serve immediately.

title: EZCR#132-ANG CHOW FRENCH BEANS
text: ANG CHOW FRENCH BEANS aka [STIR FRY FRENCH BEANS WITH RED YEAST RICE RESIDUM].Â  If you are familiar with red yeast rice residum [ang chow in Hokkien dialect], you may like to try out this recipe for a change.Â This is a healthy, good dish.Â  Aromatic and tasty stir fry French beans. I have skipped the waterchestnuts but with it would be great as waterchestnuts is sweet and crunchy.You can cook this as a vegetarian dish by substituting the minced meat with dried gluten pieces and omit the chopped garlic.Â  I believe it would be a great vegetarian dish.Ingredients[serves 2-3]200 gm French beans - cut 1 cm sections30 gm carrots - cut small cubes50 gm minced meat1/2 tbsp each of chopped ginger and garlic2-3 water chestnuts - peeled and diced [omit]100 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp red yeast rice residumÂ 1 tbsp cooking wine1/4 tsp saltdash of msgMarinate the minced meat with some salt and pepper.Heat a non stick wok, saute chopped garlic and ginger until fragrant.Â  Add in minced meat.Â  Stir until firm.Add in carrots and ang chow.Â  Stir fry to mix the ingredients well.Â  Add in seasoning and water.Â  Bring to boil.Add in French beans, cover to cook for 1-2 minutes or until beans turn bright greenish in colour.Remove cover, stir to mix well.Â  Cook until water is almost dry, drizzle in some sesame seed oil.Dish up to serve.

title: BRAISED TAUPAU WITH TOMATOES AND MUSHROOMS
text: I planned to prepare this vegetarian dish when I was on vegetarian diet in September.Â  There were so many recipes to try butÂ just couldn't find the time.Â  Anyway, it is nothing wrong to add some meatless dishes in our daily meals often.This recipe is quite similar to the earlier dishÂ [here] I prepared but with addition of mushrooms and the fresh beancurd pieces [taupau] are seasoned with some oyster sauce and black pepper before frying.Another tasty, appetising and delicious vegetarian dish to try if you like meatless dishes.Â  Savoury, sweet and sourish dish.Great with steaming hot rice.Ingredients6 pieces fresh beancurd sheet [tau pau] - pan fried1 tomato - diced2 Ernygii mushrooms - dicedsome chopped gingerenough water to cover ingredientsSeasoning [combined]1-2 tbspÂ tomato sauce1/2 tsp sugar1 tbsp black vinegarsaltÂ to tasteOpen up the fresh beancurd pieces.Â  Spread some oyster sauce over it.Â  Sprinkle some black pepper.Â  Fold and lightly coat with cornflour.Pan fry them in a non stick wok with oil over medium low heat until slightly brown.Â  Remove.Using the same wok without oil, fry mushrooms until aromatic before adding tomatoes, seasoning and water. Bring to boil, add in the fried tau pau.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Braise until sauce is thick. Before dishing, add in chopped ginger.Â Â Mix well. Dish up to serve.

title: A SIMPLE BUTTER CAKE
text: As the name implies, it is really a simple butter cake.Â  It has been quite a while that I have not been baking butter cakes.Â  The thought that it is buttery and sweet does put me off baking butter cakes as I am 'afraid' my hubby will eat too much of it.Â  He can't stop with a few slices in one go but will continuing eating them for days until all are finished.Â  That goes the same when I baked buns.Â  One option is to share some with neighbours or relatives, hehehe!.This butter cake is buttery, has a lovely aroma of butter but not overly sweet as you would probably noticed the amount of sugar used.Â  Perhaps, it can be reduced.Â  It is soft and moist.Â  In the original recipe, it is baked in a 7 inch square tray for 25 minutes at 175 degrees Celsius, then for 25 minutes at 160 degrees Celsius or until golden brown.Here, I simply baked them in a non stick cake tray with 3 different designs.Â  The baking time is shorter.Recipe adapted fromÂ Â MiMi Bakery HouseÂ [modified]Ingredients250 gm good quality butter140 gm caster sugar4 eggs [60 gm each]2 tsp vanilla essence200 gm all purpose flour1 tsp baking powder1. Cream the butter in a mixing bowl for 1-2 minutes before adding sugar.Â  Continue to beat till creamy and light.2. Add in the eggs, one at a time.Â  Beating well after each addition.Â  Add in vanilla, continue to beat until well combined.3.Â Add in sifted flour in a few additions, mix well over low speed until well blended.4. Scoop batter into a greased baking tray until 80% full.5. Baked in preheated oven at 175 degrees C for 25 minutes, then continue to bake at 160 degrees C for 25-30 minutes or until golden brown and cooked through.6. Remove from oven to cool on wire rack before unmoulding.7.Â  Sliced to serve.Â Note: If baking in 7 inch tray, please follow original recipe "Pour the batter into a 7 inch lined square cake pan and bake in a preheated oven of 175Â°C for about 25 minutes and lower to 160Â°C for another 25~30 minutes.Â Remove the cake pan from the oven and let the cake cool in the pan for about 20 minutes before removing it to cool completely on a wire rack. Slice and serve".

title: FRIED RICE VERMICELLI [MEEHOON]
text: Weekend light meals.Â  A simple stir fry rice vermicelli [meehoon] that is easy to prepare and if you feel a fried meehoon is insufficient for your family or yourself, feel free toÂ  pre-cooked a sweet potato soup, red bean soup or green beans soup etc in a slow cooker.Â Â Red Beans SoupÂ [recipe here]A savoury meehoon and a sweet dessert is just perfect to enjoy in the comfort of our cozy home, instead of bringing the whole family out for a light meal.Â  Don't forget the weather is unpredictable these days [rainy or humid weather].This fried meehoon tastes good just with these seasoning.Â  You can marinate the pork shreds with a pinch of salt, pepper and 1/2 teaspoon of cornflour for added flavour.Awesome.Ingredients[serves 2-3]120 dried meehoon-soaked for 10 minutes, drained in colander3-4 dried mushrooms-soaked and cut shreds50 gm shredded lean pork or pork belly1 egg - lightly beaten with a pinch of saltÂ 1/2 capsicum - seeded and sliced2-3 shallots and 2 pips garlic - peeled and chopped200 ml watersome cut red chillies and spring onions for garnishingSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1/4 tsp msgdash of pepperHeat a non stick wok with 1/2 tbsp oil, pour in beaten egg to make an omelette like a flat pancake. Remove, cool and cut shreds. Set aside.Using the same wok, add in 1/2 tbsp oil to fry mushrooms and meat shreds until oil oozes out.Â  Add in chopped shallots and garlic to fry until aromatic.Add in carrots and seasoning, mix well before adding water.Â  Bring to boil, tastes to adjust seasoning before adding meehoon.Â  Toss well,Â  spread capsicum on top.Â  Cover to cook for 1-2 minutes.Remove cover, toss noodles well and fry until water is almost dry.Mix in omelette.Dish up to serve.Â  Garnish with chillies and spring onions.Green beans Sweet Potato SoupÂ [here]

title: BRAISED SOY CHICKEN WITH MUSHROOMS
text: Another simple One Dish prepared with an assortment of ingredients that is good to serve with rice for a complete meal.There are mushrooms, carrots, capsicum, black fungus, white cabbage and chicken.Â  The seasoning is very basic with light soy sauce, cooking wine and chicken stock granules [can substitute with msg or sugar] and sesame seed oil. You can substitute white cabbage leaves with celery or snow peas.Ingredients[serves 2]6 dried mushrooms - soaked, keep whole3 pieces Ernygii mushrooms - cut wedges1 piece black fungus - break into pieces30 gm carrots - sliced100 gm white cabbage - cut3-4 pips garlic - peeled and keep whole4 pieces chicken tender - cut bite size pieces100 ml waterSeasoning2-3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp cooking wine1 tbsp sesame seed oil1 tsp chicken stock granules or sugarMarinate chicken pieces with some salt, pepper, oil and cornstarch.Â  Set aside.Stir fry mushrooms without oil in a non stick wok until aromatic.Â  Add in a tablespoon of oil and garlic.Â  Stir until fragrant before adding black fungus and carrots.Add in chicken pieces, fry until lightly brown, then add in seasoning.Stir to fry until chicken pieces are firm.Â  Add in cabbage, then water, bring to boil until chicken is cooked through.Lastly stir in capsicum.Â  Dish up to serve or scoop over a plate of rice.Â  Enjoy with some sambal belacan or cut chillies.

title: BRAISED ERNYGII MUSHROOMS [SAO SIN PAO KU]
text: This is a vegetarian mushroom dish that can be pre-cooked and stored, refrigerated for later use.Â  It can be served as it is or use to stir fry with some green vegetables like broccoli, celery, bok choy etc.It is savoury with a gingery flavour and aroma of sesame seed oil.Â  If you prefer a savoury, sourish and sweet taste, add a little vinegar and sugar.Ingredients1 packet Ernygii mushrooms - cut rounds and make slitssome chopped ginger1 tbsp sesame oil150 ml water or enough to cover mushroomsSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp dark soy sauce for colourdash of pepper1 tbsp vinegar [optional]1/2 tsp sugar [optional]Saute chopped ginger until aromatic with some oil,Â  add in mushrooms.Â  Stir fry both ingredients until aromatic.Add in seasoning, stir to mix before adding water to braise.Bring to boil until mushrooms are cooked and sauce reduced.Dish up into a container.Â  If not using, refrigerate [freezed] until required.

title: VEGETARIAN CHAR SIEW
text: To Make Vegetarian Char Siew from the homemade gluten [recipe here], please refer to my post onÂ Mock Char Siew

title: MAKING FRESH GLUTEN
text: Shape dough into preferred shapes and boil till cooked.Â  Dough will floats up when cookedRecently, I was trying to get some ready made fresh gluten from the stores to prepare some vegetarian dishes.Â  But most of the stores at the wet markets which I frequent aren't selling it anymore.I googled for the recipe and came across a recipe shared on You-tube by Good Living Recipe [Making Of Fresh Gluten] where the steps were easy to follow.Â  Without delay, I went ahead to try and it works out well.Â Â If you are interested to make fresh gluten, you can refer to the above.Â  The fresh gluten which I made was used to make Vegetarian Char Siew [here].Â  Awesome.Dough After Adding 250 ml WaterDough After Adding 500 ml waterDough After Adding 750 ml WaterKnead Lightly Into A Soft DoughPour in Water to soak Dough for 30 minutesWash dough with several changes of water until the water looks like washing of riceÂ Pour washed dough into a colander to drain away the waterWash Dough looks like torn clothSoak washed dough in water for another 20 minutesThe dough will look smooth, elastic and stretchable

title: MIXED VEGETABLES DELIGHT
text: A colourful dish like this, packed with nutrients must appear often on our dinner table.Â Â The fried tofu puff pieces is available at our local Tesco store or you can get those available in the wet market.You can increase the portion if serving this as a One Dish Meal with rice.Â  A great vegetarian Lam Rice dish.Â  A nice platter of colourful ingredients that is tasty with rice.Ingredients100 gm broccoli - cut into florets50 gm carrots - peeled and cut into any shapes preferredA handful of black fungus - soaked to plump up, break into small pieces3 dried mushrooms - soaked and halved70 gm tofu puffs - rinseda few slices of ginger100 ml water1 tbsp cooking wineSeasoning [combined]1 tbsp each light soy sauce, vegetarian oyster sauce, cooking wine1 tsp sesame oil1/2 tsp mushroom stock granules to tastedash of pepper50 ml water +Â 1 tbsp cornstarchSaute ginger slices with oil until aromatic.Â  Add in the mushrooms, carrots, black fungus and tofu puff.Stir fry to mix well, add in water.Â  Bring to boil until ingredients are cooked.Â  Add in seasoning ingredients.Add in broccoli, stir fry to mix well.Thicken with cornstarch water, bring to boil and dish up to serve.

title: FRAGRANT ERNGYII MUSHROOM SALAD
text: A surprisingly good, appetising salad which is not difficult to prepare.Â  As the name implies, it is a fragrant salad.Â  The fragrance comes from the addition of lemongrass.Here, the lemongrass are finely chopped.Â  The originalÂ  recipe uses blending method to combine the salad dressing.Â  My hubby says both ways, it is alright.I wouldn't mind preparing this often.Â  Awesome and a healthyÂ  vegetarian salad.Ingredients1 packet Erngyii mushrooms - rinsed/drained4 Lady's fingersÂ some chopped red chillies2 lemongrass [white part only] - finely choppedDressing [Combined]3 tbsp lemon juice or lime juice or calamansi juice3 tsp sugar1/2 tsp saltCut mushrooms lengthwise into half.Â  Make slits on one side.Blanched lady's fingers till cooked.Â  Drained before cutting into 1 cm wide pieces.Â  Set aside.Heat a non stick pan with some oil, pan fry the mushrooms until slight brown on both sides.Â  Cover the pan while frying to ensure mushrooms are cooked.Â  When cooked the mushrooms are aromatic.Meanwhile, combine the dressing ingredients, add in the lemongrass.Â  Set aside.Dish up, cutÂ  each piece into bite size pieces.Mix mushrooms, lady's fingers and chillies together.Drizzle in dressing, toss well and serve immediately.

title: STIR CABBAGE WITH TAU PAU
text: 'Best not to add water when frying vegetables'.Â  This is the tip shared by the chef of this recipe in a TV cook show which I viewed lately.Â  Vegetables cook very fast from 5 to 10 minutes.Â  Stir frying the vegetables over medium heat brings out its natural sweetness.This dish is simple, easy and a quick stir fry.Â  The cabbage is tender but still crunchy and sweet.Â  Seasoned with salt and wine with mushroom granules makes his vegetable dish awesome, healthy too.Ingredients250 gm cabbage - cut thick shreds [0.5 cm wide]30 gm carrot - cut strips1 small piece wood ear fungus - soaked and cut strips2 pieces fried tau pau - cut stripsÂ some chopped gingersome Chinese celery for garnishing2 tbsp cooking oilSeasoning1 tsp salt1/4 tsp vegetarian mushroom granules1 tsp cooking winedash of sesame seed oilBlanched carrot and wood ear fungus for a few seconds.Â  Drained.Â  Soak in cold water, drained.In a non stick pan, add oil, ginger and tau pau strips.Â  Stir fry to mix until aromatic.Â  Add in cabbage, stir fry for 3-5 minutes together with the seasoning.Â Lastly add in blanched carrots and black fungus.Continue to fry over medium heat for a few seconds.Dish up.Â  Garnish with Chinese celery [kin chye].

title: BRAISED SWEET SOUR TAU PAU WITH TOMATOES
text: A very simple dish with fresh beancurd sheets [tau pau], tomatoes and sweet sourish seasoning.This dish is tasty and appetising with rice.Â  The basic bland taste tau pau pieces are full of flavours after absorbing the sauce through braising.Â  Â It is suitable for the young and old.Simple and great dish to prepare for your family.Â Â Ingredients5 pieces fresh beancurd sheet [tau pau] - fried and cutÂ bite size pieces2-3 tomatoes - cut wedgessome chopped gingerenough water to cover ingredientsSeasoning [combined]2-3 tbspÂ tomato sauce1 tbsp sugar1 tbsp vinegar1 tbspÂ light soy sauce to tasteDrizzle some sesame seed oil over tau pau pieces. Pan fry them in a non stick wok with oil over medium low heat until slightly brown.Â  Remove and cut.Using the same wok without oil, add in tomatoes and seasoning and water. Bring to boil, add in the fried tau pau.Braise until sauce is thick. Before dishing, add in chopped ginger.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Â Mix well. Dish up to serve.

title: BRAISED FRAGRANT BEANCURD [å¤ è±†å¹²]
text: Time flies, again is time for my compulsory annual vegetarian food diet this year which began on 9 October.Â  Vegetarian food cooking is at times so simple yet the food is tasty and delicious.Â  Rather difficult to understand but it is acceptable however simple it could be.Just like today's lunch, I came across a vegetarian dish 'Stir Fry Sweet and Sour Potatoes'.Â  The basic ingredients are potatoes and I think the seasoning is a combination of tomato sauce, vinegar, sugar and salt.Â  Yet, it tasted so good and appetising.Â  I must check it out and try preparing it at home.Back to this dish, quite a popular one among Chinese chefs who specialise in vegetarian cuisine.Â  There are various versions and cooking methods from braising to stir fry and stewing.The beancurd pieces are tasty and aromatic, braised with the spices and aromatics.Â  The tastes could be too sweet for some but acceptable to others. You can fine tune to suit your own preference.Ingredients4 pieces firm beancurd - cut each into 9 cubes1 tbsp sesame oil2 cups waterBraising Ingredients3 cinnamon sticks2 star anisea few slices ginger2-3 pieces liquorice [ç”˜è‰]1 tsp 5 spice powder1/2 tbsp preserved soybean paste2-3 dried chillies80 ml light soy sauce40 gm rock sugarBring some water to boil.Â  Blanch beancurd cubes for 5-10 minutes.Â  Drained.Bring braising ingredients to boil in a pot, add in blanched beancurd cubes.Continue to braise over medium low heat, stirring occasionally while braising until water is reduced.Turn to medium heat and stir fry until sauce is reduced to thick and coats the beancurd cubes.Dish up to serve.

title: MIXED VEGETARIAN CURRY
text: Cook as you like is how I described this curry dish.Â  You can mix or combine whatever ingredients you think are suitable for a vegetarian curry.Â  This is my 'agak-agak' recipe but it tastes as good as some recipes which you follow to the T.The thick curry comes with coconut milk and the slight sourish taste comes from the tamarind slices [you can substitute it with tamarind juice].Â  You can increase the liquid if you prefer it to be of runny consistency.Ingredients2 medium size potatoes - peeled and cut wedges - parboiled to tender1 piece tempeh - cut into small rectangles - fried100 gm taufu puffs - halved5-6 lady's fingers - blanched and cut halvedÂ 1 tomato - quartered2 sprigs curry leaves2 pieces tamarind slices [assan gelugor]100 ml thick coconut milk50 ml cooking oil2 cups waterCurry Paste50 gm chilli boh30 gm blended lemongrass1 tsp tumeric powder1 tsp grated ginger1 tbsp meat curry powder1/2 tbsp vegetarian mushroom granules [optional]Seasoningsalt and sugar to tasteBoil potatoes until tender.Â  DrainedBoil lady's fingers until cooked [bright greenish colour], drained and cut half.Heat some oil in a non stick pan, fry tempeh until golden brown.Â  Dish up.Using the same pan, add in oil.Â  Saute curry paste, tamarind slices, curry leaves with 1 tsp salt and sugar until oil separates.Â  Add in half the coconut milk and some water, then the boiled potatoes and tomatoes.Â  Bring to boil until potatoes are soft.Add in taufu puffs, boil for a few minutes before adding the tempeh, lady's fingers and remaining coconut milk.Â  Stir to mix well.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Dish up to serve.

title: STEAMED MINI MA LAI KOH
text: If you love Ma Lai Koh but do not have a bamboo tray to steam a whole cake, perhaps, you can try this recipe.Â  Â You can steam the batter in plastic cups [the type used by some kuih vendors to steam huat kuihs].Â  Though there is no honeycomb texture in these mini cakes, they are delicious, too.Â  The texture is spongy soft, not too sweet and easy to prepare.These Ma Lai Koh should be great for tea time treats or potluck gatherings. Stay soft and spongy for 2-3 days.In the original recipe, the batter is steamed in a loaf pan.Recipe adapted fromÂ Coaster KitchenÂ Ma Lai Gao recipe [modified]Ingredients[makes 14 mini cakes]Starter Dough100 gm cake flour1/2 tsp instant yeast1/2 tsp sugar100 ml waterMix the dry ingredients together in a small bowl.Â  Add in water, mix well into a soft dough.Cover with cling wrap and set aside to rest for more than 1 hour or double in size.Other Ingredients2 large eggs100 gm dark brown sugar20 gm cake flour20 gm custard powder1/4 tsp baking soda25 ml melted butterBeat eggs with sugar.Â  Whisk until sugar dissolves and well incorporated.Sift in cake flour, custard powder and baking soda.Â  Mix well and stir in melted butter until well blended.Strain the egg mixture into starter dough.Â  Mix well into a smooth runny batter.Bring water in steamer to boil.Â  Arrange plastic cups in steaming tray. Pour in batter until 80% full.Â  Place over boiling water.Â  Cover tray with aluminium foil [lightly].Steam for 30-35 minutes or until cake is ready.Remove to cool on wire rack for 10-15 minutes before removing from cups.

title: CARAMEL KAYA
text: Lately, have been really busy with many activities and chores to attend.Â  Home-made preserves [fruit jam] depleting soonÂ  and there is the urgent need to get ready some for our daily breakfast.Â  It came to my mind that making caramel kaya would be a good alternative as it is quick to prepare.Remembered that I have downloaded theÂ recipeÂ to try sometime ago.Â  It is always good to download some recipes whenever I have the time and it will come in handy for immediate retrieval during busy days.This caramel kaya is easy to prepare with only a few ingredients, simple steps and yet the result is awesome.Â  It can be kept in the fridge and stays spreadable even chilled.Recipe adapted fromÂ  Kathrine Kwa You-tube RecipeIngredients5 size B eggs200 gm + 50 gm castor sugar250 ml thick coconut milk3 blades screwpine [pandan] leaves - knottedBeat eggs lightly with 200 gm sugar until sugar dissolves.Place 50 gm castor sugar in a heavy base pan.Â  Heat over medium heat to dissolve the sugar until caramelised, stir ocassionally but careful not to burnt it.Â Â Off heat, gradually pour in coconut milk, stirring while pouring in.Â  Turn to low heat and stir until the caramelised sugar dissolves but not boiling.Remove from heat, gradually stir in the egg mixture.Â  Strain into a heavy base pan or wok [I used my Thai copper wok].Add in pandan leaves, cook over medium low heat and stir constantly until kaya is of runny consistency.Â  Note: If using kaya as filling, best to cook until thick paste consistency for easy wrapping.Cool, remove pandan leaves and store in air tight container.

title: DARK BROWN SUGAR MA LAI KOH (WITH YEAST)
text: Has been a long while since I last prepared Ma Lai Koh.Â  But when I came across this recipeÂ here, with all the ingredients in hand, there is nothing to stop me from making it right away, hehehe!Anyway, no regrets preparing this Ma Lai Koh. My hubby and mum said it is 'good'.Â  The cake is soft and spongy especially with the 'honeycomb' look.Â  This recipe is a keeper.Recipe adapted fromÂ My Kitchen 101 EnIngredients3 large eggs160 gm evaporated milk3 tbsp pandan juice [or plain water]180 gm plain flour190 gm dark brown sugar1 tsp instant yeast1/4 tsp fine salt1 tsp baking soda/sodium bicarbonate1 tsp baking powder50 gm corn oilLine 7 inch bamboo steamer with parchment paper.Beat eggs lightly, add in evaporated milk and water or pandan juice.Â  Mix until combined.Place plain flour, dark brown sugar, instant yeast and fine salt in a mixing bowl, mix until combined.Add in egg mixture gradually into dry ingredients until a batter is formed.Â  Sieve mixtureÂ  through to have a smooth batter.Cover the mixing bowl, set aside to proof forÂ  2 hours at room temperature.Â  The mixture will look bubbly/foamy after proofing for 2 hours.Bring enough water to boil in a large steamer.TransferÂ  3-4 tablespoons of the proofed batter into a small bowl, sieve in baking soda and baking powder and mix well.Â  Â Lastly, stir in the corn oil until well combined.Add mixture to the remaining batter, mix until well blended.Pour batter into lined bamboo steamer and steam over medium-high heat for 40 minutes.Â  [Note: Do Not Open the steamer before 30 minutes or the cake might collapse].Remove cake, unmould and cool on wire rack before slicing to serve.

title: MINI CHEESY SHANGHAI MOONCAKES [ä¸Šæµ·æœˆé¥¼]
text: This is a workable Shanghai Mooncake recipe which is great if you are celebrating Mooncake Festival with a big group of friends.Â  The size is the same as that of Tambun Biscuits [Mungbean Pastry Biscuits], so serving it as a whole is just perfect.The pastry is buttery, cheesy and savoury, while the lotus paste filling is not too sweet.Â  The taste of both the pastry and filling is perfect.Â  Crispy just after baking.Â  Cute little mooncakes.Ingredients[makes 36 small size mooncakes]180 gm butter [room temperature]60 gm castor sugara pinch of salt3 tbsp milk3 tbsp cheese powder270 gm plain flour1-2 tbsp cornflour300 gm lotus paste for mooncake or other filling of your choice mix with 25 gm toasted melon seedsEgg wash -1 egg yolk +1 tbsp waterSome toasted black and white sesame seeds for toppingCream butter and sugar until light, add in milk and continue to beat until creamy.Gradually fold in the flour mixture to form a soft dough [like cookie dough].Place dough in a clean plastic bag and chill in the fridge for 1/2 an hour.Meanwhile, mix filling and divide into small portion of about 1 teaspoon.Â  Roll into balls, place on a plate and chill before use.Remove dough from fridge. Divide into small portions [about 1 level tablespoon].Â  Shape into round, flatten and wrap filling.Â  Seal the edges well and roll into a balls.Â  Flour your hands if dough is sticky.Place on a lined baking tray with some space in between.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 10 minutes, remove from oven, leave to cool a little before brushing egg wash.Â  Sprinkle some sesame seeds.Return to bake in oven for another 15-20 minutes or until golden brown.Remove and leave to cool on wire rack before storing in air-tight container.

title: EZ CHAR HOR FUN
text: Fried Flat Rice Noodles [Cantonese style Char Hor Fun] seems to be quite a tedious noodle dish to prepare in the home kitchen. Usually, you need the 'wok hei' to make this fried koay teow tasty and delicious.Not to worry anymore about the 'wok hei'.Â  You can try this recipe which is easy, though without the necessary 'wok hei', it turned out tasty and delicious and no smoky or greasy kitchen after preparing this noodle dish.Serve with cut chillies or sambal belacan, it is awesome.Recipe adapted from Ajinomoto Recipes [slightly modified] using Tumix Chicken stock seasoningIngredients[serves 2-3]400 gm flat rice noodles [hor fun] - cut chunky pieces1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tbsp cooking oil2 tbsp cornstarch mix with 2 tbsp water1 eggIngredients A700 ml water1/2 tbsp chopped garlic2-3 tbsp Tumix Chicken Stock seasoning*1/2 tsp sugarsalt to tasteIngredients B100 gm pork or chicken slices8-9 medium size prawns40 gm carrots - sliced2-3 stalks chye sim or bok choy or kailan - cutHeat a non stick wok with oil, put in flat noodles.Â  Separate out in a thin layer [do not stir until slight firm], drizzle in dark soy sauce.Â  Lightly stir fry the noodles until the edges are slightly crispy and charred.Â  Dish up and place on individual plates.Using the same wok, add water, bring to bowl.Â  Add in the meat, prawns, carrot and vegetables to cook.Â  Add seasoning.Â  Dish up the boiled ingredients [without the soup] and place over fried noodles.Thicken soup with cornstarch water, bring to boil.Â  Off heat, stir in the lightly beaten egg.Scoop egg gravy over noodles, serve with cut chillies or sambal belacan.Note: * can substitute the Tumix seasoning if you do not have it by 1/2 teaspoon each Ajinomoto, 1/2 tsp sugar and salt to taste, 1/4 tsp pepper

title: EZCR#130 - KOCHA FLAVOUR EU P'NG [STEAMED GLUTINOUS RICE]
text: Love glutinous rice dish like rice dumplings [bak chang], nasi kunyit, lor mai gai or any savoury glutinous rice dishes?Â  This steamed savoury glutinous rice is just perfect to whet your appetite.Â  Moreover, you can cook in a small portion like in this recipe.Â  It is also quick to prepare compared to those I mentioned above.A fragrant and tasty glutinous rice dish, not too greasy and of course, a traditional Chinese rice dish.This Eu P'ng [in Chinese] can be eaten warm or at room temperature.Â  Tastes good with some sweet chilli sauce.Ingredients1 cup glutinous rice - washed, rinsed and soaked overnight or at least 4 hours, then drainedOther Ingredients2 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips1 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed a few times and drained100 gm pork belly or shoulder meat - cut thin stripsa few slices ginger2-3 tbsp shallot crisps2 tsp sesame seed oilSeasoning3 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp wine1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp sugar1 tsp pepper to tastedash of msgPlace rice in a steaming tray, sprinkle some water. Steamed rice in steamer for 30 minutes or until rice is cooked and soft.Â  Keep warm in steamer until required.Heat a non stick pan with sesame oil, saute ginger slices until aromatic.Â  Add in mushrooms, meat and dried prawns.Â  Continue frying until ingredients are cooked and aromatic.Â Â Add in the seasoning, stir to mix well, add a little water if necessary.Pour seasoning over steamed rice, add shallot crisps and stir to mix evenly.Â  Scoop rice into small bowls and invert onto serving plate to serve or in a large bowl.Serve.

title: STIR FRY CABBAGE SPECIAL
text: This can be a One Dish Meal dish as it has the combination of meat with vegetables and the taste is awesome especially if you love spicy dried chillies.Â  The meat slices are tasty, delicious and blends so well with the crunchy sweet cabbages pieces.Â  It is an appetising dish with rice.Â  You would enjoy chewing at the meat, cabbage leaves, even the dried chilli pieces tastes good and full of 'oomph!'Ingredients[serves 2]200 gm cabbage leaves - washed and break into small pieces30 gm carrots - cut thin slicesa handful of black fungus [bok nee] - soaked and drained3-4 slices of streaky pork belly - cut into sections3-4 dried chillies - soaked and cut small sectionssome chopped ginger and garlic1 star anisea small bunch of glass noodles - soaked and cut sections1 stalk spring onions - cut sectionsSeasoning [combined]1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, oyster sauce and cooking wineDash of pepper, salt and msg to taste1 tsp sesame seed oilSeason streaky pork pieces with some pepper and salt.Heat some oil in a non stick wok, stir fry cabbage and carrots over high heat until the vegetables are limp but still crunchy.Â  Dish up.Using the same wok, add sesame seed oil, fry meat slices until firm, add in dried chillies, ginger, garlic, some spring onions and star anise.Â  Continue to fry until aromatic, pour in the sauce.Â  Add some water, bring to a rolling boil.Add in black fungus and fried vegetables.Â  Stir to mix well. Add in glass noodles and spring onions, cook for a few seconds.Dish up to serve over a plate of rice.

title: KONG PAO STYLE FRIED TAUFU
text: 'Kong Pao' sauce is a fragrant sauce that goes well with various fried foods like prawns, fish and chicken to name a few.Â  There are also various recipes for 'Kong Pao' sauce in Szechuan cuisine but I find this one the simplest though, I think it may not be authentic.Â  Nevertheless, if you are looking for a spicy, savoury, sourish and sweet sauce for any stir fry fried food, this one is easy yet delicious.I have tried it with fried prawns, chicken and fish fillets but this time, I am using the sauce for fried taufu pieces.Â  This makes the bland taufu pieces just as appetising.Ingredients For Kong Pao Sauce5-6 dried chillies [more if you can stand the spiciness] - soaked, rinsed and cut into sections8 slices of ginger3 pips garlic - sliced1 large onion - cut wedges or thick slices1 stalk spring onions - cut sections1 small tomato - cut wedges [optional]Seasoning [combined]2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp chilli sauce1 tsp black vinegar1 tsp sugar1 tsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp water [mix for thickening]Other Ingredient2 blocks of taufu - cut into square slicesHeat oil in a non stick pan over high heat, fry taufu slices in batches until golden brown.Â  Dish up.Remove excess oil.Â  Using the same pan, saute dried chillies, ginger and garlic until fragrant.Â  Add in onions and tomatoes.Â  Stir to mix well.Pour in the seasoning ingredients and fried taufu slices.Â  Mix lightly and bring to boil.Â  Thickened with cornstarch water.Â  Lastly, throw in the spring onions.Mix and dish up to serve.

title: STEAMED STUFFED BRINJALS
text: Came across this lovely steamed brinjal dish on You-tube.Â  I love the sweetness of brinjals but never like the greasiness of fried brinjals.These steamed brinjals stuffed with the tasty minced meat and simple sauce is great.Â  Moreover, it is not difficult to prepare at all.Â  You can stuffed the brinjals in advance and just need to steam them for 15-20 minutes before serving them.Â  No greasy kitchen and or sweating in the kitchen.Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 medium size brinjal -Â  cut 3 cm thick pieces1 tbsp chopped garlicsome chopped red chilliSauce Ingredients [combined]1 tsp oyster sauce1 tsp light soy saucedash of msg and pepper1 tsp cornstarch and 3 tbsp watersome chopped spring onions or coriander leavesMinced Meat Filling [mixed well]300 gm minced meat with some fats1-2 tsp light soy sauce1 tsp chicken stock granulesdash of sugar, pepper and sesame seed oil1 tbsp cornstarchMake 4 slits [without cutting through to the base] on each section of the brinjals.Mix filling ingredients well and set aside.Stuff the brinjal pieces with the minced meat place and place on a steaming plate.Steam over high heat for 15-20 minutes.Â  There may be some water released from the steamed brinjals. You may discard the water.Â  Sprinkle chopped spring onions over the steamed brinjal.Meanwhile, put some oil in a pan, saute garlic and red chilli until aromatic, pour in the mixed sauce.Â  Stir well until thick consistency.Pour over steamed brinjals, serve.

title: PAN FRIED SWEET SAUCE CHICKEN
text: Delicious, yummy pan fried and braised chicken whole legs.Â  Another method is by baking if you are preparing a bigger portion.Â  Â Since my non stick wok is big enough for 3 pieces chicken whole leg, I opted to pan fry and braise.Â  Much easier as I do not have to bake and baste with the sauce several times throughÂ  baking.These yummy succulent chicken whole legs are not overly sweet or savoury.Â  Just nice to serve with mashed potatoes and some coleslawÂ [recipe here].Recipe adapted from Y Tower Gourment FoodIngredients[serves 3]3 pieces chicken whole legs - fats removed but skin intactMarinade1 tsp each of grated garlic and black pepper powder2 tsp each of sugar and cooking wine1/4 tsp saltSauce Ingredients [Combined]2 tbsp honey2-3 tbsp orange juice3 tbsp tomato sauce1 tsp each grated garlic and ginger1 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp saltMake a few slits on the meat side of the chicken whole leg.Â  Marinate them with marinade.Â  Mix well and leave in fridge for an hour.Grease a non stick wok with oil, pan fry the chicken pieces [skin side first] until brown or nicely coloured.Â  Â Flip over to fry the meat side.Â  Cover to ensure even cooking.Pour sauce over chicken pieces. Make sure the meat is well coated with the sauce.Â  Add 50-100 ml water.Â  Â Leave to braise for 1-2 minutes.Â Â Flip over, cover and continue to cook until meat is tender and sauce is reduced to thick consistency [takes about 20 minutes].Â  Can add more water if chicken is not tender.Dish up to serve with rice or boiled potatoes and salad.

title: TASTY SAVOURY PANCAKES
text: This savoury pancake recipe is from Amy Beh.Â  It was published many, many years ago in the newspapers and I had kept the cutting since then.Â  Â I love savoury pancakes more than the sweet ones.Â These pancakes can be served as a light lunch and it is tasty and delicious.Â  It is crispy at the edges but soft, chewy and moist.Â Though, I have been preparing this pancake for many times but have yet to share them here.Â  Anyway, I am sharing the recipe of Amy Beh here with some adjustments to the portion.Â  It is a versatile recipe where you can mix and matchÂ or substitute someÂ the ingredients lest at times you may not have all the ingredients in hand.Â  Most important is the seasoning.Â This portion is enough to make 4 pieces pancakes [16 cm diameter].Ingredients[serves 3-4]80 gm French beans - finely sliced60 gm carrot - finely chopped80 gm fresh sweet corn kernels [omit, add chopped prawns]200 gm self-raising flour300-350 ml UHT milk2 eggs2 tbsp melted butter or corn oilSeasoning1 tsp each of salt and pepper2 tsp chicken stock granules or dash of msgSift flour in a bowl or container, pour in milk.Â  Beat in the eggs and add melted butter or corn oil.Â  Mix.Add in the remaining ingredients and seasoning.Mix into a thick batter.Â  Divide into 4 equal portions [can make smaller pancakes using any size ladle you have].Â Lightly greased a non stick pan with oil.Â  Pour in one portion, cover to cook for 1-2 minutes over medium low heat.Â  Remove cover, flip over to fry the other side.Â  Cover to cook for 1 minute or until the edges are a litte crispy.Â Remove to serving platter.Â  Serve hot or warm with sweet chilli sauce.Finish the same with the remaining batter.

title: NAM YEE CHICKEN CHAR SIEW
text: I believe this is one of the easiest and simplest char siew to make.Â  The marinade ingredients are common seasoning ingredients found in most kitchens.Â  This is also a quick cook char siew as the most tender part of the chicken breast called 'hanging tenders' is used.Â  There are only 2 pieces of these 'hanging tenders' in a chicken breast and it is inexpensive.You can choose to roast them or just pan fry these pieces.Â  Â I would choose pan fry if it is only a small portion.Â  Â This chicken char siew is very tender, tasty and aromatic. Looks tempting and it is delicious. It only need several minutes to cook.Â  The tastes is just perfect, not too sweet or savoury.Â  Most probably, I will cook this often since it is so easy and delicious.Ingredients[serves 2]6 pieces 'hanging tenders' of the chicken breast - keep wholesome sliced cucumbersMarinade1 piece red fermented beancurd 'nam yee'2 tsp sugar1/2 tsp 5 spice powderdash of pepper2 tsp cooking wine1 tsp each light soy sauce, oyster sauce and dark soy sauce1/2 tbsp chopped garlic1 tbsp honey [add to marinade when boiling]Remove the small bones and thin membrane from the hanging tenders.Add marinade [except honey] to marinate the chicken meat, mix well and leave to marinate for 1-2 hours.Heat a non stick pan with some oil, arrange the pieces of chicken without the marinade in the pan.Â  Let them fry until cooked before flipping over to fry the other sideÂ  until brown and aromatic.Dish up onto serving plate lined with cucumber slices.Remove excess oil from the pan, pour in the marinade, add in honey and 2-3 tbsp water.Â  Bring to a rolling boil or until sauce is of running consistency.Pour over char siew, can garnish with some spring onions. Serve with rice or noodles.

title: GOLDEN FUNGUS WITH CHICKEN SOUP
text: Have you seen Golden Fungus or ate it before?Â  Â I happened to come across these dried golden fungus at the hypermarket the other while looking for dried stuff like black fungus, beans and mushrooms.Â  Out of curiosity, I bought some of these [25 gram].Â  A kilo cost about RM85.00.Â  Â  I believe these can be used in soup, braised or stir fried dishes or sweet dessert.Â  The easiest and fastest, perhaps is to cook soup with it.According to Wikipedia, this golden fungus is bland and flavourless and is edible.  Although some have claimed the fungus to be inedible or merely "non-poisonous",Â most other sources agree that it is edibleÂ but flavourless.Â The gelatinous to rubbery consistency lends texture to soups.Â Â In China, the fungus is used by vegetarians to prepare "an immunomodulating cooling soup with lotus seed, lily bulbs, red dates etc.Ingredients[serves 3]15 gm golden fungus - soaked to plump up, drained1 large chicken whole leg [skin and fats removed] - cut bite size pieces6-7 red dates3-4 pips garlic800 ml waterSeasoning1/2 tsp salt to tastedash of chicken stock granulesdash of pepperSoak golden fungus until soft and plump up, break into smaller pieces.Blanch chicken pieces with hot boiling water, drained.Bring water to boil in a soup pot or claypot.Â  Add in golden fungus, garlic and red dates.Â  Bring to boil for 5-10 minutes before adding the chicken pieces.Â  If using free range chicken, all ingredients can be added at the same time.Once the soup boils, lower to medium heat and simmer for 30 minutes.Taste to adjust seasoning.Serve hot.

title: EZCR#129 - SAVOURY SWEET CHICKEN WINGS
text: This braised chicken wings taste savoury sweet with some basic seasoning ingredients easily available in most kitchens.Â The preparation and cooking method is simple, quick and easy, yet thedish looks tempting and delicious.Â If you can get thebutcher to tidy up the wings, preparing this dish is a breeze.Â Â Â  I got my regular butcher to cut off the endtip of the wings, removed the excess skin and fats of the drumletsÂ  when I bought the wings from him.Â  This saves me much time.Ingredients6 chicken wings1 stalk spring onions â€“cut Â½ inch sections [keep some toadd last]1 red chilli â€“ seeded and cut diamond shapeA few slices of ginger200 ml water Seasoning2 tbsp each of tomato sauce, light soy sauce and cookingwine1 tsp sugarSalt to tasteMarinate chicken wings with some light soy sauce andpepper for 20 minutes.Heat Â½ tbsp oil in a non stick pan.Â Â Swirl the oil and put the chicken wings tofry until brown.Â Â Cover to cook on bothsides. Push aside.Add in ginger slices and spring onions until aromatic. Pour in the sauce, add red chilli.Stir fry to coat well before adding water.Bring to boil, cover and simmer over medium low heatuntil chicken wings are tender and cooked.Remove cover and continue to cook till sauce isthick. Add salt to taste if necessary. Lastly, addin the remaining spring onions.Dish up and serve.

title: KIAM BAK CHANG WITH BRAISED PEANUTS [2018]
text: HAPPY DUAN WU JIE [Â ç«¯åˆèŠ‚]Â 2018Â TO ALLÂ As in my previous posts on Savoury Rice Dumplings [Kiam BakChang] -Â Rice Dumplings, I used to mention that there are many versions of this dumpling and eachfamily has theirÂ  own unique recipe.Â  Practically, all tastes good and enjoyed bymany.This year, I tried another recipe with addition of braisedpeanuts.Â  The idea was adapted from My Kitchen 101Â while I was browsing for new dumpling recipes.Â  I had the time to try this version as I do not have to make rice dumplings for my mum, this year.Â Â  My sister in-law wanted to try her hand inmaking rice dumplings with my mumâ€™s recipe and guidance.Â  She succeeded with the â€˜sifuâ€™ around.Â Â  These are my mumâ€™s rice dumplings.Â My Recipe here makes 20 medium to large dumplings.Â  My hubby prefers large dumplings.Â  According to him, 1 large serving is most satisfying.Ingredients ForÂ The Filling600 gm pork belly with skin â€“ cut into 40 pieces2 tsp 5 spice powder1 heaped tsp white pepper powder1.5 tsp salt3 tsp sugar1 tbsp dark soy sauce100 gm shallots â€“ peeled and sliced thinly1.5 tbsp cooking oilMarinate pork pieces with seasoning ingredients for 30minutes.Heat oil in a non stick pan,fry shallots until aromaticand crispy.Add in the marinated pork.Â Stir fry until meat is firm, aromatic andwell coated with the seasoning.Add in the mushrooms and stir fry to mix well.Â Â Add in the chestnuts, stir fry. Dish up ingredients, separate them if possible.Â Â Set aside.Ingredients For The Rice900 gm glutinous rice â€“ washed andÂ  soaked for at least 4 hours orovernight.Â  Drained in colander100 gm shallots â€“ peeled and sliced thinly3 tsp salt3 tsp 5 spice powder1 tsp pepper1.5 tbsp dark soy sauce50 gm dried prawns â€“ rinsed and drained2-3 tbsp cooking oil1 canned braised peanuts - drained off liquidMix rice with all the seasoning ingredients.Â Toss well.Heat up oil in a non stick pan, fry shallots until goldenbrown and crispy.Â Add in dried prawns,stir fry to mix, then add in the rice.Â Continue to fry for 5-10 minutes or until ingredients are wellcombined.Stir in the braisedpeanuts. Mix well. Dish up. Set aside.Other Ingredients20 pieces small size dried mushrooms â€“soaked and drained20 dried chestnuts -Â soaked for several hours, removedthe membrane if any.Â Boiled for 30minutes to soften.Â Drained and setaside.10 salted egg yolks -Â steamed 10 minutes, cooled and halved1 can [170gm] braised peanuts â€“ drained off the liquid40 pieces dumpling leaves â€“ soaked until soft, rinsed andwipe dry â€“ set asideDumpling stringsTO WRAP RICE DUMPLINGS[See Post For Step By Step Pictures]To wrap dumplings, take 2 pieces of bamboo leaves and fold into a cone.Â Â Add 1 heaped tablespoon of rice, add 1-2 slices of pork, a piece of mushroom, a chestnut, a piece of salted egg yolk, top up with 2 heaped tablespoon of rice.Wrap into a pyramid shape dumpling and secure tightly with a hemp string. Â Do the same until all the ingredients are finished.Put the bundles of rice dumpling in a big pot. Â Top up with water enough to cover the changs. Â Add a tablespoon of salt to the water.Bring to boil over high heat, then lower to medium and continue to cook for 2 hours or until rice dumplings are cooked. Â Replenish with more hot water to the pot when required.Remove and hang to let it dry. Â Best to serve rice dumplings warm.

title: CHICKEN CUBES IN BLACK PEPPER SAUCE
text: A simple one dish that suffice for a meal with rice.Â  Great to add in all the capsicums, tomatoes and onions.Â  All blends well with the fragrant black pepper sauce that is a little spicy but good.Â  Â The spiciness of the black pepper sauce is acceptable to me and so appetising over rice.Â  The chicken cubes are tender but not dry.Â  You can actually deep fried them but I prefer to pan fry them till brown.Â  Do not over fry the other ingredients if you like them to stay crunchy.Ingredients1/2 chicken breast - cubedMarinade - 1/2 tsp salt, dash of pepper and 1 tsp cornstarch1/2 red capsicum - cubed1/2 green capsicum - cubed1 tomato - cubed1 large onion - cubed1-2 tbsp oilSeasoning [combined]1/2 tbsp ground black pepper1 tbsp each light soy sauce and oyster sauce1 tsp sugarÂ 2 tbsp shaoxing wine50 ml water1 tsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp waterMarinate chicken cubes with marinade.Â  Chill in fridge until required, while you assemble the other ingredients.Heat a non stick pan with oil, fry chicken cubes until brown on all sides.Â Â Push aside, add in the cut vegetables.Â  Stir to mix wellÂ Pour in the seasoning ingredients.Â  Continue to fry for 5-10 minutes until all ingredients are cooked through.Thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up to serve with rice.

title: EZCR#126 - FRAGRANT YAM WITH CHICKEN
text: Chinese style cooking, simple and easy with only a handful of basic ingredients and seasoning, yet the food tastes good.Â Â This is another of such dishes with only 2 main ingredients [fragrant yam and chicken].Â  The cooking method is also made simple from deep frying to pan frying.Â  If you are cooking a bigger portion, you can choose deep frying but for home cooking, I still prefers pan frying as I need not use too much oil.Â  Moreover, I kept the skin intact, no oil is need when you fry them in a non stick pan.I love the fragrance of the ginger, spring onionsÂ  which goes well the seasoning of this dish.Â  The fried yam pieces and chicken are both tasty in the thick sauce.Â Ingredients1 large deboned chicken whole leg [with skin, fats removed] - cut bite size pieces150-200 gm yam - cut thick strips or cubed1 stalk spring onions4-5 slices of gingerMarinade - some light soy sauce, wine, dash of pepper and cornstarchSeasoning1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, oyster sauce, cooking wine and dash of pepperHeat oil in a non stick pan, pan fry yam pieces over medium heat until brown.Â  Dish up.Using the same pan, pan fry the chicken pieces, skin side down until golden brown, flip over to fry the meat side until lightly crispy.Â  Dish up.Remove excess oil, using the same pan, saute ginger and spring onions until aromatic.Â  Add in the fried ingredients, pour in the seasoning.Stir to mix all ingredients well before adding enough water to cover ingredients.Bring to boil, then simmer for about 10 minutes untilÂ  yam and chicken pieces are tender and sauce reduced.Dish up to serve. Garnish with coriander leaves.

title: STEAMED MINCED PORK WITH CAI CHOY
text: This looks a simple, easy dish but turns out to be surprisingly good.Â  It is savoury, tasty and aromatic.Â  The minced meat if full of flavours, while the Szechuan vege is still crunchy. Â  A lovely, appetising dish to go with porridge.Â Â I had it with steaming hot plain rice.Â  When I first tasted this dish, I hope my family can accept the savoury taste. But when I ate it with rice, it turns out perfect, tasty and the savoury taste is just nice.Remember to try out this dish if you are cooking porridge. Recipe adapted fromÂ My White Kitchen with modificationsIngredients1 small bulb of Szechuan vegetable [cai choy] - rinsed and soak for 5-10 minutes, sliced or cut thick strips200 gm minced pork - marinate with 1 tbsp light soy sauce, 1 tsp sesame seed oil, dash of pepper and 1 tsp cornflourPlace marinated minced meat on steaming plate.Mix in the sliced cai choy or place them over the meat.Steam over high heat for 15-20 minutes.Remove, garnish with crispy fried garlic and chopped spring onions.Serve hot with rice.

title: HERBAL CHICKEN SOUP
text: Occasionally, I will crave to have a bowl of hot herbal soup.Â  The fragrance of the Chinese herbs can sometimes be irresistible though it may taste a little bitter.Â  Anyway, this is a light herbal soup great to serve with hot steaming rice.Â Ingredients450 gmÂ  free range chicken - skin removed, cut bite size pieces - blanched and rinsed8 red dates2 slices huai san6-7 strips yuzhuk1 tbsp kei chee [wolfberries]5-6 sections of tong sum4-5 sections of pak kei4-5 sections of dang quai800 ml watersalt and chicken stock granules to tasteÂ Â Â Place tong sum, pak kei and dang quai in a spice bag.Â  Secured with a string. Bring water to boil, add in herbs' bag, huai san, red dates and yuzhuk.Â  Boil for 15-20 minutes then add in blanched chicken'.Add in blanched chicken pieces.Â  Bring to boil again, then add in kei chee,Â  simmer over low heat for 30 minutes or until chicken is tender and soup aromatic.Season with some salt and chicken granules to taste.Serve hot with steaming hot rice.

title: STEAMED TOFU WITH CHAI POR SAUCE
text: One of the simplest recipe but this dish is nice.Â  The fried cai por sauce is fragrant and tasty.Â  A good steaming sauce for the bland, soft tofu.Â  I enjoyed it very much.This is a small portion but you can always increase the portion if preparing for more people. You can prepared it way ahead of meal time and steamed just before serving.Recipe adapted fromÂ My White Kitchen with modificationsIngredient1-2 pieces tofu - keep whole or slicedsome chopped spring onions - for garnishingSteaming Sauce20 gm salty cai por - rinsed20 gm sweet cai por - rinsed1 tbsp each of chopped shallots and garlic some chopped red chilli1 tbsp oyster saucePlace tofu slices on steaming plate.Heat a non stick pan, add 1/2 tbsp, saute shallots and garlic until fragrant.Â  Add in chopped cai por and red chilli.Continue to fry until aromatic.Â  Add in oyster sauce.Dish out and place over tofu slices.Steam over high heat for 5-10 minutes.Remove, garnish with spring onions.Â  Serve hot.

title: SWEET SOUR CHICKEN FILLET
text: This recipe is adapted from a TV cook show.Â  The original recipe uses pork tenderloin slices which are deep fried and then cooked with the other ingredients with a sweet and sour seasoning.As I happened to have some chicken breast fillets in hand, I had substituted the pork slices with chicken fillets.I had used pan fried method instead of deep frying the meat fillets which requires only minimal amount of oil if using a non stick pan.This dish turns out perfect, tasty sweet and sour but not overwhelming.Â  The fried chicken fillets are tender and moist.Ingredients150 gm chicken breast fillet - sliced1/2 green capsicum - cut diamond shape1/2 yellow capsicum - cut diamond shape1/2 red chilli - seeded and cut [can use red capsicum]some spring onions - cut sectionssome chopped garlic1/2 tbsp oil Seasoning [combined]1 tbsp each of vinegar, wine,tomato sauce, sugar and watera pinch of saltMarinate chicken fillet with some light soy sauce, dash of pepper and cornstarch.Â  Mix in some oil and set aside.Add oil to a non stick pan, pan fry the chicken slices in batches until both sides are golden brown and cooked.Â  Dish up.Using the same pan, saute garlic and spring onions until aromatic.Â  Add in the remaining ingredients, stir to mix and add in the fried meat slices and pour in the seasoning.Keep stirring to coat well with the seasoning sauce.Dish up to serve with rice.

title: EZCR#125 - FRAGRANT PINEAPPLE PORK
text: A dish even a novice cook can prepare, yet you may not realize it because is it that good.Â  This dish isÂ  really tasty, delicious and appetising.Â  Just this one dish is enough to go with a plate of plain white rice.The meat slices are quick to cook and tender if you use pork tenderloin.Â  The pineapple slices are soft and sweet, while the capsicums are still crunchy if not overcooked.Â  The seasoning blends well with all the ingredients, tasting sweet and sourish.Ingredients200 gm pork tenderloin - sliced thinly150 gm pineapple - cut 1 cm thick slices1 tomato - cut wedges1/4 green capsicum - cut wedges1/4 yellow capsicum - cut wedges1 red chilli - seeded and cut thick strips [you can use red capsicum if available]50 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce, cooking wine and Apple Cider vinegar1/2-1 tsp brown sugarÂ Marinate meat slices with 1/2 tablespoon light soy sauce, dash of pepper and sugar [an add 1 tbsp beaten egg if preferred].Â  MixÂ  before adding 1/2 tbsp of cornstarch.Â  Mix well.Pour 1/2 tbsp oil in a non stick pan.Â  Add in the marinated meat slices.Â  Stir continuously to ensure meat slices are evenly cooked.Â  Dish up.Using the same pan, add in the pineapple slices and fry till soft, then return fried meat to pan. Add tomato wedges and seasoning. Stir to mix well.Lastly add in the remaining ingredients and some water.Â  Stir fry for another 1-2 minutes.Dish up to serve with rice.

title: STIR FRY CHICKEN WITH BLACK FUNGUS
text: This is a stir fry dish if you use chicken breast but if like here, I have used free change chicken, there is a need to braise it after stir fry so as to tenderise the meat well.This dish can be prepared ahead of meal time and just reheat before serving.Â  The chicken meat and black fungus absorb the flavours of sesame seed oil which is fragrant combined with the remaining seasoning.Recipe adapted from My White Kitchen with modificationsIngredients300 gm free range chicken - cut into chunky pieces1/2 bowl soaked black fungus2 pips garlic - sliced some shredded gingersome shredded red chillies1 stalk spring onions - cut sectionsSeasoning2 tbsp sesame seed oil2 tbsp cooking wine2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp sugar1/4 tsp salt250 ml watersome cornstarch water [optional]Heat a non stick wok, add in shredded ginger and garlic, saute until aromatic and lightly brown before adding chicken pieces.Â  Stir well.Add in the seasoning, bring to boil and coats the chicken pieces well. Add in the black fungus and some shredded red chillies.Â  Stir well.Pour in water, bring to boil, lower heat, cover to simmer chicken until meat is tender and sauce reduced to thick or thicken with so cornstarch water.Lastly, add in spring onions.Â  Dish up to serve with rice.Garnish with remaining red chillies and spring onions.

title: CHAI POR CHICKEN SOUP
text: This recipe is adapted from Y-Tower Cooking You-tube Show.Â  There are 4 different kinds of soup recipesshared, in which I have selected 2 to try.Â The first that I tried was Dried Mushroom Chicken Soup [yet to share the recipe] with somemodifications for simplicity and this is the second recipe which I triedrecently.It is really simple with just 3 basic ingredients[chicken, chai por and garlic].Â Â Â  Theportion [serves 2-3 persons] shown in the pictures is a reduced portion of theoriginal recipe which I am sharing below.Â This simple, homey soup is awesome.Â  It has the natural aroma and saltiness of thepreserved salted radish [cai por].Â  Theoriginal recipe has some salt added which I have omitted as I find thesaltiness and sweetness suit me well.Â  The chai por strips are no longer salty after boiling. Recipe adapted from Y Tower You-tube with modificationsIngredients[serves 4-5]500 gm free range chicken â€“ cut into chunky pieces [blanched and rinsed]100 gm chai por strips â€“ rinse a few times [do not soak]4-5 pips garlic with skin [keep whole]1000 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp cooking wine [optional, to add last]Â½ tsp salt [I omit]Dash of msgÂ Bring600 ml water to boil in a soup pot, add in the chai por.Â  Boil for about 10 minutes or until aromatic.Â Add in the garlic, chicken piecesandÂ  remaining water [400 ml].Â  Bring to boil again, then lower heat.Â Cover and simmer for 30 minutes or untilchicken is cooked through. Remove scums, if any.Â Before dishing up, add in wine andseasoning to taste.Serve hot.

title: SZECHUAN VEGETABLE SOUP
text: Most of the recipes I am sharing here these days are getting simpler and easier.Â  The main reason being I am really occupied with many activitiesÂ  and commitments but still prefer home-cooked food then eating out.This is aneasy, simple and homey type of soup.Â  Ibelieve even a novice cook can prepare this soup because it is reallyeasy.Â  You can boil it in a soup pot oreven in a slow cooker.Just a fewbasic steps and you can get to enjoy a fragrant, savoury,Â  tasty and boiling hot soup in the comfort of your home.Recipe adapted from My White Kitchen with modificationsIngredients[serves 3]300 gmmeaty pork ribs â€“ washed, blanched and rinsed1 smallbulb Szechuan vegetable [Cai Chye] â€“ sliced and rinsed several times [not necessary to soak]2 tomatoesâ€“ cut wedges800 mlwater or add more if preferredSeasoningSalt andmsg to tastePreparethe above ingredients as stated.Â Bringwater to boil in a soup pot.Â  Add inblanched pork ribs and boil for about 20-25 minutes.Add inSzechuan vegetables and tomato wedges.Â Bring to boil again, then lower heat, cover and simmer for another 30 minutesor until pork ribs are tender.Â  Add alittle more water if soup has dried up a little. Â Addseasoning to taste.Â  Dish up to servehot.

title: STEAMED BRINJAL WITH CHILLI BEAN SAUCE
text: I believe many loves brinjals but put off preparingÂ  a dish with it especially when using stir frymethod.Â Â  Most times,Â  the sliced brinjals are deep friedÂ  or more oil is needed to stir fry them.Â  I,Â  forone would look for an easier and healthier cooking method.Â  The best way, Â I discovered is by steaming the brinjals witha minced meat paste.Instead of steaming everything together,Â  you canÂ stir fry the minced meat paste ingredients and spread in over thesteamed brinjals.Â Â  But, this way youwould need some oil to fry the meat paste.This dish istasty,Â  delicious and a good dishsuitable for both the old and young.Â  The brinjals look firm but it is soft and sweet.Add seasoning sparingly as the soybean post are sometimes quite salty. Ingredients[serves 2]Steaming Minced Meat Paste [combine well]100 gm minced meat1 tbsp chilli bean paste or minced soybean paste1 tbsp chopped red chilli [keep some for garnishing]1 tbsp each chopped garlic and ginger1 tbsp chopped spring onions [for garnishing]Dash of sugarOtherÂ  Ingredients1 medium size brinjal â€“ washed and cut Â½ inch roundsMix and combine the minced meat paste ingredients well.Â Arrange sliced brinjals on a steaming plate.Â  Top each piece with some minced meat paste.Â Steamed over boiling water for 15-20 minutes or until thebrinjals are soft and meat paste is cooked through.Remove from steamer and sprinkle some chopped springonions and red chilli.Note:Â  Tastes theminced meat paste before adding seasoning.Â Some chilli bean paste or soybean paste are salty.Â  Season sparingly with sugar or msg.

title: EZCR#122 - OYSTER SAUCE CHICKEN DRUMSTICKS
text: What can be more easier than this recipe to cook an oyster flavoured chicken drumsticks?Ingredients are few, seasoning easily available in any kitchen, cooking method is also simple.Â  Yet, this chicken dish tastes awesome.Â  It is aromatic, tasty and delicious with steaming hot rice.These drumsticks look so tempting.Ingredients4 pieces chicken drumsticks - make a few slits on the drumsticks1 stalk spring onions - cut sections300 ml waterSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp cooking wine1/4 tsp sugardash of msg2 tbsp oyster sauceLightly season the drumsticks with some light soy sauce.Heat a non stick wok with some oil, pan fry drumsticks to brown.Add in some spring onions and seasoning [except the oyster sauce], then water.Bring to boil and braise for about 5 minutes before adding the oyster sauce and some spring onions.Continue to cook until chicken is tender and sauce is reduced.Â  Dish up to serve.Â  Garnish with some spring onions.

title: EZCR#121 - CHICKEN ZUCCHINI BLACK FUNGUS SALAD
text: With the present hot, humid weather, this refreshing, light salad is most welcome.Â  An appetisingÂ  salad, good to enjoy on its own, with rice, bread or blanched noodles.The black fungus and zucchini are crunchy, while the chicken meat has its natural sweetness.Â  Combined with the dressing, makes a delicious and tasty salad.Ingredients200 gm chicken breast - skin removeda handful of black fungus - soaked1 zucchini - shredded1 red chilli - seeded and cut shreds1 tbsp each of chopped garlic and ginger1 stalk coriander leaves - choppedsome toasted sesame seedsDressing1 tbsp each of chopped gingerÂ  and garlic1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, oyster sauce, sweet chilli sauce1 tbsp chilli oil1/2 tsp sugar3 tbsp calamansi lime juiceBlanched black fungus, drained and cut shreds.Steam chicken breast meat for 15 minutes, cool and shred.Combine dressing ingredients in a bowl.Combine shredded ingredients in a bowl.Mix [3] and [4] together.Toss well and add some toasted sesame seeds.

title: EZCR#120 - DIPPING SAUCE FOR FRIED FOOD
text: This is a lovely sourish, sweet and spicy dipping sauce for various fried foods like firm beancurd, tofu, fried cuttlefish and others.Ingredients1/2 yellow onion - peeled and chopped2-3 pips garlic - peeled and chopped1 red chilli - seeded and chopped1 stalk coriander leaves - choppedSeasoning1 tbsp each fish sauce, sweet chilli sauce and honey3 tbsp lime juice or lemon vinegarPulse chopped ingredients several times.Add in seasoning and pulse several times to combine.Add a little more of honey if the honey you are using is not too sweet.Pour into a container and chill until required.Serve with fried beancurd or other fried foods.

title: EZCR#119 - BRAISED YOUNG CORN CHICKEN
text: Cooking for one is not that difficult.... Put your thoughts into action and see what you get.Â  Â If you find the dish good, just enjoy, keep the recipe and share.Â  If it does not, just take it as a lesson learned.Â  There is no one to make comments, so no worries.My home alone dish, complete with chicken and vegetables. Simple, yet awesome, tasty and delicious chicken dish with noÂ  oil used to fry the chicken.Ingredients1 deboned chicken whole leg [with skin but fats removed] - marinate with some light soy sauce1 piece Ernygii mushrooms - cut wedges5 pieces young corn - keep whole or cut sections1 tbsp wolfberries [kei chee] - rinsedSeasoning1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and winedash of pepper and msg or 1/4 tsp sugar to tasteHeat a non-stick pan, pan fry chicken [skin side first] until oil oozes out and brown.Add in mushrooms, young corn, seasoning.Â  Let it boil for a minute before adding enough water to cover ingredients.Cover with lid and braised until sauce is reduced.Â  Dish up the young corn and mushrooms onto serving platter [you can line plate with some salad leaves].Add in kei chee and a bit more water if gravy is to little, or thicken with some cornstarch water if too watery.Â  Bring to boil, dish up chicken, put on top of young corn and mushrooms.Pour remaining sauce over ingredients. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.Â  Serve immediately.

title: EZCR#117 - BRAISED SPICY TAU SEE CHICKEN
text: Since last week, I have started only cooking for myself at home.Â  Other members of the family are away from home for their duties, commitments and endeavours.Friends told me that I can enjoy meals outside for the time being but do you think it is possible to someone who loves home-cooked food, however simple?Â  I just wonder what if I do try, how long I can do it.Â  For 2 months, at least 3 meals a day, I don't think I so.Â  I would have to face the question of 'what to eat for breakfast, lunch and dinner?'Anyway, I take this opportunity to try the list of recipes that I have bookmarked earlier.This recipe is one of the many....simple, easy dish enough for one.Â  Awesome dish that's great with a plate of steaming hot rice and some blanched leafy greens or salad.The chicken absorbs the savoury, spicy and tasty seasoning.Â  With the sugar added, the sauce is still savoury with the fermented black beans and light soy sauce.Ingredients1 chicken whole leg with skin or 2 drumsticks1 tbsp chopped garlic1 red chilli - seeded and choppedsome chopped spring onions1/2 tbsp fermented black beans [tau see] - rinsed several times, drainedSeasoning1 tbsp each of chilli sauce, light soy sauce, cooking wine and sugarSaute garlic until aromatic, push aside.Â  Add in chicken [skin side down], pan fry over medium heat until lightly brown.Â  Flip over to fry the meat side, cover to cook for 5 minutes.Add in the seasoning, tau see, some chopped red chilli and spring onions.Â  Add in enough water to cover chicken.Bring to boil, cover with lid and simmer until chicken is tender and sauce is reduced.Â Â Dish up to serve, garnish with some chopped chillies and spring onions.

title: EZCR#116 - SPRING ONIONS GINGER SOY CHICKEN
text: Another easy and simple chicken dish.Â  Great soy sauce chicken to serve with blanched vegetables and a bowl of rice.The spring onions are naturally sweet and fragrant sliced ginger blend well the meaty chicken whole leg.Â  Without much seasoning the chicken meat retains it natural sweetness and succulent though braised.Awesome dish which I would love to prepare often.Ingredients1 deboned chicken whole leg1 stalk spring onions - cut sections [keep some to add last]a few slices of gingerenough water for braisingsome blanched leafy vegetables [I used bayam]Seasoning1 tbsp soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp cooking winedash of pepper1 tsp sesame oilHeat a non stick pan with a teaspoon oil, saute ginger slices and some spring onions until aromatic and lightly brown.Push aside, put in the chicken whole leg [skin side down]Â  to brown over medium high heat, cover to cook.Remove cover, flip over chicken and fry meat side for several minutes.Â  Flip over again before adding seasoning and water [enough to cover chicken].Bring to boil and simmer until chicken is cooked through and sauce is thick.Lay serving platter with blanched vegetables. Put braised chicken on top vegetable and spread sauce over chicken.Serve immediately with a bowl of rice and separately.

title: EZCR#115 - TUNG CHYE FRENCH BEANS
text: Again, another simple Chinese style stir fry vegetable dish.Â  Great to serve with rice or porridge.The fried French beans are crunchy, mushrooms are fragrant and balance well with the crunchy preserved cabbage [tung chye].Ingredients200 gm French beans - cut short sections2-3 dried mushrooms - soaked and diced2 tbsp preserved cabbage [tung chye] - rinsed and chopped1 red chilli - seeded and chopped1 tsp chopped garlicSeasoning1 tbsp light soy sauce to tastedash of msg and pepperStir fry mushrooms in a pan without oil until fragrant and lightly brown.Â  Add in 1 tablespoon oil, saute garlic and tung chye until aromatic.Add in French beans, stir to mix then add in some water.Add in seasoning and red chillies.Stir to combine all ingredients together over high heat till cooked.Dish up to serve with rice or porridge.

title: CHICKEN AND BROCCOLI STIR FRY
text: Came across this lovely dish, Chinese-style fry chicken with broccoli.Â  Being a Chinese, I am not good in differentiating which stir fry dish is Chinese or not.Â  According to the chef, the cooking technique of preparing it is called 'velveting'.Â It is an easy way and a healthy stir fry.Â  I fully agree as there is no oil used to cook it, yet it tastes delicious.Â  The chicken pieces are tender, while the blanched veggies are still crunchy.Just this dish alone is enough to go with a plate of steaming hot plain white rice.This recipe is adapted fromÂ Tess Cook 4U.Ingredients1 large chicken breast - sliced1 broccoli - cut into florets1 small carrot - peeled and sliced1 tbsp cornstarchÂ + 1 tbsp water [thickening]Marinade for Chicken2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tsp cooking winesome egg white1 1/2 tbsp cornstarchSeasoning Sauce [combined]3 cloves garlic - minced2 tsp chopped ginger2 tbsp oyster sauce2 tsp dark soy saucedash of pepperdrizzle sesame oil125 ml water or 1/2 to 1/3 cup water or chicken brothBlanch veggie in boiling water for 1/2 minute.Â  Drain into cold water.Using the same water, blanch marinated chicken [about 2 minutes], give one or two pushes to prevent chicken pieces from sticking together.Â  Drain.Using a clean wok, add in sauce.Â  Bring to boil and simmer for 1 minute. Add in blanched ingredients, thicken with cornstarch water.Stir to coat ingredients well.Remove and serve with rice immediately.

title: EZCR#112 - FRIED CHICKEN WITH CABBAGE
text: A simple stir fry chicken with cabbage dish over plain white rice that is good enough for a simple meal at home.There is only 2 main steps to cook this dish.Â  First, is to pan fry marinated boneless chicken pieces until slightly crispy and brown.Â  Second, is to fry the cabbage with the required seasoning.Â  Toss and mix both ingredients.Â  Dish up to serve with a plate of rice or serve separately.Hmmm...., tasty, delicious, homey Chinese style chicken and vegetable dish.Ingredients1 deboned chicken whole leg [with skin] - cut big cubesMarinade - some salt, 5 spice powder and pepper150 gm cabbage - washed and break into small pieces1 small stalk Chinese leek - sliced thinly1 red chilli - seeded and chopped1 tbsp fermented black beans - rinsed1 tbsp dao ban jiang or chilli bean pasteSeasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce and cooking wine1/4 tsp sugar or dash of msg [optional]Pan fry chicken pieces withÂ  some oil in a non stick wok until brown.Â  Push aside or dish up.Using the same wok, fry cabbage leaves for a minute, add in fermented black beans and dao ban jiang.Â  Toss to mix well.Â  Add in seasoning and some water.Fry ingredients or until cabbage is cooked through but still crunchy.Add in leeks and red chilli.Â  Toss to combine ingredients together.Dish up to serve with rice.

title: EZ STIR FRY PURPLE SWEET POTATO LEAVES
text: These purple sweet potato leaves are home grown from my neighbour's garden.Â  Looks radiant, clean and healthy growing in one's own garden.My neighbour gave me a bundle of these.Â  I tried an easy method which I use to fry leafy greens like spinach [por cai] and bayam leaves.Â  This simple stir fry is not as tasty as when you fry sweet potato leaves with sambal belacan.Â  The tastes is very original.Â  No idea why only the stems are purplish in colour, while the leaves look greenish.Ingredients1 bundle of purple sweet potato leaves - rinsed with the stems, several times - pluck the leaves and drained in a colanderSome shredded gingerSome sliced garlic1 red chilli - sliced1 tsp lemon juice2-3 tbsp oilsalt to tasteHeat oil in a non stick wok, saute ginger and garlic over medium heat until aromatic.Â  Add in the red chillies.Â  Stir to mix.Add in sweet potato leaves, pour in some hot water or stock around the wok.Â  Then stir to mix until the vegetables are limp.Â  Add in salt to taste.Drizzle in lemon juice, stir to mix well. [Lemon juice will help to keep the leaves greenish in colour if using green sweet potato leaves].Dish up to serve immediately.

title: CAI POR NOOI [CAI POR EGG OMELETTE]
