text: This is another way of making the popular Chinese egg omelette with preserved radish [cai por], a little different from my mom's versionÂ [here].Â  This omelette is always good to eat with a bowl of plain hot porridge.Â  I believe, any novice cook can try making it, rather fail proof, so long as you don't burnt the omelette, hahaha!Â Â Very simple steps with only a few ingredients.Ingredients[serves 4-5]5 eggs - break into a bowl, beat till fluffy1/2 bowl preserved radish [cai por] - rinse and drained1 stalk spring onions - chopped1 tsp oilenough oil for frying omeletteBeat eggs in a bowl, set aside.Â  Add in chopped spring onions.Pan fry the cai por in a non stick pan without oil until dry.Â  Add in 1 tsp oil, continue to fry until fragrant.Â  Dish up into beaten egg.Â  Mix well.Add some oil into pan, swirl to spread out the oil.Pour some egg mixture into pan.Â  Do not stir immediately.Stir lightly with a pair of chopstick when the edges turn white, leave to fry until lightly brown.Â  Flip over to fry the other side until firm and edges are crispy.Slide onto serving platter.Serve with porridge or rice.

title: EZCR#110 - TASTY CHICKEN WITH ASSORTED VEGETABLES
text: I always love recipes that have various ingredients that provide sufficient nutrition for a simple meal - One Dish Meal.This recipe should fulfill my expectation when I am thinking of One Dish Meal.Â  Feel free to cook this dish with any types of vegetables of your choice, it should be as tasty and delicious.I am also sharing a tip on how to marinate chicken to get smooth texture pieces when cooked with other ingredients.How To Marinate Chicken Pieces?1 deboned chicken whole leg with skin or without skin - cut broad strips or bite size piecesMarinate with 1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and cooking wine, 1/4 tsp sugar [stir to mix well], then add in some egg yolk [stir mix], then add in 1/2 tbsp cornstarch [stir mix well]IngredientsAbove marinated chickenÂ 2 dried mushrooms - soaked and slicedsome garlic slicessome spring onionssome sliced red chillisome sliced capsicum1 stalk celery - peeled and slicedSeasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce and cooking winedash of pepper and msg [optional]1 tbsp taucheo [spicy or non spicy]some waterPan fry marinated chicken with some oil until brown and cooked.Â  Meat pieces will not stick to pan.Â  Push aside.Fry aromatics - garlic, some spring onions, mushrooms.Â  Stir fry to mix well.Add in celery, seasoning, capsicum and red chilli.Â  Add in taucheo and some water.Stir to mix well and cook until ingredients are well coated with seasoning.Dish up to serve with steaming hot rice.

title: CNY 2018 - BEE KOH [COCONUT GLUTINOUS RICE PUDDING]
text: There are numerous versions/recipes for this glutinous rice pudding. Â Up till now, I have tried 4 recipes and the variation is not much. Â As I went along to try, I find this recipe most suitable to my expectations and taste. Loved this recipe and honestly feel proud of myself that I am able to make this Nyonya kuih.Â It is very aromatic, 'lemak' and not too sweet. Â The glutinous rice is soft, chewy not not soggy. Â Really awesome, even my mum and mum in-law have to agree that this is nice.Â  An easy and simple enough recipe.Ingredients[makes 2 big plates and 3 small plates]500 gm glutinous rice â€“ washed then soaked for 4 hours and best overnight, drained3 pandan leaves â€“ washed and knotted50-100 ml water200-220 gm granulated sugar [original recipe is about 240 gm]350 ml thick coconut milkÂ A pinch of salt2 pandan leaves â€“ washed and knottedSteam the soaked and drained glutinous rice over boiling water with pandan leaves for 40 minutes. After 10 minutes, sprinkle some water, toss well and steam for another 10-20 minutes or until rice is cooked, tender but not too wet. Â Off heat and leave in the steamer while you prepare the syrup.Put sugar, salt, pandan leaves and 50 ml coconut milk in a wok. Stir over low heat until sugar dissolves, then add in the remaining coconut milk [Do not boil the coconut milk at all, just simmer]. Â Remove the pandan leaves.Add in the steamed rice to sugar mixture in the wok. Stir constantly over medium low heat until mixture becomes a paste which is fairly thick, leaves the wok clean and turns into a ball.Â  I used my 'golden wok' from Thailand to prepare this and it is awesome, rice doesn't thick to the wok throughout the process.Transfer to individual plates or trays lined with cling wrap or banana leaf. Use a banana leaf or cling wrap to level up the surface neatly.Cool completely or until firm before slicing to serve.

title: CARAMEL NIAN GAO å¹´ç³• [TI KUEH]
text: Nian Gao [Ti Kueh] aka Kuih Bakul is a must for Chinese New Year.Â  I have triedÂ  several Nian Gao recipes and was lucky this time to come across a simple version of this kuih yet the result is awesome.Â Â Thanks toÂ Mykitchen101enÂ for sharing this great recipe.Really simple and long steaming hours.Â  You only need 1-2 hours of steaming.Â  The kuih has a nice colour, chewy and not too sweet.The only difficulty is lining the cans with banana leaves and patience when preparing the caramel.Â  But it is still worthwhile to try this recipe if you wish to make your own kuih bakul.Â  Much, much economical to make your own if you need to buy a lot.I have doubled the portion of original recipe and managed to make about 7 pieces of various sizes.Do visitÂ Mykitchen101enÂ for the steps to prepare this kuih.Â  It is very well presented with step by step pictures and video.Ingredients700 gm glutinous rice flour700 gm caster sugar860 ml hot watersome scalded banana leavessome aluminium cansPlace sugar in a heavy based pan, pour 4-5 tablespoons of hot water around the sides of the pan.Â  Stir lightly [but do not over stir].Â Â Cook sugar over medium low heat until it is golden brown in colour and the sugar meltsDo not cook caramel until it is too brown in colour.Â  The caramel my be bitter if overcooked.Off heat, then gradually pour remaining hot water into caramel.Turn on heat and cook until caramel sugar melts.Â  Allow to cool completely before mixing into glutinous rice flourGradually add in the syrup water into the flour.Â  Mix until smooth.Â  The batter is of thick consistencySieve batter to remove the lumps before pouring into prepared cans.Pour batter into lined cans, cover with foil to prevent water condensation,Â  Place in a steaming tray, cover tightly with lid.Â  Steamed over high heat for 1 hour, then simmer over low heat for 30 minutes to an hour or until kuih is fully cooked.A tray of lovely ti kueh [steamed glutinous rice cakes]WISHING ALL MY CHINESE FRIENDS HERE"HAPPY CHINESE NEW YEAR 2018"&"STAY HEALTHY, SAFE AND BE HAPPY"

title: EZCR#109 - BRAISED CHICKEN THIGHS WITH ONIONS
text: CNY is around the corner, so much to buy and so many things to do for this year.Â  Best to try simple easy recipes during pre-CNY days.Â Â Just this with a simple stir fry vegetable dish would suffice for a complete meal for the family.Â The chicken thighs need not be marinated before cooking as the seasoning is sufficient.Â  Tastes savoury sweet and fragrant.Â  Delicious to serve with steaming hot rice and a vegetable dish, similar to the set meals you get at the food outlets.Â Â Ingredients4 chicken thighs - deboned with skin intact1 stalk spring onion - cut sections [keep some to add last]1 red chilli - cut strips [keep some to add last]1 yellow onion - peeled and sliced1 tbsp oil250 ml waterSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp cooking wine1 tsp sugar to tasteHeat oil in a non stick pan, brown the chicken thigh pieces [skin side done first], then the meat side.Â  Push aside.Add in the onions and some spring onions, saute until fragrant.Â  Pour in seasoning, bring to boil for a few seconds.Â  Add in water.Bring to boil, add in red chilli and braise for 15-20 minutes or until chicken pieces are cooked through and sauce is reduced.Add remaining chilli and spring onions.Dish up to serve.

title: CNY 2018 - CHEESY FLOWER PINEAPPLE TARTS [RUB IN METHOD]
text: Happened to have many pineapple tarts recipes inhand.Â  After reading through, discoveredthat all is about the same with just a little difference.Â  I have not tried the cheesy type, so here isone of them.Â  SomeÂ  recipes use Parmesan cheese while others usecheddar cheese, but here I used cheese powder as advised by the store sellingbaking ingredients.The result of these tarts arenâ€™t the melt in mouth typebut they are crispy, not crumbly and of course have the added aroma of cheeseand savoury.Â Anyway, still acceptable to my family members buthonestly I prefer the melt in mouth, fragile type.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No.87 with modificationsIngredients[makes 90 pieces]330 gm plain flour50 gm milk powder30 gm cheese powder40 gm icing sugar250 gm cold butter - cubed1 large eggPineapple Filliing â€“ divide into 90 parts of 5 gm eachEgg yolk beaten for glazingSift flour, milk powder, icing sugar, cheese powder intoa mixing bowl.Add in cold butter into flour mixture.Â  Use finger tips to rub in butter with flouruntil crumbly.Add in the egg and knead into a soft and smoothdough.Â  Rest dough for about 30 minutes.Roll a portion of the dough into about 5 mm thick between2 plastic sheets.Â  Dust with extra flourif necessary to prevent sticking.Â  Cutout with flower shape cutter. Put a pineapple filling ball in the centre.Arrange on a lined baking tray, lightly brush pastry with eggglaze.Baked in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 15-20minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtightcontainer.

title: CNY 2018-PINEAPPLE JAM TARTS
text: There are several pineapple jam tarts in various shapesand designs which I have shared over the years.Â This one is another lovely tart recipe which is a keeper.The pastry is crispy, crumbly and fragile and not sweetat all.Â  The less sweet pastry helps tomellow down the sweetness of pineapple jam filling.I made these pineapple shape tarts using a jelly mouldand they turned out lovely, lovely and lovely.Â Â I usedstore bought pineapple jam, so making these tarts is hazzle free.Ingredients[makes 50 pieces Pineapple Shape Tarts]250 gm butter30 gm icing butter1 egg yolk350 gm plain flour2 tbsp each custard powder and milk powder1 beaten egg â€“ for glazingSift flour, custard flour and milk powder together.Â  Set aside.Beat butter and sugar until light.Â  Add in egg yolk and beat until creamy thenfold in the sifted flours and milk powder.Fold into a soft dough.Â Leave aside for 30 minutes.Divide filling into small lumps [6 gm] and roll intoround balls.Â  Divide pastry dough intosmall portionsÂ  [11 gm] enough to wrapfilling.Wrap filling with dough, dust a little flour and pressinto pineapple shape mould, then knock it out.Â Finish doing the rest and place on a lined baking tray.Glaze with beaten egg and baked in preheated oven at 180degrees C for 20 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtightcontainer.

title: CNY 2018 - RUB-IN METHOD CHEESY PINEAPPLE  BALLS
text: I happened to have many pineapple tarts recipes inhand.Â  After reading through, discoveredthat all is about the same with just a little variation.Â  I have not tried the cheesy type, so here isone of them.Â  SomeÂ  recipes use Parmesan cheese while others usecheddar cheese, but here I used cheese powder as advised by the store sellingbaking ingredients.The result of these tarts arenâ€™t the melt in mouth typebut they are crispy, not crumbly or fragile but of course with the added aromaof cheese andÂ  a little savoury in taste.Anyway, still acceptable to my family members buthonestly I prefer the melt in mouth, fragile type.Â Â  However, these cheesy pineapple ballsÂ  look cute with the design and glaze.Â  They are yummy, though and lovely forgiveaways.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 93 withmodificationsIngredients[makes 65 pieces]280 gm plain flour60 gm milk powder20 gm cheddar cheese powder60 gm cornstarch60 gm icing sugar220 gm cold butter â€“ cubed1 large egg yolk or 2 small egg yolksPineapple filling â€“ divide into about 6 gm portion androll into small ballsEgg yolk â€“ lightly beaten for glazingSift the first 5 ingredients into a large mixingbowl.Â  Add in the cold butter.Â  Use finger tips to rub in butter untilmixture resembles bread crumbs.Â Add inegg yolk and knead into a soft and smooth dough.Â  Set aside to rest for 30 minutes.Divide into small portions [to fit size of paper cases],wrap pineapple filling with dough.Â  Rollinto ball and cut lines on top [with a pincer] for decoration.Â  Place in paper case, then brush lightly withegg glaze.Â  Place on baking tray.Â  Do the same for the remaining ingredients.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 20 minutes oruntil golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtightcontainer.

title: CNY 2018 - RUB-IN METHOD-ROSE PINEAPPLE TARTS [çŽ«ç‘°èŠ±é»„æ¢¨é¥¼]
text: Grateful, my mother in-law discharged yesterday, after 33 days in hospital, not fully recovered but stable.Â Back to this, I cannot remember where I have seen this recipe but it was shared by various food bloggers and tried by many.  This year, I finally tried this recipe and it turned out lovely.I have doubled the portion of the recipe which I copied as these are for giveaways.This recipe is a keeper. Â I am not too good is describing these tarts, I can only say they are very nice.Ingredients[makes 80 pieces]250 gm butter [cold]300 gm plain flour140 gm corn flour50 gm icing sugar [original is 60 gm]2 tbsp custard powder1 large egg yolkPineapple Filling - 300 gmSift flour, cornflour, icing sugar and custard powder into a mixing bowl.Add in butter and use finger tip to rub in butter with the flour until breadcrumb like.Add in egg yolk and knead well to form a smooth dough. Â Place in a container and chill in the fridge for 15-20 minutes.Â Divide the dough into 10 gm each portion, wrap in the pineapple filling [about 7 gm per ball]. Roll into ball, place into a paper liner, use the metal peg to shape the rose petal.Lightly glaze with egg on the surface and bake in a preheated oven at 170 degrees Â C for 20 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: BRAISED FRESH MUSHROOMS WITH TOFU PUFFS
text: The 2 main ingredients [fresh mushrooms and taufu puffs] for this dish were from Tesco Store.Â  I like the sweet taste of the fresh mushrooms and the compact but soft taufu puffs.Â  These ingredients soak up the flavours and are tasty when braised.Â  For better flavour, add the cooking wine last before dishing up.Â This meatless dish can be a delicious vegetarian food that goes well with rice.Â Â Ingredients4-5 fresh Shiitake mushrooms100 gm taufu puffs - halved1-2 stalks spring onions - cut sectionsA few slices gingerA few cloves garlic - peeled and crushed1/2 tbsp oilSeasoning2-3 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp cooking wine1/2 tsp sugar1 tsp dark soy sauce for colourdash of pepperdash of sesame seed oilLightly rinse fresh mushrooms, remove the head and slice slantwise, set aside.Heat a non stick wok with oil, saute garlic and ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in the spring onions, continue to stir until fragrant.Add in the fresh mushrooms.Â  Stir for a minute or so, then the seasoning.Â  Add seasoning, bring to boil before addingÂ the taufu puffs, stir well to combine.Add enough water to cover ingredients, bring to boil.cover with lid, simmer over low heat.Braise ingredients until soft and sauce has thickened before dishing up to serve.

title: BRAISED CHICKEN WITH FRESH DATES
text: This recipe is a similar recipe toÂ Braised Chicken with Red DatesÂ with a little substitution.Â  The difference is with the dates used.Â  Here, I used fresh dates which are now available in the markets.Â Â The fresh dates when cooked are soft and naturally sweet.Â  Lovely, tasty dish with rice.Ingredients1 large deboned chicken whole legs [with or without skin] â€“ cut bite size pieces9 fresh dates4-5 cloves garlic â€“ peeled keep whole4-5 slices ginger200 ml water1 tbsp oilSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp Shaoxing wine1/2 tsp dark soy sauce for colour1/2 tbsp brown sugarLightly marinate chicken pieces with some light soy sauce for 15 minutes. Mix well until liquid is well absorbed.Heat up a non-stick wok with oil. Pan fry the chicken pieces [skin side down] about 5-10 minutes until golden. Turn over to fry the other side for another 5 minutes.Â Push aside and remove excess oil if Â any, then add in the garlic and ginger to fry until aromatic and slightly browned.Â  Add in the fresh dates.Mix well all the ingredients, add in dark and light soy sauce, wine and sugar. Bring to a bubbly boil then add in water to braise [add more if you like to have more sauce].Cover with lid and braise until sauce is reduced or thick, the fresh dates and the chicken pieces are tender.Dish up to serve.

title: CNY 2018 - BBQ FLAVOURED CHIPS COOKIES
text: I would not be baking these cookies if I hadn't bought the ingredients before Christmas. With my mother in-law alreadyÂ  in hospital for 18 days, I needed to do the baking during the night.Last year I madeÂ Savoury Potato Chips CookiesÂ [with sour cream and onion flavour potato chips] which was so good that I regretted not making more.Â  This time, I baked double portion of these cookies and also tried baking this batch of chips cookies with BBQ Flavoured Potato Chips.Â Â Preparing the dough is easy and baking them is quite fast, too.Â  These cookies taste savoury, buttery and aromatic.Â  Another batch of lovely cookies and I believe you can bake similar cookies with any flavour potato chips.Â Ingredients[makes 110 pieces]250 gm butter80 gm caster sugar50 gm toasted walnuts â€“ chopped160 gm BBQ flavour potato chips â€“ crushed2 tbsp cheese powder250 gm plain flour + 1 tsp baking powder â€“ siftedCream butter and sugar until light and fluffy.Sift flour with baking powder and mix in the walnuts, crushed potato chips and cheese powder.Â  Mix well.Fold [2] into [1].Â  Mix into a dough.Â  Scoop into small portions and place on a lined baking tray.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: CNY 2018 - CHEESY GERMAN BUTTER COOKIES
text: These batch of cookies were baked after Christmas, justÂ  before my mother in-law was admitted to the hospital for surgery. Just couldn't find the time to post this, then.I just love baking German butter cookies as they are so buttery, crispy and aromatic.Â  This recipe is similar to my postings on the various German Cookies with a little adjustments to the ingredients by adding cheese powder and omitting the some other ingredients like cocoa powder etc.Seems like it is never too early to start doing anything.Â  Life is constantly moving and anything can happen out of expectation.Â Nevertheless, I did end up with these lovely cookies that are buttery, crispy and fragrant.Â  This recipe is a larger portion.Ingredients[makes 150 pieces]500 gm butter150-160 gm icing sugarÂ - sifted500 gm potato starch30 gm cheese powder130 gm plain flourÂ - siftedÂ Beat butter and icing sugar till fluffy and lighter in color.Sift in potato starch, cheese powder and plain flour, mix to form a soft dough.Â  Chill for 30 minutes.Fill the dough into nozzle mould of your choice, press it with the thumb into the baking tray line with parchment paper and place a small pieces of cherry on top of the piped out cookie dough.Bake at preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 13-15 mins depending on the size of your cookies.Remove from oven, leave to cool completely on Â a wire rack and store in airtight container.

title: SPICY FRAGRANT FRIED TEMPEH
text: My family has learned to love fried tempeh which I prepared for them.Â  Tempeh tastes good be it pan fried or deep fried.Â  It can be served with a salad or any tasty dipping sauce.Here, I have made it very simple.Â  The pan fried tempeh pieces are served with mayonnaise.Â  You can serve the with chilli sauce, too.Â Â Though tempeh is a naturally cultured and fermented patty, it has a unique taste and flavourful on its own when fried.Â Ingredients1 big piece tempeh - sliced 1/2 cm thicknessOil for fryingMayonnaiseSeasoning1/2 tsp each of salt and ground black pepper1 tbsp meat curry powder1/4 tsp sugardash of msg or chicken stockÂ Combine seasoning ingredients in a deep plate or bowl.Cut tempeh into slices of cubes.Â  Add to combined seasoning.Â  Toss well and set aside for several minutes.Heat oil in wok and fry tempeh until golden and crispy. One tip - best to fry in batches because oil for frying cannot be re-used.Dish up on serving platter.Â  Drizzle over with mayonnaise.Serve immediately.

title: PUMPKIN PAUS
text: I made these paus for Winter Solstice family gathering.Â Â Easy to prepare pumpkin filling and easy to handle pau skin dough.These paus are fluffy, soft and chewy, while the filling is tasty and not too sweet.Lovely paus, tempting creamy pumpkin paste with a bit buttery flavour.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜Paus By Coco Kongâ€™Â with modificationsIngredients for Filling300 gm pumpkin paste30 gm castor sugar15 gm butter50 ml milkÂ 1/2 tsp saltsome toasted sesame seeds - optionalMix all the ingredients together [except sesame seeds] in a non stick pan.Stir fry over low to medium heat until paste is very thick and leaves the pan clean.Â  Sprinkle sesame seeds and mix.Dish up and set aside to cool or refrigerate until required.Ingredients for Skin Dough[makes 16 paus]375 gm pau flour45 gm icing sugar3/4 tsp double action baking powder1 1/2 tsp instant yeast230 â€“ 250 ml water30 gm shorteningFor Skin â€“ Combine all the dry ingredients in a mixing bowl.Â  Gradually, add in the water and knead at low speed until well combined.Â  Add in the shortening and knead at medium speed until dough is soft, smooth and shiny.Â  Shape into a ball, cover with a damp cloth and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or double in size.Â  Gather the dough before dividing it into 16-20 equal portions.To Shape â€“ Make [1] into a round and flatten it, ensuring that the center is thicker than the sides.Â  Place 1/2 tablespoon of filling in the centre, pleat the edges or pull the centre up to seal edges to make round pau or shape it according to your preference.Â  Place on flattened paper case in a steamer. Proof for 20-30 minutes.Bring water to a rapid boil, place steaming tray over boiling water, cover and steam for 10-12 minutes.Â  Off heat and leave the paus in the steamer for another 2-3 minutes before removing the lid and paus.Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #24Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: HOT AND SPICY THAI VEGETABLE CURRY
text: This is a Thai creamy curry with coconut milk andblends well the yellow curry paste which is easy to make yourself.Â  Just combine all the ground spicepowdersÂ  with the blended curryÂ  paste ingredients into a smooth paste.Vegetable curry cooked with coconut milk is one of myfavourite curries but add the palm sugar sparingly otherwiseÂ  you may find the curry a bit on the sweet side.Â  This curry isn't spicy and you can increased the amount of chilli powder.Just this curry withrice is enough for me to enjoy a good meatless meal for the day.Recipe adapted from â€˜500 Curriesâ€™ with modificationsIngredients For Yellow Curry Paste1 tbsp freshly chopped galangal or ginger2 tbsp chopped lemongrass 1 tbsp chopped garlic4 shallots â€“ chopped1 tsp lime rind or zest2 tsp hot chilli powder or more2 tsp coriander powderÂ Â 2 tsp cumin powder1 tsp turmeric powderOther Ingredients150 gm long green beans â€“ cut 1 inch lengths100 gm baby corn [I suggest to use canned baby corns]1 medium zucchini â€“ sliced Â½ cm thick1 small brinjal â€“ sliced 1 cm thick 1/2 tbsp palm sugar to taste2 tbsp Thai mushroom ketchup [I used mushroom flavoured oyster sauce]salt to taste2 tbsp oil150 ml thick coconut milk400 ml waterPlace all the curry paste ingredients in a blender with2-3 tbsp water.Â  Blend into a smoothpaste.Heat oil in a non-stick pan, add in curry paste, palm sugar and stirfry until aromatic.Â  Add in the thick coconut milk and gently cook for 8-10minutes or until the mixture starts to separate.Add in the vegetables [except the zucchini], stir fry to mix well for 5-10minutes, then add in the zucchini.Pour in water or thin coconut milk.Â Bring to boil, cover toÂ  cook gently until vegetables are tender.Add in the seasoning to taste.Â Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.Â  Serve hot with rice or blanched noodles.

title: SWEET AND SPICY FRIED TUMERIC TEMPEH
text: Simple, delicious and appetising side dish that you can prepare for your family.Â  Thought of not sharing this dish but should be good to keep this recipe here for future reference.The original recipe is fried tumeric tempeh served with a savoury, sourish and sweet chilli dipping sauce.Â  I have modified it by replacing the dipping sauce with some freshly shredded cucumber, onions, carrots and a sweet, spicy fragrant sauce.Â Â My family loves this dish.Ingredients1-2 pieces tempeh - cut thin slices1-2 tsp tumeric powder1/2 tsp saltoil for fryingSome shredded cucumber, onions and carrots - rinsed with cold water and drainDressing Sauce [Combine]2 tbsp each of tomato sauce and sweet chilli sauce1 tbsp Worcester saucesome toasted sesame seedsCoat tempeh slices with tumeric powder and salt.Line serving platter with shredded vegetables.Combine dressing sauce in a small bowl.Pour oil in a non stick pan, add in tempeh slices [fry from cold oil] until tempeh slices are golden brown and crispy.Dish up and place over shredded vegetables.Scoop dressing over tempeh slices.Serve immediately.

title: TARO COCONUT PAUS
text: For this pau recipe, the Taro Filling is easy to prepare, fragrant and tasty, but I am not too happy with the look of some of the triangular paus after steaming. I think, I took too long to wrap the paus thus over proofing some of the paus.Â The pau skin recipe below is 50% more of the original recipe.Â  I should have use the actual recipe and make only 16 small paus.Â  Anyway, the pau skin is chewy with a QQ texture.Â  Doesn't look pretty but overall they taste good for home consumption.I have added some toasted sesame seeds to the filling.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜Paus By Coco Kongâ€™Â with modificationsIngredients for Skin Dough[makes 20 paus]300 gm pau flour45 gm wheat starch [tang mian flour]150 gm steamed taro â€“ mashed while still hot50 gm icing sugar1Â½ tsp double action baking powder3 tsp instant yeast120-160 ml water [depending on the steamed taro]1Â½ tsp vinegar30 gm shorteningIngredients For Â Taro Filling200 gm steamed Taro [yam]Â mashed while still hot till smooth65 gm castor sugarÂ½ tsp salt40 ml corn oil80 ml coconut milk20 paper cases â€“ flattenedFor Filling â€“ combine filling ingredients in a non stick pan.Â  Stir fry until mixture has aÂ  thickened consistency [takes about 15-20minutes].Â  Turn off the heat, stir untilsmooth.Â Â  Dish up to cool.For Skin â€“ Combineall the dry ingredients and steamed taro in a mixing bowl.Â Gradually, add in the water and knead at low speed until wellcombined.Â Add in the shortening andknead at medium speed until dough is soft, smooth and shiny.Â  Shape into a ball, cover with a damp cloth andleave to proof for 20-30 minutes or double in size.Â  Gather the dough before dividing it into 20equal portions [35 gm].To Shape â€“ Make [2] into a round and flatten it, ensuringthat the center is thicker than the sides.Â Place a piece of filling [about 1 tbsp] in the centre, pull the centre up to sealedges.Â  Hand shape it into triangular pieces with the sealed edges facing up.Â  Use a chopstick to dot the side surfaces with some colour dots. Repeat process.Placeon flattened paper case in a steaming tray. Proof for 20-30 minutes.Bring water to a rapid boil, place steaming tray overboiling water, cover and steam for 10-12 minutes.Â  Off heat and leave the paus in the steamerfor another 2-3 minutes before removing the lid and paus.Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #24Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: PANDAN CUSTARD PAUS
text: I have prepared the filling a day ahead and made the paus the next day.Â  The pandanÂ  custard filling is easy to prepare and it is a tasty, good pau filling. Very fragrant with the combination of butter and pandan juice and paste.Â  This pandan custard filling recipe is a keeper.Verdict - Pandan Custard Filling â€“ easy to prepare, fragrant, smooth and tasty.The pau skin dough is easy to handle and pleat but remember not to over proof it.Â  It has a QQ [chewy] texture and complement well with the filling.Â  I have added some pandan paste for colour but you can omit it [it is not in the recipe].Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜Paus By Coco Kongâ€™Â with modificationsIngredients for Skin DoughÂ [makes 20 paus]300 gm pau flour50 gm icing sugar1Â½Â  tsp instantyeast150-170 ml water20-30 gm shorteningIngredients For Â PandanCustard Filling2 eggs80 gm castor sugar25 ml pandan juice + Â½ tsp pandan paste100 ml milk65 gm plain flourÂ½ tsp salt65 gm melted butter20 paper cases â€“ flattenedFor Filling â€“ combine filling ingredients in a non stick pan.Â  Stir till mixture is not lumpy.Â  Stir fry until mixture over low medium heat until it has aÂ  thickened consistency [takes about 10 -15 minutes] .Â  Turn off the heat, continue to stir untilsmooth.Â Â  Dish up to cool.Â For Skin â€“ Combineall the dry ingredients in a mixing bowl.Â Gradually, add in the water and knead at low speed until wellcombined.Â  Add in the shortening andknead at medium speed until dough is soft, smooth and shiny.Â  Shape into a ball, cover with a damp clothand leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or double in size.Â  Gather the dough before dividing it into 20equal portions [25 gm].To Shape â€“ Make [2] into a round and flatten it, ensuringthat the center is thicker than the sides.Â Place a piece of filling [about 1 tbsp] in the centre, pull the centre up to sealedges.Â  Roll into a round ball or shapeit according to your preference.Â  Placeon flattened paper case in a steaming tray.Â  Make design with a pincer.Â  Â Proof for 20 minutes.Bring water to a rapid boil, place steaming tray overboiling water, cover and steam for 10-12 minutes.Â  Off heat and leave the paus in the steamerfor another 2-3 minutes before removing the lid and paus.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #24Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: COFFEE MUNG BEAN PAUS
text: This pau recipe makes 24 paus.Â  If you are using a small steamer, it is advisable to make half portion of this recipe to prevent over proofing of the paus.The skin dough is easy to handle, roll and shape.Â  There is a light aroma of coffee and the mung bean paste filling complements well with the flavour.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜Paus By Coco Kongâ€™Â with modificationsIngredients for Skin Dough [A]400 gm pau flour10 gm instant yeast250-260 ml waterIngredients for Skin Dough [B]100 gm pau flour60 gm icing sugar1 tsp double action baking powder1 tbsp milk powder20 gm shorteningIngredient for Skin Dough [C]2 tbsp coffee pasteIngredients For Filling720 gm Mung Bean paste or Lotus paste for paus [divide into 30 gm each and shaped rounds]24 small size paper cases [flattened]For Skin â€“ Combine all the ingredients [A] in a mixing bowl.Â  Knead at low speed until well combined for a few minutes or until soft and shiny.Â  Roll into a ball, cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Add in ingredients [B] and knead at medium speed until dough is soft, smooth and shiny.Â  Scale 300 grams of dough, add in coffee paste.Â  Knead to mix well.Â  Â ShapeÂ  both the dough into balls, cover with a damp cloth separately and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or double in size.Â Â Divide original and coffee dough each into 2 portions.Â  Roll each portion into squares or rectangles.Â  Place coffee dough on top of original dough and roll up like Swiss roll.Roll out each portion into 12 pieces making it a total of 24 pieces.Â  Invert it, roll flat, wrap in filling, sealed edge face downwards.Â Â Â Place on flattened paper case in a steamer tray. Proof for 20-30 minutes.Bring water to a rapid boil, place steaming tray over boiling water, cover and steam for 10-12 minutes.Â  Off heat and leave the paus in the steamer for another 2-3 minutes before removing the lid and paus.Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #24Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: MUI CHOY MUNG BEAN PASTE PAUS
text: This recipe is a slight variation of the original recipe[Mui Choy Lotus Paste Paus].Â  I had toreplace the Lotus Paste for making these paus with Mung Bean Paste as I was advisedby the store owner that the former is unavailable.Â  It seems that lotus seeds are ratherexpensive these days, thus will be the paste.Â These days suppliers are using mung beans as substitute.Â  Looks like I have no choice but Â to use mung bean paste as I donâ€™t intend tomake the lotus paste myself [itâ€™s too tedious].Anyway, I am happy with the substitution which tastes savoury and sweet.Â  The pau skindough is pliable, easy to handle and shape.Â Â These paus are light and fluffy, though I found the size a bitsmall.Â  You can make less to getbigger size paus [maybe 16 pieces will do].Note - The savoury mui choy must be properly rinsed toremove the sand and grit.Â  Rinsing itwith salt helps to dispel excess savoury taste.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜Paus By Coco Kongâ€™Â with modificationsIngredients for Skin Dough250 gm pau flour30 gm icing sugarÂ½ tsp double action baking powder1 tsp instant yeast135 â€“ 150 ml water20 gm shorteningIngredients For Filling250 gm Mung Bean paste or Lotus paste for paus60 gm savoury mui choy [preserved savoury vegetable] â€“rinsed with some salt, drained and chopped20 small size paper cases [flattened]For Filling â€“ heat a non stick wok without oil, dry frychopped mui choy till dry.Â  Turn off theheat,Â  mix it with the paste.Â Â  Dish up to cool and divide into 20 equalportions [14 gm] for the filling.For Skin â€“ Combine all the dry ingredients in a mixingbowl.Â  Gradually, add in the water andknead at low speed until well combined.Â Add in the shortening and knead at medium speed until dough is soft,smooth and shiny.Â  Shape into a ball,cover with a damp cloth and leave to proof for 20-30 minutes or double insize.Â  Gather the dough before dividingit into 20 equal portions [22 gm].To Shape â€“ Make [2] into a round and flatten it, ensuringthat the center is thicker than the sides.Â Place a piece of filling in the centre, pull the centre up to sealedges.Â  Roll into a round ball or shapeit according to your preference.Â  Place onflattened paper case in a steamer. Proof for 20-30 minutes.Â  Notes: For this shape, make the lines with a thick string, then use tip of a chopstick to make the holes in between the lines.Bring water to a rapid boil, place steaming tray overboiling water, cover and steam for 10-12 minutes.Â  Off heat and leave the paus in the steamerfor another 2-3 minutes before removing the lid and paus.Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #24Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: MUSHROOM CURRY WITH GARAM MASALA
text: I have never imagined canned mushrooms can be preparedthis way and yet delicious.Â  The chefadvised that this goes well with meat dishes and is also great to serve on itsown as a vegetarian main course.Â  Thedistinctive flavor of mushrooms goes well the mixture of the spices used.Â  The mushrooms can be substituted with anyother mushrooms [dried mushrooms, white mushrooms etc].Personally, I feel this is great to serve withspaghetti.Â  The dish tastes savoury,sourish, spicy and aromatic.Â  This dish is nice and I love it.Â  Bookmarked to prepare this for my hubby's siblings who are vegans.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜500 Curriesâ€™Â with modificationsIngredients2 cans button mushrooms â€“ sliced1-2 ripe tomatoes â€“ blended [can you tomato puree]Some coriander leaves for garnishing1-2 tbsp oil1 onion â€“ finely chopped1 fresh green chilli â€“ seeded and chopped2 cloves garlic â€“ peeled and chopped1 inch piece ginger root â€“ choppedSeasoning [Combined]1 tsp cumin powder1 tsp coriander powderÂ½ tsp garam masalaÂ½ tsp ground black pepperÂ½ tsp turmeric powderÂ¼ - Â½ tsp salt to taste2-3 cardamon podsHeat oil in a pan, sautÃ© onions and the remaining choppedingredients until aromatic.Add in the spice seasoning, fry for 2-3 minutes, stirringall the time until fragrant.Â  Add the blended tomato andsalt.Â  Bring to boil and simmer for 5minutes.Add in the mushrooms and stir to mix. Cover and simmerover a low heat for 10 minutes or until the flavours are well absorbed.Dish up, garnish with chopped coriander before serving.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #23Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: SPICED AUBERGINE WITH CHILLI SAUCE AND SESAME SEEDS
text: One simple and easy vegetable dish recipe for '500 Curries'.Â  The recipe looks complicated but I made it simple with some modifications.Â  The result is as good if you have not seen the original, hehehe!.I love the spicy flavour and the tangy taste which blends well with the sweet taste of aubergine/eggplant/brinjals.This is the description of the Chef of this recipe.Â  'Chunks of aubergine coated in a rich sauce and sprinkled with sesame seeds makes an unusual side dish that is quick to cook.Â  A versatile vegetarian dish that can be served hot,Â  warm or cold'.Â  A dish well describer and it's a must try if you like aubergine.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜500 Curriesâ€™Â with slight modificationsIngredients300 gm aubergine - cut chunks1/2 tsp salt1 tsp chilli powder1-2 tbsp cooking oilsome toasted sesame seedsSeasoning [Combined]2-3 cloves of garlic - peeled and crushed1/2-1 tbsp chilli paste1/2 tbsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp rice vinegarÂ 2 tsp light soy saucesalt and ground black pepper to taste100 ml waterSprinkle cut aubergine with salt and leave to stand for 15-20 minutes.Â  In a colander, rinse well and drain off excess water.Â  Sprinkle chilli powder and toss well.Meanwhile, combine seasoning ingredients in a small bowl.Â  Set aside.In a non-stick pan, heat oil until hot, fry aubergine chunks.Â  Stir constantly until a little brown, pour in water.Â Cover to pan for 1-2 minutes to steam.Â  Add in seasoning ingredients.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Sprinkle sesame seeds and dish up to serve.Sprinkle more sesame seeds if preferred.Â Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #23Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: KOREAN CUCUMBER NAMUL
text: This sort of salad is a sautÃ©ed version that retains thenatural succulence of the cucumber or zucchini, while also infusing the dishwith pleasant hint of garlic and red chilli.Â You can also replace the chilli strips with thinly sliced bell peppers ifyou prefer a less heaty version.Itâ€™s great to serve this dish with fried meats which iswhat I did.Â  The accompaniment 'friedpork strips' are marinated with blended ginger, garlic and seasoned with somelight soy sauce, lemon juice and honey.Â Awesome.Â  Looks good, isn't it with the sprinkle of toasted sesame seeds.Believe me, the sauteed zucchini slices are still crunchy.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜500 Curriesâ€™Â with slight modificationsIngredients1 medium size zucchini â€“ cleaned1 tsp chopped spring onions1 tsp chopped garlicÂ½ red chilli â€“ seeded and cut thin stripsÂ½ tbsp cooking oilÂ½ tsp sesame seed oilSalt to tasteSome toasted sesame seeds for garnishingThinly sliced the zucchini which a scrapper and place ina colander over a bowl.Â  Sprinkle somesalt [1 tsp], then leave to stand for about 10 minutes.Â  Squeezed off any excess liquid from the zucchinislices and transfer Â to a plate.Swirl oil around a pan over medium heat, add in choppedspring onions and garlic.Â  Saute untilaromatic, add in the zucchini slices. Quickly stir fry forÂ  a minute to prevent over cooking.Remove from heat, add sesame seed oil, red chilli, tosswell.Place salad onto serving plate and sprinkle sesameseeds.Â  Serve with fried meats.Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #23Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: MASALA FRENCH BEANS WITH FENUGREEK
text: According to the chef of this recipe, the term 'masala' refers to the blending of several spicesto achieve a distinctive taste, with different spice-combinations being used tocomplement specific ingredients.The recipe calls for blending of the spices into a pasteto fry the French beans, which I believe is more fragrant.Â  But, if you find ittoo troublesome, it is alright to use garam masala powder or use powder form ofthe specified spices needed, which is what I did.I like the taste of this fried beans, aromatic and tasty.Â  Loves the slight tangy taste from the lemon juice.Â  Does make it extraordinary.Â  Next time, when you wish to fry French Beans, perhaps can try this recipe for a change.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜500 Curriesâ€™Â with slight modificationsIngredients1 onion â€“ finely chopped1 tsp chopped garlic1 tsp ground cumin [Jintan Putih]1 tsp ground coriander [ketumbar]1 tsp chilli powderÂ¼ tsp turmeric powderÂ½ tsp fenugreek1 tbsp oil200 gm French beans â€“ cut slantwise and blanched4-5 cherry tomatoes [halved] or 1 tomato â€“ quarteredÂ¼-Â½ tsp salt to tasteÂ½ - 1 tbsp lemon juiceSome chopped coriander leavesSome toasted sesame seedsCombine the spice powders, fenugreek Â with chopped onions and garlic.In a wok, heat up the oil, fry the spice ingredients fora minute until aromatic.Add in the tomatoes and blanched beans.Â  Stir fry to mix well for 5 minutes.Add in the coriander leaves, sesame seeds and sprinklelemon juice.Dish up to serve.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #23Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: MANGO CHUTNEY
text: I discovered that this is a rather quick and easy recipeto follow to prepare a Mango Chutney.Â  According to the cook of this dish, no Indianmeal would be complete without this classic chutney.It is ideal to use a slow cooker to cook thischutney as you need not have to watch over the stove.It is gloriously sweet, aromatic, tangy and complement Â well with the aromatics and spices.Â  With just this chutney, I think it is not a problem to enjoy a meal of plain rice.Â  Very appetising.Recipe adapted from the bookÂ â€˜500 Curriesâ€™Â with slight modificationsIngredients3 mangoes [about 600 gm]Â½ cup cider vinegar1 inch piece of ginger root â€“ cut thin strips2 cloves garlic â€“ sliced or chopped5 cardamon pods1 bay leaf1 small chilli â€“ split [can use Jalapeno chilli]150 gm jaggery sugar or brown sugarÂ½ tsp salt to tastePeel the mangoes, remove the pith and cut into chunks orwedges.Put the mangoes in the ceramic cooking pot Â of the slow cooker, add in the vinegar, stirto mix well.Â  Cover and leave to cookover high heat for about an hour, stir halfway through the cooking time.The mangoes must be soft before adding theremaining ingredients.Â  Stir to mix welland until sugar has dissolved.Cover and continue to cook until the chutney is reducedto a thick consistency and no excess liquid remains [about 30 minutes].Stir constantly the chutney towards the end of the cooking time.Remove and discard the bay leaf.Â  Spoon chutney into hot sterilizedcontainer/jars and seal. Store for 1 week before serving and use within 1 year.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #23Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: SPICY GLAZED PUMPKIN WITH COCONUT SAUCE
text: For this monthâ€™s cookbook countdown event, I have chosena â€˜bigâ€™ recipe book which consists of 500 recipes.Â  The name of the book is â€˜500 Curriesâ€™ whereyou will discover a world of spice in dishes from India, Thailand and South EastAsia, as well as Africa, the Middle East and the Carribean.With a wide range of delicious, spicy recipes to choosefrom this book, I may be spoilt with so much choices..Â  Should I thank my hubby for getting me thisbook or complain he is giving me too much work to do?Â  Hehehe!Â This is the first recipe which I tried and I likeit.Â  So, is going to be thanks to him,lolâ€¦Â  and I shall continue to try someother recipes from this book to share with all of you who loves curries be itmild, red hot or more complex in tastes.According to the cook, pumpkins, butternut squash andwinter melons can all be cooked in this way.Â Throughout Vietnam and Cambodia, variations of this sweet, mellow dishare often served as an accompaniment to rice or a spicy curry.Recipe adapted from the book â€˜500 Curriesâ€™ with slightmodificationsIngredients300 gm pumpkin flesh â€“ cubed2 cloves garlic â€“ chopped1 cm piece ginger â€“ chopped100 ml thick coconut milk1 tbsp fish sauce or nuoc mam â€“ popular fish sauce fromVietnam and Cambodia1 tbsp gm palm sugar or jaggery sugar1 tbsp cooking oil100 ml waterSome ground black pepper for taste1-2 sprigs curry leaves or Basil leavesSome chilli oil from drizzling [optional]Some fried shallots [optional]Combine coconut milk, sugar and fish sauce in a bowluntil sugar dissolves.Heat oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© garlic and gingeruntil golden, add in the pumpkin cubes.Â Stir to mix well for 1-2 minutes.Pour in the coconut milk and water, mix well, reduce heat and simmer for20 minutes until pumpkin is tender and the sauce has reduced.Season with black pepper and add in curry leaves or Basilleaves.Dish up, garnish with fried shallots and drizzled withchilli oil if preferred.Serve hot with plain or coconut rice.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #23Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: NYONYA CHAP CHAI
text: Ten days of strictly meatless meals for my family.Â  Gosh!, great achievement and is it possible that we can cut down our meat intake from now on?Â  Must keep it up, at least 75%, maybe??? All depends on my hubby, if he can we all can.This is a Nyonya [Peranakan] style mixed vegetablesshared by Baba, Kenny Chan.Â  The recipewas published in Home Cooking Magazine February 2001 Issue.Â  I had this magazine since then but have notgot down to try the recipe.There are numerous versions of the Nyonya Chap Chai, evenmyself have tried preparing this dish in different ways at differenttimes.Â  I have never tried using prawnsin this dish.Â  Again, here I have omittedthe prawns in the recipe [250 grams small size prawns] because I want to prepare a meatlessdish.Â  This dish will look a little darker if the taucheong you used is of a darker colour.Recipe adapted from Home Cooking Magazine February 2001Issue with modificationsIngredients[serves 3-4]20 dried lily buds â€“ soaked, knotted and remove the hardtips.2 strips dried beancurd stick [tau kee] â€“ soaked in warmwater with a dash of salt for 20 minutes1 tbsp black fungus [bok nee] â€“ soaked3 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked and slicedA few slices of ginger1 small bundle of glass vermicelli [tunghoon] â€“ soakedfor 5-10 minutes, cut 3 inch sections100 gm cabbageÂ  -break into small piecesSome slices carrots2 tbsp oil1 â€“ 2 tbsp preserved soybean [taucheong] - chopped1 cup waterSalt, pepper and msg to tasteHeat oil in a non-stick wok, sautÃ© ginger,Â  mushrooms until fragrant and taucheong.Â  Fry until aromatic.Add in cabbage, carrots, black fungus and beancurdstick.Â  Stir fry for awhile, add inseasoning.Stir fry to mixwell, add in water, bring to boil until cabbage is tender.Lastly add in tunghoon and dried lilybuds. Tastesto adjust seasoning.Â  Cook until sauce isslightly reduced.Dish up to serve, garnish with chopped Chinese celery[kin chye].

title: VEGETARIAN CHICKEN KERABU
text: Unbelievable, a vegetarian kerabu chicken.   You may think it is the processed vegetarian food ingredient that resembles and tastes like chicken.  Not at all, there is totally nothing related to  chicken here.  This salad [kerabu] is strictly meatless  though you may see there is a whole lot of stuff that looks like chicken breast shredded.   Guess what that is?This kerabu looks and tastes like a chicken kerabu which you may have eaten some Nyonya food outlets or at home.   All the ingredients are in here except that the chicken breast meat has been replaced by a secret ingredient â€˜Erngyii Mushroomsâ€™.Ingredients1 packet Erngyii mushrooms - rinsed1 tbsp black fungus [bok nee] - soaked and cut strips50 gm red carrot - peeled and shredded1-2 small red chillies - thinly slicedsome mint leavesSalad Dressing [Combined]1/2 torch gingerÂ flower - minced5-6 calamansi limes - juiced2 tbsp sugar to taste1/2 tsp mushroom granules or vegetarian belacan or dash of saltsome toasted sesame seedsHalve mushrooms lengthwise, blanched in boiling water for a minute. Drained, cooled and tear into strips.Using the same water, blanched black fungus, drained and cut strips.Combined dressing ingredients in a bowl.Â  Taste to adjust.Mix the salad ingredients together, pour in dressing, toss well and refrigerate until serving time.Sprinkle sesame seeds over salad before serving.

title: VEGETARIAN MA PO BEANCURD
text: When we come across the word 'Ma Po', automatically we relate it to Chinese cuisine.Â  Indeed it is and according to the Chef of this cookbook, there is a story behind the word.Â  Chef Yee Yo wrote that Ma Po, is the pockmarked Grandma who invented this dish in the 1860s.Â  She creatively transformed the bland bean curd into a powerfully spicy dish.Â  The family owns a food shop 'Chen's Ma Po Bean Curd Shop' in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province.Â  Apart from Ma Po Tofu, the shop serves many other bean curd and non bean curd dishes.Â  It manufactures fresh bean curd daily.Â  The ingredients in this recipe are essentially the same as those used by Ma Po more than a 100 years ago.A tasty vegetarian Ma Po TofuÂ  dish which is not that spicy as you expect of a Sichuan dish.Â  It is quite mild in taste and not as oily like in most Sichuan cuisine.Â Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoÂ with modificationsIngredients[serves 3-4]Â 2 pieces tofu [soft bean curd] - cubed30 gm dried glutton piecesÂ 1 tbsp chopped ginger1 heaped tbsp fermented black beans - rinsed and chopped1 tbsp preserved soy bean paste - chopped *1 tsp chilli boh* [replacing 1 tbsp of hot dao ban jiang]2 tbsp oilSeasoning Sauce1/4 tsp each salt, pepper and msg1/2 tsp sugar1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp dark soy sauce1 tsp sesame seed oil1 cup water1 tbsp cornstarchÂ + 2 tbsp waterGarnishing - chopped Chinese celery [kin chye] or coriander leavesHeat oil in a non-stick wok, saute ginger until aromatic, add in black beans, soybean paster and chilli boh.Stir to fry until fragrant, addÂ  in the dried glutton.Â  Stir after addition.Â  Add in seasoning sauce and water.Bring to boil, then add in the tofu cubes.Â  Simmer for 5-10 minutes until the flavours are well infused.Thicken with cornstarch mix, bring to boil.Dish up and garnish with Chinese celery or coriander leaves.Â  Serve hot.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #22Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: EIGHT JEWELLED VEGETABLES
text: The Chef of this dish advised that this is a vegetariandish high in protein and hearty in taste that nobody would even miss themeat.Â  The dish looks and tastes so meatyand could be mistaken for a meat dish.As the name implies, there are at least 8 mainingredients in this dish that can be served with rice or porridge or even eatenas a noodle dish.You can try different combination of ingredientsaccording to your preference but always cook the vegetables that the longestfirst before adding other vegetables like snow peas, dried glutton, Enoki mushrooms etc. and stirring after eachaddition.This dish is very tasty with the some sugar add that brings out the overall flavour of the other ingredients.Â  Lovely dish.Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoÂ with modificationsIngredients3 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked, discard the stems and cutstripsÂ¼ cup black fungus - break into small piecesÂ¼ cup dried lily buds â€“ soaked, knotted and snip off thehard ends50 gm red carrots â€“ sliced4 baby corns â€“ cut 1 inch lengths1/2 broccoli - cut small florets1 piece sweet beancurd stick - cut 1 cm width pieces2 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and mushroom flavor sauce1 tsp each sugar, dark soy sauce and sesame seed oilDash of pepper and salt to taste1 cup waterA bundle ofÂ  glassnoodles â€“ soak for 5-10 minutes, drained and cut 3 inch sectionsHeat oil in a non-stick wok, pan fry beancurd stick until golden and crispy.Â  Dish up.Using the same wok,Â Â fry mushrooms, black fungusÂ and lilybuds for Â½ a minute.Add the remaining ingredients according to the orderlisted and stir frying after each addition.Pour in seasoning and bring liquid to a boil beforeadding the noodles.Stir to mix well for 1-2 minutes until ingredients are cooked through.Dish up to serve hot or cold.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #22Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: VEGETARIAN POTATO CURRY
text: This is a fragrant, tasty and non-soupy vegetable curry.  It can be meal on itself spread over a plate of steaming hot rice.  With this recipe, I realised that curries need not have to be prepared in big portions. There is cauliflower and dried glutton pieces that resemble coarsely minced meat in the potato curry.  You can add more curry powder if you like more spicy curry. It taste sourish, savoury and not too spicy.Â  Appetisingly good that you will not missmeaty dishes.Â Â Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoÂ with modificationsIngredients[serves 3-4]1 large potato â€“ boiled till tender, peeled and cubed50 gm dried glutton pieces150 gm cauliflower â€“ cut small piecesA sprig curry flowerÂ½ tbsp tamarind [assam jawa] mix with 1 cup water -strainedCurry Paste [mix]1 tbsp each chilli boh, meat curry powder and blendedlemongrassÂ¼ tsp each turmeric powder and vegetarian mushroomgranules or belacanSeasoningÂ½ tsp salt and sugar to taste1 tsp cooking wine1 tbsp light soy sauceHeat 1-2 tbsp oil in non stick wok,Â  sautÃ© curry paste and curry leaves untilaromatic.Add in the dried glutton pieces, stir to mix well, thenadd in the cauliflower and potato cubes.Stir to mix well, pour in the tamarind juice, bring toboil.Add in the seasoning to taste.Â  Add more water if necessary.Â  Simmer until cauliflower is tender and gravyreduced to thick.Dish up to serve with rice.Â Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #22Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: VEGETARIAN BEAN SPROUT ROLLS
text: According to the Chef, Chinese vegetarians like to makevegetable dishes taste like meat, fish, chicken etc.Â  Whether or not they taste so, this iscertainly a delicious dish like other vegetarian dishes which I tried.Â  Moreover, this is a healthy dish.Â  The rolls can be prepared ahead andrefrigerated .Â  It can be served hot orcold.The garnishing sauce can be prepared ahead by boiling orjust mix and pour over the fried rolls before serving.Â  It is very, very easy dish to prepare.The fried rolls are fragrant and flavoured with the savoury, sourish sauce.Â  Awesome.Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoÂ with modificationsIngredients[makes 8-10 rolls]300 gm bean sprouts â€“ tailed, rinsed and drained50 gm red carrots â€“ peeled and shreddedSome chopped Chinese celery [kin chye]1 piece beancurd skin [foo peh]Seasoning â€“ Â½ tsp salt, Â¼ tsp pepper and 2 tbspcornstarchGarnishing Sauce [combined]Â½ tsp sugar2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp black vinegarÂ¼ tsp dark soy sauceDash of sesame seed oilSome chopped coriander leaves and toasted sesame seedsBlanch beansprouts in hot water, drainedimmediately.Â  Rinse in cold water anddrained.Mix in carrots, celery, salt, pepper and cornstarch.Cut beancurd skin into 6â€x 9â€ pieces.Â  Place beansprout mixture in the centre, rolltightly halfway, fold both ends toward the centre, dab some water along theedges.Â  Roll tightly the remaining half.HeatÂ  1-2 tbsp oilin non stick pan until hot.Â  Turn heat tolow and place the rolls in pan with sides touching.Â  Fry until golden brown.Â  Take care not to burn then.Â  Turn and repeat.When cool, cut into 2 inches sections and arrange on aplatter.Â  Pour garnishing sauce over,garnish with chopped coriander and sesame seeds.Â  Serve.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #22Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: PAN FRY TAU PAU WITH BLACK FUNGUS
text: One of the best ways to cook fresh beancurd skin is to pan fry the pieces until golden brown and crispy.Â  It is crispy outside and soft and moist under the fried surface.Â  In home cooking, I will use pan fry method as less oil is needed.Â  Unless you are prepare a big portion then, deep frying would be a good method.Â  The beancurd skin looks like a sunny up omelette.This recipe here is slightly different from my previous posts.Â  It is a dry version which little sauce.Â  The fresh beancurd skin [tau pau] are lightly coated with cornflour before frying to prevent them from sticking to the pan and making them more crispy.A savoury dish with fragrance of sesame seed oil and ginger.Ingredients6 pieces fresh beancurd skin [round shape]Some soaked black fungus [bok nee]30 gm ginger - cut thin strips2-3 tbsp sesame seed oilSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp cooking wine1 tbsp oyster sauce1/4 tsp sugar2-3 tbsp waterDefrost beancurd skin, press out excess water.Â  Lightly coat each piece with cornflour on both sides.Heat up a non-stick wok with some oil, pan fry tau pau pieces until golden brown on both sides.Â  Dish up.Remove excess oil, add in sesame seed oil, saute ginger until aromatic and crispy.Â  Add in the black fungus and fried tau pau.Pour in seasoning, stir fry to mix ingredients well.Â  Bring to boil and simmer until the tau pau have soaked up the seasoning sauce.Dish up to serve.

title: VEGETARIAN STIR FRY CAULIFLOWER
text: These days, I am enjoying lots of meatless dishes, though simple, they seem to be very appetising to my family members.Â  I need to cook extra rice whenever we have meatless dishes.Â  No idea why but probably because they feel hungry without meaty dishes.Â Meatless dishes are not difficult to prepare but they seem to tasty and delicious just like this dish.Â  Looks colourful, healthy with a combination of 5 colour ingredients and tastes good with the mushroom sauce flavouring.Â As I said, this dish is not difficult to prepare at all.Â  You can just 'agak-agak' the portion of ingredients and increase or decrease the seasoning.Â  It will tastes perfect with rice.IngredientsA few slices ginger2 dried mushrooms - soaked and sliced1-2 pieces beancurd stick - soaked in warm water with a dash of salt for 20 minutes - drained and cut 2 inch sectionssome black fungus - soaked and break into smaller pieces150 gm cauliflower - cut into florets30 gm carrots - peeled and sliced1 stalk celery - peeled and cut slantwise1/2 red capsicum - seeded, cut diamond shapesSeasoning [combined]2 tbsp mushroom sauce [vegetarian oyster sauce]1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and cooking winedash of salt and pepper to taste1 tsp sesame oil1/2 tbsp cornstarchÂ + 2 tbsp water1/2 cup water [more according to preference]Heat a non stick wok with 1 tbsp oil, saute ginger and mushrooms until aromatic.Â  Add in black fungus and beancurd stick.Â  Stir fry after addition for a few seconds.Add inÂ  seasoning [except water and cornstarch], stir to mix well.Â  Pour in water, bring to boil before adding cauliflower and carrots.Â  Stir fry after addition.When vegetables are tender and soft, add in celery and capsicum.Â  Stir to mix well and thicken with cornstarch water.Â  Do not overcooked celery if you want it crunchy.Dish up to serve immediately

title: STIR FRY FRENCH BEANS IN FRAGRANT SAUCE
text: Again, once a year is time for vegetarian meals inconjunction with Nine Emperor Gods Festival.Â In my home vicinity there is a makeshift temple set up to celebrate thefestival in a rather grand scale with numerous temporary vegetarian food stallsalong both sides of the road leading to the temple.The area is full of activities throughout the nine daysstarting from 20 October 2017. Many can get to enjoy vegetarian food notnecessarily for religious reasons.Â  Anyway,my family members have been observing vegetarian meals during the duration ofthe festival for almost 4 generations.A wooden boat loaded with offerings that will be send-off to seaÂ on the 9th day nightThe main reason is because my family members are involved with theyearly send-off of the Nine Emperor Godâ€™s â€˜Boatâ€™ to the sea on the 9thday night from our clan jetty [Ong Jetty, Penang].Â Â  Those involved have to be on vegetarian dietas a respect.Back to this dish, it is a simple stir fry vegetable withfirm beancurd [taukwa] in fragrant sauce.Â  Ittastes savoury, sweet, sourish and fragrant, appetizingly good with steaming hotrice.Â  Anyway, we always enjoy vegetarianmeals during this time with very good appetite no matter how simple the dishesare.Â Â  If you like to try vegetarianfood, do check it out here.Â  These arethe numerous vegetarian dishes which I have prepared over the years.Ingredients2-3 pieces firm beancurd [taukwa] â€“ cut cubes100 gm French Beans â€“ cut Â½ inch lengths1 red chilli â€“ slicedsome chopped or sliced ginger Seasoning Sauce [combined] â€“ can increase the amount formore sauce1 tbsp each light soy sauce, wine and black vinegar1 tsp sugarDash of salt and vegetarian msg [optional]Â½ tsp cornstarch2-3 tbsp waterHeat enough oil in a non-stick wok, fry beancurd cubesuntil crispy and golden brown.Â  Dish up.Remove excess oil, sautÃ© ginger and chillies untilaromatic, then add in French beans.Â  Stirfry until almost cooked through, add in beancurd cubes and seasoning.Stir to mix well.Â Dish up to serve.

title: PINEAPPLE SAMBAL
text: Lookingat this recipe, reminds me of one favourite Malay dish â€˜PajeriÂ  Nenasâ€™ which I used to enjoy during my schooldays.Â  I love the sweet and tenderpineapple slices and the gravy spread over a plate of hot white rice is sosatisfying.Â  Moreover, it was one of thecheapest dishes at the Malay stall of the school canteen.Â  Those days, my pocket money was only RM5.00per week, so at times, need to be frugal and thrifty.Thisrecipe is a bit different as it has more ingredients, all of which makes thisdish as good and delicious. Ingredients50gm anchovies â€“ split and rinsed several times, drain1small pineapple â€“ cut wedges and sliced1piece tempeh â€“ cut 1cm x 3cm pieces1large onions â€“ peeled and sliced 2star anise2-3tbsp blended red chilli 1tsp belacan granulesSaltand sugar to tasteJuiceof 5 calamansi lime200ml waterDeepfry tempeh slices until golden brown, dish up.Â Using the same oil, fry anchovies until crispy and dish up.Removeexcess oil.Â  Leave about 2 tbsp oil, sautÃ©blended chillies, star anise, and belacan granules until oilseparates.Â  Add in pineapple slices and onions, stirfry to mix well, add water.Â  Bring toboil until pineapple has softened, add in seasoning to taste.Addin fried tempeh and anchovies, stir to mix well.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Dishup to serve.

title: SPLASHED EGGS
text: This is a very simple egg dish where hard boiled eggs areshallow fried to brown and splashed with sauce.According to the chef, â€™splashingâ€™ is of the many supportiveor auxillary methods of cooking which are no self-sufficient cookingmethods.Â  Splashing is abruptly pour liquids[water, wine or seasoning] over food toward the end of Stir-frying or ShallowFrying.Â  Because splashing is done whenfood is very hot, it absorbs the flavor in a special way which makes the tastequite exciting.Â  Splashing wine [1teaspoon] towards the end of any stir-frying or shallow frying, it does makethe taste different.Splashing Liquid Over Fried FoodÂ Another recipe which applies this splashing method wasearlier sharedÂ [here].This egg dish is easy and fool-proof yet the result isawesome, yummy, yummy good.Â Â  You cancook up to 8 eggs with this sauce.Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoÂ with modificationsIngredients[serves 3]8 hard-boiled eggsSplashing Sauce [Mix together]1 tbsp each of chopped ginger, garlic and spring onions[I used more]Â½ Â tsp salt2 tsp sugar2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp black vinegar1 tbsp wine1 tsp sesame seed oil [optional]Peel eggs and split into halves.Combine sauce ingredients.Heat a non stick wok with 1-2 tbsp of oil untilÂ  hot, swirl the wok to distribute the oil.Â  Lower to medium heat, place the eggs, cutside down and fry until brown.Â Â  Turn andrepeat.Â Â Pour combined sauce over fried eggs, then off heat and dish up to serve.Serve hot or cold.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #22Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: PEACH DOLL MOONCAKE WITH MEAT FLOSS [å…¬ä»”é¥¼]
text: The original recipe is from Huang KitchenÂ [Fish Doll Mooncakes â€“ Kung Chai Peng å…¬ä»”é¥¼]. For this recipe, I have used the peach shape mould [AKK mould] as I thought of making bigger size doll mooncakes.These doll mooncakes are lovely with a combination of nuts, seeds and meat floss.  Itâ€™s crunchy, sweet and savoury with this combination of ingredients.  The sweetness is acceptable to me [not that sweet]. Â AFTER AIRING FOR SEVERAL DAYSJUST BAKED AND BEFORE AIRINGThe dough is soft and not sticky, easy to shape and mould. Â Mooncakes will be hard and soften only after resting for few days.Recipe adapted from Huang Kitchen with modificationsIngredients[makes 22 pieces]Ingredients A-Golden Syrup Mixture375 gm golden syrup150 gm peanut oilÂ½ tbsp alkaline water [lye water]1 tbsp plain flourIngredients B-Mooncake Dough Mixture500 gm plain flour or cake flour25 gm toasted melon seeds25 gm toasted white sesame seeds1/4 cup toasted and chopped walnutsIngredients C-Mooncake FillingÂ 100 gm meat flossEgg Wash/Glaze - 1  egg yolk + 1 tbsp waterCombine and mix golden syrup, peanut oil, alkaline water and 1 tbsp flour in a deep container.  Stir to mix well, cover and set aside for a few hours [I leave it overnight].Combine  all the dry ingredients in a mixing bowl and stir to mix well.Add slowly into the golden syrup mixture. Mix with a spatula to form a soft dough.  Do Not Knead the dough. Cover with lid and set aside for 2 hours [I leave it overnight].Divide dough into small portions according to the size of the mould used. Roll into balls.  Wrap about one teaspoon of meat floss in each dough ball. Pinch dough to secure the seam, then roll again into round shape. Lightly dust a mooncake mould and place rolled dough in the mould and press.  Tap gently to dislodge the dough from the mould. Place on a baking tray lined with parchment paper.Repeat the same with the rest of the mooncake dough.Â Bake the mooncakes in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 10-15 minutes.Remove to cool on wire rack for 15 minutes before brushing the top with egg glaze.  Brush sparingly.Â Return to oven and continue to bake for another 15 minutes or until just golden brown.  Remove  to  cool on wire rack and leave to cool completely before storing in air tight containers.Â How To prepare egg wash*Mix 1 egg yolk and 1 tbsp water, then strain through a fine sieve.

title: WALNUT MOONCAKE BISCUITS
text: Last year I tried this mooncake biscuit recipe [Cranberries Mooncake Biscuits]Â and itâ€™s good recipe where we can enjoy a doll mooncake with some dried fruits and seeds.This year, I tried another mooncake biscuit recipe from the same book with addition of toasted walnuts and brown sugar.  I have replaced the brown sugar with Jaggery sugar [gula merah] and the result is good.These biscuits turned out well and nice as the sweetness is perfect for those who love doll mooncakes but afraid of the sweetness.Â  They are soft after airing for several days.This is a lovely nutty doll mooncake biscuits which definitely is nice for a snack and better still served with Chinese tea.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 102 [makes 32 pieces]Ingredients A240 gm golden syrup75 ml peanut oil1/2 tbsp alkaline waterIngredients B380 gm plain flour + 1/2 tsp baking sodaIngredients C100 gm toasted walnuts lightly crushed100 gm brown sugar [I replaced it with 50 gm Jaggery sugar]Glaze1 egg â€“ lightly beaten1.     Combine ingredients A in a mixing bowl and mix well.  Add in ingredients B, stir well [do not over mix].  Add in ingredients C, mix well.2.     Cover the bowl with cling film and leave to rest for at least 30 minutes.  Divide dough into small portions, flatten slightly and arrange on a lined baking tray [leave some space in between as the dough will spread a little].Â  The design does not stay after baking.3.     Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 10 minutes.  Remove to cool for 15 minutes before applying egg glaze.4.     Return biscuits to oven and continue to bake for 15 minutes or until golden brown.5.     Remove from oven, leave to cool and air for several days for storing.

title: STUFFED BEAN CURD
text: The original recipe is a big portion using about 12pieces of firm beancurd.Â  I have reducedit to only 4 which is one third portion.Â For the stuffing, you can substitute pork with prawns and vice versaaccording to own preference.Â  If usingpork add 1 tablespoon of dried shrimps [rinsed and minced] and omit the salt.The water chestnuts are crunchy and blends well with thenice aroma of fresh prawns, usually sweet.Â The fried bean curd is aromatic and goes well with the simple sauce ingredients.Â  Homey dish.Â If you have leftover stuffing ingredient, it can be used as stuffing forfried tofu puffs or as topping for steamed shiitake mushrooms, too.Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoÂ with modificationsIngredients[serves 3-4]4 pieces firm beancurd â€“ cut each squares diagonally intotrianglesSome chopped spring onions or leeks for garnishingÂ½ tbsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp water - thickeningSauce Ingredients1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and wineDash of msg and pepper100 ml waterStuffing Ingredients100 gm prawn meat â€“ coarsely minced1-2 water chestnuts â€“ crushed and chopped1 tsp chopped ginger1 tbsp chopped spring onionsDash of salt and pepper to tasteÂ¼ tsp sesame seed oilCombine the stuffing ingredients well into a paste.Make a slit along the long side of the beancurd trianglesand fill it with some stuffing.Â  Finishdoing the same for all the triangles.Heat up a non stick wok with some oil.Â  Over medium heat, stand the triangles withthe opened side down in oil.Â  Fry untillight brown before turning to brown the 2 sides of the beancurd triangles.Â  Remove excess oil before adding the sauceingredients.Â Bring to boil, stir inthickening and throw in some chopped spring onions or leeks.Dish up to serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #21Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: LOTUS PASTE DOLL MOONCAKES
text: This doll [figurine] mooncake dough recipe is similar to my earlier postingÂ Peach Doll Mooncakes. Â As mentioned in my earlier post, this dough recipe is a keeper. Â You can make use of it to make any shapes of your choices and is endless. Â Aunty YoungÂ has made numerous lovely doll Â mooncakes with this dough which is easy to handle and mould. Â The dough is soft and moist, does not stick to the mould.Here, I have used a small size mooncake mould to shape the dough with sesame seeds topping.Ingredients[makes 40 pieces]350 gm plain flour - sifted230 gm golden syrup100 gm peanut oil5 gm alkaline water [1 tsp]150 gm lotus seed pasteFor surfacesome toasted sesame seeds1 egg + 1 tbsp milk, mix well and strained.In a mixing bowl, add in syrup, peanut oil, alkaline water and lotus seed paste.  Stir mix until well combine.Add in sifted flour and form dough. Cover the dough with a cloth and rest for 2 - 3 hours.Divide the dough into portions that fits the mould you are using.   Roll each into a ball.  Press in some sesame seeds. Press the dough into the plastic mould.  Tap lightly to unmould.   Arrange in a baking tray.For vegetarian version, bake mooncake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 20-25 minutes or until golden brown.Â After allowing the mooncake to cool on a metal rack, it can be kept in an air-tight container. It can be kept up to weeks if it is dry enough after baking.For non-vegetarian version, bake mooncake for 10 minutes, remove from oven, leave tray of mooncake to cool for 10-15 minutes.  Apply sparingly egg glaze.  Return to oven and bake for another 10 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool in a tray before storing.  Mooncake will be soft after resting for several days.

title: EGGS AND SCALLIONS
text: The Chef of this dish has asked â€˜Who says a Chinese meal has to be complicated?â€™  If you canâ€™t think of anything else for dinner, try this simple, easy and pleasing dish.   Just add a stir fried vegetable and a pot of hot rice, dinner is ready.My answer is â€˜Not At Allâ€™ after trying this dish.  Yes, Chinese meal  arenâ€™t complicated and difficult, most important is, eat it right away, you are sure to enjoy a satisfactory meal.Â I served this fluffy fried egg with a stir fried bok choy and braised pork belly on a weekend.  We enjoyed it very much.   This plate of scrambled eggs is fragrant, soft and moist.  Best of all, it is packedwith proteins and economical, too.Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoÂ with modificationsIngredients[serves 3]3 eggs2 stalks scallions [spring onions] â€“ choppedÂ½ tsp salt to taste2 tbsp oilChop scallions.Â Mix eggs with salt.Â  Beat well.Heat a non stick wok with oil until smoking hot.Â  Swirl the oil to coat the wok.Pour in the eggs and stir quickly continuously until set.Dish up on serving plate.Â Serve hot.Â  Sprinkle some choppedred chillies if preferred.Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #21Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: PASTRY MOONCAKE WITH MUNGBEAN/MEAT FLOSS
text: This recipe is adapted from Yum Yum Magazine Issue No.102.Â  I used the pastry mooncake skinrecipe from their Three Coloured Sweet Potato Mooncake recipe.Â  The pastry dough is similar to cookie doughand is easy to handle.The pastry is crispy and can be used to bake any kind ofpastry mooncakes with various fillings of your choice.This pastry mooncake recipe is a keeper.Â  I will use it in future with other types ofmooncake fillings.Ingredients[makes 16 medium size pastry mooncakes]150 gm butter100 gm icing sugarA pinch of salt2 eggs300 gm plain flour60 gm milk powder20 gm custard powder1 tsp baking powderFillings â€“ mungbean paste [store bought]Some crispy meat flossSome egg glaze and melon seedsSkin: Beat butter and icing sugar until soft in a mixingbowl. Add in eggs one at a time and beat until well mixed.Â  Fold in the flour ingredients and mix into adough.Â  Set aside in the fridge.Meanwhile, divide filling into 16 equal portions [about 20gm].Â  Roll into rounds and wrap meatfloss with paste.Divide pastry dough into 16 equal portions [about 40 gmeach] and wrap up filling.Â Â  Arrange ontoa baking tray lined with parchment paper.Â Brush egg glaze over pastry and decorate with some melon seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes oruntil golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing or cut intopieces to serve.

title: SHRIMP OMELET
text: This is a lovely omelet with a twist and veryversatile.Â  You can substitute theshrimps with pork, beef, crabmeat [fresh or canned].Â  The fluffy egg omelet is light, soft andmoist and aromatic.Â  It is a simpleomelet served with the fried bean sprouts, shrimps and light sauce that lookstempting and delicious to the young and old.Â Good flavor.I would definitely try this recipeÂ  again with other substitutes mentionedabove.Â  I believe it would turned outawesome.Recipe adapted fromÂ â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™Â Cookbook by Madame Yee Yo with some modificationsIngredients[serves 3]50 gm prawn meat â€“ coarsely chopped3 eggs50 gm bean sprouts â€“ tailed, rinsed and drained1-2 stalks spring onions â€“ choppedSauce Combined125 ml water or stockÂ¼ tsp dark soy sauceÂ½ tsp sesame oilDash of salt and pepper to taste1 tsp cornstarchMarinate shrimps with some salt, pepper, wine andcornstarch. Â Mix well.In a bowl, mix together Â 1 tsp flour, 1 tsp water and Â¼ tsp salt.Â  Add in the eggs and beat until foamy.Heat 1 tbsp oil in a non-stick wok, sautÃ© shrimps untilfirm, add in bean sprouts and spring onions.Â Quickly stir to cook, do not overcook.Â Â Dish up onto serving platter without liquid.Â  Drain liquid into sauce mixture.Heat 1 tbsp oil in a non-stick pan, pour in the eggmixture to fry.Â  Cover to cook overmedium heat until the edges are crispy and firm, flip over to fry the other sideuntil omelet is cooked through.Dish up and place on top of fried bean sprouts.Using the same pan, bring sauce ingredients to boil untilthick, pour over omelet.Serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #21Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: FISH FRAGRANT EGGPLANT
text: According to the Chef Madame Yee Ho of this cookbook,thereÂ  are 21 distinct flavours inSzechuan cuisine.Â  The best known areGung Bao, Peppery Hot, Sour Hot, Garlic Sauce, Ginger Sauce, Five Fragrant, OddFlavour and Fish Fragrant.Â  No matter howhard you try, this dish never tastes fishy.Â It is called Fish Fragrant because the original recipe called for oil inwhich fish was fried.Anyway, without the fried fish oil, this stir fried eggplantlooks tempting and delicious.Â  I havemodified the recipe a little to make it simple and easy hoping not tocompromise the taste and flavor.This dish is good, flavourful soft eggplant and minced meat and prawns are tasty, a little spicy, sweet and savoury.Recipe adapted from â€˜You Can Cook Anything Chineseâ€™ byMadame Yee Yo with modificationsIngredients500 gm Chinese eggplant50 gm minced meat50 gm minced prawns [can use all meat]1 tbsp each of chopped garlic and ginger1 stalk spring onions â€“ chopped1 tbsp preserved soy bean paste [taucheong] â€“ chopped1 tsp chilli boh [you can use 1 tbsp dao ban jiang]SeasoningÂ¼ tsp salt1 tsp each of black vinegar, wine and honey1 tbsp light soy sauce80 ml water1 tsp sesame oilÂ Heat 2 tbsp oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© ginger, Â garlic and spring onions until aromatic. Addin taucheong and chilli boh.Â Â  Stir fryuntii fragrant.Add in minced meat and prawns, stir fry until meat/prawnsare firm, then add in eggplant.
