Stir fry to mix well, then add in seasoning and water.Â  Mix well.Cover to cook for 5-10 minutes and stirring in betweencooking.Â  Add more water if you prefersome gravy for this dish.Uncover and sprinkle spring onions when eggplant aresoft.Dish up to serve.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #21Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: CANTONESE PICKLES
text: This recipe is from a very old recipe book published inTaiwan from my collection of food recipes.Â Â Looking at the year of publication, it is not less than 30 yearsold.Â  There are numerous recipes and thechef apart from sharing food recipes also shares much knowledge about Chinesecooking.Â  It is a valuable reference bookfor novice cooks.According to the Chef, the pickled vegetables are sweet,sour and crunchy.Â  It tastes refreshingafter a rich meal and is used in sweet and sour dishes.Â  This pickle keeps well in refrigerator forseveral weeks.Great to serve this pickle with fried meats.Recipe adapted from the book â€˜You Can Cook AnythingChineseâ€™ by Madame Yee YoIngredients[serves 3-4]1 red carrot - peel1 white carrot - peel1 zuchini 1 tsp saltSeasoning3 thin slices of ginger3 tbsp each of sugar and white vinegar1 small red chilli â€“ slicedRoll cut the carrots and zucchini.Â  Mix in salt and let them stand at roomtemperature for about 4 hours.Â  Stiroccasionally.Â  Drain. Squeeze out anddiscard excess liquid in vegetables.Combine ingredients with seasoning, add in chilli.Â  Mix well and chill in the refrigerator forseveral hours or overnight.Â  Stiroccasionally.Â  May be kept in therefrigerator for several weeks.Â I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #21Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: EZCR#105-FRIED TUNA PUMPKIN NOODLES
text: Fried noodle is quick to prepare especially during busydays or when the â€˜lazy bugâ€™ comes and you are not in the mood to cook anythingmore. Â Many people will recommend to eatout but when most of your family members are already having their first twomeals of the day outside, they would love to enjoy a meal of home-cooked food when theyreached home.This fried noodle was what I prepared for my family whenthe above situation happens.Â Â  I came upwith this noodle for dinner with whatever available ingredients in hand.Â  I didnâ€™t measure the exact portion of eachingredients, so itâ€™s â€˜agak-agakâ€™ only.Â  The fried tuna beehoon is light and tasty but didnâ€™t looktempting all because of the pumpkin colour, otherwise it would look but ittastes good.Ingredients[serves 3]Â½ packet of rice vermicelli [beehoon] â€“ soaked for 5-10minutes, drained1 can tuna flakes â€“ drain away the oilSome shredded mushroomsSome shredded cabbageSome shredded pumpkinSome pumpkin pureeSome spring onions â€“ cut into sectionsSome chopped Chinese celery [optional]Seasoning Salt, pepper and cooking wine to tasteHeat a non-stick wok with some oil [depends on theportion of ingredients], fry mushrooms, tuna, spring onions untilaromatic.Â  Add in cabbage to fry, thenpour in some water.Â  Add in pumpkinpureed if using.Bring to boil, add seasoning to taste.Add in beehoon, toss well and more water if it is toodry.Â  Add in pumpkin, cover to cook for 5minutes.Â  Uncover wok, Â lightly toss noodles Â to mix well the ingredients.Dish up to serve with cut chillies, garnish with choppedcelery or coriander leaves or spring onions.

title: EZCR#102-FRIED CHICKEN WITH ASSORTED VEGETABLES
text: A word of caution, this kind of dishes is not suitable for small eaters unless you it as a One Dish Meal. Â Just a small portion of each ingredient, you can end up with a big portion to serve many.Luckily, we are 3 great eaters and managed to finish it in a meal.The fried chicken pieces are tender, tasty and goes well with the assorted ingredients. Â Do not overcook the celery and lotus roots to keep them crunchy. You can substitute the vegetables with other vegetables like asparagus, fresh mushrooms, snow peas etc. Â Best to serve this dish immediately.Ingredients[serves 3-4]1 large deboned chicken whole leg - cut thick strips2 dried mushrooms - soaked and sliced2 stems of celery - sliced slantwise1 small section of lotus root - sliced thinly and blanched50 gm red carrots - sliced1 red chilli - sliced2 cloves garlic - sliced1 stalk spring onions - cut sectionsSeasoning1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and winedash of pepper and msg1 tbsp fermented black beans [tau see] - Â rinsed and drainedMarinate chicken pieces with 1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, wine and 1/4 tsp sugar. Â Mix well, then add 1 tbsp of egg, stir to mix and add in 1 tbsp cornstarch. Â Mix well.Heat a non stick wok with 1 tbsp oil, pan fry chicken pieces until brown. Â Dish up.Using the same wok, saute garlic, red chill Â and some spring onions until aromatic. Â Add in the mushrooms and stir fry for a minute before adding the vegetables and seasoning [except the tau see] and some water.Â Quickly, stir fry to mix then add in the chicken pieces and tau see. Â Toss well and dish up when all ingredients are cooked.Dish up to serve immediately.

title: EZCR#101-STEAMED CHICKEN GLUTINOUS RICE
text: This recipe is adapted from a Lotus Leaf Wrap Chicken GlutinousRice recipe.Â  I have modified the recipeby not using lotus leaf and substituting a portion of the glutinous rice withplain rice.Â  I know there are many peoplewho love to eat rice dumplings but suffer from glutinous rice intolerance.Â  This steamed rice with a small portion of glutinous rice may be suitable for them.The steamed rice is fragrant, tasty and delicious,suitable as a One Dish Meal.Â  It isperfect to serve this with any vegetable soup or pickled vegetable [cucumber,carrots or cabbage].Ingredients[serves 3-4]200 gm rice â€“ washed and drained100 gm glutinous rice â€“ soaked for several hours anddrained1 large deboned chicken whole leg â€“ cut into thick strips3 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked and cut strips1 tbsp dried prawns â€“ rinsed and drained2-3 shallots â€“ peeled and slicedMarinade â€“ 1 tbsp wine, dash of salt, pepper and msgSeasoning3 tbsp each of light soy sauce and wineÂ¼ tsp msgDash of pepper and salt to tasteMarinate chicken with marinade.Heat 1-2 tbsp oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© shallots until fragrant and crispy. Push aside, sautÃ© dried prawns and mushrooms until fragrant, then add in chicken pieces. Stir fry to mix well.Â Add in glutinous rice, stir fry until rice turns translucent, then add in plain rice and seasoning. Stir fry to mix well for several minutes. Off heat.Â Dish up rice into 3 steaming cans. Add in enough water to cook rice [about less than 1 cm above rice level or depends on quality of rice used].Â Steam rice for at least 30 minutes or until cooked through. Leave rice for about 5-10 minutes.Â Transfer to a serving plate, invert can to dislodge rice. Serve immediately.

title: EZCR#100 - BRAISED CHICKEN WITH WOLFBERRIES [KEI CHEE]
text: This is again an easy and simple chicken dish yet tastyand delicious.Â  It is especially suitablefor Autumn season where fresh dates can be used to cook this dish.Â  I have substituted it with red dates.The combination of red dates, wolfberries and shaoxingwine bring about an aromatic dish, great to serve with rice.Â  The meaty chicken pieces are sweet and savoury withthe aroma of the wine. Â For this dish, no water is added. Â The thick gravy is a combination of light soy sauce, wine and juices from the chicken meat. Â Awesome and simple fried chicken dish, Chinese style.Ingredients1 large deboned chicken whole leg with skin and fatsremoved â€“ cut into bite size pieces5-6 red dates â€“ rinsed, seeded and sliced1 tbsp wolfberries [kei chee] â€“ rinsed and soak in 1 tbspwine20 gm shredded ginger1 tbsp chopped garlic1 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp light soy sauceÂ¼ tsp sugar or dash of msg50 ml shaoxing wineHeat oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© shredded ginger, garlic and sliced red dates until aromatic.Add in the chicken pieces and continue to fry until the meat changed colour to white and firm. Add in Shaoxing wine.Â Add in the seasoning, stir fry to mix well.Â Add in kei chee then cover to let it continue cooking for 5-10 minutes. No water is needed to cook the chicken pieces.Â Uncover, dish up and serve hot.

title: BAKED TAPIOCA CAKE
text: Baked Tapioca Cake aka Cassava Cake is my family and my favourite Kuih of all Kuihs. Â This recipe is quite similar to my earlier post on this kuih. Â I was tempted to bake this kuih because the fresh tapioca was selling so cheap at Tesco for only RM0.99 cents a kilo.I have baked it in 2 portions in a loaf pan and aluminium foil as I intend to give away a portion to a relative. Â The cake should look tall and nice if I had baked it in a 7 inch square tin.The kuih is not too sweet and packed with grated tapioca. Â No flour is added and the sweetness is acceptable to me with the lovely aroma of grated tapioca. Â  My hubby says it's nice and he can have more because the sweetness is acceptable.This is an easy baked kuih to make but the only tedious part is the grating. Â However, you can blend the fresh tapioca with a little water in the blender to form into a paste.Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum MagazineÂ with modificationsModified Recipe600 gm grated tapioca100 gm grated white coconut150 ml thick coconut milk150 gm caster sugar75 ml melted butter2 eggs1/2 tsp saltA 20 cm square tin, lined and greased at the sides or 2 small loaf pansCombine all the ingredients [except melted butter] until well mix and sugar dissolves. Lastly add in melted butter, mix well.Pour into baking container and bake in a preheated oven at 180 degrees C for about 1 hour or until cooked through [test with a skewer] and top is golden brown.Remove to cool in the pan before slicing to serve.

title: SAUTEED PORK WITH SPRING ONIONS
text: This is a rather easy and simple meat dish to prepare yetthe taste is delicious.It is a homey dish and kind of a motherâ€™s signature dish for mostfamilies but my mum prepares it without addition of black pepper.Â  The addition of this ingredient does give itan added aroma and taste.Â The meat slices are aromatic, tasty and I love the spring onions. Â Add more if you like the fragrance and sweetness of spring onions. Best to use really tender meat because this is a pan fry dish without braised. Â Recipe adapted from Chinese Cuisine Cookbook withmodificationsIngredients300 gm pork tenderloin â€“ cut Â¼ inch thickness1 stalk spring onion â€“ cut into sectionsMarinade3 cloves garlic â€“ finely chopped1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp cooking wineÂ½ tsp sugar1 tbsp cornstarchSeasoningÂ½ tsp sugarÂ¼ tsp msgÂ¼ tsp ground black pepper1 tsp sesame seed oil1 tbsp light soy sauceTenderise the meat slices and season with marinade for atleast 30 minutes.Pan fry marinated pork with 2-3 tablespoons of oil untilgolden brown and cooked through on both sides over medium heat.Add inseasoning and green onions.Â  Stir fry tomix well and heated through. Â Sprinkle some water if you think it is a little dry but the seasoning is just coat the meat.Dish up to serve.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #19Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: FRIED SHRIMP BALLS
text: This kind of shrimp balls is type which I remembered having them during my childhood days where the economy rice stalls used to sell them with a plain gravy. Â They looked plain but tastes good. We paid about 20 cents for a few pieces with gravy and a plate of white rice. Â This plate of goody was our breakfast and we never got tired eating them.These shrimp balls are not crispy but they are chewy and has the aroma and taste of prawns. Â Simple and nice. Â You can just nibble them with satisfaction.Recipe adapted from Chinese Cuisine Cookbook with modificationsIngredients[serves 6]300 gm prawns - shelled and chopped fine1/4 tsp each of msg, baking powder and ground black pepper1/2 tsp salt1 tsp cooking wine1 egg125 gm all purpose flour2 tbsp water1 tsp oil1 tsp grated gingersome chopped spring onionsMix chopped prawns with the seasoning ingredients, then add in the egg. Â Mix well before stirring in the flour, water and oil.Lastly add in the chopped spring onions. Â Lightly stir to combine.Heat up enough oil in a wok or small saucepan [saves oil] over medium heat. Â Drop batter by spoonfuls to fry until golden brown or cooked through. Â Fry shrimp balls in batches.Dish up and drain on kitchen paper.Serve immediately with or without chilli sauce.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #19Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: BLACK PEPPER PORK BELLY AND TROTTER
text: This is a braised soy sauce pork dish which is a littledifferent from the usual.Â  Apart from theusual spice condiments, the seasoning has an additional ingredient, that is,tomato sauce.Â  It is ratherdifferentÂ  in taste withÂ  black pepper and tomato sauce.I have prepared a double portion of this recipe for myfamily gathering.Â  You can use only porkbelly for this recipe.Recipe adapted from Feminine Magazine No. 585 withmodificationsIngredients500 gm pork belly and pig trotter [meaty part] â€“ blanchedand cut into pieces.250 ml water30 gm julienne gingerSpiced Condiments1 star aniseÂ½ inch cinnamon stick1 bulb garlic â€“ with skin15 gm rock sugarÂ½ tsp salt1-2 tbsp soy sauce1 tbsp dark soy sauceSeasoning Sauce1 tbsp ground black pepper1 tbsp sugarÂ½ tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp tomato sauceThickening Sauce â€“ 1 tbsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp water [optional]Heat a non stick wok with a tablespoon oil, saute ginger until aromatic, add in meat pieces to fry until slightly brown.Add in spiced condiment ingredients, stir fry to mix well. Add in seasoning sauce and Â continue to stir fry until meat pieces are well coated with the seasoning sauce before adding water.Bring to boil, cover and then simmer until meat is tender and sauceis reduced or thicken with thickening sauce.Serve with rice or reheat before serving.

title: DICED CHICKEN WITH DRIED CHILLIES
text: I think this is the simplest â€˜Gong Pao Chi Tingâ€™ recipe thatI have came across.Â  It is too simple tobelieve with only 2 main ingredients [Chicken meat and dried chillies] and aseasoning sauce.Â Perhaps, this isbecause the recipe is from a very old recipe book where the recipes are allvery simple [no frills].Â  There is noonions, spring onions, capsicum, some usual accompaniments added but I did add some garlic becauseIÂ  thought the garlic would be good withthe sauce.This fragrant dish tastes awesome, savoury and spicy. Â Perfect with plain white rice.Recipe adapted from Chinese Cuisine CookbookIngredients[serves 3]2 large deboned chicken whole legs â€“ cut into Â½ inch cubesMarinade â€“ 1 tbsp light soy sauce, Â½ tbsp cooking wine and 1heaped tbsp cornstarch10 dried red chillies â€“ soakedÂ  to soften and cut small sectionsSome crushed garlic [optional]Seasoning Sauce [combined]Â¼ tsp msgÂ 1 tbsp eachÂ  sugar andÂ water1 tsp each wine,Â  darkvinegar,Â  sesame oil and cornstarch1 Â½ tbsp light soy saucePound the meat lightly and cut into cubes.Â  Season with marinade for 20 minutes.Heat 1 tbsp oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© dried chilliesover medium heat until aromatic, add in garlic, stir fry before adding chicken.Continue to fry until well done [about a minutes], then addin the seasoning.Stir until sauce is bubbly and coats the chicken pieceswell.Dish up to serve. Garnish with sliced cucumbers.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #19Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: HOME STYLE STEWED CHICKEN
text: Home style stewed chicken is a dish most mothers willcooked for her children or family gathering in a big portion.Â  The original recipe uses a whole chicken thatweighs about 1.2 kg but here I have reduced it to just 2 chicken whole legs fora small family.It is a dish, perfect after resting, can be prepared in advance and needs reheating just before serving.Â  Â Â This dishis tasty and the other ingredients like mushrooms, lily buds and black fungusare all so flavourful as they absorbs the tasty sauce.Â  A good, homeydish to serve with plain rice.Recipe adapted from Chinese Cuisine Cookbook withmodificationsIngredients[serves 3]2 deboned chicken whole legs â€“ season with 1 tbsp lightsoy sauce5-6 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked20 gm dried lily budsÂ - soaked and knotted, cut off the hard tips20 gm black fungus â€“ soaked and break into pieces50 gm red carrot â€“ cut floret slicesA few slices ginger1 stalk spring onions â€“ cut into sectionsÂ½ tsp sesame oil250 ml waterSeasoning Â½ tsp each of salt and sugarÂ¼ tsp black pepper1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp cooking wineDash of msgÂ½ tbsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp waterHeat Â½ tbsp oil in a non stick wok, pan fry chicken wholelegs [skin side first] to brown nicely.Â Dish up.Using the same wok, sautÃ© gingerÂ  and some spring onions until fragrant, add inmushrooms, black fungus, lilybuds and carrots.Â Stir fry to mix well, add in seasoning.Â Toss well, place fried chicken pieces on top, pour in water, bring toboil.Lower heat to braise until chicken is cooked and saucereduced or thickened with cornstarch water.Â Drizzle in sesame oil.Dish up, slice braised chicken pieces and placed on topof the remaining ingredients.Â  Pour oversauce and serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #19Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: SWEET AND SOUR PORK [GU LAO ROU å’•å™œè‚‰ ]
text: This is my second posting for Sweet and Sour Porkdish.Â  It is a simple dish and not that difficultto prepare yet the result is awesome. Â As the name implies, the sauce is sweet and sour andblends perfect with the crispy fried meat pieces.Â  There is only one thing to note, if thepineapples you add in is very sweet, you can reduce the sugar a littleotherwise you may find it too sweet to your taste buds.Â  I find the sweetness acceptable but my hubbymentioned it is too sweet.Â  Anyway, servewith plain white rice, it is tasty good.Lovely home-cooked Gu Lao Rou, crispy meat in sweet andsour sauce ,crispy capsicum and sweet pineapple slices.Recipe adapted from Chinese Cuisine CookbookIngredients[serves 3-4]300 gm pork tenderloin â€“ slice Â½ cm thick piecesMarinade1 tbsp Â light soysauce, dash of pepper, 1 egg yolk and 1 tbsp cornstarch3 tbsp potato starch or more1 red chilli â€“ seeded and cut wedges1 green capsicum â€“ seeded and cut wedges1 slice ripe pineapple â€“ cut wedgesEnough oil for fryingSauce [combined]3 tbsp each vinegar, tomato sauce, sugar and water1/3 tsp salt1 tbsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp waterSeason meat slices with marinade for at least 20minutes, then coat with potato starch before frying.Heat enough oil in a deep pan, deep fry meat slices untilcooked and crispy for about 3 minutes. Â Â Drain.Â Reheat oil, return fried meat to fry again until crispy [optional].Â  Drain.In Â a separate wok,pour in sauce, bring to boil then add in all the cut ingredients.Â  Toss well and add in crispy fried meat.Â  Mix thoroughly to coat well.Dish up, serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #19Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: SHREDDED CHICKEN WITH SESAME SAUCE
text: This is one of the Chinese dishes which I chose toprepare from this monthâ€™s selected cookbook for Cookbook Countdown Event #19.It is an easy and simple dish to prepare.Â  The shredded chicken meat is tender andsweet.Â  The sauce is easy to prepare, fragrantand tasty spread over the shredded meat.This is a lovely chicken dish.Recipe adapted from Chinese Cuisine CookbookIngredients1 large deboned chicken whole leg Â½ tbsp each chopped ginger, garlic andÂ  spring onionsÂ½ tbsp hot chilli oilBlended Sauce1-2 tbsp toasted white sesame seeds1 tbsp each light soy sauce and black vinegar1 tsp each sugar and sesame seed oilBring a pot of water to boil, add in chicken whole leg tocook. Bring to boil again, then off heat.Â Leave chicken whole leg to steep for 5-10 minutes until cookedthrough.Â  Remove to cool beforeshredding.Meanwhile, put sauce ingredients in a blender to blenduntil fine and thick.Â  Mix with choppedgarlic and ginger.Arrange shredded chicken on serving platter, spread sauceon top, drizzle hot pepper oil and garnish with spring onions.Serve.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #19Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: EZCR#99 - CHINESE  PEAR, LONGAN & RED DATES DESSERT
text: This is an awesome â€™tong suiâ€™ for dessertÂ  lovers who love desserts butÂ  afraid of the sugar content in â€˜tongsuiâ€™.Â  The main reason is that this sweetdessert is without sugar added.Â  The sweetnesscomes from the ingredients itself [Chinese pear, dried longans and reddates].Â  Unbelievable when I saw that there isno sugar in the recipe and was thinking it could be a typo error.Â  There is no error, really no sugar is neededfor this dessert. Â It is sweet enough without the sugar.Moreover, I was told that this dessert is very suitable forwomen folks, blood circulation and anti-aging. It is good to be takenduringÂ  Autumn and Winter seasons.Â  Why this is good, I have no idea but if youlike to confirm the facts, do check up the Wikipedia for the health benefits ofthe 3 main ingredients, hahaha!.Anyway,I donâ€™t mind having this dessert throughoutÂ the year because of its so called benefits and it is so easy to prepare, too.Â  Just dump everything into the slow cooker,wait for 2-3 hours and the lovely dessert is ready to be enjoyed.Ingredients1 Chinese Pear â€“ peeled, deseeded and cut big cubes10 red dates â€“ halve if using big ones50 gm dried longan â€“ rinsed and drained600-700 ml water PlaceÂ  Chinese pearand red dates in a slow cooker.Â  Pour inhot water, turn to high, cover and leave to cook forÂ  over an hour before adding the dried longans.Continue to cook until longans are plump up.Â  Taste to adjust the sweetness [add sugar ifnecessary].Serve hot, warm or chilled.

title: STEAMED PORK WITH MEI CAI
text: I prepared this dish to serve with porridge.Â  Quick and easy steamed meat/vegetable dishthat is tasty and delicious, though dull looking. Â The savoury taste of the meat cake is appetisingly good with rice too.The minced meat is tasty while the preserved vegetable[sweet mei cai] is sweet on its on with a savoury taste from theseasoning.Â  A fragrant dish that smellsgreat with the addition of ginger, garlic, sesame oil and wine.Â  Using the minced meat with a little fat willmake this dish perfect.Ingredients200 gm minced meat 100 gm preserved sweet vegetable [mei cai] â€“ rinsed severaltimes, soaked for 5 minutes and choppedSome chopped spring onions1 tsp each chopped ginger and garlicSeasoningÂ¼ tsp each salt, sugar and pepper1 tsp each light soy sauce, cooking wine, sesame oil andcooking oil2 tsp cornstarch + 2 tbsp waterIn a mixing bowl, mix seasoning with meat, stir well tocombine.Add in chopped ginger , garlic and mei cai.Â  Stir to combine well.Transfer to a steam tray, lightly packed to ensure evencooking.Steam over high heat for 15 minutes.Remove, sprinkle chopped spring onions and serve.

title: EGG DROP BITTERGOURD SOUP
text: Actually, I bought the bittergourd with the intention to prepare a Braised Bittergourd with Pork Ribs with Black Beans. Looking at the recipe, changed my mind because there are too many ingredients needed.I remembered coming across this recipeÂ shared by Cheah of No FrillsÂ Recipes quite long ago. Â I prepared this soup right away as I have all the ingredients in hand except for the fish balls which I omitted.This is a lovely soup as commented by my hubby. Â We enjoyed it very much. The bittergourd slices are not bitter as expected. Â Thanks to Cheah for sharing this homey recipe. Â I have slightly modified the recipe.Ingredients250 gm bittergourd - sliced100 gm pork fillet - sliced750 ml water1 egg - lightly beatenSalt to tasteSesame oilDash of pepperWash and remove the seeds from the bittergourd, slice it up and mix in some salt. Set aside for 5 minutes, rinse and drain.Marinate pork slices with some salt, pepper, sesame oil and cornflour.Bring water to the boil in a soup pot. Â Add in marinated pork, cook for a minute or two. Â When the soup boils, add in bittergourd slices and seasoning to taste.Drizzle in lightly beaten egg. Â Bring to boil and serve hot.

title: MASALA CHICKEN FRENCH BEANS
text: This recipe is similar to the earlier post on Masala Fried Cauliflower. Â As I loved the masala flavour fried cauliflower, I just substituted the cauliflower rice with French beans and it turned out as good.It is fragrant, tasty and delicious with rice. Â This is a nice variation from the usual way of frying French beans with preserved radish and eggs or with fried firm beancurd. Â For this recipe, you can substitute the chicken with pork, prawns or even add in eggs. Â It should be as good.Ingredients250 gm French beans - diced50 gm carrot - diced1 onion - peeled and diced1 tbsp chopped ginger1 tsp chopped garlic50 gm diced chicken breastÂ 1 tsp garam masala1-2 tbsp curry powderSeasoning1/2 tsp salt, dash of msgÂ 1/4 tsp pepperHeat up a non stick wok with 1 tbsp oil, saute chopped ginger, garlic until aromatic. Â Add in diced chicken, garam masala and curry powder. Â Stir fry until fragrant, add in carrots.Continue to fry, add 2-3 tablespoons of water, then add in french beans, onions and seasoning.Toss well and dish up when French beans turned a lovely green colour.Serve immediately.

title: EZCR#98 - MEAT AND CARROTS  STEW
text: These days, I have been preparing simple and easy dishesfor the family.Â  There is really nothing greatÂ to shout about Â these dishes but these recipes do come inusefulÂ  especially when Â prices of Â food ingredients are increasing beyond our control and during ourbusy days.For an averagefamily, one cannot be serving food fit for fine dining all the time.Â  This is when homeyand comfort food are most welcome and much easier for the cook at home who often has to face these problems.This dish has only a few main ingredients and easy toprepare yet the end result is awesome.Â The meat pieces and carrots are very tasty and the sweet, savoury sauceis appetizing with plain white rice.It can also be prepared earlier and just needs to bewarmed up before serving.Ingredients200 gm pork meat [shoulder neck meat] -Â cut big cubes1 small red carrot â€“ peeled and cut wedges1 small white carrotÂ - peeled and cut wedges1 yellow onion â€“ peeled and cut into squares2 star aniseSome blanched broccoli florets [optional]Â½ tbsp cooking oilSeasoning2 tbsp tomato sauce 1 tbsp wine and light soy sauceÂ½ tbsp chilli sauce 200 ml waterHeat oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© onions until aromaticand add in meat pieces and fry until brown.Add in carrots and stir anise.Â  Stir to mix well, then add in seasoning.Stir to mix well before adding water gradually in betweencooking.Bring to boil, then simmer until meat is tender and sauceis reduced.Â If adding broccoli, cover to cook for 1 minute then dishup to serve.Garnish with some spring onions.

title: SWEET AND SOUR FRESH TOFU SKIN [TAUPAU]
text: If soya products are your favourite cooking ingredient, then do take a look at the list of recipes in my blog which I have labelled 'Soya'. Â  As I have mentioned repeatedly, I love soya products from dry to fresh and frozen ones [soft and firm beancurd, tofu puffs, beancurd skin, frozen tofu skin etc].Fresh tofu skin [taupau] is one of them. Â It can be cooked with various sauces and the end result is never disappointing so long as they are fried until golden brown and firm. Â They can be braised with other ingredients and sauces. Â They are 'Awesome'.This is is basically the same as some of my previous recipes on fresh soya skin but I have added other ingredients like capsicum, onions and tomatoes into the sauce. It's tasty and nice. Â A healthy dish suitable for the old and young.Ingredients[serves 3]6 pieces of fresh soya skin - pan fried until golden brown [keep whole or cut into halve]1 tomato - diced1 small green capsicum - diced1 onion - peeled and diced1 red chilli - seeded and dicedsome toasted white sesame seeds for garnishSeasoning Sauce2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp each light soya sauce, plum sauce, black vinegar and wineÂ¼ tsp sugar2 tbsp water1 tbsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp waterIn a non stick wok, pan fry tofu skin until golden brown and crispy at the edges. Â Dish up.Remove excess oil, using the same wok, put in all the diced ingredients. Â Stir fry to mix well.Pour in the sauce, add in water and fried tofu skin.Bring to boil, taste to adjust seasoning. Â Sprinkle some toasted white sesame seeds.Dish up to serve immediately.

title: EZCR#97 - STEAMED CAI POR EGG
text: Fried Cai Por Egg [Fried Preserved Radish EggÂ èœè„¯è›‹Â ] is a very homey and common egg dish in most Chinese families all over the world. Â It is always good served with porridge or rice and every mother's speciality. Â I remembered my mum will fry this kind of egg every week and we are never tired eating it.This recipe here is something which I haven't tried before. Â The egg mixture is steamed instead of pan fried. Â Looks nice though and should be a healthy version minus the fats and 'heat'. Â The egg custard if silky, soft but firm. Â It is savoury and has the fragrance and taste of the preserved radish [cai por].Ingredients3 eggs - break into a bowlAdd in water, same portion as the eggsdash of pepper and msgsome chopped coriander3 tbsp preserved radish [cai por] - rinsed and drainedÂ Break eggs into a bowl, add in same portion of water.Mix all the ingredients well in a steaming bowl. Â Cover bowl with foil.Steamed over moderate heat for 20-25 minutes or until set. Â Do not over steam.Remove, garnish with fried shallots [optional] or serve immediately.Half way through steaming

title: FRIED CRISPY GARLIC PORK BELLY
text: This is another lovely meat dish shared generously by chefs of Yum Yum Publications.Â The fried pork slices are fragrant, tasty and aromatic from the fried garlic and chillies. Â Really nice and awesome crispy fried garlic pork belly and regretted I didn't cook a bigger portion as per original recipe. Â The recipe here is half the portion of the original quantity.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82 slightly modifiedIngredients300 gm pork belly â€“ skin removed and cut thick slices2 tbsp chopped garlic1 red chilli â€“ seeded and chopped finely1 stalk coriander leaves - choppedMarinadeÂ½ tsp 5 spice powderÂ¼ tsp salt 1 tsp sugarÂ½ egg Â½ tbsp cornstarchSeasoningÂ½ tbsp each oyster sauce and light soy sauceMarinate pork belly with marinade and season Â for at leastÂ Â½ hour.Deep fry marinated pork slices until golden brown.Â  Dish and drain.LeaveÂ  1 tbsp oilin pan and sautÃ© garlic until aromatic. Add in red chillies and fried pork,seasoning and stir fry over high heat until well mixed.Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves, stir well and dish upto serve.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: MASALA FRIED CAULIFLOWER
text: This recipe is inspired from an Indian style fried rice recipe. Â I have substituted the cooked rice with grated cauliflower and this dish turned out awesome.It is so fragrant, tasty and delicious. Â My hubby thought it is fried rice and was asking why I have fried rice for dinner with other dishes and plain white rice. Â Really, it looks like fried rice and tastes like one too.Â If you are on a low carbo diet, it would be good to try this dish.Ingredients300 gm cauliflower - grated50 gm carrot - diced50 gm French beans - diced1 tbsp chopped ginger1 tsp chopped garlic50 gm diced chicken breastÂ some diced prawns [optional]1 tsp garam masala1-2 tbsp curry powderSeasoning1/2 tsp salt, dash of msgÂ 1/4 tsp pepperHeat up a non stick wok with 1 tbsp oil, saute chopped ginger, garlic until aromatic. Â Add in diced chicken, garam masala and curry powder. Â Stir fry until fragrant, add in cauliflower and carrot.Continue to fry until cooked, add in french beans and seasoning.Toss well and dish up.Â Serve immediately.

title: BRAISED CHICKEN WITH MANDARIN ORANGE PEEL
text: This recipe is adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82.Â  TheÂ original recipe uses duck but I have substituted it with chicken wholelegs as it is not possible to get duck meat from the wet market which Ifrequent.Anyway, it is a rather easy braised chicken recipe withonly a few ingredients.Â  This dish israther unique as you can smell the aroma of orange peel more than theseasoning.Â  A citrusy scent but tastewise, it is savoury.Â  Overall result, thechicken and sauce tastes good.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82 withmodificationsIngredients2 chicken whole legs â€“ cut into 2 pieces each1 piece dried Mandarin orange peelÂ  - rinsed and scrap off the white pith, breakinto piecesSeveral slices of gingerÂ½ tbsp cooking oilSeasoning1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp each Shaoxing wine, light soy sauce and oystersauceÂ¼ tsp salt1-2 tsp sugar to taste400 ml waterHeat oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© ginger slices untilaromatic, add in the chicken pieces [skin side down] to fry until brown.Add in the orange peel and seasoning.Â  Stir fry to mix the ingredients well beforeadding water.Bring to boil, cover and lower heat to simmer untilchicken is tender and sauce is reduced.Â Flip over chicken pieces occasionally to ensure even cooking.Dish up chicken pieces, cut into bite sizes pieces.Â  Arrange on serving platter.Â  Bring sauce to boil until thick, taste toadjust seasoning.Pour over chicken pieces.Â Serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: BLACK BEANS PORK SPARE RIBS
text: Are we eating too much meat? After the numerous wedding dinners, then Duan Wu Jie [rice dumplings/Bak Chang festival], again these 'meaty' recipes are still as tempting to try.I have bookmarked this recipe Â fromÂ Minty's KitchenÂ for a long time but never get down to prepare until now.Initially, I intend to use my Thermal Cooker to prepare this dish which saves time at the stove. Â However, I totally forgotten my intention and just followed the method according to the recipe.The ribs and sauce are very tasty and yummy to serve with rice. Â Not too savoury, flavour is good.Ingredients350 gm pork spare ribsMarinade -1/2 tbsp Chinese cooking wine,Â 1 tbsp light soy sauce,1/2 tsp each of sesame oil andÂ 1/2 tsp cornflour, dash of pepper2 tbsp dried fermented black beans - rinsed3 cloves garlic - chopped1 shallot - choppedÂ A small knob of ginger - chopped1 dried chilli - soak to soften and cut into big chunks [replaced with 1 red chilli - finely chopped]Seasoning1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp each of dark soy sauce,Â sugar and pepper1 tbsp cooking oilGarnishing - spring onionsThickening - 1/2 tbsp cornflour + 1 tbsp waterWash and pat dry the pork ribs and marinate with marinade. Â Mix well and set aside for at least 1 hour.Â Heat oil in a non stick wok, saute chopped ginger, shallot, garlic and dried chilli [red chilli] until aromatic. Toss in fermented black beans and fry for about a minute.Add in pork ribs and fry until light brown. Add in dark and light soy sauces and sugar. Pour enough water to cover the ribs.Bring to boil and lower heat to simmer ribs for 30 minutes or more or until ribs are tender.Thicken sauce with cornflour mixture, stir well.Garnish with chopped spring onions and extra chopped red chilli. Serve hot with steamed rice.

title: CHICKEN WITH HERBAL SESAME SAUCE
text: I was supposed to buy deboned chicken whole legs to cookthis dish but instead I bought half a free range chicken.Â Â  Without choice, I have to modify the methodfor this recipe.Â  The original recipeused pan fry method and here I have to braise the chicken pieces using myThermal Cooker.Â  The reason for using thethermal pot is because I was afraid that the chicken bones may leave scratcheson my non stick wok.Â  â€˜Sayangâ€™ if my wokgot spoiled this way.Anyway, this is an aromatic chicken dish with a slighttaste of the dang qui, a stronger sesame aroma and savoury in taste.Â  It is quite similar to sesame oil chicken butyou know there is a herb in it.Â  Itâ€™stasty and delicious to serve with rice.Â The chicken pieces are tender and sweet.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82 withmodificationsIngredientsÂ½ free range chicken â€“ skin removed and cut chunky pieces2 tbsp sesame seed oilMarinade3 tbsp each light soy sauce1 tbspÂ  glutinuousrice wine [Ang Chow Wine]2 tbsp grated ginger with juice1-2 small slices of Dang Qui â€“ chopped1 tbsp sesame seed oilSeasoningDash of pepper1 tbsp wolfberries [kei chee]2 tbsp cornstarch waterEnough waterMarinate chicken pieces with marinade for at least anhour.Heat sesame oil in thermal cooker pot, add in marinatedchicken pieces to fry until firm and brown.Â Stir to prevent sticking to base of pot.Â Add in marinade, stir fry for a minutes before adding water.Bring to boil for a further 10 minutes. Transfer to the outer pot, place the lid and cover.Â  Leave to continue cooking in the ThermalCookerÂ  until serving time.Before serving, bring to boil, add in pepper andwolfberries.Â  Let it boil for a minute ortwo, then thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up to serve.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: BRAISED WINTER MELON & PEARL BEANS
text: Looks like a complicated dish but not so.It is easy to prepare with only a few main ingredients and seasoning is just basic with oyster sauce etc. Â But the end result is awesome. Â You can serve it as a thin or thick soup just by adjusting the water [between 300 to 400 ml] to be added, depending on your preference.This soup is tasty and the pearl beans are soft and tender.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82Ingredients200 gm winter melon - scooped into meatball shape50 gm red carrots - peeled and cut cubes100 gm pearl beans1 deboned chicken whole legs - cut cubes1/2 tbsp chopped garlic300 - 400 ml water1/2 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp oyster sauce3/4 tsp saltdash of pepper1 tbsp cornstarch for thickeningHeat up wok with oil, saute garlic until fragrant.Add in chicken, continue to fry until firm. Â Add in remaining ingredients, Â toss well.Add in seasoning and pour in water gradually.Bring to boil, taste to adjust seasoning.Transfer ingredients to a claypot and continue to simmer until beans are tender.Thicken soup with cornstarch water. Â Serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: EZCR#96 - BRAISED TOFU WITH SPRING ONIONS
text: I have tried this simple tofu recipe a few times. Â As it is too simple, I did not take the trouble to share the recipe earlier.Today, I made this dish again and decide to put this recipe in my blog for future reference.This tofu and minced meat dish is great with porridge or plain white rice as it is tasty and appetising with savoury and a little spicy flavour. Â You can cook with just a piece or two of the tofu. Â I used to cooked 2 pieces before but not today.Ingredients1-2 pieces square tofu - cut into eight pieces1-2 stalks spring onions1 tbsp chopped garlic50 gm minced meat1 tbsp chopped ginger1 tbsp oil100 ml waterSeasoning2 tbsp light soy saucedash of pepper and msg1 tsp chilli bohdash of pepperHeat wok with oil, saute garlic and spring onions until aromatic. Â Add in the minced meat and fry until it turned whitish, push aside. Â Add a little extra oil, pan fry the tofu pieces until brown on both sides.Add in seasoning and water. Â Bring to boil, toss to mix well.Add in chopped ginger and continue to braise till sauce is reduced.Dish up and garnish with some spring onions. Â Serve hot.

title: ROASTED BEAN PASTE CHICKEN THIGHS
text: I have been rather lazy for the past months, just preparing simple dishes for the family. Â The simpler, the better and luckily there were no complaints from the house master. Â They finished up all the dishes laid on the dinner table. Â Today, I was in the mood to make something better. Â While browsing through this month's selected cookbook Yum Yum Magazine No. 82, I found this recipe. Â Looks easy and good to try. Â It has been also awhile I didn't make any meat dishes by roasting.Â This roasted chicken whole legs are yummy, yummy. Â It's tasty, not too savoury but aromatic. Â The peanut butter and preserved soy bean paste do blend well. Â Tastes rather unique. Â I believe this marinade would be lovely for other types of meat.Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82 with modificationsIngredients3 chicken whole legs with skin but fats removedMarinade [blend together into a paste]5 shallots1 red chilli2 small chilli2 cloves garlic2 Â tbsp preserved soy bean paste [taucheong]2 tbsp peanut butter1/2 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp salt1 tsp pepper1 tsp dark soy sauceMarinate chicken thighs with marinade for at least an hour or overnight.Preheat oven to 250 degrees C.Place marinated chicken whole legs on a baking tray, then bake in preheated oven for 25 minutes or well cooked.Remove and serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: GU LAO ROU [å’•å™œè‚‰]
text: Cantonese Style Sweet and Sour Pork aka as Gu Lao Rou [å’•å™œè‚‰] in Mandarin is a highly popular Chinese dish among Chap Fan stalls, Chinese restaurants and even in the Western world.This recipe is a simplified and modified version from the original recipe Ku Loh Vegetarian Chicken. Â As I am not a fan of vegetarian mock chicken [which is a processed food ingredient], I made this dish with pork tenderloin. Â  Â The fried meat pieces are tender and crispy with the light batter, while the taste is sweet and sour. Â Very appetising with rice. The vegetables must not be overcooked to retain their crunch and colour. Â Best to serve this dish immediately to enjoy the crispy meat slices and crunchy vegetables.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82 [modified]Ingredients200 gm pork tenderloin - sliced1 tomato - cut small pieces1 small onion - peeled and cut small pieces1/2 green capsicum - seeded, cut diamond shape pieces1/2 zuchini - seeded and cut small diamond shape1 red chilli - seeded and cut small piecesBatter Ingredients100 gm self raising flour150 ml water1/2 tsp salt1/2 tbsp oilSeasoning [combined]2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp each apple cider vinegar, light soy sauce and sugar1/2 tbsp sweet chilli sauce1/4 tsp salt1 tsp cornstarch100 ml water1/2 tsp sesame seed oilMix batter ingredients [do not over mix batter] and set aside.Marinate the meat slices for 30 minutes, then heat up enough oil in wok.Add in the meat pieces to fry [in batches if you are using a small container] until cooked and crispy. Â Dish up and set aside.Â Remove excess oil. Â Add in the cut vegetables and toss quickly to mix before pouring in the combined sauce ingredients.Add in fried meat slices. Â Mix well and fry until sauce has thickened.Dish up and serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: RED YEAST REMPAH CHICKEN
text: This recipe has quite a number of ingredients but no worries. It is not difficult to make if you can find cekur roots [sand ginger] for this dish. The rest is just to assemble them according to the steps and you get to enjoy a very tasty, fragrant chicken dish. Â It tastes slightly salty to me but you can always adjust a little and fine tune the seasoning to suit your tastes buds. Â My hubby says the taste is perfect.My neighbour has a pot of cekur plant and he happily dug up the roots for me to make this dish. Â I should have cook a bigger portion and share some with him. Â Next time, next time. Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82 with modificationsIngredients3 deboned chicken whole legs with skin - cut into bite size pieces2 tbsp sesame seed oilMarinade1 tbsp coriander powder1 tbsp red yeast1 tsp pepper2 tbsp light soy sauceSpices [Blended]1 lemongrass - cut small pieces3 shallots50 gm gingerÂ 1.5 cm cekur rootsSeasoning2 tbsp glutinous rice wine1/4 tsp salt [original was 1/2 tsp]3-5 tbsp waterMarinate chicken pieces with marinade for at least 30 minutes or longer.Blend spices in the blender. Â Set aside.Heat up a non stick wok with sesame seed oil, saute spices until aromatic before adding the marinated chicken. Â Continue to stir fry chicken over low heat for several minutes.Continue to stir fry over low heat until chicken pieces are cook d through.Add in the seasoning, then continue to braise until meat is tender and Â sauce is thick.Dish up to serve immediately.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: STEWED PORK RIBS RADISH COUNTRY STYLE
text: This is a Hakka style pork ribs with radish soup with just2 main ingredients yet the taste is superb.Â According to the Chef, Hakka people love this kind of soup for the natural flavours of the ingredients.A simple soup yet, I could get a Thumbs Up from my hubby. He loves this soup so much with his remarksÂ  â€˜this is the kind of soup to savour andenjoyâ€™.Â  His comment was 'why many cookslove to add lots of other ingredients when cooking soup when in fact soupslike this is awesome'.Â  He is not Hakkabut seems to like this Hakka style soup mainly for its simplicity.I was lucky to get local white carrots with fresh leavesintact to make this soup.Â Before I added the carrot leaves, I did ask the vegetable seller if the leaves are 'edible'.Â He gave me a funny look and asked 'What's wrong, some people will only buy carrots with the leaves. Â It has to be edible'. Â Cute answer.This soup is clear with the natural aroma and taste of white carrots that blends well with the sweetness of the ribs. It's really good, simple and easy to prepare. Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No.82 slightlymodifiedIngredients[serves 3 ]300 gm pork ribs â€“ chopped bite size pieces2 stalks white carrots â€“ peeled and cut wedges800 ml water1 tsp salt to tasteDash of chicken stock granules or msgPepper to tasteBlanch pork ribs in hot water, drained and rinsed under running tap water to remove scums.Bring water to boil in a soup pot, add in carrots together with theleaves and pork ribs.Bring to boil, then lower heat to simmer for 40 minutesor until pork ribs are tender.Add salt and remaining seasoning ingredients to taste.Serve hot, garnish with coriander leaves.I am sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #18Â hosted by Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayÂ respectively

title: BLACK VINEGAR SPARE RIBS
text: This is a finger licking good spare ribs dish that tastesnot sourish but has a lovely sour aroma.Â The cooking time is a bit longer but it is worth the long braising timewhen you enjoy the tasty ribs with rice.Awesome, homey dish which you must make for your family.Â Â  I believe this dish is good with chicken.'Black vinegar is reputed to have an array of health benefits like other vinegar. Black vinegar has a deep color, rich in flavor and is a tasty ingredient for dipping sauces and braised dishes. Black vinegar is made from unpolished rice, millet, wheat or sorghum. It has long been used in China and Japan as natural treatments for the heart and blood vessels. Black vinegar contains acetic acid, an organic acid that may help to reduce glucose or sugar levels in the blood which can have a preventative effect with an array of cardiovascular diseases, including high blood pressure, artery disease, heart disease and stroke'. Â With the above benefits of black vinegar, we may well use this ingredient often when preparing meat dishes.Ingredients300 gm meaty spare ribs â€“ cut into small pieces1 onion â€“ sliced1 inch ginger â€“ slicedÂ½ tbsp chopped garlic1 stalk spring onions â€“ cut into sectionsÂ½ tbsp oilEnough waterSeasoning2-3 tbsp black vinegarÂ½ tsp dark soy sauceÂ½ Â tbsp sugar totaste1 tbsp rock sugar1 tbsp cooking wineSalt to tasteFry ginger, garlic, spring onions and onion with oil in anon stick pan until aromatic.Add in pork ribs and stir fry to mix well, then add in theseasoning.Bring to boil before pouring in enough water to cover theribs.Bring to boil, lower heat and cover to simmer for atleast 45-60 minutes or until ribs are tender and sauce is thick.Â Serve hot with rice.

title: MANGO SALAD WITH LEMONGRASS DRESSING
text: Don't be put off with this salad recipe after looking at the long list of ingredients needed. Â First look you may not wish to try. Â This was my experience and response when I first looked at the recipe. Â I chucked it aside straight away and that was years ago.Last week, I was clearing my drawer and came across this piece of paper with the recipe. Â Since, I had a some time, I took the trouble to read through the ingredients. Â Hahaha!, I happened to have all the ingredients needed. Â Timing is just right and I made this salad that day itself and I could clear off a can of lychee in the pantry.Light and refreshing salad. Â Crunchy mango, sweet canned lychee flesh and fragrant mint and coriander leaves. Â Dressing is not overly savoury or sweet. Â Add more lime juice if you want it to be more tangy.Ingredients150 gm shelled prawns - blanched to cook and drain1-2 mango [depending on the size] - peeled and shredded4 sprigs of fresh mint leaves4 sprigs coriander leavesDressing [ combined]1 stalks of lemongrass - white part only - thinly sliced1 red chilli - seeded and slicedJuice of 5 calamansi lime1 1/2 tbsp fish sauce1 1/2 tsp sugarMix dressing ingredients in a mixing bowl. Â Set aside.Prepare the remaining ingredients and toss well with dressing.Chill in the fridge until serving time.

title: EZCR#95 - BRAISED TOFU WITH FOO YEE
text: Soya products are my favourite and I donâ€™t mind eatingthem every day because there are so many ways to cook them and in variousflavours from savoury to sweet, spicy to non-spicy.Â  They can absorb any kind of flavours well.Â  A simple crispy fried firm beancurd can be sogood with a chilli dip and a fried tofu with a splash of light soy sauce is as appetizing.This one is a good example, just tofu with a simplefermented beancurd sauce, it is tasty and delicious. Yummy, yummy!I love the chopped garlic which is not sautÃ©ed and youcan still enjoy its' raw taste.Â  If youlove garlic, I suggest to add more.Â  Thetofu pieces absorb the flavours of the foo yee sauce which is not salty at all but fragrant.Recipe adapted from a Chinese TV Cook ShowIngredients2 blocks of soft beancurd [tofu] â€“ cut into Â½ inch thickslicesSome chopped coriander leaves1-2 tbsp chopped garlicSeasoning Â [blendwell]3 pieces of fermented beancurd [foo yee]1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, cooking wine and sugarDash of sesame seed oil3 tbsp waterÂ½ tsp cornflourHeat a non stick wok with 1 tbsp oil, pan fry tofu piecesuntil brown on both sides.Pour seasoning sauce evenly over fried tofu, add inchopped garlic.Add a little more water if sauce is too thick.Â  Bring it to boil until the sauce coats thetofu pieces.Add in chopped coriander [no need to stir, just shake thewok lightly].Dish up to serve.

title: EZCR#95 - YAM MUSTARD CHICKEN SOUP
text: If you love yam, if you love thick soup, if you lovemustard leaves [kai choy], then this soup is a must try.Â  The thickness texture [starchiness] of the soup is not fromany thickening but comes from the yam pieces that are boiled till soft and fragrant.This is a lovely soup with only 3 main ingredients andseasoning.I like this soup and had it as a light lunch as this souphas carbo, fibre and protein.Â  Simplyeasy and yet delicious.Ingredients1 large chicken whole leg â€“ skin removed and cut intochunky pieces, blanched and rinsed 150 gm yam â€“ cut chunky pieces100 gm mustard leaves â€“ stems only and cut into piecesSome ginger slicesSeasoningSalt, pepper and cooking wine to taste800 ml waterBringÂ  water toboil in a soup pot, add in ginger slices.Add in chicken and yam pieces.Â  Let it boil for 10-15 minutes.Continue to boil until yam pieces are soft, add inmustard stems to cook till tender but still greenish in colour.Add in seasoning to taste.Â  Scoop into serving bowl.Serve hot.

title: EZCR#94 - TAIWANESE STYLE BRAISED PORK
text: Sometimes when I look at a recipe especially those withjust a handful ingredients and simple seasoning, I was skeptical if it would beworth trying.Â  Honestly, most times Iwill give them a try because of itsâ€™ simplicity and really I am glad I tried. They did turn out well and good and I ended up jotting down the recipes because they are going to be very useful during my busy days.Â Â This braised pork dish [Kong Bak in Hokkien dialect] is one simple dish withonly 3 main ingredients, some aromatics and seasoning yet it is awesome.Â  The sauce is perfect to spread over rice, themeat and carrots are tasty, aromatic and tender.Â Â  Best of all, it tastes even better afterresting which means that this dish can be prepared way ahead of meal time.Â Â  That suits me well for busy days.Â I Â am not going to Â describe further, perhaps the pictures mayconvince you that this is a delicious pork dish.Â Â  I just love the pieces of lean pork with thethin layer of fat which is so good to chew at. Â Pork belly can be used for this dish, too.Recipe adapted from a Chinese TV Cook ShowIngredients400 gm pork shoulder meat [pork with some fats] â€“ cut intobig cubes1 white carrot â€“ peeled and cut wedges1 red carrot- peeled and cut wedgesSome chopped coriander leaves 3 star anise3-4 bay leaves300 ml water1 tsp oil1 tbsp sugarSeasoning3 tbsp light soy sauce3 tbsp cooking wine1 tbsp rock sugarHeat a non stick wok with oil, add in sugar to caramelize[dissolve sugar till big bubbles and brown].Add in pork pieces and stir fry quickly to sear and coatthe meat well with the caramel. Â Add in carrots, star anise, bay leaves andseasoning.Â  Stir to mix wellÂ  until fragrant.Pour in water, bring to boil.Â  Cover wok, lower heat and simmer for about30-40 minutes or until meat is tender and sauce reduced to thick.Â Dish up, garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve.

title: FRIED BEANCURD WITH SWEET CHILLI PEANUT SAUCE
text: This is a popular Thai street food, crispy deep friedtofu [tao hu tod].Â  The firm beancurd isdeep fried till golden and crispy on all edges and serve with a sweet chillipeanut sauce.Â  I love fried tofu or firmbeancurd and this is especially good with a home cooked sweet chillisauce.Â  The peanuts and cilantro enhancefurther this sauce.Â  As I do not havecilantro, I made do with spring onions which is also good.This sweet chilli sauce can be used as a dipping saucefor any other fried food, so it is worthwhile to prepare the whole portion andstored away for later use. Â I have omitted the chilli flakes as the sauce is rather spicy and hot.Honestly, I donâ€™t mind having just this for a lightweekend lunch in the comfort of my home.Recipe adapted from Â Hot Thai KitchenÂ with modificationsIngredients3 pieces firm beancurd â€“ quartered and deep fried or panfriedEnough oil for deep frying or pan fryingIngredients for SWEET CHILLI PEANUT SAUCE2 red chillies â€“ cut small pieces [spicy specie]1-2 large cloves garlic 3 tbsp vinegar, tamarind juice and water3 tbsp sugar3 tbsp palm sugar â€“ choppedÂ¼ tsp salt3-4 tbsp coarsely ground toasted peanuts2 tbsp chopped cilantro or spring onionsIn a blender, add chillies, garlic, water, vinegar andtamarind.Â  Blend until there are no bigchunks of the ingredients [ not necessarily smooth and fine].Â  Transfer to a sauce pan, add in sugar, palmsugar, salt.Bring ingredients to boil over low medium heatÂ  for 5 minutes or until slightly thick but not thick[the sauce will thicken a little when cooled].Â Â Taste and adjust seasoning.Â  When readyto serve, add in peanuts and cilantro or spring onions.For the firm beancurd, deep fry in medium hot oil or panfry until golden brown or crispy.Dish up on serve platter [I laid the base with someshredded cabbage],Â  pour sweet chillisauce on top , sprinkle peanuts and cilantro or serve fried beancurd with sweetchilli sauce as dipping sauce.

title: GINGER SOY CHICKEN
text: Accidentally, came across this recipe ofÂ Pailin's KitchenÂ on you tube where the chef has shared this easy and delicious stir fry chicken dish.  This dish is cooked without adding any water.According to the chef, the original recipe uses cooked boiled chicken which is chopped and fried with soy sauce.Â As I love ginger with chicken, this dish seems easy and simple to cook. Â Easy and simple recipes without compromising the taste and flavour are always my favourite.I tried the recipe with slight modification to the method and no regrets, this is an awesome ginger flavoured chicken which is so much faster to cook compared to braising it.If you are a ginger lover, I suggest to add more which I will do next time when I prepare this yummy dish again. As I do not have cilantro in hand, I have used spring onions. Â I believe using cilantro will make the flavours more Thai......Recipe adapted fromÂ Pailin's KitchenÂ with modificationsIngredients[serve 3]2 deboned large chicken whole legs [about 500 gm] - cut into big cubes3 tbsp soy sauce2 tsp black soy sauce4-5 cloves garlic - chopped2-3 tbsp chopped ginger20 gm palm sugar - finely choppedÂ¼ tsp ground white pepper or black pepper1 stalk cilantro with stems - choppedÂ Some fresh julienned ginger for garnishMarinate chicken with light and dark soy sauce for 15-20 minutes [mine was marinated for several hours].In a non stick wok, add 1/2 tbsp cooking oil, saute garlic and ginger until aromatic and garlic starts to turn golden. Â  Push aside, using the oil in the wok, add in marinated chicken pieces with marinade, if possible skin side down and pan fry until brown on both sides.Constantly, stir fry chicken until firm and cooked. Â Lastly add in palm sugar and fry until sugar dissolves and chicken is completely cooked.Off heat, add cilantro, toss and plate.Garnish with extra julienned fresh ginger if desired. Serve with rice.Note: If you want to make this spicy, add some chopped Thai chillies along with the ginger and garlic.

title: PORK, ALMONDS AND MELON SOUP
text: This soup looks very plain and simple but I loved thecrunchy almonds though boiled and simmered for some time.The almonds here are of two different types [sweet &bitter]. Â Â These are available at allChinese medical shops and I was told some comes with brown skin.Â Â  Most people prefer the almonds without theskin.Â  For this soup, you can use honeydew instead of winter melon.A homey soup suitable for all ages and especially goodduring hot weather.Recipe adapted from Lisa Yamâ€™s World Cookbook withmodificationsIngredients200 gm winter melon â€“ peeled, remove seeds and cut into chunkypieces200 gm lean pork or pork shank â€“ cut into slices 2 tbsp assorted almonds [nam hang & pak hang] -rinsed800 ml water2 slices gingerSeasoningSalt to tasteDash of pepper to tasteBring water to boil in a soup pot, add in all theingredients.Bring to boil, then lower heat to simmer till tender andsoup thickens.Season with salt and pepper.Dish up to serve hot.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #17Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: EZCR#93 - STIR FRY BITTERGOURD WITH SALTED EGGS
text: This is a detoxifying dish.  Bittergourd is a rich in nutrients and vitamins A,B, C and several minerals that contributes to a healthy diet. The benefits of bitter gourd range from treating mild gastrointestinal problems and inflammation and reducing blood pressure and sugar levels to treating cancer and fighting HIV infections.  It is low in calories and a good source of dietary fiber.With the above benefits, it is worth consuming this bitter taste vegetable.  However, if the white inner pith is well removed, the bitterness is usually acceptable when cooked with other ingredients.Back to this dish, the savoury salted egg blends well with bitterness of the bittergourd. Â This is a tasty dish that goes well with porridge or rice.Ingredients1 bittergourd [300 gm] -remove white pith, sliced thinly1 red chilli -seeded and chopped1 hard boiled salted egg - shelled and chopped1 century egg [pei tan] - shelled and chopped1 tbsp chopped garlic and spring onions1 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp cooking winedash of msg and salt to tasteBlanch sliced bittergourd in boiling water for a minute. Â Drain and rinse in cold water to retain its' greenish colour and crunchiness.Heat a non stick wok with oil, saute chopped garlic until aromatic, add in bittergourd,salted egg, pei tan and red chilli. Â Stir to mix ingredients well.Add in seasoning to taste and lastly add in spring onions.Dish up to taste.

title: STUFFED LOOFAH WITH PORK & SHRIMP PASTE
text: There was a day, I was very hardworking.Â Â Â  You must wondering why.Â  Usually, I wouldnâ€™t try more than one newrecipe in a day.Â  This is because thereis really much to do when trying out new recipe for sharing and keeping it inmy food blog.Â  Every step has to benoted, photos have to be taken and recipe rephrased before posting it in theblog.Â  At times, I prefer to simplify thesteps so that it is easier for others to follow without compromising its tasteand flavor.This dish was prepared the same day as I cooked the Stewed Beancurd With PorkÂ [the third recipe from this book].Anyway, this dish is not difficult when comes to cookingit as it is a steamed dish.Â  Thepreparation and assembling take some time but this can be done earlier and leftin the fridge until meal time.I love the crunchy prawn with meat filling and the softloofah which is sweet.Â  The sauce issavoury and aromatic.Â  All these seem toblend well, making this dish worth giving it a try.Recipe adapted fromÂ 'Lisa Yam's World' CookbookÂ with modificationsIngredients1 fresh loofahÂ [240 gm]120 gm minced pork80 gm prawns â€“ shelled and diced2 tsp chopped garlic and spring onions [keep aside Â½ ofthese ingredients]Marinade2 tsp grated ginger2 tsp light soy sauceDash of pepper, msg and sesame seed oil1 tbsp cornflourSeasoning2 tsp light soy sauce2 tsp oilPeelÂ  loofah, cutinto half, remove the inner tissues and seeds, then cut into 2 inch sections.Â Rinse and scald, then rinse again with water.Â  Drain well.Mix marinade with minced pork, then mix in the dicedprawns.Â  Mix well into a thick paste forfilling.Stuff filling into cut loofah, arrange on a steamingplate.Steam over high heat for 15-20 minutesÂ  until well done.Â  Remove and sprinkle garlic and spring onionon top.Meanwhile,heat up oil in a saucepan until hot, add inlight soy sauce. Pour hot oil over steam dish and serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #17Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: STEWED BEANCURD WITH PORK
text: This is the third recipe which I tried from thisbook.Â  It is a homey dish, great to gowith rice or porridge for lunch or dinner.Â The ingredients are easily available and to cook up this dish is notdifficult at all.This dish is healthy, aromatic and tasty with thefragrant seasoning sauce.Â  You can alsosubstitute the chives with leeks or garlic sprouts etc.Â  Recipe adapted fromÂ 'Lisa Yam's World' CookbookÂ with modificationsIngredients[serves 3]120 gm pork tenderloin â€“ slicedMarinade â€“ 1-2 tsp light soy sauce, dash of msg, 1 tspoil and cornflour2 pieces soft beancurd â€“ cut 1.5 cm thick pieces [I used Teochew beancurd]80 gm chives â€“ cut sectionsA few slices of carrots1-2 tbsp oilSeasoning Sauce [combined]2 tsp light soy sauceÂ¼ tsp salt1 tsp cooking wineDash of msg, pepper and sesame seed oil1 tsp cornflour125 ml waterRinse pork, sliced and marinate with marinade for 15minutes.Heat up a non-stick wok, add in oil, pan fry beancurdpieces until golden brown on both sides.Â Dish up.Using the same wok, add in marinated pork pieces to fryuntil brown and cooked.Â  Push aside.Add in carrots, stir fry to combine ingredients.Â  Add in fried beancurd and pour in seasoning.Bring sauce to boil for a minute, then add in cutvegetables.Â  Lightly stir to mixingredients until sauce is thick.Dish up to serve with rice.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #17Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: EZCR#92 - STIR FRY BLACK FUNGUS WITH PINEAPPLES
text: I have cooked this dish several times as IÂ just love it forits goodness, simplicity and tastes.Â This time, thought it would be good to share the recipe here and also asa record for my future reference.Â  Theoriginal recipe is without pineapples but uses fresh Shimeji mushrooms.This dish is a healthy dish and is good for our bloodcirculatory system.Â  If using mushrooms,both the mushrooms and black fungus are crunchy with the natural sweetness ofthe fresh mushrooms.Â  The taste withpineapples especially ripe ones,Â  is alsosweet and sourish while the black fungus is crunchy and absorbs the flavourswell.Â  This is a delicious and tasty vegetariandish,Â  too.Ingredients1 quarter pineapples â€“ cut 1 inch stripsA bunch of wood ear fungus [bok nee] â€“ soak to plump upand cut thin shreds1-2 tbsp shredded ginger1 red chilli â€“ seeded and cut thin stripsSome spring onions â€“ cut into sections1 tbsp oilSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce to taste1 tbsp cooking wine to tasteÂ¼ tsp sugar to taste or a dash of msgSome waterHeat wok with oil, ginger and red chilli until aromatic,add in black fungus and pineapples.Stir fry until pineapples are soft, add in seasoningingredients and some water.Bring to boil and continue to fry until sauce is reducedand thick.Lastly add in spring onions.Â  Dish up to serve.Note: If using fresh mushrooms, dry fry them untilslightly brown before adding oil to sautÃ© ginger and other ingredients.

title: STEAMED CHICKEN WITH SHRIMP PASTE
text: This recipe is at least a quarter century old.Â  It is from my collection of recipe booksdated 1992.Â  Just wondering how I cankeep the book for so long and yet never tried a single recipe at all.Â  Anyway, I was thinking of giving away thisbook but before I do so, I found several recipes that look easy andsimple.Â  I had earlier tried a homeydish, â€˜Stewed Winter Melon with Tofu Puffsâ€™ which is simple enough, healthy andtasty.Back to this second dish, only a few procedureÂ  to follow and you get to enjoy a tastychicken dish that is aromatic, a little spicy and savoury.Â  Great to go with steaming hot rice.Recipe adapted fromÂ 'Lisa Yam's World' CookbookÂ with modificationsIngredients300 gm chicken meat pieces with bones â€“ cleaned Â and pat drySome chopped spring onions [keep some for garnishing]Marinade [mix well]1-1Â½ tbsp toasted hard shrimp paste [belacan] orpreserved shrimp paste1 tsp chilli boh1-2Â tsp grated ginger1 tsp each of Â cooking wine and sugarDash of pepper and sesame seedoil1 tbsp cornstarchMarinate chicken pieces with the marinade for at least an hour.Place marinated chicken on steaming plate.Steam over boiling water for 15-20 minutes or until chicken is cooked through. Steaming time depends on the size and type of chicken meat used.Remove from steamer, garnishing with chopped spring onions and serve immediatey.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #17Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CHICKEN ASADO
text: After cooking the FilipinoÂ Chicken Adobo, I told myself I have to try other Filipino dishes. Â I started to search for some easy dishes and this Chicken Asado was one of them that looks delicious.According to Panlasang Pinoy, 'Chicken Asado is a Filipino chicken recipe where chicken is pan-fried and cooked in a tomato based sauce along with soy sauce and lemon juice. Chicken Asado is said to originate from Central Luzon, in Pampanga'.My hubby asked to cook curry chicken for my mother in-law, but I prepared this for her, a new dish I believe she has not tried before. Â I think she will like this because she loves Â almost all dishes that taste savoury and sourish.Recipe adapted fromÂ Panlasang PinoyÂ with modificationsIngredients[serves 4-5]2 large chicken whole legs [with skin] - cut into chunky pieces1 large onion - peeled and dicedsome bay leaves3 medium size potatoes - peeled and cut wedges1 tbsp butter30 ml lemon juice1 tbsp oilSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce5-6 tbsp tomato sauce1/2 tsp ground black pepper1/4 tsp salt to taste200 ml waterMarinate chicken pieces with some salt and pepper for 30 minutes.Heat up a non-stick wok, pan fry chicken pieces [skin side] first until brown, flip over to fry the meat side. Â Dish up.Using the same wok, pan fry the potato wedges until brown. Â Push aside, add in butter and saute diced onions and bay leaves until onions are soft.Stir to mix ingredients well, add in fried chicken, lemon juice and seasoning.Stir to mix, pour in water, bring to boil, then cover wok and simmer until ingredients are tender and cooked through.Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking. Â Uncover and cook till sauce is thick.Dish up and serve hot.

title: STEWED WINTER MELON WITH TOFU PUFFS
text: This is a very old recipe book 'Lisa Yam's World Cookbook' which I have kept for umpteen years. Â The dishes in this cookbook is basically Chinese Cuisine. Â After running through the book, I have selected several recipes to try. Â These recipes are simple and easy and rather fast to cook yet they are tasty.The winter melon can be replaced with white carrots or even honey dew.I have selected this cookbook for Cookbook Countdown Event #17.Recipe adapted from 'Lisa Yam's World' Cookbook with modificationsIngredients200 gm winter melon - skinned and cut oblong pieces100 gm tofu puffs - rinse and squeezed out moisture50 gm carrots - sliceda few slices ginger1 stalk spring onions - cut sections1/2 tbsp cooking oil250 ml waterSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp sugardash of sesame oilHeat oil in non stick wok, saute ginger and spring onions until lightly charred and fragrant.Add in winter melon to fry, add in seasoning, stir fry to mix well.Add in tofu puffs, carrots and water. Â Bring to boil, then simmer until ingredients are soft and sauce reduced to thick.Lastly, add in spring onions. Â Dish up to serve hot.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #17Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: EZCR#91 - PORK RIBS SOK TEI SOUP
text: A nourishing herbal soup using Shu Di [Chinese Foxglove Root], known to treat a range of conditions related to women's health. Â For details about this herb, please visitÂ here]. Â Shu Di [Chinese Foxglove Root]This herbal soup looks dark but it isn't as bitter in taste as other Chinese herbal soup.Â Ingredients300 gm meaty pork ribs - cut chunky pieces2 pieces shu di [Chinese Foxglove Root]1 piece dong quai6 red dates3 slices ginger1 tbsp goji750 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp winelight soy sauce to tasteBlanch pork ribs in boiling water to remove scums. Â Rinsed.Bring water to boil, Â Add in all the ingredients, bring to boil then simmer until soup is fragrant and pork ribs are tender.Add in seasoning to taste.Serve hot.

title: EZCR#90 - PAN FRIED 5 SPICE CHICKEN CHOP
text: This chicken recipe is a good dish to energise the body. It is also a healthy dish for slimming diet if you are cutting down on carbo intake and yet can enjoy a good meal while shaping up.A very simple fried chicken that is aromatic, tasty, savoury and sourish. Â Great to have them with a bowl of salad or raw leafy greens. Â Adding lime juice helps to eliminate some of the fat content.Ingredients3 deboned chicken whole legs with skin - remove excess fatssome chopped coriander leavessome toasted sesame seedssome lime juiceMarinade1 tbsp cooking wine1 tsp each of 5 spice powder and ground black pepper1/4 tsp salt to tastePrepare the chicken whole legs, chicken chop style. Â You can get the vendor to prepare this for you. Â Marinate chicken whole legs with marinade for several hours or overnight. Store is a tight container in the fridge.Heat a non stick wok without oil, pan fry chicken whole legs [skin side first] until oil from the skin oozes out. Â Use this oil to fry until the skin is golden brown and crispy at the edges.Flip over to fry the meat side until chicken is cooked through. Â You can cover to fry the chicken pieces to speed up the cooking time. Â Sprinkle some sesame seeds .Flip over to fry the skin side for 1-2 minutes before dishing up o n a plate. Â Remove excess oilCut the fried chicken, drizzle over some lime juice and then sprinkle with some toasted sesame seeds and extra ground black pepper.Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Â Serve immediately.

title: LOW FAT BANANA BREAD
text: These days I have been buying bananas regularly asbananas is high with potassium which is good for regulatingÂ  the sodium level Â in our body.Â Too much sodium affects the level of blood pressure.Today, I baked this banana bread using a muffin tray which shortens thebaking time by half Â if it is baked in aloaf tin.Â  Looks like an energy savingtip, hehehe! which I discovered.This recipeÂ  isadapted from Stephanie of Joy Of BakingÂ with some modifications to the ingredients such as substituting a portion of the brown sugar with jaggerysugar.Â  Maybe is for this reason, themuffin shaped banana bread looks a little darker than usual.Â  Anyway, it is okay to me.The banana bread is soft, moist and of course aromatic withcinnamon and vanilla essence.Â  Canâ€™t waitto let it cool completely before I tried a piece while still warm, hmmmâ€¦ it isawesome.Really, didnâ€™t expect the bread to bethat good, so much difference from store bought.Â  There is no overly strong scent of banana essence,non-greasy and the sweetness is just perfect.Â This recipe is a keeper and I wouldnâ€™t mind baking this bread often.Ingredients[makes 6 large size muffin shape banana breadÂ or 10cm x20 cm greased loaf tin]Dry Ingredients [ sifted and mix together]130 gm plain flour + 65 gm wholemeal flour1 tsp baking powder + 1/2 tsp cinnamon powder + Â¼ tspsalt45 gm dark chocolate chipsWet Ingredients 1 [mash and mix together]3 medium size bananas or 2 large bananas â€“ peeled andmash with a fork120 ml plain yoghurt1 tsp baking sodaWet Ingredients 2 [whisk together]1 large eggÂ 60 gm brown sugar + 60 gm jaggery sugar [gula merah]60 ml corn oil1 tsp vanilla essenceSift and combine dry ingredients in a mixing bowl.Â  Set aside.Mash bananas in a bowl, mix in plain yoghurt and bakingsoda.Â  Mix till well combined.Whisk Â wetÂ ingredients2 until sugar dissolves and blend well.Combine the mashed banana mixture with egg mixturelightly with a spatula.Pour it into the dry ingredients.Â  Mix lightly until well incorporated. Â The batter is thick.Scoop into prepared muffin tray until 80% full.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20minute.Â  Test with a skewer beforeremoving to coolÂ  on wire rack.

title: KELANTAN STYLE HONG BAK
text: Hong Bak is basically quite similar to Tau Eu Bak [SoySauce Pork Belly] but there is some variations to ingredients, seasoning and steps. Â Each one recipe for Hong Bakhas itsâ€™ own unique taste and flavor.Â  Itis just a matter of oneâ€™s preference, choice and familiarity of the dish.Though this recipe is different from my usual familyrecipe or other chefâ€™s recipes, I like this too.Â  I love trying various Hong Bak or Tau Eu Bak recipes but Iwill keep those which I really like the tastes.Â  This one is more on the sweet side which myhubby commented and he still prefers the one which tastes savoury.Â  As I said, it is a matter of preference andto me, I like the chewy pork belly pieces which is well braised, the tastyhard-boiled eggs and the thick sauce which is packed with all the flavours of this dish.The thick sauce was good with plain white rice mixed with sambalbelacan and freshly cut cucumber slices.Â It is just awesome for a simple meal in the comfort of my home.If my hubby doesn't like, no problem, I get to enjoy a bigger portion, hehehe! Â Anyway, there isn't much left because half of this portion went to my mother in-law who loves braised pork belly with soy sauce. Â In fact, it is my hubby who asked that I cooked this for his mum.Ingredients600 gm pork belly with skin Â â€“ cut bite size pieces10 hard-boiled eggs â€“ shelled [you can add less]1 piece cinnamon stick2 star anise6 cloves garlic â€“ crushed90 gm palm sugar [gula Melaka]450 ml water [150 ml x 3]Â½ tbsp oilSeasoning2 tsp dark soy sauce for colour2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp preserved soy bean paste [taucheong]1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp pepperÂ¼ tsp salt Heat up wok, dry fry cinnamon stick and star anise untilaromatic, push aside.Add in oil, sautÃ© garlic until aromatic, add in palmsugar.Â  Stir to mix, until sugardissolves.Â Add in pork belly pieces, stir fry to coat with thecaramel and firm up, then add in the seasoning ingredients.Continue to fry until meat pieces are fragrant and some oil oozes out from the meat.Â Â Add in 150 ml water, bring to boil for 10minutes.Pour in another 150 ml water together with hard boiled eggs.Â  Bring to boil, cover to simmer ingredients for a further 10minutes.Â Add another 150 ml water, bring to boil again, then braiseuntil meat is tender and sauce is thick.Dish up to serve with rice and sambal belacan Â [Pork dish tastes better after resting. Reheat before serving].

title: STEWED BLACK PEPPER CHICKEN
text: This is a second stewed meat recipeÂ which I triedÂ from this cookbook . The first one was the Spare Ribs With Tomato Curry StewÂ which was an awesome One Dish Meal.  I believe this stewed chicken with black pepper flavor is also as good and easy to prepare for cooking.Just love this kind of dishes cooked by stewing method where all the flavours are well combined and infused into the ingredients.  Really easy yet the result is never disappointing at all.Â The chicken and potatoes are cooked till tender and soft while the thick sauce is aromatic and spicy.  Great to serve with rice or even freshly baked warm buns.The original recipe uses some black pepper sauce which I substitute it by increasing the seasoning by a little.Recipe adapted  from Yum Yum Magazine No.103 with slight modificationsIngredients[serves 3-5]2 chicken whole legs with skin â€“ cut into big piecesMarinade for at least an hour with Â½ tsp each of salt and pepper, 1 tsp oyster sauce and 1 tbsp light soy sauce.  Mix and coat with 1 tbsp cornstarch.1 large potato â€“ peeled and cut wedgesÂ½ carrot â€“ peeled and cut wedges3 black mushrooms â€“ soaked and halved3 cloves1 onion â€“ peeled and cut wedges5 dried chillies â€“ soaked1 tbsp each sliced garlic and shallotsSeasoning1 tsp each of  ground black pepper, sugar and dark soy sauce2 tsp each of oyster sauce and light soy sauceÂ 1 tsp cornstarch [optional]300 ml waterHeat a non stick wok, then add in 1 tbsp oil.  Put in the chicken pieces to fry from skin side first until brown and firm.
