Dish up and set aside.Using the oil in the wok, sautÃ© aromatics [garlic, shallots, dried chillies and cloves] until fragrant. Add in onions, potatoes and carrot.  Stir to mix well, then add in the seasoning followed by fried chicken.Stir to mix well, pour in water.  Bring to boil, then cover, simmer over low heat for 20 minutes until chicken is tender and sauce is reduced.Turn to high heat to thicken the sauce, then dish up to serve hot.Â This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #16Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: GRAPEFRUIT MIXED VEGETABLE SALAD
text: This is a simple and easy salad with healthy foodingredients.Â  Itâ€™s very appetizing Â and refreshing too.The grapefruit flesh can be replaced by pamelo but Ithink, it is much easy to obtain grapefruit than pamelo.It is a salad that tastes more savoury than sweet withthe use of fish sauce for the dressing. Â Basil leaves gives a sweet fragrance to this salad.Ingredients1 grapefruit â€“ skinned to obtain the fleshÂ½ cucumber or 1 zuchini â€“ shredded1 small onion â€“ peeled and thinly sliced30 gm shredded carrot1 red chill â€“ seeded and cut thin strips50 gm boiled and sliced prawn1 piece ham [optional] â€“ cut stripsSome toasted white sesame seedsSome Basil leavesDressing [mixed] - depends on how much of the above ingredients used1 tbsp fish sauce to taste2-3 tbsp calamansi juice1 tsp brown sugar to tastePrepare the above ingredients as stated.Combine all the ingredients in a mixing bowl, then pourin the dressing.Â  Toss well to mix.Sprinkle toasted sesame seeds.Â Serve immediately or chill until servingtime.

title: JAGGERY SUGAR STEAMED PAUS
text: Just trying to cut down the use of refined white sugar and switching to using jaggery sugar in my cooking and baking. Â This is the first attempt using gula merah to make steamed baos. Â The pau dough is pliable, easy to handle and pleat. Â It is a good pau skin dough which can be used to wrap any sweet pau filling of your choice.These paus turned out well with a natural sugar colour. Â The pau texture is good - soft, moist and fluffy. Â It can be eaten plain but here I used the AKK mungbean paste as filling which is less sweet. Â I have also tried using jaggery sugar for the mungbean paste and the sweetness is just nice for me and should be alright for my mum who is a diabetic. Â Hope she can enjoy these paus without 'control'.Ingredients[makes 20-24 paus]500 gm pau flour1/2 tbsp double action baking powder1/2 tbsp instant yeast1/2 tsp salt100 gm jaggery sugar [gula merah]250 - 280 ml water1 tbsp vegetable shorteningBring water and sugar to boil in a sauce pan until sugar dissolve. Strain and set aside to cool.In a mixing bowl, add in all the ingredients except shortening. Â Gradually, add in cooled syrup and knead until dough is soft, add in shortening. Â If dough is too dry, add a little plain water.Continue to knead until soft, smooth and pliable. Â Dust hands with flour, shape dough into a round ball. Â Cover and leave in mixing bowl to rest for 20 minutes.Punch down dough to release the trapped air. Â Divide into 20-24 equal portions and shape into round balls.Flatten each ball into circle to wrap any sweet or savoury pau filling of your choice. Â Pleat into pau shape and place on parchment paper or flatten paper cases.Place paus in a steaming tray, cover to proof for 30 - 40 minutes.Bring water to boil in a steamer, steam paus over high heat for 12 minutes. Â Off heat.Remove paus to cool on rack or serve immediately.

title: JAGGERY SUGAR [GULA MERAH] HUAT KUIH
text: HEI TANG FAI GAOÂ Read several articles on food ingredients and came acrossone article on refined sugar.Â  It is saidthat refined sugar is not a healthy food ingredient and should be usedsparingly.Â  It also states that the bestsubstitute is pure, natural sugar known as Jaggery Sugar [é»‘ç³–]Â .Â  I did some searching on this and finally found outthat Jaggery sugar is actually Gula Merah which is a sugar ingredient I having been using for making kuih muih and some other sweet desserts not knowing it is jaggery sugar. Â I thought this is the same as brown sugar.The definition I got for Jaggery Sugar Powder â€“ it is anatural sweetening substance made by concentrating sugar cane juice without anypreservatives or colouring added.Â  It canbe used for brewing coffee, tea, chocolate drinks and preparing cakes, kuih,syrups and desserts.This steamed cake â€˜huat kuihâ€™ is made using jaggery sugarand less refined sugar.Â  I was happy tosee them smiling so beautifully.Â  Nexttime I will use 75-100% jaggery sugar for this kuih as I prefer not too sweetdesserts.Â  These huat kuihs are soft andmoist after steaming and remains the same even on the next day.Â  The sweetness is acceptable but I believe canreduced the refined sugar portion to 1/3.Â Ingredients[makes 12 huat kuihs]60 gm jaggery sugar [gula merah] + 60 gm caster sugar240 ml hot water250 gm plain flour + 4 tsp baking powder50 ml corn oil or melted butter12 small/medium papercup casesStir both sugars in hot water until dissolved, thenstrained.Sieve plain flour and baking powder into a large mixingbowl.Gradually, stir cooled syrup into flour.Â  Mix until batter is smooth, then stir in thecorn oil.Â  Mix well.Transfer batter into a plastic bag, tied up, make a slitat one corner.Â  Press batter intoprepared paper cup cases until 90% full.Heat steamer over high heat, place batter in steamingtray and steam for 20 minutes [do not uncover steamer in between steaming].Remove and serve.

title: MEATBALLS WINTER MELON AND MUSHROOM HOT POT
text: This recipe looks difficult with a long list of ingredients but actually it is not. Â There is only 3 main ingredients, the rest are marinades and seasoning. Â I have no regrets trying out this recipe. Â It does not only look refreshing and tempting but also tastes good. Â I believe, it is suitable for all ages. Â Moreover, it is a quick cook dish once you assemble the ingredients.The meatballs and mushrooms are tasty, the winter melon are soft and also absorbs the flavours well. Â It looks a presentable dish for Â family dinners or gatherings.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 103 with modificationsIngredients[serves 3]200 gm minced meat with some fatsÂ 1/4 tsp each of salt, pepper and sesame seed oildash of msg or 1/4 tsp sugar [I prefer to use msg]1/2 tsp light soy sauce3/4 tbsp cornstarch1/2 tbsp oilsome slices of ginger2 stalks spring onions - cut sections6 dried mushrooms - soaked150 gm winter melon - skinned and cut into chunkssome sliced red carrots250 ml - 300 ml waterSeasoning [combined]1 tsp each oyster sauce, light soy sauce and shaoxing wine1/4 tsp salt to tastedash of msgMeatballs - Put all the meatball ingredients into a mixing bowl [except cornstarch], stir in one direction until sticky. Â Add in the cornstarch and stir again until sticky. Â Gather up the minced meat paste and hit it against the base of the bowl for 3-4 times to firm up the mixture. Â Rest mixture while you prepare the other ingredients.Heat up oil in a non stick wok, saute ginger and some spring onions until fragrant and slightly charred.Â Add in mushrooms, carrots and winter melon. Â Stir to mix well, then pour in the seasoning and water. Â Bring to boil for 5 minutes.Put shaped meatballs to cook, cover and simmer till the meatballs are firm and cooked. Â Meanwhile, heat up a claypot. Â Stir in spring onions.Pour into claypot, serve hot.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #16Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: EZCR#89 - FRIED VEGETABLES WITH TAUCHEONG MEAT SAUCE
text: Homey, Chinese style dishes are simple and at times couldbe surprisingly good.Â Â  The use of somebasic ingredients with a main ingredient can make each dish so unique,Â  apart from being tasty and delicious.This dish is an example of what I am trying to say.Â  The basic ingredients are some meat, ginger, chilli andpreserved soy bean paste [taucheong].Â These basic ingredients can be used to fry a variety of vegetables ofyour choice [from leafy greens to beans, Â quashand gourd].Recipe inspired by Chinese TV Cook Show withmodificationsIngredients[serves 3]2 stalks of celery â€“ peeled and cut thin slicesÂ½ red chilli â€“ seeded and shredded1 cm piece ginger â€“ shredded2 tbsp preserved soy bean paste [taucheong]50 gm pork belly â€“ shredded [you can use pork tenderloin]Â½ tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp cooking wineDash of msg and pepper to tasteHeat up a non-stick wok, fry shredded meat pork with oiluntil fragrant and oil oozes out [you may need more oil if using porktenderloin].Â  Push aside and add inginger and red chilli, sautÃ© until aromatic.Add in taucheong and seasoning.Â  Stir to mix all ingredients, then add in somewater.Bring to boil for several minutes, add in the vegetables.Â  Give it a good toss and stir well until vegetables arecooked.Â Dish up to serve immediately.

title: EZCR#88 - SCRAMBLED EGGS WITH BLACK FUNGUS
text: This is a healthy, nutritious dish though withsimple ingredients.Â  It is easy, quickto cook and yet the taste is awesome, goes well with rice, porridge and I thinkperfect as a vegetable wrap filling.Â  I shouldhave got ready some salad leaves to wrap it upÂ to eat it just like this.Â  Nexttime, I will instead of serving it with rice.The mixing of eggs with the cornstarch water helps to give the scrambled eggs a soft and moist texture, while the combination of seasoningbrings out the flavor of this dish.Recipe inspired by Chinese TV cook show withmodificationsIngredients[serves 3]2 eggs lightly beaten with 1 tsp cornflour + 1 tbsp water100 gm pork tenderloin â€“ shredded and marinate with 1 tspeach light soy sauce and cooking wine, dash of pepper and a tablespoon of the eggmixture.Â  Mix well.A handful of soaked black fungus or more if you like â€“shredded 50 gm red carrot â€“ shreddedSeasoning1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, vegetarian oyster sauceand wineDash of pepperSome chopped coriander leavesHeat a non stick wok with some oil, stir fry marinatedpork until cooked.Â  Dish up.Using the same wok, add 1 tbsp oil, pour in beaten egg and stircontinuously to scramble the egg mixture until fragrant but still moist.Add in black fungus, carrots and fried pork.Â  Toss and stir well to combine ingredients.Add in seasoning, toss and mix well until all ingredientsare cooked.Dish up to serve.Â Â Garnish with some chopped coriander leaves.

title: TOMATO TOFU EGG SOUP
text: Sometimes with too many recipes books/magazines in hand,we can still run out of ideas on what to cook and how to plan a dinnermenu.Â  This happens all because there aretoo many and it is hard to make selections or you may not be able to get someof the ingredients needed to cook the dish.When this happens, I will start looking for easy, simplerecipes where the ingredients needed are easily available.This tomato, tofu and egg soup is one easy, simple and quick to cook soup.Â  The original recipeusesÂ  ready packed chicken stock but I amnever in favour of using this kind of Â stock for my soups.Â  IÂ prefer to use Eel fish for the stock as it is naturally sweet.Â Eel FishThis recipe is inspired from Mama Cheung Cookâ€™s videowhich I happened to come across on you-tube.Â Â Here is the recipeÂ  with somemodifications.Â  Itâ€™s a simple, nutritious, appetising and healthy soup with a tangy taste.Â Ingredients2 large tomatoes â€“ cut wedges1 block traditional tofu â€“ cubed1 egg lightly beaten with 1 tsp cornstarch in 1 tbspwater1-2 slices ginger2 small pieces [about Â 3" length] eel fish or 1 chicken carcass750-800 ml waterSalt to tasteGarnish â€“ chopped coriander leavesBring water to boil in a soup pot, add in eel pieces or chickencarcass.Â  Boil again and simmeruntilÂ  the flavor is well infused in thesoup.Â  Strain the stock. Â Discard the eel fish pieces or chicken carcass.Heat up a soup pot with 1 tsp oil, sautÃ© ginger slicesuntil aromatic, add in tomato pieces and fry until soft.Â  Add in prepared stock, bring to boil andsimmer for 10 minutes.Â Â Add in tofupieces, bring to boil again for 5 minutes and add in salt to taste.Â Â Stir in beaten egg, off heat.Scoop soup into serving bowl, garnish with chopped coriander leaves.Serve hot.

title: SPARE RIBS WITH TOMATO CURRY STEW
text: As I prefer to cook simple and easy dishes, I seldom prepare a stew dish because there are quite a number of ingredients in it.According to Wikipedia, 'A stewÂ is a combination of solid Â food ingredientsÂ that have been cookedÂ in liquidÂ and served in the resultant gravy.Â Â Ingredients in a stew can include any combination of vegetablesÂ [such as carrots, potatoes, onions, beans, corn, peppers and tomatoes]Â or meat,Â especially tougher meats suitable for slow-cooking, such as beefÂ or pork ribs. SeasoningÂ and flavouringsÂ may also be added. Stews are typically cooked at a relatively low temperature [simmeredÂ not boiled],Â Â allowing flavors to mingle'.This stew turned out to be an easy dish to prepare though there are a number of ingredients needed. Â It is a little spicy, tangy and the ribs are infused with the seasoning flavour. Â Nice stew to serve with rice as a One Dish Meal. Serving the stew in a claypot, retains the heat and aroma of the curry flavour.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 103Â with slight modificationsIngredients400 gm meaty spare ribs - blanched in boiling water and rinsed1 cob corn - cut into pieces1 carrot - cut into pieces1 large tomato - cut into pieces1 red capsicum - cut into pieces1 yellow onion - cut into pieces1 tbsp cooking oil1 1/2 tbsp curry powder [mix with some water into a paste]Seasoning1 - 1 1/2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp salt to taste1/2 tsp sugar500 ml water1 stalk coriander - choppedHeat oil in a non-stick wok, saute onions until aromatic, add in curry powder. Â Fry until fragrant.Add in spare ribs, carrots and corn pieces. Â Stir fry to mix well, add in seasoning followed by water.Add in capsicum and tomatoes pieces. Bring to boil, then cover to simmer ingredients for 40 minutes or until ribs are tender and gravy is reduced. Transfer to a claypot, bring to boil again.Remove from heat, sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.Serve immediately.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #16Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: OYSTER FLAVOUR CHICKEN
text: The past 2 weeks, there were so much of Nyonya dishes at home due to our families celebrating Chinese All Souls Day [Ching Ming]. Â As there were several cemeteries to go and quite a number of ancestors' graves to visit, we have to do it in a few days. Â Each time, food offerings have to be prepared for the visits and also at our family home. Â All in all there is a total of 13 graves and 2 in the columbarium to visit and you can imagine how much offerings that was prepared.In between these days, easy simple cooking is best for cook. Â This is one of the easy recipes which I tried. Â Just 2 main ingredients and a simple seasoning sauce make a wonderful tasty dish.The chicken is aromatic, tasty and flavour from the oyster sauce is perfect with the blanched broccoli florets. Â Goes well with rice.Ingredients1 large deboned chicken whole leg - cut bite size pieces1 tbsp each of chopped ginger and garlic1 stalk spring onions - cut sections1 small broccoli - cut floretsÂ Seasoning2 tbsp each light soy sauce and oyster sauce1 tbsp wine1/4 tsp sugar to tastePan fry chicken pieces [skin side first] in a non stick wok Â with 1 tsp oil until brown and crispy. Â Flip over to fry the meat side. Â The oil from the chicken is enough to cook this dish.Push aside chicken, saute chopped garlic and ginger and some spring onion sections until aromatic.Mix the ingredients together, add in the seasoning sauce and some water. Â Bring to boil and braise until chicken is cooked and sauce has thickened. Â Stir in spring onions.Meanwhile, blanch broccoli florets in boiling water. Â Dish up onto serving platter.Top with braised chicken pieces.

title: TOFU MEAT PATTIES
text: A simple pattie recipethat is easy to concoct with only 2 main ingredients, some aromatics andseasoning.Â Â  Itâ€™s so easy and yet I get toenjoy some soft and moist patties which are light, tasty and healthy.Recipe adapted from YumYum Magazine No. 103 with modificationsIngredients300 gm minced meat [you can use 50:50 minced meat and fish paste]Â½ block tofu2 tbsp diced carrots1 stalk spring onions â€“dicedSeasoningÂ½ tsp saltÂ¼ tsp 5 spice powder1 tbsp each cornstarch andplain flourÂ  Cut tofu into quarters andleave in a colander to drain off excess water, then add to the remainingingredients in a mixing bowl.Â  Mix wellall the ingredients into a paste.Form the minced meat andtofu mixture into meatballs.Put the meatballs into aheated pan, press lightly to flatten them..Â Pan fry until golden brown on both sides.Dish up and serve withchilli sauce.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #16Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: TEOCHEW SEAWEED MEATBALLS SOUP
text: In this monthâ€™s selected cookbook for Cookbook CountdownEvent #16, I came across many recipes on various meatball dishes.Â  The minced meat is combined with variousother ingredients and seasonings and each ends up to be a unique dish.I have chosen this recipe as I have in hand all theingredients and there is no reason why not to try.Â  Itâ€™s again a simple meatball soup yet ratherunusual with the addition of seaweed.Â Â The meatballs are tender and the soup is really tasty and aromatic.Â  It would be great to serve with rice or evena bunch of glass noodles.Â  Slurrp,Slurrp, Slurrp everything there is in a bowl.Recipe adapted from YumYum Magazine No. 103 with modificationsIngredients200 gm minced meatA handful ofÂ seaweedChopped carrots1 sprig coriander leaves â€“ chopped2-3 water chestnuts â€“ peeled and finely choppedChicken bones or fish bones to make stock Some chopped tong chye750 ml waterSalt and pepper to tasteSeasoningÂ½ tsp saltÂ¼ tsp sugarÂ½ tsp pepper1 tsp light soy sauce1 tsp sesame oil1 Â½ tbsp cornstarchBring Â water toboil in a soup pot, add in fish bones or chicken bones.Â  Boil Â until the sweetness of the bones is infused in the soup. Â Discard the bones and strain ifnecessary.In a mixing bowl, combine the meatball ingredients andseasoning.Â  Mix well into a sticky paste. Â Shape into'ping pong' size meatballs.Drop meatballs into boiling pot, lower heat and simmer untilmeatballs are cooked and soup liquid is clear.Â  Season soup with some salt and pepper.To serve, add in some chopped preserved vegetables [tongchye] and Chinese celery [kin chye].Enjoy!This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #16Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: BRAISED TAUPOK WITH MEI CAI
text: I was surprised that this simple dish can earn a 'Thumbs Up' from my hubby when he tried this. Â He says that this dish is suitable for all ages especially the seniors. Â He is also wondering why the 'Chap Fan' stalls [Economy Food Stalls] do not serve this dish. Â It is good with rice or porridge. Â He even asked for the recipe to share with his regular Chap Fan stall owner. Â It has to be good or maybe this dish suits his preference.Anyway, I like this too because it is easy and economical to prepare this dish, hehehe! Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 103 with slight modificationsIngredients100 gm preserved sweet mei caiÂ 100 gm minced meat [with some fats]10 pieces tofu puff - cut halve1 tbsp chopped garlicenough water1-2 tbsp oilSeasoning1-2 tbsp light sauce to tastedash of pepperRinse preserved vegetable several times and soaked for 5 minutes. Â Drain and squeeze out excess water. Â Cut thin strips.Heat oil in a non-stick wok, pan fry tofu puff until slightly brown or crispy. Â Dish up.Using the same wok, dry fry the mei cai until dry, push aside. Â Add in 1 tbsp oil, saute garlic until aromatic, add in minced meat. Â Continue to stir fry until firm, then combine all the ingredients.Add in seasoning and enough water to cover the ingredients. Â Bring to boil, lower heat to simmer for 10 minutes before adding the fried tofu puffs.Add some more water, bring to boil and simmer for another 10 minutes.Dish up and serve.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #16Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: EZCR#87 - THREE MUSHROOMS CHICKEN SOUP
text: This soup was cooked at my mother in-law's kitchen last week when the family had a gathering for Chinese All Souls Day [Ching Ming] celebration. Â As many of my hubby's siblings are now vegans and some cutting down their intake of meat, I chose to cook this soup instead of the regularÂ Pig Tripe Soup [Too Thor Th'ng].Here, I used less chicken and a variety of mushrooms. Â One of them is the dried mushrooms, a can of straw mushrooms and another type of fresh mushroom. Â You can used dried mushrooms together with any other 2 types of fresh mushrooms [like Ernygii, Shimeji mushrooms etc] according to your preference.The soup is clear, light and has the nice aroma of mushrooms. Â Mushrooms have anti-cancer properties, regulating blood pressure, improves nutrition and immune system functions etc. Â Looking at these benefits, it's good to include this ingredient in your diet.In many Chinese families, this soup is a family soup and sometimes a must have during Chinese festivities at home.Ingredients1/2 free range chicken - skinned and cut big chunky pieces1 packet Ernygii mushrooms - cut rounds10 dried mushrooms - soaked and halve if they are large1 can straw mushrooms - halved5-6 slices huang chi [Chinese herbs]1-2 tbsp wolfberries [kei chee] - rinsed3-4 slices ginger1200 ml watersalt to taste and dash of pepperBlanch chicken pieces in boiling water for 30 seconds. Â Drain and rinse well.Bring water to boil, add in huang chi, ginger slices, mushrooms and chicken.Bring to boil again, then simmer for 30 minutes or until chicken is tender.Add in kei chee, salt and pepper to taste.Serve in soup bowl.

title: MANDARIN ORANGE MARMALADE [æ©˜å­æžœé…±]
text: Thanks to Ann ofÂ AnncooÂ JournalÂ for sharing this timely preserve recipe. Â I believe most Chinese households would have ample leftover of Mandarin Oranges after Chinese New Year. Â There isn't any leftovers in my home but there was ample at my mother and mother in-law's place.I managed to gather enough from these to homes to make this preserve. Â In a way helping them to clear their stock and I get to enjoy this marmalade.Recipe adapted fromÂ AnncooÂ JournalÂ with slight modifications. Ann's post has many lovely step by step photos on the making of this marmalade.Ingredients[makes 500 gm x 3 bottles]2.2 kg Mandarin oranges700-800 gm caster sugarÂ 1 litre water [Ann uses 1375 ml]Â 4 tbsp fresh lemon juiceÂ Peels from 2 mandarin oranges [optional] - I omitSoak the oranges for about 15 minutes, then wash and scrub the oranges well.Cut into half, crosswise, break out the segments and discard the peel. Â Remove the seeds* into a bowl. Â Finish doing the same for all the oranges.Place the seeds in a small herb bag or tea bag, secure the string well.Put all the ingredients [except the sugar] in a heavy based pot, bring to boil for about 30 minutes or until the orange segments are soft. Â Add in the sugar and continue to boil over medium low heat for about an hour or longer. Â Let it bubble until gel point.Â Ladle the hot jam into the sterilized jars, cover and invert the bottles to cool before storing them in the refrigerator. *The seeds are Â good source of pectin which is needed for jam setting.

title: FRIED TAUPAU IN SWEET SOUR SAUCE
text: This recipe is quite similar to my earlier post onÂ Braised Taupau with Fish Paste. Â The paste mixture is the same while the flavour is different. Â Here, I used the round shape fresh tofu skin and the sauce is sweet and sour.Similarly, preparing the paste needs some effort but it is worth doing it as you can prepare 2 dishes with different flavours with similar ingredients. Â Ingredients for Paste100 gm fish paste50 gm prawn paste50 gm minced meatsome chopped spring onionsSeasoning [mixed together]1 tsp saltÂ 1/4 tsp pepper1/2 tsp sesame seed oil2 tbsp cold waterÂ +1 tbsp cornstarchIn a mixing bowl, combine fish paste, prawn paste and minced meat with seasoning.Stir in a one direction into a sticky paste. Â Add in the spring onions and mix well. Â Shape into ball, place in a container and chill for at least 30 minutes or until required.Other Ingredients10 pieces round fresh soya skin [tau pau] - defrostsome chopped garlic, red chilli and spring onionsSeasoning3 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp sugar1 tbsp vinegar2-3 tbsp waterSeparate the fresh tofu skin and press out excess water.Spread some prepared paste on a piece of taupau. Â Press lightly and set aside. Â Finish doing the same for the rest. Â Heat up a non stick pan with enough oil to pan fry or deep fry the tofu skin until golden brown. Â Push aside.Remove excess oil if any from wok, saute garlic until aromatic. Â  Â Add in fried tofu skin and seasoning sauce, bring to a quick boil.Â Dish up and garnish with chopped spring onion. Â Serve immediately.

title: EZCR#86 - FRY FISH FILLET WITH LEEKS AND CELERY
text: This is a very Chinese flavor dish and you can increasethe seasoning if you love the dish with a stronger flavor.Sometimes homey dishes like this is tasty good to serveeither with a bowl of porridge or a plate of white rice.Â  The dish is complete with protein and fibre.The fish fillet cooked with this seasoning is surprisingly good and a variation from the usual taucheong fish flavour with the addition of chilli sauce. Â Ingredients200 gm shark fish fillet â€“ sliced 1 cm thick pieces1 small stalk leek â€“ cut slantwise1 small stalk Chinese celery [kin chye] stems â€“ cutsections1 red chilli â€“ seeded and cut strips1 small piece ginger â€“ shredded2 pips garlic â€“ sliced1 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp each chilli sauce, light soy sauce, wineÂ¼ tsp sugar1 tbsp preserved soy bean paste [taucheong]Some cornstarch water for thickeningBring some water to boil put in fish fillet, off heat andleave in water for 1-2 minutes.Â  Drainand set aside.Heat wok with oil, sautÃ© ginger, garlic and red chilliuntil aromatic, add in taucheong and some water, then add in the remainingseasoning.Â Add in blanched fish fillets to cook, followed by celeryand leeks.Quickly toss and fry to mix well, thicken with cornstarchwater.Â  Cooks within a minute.Dish up to serve immediately.

title: EZCR#85 - FRIED SPARE RIBS WITH CAPSICUM
text: This is a lovely oriental style spare ribs dish whichneeds no braising yet the ribs are tender and very flavourful seasoned withfermented black beans.Â Â A very simple dish yet awesome to serve with rice.Â  It is savoury dish yet not salty thoughfermented black beans are salty.I wouldnâ€™t mind preparing this dish often as it is reallygood.Ingredients300 gm meaty soft bone spare ribs â€“ cut into small pieces- marinate with 1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and wine,dash of pepper, mix well and add in 1 tbsp beaten egg and 1-2 tbspcornstarch.Â  Set aside for an hour orovernight1 small green capsicum â€“ seeded, cut thin strips1 small red capsicum or red chilli â€“ seeded, cut thinstrips1 -2 tbsp chopped garlicSeasoning1 tbsp chopped fermented black beans [tau see]1 tbsp each light soy sauce and wine1 tsp sugarDash of pepperSome waterPan fry marinated rib pieces in a non stick pan untilbrown and cooked through.Â  Push aside, sautÃ©garlic until aromatic and combine with fried ribs.Add in tau see, fry and mix well. Add in some water,Â capsicum and stir to mix well.Stir fry until sauce is thick and coats the ribs well.Dish up to serve.

title: MILKY COCONUT ROLLS
text: I love buns, baos, kuihs with coconut filling.Â  They are fragrant and tasty.Â  For this breadrolls, the grated coconut is sweetened with palm sugar [gula Melaka] and condensedmilk.Â  Looks good and tastes good too.These simple bun dough is easy to handle as the dough issoft, smooth and pliable.Â  The baked bunsare soft and moist but not so after a day. Â Anyway, not to worry, it wouldn't go to waste as these are still good when reheated in the oven or steamed.Ingredients For Coconut Filling250 gm grated white coconut100 gm palm sugar [gula Melaka]2 tbsp condensed milkCombine sugar and grated coconut in a non stick pan, stiruntil sugar dissolves.Add in condensed milk and stir Â continuously Â to mix well and cook until the paste is almostdry but moist.Off heat and cool before use.Ingredients For Bun Dough250 gm wholemeal bread flour50 gm plain flour1 Â½ tsp instant yeast50 gm castor sugar 120 ml water20 gm butterCombine all the ingredients [except butter] in a mixingbowl.Â  Knead until the dough is soft andadd in butter.Â  Continue to knead doughtill smooth and pliable.Shape into round, cover to rest for 20 minutes of doublein size.Â  Punch down and roll into aball.Dust board with some flour, roll dough into arectangle.Â  Spread coconut filling evenlyall over the dough.Roll dough into a log and seal the edges well like aSwiss Roll.Cut roll into 1 inch width, make a slight in the centre Â and open up to make an inverted roll.Place on a line baking tray.Â  Leave to proof for 30 minutes or double insize.Bake in a preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 12-15minutes or golden brown.

title: EZCR#84  - RED RESIDUMM PORK TENDERLOIN
text: These days, I prefer to use pork tenderloin [li chi rou] inmany of the pork dishes which I tried.Â The main reasons are that this part of pork is lean, tender, cooks quickly and very suitable for quick stir fry recipes. Â This part of pork meat is lean, can say without fats and is much healthier.This dish tastes savoury, sweet and sourish.Â  It is fast to cook dish which is flavourful with the aroma of wine and nice to go with rice.Ingredients200 gm pork tenderloin â€“ sliced[marinate with some salt, pepper, sugar, wine and 1 tbspbeaten egg, mix well then add in 1 tbsp cornflour, mix and set aside]2-3 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked and slicedSome sliced ginger and spring onions cut into sectionsSeasoning1 tbsp red rice yeast residuum [ang chow]1 tbsp wine Â¼ tsp each of salt and sugar to tasteDash of pepper1 tbsp black vinegarHeat up 1 tbsp oil in a non stick wok, pan fry marinatedpork slices over medium heat until brown and cooked.Â  Dish up.Using the same wok, add a little more oil if necessary, sautÃ© ginger and spring onions untilaromatic, add in the mushrooms and continue to fry until fragrant.Â  Add in red residuum and water.Â  Bring to boil and add in the fried meatslices and seasoning ingredients.Quickly toss well and fry until sauce is almost dry andcoats the meat well.Add extra spring onions as garnishing. Dish up to serve.

title: KUIH BINGKA UBI
text: Most of the time when I prepare kuihs or cakes using tapioca, I Â will buy the ready grated tapioca from the wet market. Â But I stopped doing this when the vendor ceased selling it and I gave up making this kind of kuih eventhough, Kuih Bingka Ubi is one of my favourite Nyonya kuih. Â I loved the mild bitter taste and unique aroma of tapioca.I have always thought that grating the tapioca is a very difficult task but I have managed to overcome this negative thought when I took the challenge to bake this kuih. Â Now, I am looking forward to try other types of tapioca kuih recipes that I have in hand.This Kuih Bingka Ubi recipe is a keeper. Â It is not difficult at all to grate the tapioca and this kuih is awesome. Â Very, very nice though a bit on the sweet side but definitely can be overcome by reducing the sugar a little.Do take a look at the pictures and you may agree that this kuih is good without tasting. Â That's my opinion, hahaha!Here, I am sharing the original recipe and also the modified recipe. Â I have to modify the recipe as I could not obtain the 750 grams grated tapioca from the tapioca I bought [I bought about 820 gm tapioca, should have bought more]. Â I made up the portion with white grated coconut. Â Luckily, the kuih turned out perfect.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 95 with modificationsModified Recipe650 gm grated tapioca100 gm grated white coconut150 ml thick coconut milk220 gm caster sugar75 ml melted butter2 eggs1/2 tsp salt1 7-inch square tin, lined and greased at the sidesOriginal Recipe750 gm grated tapioca180 ml thick coconut milk270 gm caster sugar75 ml melted butter2 eggs1/2 tsp salt2 loaf tins [18cmx10cmx8cm]Combine all the ingredients until well mix and sugar dissolves.Pour into baking container and bake in a preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 45-60 minutes until cooked through [test with a skewer] and top is golden brown.Remove to cool in the pan before slicing to serve.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #15Â Â  hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: CARAMELISED BLACK PEPPER FISH SAUCE CHICKEN
text: This sauce is not only good for fish but it is awesome with fried chicken, too. Â A look at the pictures is convincing enough for you to give this a try. Â Believe me, this is really good, quick and easy for a complete One Dish Meal.Ingredients forCaramelised Black Pepper Fish Sauce [kho quet][see earlier post on preparation and its' use]2 tbsp oil3 tbsp sugar1 tbsp ground black pepper3 tbsp fish sauce or more3 tbsp waterOther Ingredients[serves 3]3 pieces chicken whole legs - deboned with skin and fats removed [chicken chop style]oved and slicedSome chopped coriander leavesSome sliced cucumbers, cherry tomatoes and blanched carrotsPut oil and sugar in a saucepan, heat up with low heat and stir until the mixture is lightly brown.Add in black pepper, fish sauce and water. Bring to boil until bubbly and slightly thick.Â  Off heat and store in a glass container for later use.Â  This mixture can be prepared earlier.Pan fry chicken pieces [skin side first] in a non stick pan until oil oozes out and golden brown. Flip over to fry the meat side, cover to speed up the cooking for 1-2 minutes.Flip over the chicken pieces, then add inÂ 3-4 tablespoonsÂ of prepared caramelized black pepper fish sauce and 100 ml or enough water.Â Bring to boil for about 5-10 minutes until chicken pieces are cooked through and the sauce is reduced to thick.Add in some chopped coriander leaves and blanched carrots. Â Mix well, off heat.Dish up to serve with a plate of rice, garnish sliced cucumbers, cherry tomatoes and with extra coriander leaves.Â  Serve immediately.

title: CHICKEN ADOBO
text: One of my best friend and so called Swiss 'brother' Heinz was married to a Filipino lady of American and Chinese descend, Edith. Â During our [me and my hubby] last visit to their home in Cebu, Philippines, we got to try many interesting Filipino dishes. Â Some are authentic Filipino dishes while several are a mixture of flavours ranging from Swiss to Spanish and Mediterranean. The ones which we particularly remembered and liked are the Lechon, Pork Braten and Chicken Adobo. Â Of course, we loved the simple fresh salads and boiled potatoes prepared by brother Heinz which go so well with the meat dishes. We were never tired of the Chinese steamboat dinners [at home or at the restaurants] which we enjoyed whenever we met either in Switzerland, Philippines or Malaysia.Back to this Chicken Adobo, it is quite similar to the Chinese braised soy sauce chicken but with the addition of vinegar, bay leaves and black peppercorns. Â In fact, there are quite a number of Filipino dishes which taste sourish. Â Either vinegar or lemon/lime juices are use in the preparation. Â There are some meat dishes with Chinese influence too like their pig trotter stew which they also called 'hong bak'. Â This recipe is very basic Chicken AdoboÂ recipe which I modified slightly.Â It tastes savoury, sourish and has the flavour and aroma of black pepper. Â  It's awesome.I am sharing this post today in memory of dear Heinz who passed away Â suddenly this day 2016. Â Sadly missed and forever remembered by all of us. Â Ingredients3-4 chicken thighs - cut into 2 piecesseveral pieces of dried bay leaves4 tbsp light soy sauce2-3 tbsp Apple Cider vinegar4-5 cloves garlic - skinned and crushed3 tsp sugar1 tsp ground black pepper1 tsp whole black peppercorns1/4 tsp salt to taste1 cup or more water1/2 tbsp oil [can omit if using non-stick pan]Marinate chicken pieces with all the ingredients except whole black peppercorns, salt and water for 1-2 hours or overnight.Heat up a non stick pan, put in the marinated chicken [skin side first] to cook until nicely browned. Â Flip over.Pour in the marinating sauce and add in the whole black peppercorns and water.Bring to boil, cover then simmer for about 20-30 minutes over low medium heat until chicken is tender.Uncover and continue to cook until the sauce is reduced and thick.Dish up to serve with rice.

title: MUNG BEANS WITH WATER CHESTNUTS DESSE
text: This is actually Lek TaoSuan [Split Mung Bean Sweet Dessert] with a twist by adding water chestnuts. There was another dessert with Dumplings with Split Mung beansÂ which I have shared some time ago.The preparations are quitesimple and done separately in a few steps.TheÂ  soupÂ is then thickened by using potato starch water and awesome to serve withsome crispy fried Chinese cruellers [yu char koay].Â  The sweetness is acceptable but you mayreduce it a little, it still tastes good. Â A point to note is to try get good qualitysplit mung beans.Â  I got to know thatthere are different quality ones.Â  When Ilast made the mungbean paste for making Angku Kuih, the mungbeans I bought Â took much longer time to steam until cookedand yet it wasnâ€™t soft and fluffy as expected after steaming.Â  For this dessert, I bought the mungbeans fromanother vendor and they were good because after steaming they were soft, fluffyand light.Â  The price is the same.A lovely dessert to servein the afternoon or after dinner.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 95 withmodificationsIngredients200 gm split mungbeans10 waterchestnuts â€“ peeledand quartered2 litres water200 gm caster sugar2 pandan leaves â€“ knotted60 gm potato starch + 100ml water1 piece Chinese Cruellers[yu char koay] â€“ cut small piecesWash and soak splitmungbeans for at least 4 hours or overnight.Â Drain well.Â  Place on steamingtray and steam for 45-60 minutes or until cooked, soft and fluffy.Â  Set aside.Bring water and pandanleaves to boil in a pot or slow cooker [high heat], add in waterchestnuts andthen sweeten with sugar.Gradually pour in potatostarch water, stirring continously until thick.Â Add in steamed split mung beans and mix well.Scoop into serving bowlsand top with cruellers to serve.Â This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #15Â Â  hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: CHIVES AND SAUSAGE OMELETTE
text: EGGS - so long as there are eggs in the kitchen, you will not go hungry. Â Eggs can be cooked in numerous ways - boiled, fried, poached etc. according to how you like to eat it. Â It is such a very versatile cooking ingredient that can be mixed and matched with lots of other ingredients. Â Most times, the result is awesome. Â It can be served with rice, porridge, bread, noodles and salads etc.Back to this dish, it is an easy and simple omelette with 3 main ingredients - eggs, chives and Chinese sausage [lap cheong]. Â Smooth and firm in texture, retains the moisture of the chives and the diced sausages add aroma and taste to this simple omelette.Â A good option when you are short of dishes to serve for lunch or dinner.Ingredients[makes 3 pieces]50 gm chives - washed and cut small pieces1 Chinese sausage - remove outer skin and diced1 red chilli - seeded and chopped3 eggs1/4 tsp of pepper and salt to tasteCombine chives, chilli, eggs and seasoning in a bowl.Heat up a non-stick wok, fry sausage until aromatic and oil oozes out. Â Dish up and add to [1]. Â Mix well.Add some oil to wok, pour in 1/3 portion of egg mixture. Â Fry omelette until firm and brown, then flip over to fry the other side until cooked. Â Dish up onto serving platter.Finish frying the remaining in 2 portions.Serve immediately.

title: EZCR#82 - BRAISED SPICY BABY RIBS
text: There are numerous easy Chinese recipes in my collectionwaiting to try.Â  This provides ampleoptions for me to select and my priority to choose those really easy ones, bestare those with the least ingredients or ingredients that are easily available. Such recipes do help make cooking for the family a much easier task and all gets to enjoy a variety of good food.This recipe is one of the many which I find really simpleand easy with only a few steps.Â  You canbraise the baby ribs in a wok [which needs watching over the stove], using a slow cooker, steamer and even a thermalcooker.Â  Whichever way you choose, theonly thing you have to note is the volume of water to add.Â If using a wok, more water is needed than the others to cook the ribs till soft and tender.For this dish, the ribs have to be braised till tender and the sauce is thick. This is an aromatic, tasty, spicy, sweet and sourish dish, awesome to serve with rice. Â Best of all, it can be pre-cooked before meal time and just needed to reheat before serving.Ingredients[servesÂ  4]500 gm baby ribs [ the part with soft white bones] â€“ cutsmall pieces1 yellow onion â€“ chopped1 tbsp each of chopped ginger and garlicSome coriander leavesSeasoning3 tbsp each of chilli sauce and plum sauce1 tbsp each ofÂ wine and light soy sauceÂ¼Â  tsp saltEnough water to cover ingredients Heat 1 tbsp oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© chopped garlic,ginger and onions until aromatic.Add in baby ribs and sweet chilli sauce.Â  Stir fry ingredients for awhile before addingthe remaining seasoning. Â Mix well.Add in water,bring to boil for 5 minutes, then lower heat, cover and simmer for about 40minutes or until ribs are tender and sauce reduced.If ribs are not tender when the sauce has thickened, add a little more water, uncover andcontinue to braise until ribs are soft and sauce reduced.Dish up and garnish with coriander leaves.

title: TEOCHEW STYLE FRIED MEE SHUA
text: This is a third recipe for Chinese Teochew style fried noodles [aka mee teow or mee shua] which I am sharing here. Â Basically, the preparation and cooking for these 3 recipes are almost similar except for some ingredients used. Â Here, preserved radish [sweet cai por], chives and beansprouts are used while my earlier recipeÂ Family Style Fried Teochew Mee TeowÂ uses Chinese leeks. Â The otherÂ recipeÂ is a spicy, sweet and sour version. Â All in all, they are delicious and tasty noodles.Looks like there are varied ways to use one basic ingredients, the Teochew Mee Sua or Mee Teow. Â The choice is yours, then. Â I loved having this fried noodles with sambal belacan or chopped small chillies for extra oomph!Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 95 with modificationsIngredients[serves 4-5]300 gm Teochew noodles - loosen and cut to shorten the strands2 tbsp oil2 tbsp chopped garlic2 tbsp preserved sweet radish [cai por]150 gm pork belly meat - cut thin stripsÂ 2 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed200 gm beansprouts - tailed100 gm chives - washed and cut into sections1 small carrot - cut thin stripsÂ 250 ml waterpepper and msg to tasteBlanch noodles in boiling water until cooked and soft. Drain in a colander and rinse under running water.Heat oil in wok, saute garlic, cai por, meat until aromatic and firm. Â Add dried prawns and carrots, fry until fragrant. Â Add in water, bring to boil.Add in blanched noodles, stir fry to combine ingredients well.Add in beansprouts and chives. Stir fry until vegetables are cooked. Â Add in seasoning to taste.Dish up to serve Â with cut chillies or sambal belacan. Garnish with some fried crispy shallots.Â Â This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #15Â Â  hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: EZCR#81 - PLUM SAUCE MEAT WITH ASPARAGUS
text: Surprisingly good dish with 2 main ingredients [lean meat and asparagus], some aromatics [ginger, garlic and chillies] and simple seasoning [plum sauce and vinegar].If you do have these ingredients in your kitchen, do give this recipe a try and I bet you will enjoy it. Â I will definitely prepared this again. Â The fried meat is tender, while the asparagus are a little crunchy and blends well with the simple sweet sourish sauce.In this dish, no water is added in the sauce.Ingredients200 gm pork shoulder meat or mei hua rou - sliced thinly[marinate meat with salt, pepper, some beaten egg and cornstarch]200 gm asparagus - peeled and slice slantwise1 tbsp chopped ginger or more1 tbsp chopped garlic or more1 tbsp chopped red chillies or more1 tbsp chopped spring onions or more [keep some for garnishing]some toasted sesame seeds [optional]SeasoningÂ 2 tbsp plum sauce or more2 tbsp Apple Cider vinegarMarinate meat slices with salt, pepper and beaten egg. Â Mix well and add in the cornstarch. Â Set aside.Combine the seasoning in a bowl.Heat up some oil in a non stick wok, pan fry meat slices until brown and cooked through. Â Push aside.Add in the chopped ingredients, saute until fragrant. Â Mix well with fried meat slices and add in the asparagus.Pour in the seasoning sauce. Â Bring to boil until almost thick and coats the meat slices well.Dish up, garnish with some spring onions and toasted sesame seeds.Serve hot.

title: FRIED CHICKEN WITH FISH SAUCE
text: I have picked another cookbook from Yum Yum Publications for this month's Cookbook Countdown Event#15. The chosen recipes from this book are very easy and simple, yet they are awesome.Â The flavours are quite unusual with the fragrance of fish sauce and made spicy with a good quality sweet chilli sauce. Â I loved this dish. Â The chicken wings are succulent and well coated with the thick sauce. Â It's finger licking good.Â This is an authentic and delicious Vietnamese fried chicken aka canh ga chien nuoc mam. Â It can be a good party dish serve with a spread of fresh salad.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 95Ingredients[serves 3]6 chicken wings - tip removed and cut into drumettes and wingettes1 tsp saltÂ + 1/2 tsp pepperSeasoning [combine]1 tbsp each of Â fish sauce and sweet chilli sauce1 tsp sugar3 tbsp waterMix chicken wings with salt and pepper. Â Season for at least 30 minutes.Heat up a non stick pan with 1 tbsp oil, pan fry chicken pieces in batches until golden brown. Dish up. Pour out excess oil. Â You can also deep fry the chicken pieces.Bring combined seasoning sauce to boil until bubbly. Â Returned the fried chicken pieces to wok, toss well and boil until sauce is almost dry.Dish up to serve immediately.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #15Â Â  hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: CHEESY LEMON CARROT OGURA CAKE
text: It has been a long while I have not bake Ogura cake with a new flavour. Â This is a new combination of flavour which I tried and it turned out well and good. Â I had baked this cake twice, one for my mother in-law and another time was for my mum.I couldn't snap some photos of the sliced cake as both times they were for giveaways. Â The cook's family only gets to eat the cake edges, poor thing, which is always the case when it is for someone else. Â Perhaps, I have to bake another piece for the family.You can add more cheese powder for strong flavour.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg50 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]2 tbsp cheese powder [available at confectionary store]50 ml Â warm25 ml fresh lemon juice and zest of the lemon2 tbsp freshly grated carrot with the liquidMix warm water with the cheese powder, then mix in the lemon juice and grated carrot.Place the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make a well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil, and combined ingredients [1].Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Â  Smooth the surface with a spatula or just lightly shake the baking tin and the batter will spread out nicely.Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then reduce temperature to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will be dry after baking].Remove from oven and invert the cake after baking. Â Let it cool slightly [about 5-10 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper]. Â Shake the pan lightly from left to right on both sides to dislodge the cake.Cool cake on wire rack before slicing to serve or chill in the refrigerator for slicing and serving later.

title: FRIED ASPARAGUS WITH BEANSPROUTS AND DRIED SQUIDS
text: Stir fried beansprouts is a simple homey dish but you can dress it up a little by adding asparagus and shredded dried squids[cuttlefish]. You will find that there is some difference and tempted to give it a try when you take a look at the photos. Â This is exactly my response when I came across this recipe.The beansprouts must not be overcooked to keep itscrunchiness. Â Great idea to thicken lightly this dish with some cornstarch water, gives a shiny look and moist.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 95 withmodificationsIngredients300 gm beansprouts - tailed3 stalks asparagus â€“ removed the hard stems and stingyparts â€“ sliced thinly1 tbsp shredded ginger25 gm dried cuttlefish shreds â€“ rinsed several times andsqueezed out excess water1 red chilli â€“ seeded and shredded2 tbsp oilSeasoningÂ½ tsp salt to tasteDash of msg1 tbsp Shaoxing wine100 ml water1 tbsp cornstarch waterHeat up wok, add oil and pan fry cuttlefish shreds untilaromatic and crispy.Â  Dish up and setaside.Add in ginger and stir fry until fragrant.Â  Add in beansprouts, red chilli and asparagus. Stir fryuntil well mixed.Add in seasoning and half of the crispycuttlefish shreds.Â  Stir to mix well, addin water, bring to boil and thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up to serve.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #15Â Â  hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: LEMON CHICKEN WINGS
text: This lemon chicken wings dish does not need any deepfrying.Â  The chicken wings are pan friedtill brown and then braised withÂ  lemonslices and seasoning. Â You may deep fry the wings if you like.It is also as flavorful as the usual lemon chicken dish, tastes sweet and sourish.Â  Anappetizingly good dish to have with plain white rice.Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 95 with modificationsIngredients6 chicken wings â€“ cut into two1 tbsp oil1 small lemon â€“ cut into slicesSeasoning2 tbsp plum sauce1-2 tbsp sugar to taste1 tsp salt250 ml water2-3 chilli padi â€“ chopped1 tbsp chopped spring onions or coriander leavesHeat oil in a non-stick pan, pan fry chicken wings untilbrown and fragrant.Add in lemon slices and seasoning.Â  Stir to mix well, then pour in water.Bring to boil, cover with lid and lower heat to simmeruntil sauce has thickened.Sprinkle chopped chilli padi and spring onions.Dish up to serve.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #15Â Â  hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: TEOCHEW TRADITIONAL SNACK KWANG CHEANG
text: These are pan-friedSometime during the Chinese New Year, a blogger friend was asking about this snack when he visited my earlier post. Recently, while browsing through this magazine, I chance upon this recipe which is slightly different from my recipe.I gave this Kwang Chian recipe a go and it turned out welltoo.Â  The texture is soft, with lots ofpeanuts and it isnâ€™t salty as I thought.Â Â Since these rolls can be prepared and refrigerated until required, I made a double the portionof the original recipe and managed tomake 8 rolls.Â I had deep fried and pan fried them. Â Both ways, they are delicious and rather addictive eatenon its own or with a good chilli sauce.The differences between my first recipe and this one arewith the seasoning , flours used and method.Â The first recipeÂ can be for vegetarians while this one is not as ithasÂ  fish sauce and chicken stockgranules in it.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 95 withmodificationsIngredients [Doubled Portion of Original Recipe][makes 8 Rolls]800 gm yam bean [sengkuang] â€“ peeled and shredded300 gm yam â€“ peeled and shredded200 gm red carrot â€“ peeled and shredded200 gm peanuts â€“ washed and boiled till soft â€“ choppedcoarsely200 - 250 gm rice flour2 tbsp each of plain flour and cornflour1-2 pieces foo peh [dried beancurd sheet]Â  - cut into 8 piecesSeasoning4 tbsp of fish sauce or more to taste2 tbsp chicken stock granules [I used 1 tsp msg]2 tsp pepperFilling â€“ mix vegetables and peanuts in a large mixing bowltogether with seasoning.Â  Add in theflours, mix well.Â  Divide into 8 equalportion.Put a portion onto a piece of beancurd sheet, roll uptightly and neatly into baton.Â  Seal theedges with some flour paste.Â  Place on anoiled steaming tray.Â  Finish doing theremaining.Steam rolls over high heat for about 40 minutes or untilcooked and firm.Â  Remove to cool on awire rack before storing or slicing.To serve, pan fry or deep fry kwang chian pieces untilgolden brown.Â  Serve immediately withchilli sauce.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #15Â Â  hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: FRIED TOFU JAPANESE STYLE
text: I love to cook and enjoy Â most of the soya food products such assoft/firm beancurd, tofu puffs and even Tempeh.Â This dish is another tasty tofu dish with simple ingredients andseasoning. Â This is the second time I cooked this dish and as I like it very much, thought it would be good to keep the recipe here.The fried tofu has thenatural flavor of soya and blends well with the savoury/spicy seasoning sauce.A homey dish that is quick to prepare for your family.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 93 withmodificationsIngredients[serves 3-4]3 pieces Teochew Tofu [beancurd] â€“ quarteredSome cornstarch and salt for coating before fryingSome chopped coriander leavesSome Japanese seaweed mix [a gift from a friend]Seasoning Sauce [combined]2 tbsp light soy sauce orÂ Japanese soya sauce1 tbsp cooking wine or Japanese cooking wine2 tsp sweet chilli sauce50 ml vegetarian mushroom stockHeat up a non stick wok with enough oil to deep fry orpan fry tofu pieces until golden brown.Â Dish up onto serving platter.Remove excess oil, pour in combined seasoning sauce.Â  Bring to boil until almost thick.Â  Pour over fried tofu pieces.Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and sprinkle overwith some crispy Japanese seaweed.Serve immediately.

title: STEWED ROASTED PORK RIBS
text: In Penang,Â  ChineseNew Year to the Hokkiens of Taoist faith is incomplete without the â€˜Pai ThniKongâ€™ [Jade Emperor Godâ€™s Birthday prayers].Â Â Â Â At my paternal home, it has been 5 Â years, we did not celebrate this occasion becauseof the passing of my father [2011] and youngest brother [2013].Â  Â Accordingto traditional, the family does not observe this practice for 3 years whensomeone in the family passed away.It is only this year, the family celebrated this occasionin a rather elaborate way complete with almost all the necessary items asofferings to the God of Heaven.Â  One ofthe items was one whole roasted pig.Â After prayers, Â it was chopped upinto pieces and distributed to relatives, friends and neighbours. Â I asked my mum for the rib part [pai kut] whichI like very much to make a stew or the popular Chai Boey.This is the roasted ribs which I prepared.Â  It is aromatic and tasty, so good to go withrice or porridge. I can just say the flavor is something like canned stewedmeat.Ingredients900 gm roasted pork ribs or trotter â€“ cut into chunkypieces500 ml water5 cm piece cinnamon,Â 2 star anise,Â 2 cloves,2 bay leaves1 big garlic â€“ with skinSeasoningÂ½ tbsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp each wine and oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce30 gm rock sugarÂ½ tsp each of pepper and salt to tastePlace all the ingredients in a heavy based pot.Â  Bring to boil for 5-10 minutes.Lower heat and continue to simmer for about 45 minutes oruntil meat is tender and sauce reduced to thick or consistency preferred.Dish up to serve.Â You can thicken the sauce lightly with some cornstarch water beforeserving.

title: BAKED CURRY CHICKEN IN  FOIL
text: It is common that during festive season, most familiesespecially the Nyonyas would prepare at least one curry chicken dish.Â  But, it wasnâ€™t so at my mother in-lawâ€™s placeduring this yearâ€™s Chinese New Year.Â She has prepared a menu without curry chicken from the eve untilafter.Â  For me, it seems like somethingis missing or incomplete without a curry chicken.Â  Honestly, I do miss this dish then.Â  When I came back to my â€˜nestâ€™ after a week,this is the first curry I prepared in my kitchen.Â You may be wondering why I didn't cook a pot of it then. Â The situation was, I couldn't as I was supposed to prepare dishes with ingredients that were bought by my in-law. Â She didn't buy the ingredients for curry chicken. You may also be wondering why I'm sharing this post long after CNY. It's because I was so busy right after the CNY with company accounts to prepare for submission etc. Â I'm back now, what a relief.Coming back to this dish, there is no usual frying orÂ cooking over the stove.Â  This iscurry chicken baked in an oven.Â  First, I prepared the paste which is then fried, Â marinate the chicken pieces with it, placethem in foil trays and just baked them for 30 minutes. Â While baking, my kitchen was filled with the nice aroma of a yummy curry.So this is it, aromatic, tasty and spicy baked currychicken which I considered a rather healthy version as not too much oil isused toÂ  sautÃ© the curry paste. Â Isn't this awesome.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 87 withmodificationsIngredients[serves 3]2 large chicken whole legs â€“ skin removed and cut bitesize pieces1-2 blades pandan leaves â€“ washed and cut into sections1 tsp salt to taste3 tbsp oilIngredients for Curry Paste [blend and mix]4 shallots - peeled2 stalks lemongrass â€“ cut small pieces3 candlenuts4 red chillies â€“ cut small pieces [I added some small chillies]50 ml coconut milk50 ml waterÂ½ Â tsp salt1 tsp sugarSeason chicken with salt.Â Set aside in the fridge.Blend the ingredients for curry paste until fine.Â Heat up a non stick wok, sautÃ© blended currypaste in oil until aromatic and oil separates.Â Seasoned with salt and sugar, then add in the coconut milk andwater.Â  Bring to boil until fragrant andpaste is slightly thick.Â  Cool beforemarinating chicken with it. You can prepare until this stage and bake the chicken just before serving.Arrange chicken pieces in an aluminium foil tray, topwith pandan leaves and cover with a piece of foil.Â  Seal the edges well.Heat oven to 200 degrees C, then baked chicken for 30minutes or until cooked through.Remove and serve hot.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #14Â Â hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: BRAISED TAU PAU WITH FISH PASTE
text: This dish needs a little extra effort to prepare. Â First, you need to prepare the paste for the filling, then the frying followed by the braising. Â But, it isn't difficult if it is done step by step at different times.The paste filling can be used to make fish balls for soups or noodles. Â It can be stuffed in various vegetables like brinjals, okra, chillies, bittergourd or in soft/firm beancurd. Â Of course, this is a tasty and aromatic dish which is savoury and sourish. Â The fresh tofu skin is tasty when it soaks up the seasoning sauce and fragrant. Â Â Ingredients for Paste100 gm fish paste50 gm prawn paste50 gm minced meatsome chopped spring onionsSeasoning [mixed together]1 tsp saltÂ 1/4 tsp pepper1/2 tsp sesame seed oil2 tbsp cold water1 tbsp cornstarchIn a mixing bowl, combine fish paste, prawn paste and minced meat with seasoning.Stir in a one direction into a sticky paste. Â Add in the spring onions and mix well. Â Shape into ball, place in a container and chill for at least 30 minutes or until required.Other Ingredients1 packet [10 pieces] fresh soya skin [tau pau] - defrostsome chopped garlic, ginger, red chilli and spring onionsSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp wine1 tbsp black vinegar1/4 tsp sugar2-3 tbsp waterSeparate the fresh tofu skin and press out excess water.Spread some prepared fish paste on a piece of taupau and top up with another piece. Â Press lightly and set aside. Â Finish doing the same for the rest. Â Dust stuffed tofu skin with some cornflour before frying.Heat up a non stick pan with enough oil to pan fry or deep fry the tofu skin until golden brown. Â Dish up and set aside.Remove excess oil from wok, saute ginger, garlic and red chilli until aromatic. Â Add in seasoning sauce, bring to boil. Â Return the fried Â taupau pieces to the wok, braise until sauce is reduced slightly.Dish up and garnish with chopped spring onion. Â Serve immediately.

title: FRIED BRINJALS WITH PEANUTS
text: There seems to be lots of unending meat dishes served during the Chinese New Year and till now. Â Rather tired of preparing meat and seafood dishes which I wasn't too keen to indulge.This is a colourful, light, tasty and easy vegetable dish thattastes awesome came to my rescue. Given a choice, I would choose this instead of chicken, pork or prawns. It's suitable for the old and young, Â good to serve this with riceor porridge.The brinjals and tomatoes are soft, sweet andsourish.Â  The braised peanuts are tenderand tasty.Â  If you like the peanuts to becrunchy, just replace the canned braised peanuts to crispy peanuts which is to be addedjust before dishing up.The first time, I prepared this dish, I had no intentionto post the recipe here as I thought it is nothing special.Â  But after tasting it, I changed my mind whichprompted me to cook this again and here is the recipe.Ingredients300 gm brinjal â€“ cut lengthwise and halved1 tomato â€“ cut wedges1 stalk spring onions â€“ cut into sections1 tbsp chopped garlic1 small can braised peanuts â€“ drained off the liquidSeasoning2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp cooking wineÂ½ tsp sugarSalt to tasteDeep fry brinjals in hot oil over high heat in a smallsaucepan until bright purple colour.Â Drained and set aside.Using another wok, add Â½ tbsp oil, sautÃ© chopped garlicuntil aromatic, then add in tomatoes and seasoning.Â  Return the fried brinjals to the wok, tosswell, add a little water and braised peanuts.Stir to mix well and bring the sauce to boil until thick.Â  Add in the spring onion.Â  Mix well, dish up to serve.

title: FRIED PORK WITH MUSHROOMS & FUNGUS
text: This is a very tasty, fragrant fried pork dish. Â Basically, coloured and flavoured with the fermented red beancurd [nam yee] sauce and this dish is awesome.The original cooking method is to deep fry the marinated pork but I have used pan fry method to avoid using too much oil. Â With pan fry method, the pork fillets are tender and flavoursome. Â This dish is quick to cook with the use of pork tenderloin. Â You can use pork belly for this dish but it has to be deep fried otherwise, the braising time will be a little longer to tenderise the meat.Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 87Â with modifications. This is my selected cookbook for this Cookbook Countdown Event #14Ingredients200 gm pork tenderloin - slicedMarinade1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 egg1 tbsp cornstarch10 slices of ginger2 pips garlic - sliced1 red chilli - seeded and cut into pieces2 dried mushrooms - soaked and sliced30 gm red carrot - sliceda handful of black fungus - soaked1-2 tbsp oilSeasoning [combined]1 tbsp each of shaoxing wine, red fermented beancurd sauce, oyster sauce and sugar150 ml water1 tsp cornstarch mixed with 2 tbsp water for thickeningMarinate meat slices with marinade for 30 minutes.Heat up oil in a non-stick pan, pan fry meat slices until golden brown and almost cooked.Push aside, saute ginger, garlic until fragrant, then add in mushrooms, carrot and black fungus. Â Stir to mix well and pour in seasoning sauce. Â Fry to mix ingredients, add in chillies then pour in water and bring to boil. Â Thicken gravy with cornstarch water.Dish up to serve.This post is linked toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #14Â Â hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: HOT AND SPICY FRIED TRADITIONAL TOFU
text: The original recipe uses the seasoning sauce to frymussels.Â  These days Â we do not take seashells so I used theseasoning ingredients to cook this tofu dish.Â It turned out to be a very delicious and tasty dish. For strict vegetarians, just omit the garlic.This sweet, spicy, sourish sauce blends very well withthe fried tofu.Â  I have bought the readyfried traditional tofu from the popular wet market at Air Itam, Penang.Â  Each day the vendor prepares only a limitedamount for sale and you have to be there early to grab these tofu pieces.Â  Anyway, they can be substituted with otherdeep fried tofu.This is an appetizing dish to serve with rice, suitable for vegetarians or if you are looking for healthy soya dish.Ingredients3 pieces fried tofu â€“ cut into smaller pieces1 tbsp each chopped garlic, ginger and red chilli3 small chilli â€“ chopped1 stalk spring onions â€“ chopped1 tbsp oilSeasoning [combined]1 tbsp each light soya sauce, tomato sauce and chilli sauce1 tsp sugar, Â½ tsp salt to taste1 tsp cornstarch3 tbsp waterHeat oil in non-stick wok, sautÃ© garlic, ginger andchillies until fragrant.Â  Add in friedtofu and pour in the seasoning sauce.Quickly stir fry until tofu pieces are well coated withsauce, add in the spring onions.Mix well and dish up to serve.

title: BRAISED CHICKEN WITH SOYA SAUCE & BASIL
text: This is a braised duck dish but I have substituted it with chicken as it is not possible to buy duck Â in parts at my place. Â If using duck, it has to be marinated, cooked till tender before adding the remaining ingredients and seasoning. Â The cooking time is much longer compared to chicken.With chicken, the cooking time is reduced as the chicken pieces are pan fried to almost cooked then braise with seasoning.Quite similar to 'Kung Pao Chicken' but different with the addition of basil leaves which gives a sightly different aroma and flavour.  Good and tasty to serve with white rice.Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 87 with modifications. This is my selected cookbook for this Cookbook Countdown Event #14Ingredients2 chicken whole legs â€“ cut bitesize pieces with skin and excess fats removed Â Â 10 slices ginger5 dried chillies â€“ cut shortlengths and seeded5 pips garlic â€“ sliced1 onion â€“ peeled and sliced1-2 tbsp oilAÂ handful of basil leavesSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp shaoxing wine1 tsp sesame oilEnough water to cover chickenÂ Marinate chicken pieces with 1tbsp light soy sauce and 1 tsp dark soy sauce for 15 minutes.Heat up a non-stick wok, Â add inoil andÂ sautÃ© ginger, garlic and dried chillies until fragrant.Add inÂ chicken and fry until firm and aromatic. Add in onions and dried chillies, stir fry to mix.Add in seasoning, stir fry well before adding water. Â  Bring to boil, lower heat andsimmer until sauce is thick.Stir in basil leaves and stiruntil cooked.Dish up to serve with rice.This post is linked to Cookbook Countdown Event #14Â Â hosted by Â Joyce and Emily ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Forays

title: CNY 2017 - BEE KOH [SWEET GLUTINOUS RICE PUDDING]
text: This is the third recipe for Bee Koh which I tried.  My first was [here]Â and myÂ second attempt was the recipeÂ from the book â€˜Nyonya Flavoursâ€™.    The recipe here is from Amy Behâ€™s first book â€˜At Home With Amy Behâ€™.  I have this book for umpteen years but has never tried this recipe until now when I make Bee Koh as a offering item for praying to Jade Emperor God [9th day of Chinese New Year - Pai Thni Kong].Â My family is Hokkien, so this day is also the Chinese Hokkienâ€™s New Year where Taoists will perform prayers to the Jade Emperor God [Thni Kong] on his birthday. Â In the past, my mother and mother in-law will prepare Bee Koh for this occasion but this is already several years ago.  These 2 great ladies are getting old [in their 80s] and not so energetic doing the usual chores that they used to do years ago.   So it is my turn to prepare it but I'm quite skeptical if mine would be like theirs, so I have to rely on recipes from my collection of recipe books.Â Anyway, I am happy that all the recipes are workable but in my opinion, I prefer this one cosâ€™ the rice is softer, the texture is chewy, sweetness is just nice, very aromatic and I like the shiny look of it. Â We finished this kuih very soon with spoonfuls of it instead of slicing cos' it is chewy and soft.As praying item - traditionally Â the kuih needs to be decorated with red dates and dried longans. Â Isn't these cute?Recipe source from At Home With Amy BehIngredients425 gm glutinous rice â€“ washed then soaked for 4 hours or overnight, drained3 pandan leaves â€“ washed and knotted100 ml water250-300 gm granulated sugar225 ml thick coconut milk [from 1 Â½ grated coconut]1 tsp salt2 pandan leaves â€“ washed and knottedÂ½ tsp fennel [jintan manis] â€“ I omitSteam the soaked and drained glutinous rice over boiling water with pandan leaves for 10 minutes.  After 10 minutes, sprinkle 50 ml water, toss well and steam for another 10 minutes.Sprinkle remaining water, toss well and continue to  steam for a further 10 minutes or until rice is cooked and soft.  Dish out and set aside.Put sugar, pandan leaves and coconut milk in a non-stick wok.  Stir over low heat until sugar dissolves [Do not boil the coconut milk at all].  Strain the mixture if using fennel.Mix sugar mixture with steamed rice in a clean wok.  Stir constantly over medium low heat until Bee Koh is fairly thick, leaves the wok clean and turns into a ball.Transfer to individual plates or trays lined with cling wrap or banana leaf.  Use a banana leaf or cling wrap to level up the surface neatly.Cool completely before slicing to serve.

title: FRIED CELERY WITH ARROWROOT
text: This can be a vegetarian dish or a healthy dish with acombination of vegetables.Â  It is also acolourful dish, at least with five colours said to be good to keep our bodyhealthy.Â Â  These days, most companiespromoting health supplements will advise that it is good to eat food with acombination of colours [at least five] daily to stay fit and strong.It is very convincing when you listen but how practical it is to follow is a big question. Anyway, I believe, so long as we eat a variety of food in a day [maybe at times according to the food pyramid], exercise regularly, keep ourselves active and rest well, we should be able to stay well and energetic.Back to this dish, it has a good combination of ingredients. At times when arrowroot [Ngaku] is in season during Chinese New Year, and when not, you can add it or replace with pork tenderloin fillet. Â  I prepared this dish during the Chinese New Year for my hubby's siblings who are vegetarians.Ingredients2 stalks of celery â€“ cut slantwise pieces3 bulbs of arrowroot â€“ skinned and sliced1 red chilli â€“ seeded and cut into piecesSome black fungus â€“ soaked1-2 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked and slicedA handful of tofu puffs â€“ cut halveÂ Â½ red carrots â€“slicedA few slices of ginger and some chopped garlic1 tbsp oilSeasoning [combined]1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauceÂ½ tsp sugar150 ml water or chicken stock1 tsp cornstarch mixed with 1 tbsp waterHeat up oil in a non stick pan, pan fry arrowroot slicesuntil slightly brown, push aside, add in ginger slices, garlic and mushrooms.Fry until fragrant, add in remaining ingredients exceptcelery.Â  Stir well to mix and pour inseasoning sauce.Bring to boil, add in celery.Â Â  Stir fry quickly and thicken with cornstarchwater.Dish up to serve.

title: EZCR#80  - NIAN NIAN YU YEE DISH [TANG CHU STREAKY PORK BELLY]
text: Again another appetizing meat dish suitable for CNY meals and other occasions.  The streaky pork belly [sua sua rou] is marinated lightly with soy sauce and cooking wine and fried until oil oozes out and crispy.  The sauce is a simple combination for vinegar, tomato sauce and sugar, giving it a sourish sweet taste.These tasty pork slices are served with a generous spread of tomatoes, zucchini and onions.This sweet and sourish sauce is also good choice to serve with crispy fried fish fillet.An awesome dish to serve with rice.Ingredients300 gm streaky pork belly â€“ cut 2 inch lengths1 tomato â€“ slicedSome shredded zucchini1 big onion â€“ peeled and thinly slicedsome toasted sesame seeds for garnishingSeasoning Sauce [combined]3 tbsp vinegar3 tbsp tomato sauce2 tbsp sugar2 tbsp waterMarinate pork belly with some light soy sauce and cooking wine.Arrange tomato slices, zucchini and onions on a serving platter.Heat up a non-stick wok, pan fry pork slices until oil oozes out , brown and crispy.  Dish up and place over serving platter.Remove excess oil.  Using the same wok, pour in the combined seasoning sauce.  Bring to boil until bubbly and thick.Pour sauce over meat slices, sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds. Â Serve immediately.With this post, I take the opportunity to wish all my Chinese friends, relatives and most of all my blogger friends and visitors of this blog:"A HAPPY, PROSPEROUS AND HEALTHYÂ CHINESE NEW YEAR 2017"

title: EZCR#79  - AUSPICIOUS CNY DISH - CAO CAI CIN PAO
text: This is another Chinese New Year dish which I prepared not during CNY. The original recipe uses canned baby abalone but here I replaced it with fish maw.  You can also use sea cucumber, too.It is a tasty vegetable dish suitable for CNY dinner and it can be prepared earlier and leave it to steam before serving.The fish maw will absorb the flavor of the fried cabbage, seasoning and stock.Ingredients[serves 3]10 slices of soft fish maw [pre-soaked till soft and cut] â€“ drain off excess water300 gm Chinese cabbage â€“ shreddedÂ½ carrot â€“ peeled and shredded3 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked, drained and cut shreds1-2 pieces dried sole [phnee hoo] â€“ rinsed, deep fried and pounded1 egg â€“ beaten and fried until crispySome blanched broccoli florets or chopped spring onions for garnishingSeasoning2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp wineÂ½ tsp each salt and sugar1 tbsp sesame seed oilLine a steaming bowl with fish maw [or abalone or sea cucumber slices].Heat a non-stick wok with some oil, sautÃ© dried mushrooms until aromatic.  Add in shredded vegetables.  Stir fry to cook with some water.  Add in fried dried sole and seasoning.  Stir fry to mix and add in crispy egg.  Mix well.Dish vegetables over fish maw.   Place in steamer to steam for 10-15 minutes.Invert onto serving plate, garnish with some chopped spring onions and blanched broccoli.  Serve.

title: EZCR#78 - NIAN NIAN RU YEE XIA [STEAMED PRAWNS WITH GLASS NOODLES]
text: The name of this dish already implies that this is an auspicious Chinese New Year dish which is suitable to serve during reunion or CNY meals.This dish not only has an auspicious name but it is really a tasty and delicious dish fit for CNY meals or other ocassions.  The prawns are fresh, sweet and tasty with the steaming sauce.  The glass noodles at the base soaks up the flavours, too.  It is an awesome dish which I would love to prepare to serve with rice but it Â can also be a delish One Dish Meal by adding more glass noodles [low calorie food].Ingredients[serves 3]9-10 large prawns or mini lobsters â€“ sliced lengthwise to open up1-2 bundles of glass noodles â€“ soaked and drained3-4 chopped garlic2 tbsp fried crispy garlicSome shredded spring onionSome shredded red chilliÂ Seasoning1 tbsp each of  fish sauce, light soy sauce and wine2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp sugarDash of pepperMix both garlic with seasoning.Place glass noodles in steaming bowl.  Add in Â½ portion of the seasoning mix, mix well with a pair of chopsticks.  Arrange prawns neatly over glass noodles and pour balance garlic and seasoning on top.Steam over high heat for 10-15 minutes or until noodles and prawns are cooked.Garnish with spring onions and red chilli.  Serve hot.

title: STEWED MEATBALLS WITH CABBAGE
text: The first reaction when my family saw this dish on the dinner table was a 'Wow'. Â Reason was because this is the first time they get to eat an extra large size meatballs. Â There no fighting for the meatballs as each is only entitled to one.This is a presentable dish which is easy to prepare withonly a few ingredients.Â Â  It looks verysimilar to Lionâ€™s Head but this is a simpler version with addition of Dong Quai[Angelica Ginseng]Â  and Qi Zi[Wolfberries] to the soup.Â  You willnotice a unique herbal fragrance and natural sweetness of the meat and cabbage.Â  The extra large size meatballs are firm butnice with the crunchy, sweetÂ waterchestnuts in them.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No.93 withmodificationsIngredients[serves 3]250 gm minced meat3 waterchestnuts â€“ peeled and choppedÂ½ egg1 tsp chopped gingerÂ½ tbsp cornstarchÂ½ tsp saltDash of pepper700 ml water6 pieces cabbage leave2 slice dong quai1 tbsp qi zi Â½ tsp salt to tasteDash of pepperMix minced meat, waterchestnuts, ginger and egg in abowl.Â  Add in salt, pepperÂ  and cornstarch.Â  Mix into a sticky paste.Â  Divide into 3 equal portions.Cook meatballs in water over low heat for 5-10 minutesuntil set. Dish up. Â Discard water.Place cabbage leaves in a small claypot, pour inwater.Â  Put in the boiled meatballs, dong quaiand bring to boil.Lower the heat and continue to simmer for 1 hour.Â  Add in qi zi and simmer for another 10-20 minutes or until meatballs are thoroughly cooked.Lastly add in seasoning [salt and pepper] and serve.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CNY 2017 - MEAT FLOSS/SEAWEED GERMAN COOKIES
