text: Another meat floss recipe which I have bookmarked tobake and finally got down to bake them.Â This recipe is from Cheryl of Baking Taitai.These cookies are crispy and fragrant.Â  Love the savoury and sweet taste, quitedifferent for the usual sweet cookies.Â  Ihave replaced the Korean seaweed with Japanese seaweed for this recipe.Recipe adapted fromÂ Baking TaitaiÂ with modificationIngredients[makes 90 pieces]250 gm butter50 gm icing sugar250 gm potato starch160 gm cake flour/plain flour50 gm crispy meat floss20 gm Japanese seaweed [break into smaller pieces]Beat butter and sugar in a mixing bowl until light andfluffy.Sift potato starch and flour together.Â  Combine with floss and seaweed.Â  Mix well.Fold [2] into [1], mix well into a soft dough [chilldough if it is too soft].Divide into small portions, roll into rounds and placeof a lined baking tray.Â  Lightly pressdough with a fork to flatten.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 20 minutesor until golden brown.Leave to cool on wire rack before storing in airtightcontainers.

title: CNY 2017 - SAVOURY POTATO CHIPS COOKIES
text: This year, I have chosenseveral cookie recipes that are savoury and sweet.Â  Particularly like this one which is savourywith the use of Parmesan cheese and crispy potato chips.These cookies has a niceonion aroma, sweet, savoury and crispy.Â Again, these are addictive and you will have more in one go.Recipe adapted from YumYum Magazine No.64 with modificationsIngredients[makes 110 pieces]250 gm butter80 gm caster sugar50 gm toasted walnuts â€“chopped110 gm sour cream &onion flavor potato chips â€“ crushed20 gm Parmesan cheese250 gm plain flour + 1 tspbaking powder â€“ siftedCream butter and sugaruntil light and fluffy.Sift flour with bakingpowder and mix in the walnuts, crushed potato chips and Parmesan cheese.Â  Mix well.Fold [2] into [1].Â  Mix into a dough.Â  Scoop into small portions and place on alined baking tray.Bake in preheated oven at180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown.Remove to cool on wire rackbefore storing in airtight container.Â I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: SPARE RIBS IN CARAMEL SAUCE
text: Loved this recipe which is easy to prepare and cook. Only a few ingredients but this dish is awesome.  The taste is like Braised Sweet Sauce Spare Ribs [Pai Kut Wong]. Â The spare ribs are not deep fried but braised with the seasoning sauce until tender and gravy is thick.If you are always busy but love to eat at home, this dish is a good one to try as it can be prepared earlier and stored.Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 93Â Ingredients800 gm meaty spare ribs â€“ cut bite size pieces2 tbsp oil2 tbsp rock sugarSeasoning4 tbsp tomato sauce to taste2-3 tbsp light soy sauce to taste600 ml waterBlanch spare ribs in boiling water for a minute.  Remove and rinse well.  Drain.Heat oil in a wok over low heat, add in rock sugar, stir and cook into caramel.  Add in blanched spare ribs, stir to mix well [be careful , the caramel is very hot].Add in seasoning, stir to coat spare ribs well before adding water.Bring to boil for several minutes.  Cover and simmer over low heat until meat is tender and sauce has thickened.Dish up to serve.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CNY 2017 - BUTTERY ROSE SHAPE PINEAPPLE TARTS
text: This is one of the many lovely pineapple tart's recipe from Angel ofÂ Â Cook.Bake.LoveÂ which I have bookmarked to try. Â Due to time constraint, I could only try out one, that is this recipe which uses rub-in method.I'm very happy with the result cos' the tarts are buttery, light, melt-in your and pastry is easy to handle. These are very fragile and it is good idea to place them in paper cup cases for easy handling and storing. I particularly like the Step 7, whereby the tarts are first baked without the egg yolk glaze. Â This way, it would not smear the design when you apply the glaze and the golden colour looks good.Angel uses a plastic peg to create the criss-cross pattern on the tarts but I used the peg to create a rose pattern for these pineapple tarts.Recipe adapted fromÂ Angel ofÂ Â Cook.Bake.LoveIngredients[makes 50 pieces]Filling - 250 gm pineapple paste [50 x 5 gm - roll into small balls]Egg glaze : 1 egg yolk mixed with few drops of watersmall paper cupcasesPastry Ingredients240 gm plain flour1Â½ tbsp cornflour50 gm icing sugarÂ Â¼ tsp saltÂ 180 gm cold salted butter [good quality butter] - cubed1 egg yolkÂ Â¼ tsp vanilla extractSift plain flour, cornflour, sugar and salt together in a big mixing bowl.Â Mix egg yolk together with vanilla extract.Â Add cubed cold butter into flour dry ingredients. Using fingertips, rub butter into flour mixture until like bread crumbs.Add egg mixture and mix till combined. Do not over mix.Â Wrap the dough and chill for 30 minutes to firm it up.Â Divide dough into small balls of Â½ level tbsp [about 50 pieces]. Lightly flatten the dough, place a ball of pineapple filling in it and wrap over. Place in small paper case and arrange it on baking tray.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for about 8-10 minutes. Remove tray and apply egg wash. Return to bake for another 5-6mins. Cool completely before storing.

title: FRIED SHREDDED MEAT WITH LEEKS
text: These days I find it easy to prepare quick stir fry meatdishes using pork tenderloin.Â  Porktenderloin are tender and quick to cook meat which can be used as accompanimentto fry various types of vegetables.Â  Oneof them is leeks.This dish is tasty and aromatic to serve with porridge orrice.Â  These ingredients in the originalrecipe are used to fry savoury glutinous rice balls [tang yuan]. Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 93 withmodificationsIngredients100 gm lean pork tenderloin â€“ shredded2 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked and shredded1 stalk Chinese leeks â€“ sliced slantwise1 red chilli â€“ sliced1 tbsp chopped garlic1-2 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp light soy sauceÂ¼ tspÂ  each saltand pepperÂ½ tsp sesame seed oil1-2 tbsp waterHeat up oil, sautÃ© garlic until fragrant, add in shreddedpork and mushrooms.Â  Stir fry untilaromatic, then add in leeks and seasoning.Stir until ingredients are cooked through.Dish up to serve with rice orÂ  porridge.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CNY 2017 - WALNUT CHOCOLATE COOKIES
text: If you have been following my recent posts on cookies,you will notice that most of them are from Yum Yum Magazines.Â  This I have to say a word of thanks to mysister in-law.Â  She has a collection ofthe magazines.Â  When I told her that Iwish to bakeÂ  some new cookies for thisCNY, she generously lend me a number of Â her magazines with cookie recipes.Â  This recipe is one of the many selectedrecipes from Â them.These chocolate walnut cookies are aromatic, crispy and crunchy but it spreads a little making it looks flattened. Â However, these are good.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 93 withmodificationsIngredients[makes 140 pieces]250 gm butter â€“ room temperature75 gm castor sugar75 gm brown sugar1 large egg2 tsp vanilla essence400 gm plain flour40 gm cocoa powder1 tsp baking sodaÂ½Â  tsp salt80 gm toasted walnuts â€“ chopped150 gm chocolate buttonsCream butter and sugar until light, beat in the eggs andvanilla essence.Â  Beat until light andfluffy.Fold in the sifted flour, cocoa powder, baking soda andsalt.Â  Mix well, add in walnuts and mixinto a soft dough.Spoon batter onto a lined baking tray and place achocolate button on top as decoration.Bake in a preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20minutes or until cooked.Remove and leave to cool on wire rack before storing inan airtight container.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: FRIED CHICKEN WITH CHIVES
text: This is one simple recipe which I picked to cook forÂ  my family during busy days.Â  It turned out to be so good that I havebookmarked to cook again when we go back to my mother in-lawâ€™s house forChinese New Year holidays.It is always good to have a collection of easy to cookand simple recipesÂ  during this time as Ihave to cook numerous dishes for a big group for several days. Â This recipe requires only 2 main ingredients â€“chicken meat and chives, yet it tastes awesome.Â I only need to increase the portion according to the number of people toserve.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No.95 withmodificationsIngredients[serves 2-3]1 large deboned chicken whole leg with skin, fats removedâ€“ cut into pieces50 gm chives â€“ diced1 tbsp oilMarinadeÂ½ tsp salt, dash of pepper1 tbsp cornstarch before fryingSeasoning [combined]1 tbsp fish sauce1 tsp sugar2 tbsp waterMix chicken with marinade and season for at least 30minutes. Â Coat chicken pieces withcornstarch before frying.Heat oil in a non stick pan, pan fry chicken pieces untilgolden brown on both sides.Â  Removeexcess oil if any, then add in seasoning and chives.Stir well and dish up to serve.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CNY 2017 - ROSE SHAPE PINEAPPLE TARTS [é»„æ¢¨å¡”]
text: This is another lovely pineapple tart pastry recipe which I tried from Ann.  She had made her pineapple tarts into various shapes and I must say she did them so well.  I must admit I can't follow each one of them, so I settled for the rose shape.The tarts are buttery, light, very fragile and melt-in your mouth type. Â Very addictive and yummy, you wouldn't stop at one.The pastry preparation is rub-in method using electric mixer but with finger tips should work well too.Recipe adapted fromÂ Anncoo JournalÂ Ingredients[makes 35 pieces]Filling Â - 175 gm pineapple paste/jam [35 x 5 gm]1 egg yolk mix with a few drops of water for glazingsmall paper cup casesPastry Ingredients125 gm soft butter150 gm plain flour25 gm milk powder15 gm icing sugar1 egg yolk1/2 tsp vanilla essenceShape pineapple filing into small round balls [5 gm each]. Â Set aside or chill in fridge until required.Use an electric mixer to blend butter, sugar, vanilla, milk powder and flour together. Â It will be like bread crumbs.Add in egg yolk and essence, then blend into a soft dough just to combine [do not over work].Divide dough into 35 equal portions. Â Wrap filling with a portions, seal and roll into round ball. Â Use a plastic peg to create a rose design.Place in a small paper case on a baking tray.Bake at 180 degrees C for 10 minutes, remove from oven, apply egg glaze. Â Return tarts to oven and continue to bake for another 5-6 minutes or until golden in colour.Remove from oven, cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: PORK NECK CHOPS IN SWEET & SOUR SAUCE
text: This is an appetizing braised pork dish suitable to servewith rice, fried rice, blanched noodles and even mashed potatoes.Â Â  It is really tasty and aromatic with theaddition of dried mandarin peel [good quality ones].Â  The good quality dried mandarin peel israther costly whereas the poor quality ones can be obtained free from Chinesemedical shops.Â  This is something that Ilearned from the medical shop owner when I went to get this item to cook thisdish.Â Anyway, it is worthy to try this dish as the result isgood.Â  The braised onions and seasoningcontribute to the sweetness of this dish.I had prepared this dish when my mom was hospitalised for appendicitis op. Â It's no joke, at 85 still have to undergo this kind of operation. Â Glad that she recovered well but still needs time to regain her stamina and energy. Â As I have to be with her during the day time, this dish was cooked the night before and after resting it becomes even more flavoursome and tasty. Â These account for the reason why the photos don't look good. Â All done in a hurry.Recipe adapted from Â my selected cookbook for the month â€˜Yum YumMagazine No. 93â€™ for Cookbook Countdown Event#Ingredients500 gm pork neck meat â€“ cut into 1.5 cm thickMarinade1 tbsp light soya sauce and Â½ tsp salt1 tbsp oil1 large onion â€“ sliced2 pieces dried mandarin peel â€“ soaked and cut into pieces1 red carrot â€“ cut into chunksSeasoning [combined]1-2 tbsp plum sauce1 -2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp sugar1 tsp sesame oilTenderise the meat slices with the back of a cleaver thenmarinate with marinade for at least an hour.Heat up a non stick wok with oil, pan fry the meat sliceson both sides until golden brown and aromatic. Add in carrots, onions, Â dried mandarin peel and seasoning.Â  Stir fry to mix ingredients well before addingwater.Bring to boil, then lower heat, cover to cook until meatis tender [about 40 minutes] and sauce has thickened.Dish up to serve with plain white rice or fried rice.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CNY 2017 - MEAT FLOSS COOKIES
text: Though busy, still managed to select a few recipes forcookies which I have bookmarked to do long ago.Â This is a nice, aromatic, Â savoury and sweet meat floss cookies.Â  These are rather addictive and you wouldnâ€™tstop with one or two.Â I like to recommend using the crispy type of meat flossfor these cookies.Â  You can use justwhite sesame seeds or a combination of black and white sesame seeds and increasethe amount of meat floss according to own preference.My opinion is, this recipe is a keeper if you are lookingfor a meat floss cookie recipe. An easy recipe yet awesome result.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 82 withmodificationsIngredients[makes 120 pieces]200 gm butter120 gm brown sugarÂ½ tsp salt2 eggs400 gm plain flour + 1 tsp baking soda â€“ sifted40 gm toasted sesame seeds100 gm crispy meat flossIn a mixing bowl, cream butter, sugar and salt untilcreamy and light.Â  Add in the eggs andwhisk until fluffy.Combine sifted flour with meat floss and sesame seeds,mix well.Fold [2] into [1] and mix into a dough.Divide into small portion, roll into rounds and place ona lined baking tray.Lightly press each rounds with a pork to flattenslightly.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 20 minutes oruntil golden brown and crispy.Remove to cool on wire rack and store in airtightcontainer.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: BRAISED CHICKEN WITH TAUCU & NAM YEE
text: Again this is a simple, easy to prepare dish yet reallytasty and delicious.Â Â  I have to say thatthe combination of seasoning is just awesome.Â The sauce is good with rice.The original recipe uses duck meat but I had substituted itwith chicken whole legs and wings.Â  Ibelieve it is a good dish if using duck butÂ I could not get to Â buy duck insections.Â  The vendor sells a whole duckwhich is a bit too much for my family.Slightly modified recipe adapted from my selectedcookbook for the month â€˜Yum Yum Magazine No. 93â€™ for Cookbook Countdown Event# Ingredients2 large chicken whole legs â€“ cut bite size pieces2 chicken wings â€“ cut into sections2 tbsp each oil, chopped garlic and shallots1 tbsp chopped gingerSeasoning2 tbsp fermented soya bean paste [taucu]1 piece fermented red beancurd [nam yee]1-2 tsp sugar to taste2-3 tbsp light soy sauce to taste600 ml waterHeat oil in a non stick wok, sautÃ© chopped ingredientsuntil aromatic and fragrant.Â  Add inchicken and pan fry for a minute before adding the seasoning ingredient.Stir fry to mix well before adding water.Â  Bring to boil, then lower heat to simmeruntil chicken is tender and sauce thickens.Dish up to serve.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CNY 2017 - ANGKU SHAPE PINEAPPLE TARTS
text: This year I tried various pineapple tart recipes shared by blogger friends over the years. Â All turned out well and satisfactory. Â I can say that they are workable recipes worth trying.The only difference which I noticed from the recipes is the dough preparation. Â Some uses creaming method while there are others which uses rub-in method.All the tarts are buttery, light, very fragile and melt in the mouth.Â You can shape them with any wooden mould or create designs with whatever gadgets that you deem fit. Â For this one, I used a small AKK mould, others I create rose pattern with a plastic peg. Â Recipe adapted fromÂ Happy FlourÂ  [slight modification]Ingredients[makes 40 pieces]Filling - 200 gm ready-bought pineapple paste/jam [40 x 5gm]Pastry Ingredients120 gm butter10 gm icing sugar1        egg yolk1/4 tsp   vanilla essence140 gm plain flour20 gm corn flour40 gm milk powderSift flour and cornflour together and set aside.Cream butter and icing sugar until light and fluffy, beat in the egg yolk and vanilla essence until well combined.Fold in flour and milk powder to form a soft dough.Transfer dough into a small container, cover and chill in the fridge for 15 minutes.Divide dough into 40 small portions. Â Flatten one portion and wrap prepared filling and seal the opening.Lightly dust mould with some flour, place dough into the cavity of the mould, press to mould and gently tap to dislodge pastry.Place on a baking tray lined with parchment paper.Baked in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 10 minutes, remove from oven, brush with some egg yolk to glaze.Return tarts to oven and continue to bake for another 5-6 minutes Â or until golden brown.Remove from oven, cool on wire rack before storing in air tight container.

title: FRIED CURRY PORK
text: Here is a continuation of the quick cook recipes which I have tried and mentioned in my previous post.Again this is an awesome quick stir fry dish suitable for family meals that can be prepared and served without much hassle.Lovely mild curried flavoured tender meat dish which I like for its' taste and flavour. Â Children will not be able to detect the spiciness of this dish. Â Best to use pork tenderloin as it is quick to cook, tender and healthy lean pork.Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 93Â [my selected cookbook for January 2017 Cookbook Countdown Event] with slight modificationsÂ Ingredients1 piece pork tenderloin [about 200-300 gm] - cut into thick slices or cubesMarinade1-2 tsp meat curry powder1 tsp salt and light soy sauce1 tbsp cornstarch with 2 tbsp waterSeasoning [combined]1 tsp curry powder1 tbsp light soy sauce and oyster sauce1/2 tsp sugar2-3 tbsp water1/2 green capsicum - cut wedges1/2 red capsicum - cut wedgesCombine pork tenderloin with marinade, mix well and marinate for at least 30 minutes.Heat up a non stick wok with some oil, pan fry marinated pork slices until brown and cooked through [you can deep fry pork slices if you like]. Â Dish a drain.Remove excess oil, add in capsicum and fried pork slices together with the seasoning. Add more water if you prefer some sauce for this dish.Quickly stir fry to mix well.Dish up to serve immediately.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CNY 2017 - ORANGE COOKIES WITH WHITE CHOCOLATE CHIPS
text: These are simple looking cookies, not that attractive butI love the orange aroma and fragrance together with the plain white chocolatechips.Â  The citrus aroma is not affectedat all with white chocolate chips and you get to wonder what the white spotsare.Â  You may think they are almond nibsor some nuts, too.Since I am not a fan of sweet cookies, I have cut down onthe sugar and I find this amount not too sweet.Â  The original recipe uses 150 grams castersugar.These cookies have the lovely aroma of orange, crispy,buttery and not too sweet .Â  Lovelycookies as a snack.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 95 withmodificationsIngredients [makes 85 pieces]120 gm butter â€“ room temperature100 gm caster sugar1 eggGrated zest of 2 oranges1 tsp vanilla essence200 gm plain flour â€“ siftedÂ¼ - Â½ tsp baking sodaÂ¼ tsp baking powderÂ¼ tsp salt200 gm white chocolate chipsLined a baking tray with parchment paper.Â  Preheat oven at 180 degrees C.Cream butter and sugar until creamy, add in the egg andcontinue to beat until light and fluffy.Add in the orange zest, vanilla essence, mix well andfold in the remaining ingredients.Â  Mixinto a dough.Divide dough into small portions of about 15 gm and roundup.Place onto prepared baking tray. Â Bake in the preheated oven for 15-18 minutes or untilgolden brown.Remove and cool on a wire rack before storing in anairtight container.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#13Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ and Emily ofÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: FRIED CHICKEN IN BLACK VINEGAR SAUCE
text: WISHING ALL MY FRIENDS/VISITORS AT THIS SITE"A VERY HAPPY, SAFE AND HEALTHY NEW YEAR 2017"There are several stir fry meat dishes and other quick cook dishes from this cookbook which I feel are very suitable for the coming Chinese New Year, too. title: CNY 2017 - MELON SEEDS WALNUT COOKIES
text: Loads of cookies recipes to try and share this coming Chinese New Year buttoo bad, my mom had an operation recently and things changed a little.Â Â  I have been kept busy with extra duties tocarry out and some plans have to change too lest I would be too stressout.Â Â  Anyway,Â  still need to make some cookies for my motherin-law, my mom and siblings.Â Â  I willtry to make as many varieties as I can if time permits.This is one of the new recipes which I tried after bakingthe usual Chinese New Year cookies [Kuih Bangkit and Peanut Cookies].Â Â  This cookie has quite a number ofingredients from nuts to seeds and raisins.Â Â It is nutty, crunchy and fragrant, sure nice to munch on while watchingmy favourite TV shows. Â The dough is a bit dry but binds well.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No.99 withmodifications.Â Â  I have substitutedpumpkin seeds with melon seeds and reduced the sugar from 150 grams to 110grams as I prefer my cookies less sweet.Ingredients[makes 100 pieces]170 gm butter110 gm brown sugar1 egg350 gm plain flour - siftedÂ½ tsp baking powder â€“siftedÂ¼ tsp salt60 gm raisins â€“ soaked in hot water for 10 minutes anddrained80 gm toasted walnuts â€“ chopped100 gm toasted melon seeds Cream butter and brown sugar until light and fluffy, thenadd in the egg.Â  Continue beating untilpale and creamy.Fold in the flour, baking powder and salt, mix well. Addin the raisins, walnuts and seeds.Â  Stirwell.Spoon the batter onto a lined baking tray.Bake in a preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 15-20minutes or until golden brown.Remove and cool on wire rack before storing in anairtight container.

title: GREEN CHICKEN CURRY [AYAM SAMBAL HIJAU]
text: This is a follow up of my previous 2 posts on green curry paste and its' uses. Â There is a recipe on how to prepare the green curry paste and Green Curry Fish. Â Here is another green curry with chicken.One portion of the Green Curry PasteÂ is sufficient to prepare two separate curries with fish and chicken.Again, this green chicken curry is awesome. Â It is fragrant, aromatic and it isn't too spicy with addition of coconut milk. The spiciness is acceptable to us.This is a perfect curry to serve with piping hot rice. I served this lovely curry with Blue Pea Flower Rice.Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 60Â with modificationsIngredients6 pieces deboned chicken drumstick with skinsome long beans - cut 1 inch sections1/2 tsp tumeric powder1/4 tsp salt1 large onion - skinned and sliced1 red chilli - deseeded and cutÂ 1/2 portion of green curry pasteÂ [from recipe below]1/2 tsp jintan putih [fennel powder]1/2 tsp toasted belacan2 tbsp coconut milk powder + 150 ml waterjuice of 2 limau kasturisome Basil leavesSeasoning1/2 tsp salt to taste1/4-1/2 tbsp sugar to tasteMarinate chicken pieces with tumeric powder and salt. Â Shallow fry until golden brown [skin side first]*. Â Dish up.* Frying the chicken pieces with skin side first in a non-stick wok does not require oil. Â Use the oil from the skin to pan fry the chicken pieces.Remove excess oil if any, saute onions, red chilli and long beans until fragrant. Â Add in green curry paste, jintan putih, belacan and stir fry until aromatic.Add in coconut milk and seasoning. Â Bring to rolling boil and add in the fried chicken.Bring to boil until sauce is thick and chicken is cooked through.Dish up to serve with rice.Ingredients for Green Sambal [Previous Post]5 green chillies â€“ cut small pieces10 green chilli padi â€“ cut5 pips garlic10 shallots2 stalks lemongrass â€“ cut small ringsSeasoningÂ½ tsp salt1 tbsp sugar5 tbsp oilBlend the aromatics until fine.Heat oil in a non-stick wok, sautÃ© blended ingredients until aromatic.Add in seasoning and stir fry over medium low heat until oil separates.Dish up, store for later use.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: GREEN CURRY  FISH [IKAN KARI HIJAU]
text: Here is a lovely fish curry using green chillipaste.Â  The fish curry is fragrant andhas a lovely aroma.Â  The spiciness ofthis curry is acceptable to me but I think the small green chillies can beincreased for more oomph.For this curry, I used white fish fillet. You canalways substitute it with Spanish Mackerel blocks, Garoupa fillet or other types of white fish.Â  This is a perfect curry to serve with pipinghot rice.Â  I will definitely cook anotherof this green sambal curry using chicken.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 60 withmodificationsIngredients200 gm white fish fillet - cut thick slicessome slices four angled beans or okra1/4 tsp tumeric powder1/4 tsp salt1 large onion - skinned and sliced1 sprig curry leaves - [I forgotten to add]1/2 portion of green curry paste [from recipe below and previous post]1/2 tsp jintan putih [fennel powder]1/2 tsp toasted belacan2 tbsp coconut milk powder + 150 ml waterjuice of 2 limau kasturiSeasoning1/2 tsp salt to taste1/2 tbsp sugar to tasteMarinate fish pieces with tumeric powder and salt. Â Shallow fry until golden brown. Â Dish up.Leave 1/2 tbsp oil, saute onions, curry leaves until fragrant. Â Add in green curry paste, jintan putih, belacan and stir fry until aromatic.Add in coconut milk and seasoning. Â Bring to rolling boil and add in the vegetables, fried fish and lime juice.Lightly stir ingredients, leave to cook for a minute.Dish up to serve with rice.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] ForayIngredients for Green Sambal [Previous Post]5 green chillies â€“ cut small pieces10 green chilli padi â€“ cut5 pips garlic10 shallots2 stalks lemongrass â€“ cut small ringsSeasoningÂ½ tsp salt1 tbsp sugar5 tbsp oilBlend the aromatics until fine.Heat oil in a non-stick wok, sautÃ© blended ingredients until aromatic.Add in seasoning and stir fry over medium low heat until oil separates.Dish up, store for later use.

title: GREEN  CURRY PASTE  [SAMBAL HIJAU]
text: This recipe is from Chef Margaret.Â  She used green chillies, shallots, garlic andlemongrass to make this lovely green sambal.Â This sambal is good to use for cooking chicken or fish.Â  It is very aromatic and tasty, too and a simpler version compared to the authentic Thai version.Â You can prepare the green chilli paste ahead and storefor later use. Â Stay tune for another 2 recipes using this sambal.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 60 withmodificationsIngredients for Green Sambal5 green chillies â€“ cut small pieces10 green chilli padi â€“ cut5 pips garlic 10 shallots2 stalks lemongrass â€“ cut small ringsSeasoningÂ½ tsp salt1 tbsp sugar5 tbsp oilBlend the aromatics until fine.Heat oil in a non-stick wok, sautÃ© blended ingredientsuntil aromatic.Add in seasoning andstir fry over medium low heat until oil separates.Dish up, store for later use.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: CHICKEN AND ERYNGII MUSHROOOMS CURRY
text: This is a simple curry which is easy to prepare and consider a healthy version of chicken curry.  Eryngii mushrooms are added to this curry which does not require coconut milk but tamarind juice. Â The addition of kaffir lime leaves give a nice aroma to this sourish taste curry and  it is good served with steaming hot rice.Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 78Â my selected cookbook for this month's Cookbook Countdown #12 with modificationsIngredients2 chicken whole legs â€“ deboned and cut bite size pieces1 packet [250 gm] Eryngii mushrooms [King Oyster Mushrooms] â€“ cut rounds of wedges1 tbsp each chopped garlic and shallots2-3 tbsp meat curry powder [use some to marinate chicken pieces]1 onion â€“ peeled and cut wedges1 small carrot â€“ peeled and cut wedges2 tbsp oilSome kaffir lime leavesSeasoning1 heaped tablespoon tamarind paste â€“ mixed with 300 ml water and squeezed out the juice1 tsp each of salt and sugar to tasteMarinate chicken pieces with a pinch of salt and some curry powder for at least 30 minutes.Heat up wok, add in oil and sautÃ© garlic and shallots until aromatic.  Add in curry paste and onions.  Stir fry until fragrant, add in the chicken pieces and carrots.  Fry until firm before adding in the mushrooms.Stir well to mix and aromatic before adding the tamarind juice.Bring to boil, add in seasoning to taste, then cover and simmer for 10-15 minutes.Uncover and cook until gravy is thick.  Lastly add in the kaffir lime leaves before dishing up to serve with rice.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: FRIED PORK WITH DRIED CHILLI AND ONION
text: This issue of food magazine has several easy, quick stirfry dishes using few ingredients.Â  I havetried a few [previous posts] and find them to be tasty and good.Â These dishes are suitable to serve with rice or porridge.Â Cooking it over high heat brings out thearoma and fragrance of the ingredients and seasoning sauce.Â  It isÂ very appetizing and tasty.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 78 with slightmodificationsIngredients300 gm pork tenderloin [li chi rou] â€“ sliced or cubed1 yellow onion â€“ peeled and cut into wedges5 dried red chillies â€“ cut into sections1 stalk spring onions â€“ cut sections1 tbsp oilMarinadeÂ¼ tsp salt1 tsp light soy sauceDash of pepper2 tbsp water1 tbsp cornstarchSeasoning Sauce2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp chilli sauce1 tsp sugar2 tbsp waterMix pork with marinade and season for at least 30minutes.Heat Â up oil in anon-stick wok, pan fry meat slices until 80% cooked.Add in onion, dried chilli and stir fry until fragrant.Add in seasoning and quickly stir fry until well mixed.Lastly add in spring onions.Â  Toss well and dish up to serve.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: MINI CURRY BURGERS
text: Curry Burgers, has anyone tried making this at home?Â  This is again one simple and easy recipe toprepare yet the result is awesome.Â  Thename says mini but you can make them into any size you prefer -Â  small, medium to large.Â  Mine here is considered as mini as I preparedthis to serve with rice.It is not spicy for my tastebuds but aromatic with the addition ofshallots, garlic and coriander leaves.Â These are best eaten immediately so as to enjoy the juicy meat burgers.Â Â  The quantity shown in the pictures is only 1/2 portion of the recipe below.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 78 with slightmodificationsIngredients500 gm minced meat50 gm shallots â€“ peeled and chopped30 gm garlic â€“ peeled and chopped1 red chilli â€“ seeded and chopped1 stalk coriander leaves â€“ chopped4-5 tbsp bread crumbs2 eggsSeasoning2-3 tbsp meat curry powder1 tsp salt to taste1 tbsp cornstarchIn a mixing bowl, combine minced meat withseasoning.Â  Mix well then add in theremaining ingredients.Stir into a thick paste, then divide into equal portionsand form into balls.Slightly flatten the meatballs to form patties beforefrying.Â  You can deep fry or pan frythese patties over medium hot oil until golden brown.Dish and drain before serving immediately.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: FRIED TAUKWA WITH TAU SEE
text: This is another simple and easy homey recipe which Itried. Â Surprisingly good and tasty dish toserve with piping hot plain porridge especially for me cos' I love soya products.If you prefer this dish to be more spicy, used small redand green chillies like I did or you can substitute with the less spicy type ofchillies and capsicum.The Â salty blackbeans are tasty and it is always good with the porridge.Â  Â Do trythis dish if firm beancurd is one of your favorite food ingredients, you willlike it.Â  You can omit the garlic ifserving this as vegetarian dish.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 60 with slightmodificationsÂ Ingredients3-4 pieces hard beancurd [taukwa] â€“ pan fried till goldenbrown and cubedÂ½ tbsp oil1 tbsp each chopped ginger and garlic 1 tbsp each chopped green and red chillies or 3 small redchillies and 3 small green chillies [chopped]2 tbsp fermented black beans [tau see] â€“ rinsed anddrainedSome chopped spring onions/coriander leaves for garnishingSeasoningÂ½ tbsp light soy sauceÂ½ tsp sugarÂ½ tsp sesame seedsHeat up oil in a non-stick wok, sautÃ© chopped ginger,garlic and chillies until aromatic.Add in the fried beancurd and fermented black beans.Â  Stir fry to mix, add in the seasoning.Quickly stir fry to mix ingredients well.Â  Toss in the spring onions.Dish up to serve.Â Â I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: EZCR#77 - MUA EU KAY WITH GIZZARDS
text: Sometimes I do miss this sesame flavour braised chicken [a common homey dish] that is so easy to prepare compared to many other chicken dishes.This one is a little different from the usual as I added gizzards and wolfberries [goji]. Â It looks good and also tastes good. Â The chicken/gizzards are tasty and the sauce is awesome to spread over rice. Â I love the ginger slices, they are good if you are a ginger lover.Ingredients1 large chicken whole leg - skin removed and cut into pieces6 pieces chicken gizzards - cleaned, halved and blanched1 tbsp wolf berries30 gm ginger - thinly sliced2 tbsp sesame seed oilSeasoning2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp wine1/4 tsp sugarHeat wok, add in sesame oil, saute ginger slices until aromatic and crispy at the edges.Add in chicken, fry until it turns firm, add in gizzards and seasoning ingredients. Â Stir to mix and coat well before adding enough water to cover the ingredients.Bring to boil, then lower heat to simmer until gravy is reduced, stirring occasionally. Â Add in goji, stir to mix well.Dish up to serve with rice.

title: FRIED SLICED PORK WITH GREEN CAPSICUM
text: I confirmed that I am getting lazy to cook elaborate dishes because I have been busy too. You may notice that the dishes I cooked are getting Â simpler and easy to prepare. The ingredients used are less with a simple seasoning sauce. Â Anyway, self consolation, Â at least I still cook for the family.That's the beauty of cooking, it is very versatile and a little improvisation, you still get to enjoy some awesome food at home which is definitely much healthier and 'hygenic'. Â I happened to have green capsicum and pork tenderloin in my fridge, the 2 main ingredients for this dish. Â Why not use them to prepare this? Cooking oil prices going up, so have to change some preparation methods, hehehe!.Simple, tasty pork dish to serve with rice. This is a quick stir fry dish with pork tenderloin that cooks very fast.Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 78Â my selected cookbook for this month's Cookbook Countdown #12 with modificationsIngredients300 gm pork tenderloin [li chi rou] - sliced1 tbsp sliced garlic1 green capsicum - cut into chunks2 tbsp oilÂ Marinade for Meat1 tsp light soy sauce, dash of pepper1 tsp cornstarchSeasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce and oyster sauce1/2 tsp dark soy sauce3 tbsp waterMarinate pork slices with marinade for 15 minutes.Heat up wok, add oil and pan fry meat slices in single layers until brown and cooked through on both sides. Â Dish up.Remove excess oil [if you like], saute garlic until aromatic. Â Add in capsicum and stir fry until aromatic.Return fried pork to wok, add in seasoning. Â Stir fry over high heat until dry.Dish up and serve.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Fora

title: FRIED CHICKEN IN BLACK PEPPER SAUCE
text: These days, I think I amgetting lazy, always on a look out for simple, easy recipes.Â  Is it that age is catching up or myconcentration has diverted to other matters or perhaps, prices of foodingredients have escalated and I have to be careful not to waste them.Anyway, I am happy thatthe simple and easy recipes which I tried have turned out to be good and tastyeventhough the ingredients/seasoning used are few. Â Only 4 steps to follow for this recipe.This recipe is a quick, simple and easy stir fry chicken which is not difficult to prepare yet overly tasty and healthy, too. It is fragrant and aromatic with the black pepper added. The capsicum is sweet and not spicy at all. Nice dish to serve with plain white rice.Recipe adapted from YumYum Magazine No. 78 with slight modificationsIngredients300 gm chicken breast meatâ€“ sliced or cubedMarinadeÂ¼ tsp salt1 tsp light soy sauceDash of pepper2 tbsp water 1 tbsp cornstarchSeasoningÂ½ tsp saltÂ½ tbsp ground black pepper2 tbsp water1 small red capsicum â€“seeded and cut chunks2 tbsp oilsome spring onionssections for garnishingCombine chicken withmarinade, mix well and season for 30 minutes.Heat up a non stick wokwith oil, pan fry chicken until 90% cooked.Push aside, add incapsicum, seasoning and stir fry over high heat until the sauce has dried up.Dish up to serve.I'm linking this post to Â Cookbook Countdown Event #12Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: FU YONG OMELETTE
text: There are times when my mind is blur, blur of ideas on what to cook eventhough there is a long list of recipes in hand. Â Come such time, eggs come in handy. Â So long as there are eggs in the fridge, you can easily make a dish of it. Â This Fu Yong Omelette is one that you can improvise with little bits of ingredients you have in hand such as char siew, Chinese sausage, onions, Â carrots, prawns, etc.Just mix a combination of some of the mentioned ingredients with eggs, here you are a delicious omelette to add to your meal in a jiffy.Ingredients3 eggs1 Chinese sausage [lap cheong] - diced3 tbsp diced red carrot1 onion - diced1 stalk spring onions - chopped1 tbsp red chilli1/2 tsp salt1 tbsp light soy saucedash of pepper and msg or chicken stock granulesCombine all the ingredients in a bowl with seasoning. Â Mix well.Heat up 2 tbsp oil in a non-stick wok, pour in half of the mixture and pan fry over low heat until set.Turn it over and continue to fry until golden brown. Â Dish up onto serving platter.Finish frying the remaining portion as in Step 3. Â Dish up to serve.

title: THERMAL COOKER - LOTUS ROOT AND MEAT SOUP
text: It has been raining almost all evening for over a month and the most welcome dish at the dinner table is a pot of boiling hot soup to warm the body after a hard day at work or in school.This homey soup is one of the many soup dishes which I have prepared which was made easy with the use of the Thermal Cooker. Â There is a combination of ingredients [both protein and fibre] for this soup and the taste is awesome. Â  The only seasoning is just some salt to taste.Ingredients1 section of lotus root - skin scrapped and sliced200 gm lean meat or a section of meat from the pig leg - cut chunky pieces - blanched3 stumps Eryngii mushrooms - cut wedges9 red dates1 small carrot - peeled and cut chunky pieces30 gm peanuts - rinsed and soaked for several hours1 small piece of dried cuttlefish - rinsed3 pips of garlic with skinsalt to tasteBring water to boil in the inner pot with peanuts, dried cuttlefish and garlic for about 15 minutes.Add in the remaining ingredients. Â Bring to boil and simmer for about 20 minutes. Add in salt to taste. Â Cover pot, off heat and transfer to the outer pot, close the lid and leave to cook for 2 hours or until time to serve.Reheat soup till boiling before serving in individual bowls.

title: A FRIEND'S CHICKEN
text: This chicken dish is my close friend's very own creation years ago.  It is a very simple dish, aromatic, full of flavours and healthy.All you need to do is just to marinate the chicken, wrap it up in aluminium foil and bake in the oven or grilled over a BBQ stove or steamed until cooked.  The ginger,garlicky flavours are all sealed up in the package. No water is added, the juices are from the chicken and sauces.We will prepare this whenever we have a BBQ gathering and it is always a hit with guests.Ingredients2-3 pieces meaty chicken thighs - skin removed, cut bite size pieces [ I used deboned chicken whole legs]3 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut [optional]3 tbsp chopped garlicsome chopped spring onionsMarinade1 tbsp each of light soy sauce, 2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce [optional]1/2 tsp salt1/4 tsp pepper3 tbsp ginger juice or finely grated ginger1 tbsp sesame oilWash and cut chicken into bite size pieces.  Pat dry.Marinate with marinating sauce and chopped garlic for several hours or preferably overnight.Â Place marinated chicken pieces in aluminium tray or foil.  Wrap into a neat package.Â Place package in a wok, pour in 300 ml water. Â Bring to boil and cooked until water dries up. Â Leave package in the wok for a minute. Â Remove and garnish with spring onions. ORBake in preheated oven at 200 degrees for 25-30 minutes or until chicken is cooked.  You can open up the package and grill the chicken for another 5 minutes.Â Remove and garnish with chopped spring onions.  Serve immediately.

title: THERMAL COOKER-BRAISED PORK TROTTER, YAM IN SPICY FRAGRANT SAUCE
text: This recipe looks complicated with numerous ingredientsbut if you are used to braising pork, it is not that difficult as mostingredients are easily available in oneâ€™s kitchen.It was the picture of this dish in the recipe book that attractedmy attention.Â  I love to eat the nice soysauce coloured Â QQ [chewy] trotter skin pieces.Â  The aroma is awesome.Â  Moreover this dish has the soft, sticky yampieces that match so well with the other ingredients and sauce.This dish is good serve with hot plain porridge or rice.Â  There was aÂ typo error in the article and some seasoning ingredients have beenomitted here.Recipe from Amy Beh adapted from Feminine Magazine No.584 with modificationsIngredients750 gm boneless meaty pork trotterÂ  - chopped into pieces Marinade â€“ 1 tbsp light soy sauce, Â½ tsp each pepper andsalt350 gm yam â€“ cut into pieces and pan fried/deep fried2 piece firm beancurd â€“ quartered and pan fried/deepfried5-6 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked [optional]2 tbsp sesame oilAromatics1 piece cinnamon stick, 3 bay leaves, 2 star anise, 4dried chillies, 4 cloves garlic, 40 gm ginger â€“ sliced, 2 pieces Dong Quai, 2 stalks spring onion â€“ white partonlySauce Ingredients50 ml light soy sauce, 2 tbsp oyster sauce, 35 gm rocksugar, dash of msg, 700 ml water, adequate salt to tasteThickeningÂ -Â 1 tbsp potato starch + 2 tbsp waterBlanch trotter pieces in boiling water for a minute. Â Rinse clean and drain. Season pork trotters with marinade for several hours.Pan fry or deep fry yam pieces and firm beancurd untilgolden brown.Â  Dish up and set aside.Heat sesame oil in a heavy base thermal cooker pot, sautÃ©aromatics until fragrant.Put in the mushrooms, trotter pieces, stir fry to combinewell, add in seasoning ingredients.Â Leave to braise for several minutes before adding the water.Bring to boil, then low heat to simmer for 15minutes.Â  Stir in the yamÂ  and beancurd pieces.Â  Mix well.Bring to boil, then transfer to the outer pot. Cover and leave to continue cooking in the pot for anhour or until meat pieces are tender and chewy.Remove pot from outer pot, bring to boil and thicken withthickening.Serve in claypot with salad leaves.

title: MIXED VEGETABLES FISH & MEAT PATTIES
text: Meat Patties are like burgers and an all time favourite with children. Â These patties have a combination of several ingredients like fish paste, minced meat and a few vegetables like waterchestnuts, cabbage and carrots. Â A good way to get children to eat vegetables without noticing them.These patties are easy and worthy to prepare cos' they are awesome serve with mayo dip or just tomato and chilli sauce. Â The patties are soft, chewy and rich in proteins. Really nice.They need not be deep fried but easily done by pan-fry which does not require much oil.Recipe adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 102Â with modificationsIngredients200 gm fish paste200 gm minced meat3 water chestnuts - skinned and chopped3 tbsp chopped red carrot1 cabbage leaf - chopped1 stalk spring onions - choppedEnough oil to pan fry pattiesSeasoning1 tsp sesame oil1/4 tbsp salt to taste1 tsp chicken stock granules1 tbsp cornstarchCombine all the ingredients in and mixing bowl. Â Add in seasoning and mix well. Â Stir in one direction until paste is very sticky.Divide into 12 equal portions. Â Form into balls and flatten into patties.Pan fry the patties in a non-stick wok until golden brown or cooked through.Dish up and drain. Serve with some salad leaves.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#11Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: SWEET POTATO CHICKEN CURRY
text: I can say that this is the first time I have cooked curry withsweet potatoes.Â  The first look at therecipe did attract my attention right away.Â Of course, I have added pumpkin and potatoes to chicken curry before but never with sweet potatoes.This curry cooks faster than with potatoes orpumpkin.Â  Simmering over low fire for15-20 minutes is enough to cook the chicken and sweet potatoes, whichÂ means that it is rather quick to preparethis dish.It is not aÂ  veryspicy curry though the colour looks like it is but overall the curry is delicious with rice.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 102 withmodificationsIngredients3 chicken whole legs â€“ cut bite size pieces [skinremoved]500 gm orange sweet potatoes â€“ peeled and cut chunkypieces3 tbsp oil2-3 sprigs curry leaves2-3 stalks lemongrass â€“ crushed5 shallots â€“ chopped3 pips garlic â€“ chopped2 tbsp meat curry powder3 tbsp chilli bohÂ½ tbsp toasted belacanÂ½ turmeric powder â€“ optionalSeasoning1 tsp salt to tasteÂ½ tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp sweet condensed milk2 cups waterMix curry powder, turmeric powder, belacan and chilli bohwith some water into a thick paste.Heat oil in wok, sautÃ© chopped lemongrass, shallots andgarlic until aromatic.Â  Add in curryleaves and curry paste.Â  Stir fry untilfragrant, add in the chicken and stir to mix well, then add in the sweetpotatoes.Â  Continue to stir fry untilwell mixed.Â Add in water and seasoning,bring to boil, then low heat to simmer for 20 minutes or until the sweetpotatoes are soft and chicken is cooked.Dish up to serve.I'm linking this post to Cookbook Countdown Event#11 hosted by Kitchen Flavours and Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: TOMATO CURRY FISH
text: The original recipe is actually Tomato Curry Prawns.Â  I had to change it to fish as my hubby doesnot fancy prawns.Â This dish turns out to be a lovely fish dish with the aroma of curry powder, the sweet and sour taste of tomato sauce. Â A very appetising dish to go with rice. Â Glad I tried this recipe using fish. Â Feel free to substitute it with prawns if you like prawns. Â Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 102 withmodificationsIngredients200 gm fish fillet â€“ cut thick slices1 onion â€“ peeled and sliced1-2 tomatoes â€“ slicedSome diced red chillies and spring onions2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp fish curry powder100 ml waterSeasoningÂ¼ tbsp sugarÂ¼ tsp saltÂ½ tsp light soy sauceLightly coat fish fillet with some cornstarch.Â  Heat up some oil to pan fry fish pieces untilgolden brown, dish up.Using the same wok with about 1 tbsp oil, sautÃ© onionsuntil aromatic, add in curry powder, tomatoes and cook over low heat.Â  Add in tomato sauce, seasoning and water.Â  Bring to boil and stir until sauce is thick.Return fried fish to wok, toss well then add in thechopped chillies and spring onions.Dish up to serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#11Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: FRIED SPROUTS WITH ANCHOVIES
text: This is a dish which I prepare quite often.  Most times, I will use small silverfish or anchovies or dried prawns.  Recently, I came across this specie of anchovies which I was told by the vendor that it comes from Hong Kong.  Price wise, it is definitely more costly than local anchovies. Â But, it is alright to try out new ingredients in our cooking for a change otherwise we will never know that there may be good substitutes.Anyway, I love this simple stir fry sprouts, only setback is you may need some time to tail the sprouts. Â If you Â don't have the time then, best to skip it.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 60 with modificationsIngredients100 gm pea sproutsÂ 200 gm bean sprouts - tailed1/2 carrot - skinned and shredded30 gm dried anchovies - fried till crispy - dish up1 tbsp shredded gingerSeasoning1/2 tsp salt, dash of pepper and msg1/2 tbsp cornstarch water for thickeningHeat up 1-2 tbsp oil,saute ginger until aromatic. Â Add in beansprouts and carrot. Â Stir fry until well mixed.Add in the pea sprouts, quickly stir fry to mix. Add in seasoning and thicken with cornstarch water.Dish up and sprinkle fried crispy anchovies on top, serve.

title: BRAISED SPARE RIBS WITH PUMPKIN
text: This recipe looks simple where the ingredients areÂ  easily available but the cooking time couldbe a little longer.Â  The spare ribs taketime to cook till tender but it is still alright to prepare this dish whichbasically frying the ingredients,Â thenÂ  leave to braise.Â Â  I think using a slow cooker to cook thisdish would be much easier and saves time at the stove.The meat and sauce are savoury in taste which blends just well with the sweetness of the softpumpkin.Â  By adding some Basil leavesgives an extra fragrance to this dish.It can be a very tasty dish if the ribs are braised till the flavours are well absorbed in the ribs. Â  It is so nice with rice and with simple stir fry vegetable makes a complete meal.Recipe adapted from YumYum Magazine No. 102 with slight modificationsIngredients300 gm meaty spare ribs â€“ cut into bite size pieces1 tbsp oil1 tbsp each chopped shallots and garlic300 gm pumpkin â€“ peeled and cut into piecesSome Basil leaves200 ml waterMarinade and Seasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce and oyster sauce1 tsp sesame oilÂ¼Â  tsp saltÂ¼ tsp pepperÂ½Â  tsp dark soysauceÂ½ tbsp cornstarch [optional]Marinate spare ribs with marinade and seasoning for 30minutes.Heat wok, add in oil, sautÃ© chopped shallots and garlicuntil aromatic.Add in marinated spare ribs. Â Leave them to brown a little. Add in the marinade andwater.Bring to boil and leave to simmer for 20-30 minutes or untilribs are almost tender.Add in pumpkin and cover to continue cooking until soft,Lastly throw in the Basil leave to cook.Â  Dish up to serve.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#11Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: STIR FRY TOMYAM STINGRAY
text: I have cooked this dish a few times but couldn't decide if I should share it here. Â The basic reason is the brand of Tom Yam cube used. Â I have tried with different brands but find the 'M' brand a better choice.ThisÂ  is a dry tom yamflavoured fish dish. Â I recommend to usefish fillet or stingray for this dish. Â It is easy to prepare using Â Maggi Tom Yam cubes. Â As mentioned above, I havetried using other brands but I still prefer using this brand.Â  For a more spicy version, feel free to addsome small chillies as theÂ  Tom Yam cubesare not spicy but the taste is just nice.You can increase the seasoning [1-2 cubes] if you like this dish alittle soupy.Ingredients1 piece [300 gm] stingray â€“ cut bite size pieces1 stalk lemongrass â€“ sliced1 tomato â€“ sliced1 big onion â€“ peeled and sliced5-6 kaffir lime leavesÂ½ tbsp oil1 tomyam cube â€“ dissolve in 1 tbsp water50 ml water [more if you increase the seasoning cube]Heat oil, sautÃ© lemongrass until aromatic. Pour in the tomyam cube mixture. Â Bring to boil, then add in the fish pieces.Stir fry to cook, add in chillies, onions, tomatoes, and water.Cover to cook for 2-3 minutes or until fish pieces are cooked. Â Remove cover and continue to cook until sauce is reduced.Lastly add in kaffir lime leaves. Â Toss well and dish up to serve.

title: HONEY GLAZED CHICKEN
text: This is a very easy to cook chicken dish that is good with steaming hot rice and salad to make it a complete meal.The preparation is easy and quick, with minimal seasoning. Â You can also use chicken wings or any part of the chicken. Â I prefer deboned chicken whole legs as it is not too oil compared to chicken wings.The sweetness of the sauce is acceptable to me and goes well with rice. Â You can serve it with freshly sliced tomatoes, zucchini or salad leaves.I am very satisfied with this honey glazed chicken. Â It was so good with a plate of rice and vegetables. Â We had this with Watercress Soup. Sure would like to prepare this again soon.Recipe adapted from my selected cookbookÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 102Â [with slight modifications] for this month's Cookbook Countdown Event #11Ingredients3 pieces chicken whole legs - deboned with some skin, fats removed150 - 200 ml waterMarinade4 tbsp honey2 tbsp oyster sauce1/2 tsp saltCombine chicken pieces with marinade. Â Mix well and marinate for at least 2 hours.Heat a non-stick wok, pan fry chicken pieces, skin side first until brown and slightly crispy. Â Flip over to fry the meat side.Pour in the marinade, add water. Â Bring to rolling boil, then lower heat, cover and simmer until chicken is cooked through.Remove cover and braised till sauce is reduced to the consistency preferred.Dish up, garnish with freshly sliced vegetables.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#11Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: STEAMED CURRY PORK IN PUMPKIN BOWL
text: This steamed pumpkin is something similar toÂ Black Bean Spare Ribs in Pumpkin Bowl. Â The only difference is the filling. For this, I used fried curry pork as filling. Â The curry is savoury/sourish in taste which blends well with the sweetness of the pumpkin.It is easy to prepare yet an awesome and presentable dish.Ingredients1/2 a small pumpkin [about 400 gm] - seeds removedIngredients for Curry Pork150 gm pork - cubed1 onion - peeled and cubed50 gm red carrot - cubed1-2 sprigs curry leaves1/2 tsp mustard seedsÂ 1-2 tbsp oil1-2 tbsp meat curry powder1/4 tsp tumeric powder1/4 tsp garam masala [optional]1/2 tsp salt to taste2 tbsp tamarind juice50 - 100 ml waterMarinade pork cubes with curry powder, tumeric powder, garam masala and salt for 30 minutes.Heat oil in a non-stick pan, sautÃ© mustard seeds and curry leaves until aromatic.Add marinated pork cubes and stir fry until firm and fragrant. Â  Add in carrots and onions, then tamarind juice. Â Stir Â to mix well, then add water.Bring to boil, then simmer for 10 minutes or until the water has reduced or thick. Â Taste to adjust seasoning.Transfer curry pork mixture into pumpkin bowl.Steam over medium heat for 45 minutes or until pumpkin is cooked.Remove and serve immediately with rice.

title: PORK CHOPS WITH ONIONS IN SUPERIOR SOYA SAUCE
text: Just love to cook this kind of simple, easy recipe that is delicious and tasty served with rice.  I like the sweetness of the onions, simple sauce ingredients and tender meat slices.  Awesome, homey dish.Recipe adapted from my selected cookbook [Yum Yum Magazine No. 102] for this monthâ€™s Cookbook Countdown Event #11Â Ingredients300 gm pork tenderloin â€“ cut 1 cm thick slices [pounded to tenderize]2 onions â€“ shreddedMarinadeÂ½ tsp saltÂ¼ tsp pepper1 tsp sesame oil1 tbsp cornstarch2-3 tbsp waterSauce Ingredients2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp wine3 tbsp waterÂ½ tbsp sugarIn a mixing bowl, mix meat slices with water until well absorbed.  Add in the remaining marinade ingredients and lastly the cornstarch.  Mix well and marinade for an hour.Heat up 1-2 tbsp oil, pan fry meat slices until brown on both sides and at least 80% cooked.  Push aside.Using the remaining oil, add in the shredded onions and fry until fragrant.  Stir fry to combine ingredients and add in the seasoning sauce.  Bring to a simmering boil and cooked until sauce is thick.Dish up to serve.  Garnish with zucchini slices or lettuce if preferred.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#11Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: STIR FRY KAILAN WITH MEI CAI SAUCE
text: Thisdish is a continuation of my previous post on Steamed Fish with Mei Cai.Itis an easy and simple vegetable dish to prepare yet it looks good on the dinnertable.Ingredients300gm kalian â€“ cleaned and cut into 1-2 inch lengthsSomechopped garlic1tbsp cooking oilSomeshredded carrotsSome minced meat mei cai sauce [visit here for the recipe]Heatup wok, add in oil and chopped garlic.Â Fry until fragrant, then add in kalian together with the carrots.Â  Stir fry till cook and season with some salt.Â  Dish up on serving platter.Usingthe same wok, reheat pre-cooked mei cai minced meat sauce, dish up on top offried kalian.Serveimmediately.

title: STEAMED FISH WITH MEI CAI
text: After 2 months enjoying easy to prepare Thai food, this month's food to try from the latest book which I collected.I supposed this is a rather new recipe for steaming fish. Â The steaming ingredients have to be pre-cooked, then spread over fish before steaming.Â This Braised Minced Meat Mei Cai is very tasty and can be used as a spread over Stir Fry Leafy Greens or serve as a dish with porridge. Â This, I discovered when I attended a dinner at the restaurant. Â They used this to serve with Stir Fry Kai Lan and it was acceptable.Overall, this braised meat with mei cai is good and tasty for steaming fish. Â You can use any white whole fish or fish fillet. Â Here, I used stingray as I don't like to steam fish with lots of bones. Â I don't enjoy bony fishes.This portion of Braised Minced Meat Mei Cai is quite a big portion. Â You can either prepare the whole portion, store it for other uses or cook a third of this portion for the purpose of steaming fish. Â For me, it is alright with this portion as I love it with porridge.Recipe adapted from my selected cookbook Yum Yum Magazine No. 102 [with slight modifications] for this month's Cookbook Countdown Event #11Ingredients300 gm stingray - cut into 2 thick slicessome shredded spring onions and red chilli - for garnishingBraised Minced Meat Mei Cai200 gm minced meat300 gm sweet mei cai - rinsed, soaked and chopped3 tbsp chopped garlic3 small chilli - chopped2-3 tbsp oil [if using lean meat]Seasoning3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce2 tsp sesame seed oil1/2 tsp pepper1 tsp sugar250 - 250 ml water2 tsp cornstarch for thickening [I omit]Dry fry chopped mei cai in a non-stick wok until dry. Â Dish up.Heat oil in non-stick wok, saute garlic until fragrant, add in minced meat and fry until meat turns white.Â Add in the chilli and mei cai. Â Stir fry to combine ingredients well. Â Add in seasoning and water.Bring to boil, then lower heat to simmer/braise mei cai until tender and water almost dry. Â Dish up.Place fish to steam on a steaming plate, spread some braised mei cai over fish.Steam fish over high heat for 12-15 minutes [depending on size of fish] until cooked through.Remove, garnish with chilli and spring onions. Â Serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ Cookbook Countdown Event#11Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking [Makan2] Foray

title: SWEET AND SOUR SAUCE FISH
text: Sweetand sour fish is a very common dish served at home and at the restaurants.Â  Of course, there are various ways ofpreparing the sauce and various types of white meat fish are used.Â  I always prefer to cook with fish fillets asI am afraid of fish bones.Â Thisis a tasty dish and the sweetness of the sauce is acceptable to me.Â  Some sauce can be overly sweet and I feel thequality of chilli sauce and tomato sauce does contribute to the overall taste ofthe sauce.Anyway,I happy with the taste and it is great with the addition of capsicum, zucchini,tomatoes and onions.Thisrecipe is adapted from Amy Behâ€™s recipes on Sweet and Sour Sauce Fish.Ingredients300gm white fish fillet slices1Bombay onion - cubed1tomato â€“ cubedÂ½green capsicum â€“ cut into diamond shapeÂ½red capsicum or 1 red chilli â€“ cut into diamond shapeÂ½zucchini â€“ seeded and cubed1stalk spring onions â€“ cut sectionsEnoughoil to fry fishSeasoning3tbsp tomato sauce2tbsp chilli sauceDashof salt and pepper50ml waterMarinatefish slices with dash of salt and some beaten egg.Â  Coat with some cornflour before frying.Heatup wok, add in oil and fry fish fillets until golden brown and cooked.Â  Dish up onto serving platter.Removeexcess oil.Â  Using the same wok, fry onions,capsicum and tomatoes.Â  Pour in the seasoning,stir fry to mix.Add in zucchini.Â  Bring sauce to boil until Â thick.Â Dish up on to fried fish.Â  Serveimmediately.

title: THAI GREEN PAPAYA SALAD
text: Thai Green Papaya Salad aka Som-tum Koong Sod in Thai isa very popular salad in Thai cuisine.It may look difficult to prepare but in actual it is notso if you are able to separate the salad ingredients well.Â  The dressing is easy to concoct and theremaining ingredients is not difficult to assemble.Â  I prepared this salad using a home growngreen papaya from my mumâ€™s house.Â  It isa seedless small papaya, the size is just nice for making this salad. The salad ingredients are crunchy and the dressing is notoverly sourish, sweet or savoury. Appetisingly good to serve with rice.Â  The prawns can be replaced with crabmeat.Recipe adapted fromÂ Healthy and Easy Thai CookingÂ [my this month's selected cookbook for Cookbook Countdown Event #10]Ingredients For The Salad1 cup green papaya â€“ skinned an shreddedÂ½ cup shredded red carrot2-3 long beans â€“ cut 1 inch length - smashed1 tomato â€“ diced or 5 cherry tomatoes â€“ halved7-8 prawns â€“ boiled2 tbsp dried prawns â€“ rinsed, fried and pounded2 tbsp fried crispy peanuts2 red chilli â€“ seeded and chopped4 pips garlic â€“ smashed and choppedDressing [combined]2-3 tbsp gula Melaka2-3 tbsp fish sauce2-3 tbsp lime juice1 tbsp thick tamarind pasteCombine dressing ingredients and set aside.Mix shredded papaya, carrots, long beans, tomatoes,chilli, garlic and prawns in a mixing bowl. Mix in dressing, toss well to combine.Lastly add in dried prawns and peanuts.Dish up on serving platter, garnish with extra driedprawns and peanuts.I'm linking this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown #10Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking (Makan2) Foray

title: MUSHROOM AND CHICKEN IN SOUP
text: This is a dish that you can prepare in thick sauce or slightlysoupy.Â Â  It has a combination of variousingredients with proteins and fibre all in a platter.Â  Serving this with some plain white rice makesit a complete One Dish Meal.Ingredients1 chicken whole leg â€“ deboned and chopped bite sizepieces100 gm fresh large abalone mushrooms â€“ cut thick slices4-5 young corn â€“ cut sections1 stalk leek â€“ cut slantwiseSome red carrot slices6 slices gingerSome chopped garlic1 tsp sesame oilSauce Ingredients1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp light soy sauceDash of pepper and salt to tasteSome water [for thick sauce] or 2 cups water [for soupy]Marinate chicken pieces with dash of salt, msg andpepper.Heat up a non-stick wok, add in sesame oil, ginger andgarlic.Â Â Fry until aromatic, add inchicken and stir fry until aromatic.Addin mushrooms, carrot and seasoning ingredients.Â Transfer fried ingredients to a claypot [for soupy version], add inwater.Â Â Bring to boil until ingredientsare cooked through.Â  Lastly add in leeks,bring to a quick boil and serve immediately.Â For the thick version, add in water, bring to boil until ingredients arecooked, then add in leeks.Â  Stir fryuntil leeks turn bright green.Â Dish upto serve immediately.

title: YUM PLA TU-NA [THAI TUNA SALAD]
text: Thai Tuna Salad aka Yum Pla Tu-naThis is Â anothersimple yet awesome Thai salad withÂ canned tuna.Â  The third recipe using canned from this cookbook.Â You may think it isdifficult to prepare with a long list of ingredients but in fact most of themare easily available in your home kitchen.Â Initially, I didnâ€™t intend to prepare this too when I saw theingredients.Anyway, I am glad I wentahead to buy a green mango and a pack of crispy fried peanuts to make thissalad.Â  It is really nice to me and Ienjoyed it very much.Â  The green mango iscrunchy and tasty infused with the dressing sauce that is savoury and sourish.Recipe adapted fromHealthy and Easy Thai CookingÂ [my this month's selected cookbook for Cookbook Countdown Event #10]Ingredients150 gm canned tuna in brine â€“ drained off liquid1 small green mango â€“ skinned and finely shredded5-6 shallots â€“ thinly sliced4 pips garlic â€“ chopped1 cm young ginger â€“ finely shredded Â½ red carrot â€“ finely shredded3-4 small chilli â€“ finely choppedSome chopped coriander and spring onionsSome crispy fried peanutsDressing Ingredients [combined]2-3 tbsp fish sauce3 tbsp lime juice1 tsp each of sugar and honeyCombined the dressing ingredients in a big bowl.Prepare the other ingredients as stated above.Â  Add in to the dressing sauce.Toss well and dish up to serve.Â  Garnish with crispy peanuts.I'm linking this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown #10Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking (Makan2) Foray

title: THAI STIR FRY TUNA WITH BASIL LEAVES
text: Reading through this book, I cameacross 3 recipes with canned tuna.Â  It nevercame across my mind that canned tuna can be used for stir fry and salads[thought it is awesome as filling for baked buns].Â  Â Â Thefirst I tried was Nam-Prik Pla-tu-na [Tuna Salad]Â which was easy and good.Thai Stir Fry Tuna With Basil Leaves aka Phad Ka-prow Pla tu-na. Â This is the second recipe which I tried.Â  It is also very easy to prepare yetawesome.Â  Simple ingredients andseasoning yet this dish is very appetizing with rice.Â Â  Do add lots of chopped garlic if you likebut I added tomatoes and onions too which you can omit.Â Â While preparing this dish, I learnedthat fresh Basil leaves must not be left to soak in water.Â  It will turned dark like what you see in thepicture.Â Â  Just rinse under running waterbefore cooking, this is the advice from my neighbor who gave me these Basilleaves.Back to this dish, it tasted savoury,sourish and has the refreshing sweet Â aroma of the Basil leaves.Â  Overall this is a nice dish.Recipe adapted fromÂ Healthy and Easy Thai CookingÂ [my this month's selected cookbook for Cookbook Countdown Event #10]Ingredients1 canned tuna in oil â€“ drain away theliquid2 tbsp chopped garlic2 tbsp chopped red chilli [I added 2small green chilli]1 tomato â€“ cut wedges â€“ optional1 onion â€“ cut wedges â€“ optional1 bunch Basil leaves â€“ use the leavesonly1-2 tbsp cooking oil2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp sugarSome extra sliced red and greenchilliesHeat oil in wok, sautÃ© chopped garlic until aromatic and golden.Add in tuna flakes, tomatoes/onions[if using] and chillies, Â stir fry to mix.Add in seasoning and 2 tbspwater.Â  Bring to boil and lastly add inthe basil leaves. Toss well and dish up to serve with steaming hot rice.I'm linking this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown #10Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking (Makan2) Foray

title: BLACK PEPPER SAUCE FISH FILLET
text: I not good at eating fish especially those with bones. Â The best option to enjoy fish is to choose Â fish fillets or meaty fish with minimal bones like shark fish, stingray, Spanish mackerel, salmon, cod fish etc.Â This fish dish Â with black pepper sauce suits me well. Â The spicy nice of aroma of black pepper coupled with the other accompaniments and fried fish fillets is awesome. Â I can enjoy my plate of rice with this alone. Â You can reduce the spiciness by adjusting the amount of black pepper used but the portion here is acceptable to me.This dish is quick to cook if you have a microwave oven. Â My friend's way is to pre-fry a big portion of the fish fillets ahead of meal time or even days before and then store them in refrigerator. Â Reheat the fish fillets while she cook up the sauce, toss well and dish up to serve. Â Really quick way. Â I know many of my neighbours are doing this but I haven't tried as I don't have a microwave oven.Ingredients200 gm fish fillet - sliced thickly and marinate with dash of salt, pepper and sesame oil then coated with 1 tbsp each of cornflour and rice flour50 gm green capsicum - seeded and cut wedges1 red chilli - seeded and cut diamond shape1 onion - cubed1 tomato - cubeda few slices ginger2 pips garlic - sliced1 stalk spring onion - cut sectionsSauce Ingredients1 tsp ground black pepper1 tsp sesame oil1 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp oyster saucedash of msg or 1/4 tsp sugar50 ml waterHeat up enough oil to pan fry fish fillets in batches until cooked and golden brown, dish up on to serving plate. Â You can deep fry fish fillet, too.Remove excess oil. Â Using the same wok, saute ginger and garlic until aromatic, add in onions, tomatoes, capsicum and chilli. Â Stir to mix well, pour in sauce ingredients and bring to a quick boil or until gravy is slightly thick.Â Lastly add in spring onions, pour over fried fish and serve immediately. Â You can return fried fish to wok, toss well and dish up to serve.

title: THAI TUNA SALAD
text: Thai Tuna Salad aka Nam-prik Pla-tu-na in Thai.Â I understand that there are several versionsof Thai Tuna Salad, each varies basically because of different ingredientsadded to the canned tuna.This is one of the simplest from the several Tuna Saladrecipes which I have picked to try first because it has the least number ofingredients.I find this salad very appetizing and especially goodafter resting.Â  The flavours are wellinfused after resting, making the shredded cabbage and tuna flakes are very tasty.Â Â  My opinion â€“ it is nice, like it with rice.Recipe adapted fromÂ Healthy and Easy Thai CookingÂ [my this month's selected cookbook forÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #10]Ingredients1 canned tuna in water â€“ drain off water 1 tbsp dried prawns â€“ rinsed several timesSome chopped coriander4 â€“ 5 chilli padi5 shallots10 pips garlicSome finely shredded cabbage â€“ soaked in cold water anddrainedDressing [combined]2 tbsp fish sauce2-3 tbsp lime juice1 tbsp sugar2-3 tbsp waterDry fry shallots, chilli padi and garlic in wok untilslightly brown and soft. Â Â Transfer to apestle and pounded into a paste or blend in blender.Â  Mix well with dressing, set aside.Dry fry tuna for a minute.Â  Dish up into a bowl.Dry fry dried prawns until fragrant, pounded in a pestleor blended.Combine 1, 2 and 3.Â Mix well with chopped coriander.Line serving platter with shredded cabbage.Â  Top with tuna salad.Â  Serve.I'm linking this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown #10Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking (Makan2) Foray

title: THERMAL COOKER BRAISED SOY SAUCE CHICKEN WITH EGGS
text: If you donâ€™t eat pork but love the flavours of BraisedSoy Sauce Pork [Tau Eu Bak], then this may be an alternative recipe foryou.Â  For this recipe, chicken whole legsare used but the sauce is not that thick and dark looking type like the Nyonya Tau Eu Bak. It is thewatery type but you can make it thick by reducing the water and seasoningingredients.After 9 days of strict vegetarian diet, this dish serve Â on the dinner table is most welcome by family members.For this dish, I used my Thermal Cooker to prepare it â€“saves time over the stove and energy.Â  Ifusing normal pot, do increase the water by about Â¼ - Â½Â  cup.Â The eggs are braised with the shells on to get a marbled effect [Ididnâ€™t manage to get a nice marbled effect], you can shell it before braising,too.I served this aromatic braised soy sauce chicken and eggswith pickled preserved salted vegetable [kiam chye], sliced cucumber and sambalbelacan.Â  An easy and simple meal fordinner.Â  Recipe inspired and adapted from Amy Behâ€™s recipe[Braised Soy Sauce Chicken With Marbled Eggs] â€“ slightly modifiedIngredients[serves 2-3]2 large chicken whole legs â€“ skin removed and cut bitsize pieces3 hard boiled eggs [see pictures below on how I cook thehard boiled eggs] â€“ lightly tapped but do not peel6 dried mushrooms â€“ soaked and stems removedSeasoning A1/8 tsp pepper1 tbsp light soy sauceDash of chicken granules or msgSeasoning B2 star anise4 cloves aÂ  3 cm piececinnamon stick2 bay leavesaÂ  4 cm piece oldginger â€“ lightly smashed or sliced4 stalks spring onions â€“ use only the end portion1 tsp sesame oil1 tbsp brown sugar2-3 tbsp light soy sauceÂ½ tbsp dark soy sauce1 Â½ cups waterSeason chicken with A for at least an hour.Caramelise brown sugar with sesame oil in the inner pot, then add in B ingredients together with water.Â Bring to boil and simmer overlow heat until fragrant.Add in the chicken, mushrooms and eggs into the stock,ensuring all ingredients are submerged.Â Bring to boil and reduce the heat to simmer for 10-15 minutes.Transfer to outer pot, close the lid andleave to cook for about 1 hour or long until serving time.Remove the eggs from stock, shell and serve with the restof the ingredients with rice.Â  Reheatbefore serving if preferred.Notes:The eggs are boiled together with an timer/indicator [this is agift from a Japanese friend]. Â When the portion with the word 'soft' turns white, this means the egg is soft boiled. Â See howeasy it is?When you see pink, the eggs are not even soft boiled.When all turned white, this means the eggs are hard-boiled

title: THAI GRILLED BRINJAL SALAD
text: Thai Grilled Brinjal Salad aka Yum Ma-khuea-yao in Thai.This salad looks good, isn't it?  Has anyone tried cooking brinjals/eggplant this way? I have eaten often brinjals/eggplants in curries, deep-fried, steamed and in omelette but havenâ€™t tried grilled brinjals. Â Out of curiosity, I wonder whether it takes a longer time to cook brinjals by grilling.  Surprisingly, it isnâ€™t.  Just leave them to grill over low heat, the brinjals turned soft and you can even remove the skin.I believe this is a healthy salad too as it is fat free except that you have to add the sugar sparingly because Thai food is usually on the sweet side.  Anyway, the sweetness with this portion is acceptable to me. Tastes savoury, sourish and spicy. The combination of ingredients blend well into an appetizing salad.  A simple salad like this can earn a Thumbs Up from my hubby.  I was surprised and of course happy, too.Perhaps, you can give this a try to know this dish better and of course to enjoy it like I did.Recipe adapted fromÂ Healthy and Easy Thai CookingÂ [my this month's selected cookbook forÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #10]Ingredients1 long brinjal â€“ cleaned and dried1 hard-bolied egg â€“ shelled and cut wedges2-3 shallots â€“ thinly sliced2-3 garlic â€“ thinly sliced1-2 small red chilli â€“ chopped1-2 tbsp fried prawns â€“ rinsed several times and dryfried in a wok, set asideDressing [mixed until sugar dissolves]2 tbsp fish sauce3 tbsp lime juice2-3 tbsp sugarSome mint leaves and coriander leaves for garnishingGrill brinjals in a dry wok until brinjals are cooked,turning constantly to ensure even cooking.Set aside to cool before removing the skin [you can leavethe skin intact if it isnâ€™t charred], then sliced. Â Arrange on serving platter and add in theeggs.Mix well shallots, garlic, chillies and dried prawnstogether and spread over brinjals.Drizzle dressing over ingredients and garnish with mint leavesand coriander leaves.Serve immediately.Notes: The eggs and dried prawns can be replaced byboiled chicken or other meats.I'm linking this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown #10Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking (Makan2) Foray

title: THAI GLASS NOODLE MEATBALL SOUP
text: Thai Glass Noodle Meatballs Soup aka Kaeng Jud Wun-senSong-krueng in Thai.This is a clear soup.Â  The glass noodles are added into the meat andprawn paste and made into meatballs.Â  Themeatballs are seasoned only with fish sauce. These meatballs are cooked instock or water together with Chinese long cabbage and carrots.This turned out to be tasty and good to serve with rice ornoodles.Â  Again, this is the kind ofclear soup which I like as it is quick to cook and almost oil free. Â To me it is another healthy kind of soup.Recipe adapted fromÂ Healthy and Easy Thai CookingÂ [my this month's selected cookbook forÂ Cookbook Countdown Event #10]Ingredients150 gm minced meat100 gm prawn meat â€“ mashed and coarsely choppedA small bunch ofÂ glass noodle [tung fun] â€“ soaked and cut about 1 inch length1 tbsp chopped garlic 1 tbsp pounded coriander rootsÂ½-1 tsp white pepper powder1 â€“ 1 Â½ tbsp fish sauce to tasteSome sliced red carrotsSeveral leaves of Chinese long cabbage â€“ cut 2 inchlengthsÂ¼ tsp each of salt and msgSome spring onions â€“ cut 1 inch lengthSome crispy fried garlicCombine minced meat with prawn paste, garlic, corianderroots, pepper and fish sauce into a paste, then add in the glass noodles.Â  Mix into a thick paste or until all theingredients come together.Â  Set aside.Bring water or stock to boil, add in cabbage and carrotsto cook.Â Meanwhile, shape meat pasteinto meatballs and add to soup.Â  Cookover medium low heat until meatballs float up.Add in seasoning to taste. Â If using stock, do reduce the seasoning stated.Lastly add in spring onions and fried garlic beforeserving.I'm linking this post withÂ Cookbook Countdown #10Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ andÂ Emily's Cooking (Makan2) Foray

title: EZCR#76  - VINEGAR FLAVOURED CHICKEN
text: This vinegar flavoured chicken dish can be cooked usingchicken wings or chicken whole legs.Â  Itis an aromatic dish that tastes sourish, savoury but not sweet.Â  A very appetizing dish which is quick to cook and good to serve with steaminghot rice. Â  Homey, yummy home-cooked chicken dish.Recipe adapted from Chinese TV Cook Show withmodificationsIngredients2 chicken whole legs â€“ deboned with skin intact â€“ cutbite size pieces1 yellow onion â€“ peeled and shredded1 tbsp shredded ginger1 tbsp chopped garlic50 ml waterSome toasted sesame seedsSeasoning3 tbsp black vinegar2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp sugar to taste1 tbsp Apple Cider vinegar [optional]Heat a non-stick wok with some oil, pan fry the chickenpieces [skin side first] until brown.Â Push aside and add in the ginger, garlic and onions to fry for severalminutes.Stir and mix all ingredients, add in seasoning and water.Â  Bring to boil and low heat to simmer with thelid on for 5 minutes.Remove cover and cook until sauce is reduced.Â  Taste to adjust season [can add in ACV or omit].Dish up to serve.Â Garnish with some toasted sesame seeds.

title: THAI SPICY FRIED MEAT SALAD
