Mix with the other ingredients, it is a good salad dressing with is not too sweet or oily but  fragrant.Ingredients[serves 2-3]Â½ small chicken breast â€“ skinned1-2 pieces firm beancurd - cut strips1 packet fresh  Enoki mushrooms â€“ rinse and cut into half1 red chilli â€“ seeded and cut thin strips1 stalk coriander â€“ coarsely choppedSalad Dressing [mix together]2 tbsp Apple Cider vinegar1 tbsp sesame seed oil1 tsp sugarÂ½ tsp salt1/4 tsp pepperBoil or steam chicken breast for 10-15 minutes or until cooked.  Cool and shredded.Blanch Enoki mushrooms in hot water for 1 minute.  Drain and cool in a colander.Fry firm beancurd until crispy at the edges, cool and cut strips.Put all the salad ingredients in a big bowl.  Toss well and pour in the salad dressing.Cover and chill in the fridge until required.Transfer to a serving platter, sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds.  Serve.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess Wanabe

title: STEWED PORK BELLY WITH GINGER BUD
text: Hi, my friends and visitors to this humble blog, I'm back from holiday and also back to home cooking. Â This is an easy,simple yet aromatic and tasty pork belly dish which I cooked. Thick sweet and savoury sauce that is good to serve with steaming hot rice. Â The aromatics like lemongrass and ginger bud make this meaty dish yummy, yummy with rice.This dishtaste better after resting and can be cooked ahead of meal time.Â  Just reheat before serving.Â Â  RecipeSource â€“ adapted fromÂ Yum Yum Magazine No. 60Ingredients[serve3-4]500 gmpork belly â€“ cut into bite size pieces3 stalkslemongrass [white part only] â€“ pounded1 stalkginger flower bud â€“ cut into 4 piecesÂ½ tbspoilSeasoning2-3 tbspchilli sauce3 tbsplight soy sauce1 tspdark soy sauce2 tbsppalm sugar [gula Melaka]Â½ tsppepper300 mlwater or enough to cover meatHeatoil in a non-stick wok, sautÃ© pounded lemongrass until aromatic.Addin ginger bud and pork belly.Â  Stir fryto mix and until aromatic.Addin seasoning, stir to combine ingredients.Â Then add in water.Bringto boil and simmer for 40-45 minutes or until meat is tender and gravy isthick.Dishup to serve with rice.This post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: KUIH SAGO [PALM SUGAR KUIH SAGO]
text: This is another lovely Steamed Sago Cake [Kuih Sago] which I did after seeing the recipe posted by May Law. Â The recipe looks much easier, simple and the kuih requires no coating with grated coconut.Â Now I have a choice of Kuih Sago recipe to use apart from the otherÂ recipe.The kuih smells fragrant with the pandan juice and grated coconut within the kuih. Â May uses blue pea flower [bunga telang] for the blue colour but I replaced it with pandan juice as this kuih is made for my MIL. Â Was afraid she may not like the blue colour. Â If you like to make it blue, steep some blue pea flowers with 2 tablespoons of hot water overnight, then strain to obtain the juice. Â My MIL was very happy with this kuih cos' she asked for the recipe.Verdict - the sago kuih is soft, chewy, fragrant and tasty. Â The green and plain coloured layers are without sugar and the sweetness of this kuih is from the palm sugar layer. Â If you love sago kuih, you can give try this one cos' it is easy.Ingredients[use a greased 6 or 7 inch square tin]400 gm sago200 gm white grated coconut1/2 tsp salt140 gm palm sugar [gula melaka] - chopped into small pieces3-4 pandan leaves - blend with 2 tbsp water. Â Strain the juice and discard the pulp. Â Add a little green colouring if preferredwater for soaking sagoRinse and soak sago with some water for 20 minutes. Drain and strain the sago.Mix sago with grated coconut then divide into 3 equal portions [about 400 gm].Mix 1 portion with the chopped gula melaka. Â Mix well and set aside.Add 1/4 tsp salt to the remaining 2 portions. Â Keep 1 portion plain and add the pandan juice [2 tbsp] to the other portion. Â Mix well.Pour the plain portion into the greased tin and steam over high heat for 10 minutes.Remove from steamer, pour in the gula melaka portion. Â Spread Â evenly and return to steamer to steam for another 10 minutes.Remove tin and pour in the green portion. Â Continue to steam over high heat for a further 15-20 minutes or until sago turns clear and translucent.Remove kuih to cool thoroughly before slicing to serve.Â Notes: Use a plastic knife lightly greased with oil to slice the kuih.

title: FRIED TUMERIC CHICKEN [OOI KEOW KAY]
text: This is an easy yet yummylicious fried chicken which is supposed to be confinement mothers but it was so delicious [tasty and fragrant] that my whole family [young and old] loves it too.Try it if you believe me and you will love it. Â Here, I am sharing the modified version [using less of sesame oil and more of cooking oil for the frying]. Â I supposed you can use cooking oil and omit the sesame oil, it is still good. Â The original recipe uses 1 cup sesame oil and 1 tbsp pounded fresh tumeric.Recipe Source -Â adapted from Â Nyonya Flavours [modified]Ingredients1 kg chicken thigh - cut bite size pieces1 tbsp sesame oil1 cup cooking oil for fryingMarinade1 tbsp tumeric powder1 tsp salt to taste1/4 tsp pepper powder2-3 tbsp cornflourMarinade chicken pieces with marinade for at least an hour or overnight in the fridge.Heat oil in sauce pan or wok over medium heat. Â Deep fry marinated chicken pieces in batches until golden brown and yellow in colour.Dish up. Â Serve immediately.This post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursI'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess Wanabe

title: POTATO CHICKEN CURRY PAUS
text: This recipe is from Coco Kongâ€™s book on â€˜PAUSâ€™.Â  There are many recipes on paus with varioustypes of fillings from sweet to savoury, vegetarian to spicy ones.Â  Chose to make these potato chicken currypausÂ  to share with Little Thumbs UpApril 2015 Event on â€˜Chickenâ€™.These paus are not white cosâ€™ I used unbleached plainflour instead of pau flour.Â  For betterlooks, I suggest you stick to pau flour, bare in mind pau flour is doubled the price of plain flour. Â Haven't check whether there is GST for pau flour.Verdict â€“ the dough is easy to handle and aftersteaming, it is soft, moist and chewy.Â Nice texture which is not crumbly.Â The filling is not spicy but tasty.Â The portion here is enough to make about 24 paus and not 12 according tothe recipe.Â  So double this skin doughportion or cook only Â½ portion of the filling.Recipe Source â€“ adapted fromÂ Paus by Coco Kong [modified]Ingredients for Filling[enough for 24 paus]200 gm chicken breast meat â€“ diced1 onion- peeled and chopped80 gm mixed vegetables â€“ scalded and drained [I usedcarrots]200 gm potatoes â€“ boiled, peeled and diced2 tbsp curry powder1 tsp salt1 tsp sugar2 tsp light soy sauce100 ml water1 tbsp water mixed with 1 tsp cornflour for thickeningFor Filling:Heat with 1 tbsp oil, sautÃ© onions, chicken, potatoesand mixed vegetables together with curry powder and seasoning until cookedthrough.Add water and simmer untilingredients are tender.Thicken with cornflour mix.Â  Dish up and set aside to cool.Ingredients for Pau Skin[makes 12 paus]280 gm pau flour40 gm icing sugar2 tsp instant yeast1 tsp white vinegar130-140 ml water25 gm shorteningFor the Pau Skin:Place all dough ingredients [except shortening]in amixing bowl.Â  Knead into a dough, add inshortening and continue to knead until soft, smooth and pliable.Shape into a ball, cover to rest for 30 minutes.Â  Punch down and divide dough into 12 equalportions [about 40-50 gm].Â  Shape intoballs.Â  Flatten into circular disc.Â Â Wrap filling and gather the edges to makeinto a triangular shape pau.Â  SealÂ  the edges well.Â  Place on flattened Â paper cup case.Finish doing the same for the remaining dough.Leave to proof for at least 30 â€“ 40 minutes or doublein size.Bring water to boil, steam paus over medium heat for10-12 minutes or till cooked through.Remove and serve paus immediately or warm.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess WanabeThis post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: FRIED CHICKEN IN SPECIAL SWEET SOUR SAUCE
text: Easy tocook, yet tasty chicken dish.Â Suitable to serve with white rice or mashed potatoes and salad.Recipe Source - adapted from Hawkers' Simplified FlairIngredients1chicken maryland â€“ deboned1 onionâ€“ diced1 tomatoâ€“ dicedMarinadeÂ½Â  tsp saltÂ½ tspsugarÂ¼ tsp pepper1 tspcurry powderÂ½ egg1 tbspwater1 tbspcornflourSeasoning[combine together]2 tbsptomato sauce1 tbspchilli sauce1 tspWorcester sauceÂ½ tspcurry powderÂ½ tbspsugar1/4 tspsalt1 tsplight soy sauce45 mlwaterCombinechicken Maryland with marinade for at least 30 minutes.Coatwith cornflour before deep frying or pan fried until golden brown.Â  Dish up on serving platter.Removeoil.Â  Using the same wok, sautÃ© onionsand tomato for several seconds and pour in the sauce.Cookuntil sauce is slightly thick or reduced.Pourover fried chicken.Â  Serve hot.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess WanabeThis post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: ZHE JIANG PORK RIBS
text: This pork ribs dish is not  difficult to cook yet it is a delicious dish with fragrant sweet, sourish  sauce to serve with rice.  Very appetizing sauce and pork ribs are tender and has a bite that brings out the flavour and sweetness of the meat.Moreover, this dish can be prepared immediately or earlier before meal time.  Increased the sauce portion if you prefer more gravy. Â Recipe Source â€“ adapted fromÂ Hawkersâ€™ Flair Simplified [modified]Ingredients600 gm spare ribs â€“ cut into pieces1 tbsp toasted sesame seedsMarinadeÂ½ tsp saltÂ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda1 egg1 tbsp plain flour1 tbsp corn flour1 tbsp rose wine3 tbsp waterSauce  [combined]1 Â½ tbsp sugar2 tbsp black vinegar2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp Worcester sauceÂ½ tbsp chilli sauce3 tbsp waterCombine spare ribs with marinade and mix well.  Marinate for at least 3 hours or overnight.Deep fry spare ribs in hot oil for about 7 minutes or golden brown [you can pan fry the ribs in a non-stick pan].  Dish and drain.Remove excess oil.  Pour sauce into sauce pan, bring to boil.  Add in the fried ribs, mix well to coat ribs with sauce.Sprinkle sesame seeds and dish up to serve.This post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Bitter Gourd Omelette
text: Ever sinceknowing how to prevent bitter gourd from being too bitter, I started to enjoyeating bitter gourd.Â  This friedbitter gourd omelette is a very easy dish to prepare and I was happy that myhubby likes it.Â  Even my niece enjoysthis vegetable which most young people may not fancy at all.I should have cooked the whole portion which uses 4 eggs, then we didn't have to fight for it.RecipeSource â€“ Hawkersâ€™ Fair Simplified [modified]Ingredients[serves3]Â½bittergourd [about 200 gm] â€“ seeded and white pith scrapped clean â€“ thinlyslicedSalt totaste1 tbspchopped garlic2 tbspoilCombineTogether2 eggs Â½ tspsaltÂ½ tbsplight soy sauceDash ofpepper and chicken stock granulesHeatoil in a non-stick wok, add in chopped garlic and bitter gourd to fry with saltuntil soft.Spreadout the fried bitter gourd into a thin layer, then pour in the egg mixture in a circular patternto cover the vegetable.Leaveto fry until the set.Flipit over and continue to fry until golden brown.Dishup to serve.This post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Braised Bitter Gourd With Chicken
text: Tasty, easy, homely dish that is good with rice or porridge. Â My mother in-law used to cook this dish but I always avoid eating it dish, thinking that the bitter gourd is bitter and the meat could be bitter too. Â But, I know I was wrong after cooking this dish.This dish tasted good, the chicken meat and bitter gourd aren't that bitter as I thought.The original recipe uses chicken thighs but with chicken wings is as good. Tips - To prevent the bitter gourd from been too bitter, scrap off the inner white pith clean.This dish is savoury, slight bitterness that complements well with the sweetness of the chicken meat and sauce.Recipe Source â€“ Hawkersâ€™ Fair Simplified [modified]IngredientsÂ½ bittergourd [about 200 gm] â€“ seeded and white pith removed, cut into thick strips50 gm carrot â€“ cut thick strips10 slices of ginger3 chicken wings â€“ cut into bite size pieces or use chicken thigh200 ml waterOil for fryingSeasoning1Â tsp sugar1 tsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp shaoxing wine1 tbsp fermented black beans â€“ rinsed or fermented soy beans [taucheong]Heat some oil in a non-stick pan, sautÃ© bitter gourd and carrots for several minutes.  Dish up.Using the same wok, pan fry chicken wings until brown.  Push aside.  Add in ginger to fry until fragrant, then add in fermented black beans.  Stir fry to mix.Add in the seasoning and return the bitter gourd to wok.Stir fry to mix well. Add in water, bring to boil, taste to adjust seasoning.Simmer until chicken and bittergourd are tender and sauce is thick.Dish up to serve with rice or porridge.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess WanabeThis post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Palm Sugar Fatt Koh [æ¤°ç³–å‘ç³•]
text: As mentioned in my earlier post onÂ EZ Smiling Fatt Koh, I said I will be trying the gula melaka flavour fatt koh. Â I did this over the weekend for Ching Ming.This recipe works well too with palm sugar. Â I was very happy seeing the smiling kuihs in the steaming tray when I removed the cover. Â OMG, these are definitely very presentable.Â Verdict - these huat kuihs are soft, moist and aromatic. Â The sweetness is just nice. Â This recipe is a keeper. Â No yeast, ENO or proofing etc....needed.Recipe Source -Â æ¸©é¦¨å°åŽ¨Â [Rachel]Ingredient[makes 12 cupcakes]250 gm self raising flour1 tsp double action baking powder140 gm palm sugar [gula melaka]250 ml waterÂ 2 pandan leaves - washed and knotted1 egg - lightly beaten50 gm melted butter or corn oilBoil pandan leaves with water and palm sugar until fragrant and sugar dissolves.  Remove from heat, set aside to cool.  Discard the pandan leaves and the syrup.Lightly beat the egg.Sieve flour and baking powder into a mixing bowl. Â Make a well in the centre.Add in palm sugar mixture, egg and melted butter.Mix well to combine. Â  The batter is thick and smooth.Scoop batter into a baking tray lined with paper cases until 95% full.Steam over high heat for 15-20 minutes or until skewer when inserted comes out clean. Â Remove to cool or serve immediately.

title: Nyonya Kapitan Chicken Curry
text: I must say there are endless varieties of curry chicken and I can't remember how many I have tried and still many more that I haven't tried. Â Anyway, I can only do one at a time so as not to be too overwhelming for the tummy and everyone.This one is a longoutstanding dish which I had bookmarked from Amieâ€™s Little Kitchen and intend to cook.Â Â  Again, it is the sudden craving for home-cookedcurry with home-made paste that prompted me to cook this curry.Just foryour information, I cooked only half a portion of this recipe cosâ€™ my family issmall and we donâ€™t want to overeat or have too much leftovers.Â Thereare so many yummy dishes waiting to be tried but do feel free to cook the fullportion if you have a big family or would like to store some for later serving.Preparationis not difficult.Â  You can always preparethe curry paste in advance which is what I did and canÂ cook this curry anytime you wish too.Verdictâ€“Â  aromatic, spicy, tasty kapitan currythat is not too savoury, sweet or sourish.Â Tasted good, the gravy is thick and smooth.Â  Chicken is just cooked to tender and stillhas a bite to bring out its sweetness.Â Â Served with rice or even bread is definitely Yum Yum.Â  I served this curry with Tumeric Rice. Â My hubby said it's good curry and gave a Thumbs Up.Â RecipeSource â€“ Amie's Little KitchenIngredientsFor the Curry Paste [blend and mix together]15shallots4 pipsgarlic3 stalkslemongrass5 redchillies10 driedchillies3candlenutsÂ¼ tbspbelacanÂ½ inchturmeric ginger [replaced with 1 tsp turmeric powder]OtherIngredients1chicken â€“ cut into 12 pieces4 tbspoil1 inchgalangal â€“ sliced or keep whole4-6kaffir lime leaves â€“ half, quartered or shredded2 cupswater2 tbspthick coconut milk Asqueeze of limeSeasoningÂ½ tspsalt to taste [can add some light soy sauce for taste]Â½ tbsppalm sugar or brown sugarHeat  oil in wok, fry curry paste,  galangal and Â½ kaffir lime leaves until fragrant or oil separates.Add chicken, fry until well mixed.  Add in water and bring to boil until chicken is tender.Add in coconut milk and seasoning to taste.Â Continue to boil until gravy is thick.Off heat, add in balance kaffir lime leaves and squeeze of lime.Serve with rice or tumeric rice.TumericÂ  Rice1 cuprice â€“ washed, rinsed and drain3-4shallots â€“ peeled and slicedA fewslices of gingerA fewcloves1-2cardamon1 tspsalt1 tsp turmericpowderÂ Enough waterto cook riceMix all ingredients together. Â Cook in a rice cooker or steam in steaming tray for 30 minutes. Â Rest 5-10 minutes before fluffing up to serve with Kapitan Chicken Curry.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess Wanabe

title: Chicken with Coriander and Chilli Padi Dressing
text: Another delicious, tasty and spicy white cut chicken slightly different from my previous post onÂ Thai Style White Cut Chicken.Similarly, this Â can be prepared from leftover boiled chicken [pak cham kai] or cook chicken as per recipe. Â  Specially good way to clear off the Pak Cham Kai offered during ancestor worship by many who observes the Taoist faith. Â The original recipe uses blanched pork belly.Â Verdict - fragrant peanut butter, spicy and savoury sauce white cut chicken.Recipe Source - Yum Yum Magazine No. 67 with modificationsIngredients[serves 4-6]2 chicken whole legs [I used half chicken]1.5 litres water50 gm ginger - bruised5 pips garlic - bruised2 stalks spring onion1/4 tbsp saltSauce - Mixed1-2 Â tbsp peanut butter4-5 cili padi - chopped1-2 stalks spring onions - chopped1-2 stalks coriander leaves - chopped2-3 kaffir lime leaves - finely shredded [optional]2 tbsp light soy sauceÂ Â Â Â Bring water to boil with ginger, garlic, spring onions and salt.Add in the chicken, cover and bring to boil again. Â Off heat and leave the chicken in the pot for 45 minutes.Remove chicken and immerse in a basin of ice cold water for 5 minutes.Dish up and drain. Â Debone chicken Â and cut into bite size pieces. Â Place on serving platter.Drizzle the sauce over and serve.This post is linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursI'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess Wanabe

title: Coca Cola Chicken
text: This Coca Cola Chicken was cooked sometime after the Chinese New Year when there were many cans of carbonated drinks left over. Â Since I don't drink much of carbonated drinks, I used it to cook this popular chicken dish upon request of the young gal at home.I should have used the Coca Cola to cook this dish during Chinese New Year cos' it was really easy yet the outcome was very satisfactory. Â Yummy-licious dish using chicken wings or chicken thighs [preferably with some skin on].Ingredients3 chicken thighs - cut bite size pieces or 6 chicken wings1-2 tbsp light soy sauce to taste1-2 tsp dark soy sauce2-3 cloves garlic - peeled and bruised [optional - I omit]1 can regular Coca Cola1 tsp sesame oil [optional- I omit]Marinate the chicken thighs with some salt and sesame oil for 15 minutes.Â Heat up a non-stick pan, pan fry the chicken pieces until slightly brown.Â Add light soy sauce, dark soy sauce and pour in the Coke. Add garlic if using.Â Bring to boil, and taste to adjust seasoning. Lower heat to simmer for 20 minutes or until sauce is thick and chicken is cooked through.Stir once in awhile to ensure the chicken pieces are well coated with the braising sauce.Â Dish up to serve.Isn't this an easy way to cook chicken?  Yet so tasty with rice.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - ChickenÂ organised byÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana ofÂ Domestic Goddess Wanabe

title: Eight Treasure Tonic Soup
text: A tasty, delicious soup that is not difficult to cook at all. Â Most of the ingredients are easily available in the house.Verdict - A tasty soup with 8 ingredients and the quantity required can be estimated according to own preference.Recipe Source - Yum Yum Magazine No. 89 [slightly modified the quantity]Ingredients[serves 4-5]1 chicken whole leg or 2 chicken thigh - cut into pieces - blanch in hot water, drain3 chicken feet [I omit] - blanch in hot water, drain1500 ml Â water70 gm peanuts - soak until soft30 gm soy beans - soak until soft1 small piece preserved turnip [da tou cai] - sliced and soaked3-4 dried mussels - washed and soaked for 10 minutes, drain10 seedless red dates1 flower white fungus - soaked1 small carrot - peeled and sliced or cut into chunks1 tbsp medlar seeds [goji]salt and pepper to tasteBring water to boil. Â Add in all the ingredients except chicken, carrot and goji. Â Return to boil, then lower heat to simmer for about 15 minutes or until nuts and beans are soft.Add in chicken and carrots, simmer until ingredients are cooked.Lastly add in goji and seasoning to taste.Serve hot.This post is linked to Cook Your Books Event #22 [April 2015]Â hosted by JoyceÂ of Kitchen FlavoursI'm submitting this post to Little Thumbs Up Event [April 2015] Theme - Chicken organised by Bake for Happy Kids and My Little Favourite DIY, and hosted by Diana of Domestic Goddess Wanabe

title: Nyonya Heh Kean [Prawn Fritters]
text: This isa dish we used to enjoy when we were young.Â At that time, so long as we get to eat these, there is no questionaboutÂ  whether the fritters are crispy orstays crispy when cooled.Â  This isbecause we donâ€™t wait until they are cooled, all were gone fast even before my mom cleans up the wok. We were so eager to enjoy these fritters when it is piping hot and just didn't bother to take any photos on the intersection of these fritters.Foundthis simple prawn fritters recipe in Nyonya Flavours.Â  The batter tasted good and itâ€™s crispy on theoutside.Â  I find this batter good cosâ€™ itis crispy yet still has a bite, not like those which are crispy, crunchy buthard that it hurts when you bite at it. Â Nice.Â  Now I have a reliable batter recipe to fryprawn fritters [heh kean].RecipeSource â€“ Nyonya FlavoursIngredients250 gmmedium or big size prawns â€“ shelled and deveinedEnough oilfor deep frying [about 1 cup]BatterIngredients 100 gmself-raising flour25 gmcornflourÂ¼ tspsalt1/8 tsppepper150 mlwaterCombinethe batter ingredients in a mixing bowl and blend until smooth.Addin the prawns and stir to mix well.Heatoil in a wok orÂ  pan over mediumheat.Â  When oil is hot, scoop atablespoon of the prawn batter and drop it into the oil.Â  Repeat to fill the wok or pan.Fryuntil the fritters are puffy and golden brown.Dishout and drain on absorbent paper.Serveimmediately with chilli sauce.Â I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: EZ Smiling Fatt Koh [å‘ç³•]
text: I was never confident when coming to making steamed smiling kuih ['Fatt Koh' or 'Huat Kuih']. Â Afraid that they may 'smile' at me when I opened up the steamer.Anyway, I came across several postings by blogger friends, thus linking this post toÂ éƒ‘æ…§èŠ¬Â andÂ Guai Shu ShuÂ who had shared similar recipes.This recipe is adapted from their posts but with some changes. Â Since I was trying it to see if the kuihs really smiled, I didn't made them pandan or gula melaka flavour. Â Make a well in the centre.Add in sugar mixture, egg and melted butter.Mix to combine. Â Divide batter into 3 portions.Add colouring of your choice to each portion.Scoop batter into a baking tray lined with paper cases until 95% full.Steam over high heat for 15-20 minutes or until skewer Â when inserted comes out clean. title: CARROT MOCK GOLDFISH PAUS
text: Back from holiday and enjoyed too much of good food.Here is another pau recipe which I tried from the recipe book below.These paus turned out well and looks so cute with natural yellow colouring from carrots.Verdict - the paus are soft, moist and chewy. Â You can use any kind of store bought sweet paste filling or make your own but you don't really need much filling for these paus.Recipe Source - Y3K Book on Paus by Coco KongIngredients[makes 14-16 paus, dough weighs 500 gm]250 gm pau flour1 tsp double action baking powder20 gm icing sugar [original uses 40 gm]1 tsp yeast1 small carrot blend with 130 ml water - strained20 gm shortening200 gm lotus paste [I used Pandan lotus paste] about 15 gm]some red cherries - cut small bitsFor The Skin - combine pau flour, baking powder, icing sugar and yeast.Add in the carrot juice and knead until soft, then add in the shortening. Â Continue to knead until soft and smooth. Â Cover to rest for 30 minutes.Divide dough into 14 or 16 portions. Â Shape into balls.To Shape Paus - Wrap in a portion of the lotus paste. Use your thumb nail and index finger to join up the 2 edges. Â Turn the tail end outwards, use a pincer to shape out like a fish-like dough.Place cherries on the other end 2 sides acting like fish eyes.Place on parchment paper, cover to proof for 30-40 minutes after making the last pau.Steam over high heat for 10 minutes or cooked through.Â I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Kuih Sago
text: A kuih made of Â sago, commonly seen in kuih shops, Malay snack stalls or gatherings that nevertheless delicious. Â The soft, chewy texture, sweet and a little savoury taste as you bite at it, makes you reach for another piece.This sago kuih can be in any colours or combination of colours but I think the most crucial ingredient is the grated white coconut that makes it tempting.I have seen many recipes on this kuih and finally found one at Peng's Kitchen which basically is very easy yet the outcome is good. Â However, I modified slightly to make it even easier.Recipe Source -Â Peng's KitchenÂ [modified]Ingredients300 gm sago200 gm sugar [I used 180 gm]600 ml waterÂ 2 tbsp pandan juice [can omit and replace with a drop of green colouring]1 tsp pandan paste [can omit if you use pandan water]*1 tsp strawberry paste [can omit and replace with a drop of Â pink colouring]100 gm grated coconut + 100 gm for coating50 gm gula melaka - choppedÂ 1/4 tsp saltÂ * boil several blades of pandan leaves with the water and use it to cook the sagoGrease a 7" square pan and lined with plastic sheet. Grease lightly again. Set aside. I used the steaming tray of my electric steamer.Boil sugar and water in a medium pot or non-stick pan. Add in sago can cook till semi-transparent, stirring frequently. Note - theliquid will all be absorbed by the sago and the mixture will be thick.Scoop 2- 4 tbsp of the cooked sago and mix with the grated coconut, salt and gula melaka. Â Set aside.Divide the remaining into 2 portions.Â Mix one portion with strawberry paste [or pink colouring] and the other portion with pandan juice/pandan paste or green colouring.Pour the pink mixture into the pan and steam for 15 minutes or until clear.Â Spread the gula melaka mixture over steamed sago, then top up with the green sago mixture over and continue to steam for another 25 minutes or until sago is clearCool completely before unmoulding.Â Smear a knife with oil [to prevent sticking] and cut kuih into slices. Coat with extra grated coconut and serve.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone March 2015 Event Theme: My Favourite KuihÂ by Fion of Xuanhommama and co-host by Joceline of Butter, Flour and Me

title: Steamed Minced Meat With Salted Eggs
text: An easy steamed meat dish which is common in most Chinese homes and economy food stalls.The original recipe uses 3 types of eggs. Since Iâ€™m cooking a smaller portion, I omit the century egg. Â This dish is still tasty and good served with rice for dinner. Here, Iâ€™m sharing the original recipe for your easy reference.Recipe Source â€“ Hawkersâ€™ Flair SimplifiedÂ Ingredients50 gm minced meat3 eggs â€“ lightly beaten1 century egg - diced1 salted egg yolk â€“ diced1 salted egg white150 ml hot waterÂ½ tsp saltDash of pepper and chicken stock granulesSome chopped  spring onionsSome fried crispy garlic1 tsp light soy sauceCombine meat, eggs, seasoning and water in a bowl.  Mix well.Pour into a 8 inch round steaming tray.Steam at medium heat for about 10 minutes or until set.Remove, sprinkle spring onions, fried garlic and light soy sauce.This will be my last for the time being as I will be away for a short vocation until end month.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Banana Bread
text: This banana bread was made from the bananas given to me by my mother in-law when I was at her place.  She bought lots of fruits and we couldnâ€™t finish it during our stay there.   She let us â€˜ta pauâ€™ lots of it cosâ€™ there will be no one around to finish eating them after we left.With so much fruits in the fridge and the bananas getting over-ripe, I had to quickly bake this banana bread instead of letting it rot away.It tasted good, not too sweet but fragrant.  I reduced a big portion of the sugar because these bananas itself is very sweet.Â The bread is moist but the texture is quite compact not like the cake.Â Recipe Source â€“ At Home With Amy Beh [slightly modified]Ingredients[loaf tin 18 x 10 x 10 cm]275 gm over-ripe bananas [I used pisang awak]80 gm castor sugar [original uses 250 gm]3 medium size eggs350 gm plain flourÂ¾ tbsp bicarbonate of soda100 ml corn oilMix together100 ml milk + Â¼ tsp saltÂ Â Â Â Grease sides of loaf tin and sprinkle some flour over it.  Shake off excess flour. Â The bread will have crispy and brown sides.Sieve flour and bicarbonate of soda.  Set aside.Mix milk and salt, set aside.In a mixing bowl, mash bananas, add in sugar and beat well until sugar had dissolved.Add in eggs, one at a time and beat well after each addition on medium high speed.  Drizzle in the milk and beat at low speed as you add it.  Then drizzle in the corn oil and blend well.Fold in the flour in batches.  Mix well to get a smooth batter.Pour batter into loaf tin.  Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 10 minutes then reduce the heat to 150 degrees C and continue to bake for 50 minutes or until bread is done when tested with a skewer.Notes:For variety, add 50 gm chopped toasted walnuts after folding in the flour [I omit]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursI'm also submitting this post to Little Thumbs Up Event on BananasÂ hosted by Faeez of Bitter Sweet Spicy

title: Nyonya Bee Koh [Glutinous Rice Kuih]
text: This is asecond Bee Koh recipe Iâ€™m sharing in this blog.Â The first recipe Nyonya Bee Koh [Kuih Pulut]Â  that I used was a good recipe. Came across this recipe which is quite similar from Nyonya Flavours. Â The variance is probably the quantity. Here, I substituted the coconut milk with powdered coconut milk with the intention toshare the information and encourage readers to make this kuih even when theycanâ€™t find fresh coconut milk in their vicinity or so long as they have some packets coconut milk in their kitchen.Just mix the powdered coconut milk according topacking instructions.Â For this recipe,you need 2 packets to obtain 500 ml thick coconut milk.The BeeKoh turns out well and tasted good too.Â Those we ate it didnâ€™t notice the difference in taste eventhough thecoconut milk used is different.Transformed into this look as prayer item to Jade EmperorRecipeSource â€“ adapted fromÂ Nyonya Flavours [modified]Ingredients500 gmglutinous rice â€“ washed, soaked overnight450 gmglucose [I reduced to 400 gm]1 tbspliquid glucose [glucose syrup]500 mlthick coconut milk [from 1 grated coconut]Drainthe soaked rice and steam over high heat until cooked [about 40 minutes].Stirthe sugar, liquid glucose and coconut milk in a wok over low fire until sugardissolves.Strainand return syrup mixture to the saucepan.Addin the steamed glutinous rice.Â  Stir witha wooden spatula until mixture thickens [about 20 minutes].Pourinto lightly greased plates or trays.Â Press down with a small piece of greased banana leaf or back of a spoonto compact the rice.Adda little thick coconut milk [I omit this step].Coolbefore cutting.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursI'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone March 2015 Event Theme: My Favourite KuihÂ by Fion ofÂ XuanhommamaÂ Â and co-host by Joceline of Butter, Flour and Me

title: Fried Fish with Lum Chut
text: Lum Chut is a Peranakan style dipping sauce for grilled or fried fish. This dipping sauce is sourish, sweet, a little spicy and aromatic which is very appetising. Â Simply good to serve with any grilled or fried fish.I prepared this sauce to serve with fried Ikan Senangin. The original recipe uses this Lum Chut sauce for grilled Mackerel or Kembung fish but with this fried fish, it is as yummy-licious.Recipe Source â€“ Nyonya Flavours [modified]Ingredients2 whole hard-tail Mackerel or Kembung fish [I used Ikan Senangin]Oil for fryingLum Chut Dipping Sauce50 gm [5] shallots â€“ sliced thinly1 tbsp sugar to taste10 gm belacan â€“ toasted1 tbsp sambal belacan1 tbsp light soy sauce50 gm [5] small calamansi limes â€“ juicedTo make the Lum Chut Sauce â€“ combine all the sauce ingredients in a bowl. Blend with a fork until sugar dissolves and sauce is smooth. Set aside.Heat oil in wok, pan fry fish until golden brown or cooked through.Serve immediately with Lum Chut Dipping Sauce.Â Very easy, isn't?I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Nyonya Chien Chuan Hu [Fried Fish With Tau Cheong]
text: A very common fish dish in most Chinese families especially Peranakan homes.  This fish dish is cooked with preserved soy bean paste [tau cheong] and ginger. Good to serve with porridge or rice.At home, we called this dish Tau Cheong Hu or Chien Chuan Hu which is cooked according to our family way. Â But this one Â differs slightly from my family version but I find it good as the sauce tasted perfect.I cooked this dish with one half of the Ikan Senangin from my hubbyâ€™s fishing trip.   The other half was pan-fried and served with Lum Chut Sauce [see next post].  I had to cook the fish in 2 different ways/flavours because it was a  big fish which I had to halve it for easier frying.Since I love fried tofu with preserved soy bean paste, I added it to this dish. Â You can omit the tofu. Â For this dish, black promfret is a good choice.Recipe Source â€“ Nyonya Flavours [modified]Ingredients300 gm Kurau fish [I used half Ikan Senangin]Enough oil for fryingIngredients for Gravy1 tbsp oil20 gm ginger â€“ cut thin shreds2 cloves garlic â€“ sliced1 red chilli â€“ seeded and cut stripsÂ½ tbsp preserved soybean paste [tau cheong]Â½ tsp sugar1 tsp light soy sauce125 ml waterÂ½ tsp cornflour mixed with 2 tbsp waterSome spring onions â€“ cut 1 inch lengths [optional]Pan fry fish with oil over medium heat until golden brown.  Dish up on serving platter.Remove excess oil, leave 1 tbsp in wok to sautÃ© ginger and garlic until golden.Add in soy bean paste and fry until fragrant.Add in light soy sauce, sugar and water.  Bring to boil for several seconds.Thicken with cornflour mix.  Add in chilli and spring onions.Pour sauce over fried fish.  Serve with rice or porridge.I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Sour Mustard and Spicy Fish
text: Another lovely fish dish quite similar to Teochew Steamed Fish but using braising method. Saw this recipe from a food magazine.Again cooked with fresh fish from my hubbyâ€™s fishing trip, itâ€™s reallyÂ tasty and sweet. The sauce is sourish and savoury that is so tasty spread over steaming hot rice or slurp as a soup.Â Recipe Source â€“ Yum Yum Magazine No. 94 [slightly modified]Ingredients1 whole fish [about 500-700 gm] â€“ scaled and cleaned5 dried chillies â€“ cut 1 inch lengthsÂ 100 gm kiam chye [preserved mustard leaves] â€“ soaked and shreddedSome shredded carrot100 gm minced meat1 sour plum [optional]1 tbsp chopped gingerÂ 1 tbsp chopped garlicSome chopped spring onions and coriander leavesÂ½ tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp light soy sauceSalt to tasteDash of sesame seed oilDash of pepper500 ml water or moreDry fry mustard leaves for several seconds in wok.  Push aside.Add in oil, sautÃ© ginger and garlic until aromatic, add in dried chillies then the minced meat.  Stir fry to combine all the fried ingredients.Add in water and seasoning.   Bring to boil and taste to adjust seasoning. Â  Lower heat to cook for 5-10 minutes.Slide in the fish, cover to cook for another 10 minutes or until fish is cooked through.Sprinkle chopped spring onions and coriander leaves.Serve immediately.I'm sharing this post with Cook Your Books Event #21 [March 2015]Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Steamed Fish With Lemon and Sour Plum
text: This steamed fish recipe was shared by a friend.  According to her, it is quite similar to Teochew style steamed fish minus several ingredients like mushrooms, pork and tofu.With less ingredients, this steamed fish dish is nevertheless tasty.  Cooked specially with freshly caught fish from my hubbyâ€™s fishing trip, it is awesome. Â Enjoyed every bit of the sweet freshness of the fish with the sourish and savoury sauce.The next few posts that I'll be sharing are all fish dishes cooked using freshly caught fishes from my hubby's fishing trip. Â These fishes were caught before Chinese New Year and we had a good time enjoying them even before the new year when others are going after fishes for CNY steamboat, hehehe!. Â Thanks to you my dear, hubby for bringing home such lovely fishes for us.Ingredients1 whole fish â€“ cleaned and keep whole2-3 sour plumsLemon juice to tasteDash of shaoxing wine2-3 stalks spring onions â€“ cleaned and knottedSome sliced spring onions and coriander leavesStuff spring onions into the fish bladder.Spread sour plum over fish.Steamed over high heat for 10 minutes or until cooked through.Remove from heat, pour in lemon juice and shaoxing wine.Garnish with chopped spring onions and coriander leaves.Serve immediately while still hot.Malay Style Fish CurryThis curry was easy to cook and so good with fresh fish

title: Choc Chips Orange Cupcakes
text: Tasty and easy to bake orange flavoured cupcakes with choc chips.  Citrus flavor of this buttery cupcake blends well with the sweet choc chips.Love the way these cupcakes rose - beautifully. Â These would be good for gatherings and small parties.I reduced the sugar and the sweetness is just nice for me cos' the choc chips are bitter sweet too.Recipe Source â€“ No Frills [slightly modified]Ingredients[makes 24 cupcakes]220 gm  butter150 gm castor sugar  [can reduced to 130-140 gm]Zest of 2 oranges4 eggs280 gm plain flour â€“ sifted with baking powder1 tsp baking powderA pinch of salt60 ml orange juice100 gm choc chipsCream butter and sugar until creamy, light and fluffy.Beat in the eggs, one at a time, beat well after each addition.Fold in the flour using lowest speed or with spatula, alternating with orange juice.Fold in the choc chips.Spoon batter into cupcake cases on patty tins until 90% full.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C on middle rack for 20 minutes or until golden brown and done.Remove to cool on wire rack.This post is linked to "Little Thumbs Up" February 2015 Event [Cocoa] organised by Zoe ofÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ and Doreen ofÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Grace ofÂ Life can be Simple.

title: All In One Belanda Sauce Eggs
text: A easy dish to cook up whenever you wish to add an extra dish on the dinner table. Â Simple and easily available ingredients in any kitchen.This issimilar to the Nyonya Belanda Hu [Fish]Â which I cooked earlier. Â My brother in-law says that eggs can be cooked this way Â instead of fish.SinceIâ€™m using a flat base non stick wok, I fried the eggs all at the same time thenbraisedÂ  them with the sauce.Â  Very easy way to cook and less oily.The photos don't look good but the dish tasted good. Â Reason is all because I cooked this in a jiffy....Ingredients[serves3]3 eggs6shallots â€“ thinly sliced3 garlicâ€“ thinly sliced1 [3 cm]piece cinnamon stickA pinchof tamarind past mixed with 150 ml waterSomeshredded red chilli and spring onions1 tbspsugarÂ½ -1 tspsalt to taste1 tbspoilHeatoil in a non-stick wok.Â  Saute shallotsand garlic until crispy.Â  Dish up.Usethe oil to fry the eggs together until firm up.Â Pour in the tamarind juice and add the seasoning and cinnamon stick.Bringto boil and simmer until sauce is fragrant.Â Taste to adjust seasoning.Addin the chilli and spring onions.Dishup to serve with rice.

title: Chinese Cabbage, Prawns and Egg Soup
text: One of my easy and  quick cook soup with simple ingredients yet it is tasty enough for serving on busy days.  Suitable for all ages in the family, too.I cooked this soup during the time when I was suffering from sensitive teeth and needs to eat really soft vegetables. Â Cooked this again yesterday and I'm sharing it here as my last posting before CNY. Â Going back to my in-law's place Â tomorrow and from then on is very busy time for me till after CNY.The soup is tasty with the Chinese cabbage and prawns. The beaten egg brings the cabbages together. Â Nice.Ingredients[serves 2-3]200 gm Chinese cabbage [pak choy] â€“ rinsed and cut thin shreds1 small carrot â€“ peeled and shredded1 egg â€“ lightly beaten with some pepper and light soy sauce to taste100 â€“ 150 gm prawns â€“ shelled with tails intactÂ½ tsp salt and Â½ tsp chicken stock granules to tasteDash of pepper and sesame seed oilSome fried crispy garlic oilSome chopped spring onions750 ml waterBring water to boil in a soup pot or claypot.  Add in Chinese cabbage and carrots.  Let it boil and cooked until soft or crunchy according to own preference.Add in the seasoning to taste, then add in the prawns to cook.Once prawns are cooked, pour in the beaten egg in a circular pattern.  Do Not Stir, just let it cook for 1-2 minutes or until cooked.Off heat and serve hot. Â Garnish with spring onions and fried crispy garlic.Â HAPPY, PROSPEROUS, HEALTHY ANDÂ SAFE CHINESE NEW YEARÂ TO ALLÂ CHINESE FRIENDS, VISITORS, FELLOW BLOGGERSÂ ANDÂ ALL CELEBRATINGÂ CHINESE NEW YEAR.Â Â HAPPY HOLIDAYS TO ALLÂ WHO ARE ON HOLIDAY DURING THIS TIME.

title: Pan Fried Salmon With Tasty Onion Salad
text: Whenever fresh fish are not available in the wet markets, I will look for salmon blocks in the supermarkets. At times, they are reasonably cheap and is a good option.Â  Bought several pieces to cook this simple dish which costs less than RM 10.00.Just pan fry the salmon blocks until brown and serve with an easy onion/carrot salsa. I didn't add any oil to the salsa. Hmmm.....isn't this dish yummy at the dinner table.Ingredients[serves 3]3 pieces of salmon blocks â€“ seasoned light with some saltOnion/Carrot Salad1 white onion â€“ thinly sliced1 small carrot â€“ shredded1 tbsp plum sauce1 tbsp chilli sauce2 tbsp lime juice1 tbsp sugarÂ¼ tsp saltSome chopped corianderSome toasted sesame seedsSoaked shredded onion and carrot in ice cold water.  Drain in colander.Combine the salad ingredients in a bowl.  Add in the onions, carrot and coriander.Mix well and sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds.  Set aside.Heat up a non-stick wok with minimal oil.  Pan fry salmon pieces until brown and cooked.Dish up on serving platter, serve with salad and a sprinkle of toasted sesame seeds.

title: Fried Bean Curd in Black Bean Sauce
text: Chinese New Year around the corner and it's expected that lots of dishes will be meaty. Â A simple dish like this would be better for our tummy before CNY.Surprisingly good and tasty dish with simple ingredients - soft tofu and fermented black beans.This is a homey dish, good with rice and easy to cook. The original recipe uses fish balls [I don't buy fish balls especially the springy and pure white coloured ones] so I replaced it with tofu puffs which soaks up the sauce. Â You can cook this dish just with tofu.Recipe Source - Hawker Fair Simplified [modified]Ingredients2 pieces soft beancurd [tofu] - cut into thick slicesa few tofu puffs - rinsed and sliced [optional]1 tbsp chopped garlic1 tbsp chopped ginger1 tbsp fermented black beans - rinsed, drained and chopped1 red chilli - seeded and chopped1 stalk spring onion - choppedsome oil for fryingSeasoning1 tbsp each of oyster sauce and light soy sauce1 tsp sugar100 ml water1 tbsp cornflour water for thickeningHeat oil in a non-stick pan, pan fry tofu slices until golden on both sides. Dish and drain.Use the same pan,saute chopped garlic, ginger and red chilli until fragrant. Add in black beans. Â Stir to mix. Â Add in tofu puffs.Add in seasoning and water. Â Bring to boil. Â Return the fried tofu pieces to mix with sauce.Thicken with cornstarch water. Â Dish up to serve with rice. Â Garnish with spring onions or chopped Chinese celery

title: Meatball and Taukee Soup
text: This is a very homey soup that is easy and simple to prepare yet good with rice for dinner.It is a quick cook soup that takes only minutes.My mother in-law gave me some taukee which she told me is good quality ones.  These days, taukee could be quite rubbery after cooking but this one isnâ€™t.The soup turns out so good with just 2 main ingredients.  This soup is so easy to cook and I only estimate â€˜agak-agakâ€™  the quantity of the ingredients just enough for 3 persons.I added light soy sauce for colour and to add some sweetness to the soup.IngredientsÂ [serves 2]100 gm pork minced with some chopped garlic and preserved vegetables â€˜tung choiâ€™Several sticks of the taukee [beancurd sticks]  â€“ soaked and cut into 2 inch lengthsSome tung choi â€“ rinsedLight soy sauce, salt and pepper to taste750 ml waterMarinate minced meat with some pepper, dash of sesame oil and cornflour.  Mix well and shape into meat balls.Bring water to boil in a soup pot.  Add in the tung choi and boil for several minutes.Add in the meat balls to cook followed by the taukee.Let it boil for several minutes.  Add light soy sauce, salt and Â pepper to taste.Scoop up onto soup bowl, serve hot.

title: Chocolate Flavour Bread Loaf
text: Received a gift box of the Chocolate Flavour Instant Mix.  This is a vegan product and without preservative.  Made from organic ingredients, it consists of cocoa powder, red beans, pearl barley, brown rice, rock sugar, malt extract powder, natural vanilla powder and salt.  A sachet weighs 30 gm.   Was told that this product is given out to those affected during natural disasters when it is inconvenient to cook nutritious food.Since I wasnâ€™t drinking it, I used it to make this bread loaf.  Like my previous bread making, I used white coffee instant mix instead of wasting them.  So if you happen to have whatever instant beverage mix and not drinking it, do try to use them in bread making  rather than leaving them until the shelf life is over.Verdict â€“ the bread turns out soft, moist and chewy.  Tasted good and very aromatic.Ingredients350 gm bread flour70 gm superfine flour1 tsp cinnamon powder2 tbsp milk powder1 tbsp instant yeast50 gm sugarÂ½ tsp salt1 sachet [30gm] chocolate flavour instant mix dissolve with250 ml water hot water â€“ cooled1 egg40 gm butter40 gm raisins â€“ rinsedMix all the dry ingredients in a mixing bowl with a dough hook.  Add in the egg and cooled chocolate mix.  Knead until soft dough, add a little more water if it is too dry.Add in butter and continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic.Add in the raisins.  Mix until well combined.Shape into a ball, leave in the mixing bowl, cover to proof for 30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down and divide into 3 equal portions.  Shape into balls then roll each into a Swiss roll.Place in a greased and lined Pullmanâ€™s tin.  Cover to proof for at least an hour or until well risen.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes or until brown.Remove from oven and tin.  Leave to cool on wire rack before storing or serving.This post is also linked to "Little Thumbs Up" February 2015 Event [Cocoa] organised by Zoe ofÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ and Doreen ofÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Grace ofÂ Life can be Simple.

title: CNY 2015 - Honey Cornflakes [èœœç³–ç²Ÿç±³ç‰‡]
text: This is the simplest cornflakes cookies that I came across here [Spice Up My Kitchen] and even a novice like my niece could scoop them into the paper cups to bake.I made 3 portions of the original recipe and finished baking them very soon.Verdict - very aromatic and crispy cornflakes that aren't too sweet. Â I added some chocolate rice apart from the coloured rice.Ingredients[makes 172 pieces]150 gm butter [ç‰›æ²¹]6 tbsp honey [èœœç³–]450 gm cornflakes [ç²Ÿç±³ç‰‡]Other ingredientssome coloured icing rice [é€‚é‡ å½©è‰²ç³–]some chocolate ricesome small paper cupsMelt butter and add in honey and mix well,.Add in cornflakes, coloured icing rice and chocolate rice. Â Mix well.Spoon into small paper cups to the rim.Bake in pre-heated oven at 150 degree Celsius for 15 minutes.Remove and leave to cool on wire rack before storing in air-tight container.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme:Â My Homemade Cookies by Fion ofÂ XuanHom's MomÂ and co-host by VictoriaÂ Baking Into The EtherI'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In Flandersand co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery HouseI am also submitting this to the "Cook & Celebrate: CNY 2015" event hosted byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy Kids, co-hosted by Yen ofÂ Eat Your Heart OutÂ andÂ Diana of The Domestic Goddess Wannabe.

title: CNY 2015 - Sunflower Melon Seed Crisps
text: I baked Kuih Bangkit and remembered that Soke Hah had a recipe where I could use up some of the remaining egg whites.  Found this recipe of hers to make this crispy biscuit.Sorry Soke Hah, I have to replace pumpkin seeds with melon seeds cos' I have these available and not thinking of buying too much baking ingredients until I have finished using up those that I have in hand.Easy and quick to prepare and bake. The difficult part is just the spreading of the batter before baking.  Otherwise, the mixing and baking is easy and quick.Recipe for Pumpkin Sunflower CrispsÂ [here]Ingredients[makes about 50-60 crisps]2 egg whites about 60 gm - lightly beaten80 gm caster sugar2 tbsp or 1 oz melted butter50 gm plain flour75 gm pumpkin kernels [I used melon seeds]75 gm sunflower seeds1/4  tsp vanillaSift flour into a mixing bowl, add in sugar, mix well. Â Add in the seeds.Make a well in the centre, add in the melted butter, lightly beaten egg whites and vanilla.  Mix till well combined.Leave batter to rest for 30 minutes.Drop 1 level tsp of batter onto a parchment lined baking tray.  Using the back of the spoon spread thinly to any shape taking care not to overlap the seeds.Bake in a preheated oven @ 180 degrees C for 8 to 10 minutes on middle rack [taking care not to over-bake].Let cool in tray for a while before transferring onto a wire rack to cool completely.Store crisps in an air-tight cookie jar.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme:Â My Homemade CookiesÂ by Fion ofÂ XuanHom's MomÂ and co-host by VictoriaÂ Baking Into The EtherI'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In Flandersand co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery HouseI am also submitting this to the "Cook & Celebrate: CNY 2015" event hosted byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy Kids, co-hosted by Yen ofÂ Eat Your Heart OutÂ andÂ Diana of The Domestic Goddess Wannabe.

title: CNY 2015 - Cocoa Bubble Rice Cookies æ³¡æ³¡ç±³æ›²å¥‡
text: First time baking cookies with bubble rice after seeing them in Ann and DG's blog.No regrets giving it a try as these cookies turned out very crispy, crunchy and I like the choc chips in it. Â Not sweet at all too. Â I used the cocoa flavour bubble rice.As usual, these are for giveaways, the quantity here is double portion of the original recipe.Recipe adapted from [here] and [here]IngredientsMakes 185 pieces [double portion]260 gm butter120 gm castor sugar2 large eggs2 tsp vanilla extract340 gm plain flour1 tsp baking soda1/4 tsp salt160 gm rice bubbles (crispy rice)140 gm chocolate chipsCream butter and sugar till white and fluffy.Add in eggs one at a time and vanilla extract, beat well.Sift in flour, baking soda and salt and continue to mix well over low speed.Lastly pour in crispy rice and chocolate chips, fold well with a rubber spatula.Scoop chocolate mixture with a dessert spoon and drop onto a lined baking tray.Bake at preheated oven at 160 degrees C for about 20 minutes or until golden crisp.Cool down cookies and store in an airtight container.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme: My Homemade CookiesÂ by Fion ofÂ XuanHom's MomÂ and co-host by VictoriaÂ Baking Into The EtherI'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015Â hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In FlandersÂ and co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery HouseThis post is also linked to "Little Thumbs Up" February 2015 Event [Cocoa] organised by Zoe ofÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ and Doreen ofÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Grace ofÂ Life can be Simple.I am also submitting this to the "Cook & Celebrate: CNY 2015" event hosted byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy Kids, co-hosted by Yen ofÂ Eat Your Heart OutÂ andÂ Diana of The Domestic Goddess Wannabe.

title: CNY 2015 - Chocolate Marble German Cookies
text: Many blogger friends have baked this melt-in the mouth German Cookies for awhile. Â There were so many last year but I was attracted to the marbled ones shared by Ann Low of Anncoo JournalÂ which looks simple yet attractive.Like other cookie recipes, I baked a double portion to get enough to share with my siblings and mother in-law. Â Separately baked another portion for my neighbour when the first bake turned out to be so good.All in all, I ended up baking 4 portions of this recipe. Â Isn't it a bit too much, but they really are good.Verdict - lovely, lovely cookies that are so crispy, fine and aromatic. Â Taste perfect, melt in the mouth too. Â ThisÂ is my favourite kind of cookies. It's a keeper. Â Made some for my neighbour and she gave a Thumbs Up. Â Ingredients - Plain Portion[double portion in red - makes 210 pieces]125 gm butter [250 gm]40 gm icing sugar [80 gm] - sifted125 gm potato starch or corn starch [250 gm]80 gm plain flour [160 gm] - sifted twiceBeat butter and icing sugar till fluffy and lighter in color.Sift in potato starch and flour, mix to form a soft plain dough and set aside.Ingredients - Cocoa Portion125 gm butter [250 gm]40 gm icing sugar [80 gm] - sifted125 gm potato starch or corn starch [250 gm]20 gm cocoa powder [40 gm] - sifted twice60 gm plain flour [120 gm] - sifted twiceBeat butter and icing sugar till fluffy and lighter in color.Sift in potato starch, cocoa powder and plain flour, mix to form a soft chocolate dough.Divide plain and chocolate dough into 4 portions.Roll plain and chocolate dough separately into long strips. Using 1 tsp measuring spoon of plain and chocolate dough, wrap them around each other with your hand and place on a lined baking tray and gently press dough with your finger.Bake at preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 13-15 mins depending on the size of your cookies.Remove from oven, leave to cool completely on Â a wire rack and store in airtight container.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme: My Homemade CookiesÂ by Fion ofÂ XuanHom's MomÂ and co-host by VictoriaÂ Baking Into The EtherI'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015Â hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In FlandersÂ and co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery HouseThis post is also linked to "Little Thumbs Up" February 2015 Event [Cocoa] organised by Zoe ofÂ Bake for Happy KidsÂ and Doreen ofÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Grace ofÂ Life can be Simple.I am also submitting this to the "Cook & Celebrate: CNY 2015" event hosted byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy Kids, co-hosted by Yen ofÂ Eat Your Heart OutÂ andÂ Diana of The Domestic Goddess Wannabe.

title: Mixed Vegetables with Glass Noodles
text: This vegetable dish is a mixed vegetable dish with glass noodles.  The glass noodles are soft and soaks up the flavours of the vegetables.   This is not served as a noodle dish but more common with rice and the ingredients can varies according to own preference.Â Quite similar to Lou Han Chye but not exactly the same as this is a family style kind of dish very common in most Chinese Hokkien family home.  So here, Iâ€™m not giving the exact quantity of the ingredients used as you can mix and match them according to own preference.Some Chinese families will cook this vegetarian dish on the first day of Chinese New Year, too.Shredded pork belly and canned green peas can be added and this dish tasted even much better.IngredientsSome cabbage â€“ cut thin shredsSome carrots â€“ cut thin shredsSome black fungus â€“ cut thin shredsSome dried mushrooms â€“ soaked and cut thin stripsSome fresh foo peh â€“ cut thin stripsSome dried lily buds â€“ knotted and rinsedA small ball of glass noodles â€“ soak for 5 minutes, drainedSome chopped ginger and garlicOyster sauce, light soy sauce, chicken stock granules and pepper to tasteSome dark soy sauce for colourOil and sesame oilHeat oil in wok, sautÃ© chopped ginger and garlic until fragrant.  Add in mushrooms, black fungus,foo peh and dried lily buds. Â If using pork belly, fry it after garlic, then add the remaining ingredients.Stir fry to mix.  Add in cabbage and carrots, seasoning then water.  Bring to boil and cook until vegetables are soft.Lastly add in the glass noodles to cook until soft and gravy is reduced. Â Dish up to serve.I'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In FlandersÂ and co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery HouseI'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event January 2015 [Noodles and Pasta]Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ My Bare Cupboard

title: Steamed Fish With Fragrant Ginger Sauce
text: Notice how fresh this fish is? Â The flesh is firm and pure white. Freshly caught Garoupa from my hubby's fishing trip. Â Pity it isn't bigger.Â YummyÂ steamed fish with a simple, easy to prepare fragrant Â and tasty ginger sauce.Iâ€™m sharing the original recipe here.  The actual that I cooked is only half portion of the sauce as the fish is small [about 300 gm]. Very nice.The sauce is gingery and fragrant.  Goes well with the fresh fish.  I like the sauce very much and itâ€™s so easy to prepare. Â We were so eager to eat it right away, so no time for more photo taking, hehehe!I was told that this is a Cantonese style of steaming fish which should be suitable and a tasty steamed fish dish for Chinese New Year.Recipe Source - Hawker's Fair SimplifiedIngredients1 fish [about 500 gm] â€“ scaled and cleaned2 stalks of spring onions â€“ shreddedGinger Sauce100 gm fresh ginger â€“ skinned50 ml water1 tsp saltÂ½ -1 tsp sugar1 tsp oyster sauce1 tbsp shaoxing wine1-2 tbsp oilÂ½ tsp sesame oilDash of msg or chicken stock granules to taste1 tbsp cornflour water for thickeningÂ½ -1  tbsp fried garlic crisps and oilGinger Sauce â€“ put fresh ginger and water in a processor and blend until very fine.  Pour  into a small saucepan.   Add in the remaining sauce ingredients.   Bring to boil until fragrant then thicken with cornflour water.  Set aside.Place fish on a steaming plate.  Steam fish over high heat for 10-12 minutes [depending on the size of the fish] or until cooked through.Remove the fish, discard the water.  Pour ginger sauce over fish and sprinkle crispy fried garlic with the oil.  Garnish with spring onions.Serve immediately.I'm submitting this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #20Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursI'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015Hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In Flandersand co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery House

title: Fried Koay Teow [Fried Flat Rice Noodles]
text: This version of fried koay teow [Char Koay Teow] is a home-cooked version of Penang Char Koay Teow.   It is very tasty and can be easily prepared in your own kitchen. I didnâ€™t include clams cosâ€™ these days with contaminated sea water, it is best to avoid eating clams [si harm].The sauce ingredient is sufficient for 3 servings.  Just do some simple calculation if you are cooking a varied portion.  I used 600 gm koay teow cosâ€™ 450 gm isnâ€™t enough to fill my family membersâ€™ tummy for a meal, hehehe!.Â For nicer taste, it is advisable to fry one serving at a time.  Better â€˜Wok Heiâ€™ and you will enjoy a plate of fragrant 'char koay teow' in the comfort of your home. Â Moreover, it isn't as oily as from the hawker's stall. Â Lard can also be used for frying this noodle. Â Ingredients for Sauce[mix and bring to boil, set aside] - boiling is optional[3 servings]3 tsp premium oyster sauce2-3 tbsp fish sauce3 tsp dark soy sauceSalt and pepper to taste1 Â½ tsp sugar to taste3 tsp waterOther Ingredients[serves 3]450 gm fresh flat rice noodles [koay teow] â€“ loosened6-9 medium or big prawns â€“ shelled150 gm beansproutsA bunch of chives â€“ cut into 3 cm lengths1 Chinese sausage â€“ thinly sliced1 tbsp chopped garlic1 tbsp chai por â€“ rinsed and drained [optional]1-2 tbsp chilli paste [according to own taste]3 eggs [I used duck eggs]3 tbsp oilHeat a non-stick wok with oil, sautÃ© garlic and chai por [if using]  until fragrant.Â Add in prawns, followed by noodles.   Do not stir noodles, add in sauce ingredients and chilli paste.  Then lightly stir to mix well [best to use chopstick or edge of wok ladle].Push noodles aside, break in the eggs.  Cover with noodles and add beansprouts. Â  Give it a good stir to mix over high heat and until noodles are firm [slightly charred if you like] and fragrant.Lastly add in sausages and chives.Lightly stir to mix.Dish up to serve immediately.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event January 2015 [Noodles and Pasta]Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ My Bare Cupboard

title: CNY 2015 - Crispy Oatmeal Raisin Cookies
text: This cookie recipe was shared by Esther Lau of Copycake Kitchen in November 2013 which I had bookmarked to do cos' I like crispy and crunchy cookies. Too bad, due to an unforseen circumstance, I didn't manage to bake these last year.So this became one of the first cookies I baked this year. Â I doubled the original recipe to make more for giveaways. Â The sugar quantity here is the reduced amount cos' raisins are sweet.Verdict - very crispy, crunchy and aromatic cookies. Â With the reduced sugar, the sweetness is acceptable to me. Â I find the raisins a bit too much. Â Maybe, it can be reduced to 150 gm for double portion. Â My hubby said, these cookies will finish off very quickly when he tested it while I did the baking.Recipe from Copycake Kitchen which she adapted from Fabtastic Eats.Ingredients[double portion in red - 190 pieces]170 gm salted butter - room temperature [340 gm]70 gm brown sugar [140 gm]70 gm castor sugar [140 gm]1/2 of a large egg [1 whole egg]3/4 tsp vanilla [1 1/2 tsp]130 gm instant oats [260 gm]170 gm plain flour [340 gm]1/4 tsp fine salt [1/2 tsp]1/4 tsp baking soda [1/2 tsp]1 tsp cinnamon [2 tsp]1/2 tsp nutmeg [1 tsp] - I omit100 gm raisins [200 gm]Line baking sheets with parchment paper.Â In a large bowl, whisk together the oats, flour,salt, baking soda, cinnamon and nutmeg.Cream butter and sugar in a mixing bowl until light and fluffy.Beat in the egg and vanilla extract.Fold the dry ingredients into wet ingredients until just combined using low speed.Stir in the raisins.Â Pinch about a tablespoon each and place on baking sheet leaving some space in between. Â Press lightly to flatten dough. Â The cookies will spread out a little.Bake cookies in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15 minutes or until golden brown.Remove and leave to cool on wire rack before storing in air-tight container.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme:My Homemade Cookies by Fion ofÂ XuanHom's MomÂ and co-host by VictoriaÂ Baking Into The EtherI'm also linking this post to My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015hosted by Miss B of Everybody Eats Well In Flanders and co-hosted by Charmaine of Mimi Bakery House

title: Dry Wantan Noodles With Char Siew
text: This is a simple and tasty dry wantan noodle recipe that is easy to prepare for your family.  You can make your own char siew [see recipe]Â or use store bought and also make some boiled or fried wantan to serve with this noodles.The sauce portion here is for 3 servings, just do some calculation if you are preparing  a varied number of  portions.  The condiment portions are variable according to own preference.Ingredients for Dry Wantan Sauce[bring to boil in a saucepan, set aside][serves 3]3 tbsp abalone sauce or oyster sauce3 tsp light soy sauceÂ½ tsp each of sugar and saltSeveral dashes of pepper6 tbsp of prepared chicken soup or waterChicken Stock/Broth [optional] â€“ bring to boil until fragrant and strainedÂ¼ chicken breast750 ml water1-2 slices of ginger50 gm carrot1 stalk spring onionOther Ingredients3 servings of store bought fresh wantan noodlesÂ 1-2 stalks of mustard leaves [cai xin]Â Some chopped spring onionsSome char siew â€“ slicedSome boiled or fried wantan [see recipe]Some pickled green chillies or sambal belacanBring sauce ingredients to boil for several minutes.  Set aside.Bring chicken stock to boil.  Set aside.  Shred the boiled chicken breast to serve with noodles if you are not using char siew.Scoop 1-2 tbsp of sauce into serving plate.Bring a wok of water to boil, blanched vegetables.  Dish up and set aside.Using the same water, blanch wantan noodles for 1/2 minute. Stir with a pair of chopstick.  Remove from boiling water and soak briefly in cold water.   Transfer noodles back to boiling water to cook for another 1/2 minute or until soft but chewy.Dish up, drain excess water and transfer noodles to serving plate.  Toss well with sauce ingredients and top noodles with blanched vegetables, char siew and fried/boiled wantan.Serve with pickled green chillies or sambal belacan.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event January 2015 [Noodles and Pasta]Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ My Bare Cupboard

title: CNY 2015 - Lemon Poppy Seeds Cream Cheese Cookies
text: Saw this recipe of Yan [Simple Menu]Â in 2013 and has bookmarked to do but didn't make it cos' I wasn't in the mood to bake cookies for 2014 Chinese New Year.This year, I chose to bake these cookies ahead of other cookies as I have all the ingredients ready. Â I have doubled the portion of this recipe to make more for giveaways.Verdict - cookie dough is easy to prepare so long as the cream cheese is soft at room temperature. Â Very buttery and aromatic with the lemon zest and cheese. Â The citrus flavour make these cookies quite addictive. Â They are crunchy but not the melt in the mouth type of cookies.Ingredients[double portion in red - makes 140 pieces]140 gm cream cheese ( room temperature] [280 gm]70 gm butter [140 gm]100 gm castor sugar [200 gm]1/8 tsp salt [1/4 tsp]20 ml lemon juice [40 ml]1 tbsp lemon zest [zest of 1 lemon]215 gm all purpose flour [430 gm]20 g poppy seeds [40 gm]1 tsp baking powder [2 tsp]1/8 tsp bicarbonate of soda [1/4 tsp]Sift flour, baking powder and baking soda in to a bowl. Â Stir in the poppy seeds.Cream butter, cream cheese and sugar until creamy and fluffy.Add in salt, lemon zest and lemon juice. Â Mix well.Fold in flour mixture on lowest speed in several batches. Â Mix well.Rest dough for 10 minutes. Â Shape into small balls, place on baking tray lined with parchment paper [leaving some space in between the balls] and use a fork to press the dough to create a design before baking. I used the serrated plastic cutter to make Â the design.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C [middle rack] for 20-25 minutes.Remove to cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.Â I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme:Â My Homemade Cookies by Fion ofÂ XuanHom's MomÂ and co-host by VictoriaÂ Baking Into The EtherI'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015Hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In Flandersand co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery House

title: Braised Nam Yee Pork Tenderloin
text: These days, I just love cooking meat by braising which helps to keep my kitchen cleaner and the food healthier as little oil or no oil is required.The original recipe uses pork ribs and steaming method which takes a longer time to cook. You can also use pork belly which would beÂ good too but a longer braising time for the meat to get tender.Â Braising meat fillet takes about 30-40 minutes only. Â This one is a healthier version.Verdict - the meat is tender and the gravy is tasty and goes well with steaming hot rice.Recipe Source - Hawker's Fair Simplified [modified]Ingredients500 gm pork fillet [tenderloin] - cut thick slices1 tsp cornflour mix with 1 tbsp water for thickeningsome sliced spring onions250 ml water or enough to cover meatMarinade and Seasoning1 piece fermented red beancurd/nam yee1 tbsp fermented soya bean/fine taucheong3 pips garlic - chopped1 tbsp oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp shaoxing wine1 tsp sesame oilMarinade pork fillet with marinade and seasoning for several hours or overnight in the fridge.Heat up wok, pan fry meat slices with some oil to brown both sides.Add in water and the remaining marinade. Â Bring to a rolling boil, then lower heat to simmer for 30 minutes or until meat is tender. Â Remove meat and thicken sauce with some cornflour water.Slice meat fillet and pour sauce over meat. Â Garnish with spring onions. Â Serve with rice or fried noodles.I'm submitting this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #20Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: CNY 2015 - Crunchy Peanut Cookies
text: I always preferÂ Melt In The Mouth Peanut CookiesÂ but this year I tried the crunchy version cos' my grinder isn't functioning too well. I couldn't grind the peanuts until creamy. My neighbour used to tell me she likes the crunchy version more.So this is another version of my Peanut Cookies with a little coarser peanuts instead of the creamy peanuts. Basically, for this recipe, the toasted peanuts are not grind until fine like peanut butter but more grainy. Â The peanut and flour ratio is 1:1 which is slightly different fromÂ Melt In The Mouth Peanut Cookies.Here, I toast the peanuts instead of frying. Â Toasted peanuts give a more even colour than fried peanuts. Click here onÂ How To Roast Peanuts?Verdict - Good, cookies are crunchy, has a bite compared to the melt in mouth peanut cookies and does not stick to the teeth or mouth. Â Taste wise, both versions are yummy and rather addictive.Ingredients[makes 4-5 small bottles]950 gm peanuts - rinsed and drained950 gm plain flour320 gm icing sugar1 tsp saltÂ 1 tbsp butter200-250 ml vegetable oil1 egg - beaten for glazingSpread peanuts on baking tray evenly and toast peanuts at 180 degrees C for 25-30 minutes on middle rack. Â Cool and skinned the peanuts. Â Ground peanuts until fine but not creamy.Transfer into a mixing bowl, add sugar, salt and butter. Â  Mix well, then add in flour in batches.Combined well then gradually add in oil [you may need all the oil]. Â The dough is ready once you can roll it into a ball and does not stick to the hand. Â Rest dough for 30 minutes.Pinch a small piece and roll into a ball. Place on parchment paper, leaving some space in between. Â Do the same until the baking tray is filled with dough.Press each ball lightly with the end of a chopstick. Â Brush egg glaze evenly over peanut cookies.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 12-15 minutes or until golden brown.Remove cookies to cool on wire rack before storing in airtight containers. Â The cookies are very 'fragile', handle with care.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme:Â My Homemade Cookies by Fion of XuanHom's Mom and co-host by Victoria Baking Into The EtherI'm also linking this post to My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015Hosted by Miss B of Everybody Eats Well In Flanders and co-hosted by Charmaine of Mimi Bakery House

title: Fried Crispy Fish With Fragrant Soy Sauce
text: Another simple yet tasty fried fish with soy sauce.The fish is crispy but not hard and the flesh is very fresh. Â Served with fragrant light soy sauce, the fried fish is very yummy-yummy with rice and sambal belacan.Recipe Source - Hawker's Fair Simplified [modified]Ingredients4 medium size white promfret - cleaned, pat dry and make a few slitssome coriander leavessome fried crispy garlic - I omitsome oil for frying fishSauceÂ 1 tbsp light soy sauceÂ 1/2 tbsp oyster sauce1/2 tsp salt1 tsp sugar1/2 tsp sesame oil1/4 tsp dark soy sauce1 stalk coriander leaves100 ml waterPour sauce ingredients in a small saucepan, bring to boil for several minutes until fragrant. Remove the spring onions and coriander roots.Â Set aside.Heat up enough oil in wok, pan fry fish one at a time until cooked and crispy on both sides. Â Remove and place on serving platter. Â Finish frying the fish.Warm up sauce, then pour over the fish. Â Garnish with coriander leaves and serve immediately.I'm submitting this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #20Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Soybean Noodle with Yam Soup
text: This is similar to my post on Kocha Flavour Noodle SoupÂ a family style/way of cooking a variety of noodles. Â As I mentioned before, it is suitable to use soy bean noodles, flat rice noodles or instant noodles using the soup ingredients.In the recipe, I added yam to the noodle soup. Â With yam added the soup is thicker when the yam turns soft and more aromatic.Ingredients[serves 3-4]4 bundle of soybean noodles [tau chiam noodles]2 pieces dried mushroom - soaked and cut strips1 tbsp dried prawns - wash and drain150 gm meat slices - marinate with light soy sauce and cornflour150 gm yam - peeled and cut chunks1 tbsp chopped shallots and garlicsome cut chilliseasoning - salt, chicken stock granules and pepper to taste1/2 tbsp oil1 litre water Â Blanched noodles in boiling water to cook and drain [cook noodles as per instructions - depending on what noodles used].Â  Set aside.Heat oil in a wok [I use my brass wok to cook and serve], lightly fry the yam, dish up and set aside.Add a little oil, Â saute shallots and garlic until aromatic and golden.Â  Add in mushrooms and dried prawns, fry until fragrant, then add in the meat slices.Â  Fry for several seconds, add in water and seasoning. Â Bring to boil for 5-10 minutes.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning, add in yam to cook over low heat.Add in blanched soybean noodles to cook. Â The soup will thicken slightly, add more water if you like to have more soup.Off fire and serve immediately once the yam is soft.Scoop up noodles into serving bowls, garnish with chopped coriander and sliced red chilli and a dash of pepper.Â Notes:You can use any type of leafy vegetables you prefer.Â  I usually add more vegetables and try to cut down on meat.I'm submitting this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up Event January 2015 [Noodles and Pasta]Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ My Bare Cupboard

title: CNY 2015 - Crispy Cashew Nuts Cookies
text: Made these with the fried cashew nuts which I bought from Bangkok.These cookies are crispy, buttery and aromatic. Â  It's a keeper.The original recipe is only 1/4 portion of this recipe.Recipe Source - At Home With Amy Beh [ slightly modified]Ingredients[makes about 5 small bottles]500 gm butter250 gm castor sugar2 tsp vanilla essence2 whole eggs600 gm self raising flour4 tbsp rice flour1 tsp salt120-150 gm toasted finely ground cashew nutssome cherry bitsCream butter, sugar and vanilla essence until light and creamy.Beat in the eggs one at a time until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and salt on lowest speed.Stir in ground cashew nuts. Â Mix well into a soft dough. Chill in the fridge for about 15 minutes.Pipe into rossette using a noozle mould onto a baking tray lined with parchment paper.Top each with a small bit of cherry.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C on middle rack for 15 minutes or until golden brown.Remove from oven and cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.I'm submitting this post to Best Recipes for Everyone Jan and Feb 2015 Event Theme:Â My Homemade Cookies by Fion ofÂ XuanHom's MomÂ and co-host by VictoriaÂ Baking Into The EtherThis post is also linked toÂ Cook Your Books Event #20Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen FlavoursI'm also linking this post toÂ My Treasured Recipes #5 - Chinese New Year Goodies Jan/Feb 2015hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well In Flandersand co-hosted by Charmaine ofÂ Mimi Bakery House

title: Mixed Vegetable Salad
text: Crunchy salads are my favourite especially when there are meat dishes in a meal. Â Vegetable dishes is a must have for every meal with rice or noodles for my family.I made this salad to serve with theÂ Spicy Angel Hair Pasta With Minced Meat SauceÂ for a complete meal.Verdict - the shredded vegetables are crunchy and the dressing is not sweet but flavourful with the toasted sesame seeds. Â This salad can also be served with crispy fried firm beancurd pieces [taukwa] with a sprinkle of toasted ground peanuts. Best of all, it is easy to prepare and can be done ahead of meal time.
