title: ORANGE SWEET POTATO CINNAMON COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: I have baked the Purple Sweet Potato flavour cottony cake sometime agoÂ [recipe here]. Â Â This time, I used orange sweet potato and added cinnamon powder. Â  Â Cake turns out well with no cracks cos' I had used a bigger pan [9 inch] instead of 8 inch pan. Â This has resulted in a lower cake compared to the earlier one where I used an Â 8 inch pan.Anyway, the texture is the same - soft, spongy and moist with a tinge of cinnamon.Ingredients[use 9 Â inch pan][recipe from a food magazine with modifications]5 egg yolks1 egg60 ml corn oil [I used 50 ml]70 ml milk Â [2 tbsp condensed milk mix with 60 ml hot water]65 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside1/2 tsp cinnamon powder50 gm mashed sweet potato [orange sweet potato]1/4 tsp salt5 egg whitesÂ 50 gm sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 9" square tin with grease proof paper. Â Preheat oven to 170 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it.WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg with mashed potatoes, flour, milk and corn oil. Â  Whisk until well combined and batter is smooth.Â  Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â Pour the batter into prepared cake tin. Â Â Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking.Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 45 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up]. Â Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 5 minutes. Â Turn over and run a thin spatula along the edges to dislodge the cake.Â Â Invert again to remove baking tin andÂ the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards].Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Turn the cake over when completely cooled. Â Refrigerate before slicing if preferred or sliced to serve immediately. Â Cakes keep well in the fridge in airtight container.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]

title: Plum Sauce Roast Chicken
text: A roast chicken recipe with simple ingredients. Â Pairs well with onions and salad or just another yummy delicious chicken dish with rice for dinner.No oil needed or frying to do. Â Only marinating and roasting them in the oven before dinner.Original recipe is from Â The Waitakere Redneck's KitchenÂ , which is for 1 whole chicken but I used only 3 chicken thighs as I'm serving it just as a dish to go with rice for dinner.Taste - aromatic from the spices/herbs and slightly sweet sourish taste from the plum sauce. Â I added some salt and pepper for taste.IngredientsRecipe Source -Â The Waitakere Redneck's KitchenÂ with modifications[serves 3]3 chicken thighs - with skin and debonedMarinade - boil together2 tbsp sugar1 cinnamon stick1 star anise3 cloves3 tbsp plum sauce3 tbsp watersalt and pepper to tastesome toasted sesame seeds - optionalHeat saucepan on medium heat. Â Add in sugar to dissolve but not caramelised.Add herbs, on low heat add water and plum sauce. Â Boil gently for a few minutes.Pour sauce over chicken and marinade for at least 4 hours or overnight in the fridge.Preheat oven at 220 degrees C and roast chicken for 20 minutes [skin side down]. Â Then turn over to roast the skin side for another 15-20 minutes, brush some extra plum sauce over the skin and sprinkle sesame seeds [turn to grill function for the last 5-10 minutes if you prefer the skin a little charred].Cool and cut chicken or serve as a whole piece immediately. Â Â Â Note: Â If using whole chicken, just increase the marinade and roast chicken at 170 degrees C for 1 hour or until cooked. Â Left over marinade can be boiled, freezed and reused for next plum sauce chicken preparation.Notes: Visit this site for its'Nutritional Facts [here]

title: Kuih Ee [æ¹¯åœ“] - 2013 [for å†¬è‡³ Dongzhi Festival]
text: Kuih Ee [æ¹¯åœ“] - 2013 [for å†¬è‡³ Dongzhi Festival], a busy day apart from making the glutinous rice balls in ginger sugar syrup soup, IÂ  also have to prepare a variety of dishes and other foods for ancestral worship at my MIL house. Â Luckily, it falls on a Sunday and I have a Saturday to make the preparations.I won't be posting the recipe for the Kuih Ee [for the recipe, please look up my earlier posts on Kuih Ee] but only some photos of it. Â This year I was lucky, my neighbour gave me some natural colourings for my kuih ee. Â I made 5 colours [white, red, yellow, green and blue] for this year's rice balls [tang yuan].The green is from pandan paste, yellow is from pumpkin and blue is from the blue flower [bunga telang]. Â I used Bentong ginger for the sugar syrup. Â The end product - yummylicious tang yuan [æ¹¯åœ“] [kuih ee].For ancestral worship, I had a long list of items to prepare [some are specified by my MIL, while some I can try out with different tastes]. Â Â My mother in-law's list of must have.- Kuih Ee - Seng Lay - Pak Cham Kai, Â Dried cuttlefishÂ and Roasted Pork- Fried Fish- Fruits [I bought Persimmons only] but she added 3 other varieties- Jiu Hoo Char- a pork dish [I cooked the Palm Sugar Braised Pork Belly from No Frills Recipe]- a curry dish [I cooked the Fish Sauce Curry Chicken, recipe from Yum Yum magazine] - recipe posting soon.- a soup dish [I cooked the Tom Yum Pig Trotter Soup, similar to myÂ Tom Yam Gradoog Moo]. Â I replaced the pork ribs with pig trotters because I was told that pork ribs cannot be used for ancestral praying [I don't know why - anyone knows the reason?]. Too busy, didn't have time to take photos of the soup with pig trotters.- a noodle dish [I cooked the Hokkien Fried Yellow Noodles - non-vegetarian] Â [picture shows the vegetarian version].- Cakes - I baked a chiffon cake and an Ogura cake- Chinese Kuih Muih - I made Steamed Red BunsÂ Â [Mi Koo Recipe]- Rice and wine etc..Of course, as a Taoist's family, burning of josspapers and paper money for our fore-fathers/ancestors is a must have too. Â  Â After prayers usually by 12 noon, it is time for the family members to feast on the food prepared, hehehe!. Â Most times, I'm too tired to enjoy the food after an early start to prepare these things....and later the clearing and cleaning up to do.Â Â  This is how I spent Solstice Day year in and year out since I got married....hehehe!

title: My Daily Home-baked Bread Loaf [Wholemeal]
text: This has been my daily bread and I was wondering why I have not posted the recipe all this while. Â Anyway, it's an easy bread recipe worth following if you are having bread for daily breakfast like my family. Â  Super soft, fluffy, light and moist bread. Â Served either with butter and or home-made preserves and a cup of hot beverage is better meal to start the day. Â We usually will toast or steam the slices on the fourth day. Â  They are still as good as freshly baked.This recipe is for 2 loaves which is enough for four days for my family of three.Ingredients[makes 2 loaves x 600 gm or 24 slices of 1.5 cm width]500 gm bread flour100 gm wholemeal flour100 gm plain flour2 tbsp milk powder [I omit]1 tsp salt4 tbsp sugar [I used brown sugar]6 tsp instant yeast1 eggÂ 380 ml water [or egg + water = 410 ml]60 gm butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter and water] on slow speed to combine.Â  Add in water gradually as you may need less than 380 ml because of the egg. Â  Continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed [Kenwood mixer - speed 3] when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 20 minutes or double in size.Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 2 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a long rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â  Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tins.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour or rise over the rim of the baking tin].Bake in preheated oven at 150 degrees C for 40 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack.Â Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]

title: Fried Instant Noodles with Dark Soy Sauce
text: For the past weeks, there have been several wedding receptions to attend which means no dinners at home during the weekends. Â So I kept my lunch simple as I didn't buy too much of fresh groceries as there won't be much cooking.Â This is a simple stir fry noodles where all ingredients are usually available in the kitchen.It's kind of comfort food but quite complete for weekend lunch.The original recipe uses 250 grams of longevity noodles but I replaced it with instant noodles. Â IngredientsRecipe Source - Yum Yum Magazine No. 77Â - Fried Longevity Noodles with Dark Soy Sauce[serves 4]4 pieces instant noodles - blanched in boiling water for 1-2 minutes to loosen - drained1 stalk spring onions - shreddedsome cut red chillies2 tbsp oil100 gm lean pork - cut thin strips4 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips1 carrot - peeled and shredded100-150 gm cabbage - shredded [can add more]1 tbsp chopped garlic2-3 tbsp dark soy sauceSeasoning1 tsp 5 spice powder1 tsp each of salt and sugar1/2 tsp pepper2-3 tbsp light soy sauce50-100 ml waterHeat oil, saute garlic until fragrant. Â Lower heat, add in dark soy sauce. Â Add in mushrooms and meat. Â Stir fry to mix, add in cabbage and carrot.Add in seasoning and water. Â Turn to medium high heat, add in noodles. Â Stir fry to combine all ingredients.Continue to fry until noodles are cooked and almost dry.Dish up to serve. Â Garnish with cut chillies and spring onions.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook-Your-Books Event #7Â hosted byÂ Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Fried Mixed Vegetables In Yam Ring
text: This dish was prepared upon request by my hubby. Â Usually, I wouldn't cook this kind of dish cos' the fat content is very high. Â The fragrant crispy skin of the yam ring is too 'fatty' to my liking. Â But once awhile [months-years] it's alright, hehehe!. Â Anyway, we all enjoyed it very much especially the young girl at home [my niece/god-daughter].For the accompaniment, I prepared an easy vegetarian stir fry mixed vegetables. Â You can use any combination of ingredients from assorted mushrooms, carrots, tofu puffs or beancurd to carrots, broccoli, green peas/beans etc. Â All are as good.Instead of making just one yam ring, I made 3 smaller yam rings Â for easier frying, so that I don't have to use too much of oil. Â  The yam rings do not look very fluffy cos' I reduced the vegetable shortening from 3 tablespoons to 2.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum magazine with some modifications[serve 6]For Yam Ring:300 gm yam - peeled and sliced70 gm tang mien flour [wheat starch]1 tsp 5 spice powder1/2 tsp salt1 tbsp oyster sauce2 tbsp vegetable shorteningFor Mixed Vegetables:1/2 tbsp oila few slices of ginger3 dried mushrooms - soaked and quartereda few fresh abalone mushrooms - cut10 tofu puffs - halved1 small carrot - peeled and cut into cubes1 small broccoli - cut into small floretssome fried cashew nuts - optionalSeasoning1/4 tsp salt, dash of pepper1 tbsp each of oyster sauce and Shaoxing wine100 ml water1 tbsp cornstarch for thickeningYam Ring - steam yam until soft. Â Mix wheat starch with some hot boiling water, mix into a dough. Â Combine all other ingredients together. Â Mix into a soft yam dough. Â The dough is not sticky. Â Chilli in the fridge for about 2 hours.Remove yam dough and shape into a big ring. Â Deep fry in hot oil until golden brown. Â Dish and drain. Â Place onto a serving platter. Â [I made 3 smaller ones and a few rectangular pieces]For the Mixed Vegetables - heat oil in wok, saute ginger until aromatic. Â Add in mushrooms, carrot and tofu puffs. Â Stir fry, add in seasoning and water to cook.Lastly add in broccoli to cook. Â Stir in thickening.Dish out and spread over fried yam ring. Â Garnish with some fried cashew nuts. Â  Serve immediately.Notes: Alternatively, you can blanched all the ingredients, then do a quick stir fry before serving with yam ring.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook-Your-Books Event #7Â hosted byÂ Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Roasted Chicken with Tomato Paste
text: After seeing so many roasted chicken recipes by Phong Hong, I was so tempted to try a simple one to head start my venture in this kind of dish. Â  Only a few steps and waiting, it's time to ENJOY tasty, flavourful chicken straight from the hot oven.This roasted chicken was Â served with an easy to prepareÂ EZ Boiled Butter Cubed PotatoesÂ [see post],Â recipe taught by a American/Filipino friend and anÂ EZ Cabbage Salad [see post]. Â Ha! Ha! Â it's easy, simple and good.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum magazine[serves 3]3 chicken whole legs - with or without skin according to preferencesome Italian mixed herbsMarinade1 onion - chopped1 tsp ground black pepper1 tsp saltÂ 1 tbsp sugar1 tbsp honey1 tbsp light soy sauce4 tbsp tomato puree/pasteMarinate chicken with marinade and season for at least 2 hours.Place marinated chicken on a baking tray, reserve some marinade sauce for later use. Â Sprinkle Italian mixed herbs on top of the chicken.Roast in preheated oven at 220 degrees C for 20 minutes [middle rack].Pour remaining sauce over chicken and roast for another 20 minutes or until golden brown and well cooked. Â Remove and serve with boiled potatoes and cabbage salad [optional].Notes: Switch oven to grill the chicken for another 5 minutes to get it charred a little Â [optional]Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook-Your-Books Event #7Â hosted byÂ Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: EZ Boiled Butter Cubed Potatoes
text: This is a simple boiled potato recipe taught to me by my American/Filipino friend when I visited her in the Philippines. Â She cooked this to serve with fried crispy lemon sole fish and salad.Here, I prepared this dish to serve with Roasted Chicken with Tomato Paste [see this post]Â and a Cabbage Salad [see post]. A complete meal for dinner. Â Yummylicious chicken, sourish salad and soft boiled fragrant potatoes, hmmm...a good combination.Ingredients[serves 3]4 US potatoes - peeled and cut cubes1/2 tbsp buttersalt to tasteenough water to boil potatoesPlace cut potatoes in a pot, add enough water [just to cover potatoes].Bring to boil until potatoes are soft and water almost dry.Sprinkle in salt to taste, stir in butter and spring onions. Â Mix well, serve immediately with roasted meat.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]

title: EZ Cabbage Salad
text: Cabbage is selling cheap at the supermarket. Â Bought a whole cabbage, then was wondering what to do Â with it. Â Usually the case when you see things cheap, buy first and think later. Â Most times I won't do such things Â but I don't know why I was trapped, hehehe!Anyway, to clear it off fast, I prepared an easy cabbage salad to serve with an easy boiled cubed potatoesÂ [see post]Â and roasted chicken whole leg with tomato sauce [see recipe]. Â Sounds good enough for a simple weekend meal which turns out perfect.Ingredients[serves 3]3-4 cups shredded cabbage1 carrot - shredded3 shallots - thinly sliced3-4 small chilli - cut small pieces3 kaffir lime leaves - cut thinlyDressing - mix together3 tbsp chopped garlic3 tbsp sugar3 tbsp fish sauce3 tbsp calamansi juice3 tbsp apple cider vinegar1 tsp sesame oilMix salad ingredients together in a big bowl.Add combined dressing ingredients and mix well.Chill in the fridge before serving.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]

title: Vegetarian Braised Eggplant with Mushrooms
text: A tasty vegetarian not exactly braised vegetable dish with wet beancurd skin [tau pau] which is good. Â Quite a complete ODM [1 dish meal] if you intend to go vegetarian at times. Â Cholesterol free dish....Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum magazine with some modifications[serves 4-5]1 medium size eggplant - cut and soaked in water with salt for 10 minutes, drain before cookingsome broccoli florets [can use celery]4 pieces wet beancurd skin - fried until golden brown1 tomato1 packet enoki mushrooms [can use any fresh mushrooms] - cut5 slices ginger1/2 tbsp margarine - optionalSeasoning - combine together1 tbsp each of light soya sauce, tomato sauce, Worcester sauce and chilli sauce1/2 tsp salt200 ml waterHeat a little oil in wok to saute ginger until fragrant. Â Add in eggplant and carrot, fry and add in some water to cook eggplant.Add in fried beancurd skin, mushrooms, tomatoes and seasoning. Â Bring to boil, then simmer until sauce is thickened.Lastly add in broccoli. Â Stir fry until cooked and add in margarine [if using].Dish out to serve hot.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook-Your-Books Event #7Â hosted byÂ Joyce of Kitchen Flavours

title: Wood Ear and Red Date Soup
text: Came across this soup recipe by Christine which looks quite similar to the concoction for lowering blood cholesterol level which I usually prepare for my familyÂ Black Fungus with Dates Drink.Â  This version is slightly different with meat and salt added. Â It's a soup and not a drink. Â As a drink, I will have to discard the wood ear fungus but as a soup everything can be eaten. Â Not too bad an alternative, then.The wood ear fungus are soft and slurpy, the meat is tender and the red dates are sweet. Â Overall the soup is tasty and good.According to Christine, 'this wood ear and red date soup is suitable for women in the first month after childbirth, served as confinement food. Nevertheless, itâ€™s good for anyone, female or male adults in the family for its nutrients'. Hopefully, this version is also effective in lowering bad cholesterol.Ingredientsoriginal recipe fromÂ Christine's Recipes[serves 3-4]10 gm wood ear fungus - soaked to soften10 gm red dates - deseeded750 ml water3-4 slices gingersalt to taste80 gm lean pork - slicedMarinade for meat1 tsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp cornflourdash of pepper and sesame oilBlanch softened wood ear in boiling water for about 3 minutes. Â Drain, remove the hard stem, then cut into strips. Â Mix pork with marinade, set aside.Bring water to boil in a soup pot [I used claypot]. Â Add in wood ear, red dates and ginger. Â When it boils, reduce the heat to medium-low. Â Continue to cook for 20-25 minutes.Add in the pork, stir to combine. Â Bring to boil again and season with salt to taste.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]

title: WHITE COFFEE COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: I can't drink white coffee but have a few sachets of Â it lying in the pantry. Â Since I needed to bake a cake for a family occasion, why not use it for the cake flavour.I used the whole sachet [36 gm] for this cake as I wanted more intense flavour. Â The cake turns out good - soft and spongy. Â This time I baked the cake at 170 degrees C for 45 minutes [trying to save electricity, hehehe!]. Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg60 gm corn oil1 sachet White Coffee [36gm] dissolve in 80 ml hot water, cool before usePlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Add in eggs, corn oil and white coffee.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 170 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar60 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour the batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Â  Â Lightly shake the pan and the batter will spread out evenly.Â Steam bake in oven at 170 degrees C for 45 minutes. Â  [Notes - you can bake this cake at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then reduceÂ the temperature to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 50-55 minutes].Remove from oven and invert the cake to cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate for slicing and serving later.Â Â Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional Facts [here]

title: Brown Bean and Yam Dessert
text: The original recipe uses red beans but I prefer to substitute it with brown beans. Â I just love brown beans more than red beans. Â Anyway, the brown beans will have a very nice dark orangy colour after its cooked.Very simple dessert and with steamed yam, its more fragrant.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum magazine No.48Â with some modifications[serves Â 5-6]100 gm brown beans - washedÂ 1000 ml hot water80 gm rock sugar to taste150 -200 gm yam - peeled, cubed and steamed until soft [about 20 minutes]Put brown beans and hot water into a slow cooker pot. Â Cook on high heat until beans are soft.Add in rock sugar to taste.Add in steamed yam to cook for several minutes.Off heat and serve dessert hot or warm.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional FactÂ [here]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook-Your-Books Event #7Â hosted byÂ Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Fried Spicy Teochew Mee Teow
text: Teochew noodle is an easy noodle to cook and it can be rather tasty and appetising fried with Â different tastes. Â  Apart from the 'traditional' stir fry style Â Family style stir fry Teochew Noodles, this version is a little spicy. Â The original recipe uses spiral pasta but I replace it with Teochew noodles.The noodles are soft but chewy, tasted spicy, sweet, sourish like 'Mee Goreng'.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum magazine No. 48[serves 4]250 gm Teochew noodles - blanched in hot water until cooked, drain150 gm meat - minced or sliced100 gm prawn - shelled, keep the tail intact50 gm chives - washed and cut 1 inch length150 gm beansproutsÂ 1 tbsp chopped garlic3 tbsp oilfried omelette - cut thin stripsfried shallots, red chilli and lettuce - garnishing [I forgotten to add these]Seasoning2 tbsp each of oyster sauce and light soy sauce3 tbsp each of tomato and chilli saucesalt and pepper to tasteBlanch noodles in boiling water until cooked and soft. Â Place in colander and rinse under running water and drain.Â Notes: If using spiral pasta, cook as directed in package. Â Dish out and drain.Heat up oil and saute chopped garlic until fragrant. Â Add in the prawns and meat, fry for several seconds.Add in the blanched noodles and seasoning. Â Stir to mix well.Add in the beansprouts and chives to cook. Â Stir for several minutes until all ingredients are well mixed and cooked through.Dish out to serve. Â Garnish with shredded omelette and other garnishing.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook-Your-Books Event #7Â hosted byÂ Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Sambal Zuchini Kerabu
text: A simple kerabu [mixture of vegetables and sambal belacan]. Â  It's okay to use ready sambal, add the seasoning or just follow the sambal recipe here.This kerabu can be kept in a clean bottle and store in the fridge for at least 3-4 days.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum magazine with some modifications[serves 6]1 large zuchini or cucumber - cut into strips1 carrot - peeled and cut into strips5 shallots - sliced2 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed and toastedfried grated white coconut [kerisik] - optional4 tbsp vinegarSambal [Ground]1 red chilli2 chilli padi2 shallotsSeasoning1 tbsp toasted belacan1 tbsp sugarJuice of 4 calamansi limeBring a pot of water to boil. Â Add in vinegar, carrot and cucumber. Â Blanch for 2 minutes. Â Drain in colander.Mix sambal with seasoning then mix with blanched vegetables. Â Add in shallots, dried prawns and fried grated white coconut.Serve.Notes: Visit this site for its' Â Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm sharing this post withÂ Cook-Your-Books Event #7Â hosted byÂ Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Sri Lankan Fiery Pork Curry
text: This was supposed to be my first Sri Lankan curry that I wanted to cook earlier but I ended up cooking the curry with fish [Sri Lankan Curry Fish]Â and chickenÂ [Sri Lankan Curry Chicken]. Â  Both curries were really good - aromatic, spicy, sourish and I like the thick consistency of the gravy.This time, I cooked the curry with pork meat. Â  Â My hubby said is good [spicy but light].Ingredients[recipe adapted fromÂ Curry and ComfortÂ with some modifications][serves 5]500 kg lean pork cut into 1 inch cubes [I cut into thick strips - 1 cm]Marinade for PorkÂ 2 tbsp red chilli powder [I used thick chilli boh]2 tbsp meat curry powder1 tsp tumeric powder2 tbsp grated ginger2 tbsp grated garlic2 tbsp cider vinegarsalt and pepper to tastemix marinade and marinate pork for at least 30 minutes or overnight [forgotten to take picture of the marinated meat].Aromatics/Spices:2 stalks lemongrass - lightly bruised1 large onion - chopped4 green small chillies - chopped4 sprigs curry leaves1-2 tsp fenugreek6-7 clovesÂ 6-7 cardamon pods1 cinnamon stick3 tbsp oil250 ml water or thin coconut milk [enough to cover meat]125 ml thick coconut milk or milkÂ 1 tsp each of salt and sugar to tasteHeat oil in pan, fry aromatics until fragrant. Â Add in marinated meat. Â Fry for 3-5 minutes until oil separates and aromatic. Â Add in water.Continue to stir fry until water boils, reduce heat to simmer for 25-30 minutes [add more water if the curry is too dry].Add in milk or thick coconut milk and seasoning to taste once meat is tender.Dish up to serve with rice. Â This curry is more flavourful and tasted better after resting for some time.Â Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: PURPLE CARROT COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Came across a vegetable stall selling purple carrots. Â I bought one to try [it's RM 6/kg] baking this cake. Â The cake ...........hmm has the flavour of carrot, soft and spongy but doesn't have the colour. Â It looks greenish after baking, maybe it's because the carrot juice was exposed for sometime which makes it change colour. Â Perhaps, I should try baking this cake again, immediately after I juiced the purple carrot.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/2 tbsp skimmed milk powder1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg50 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]80 mlÂ carrot juice [from 1/2 a purple carrot]Place the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make a well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil and carrot juice.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Â  Smooth the surface with a spatula or just slightly shake the baking tin and the batter will spread out nicely.Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes, then reduce temperature to 140 degrees C and bake for a further 20 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will be dry after baking].Remove from oven and invert the cake after baking. Â Let it cool slightly [about 5-10 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake on wire rack before slicing to serve or chill in the refrigerator for slicing and serving later.Notes: For this cake, I invert the cake and left it to cool for about 15 minutes. I could just lift up the pan was easily without even having to turn back the cake.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts Â [here]

title: My Built-in Oven on Strike
text: I bought my first oven [a built in oven more than twenty years ago]. Â A reliable brand called ELBA. Â I can't remember the model number but now it has gone on 'Strike'. Â Honestly, it has served me 'faithfully' all this years until 2 years ago.I had contacted several technicians recommended by the dealers and friends. Â Some refused to come, some wanted to be paid if no repairs are done and some just gave some illogical reasons. Â Finally, I had one who came, took my oven away and told me it was the heating element problem. Â I had it changed and paid a few hundred Ringgit. Â The oven was back on duty not for Â long. Â I went back to this technician, he told me it is the thermostat Â problem and promised me to get the spare parts. Â Until today, he didn't manage to find it even though the distributor 'Fiamma' company still exist [I think in KL].Recently, I showed some relatives how to bake loaf bread at their home. Â They too have a built in Elba oven. The bread turned out so lovely and I suddenly thought I should try another time to find the most needed spare part [oven thermostat] to rescue my oven.I'm writing this post in the hope that some readers and fellow blogger friends may have some advice on this. Â Most people would say, just buy a new one after all it's more than 20 years old. Â I did buy a new one but only a small one cos' I haven't a place to fit in another built-in oven. Â I believe there are 'older' ovens elsewhere still functioning well and mine, if I can find the thermostat, it should work well again. Â I'll also check it out with Fiamma, KL for help.I'm reluctant sad to throw this oven away just because of this problem.Thank you.

title: Thai Ginger Chicken [kai pad king]
text: An easy and tasty Thai chicken dish. Â Â Very appetising with rice.Â  The gravy is slightly salty from the fish sauce and the sweetness is from the yellow onions.Â  Overall, the ingredients blend well with each other.Â  It's an easy dish to prepare and serve as a One Dish Meal with steaming hot rice.This dish was cooked at my MIL's place and the wok pan belongs to my hubby's nephew. Â  Look at the condition - this wok is not 'loved' by its' owner, hahaha! Â I bought a 'wok brush' for him. Â Hopefully the wok is going to have a clean look soon.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Thai Food RecipesÂ with some modifications[serves 4]6 to 8 chicken wings - cut [or other meaty parts of the chicken - about 500gm]1 yellow onion - peeled and cut wedges100 gm fresh mushrooms 1 red chilli - cut diagonally 50 gm ginger - cut thin slices3 cloves garlic - chopped1 spring onion - cut 1 inch length1 tbsp cooking oilsome water enough to cook chickenSeasoning4 tbsp fish sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp oyster sauce2 tsp sugarHeat oil in wok, saute ginger and garlic until aromatic. Add in the chicken pieces.Â  Fry until nearly cooked.Add in the seasoning.Â  Continue frying until the gravy is bubbly.Â  Add some water to cook chicken until tender and gravy is reduced.Add in all the remaining ingredients.Â  Give it a good stir to mix well.Serve immediately with rice.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'mÂ  linking this toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013 ThailandÂ hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Fried Fish with Tamarind Sauce [Thai Food - Pla Rad Prik]
text: Never really convince myself that Thai food is quite easy to cook and appetising until I tried several Thai dishes for the Asian Food Fest event. Â This is another lovely fish recipe that is worth preparing instead of the usual Fried Fish with Tau CheongÂ [Chien Chuan Hu]Â or Sweet Sour Fried Fish.My niece asked whether I'm cooking the same fish dish the next day.Â  Usually, she is afraid of cut chillies but this time I saw her scooping up all the sauce.Here I used Spanish Mackerel fish blocks and doubled the sauce portion as we needed more sauce to go with rice. Â  This sauce should be good for fried prawns or tofu. Â The sauce is tasty, sweet, sourish and spicy. Â Very appetising with rice.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Thai Food RecipeÂ with some modifications[serves 4]4 slices of Spanish Mackerel [about 400-500 gm] or any meaty fish150 ml tamarind juice [from 1 tbsp tamarind pulp]Sauce Ingredients2-3 tbsp chopped shallots2-3 tbsp chopped garlic5 small chillies - cut small pieces3 sprigs of coriander - chopped3 tbsp sugar3 tbsp fish sauce1-2 tsp oil Fry fish until golden brown and crispy.Â  Place on serving platter.Heat oil in wok, saute chopped garlic and shallots until aromatic.Add in chillies and tamarind juice. Bring to boil,add in sugar and fish sauce [should be like the consistency of maple syrup].Taste to adjust seasoning [according to your desire].Â  Add coriander leaves.Pour sauce over fried fish.Â  Serve immediately.TIP from Thai Food Recipe which I like : For more crispiness of the fish, just only put fried fish in the oven on 180 degrees C for 10 minutes. Â Then pour the prepared sauce over before serving.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013 ThailandÂ hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Thai Food Moo Ma-Nao [Boiled Pork With Lime, Garlic and Chilli Sauce]
text: I just can't resist this kind of dish, that is savoury, sourish, spicy and sweet. Â Best of all, no frying at all. Â Also like the idea of adding Chinese kale. Â Was lucky to get it [not too big size] at the wet market today as I intend to prepare a smaller portion. Â Also used the blanching the vegetable and meat as stock for my vegetable soup.Should have prepared the full portion cos' it was awesome.Ingredientsoriginal recipe fromÂ Thai Food Recipe[serves 3]300 gm pork tenderlion - thinly slicedÂ 1 stem Chinese kale - peel the skin and cut slantwise [can use Kailan stems]some cherry tomatoes - for garnishing [optional]Lime, Garlic and Chilli SauceÂ - combine together2 tbsp minced garlic5-10 chillies - chopped [I used 2-3 small red chilli]1 tbsp chopped coriander leaves [keep some leaves for garnishing]1 tbsp each light soy sauce and sugar2 tbsp fish sauce3-5 tbsp lime juice [I used calamansi lime juice]1. Â  Combine sauce ingredients in a small bowl. Â Taste to adjust according to  your preference.2. Â  Â Bring small water to boil, add in kale to cook. Â Dish out onto serving plate.3. Â  Use the same water, add in the sliced meat. Â Scald until cooked through. Â Dish out onto cooked kale.4. Â  Â Pour sauce over cooked ingredients, garnish with coriander leaves.5. Â  Â Serve with rice.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013 ThailandÂ hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Crispy Salty Chicken
text: I think this is rather similar to the Taiwanese Fried Crispy Chicken. This version is not sweet as Taiwanese version. Very fragrant and tasty cos' of the salt and spices. Â You can make the seasoning yourself or substitute it with the Taiwanese pepper salt [I bought a bottle from Taiwan for RM3.00].Should be a nice finger food that is welcome by many children.Ingredients[serves 4]original recipe by Alan Kok from Yum Yum magazine No. 48]300 gm chicken breast meat - skin removed, cut thin stripsenough oil for deep fryingMarinade1 tsp ginger juice1 tbsp Shaoxing wine1 tsp salt1/2 tsp 5 spice powder1 tbsp each cornflour and plain flourdash of pepper and sesame oil1/2 eggSeasoning1 tsp salt1/2 tsp ground black pepper1/4 tsp 5 spice powderMix marinade with chicken and marinate for at least an hour.Deep fry in hot oil until golden brown. Â Dish out on serving platter and sprinkle ready bought pepper salt. Â Serve. ORHeat a clean wok, stir fry salt over low heat until hot. Â Add in the remaining ingredients. Â Mix well. Â Add in fried chicken. Â  Stir well. Â Dish out to serve.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen FlavoursThis post is linked toÂ Facebook Asian Food Fest - August 2014 Taiwan FoodÂ hosted by AlanTravelling Foodie

title: Fat-Free Chocolate Chiffon Cake
text: This is my first time baking a chiffon cake without any fats [oil]. Â The cake rose beautifully and of course there are cracks, perhaps I have used a wrong size [18 cm] chiffon pan. Â The recipe calls for a 22 cm pan. Â  Anyway, this chiffon cake is very spongy, soft and moist. Â It's worth baking this if you are trying to cut down on fats in your diet, hehehe!Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture-Â [use 22 cm tube pan]original recipe from Yum Yum Magazine No. 81[makes 14 pieces]5Â egg yolks [used large eggs]70 gm cake flour sifted with 1/4 tsp baking soda30 gm cocoa powder mix with 100 ml hot water until dissolveWhisk egg yolks with cocoa mixture and flour until well combined and smooth. Â Set aside while you whisk the eggÂ  white.Â  Preheat oven at 180 degrees C.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg white80 gm sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartarWhisk egg white until frothy then add in cream of tartar. Â  Â Continue whisking until foamy then gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until stiff peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Mix until well incorporated.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue, Â Mix well. Â Â Pour Â batter into 9" tube pan. Shake a little and tap pan on table top several times to release trapped air .Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 35-40 minutes. Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake.Use a thin spatula to run around the pan.Remove cake from pan, then use a serrated knife to slice cake before serving.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Nyonya Flavour Curry Chicken
text: Oh, quite awhile haven't been cooking curry chicken with home blended paste. According to the chef Philip Yoong, this is Nyonya style curry chicken. Â I have never tried adding light soy sauce to curry. Â Out of curiosity, I just follow the recipe by adding it. Â  I tasted the curry before and after adding, believe me, it was different. Â  The curry tasted Â much better ........My opinion - it's an awesome, spicy, aromatic curry worth cooking. Â Nice. Â I wouldn't mind blending the ingredients again cos' it is worthwhile. Â Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum magazine No. 72 with some modifications[serves 8]Curry Paste [blended and mix with powdered ingredients]6 shallots - peeled4 garlic - peeled2 stalks lemongrass - white part only4 candlenuts - crushed2 red chillies15 dried chillies - soaked [or use 2 tbsp chilli boh]2 tbsp curry powder1/2 tbsp coriander powder1 tsp tumeric powder1 kg chicken - cut bite size pieces [I used 2 chicken whole legs and 4 wings]2 sprigs curry leaves100 ml tbsp oil1 cinnamon stick, 3 cardamons, 3 cloves and 1 star anise300 ml water [or enough to cover chicken]50 ml coconut milk [or use 100 ml plain yoghurt]1 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tbsp sugar1-2 tbsp light soy sauceBlend curry paste ingredients in a processor until fine and mix well with powdered ingredients. Â Set aside.Heat oil in wok, saute all the ground curry paste and curry leaves until aromatic. Â Add in the other spices, stir fry until fragrant and oil rises.Add in the chicken and seasoning. Â Stir fry until chicken pieces are firm and well mixed with paste.Add water, bring to boil and add in yoghurt or coconut milk. Â Cover to simmer for 25 minutes until chicken is cooked and gravy is thickened.Taste to adjust seasoning. Â Dish up to serve with rice.Â Notes: Visit this site for its'Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: PASSION FRUIT COTTONY CAKE II [OGURA CAKE]
text: My previous bake was passion fruits with a cocoa layer [Passion Fruit Cocoa Cottony Cake]. Â This time, I'm using just passion fruit for flavour. Â The cake is of bright yellow colour and some black spots, these are the passion fruit seeds which are very crunchy.Lovely cake, lovely flavour from the passion fruit juice with milk, hmmm.... Â Last weekend, my hubby's aunties came visiting. Â I was So happy that finally I received a big Thumbs Up from them for the cottony cakes that I baked in front of other relatives. Â  Â Many relatives have been eating my bakes but none ever bother to comment. Â Huh! this makes a big difference. Â 'Thanks Aunties for the 'booster' - compliments and encouragement. Â  Â I'll share more flavours with you.'Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg50 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]80 ml Â passion fruit juice with seeds [obtained from about 2-3 passion fruits] - I used 50 ml passion fruit juice with 30 ml milkPlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil and passion fruit juice with milk and the seeds.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour the batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Â  Â Lightly shake the pan and the batter will spread out evenly.Â Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes. Â  Reduce temperature to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 50-55 minutes. Â [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will be dry after baking].Remove from oven and invert the cake to cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate for slicing and serving later.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: Lotus Root and Peanut Soup
text: Another appetising, nutritious soup recipe, rich in fibre and suitable for the whole family shared by Agnes Chan in her book 'Let's Eat'. Â I used pork ribs instead of chicken for this soup.The soup is very tasty and not oily at all eventhough pork ribs are used.Ingredients - modified[serves 3-4]350 gm soft bone pork ribs - bite size pieces30 gm peanuts - rinsed and soaked for 3 hours1 cm piece da tou chai - washed and sliced - soaked for 10 minutes1 carrot - peeled and cut bite size pieces [omit]150 gm lotus root - washed and sliced5 red dates1 litre waterBlanch pork ribs in boiling water for 5-10 minutes. Â Drain and rinse to remove scums.Place all ingredients in a soup pot. Â Bring to boil over high heat, then lower heat to simmer for 45 minutes or until the peanuts and pork ribs are tender.Taste to adjust seasoning [soup is salty enough].Dish out to serve hot with rice.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Tau Eu Kay [Braised Chicken with Soy Sauce]
text: Always thought that chicken cooked this way isn't that flavoursome but this one happens to be simple yet tasty. Â My hubby says some Malay stalls cooked this using sweet soy sauce [kicap manis].Â Â This recipe is from Philip Yoong's book 'Nyonya Delights' which used 2 chicken whole leg [with bones and skin]. Â  Â Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Nyonya Deli with slight modifications[serves 5-6]4 chicken thighs - deboned and skin remove, cut bite size pieces1 red chilli - cut diamond shape1 green chilli - cut [I used green capsicum - cut wedges] - optional2 onions - quartered1/2 tbsp oil150 ml waterMarinadeÂ 4 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp dark soy sauce3 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp pepper1 tsp sesame oil1 tbsp cornstarchMarinade chicken with marinade for at least 2 hours.Heat oil, saute half of the onions [I like the onions to be crunchy, so I add the remaining later] for a few seconds. Â Add in the marinated chicken. Â Fry until chicken is firm and quite dry.Â Add in remaining onions and chillies. Â Stir fry to mix.Add in the water, bring to boil to cook chicken and until gravy is reduced to a thick consistency. Â Best to cook this dish over high heat if you prefer the onions to be crunchy.Dish out to serve with rice, sliced cucumbers and sambal belacan.Â Â Â Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Steamed Minced Meat with Tong Chye
text: A very simple steamed pork recipe yet so appetising and tasty served with rice or porridge. Â Good dish for busy days.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Agnes's Book 'Let's Eat'[serves 4]300 gm minced meat3 tbsp tung chye - rinsed and choppedSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp Shaoxing wine1/4 tsp each chicken stock granules, pepper and sesame oilÂ 1/2 tbsp cornstarch4 tbsp waterMix minced meat with tong chye and seasoning in a mixing bowl till well combined.Pour mixture into a steaming platter. Â Spread evenly.Steam over high heat for 20-25 minutes until cooked.Serve hot with rice and porridge.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts and print recipeÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Chiang Mai Peppery Chicken
text: In life, I believe everything has a time for it. Â  After this and that commitments and duties have been attended to and over, it's time again for good, yummy food for the family to feast on.This is quite a simple and easy dish to prepare yet tasty and appetising. Â You can add all the peppercorns if you like it 'hot'. Â The gravy and chicken is so good with rice.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Philip Yoong's book Nyonya Deli with slight modifications[serves 4]3 chicken thighs [about 500 gms] - cut bite size pieces [I used chicken thighs and wings]1 red chilli - sliced1 green chilli - sliced [I used 2 small green chilli]4 tbsp chopped coriander roots2 tbsp chopped garlic1 tbsp ground white peppercorns [I used 2 tsp white pepper]100 - 150 ml water1 tbsp oilMarinade/Seasoning [I used it to marinate the chicken]1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp fish sauce2 tsp dark soy sauce1 tsp sugarMarinate chicken with seasoning for at least 2 hours or overnight.Heat oil, saute chopped coriander roots and garlic until aromatic. Â Add in the chillies and pepper.Fry for 1-2 seconds. Â Add in the chicken. Â Stir fry until chicken is firm and fragrant.Add in water, bring to boil, lower heat to simmer until chicken is cooked and gravy is thickened.Dish out to serve immediately with rice.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen FlavoursI'm also linking this toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013 ThailandÂ hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Rad Nah [Thai Rice Noodles in Gravy]
text: I find this quite similar to our Malaysian Char Hor Fun [Cantonese Style Fried Flat Noodles]. The Rad Nah is simpler though with less ingredients although there are many versions of it. The Char Hor Fun has more ingredients like meat, seafood and even eggs are added to the noodles or gravy. Â Another difference with Rad Na is that it has yellow bean sauce which I believe is quite like our tau cheo [preserved salted soy bean paste] which has a darker colour. Â Rad Na Recipe from hereÂ with Â some modifications.Anyway, I did add our local tau cheo to see how the gravy tasted since the recipe does not use salt. Â  Surprisingly, the gravy tastes good without any traces of taucheo [I used the fine type]. Â  Â  I added more greens as my family loves vegetables. Â  A good Rad Nah has tender pork with soft chewy noodles and plenty of gravy. Â Â Â This dish turns out exactly like this and with the Prig Nam Som [chilli sauce], it is perfect noodle dish. Â Â It's a comfort food for the weekend meal. Â  This yummy noodle dish costs less than RM 10.00.Ingredients[serves 3-4]1 kg fresh flat rice noodles [about 4 sheets] - cut big pieces3 tbsp dark soy sauce250 gm tender pork - sliced thinly3-4 stalks Chinese broccoli - washed and cut1 tbsp minced garlic2 tbsp oil2 tbsp yellow bean sauce [I used 3 tbsp fine taucheo]2 tbsp sugar [I omit]4 tbsp tapioca flour [1 tbsp for marinating meat]3 1/2 cups waterMarinade sliced pork with 1 tbsp tapioca flour, some salt and pepper - mix and massage. Â Set aside. Â Mix remaining flour with some water. Â Set aside.Heat 1 tbsp oil in a non-stick wok. Â Add in noodles [hor fun] and dark soy sauce. Â Lightly stir fry the noodles until the strands separates, leave noodles to cook until slightly charred.Dish out into individual serving plates.Using the same wok, add remaining oil, saute chopped garlic until brown, add in the marinated pork. Â Fry until cooked.Add in the taucheo and water. Â Bring it to a rolling boil. Â Add in vegetables and the flour mixture. Â  Keep stirring continuously until gravy is thicken and clear.Scoop gravy over noodles and serve with chilli sauce [prig nam som].Visit this site for its' Nutritional FactsÂ [here]Prig Nam Som - Chilli Vinegar Sauce for NoodlesNote: This chilli sauce will thicken slightly left overtime. Â Can prepare it earlier.Ingredients8 Jalapeno red peppers [I used 2 red chillies and 3-4 small red chillies]2 tbsp chopped garlic1/2 cup white vinegar [I used apple cider vinegar]1 tsp saltCoarsely blend chillies and garlic. Â Mix with salt and vinegar [must be enough to cover the chillies].Serve with Rad Na [Thai Flat Rice Noodles with gravy].I'm submitting this post toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013Â Â hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Macao Style Pork Chops
text: This time is real stuff for this dish instead of my earlier recipe using mock meatsÂ [see posting]. Â  Simple preparation, yet awesome served with rice or buns and pickles. Â  This yummy dish costs less than RM 10.00. Â As One dish meal, it is enough for 3.Original recipe from Yum Yum Magazine No. 48 with modificationsIngredients[serves 5]500 gm pork chop slices [about 7-8 pieces, 1 cm thick slices] or any tender lean pork of your choicesome Â toasted sesame seedssome oil for pan fryingMarinade4 tbsp light soy sauce4 tbsp Worcestershire sauce2 tbsp cooking wine1 tsp sesame oil1 tbsp sugar1 tsp each of 5 spice powder and pepperSlice tender pork into 1 cm thickness. Â Tenderise with the back of the knife.Marinate with marinade for several hours or overnight in the fridge.Heat oil in non-stick pan, pan fry meat pieces without the marinade until the edges are brown and slightly crispy. Â Flip over to fry the other side, about 5 minutes for each side.Dish out on serving platter.Add some water to marinade. Â Pour into pan to boil until it is slightly thickened [optional if you prefer some gravy for pork chops].Pour over fried meat slices, sprinkle some sesame seeds over meat.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: CARROT ORANGE COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Fresh carrot and orange juice either with or without milk is my favourite drink. Â This is my first attempt baking the cottony cake with this flavour.The cake ...........hmm very fragrant, looks soft and spongy. Â Nice cake that has the orangy colour with strands of grated carrot. Â That was my hubby's comment when he came into the kitchen.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/2 tbsp skimmed milk powder1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg50 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]60 mlÂ  fresh orange juice [from 1 orange]2 tbsp freshly grated carrot with the liquidzest of 1 orangePlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make a well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil, orange juice, grated carrot Â and zest.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Â  Smooth the surface with a spatula or just slightly shake the baking tin and the batter will spread out nicely.Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then reduce temperature to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will be dry after baking].Remove from oven and invert the cake after baking. Â Let it cool slightly [about 5-10 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake on wire rack before slicing to serve or chill in the refrigerator for slicing and serving later.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: EZ ABC Soup
text: Another soup recipe from Agnes's Chan latest book 'Let's Eat'.Â  The original recipe uses chicken whole legs [skin removed, cut to bite size pieces], but I used pork ribs. Â Â This Â soup is tasty and a little tangy with the tomatoes.Ingredients[serves 3-4]300 gm meaty pork ribs1Â  potato - peeled and cut into wedges1/2 carrot - peeled and cut into wedges1 onion - peeledÂ  and quartered 1/2 tsp peppercorns - slightly crushed800 ml water1 tomato - cut into piecessome spring onions - chopped for garnishingsalt to tasteBlanch pork ribs in boiling water for several minutes to remove scums.Â  Rinse well.Bring water to boil in a soup pot, add in pork ribs and peppercorns, then simmer for 20-25 minutes until tender.Add in carrots, potatoes and onions, simmer until potatoes and pork ribs are soft.Lastly add in tomatoes and salt to taste.Â Â  Cook a further 5-10 minutes.Dish out to serve hot.Â  Sprinkle with spring onions or coriander leaves.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Braised Pork Belly With Red Yeast Rice
text: I have used red yeast rice 'ang chow' to cook with chicken, rice, noodles and pork but I have not tried braising pork belly with it.Here's a recipe which is easy to prepare but needs a little longer time as it requires braising pork belly until tender. Â  Nevertheless, this is worth preparing if you intend to enjoy aromatic meat dishes during your busy days. Â I prepared this dish earlier and refrigerate them until required. Â Just reheat and it's ready to go with plain white rice and some fresh salads or if you have the time, a quick stir fry vegetable.Â I love the ginger flavour Â and the fragrant smell of the red wine. Â Moreover, red yeast rice residuum is known for it cholesterol lowering effect so I believe it is not that sinful to enjoy the pork belly meat cooked this way, hehehe! Â Self consoling.. I need someone to confirm this fact.The original recipe is too big a portion for my small family, so I cooked only half this portion. Â The pork belly meat and especially the skin is chewy and aromatic.Original recipe from Yum Yum Magazine No. 72Ingredients[serves 6]600 gm pork belly [about 4 strips] - cut into half for easy cooking5 dried chillies3 pieces star anise1 cinnamon stick5 slices ginger1 tbsp red yeast rice residue [ang chow]1 tbsp rock sugar4 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp shaoxing wine500 ml waterBlanch pork belly pieces in boiling water for 10-15 minutes. Â Drain and rinse.Put all the ingredients in a pot, bring to boil.Lower heat and simmer for about 45 minutes until meat is tender.Dish up the pork pieces, slice and place on serving platter.Strain the sauce into a small saucepan, thicken slightly with cornstarch or boil to reduce the gravy. Â Pour over sliced meat and serve.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â Â  Â Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books Event #6Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Family Style Stir Fry Teochew Noodles
text: Teochew noodle [aka Teochew mee teow in Hokkien] is quite new to me until after I was married. Â My mother in-law is a Teochew and she just love this noodle so much that I got to see her cooking it very often. Â But I don't really fancy this noodle as it uses lard and pork belly for frying. Â It was later that I tried this noodle at a 'halal' hawker stall. Â Being halal, no meat or lard was used yet the noodle tasted good just with fresh and dried prawns. Â The hawker version has beansprouts and chives. Â For home cooked version, we prefer to use leeks which makes the noodles more aromatic.The noodle itself is quite salty to taste, has to be blanched in boiling water until cooked and soft but still chewy before frying. Â It's not necessary to season with salt especially when serving it with sambal belacan. Â I prefer to use the hand-made noodles that come from Hatyai, Thailand.I prepared this for my MIL while she was in hospital. Â After many days having hospital food, this was well received by her apart from my red bean soup and sweet potato soup. Â All her favourites.Ingredients[serves 3-4]250 gm Teochew noodles - loosen and cut to shorten the strands2 tbsp oil3 stalks of leek - washed and sliced slantwise or 1 inch length1 small carrot - cut thin strips [optional]100 gm meat - cut thin strips [you may use meat with some fats]1 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed and coarsely chopped or keep wholepepper and msg to tasteBlanch noodles in boiling water until cooked and soft. Â Place in colander and rinse under running water and drain.Heat oil in wok, fry meat until aromatic and firm. Â Add dried prawns, fry until fragrant.Add in blanched noodles, stir fry to combine ingredients well.Add in Â carrots and leeks. Â Stir fry until vegetables are cooked. Â Add in seasoning to taste.Sprinkle some water if you don't want the noodles dry - optional.Dish up to serve Â with cut chillies or sambal belacan.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]

title: LEMON POPPY SEEDS COTTONY CAKE 3 [OGURA CAKE]

Add in eggs, corn oil, lemon juice, zest and milk.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 8" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Smooth the surface with a spatula or shake a little and the batter will spread out evenly.Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes, lower heat to 140 degrees C and bake for a further 20 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 to 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be soggy after baking].Â Remove cake and invert it after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate before slicing to serve later.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: Steamed Fish With Ginger & Salted Wet Plum
text: A slightly different way of steaming fish using salted wet sour plums. Â Looks like no frills steamed fish Teochew style [that is minus the meat, salted vegetable and tofu].Â The gravy is savoury and sourish with the fragrant aroma of chopped ginger and garlic.Â Ingredients[serves 3-4]1 medium size white promfret - cleaned1 piece salted sour wet plum2 tbsp chopped ginger1 tbsp chopped garlic1 red chilli - seeded and chopped1 stalk spring onion - chopped1-2 tsp oilPlace cleaned fish on a steaming plate.Heat oil to saute chopped garlic and ginger until fragrant. title: Nyonya Char Muar Eu Kay [Sesame Oil Chicken]
