title: Soybeans and Sea Kelp Soup
text: Simple yet flavoursome soup that isn't difficult to prepare.The original recipe uses pork ribs but I replaced it with lean meat. Â If using pork ribs, it has to be blanched then boil or double boil all the ingredients together until pork ribs are tender. Â If using lean meat, it has to be added last after the soybeans are soft.Original recipe from Yum Yum Magazine with slight modificationsIngredients[serves 4-5]50 gm soy beans [soak for at least 2 hours] - drained20 gm sea kelp - rinsed and soaked for 5 minutes1 small carrot - peeled and cut wedges8 red datesÂ a few slices ginger300 gm pork ribs or lean meat - cut bite size piecessalt to taste750 ml waterPut all ingredients in a soup pot [except lean meat if using]. Â Bring to boil for 5-10 minutes.Reduce heat to simmer for 30 minutes or until soy beans are soft. Â Add in the lean meat and continue to cook for further 15 minutes. Â  Add salt to taste.If using pork ribs, blanched in hot water, drained and rinsed. Â Boil or double boil for about 45 minutes or until pork ribs and soy beans are soft. Â  Add salt to taste.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of CakeI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Nyonya Gulai Tumis Fish [Stingray Curry]
text: This curry is different from the Nyonya Assam Pedas FishÂ which I posted earlier. Â For this curry, as the name implies, the curry paste has to be fried in oil to bring out it's flavour and colour.You can addÂ other ingredients like lady's fingers, tomato and onion wedges to this curry [like my mom used to do] but I just wanted to enjoy the fish with the gravy according to the book.Â  The gravy is flavourful, of thick consistency and the spiciness is just nice.Ingredients[original recipe from Nyonya Flavours with slight modifications]Spice Paste - Ground Together15 gm [10] dried red chillies - soaked in hot water and drained2 red chillies - optional2 stalks lemongrass - sliced2 cm fresh tumeric - skinned and sliced or 1 tsp tumeric powder100 gm [10] shallots20 gm [3 cloves] garlic15 gm belacan1 tbsp tamarind pulp375-400 ml water100 ml cup oil400 gm stingray - cleaned and cut into chunksÂ 1 stalk ginger flower - halved and sliced finely [I omit]1/2 - 1 tsp salt to taste1 1/2 tbsp sugar to tastea few stalks of Vietnamese mint [daun kesum] - optionalBlend spice ingredients in a blender until fine. Â Set aside.Mix tamarind pulp with water and strain to extract the juice.Heat oil in wok/pot, saute blended paste until oil rises. Â Add in the tamarind juice and bring to boil for 5-10 minutes until aromatic. Â Â Season with salt and sugar.Add the fish, bring to boil for about 5 minutes or until fish is cooked.Add daun kesum if using. Dish out to serve and garnish with mint leaves[optional].Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Steamed Fish with Ginger/Soy Sauce
text: With fresh fish, steaming is the best way to cook it. Â Here is a very simple yet aromatic sauce used to steam the fish.This fish was bought from the fishing boat that came back to shore. Â  Extremely fresh.Ingredients[serves 3-4]1 white promfret [about 300 gm] - cleaned3 tbsp finely shredded ginger1 tbsp chopped garlic1 stalk spring onions - chopped1 tbsp sesame oilSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tbsp oyster sauce2 tbsp water1/2 tsp sugarHeat sesame oil in wok to saute ginger and garlic until lightly brown and crispy. Â Add in the seasoning. Â Dish out.Spread steaming sauce evenly over fish.Steam over high heat for 7-10 minutes [depends on size of fish].Garnish with spring onions before serving immediately.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional Facts [here]I'm also linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Achar Fish
text: This is a vegetarian mock fish fillet dish cooked in Fried Fish with Tumeric and Vinegar Sauce [Acar Fish]Â style. Very fragrant with fried ginger, lemongrass and tasty with the sweet sourish sauce.Ingredients10 pieces of vegetarian mock fish slices [see this post for recipe]3 tbsp shredded ginger3 stalks lemongrass - sliced finely1 red chilli - cut shreds or sliced1 green chilli - cut shreds or sliced3-4 tbsp oil [may require more oil]1 tbsp turmeric powder2-3 tbsp sugar1 tsp salt3 tbsp vinegar100 ml watersome cornstarch mixture for thickeningHeat oil in wok to fry mock fish slices in batches until golden brown.Â  Dish out. Cut into half. Â Place on serving platter.Using the remaining oil, saute ginger and lemongrass till fragrant and golden brown. Â Dish out, Â place over fried mock fish fillet, off fire.Add in chillies,Â Â turmeric powder, sugar, salt and vinegar.Â  Turn to low heat, stir to mix seasoning sauce, lemongrass and add in water.Â  Bring to a boil.Â  Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary.Â Â Add in cornstarch water to thicken slightly. Â Scoop over fish slices.Serve dish on a flat dish so that the mock fish slices are soak in sauce.I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Mock Fish Fillet
text: Strange to see people going for mock vegetarian food [such as prawns, cuttlefish, duck meat, mutton etc] when they are on a vegetarian diet. Personally, I don't fancy this kind of food but curious to know what is in the mock food. Â Here is a recipe for mock fish fillets which I made when I found out they use 'natural' ingredients.These mock fish fillets can be pan-fried or deep fried until golden brown served with chilli sauce or use as an ingredient to prepare other vegetarian dishes. Â I used these to prepare Vegetarian Achar Fish.Ingredients- original recipe from Kuali.com with slight modifications[makes 10 pieces]10 pieces wet bean curd [tau pau]Seasoning - mix together1/2 tsp each of salt, pepper and 5 spice powder1/4 tsp each of sugar, ground black pepper and vegetarian msg1 tsp sesame oil - to rub on tau pau after marinating1 piece of bean curd sheet [tau puay] - cut into 10 equal pieces [about 9"x9" size]5 pieces of Nori sheets [about 7"x7" size] - halvedCoat wet bean curd with seasoning ingredients. Â Leave aside for 30 minutes.Lightly rub sesame oil over the marinated wet bean curd.Place a piece of Nori sheet over the bean curd sheet [tau puay]. Â Wrap tau pau with nori sheet, then wrap it with bean curd sheet into a rectangle parcel.Place the mock fish fillet in a lightly greased steaming tray and steam over high heat for 10 minutes. Remove and leave aside to cool completely.Prick the steamed fish fillet with a satay stick all over before deep frying until golden brown.Cut fish fillets and serve with chilli sauce or use them for cooking other dishes.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen FlavoursI'm also linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Sambal With Okra
text: Similar to theÂ Nyonya Sambal Udang Lady's Fingers, but this is the vegetarian version. Â I used the vegetarian sambal -Â [see recipe here]Â and the dried gluten crisps to replace the dried prawns. Â Quite a delicious vegetable dish minus the cholesterol.Ingredients[serves 8]600 gm lady's fingers - washedÂ 4-5 tbsp vegetarian sambal50 gm dried gluten crispsjuice of 2 limessalt and sugar to taste150 ml waterBlanch okra in boiling water until soft. Â Drained and place on a serving plate.Add 2 tbsp oil into wok, add in vegetarian sambal and dried gluten crisps. Stir fry to mix.Add water and seasoning to taste. Â Bring to boil, then simmer until the water is reduced to a thick consistency.Add lime juice to taste.Dish out and spread over blanched lady's fingers.

title: Braised Mui Choy in Nam Yee Sauce
text: Braised salted mui choy is one of my favourite porridge dishes but it is also good with rice as I discovered while on vegetarian diet.This is a simpler version compared to my other two recipesÂ Braised Dual Mui Choy with MushroomsÂ andÂ Vegetarian Braised Mui Choy. Â For this recipe, I used just nam yee for the taste and flavour.Ingredients[serves 4-5]100 gm salted mui choy - rinsed, soaked and chopped100 gm sweet mui choy - rinsed, soaked and chopped1 piece nam yee [fermented bean curd]a few ginger slices1 small can braised peanuts - drained the sauce2 tbsp oil + 1 tsp sesame oilSeasoning1 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1/2 tbsp dark soy sauce2 tbsp sugar to taste1 tsp pepper2-3 cups waterFry both mui choy in wok without oil for a few minutes. Â Push aside.Add oil into the wok and saute ginger slices and nam yee, fry until fragrant.Push in the fried mui choy to mix.Â  Stir fry for a few minutes over medium heat.Â  Add in seasoning.Add in enough water to cover ingredients.Â  Bring it to a boil and reduce heat to simmer vegetables until soft and gravy is reduced.Â Add in braised peanuts.Â  Stir to mix all ingredients.Â Serve with plain rice or porridge.Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Braised Assorted Mushrooms with Mustard Stems
text: Mustard stems on its' own is sometimes a bit bitter but blanched and stir fried with assorted mushrooms, this dish is delicious too. Â For this dish any combination of the types of mushrooms is alright.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum Magazine No. 77 with some modifications[serves 5-6]200 gm mustard stems - cut into pieces1 small carrot - peeled and sliced100 gm fresh small abalone mushrooms50 gm button mushrooms - sliced50 gm straw mushrooms - sliced6 pieces dried mushrooms - soaked and sliceda few slices of ginger2 tbsp oilSeasoning Sauce - combine together1 tbsp each of Â shaoxing wine, vegetarian oyster sauce1/2 tsp each of salt and pepper1 tbsp cornstarch mix with 100 ml waterBring water to boil, blanch mushrooms and carrots for 1-2 minutes. Â Dish out and drainAdd a teaspoon of vinegar to boiling water, blanch mustard stems until the colour turns bright green. Dish out and drain.Heat oil in wok, add in blanched mushrooms, then mustard stems. Â Stir to mix ingredients well.Pour in seasoning sauce, stir well and bring it to a boil.Dish out to serve immediately.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Macao Style Vegetarian Mock Meat
text: Have bookmarked to cook Macao Style Pork Chops long time ago but never got down to do it. Â Looking through this recipe, I realised that I could substitute the pork chops with vegetarian mock meats.Was really satisfied with the result. Â The mock meat slices were awesome, tasty and yummy. Â I wouldn't mind preparing it again for vegans to enjoy.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum Magazine No. 48 with modifications[serves 6]500 gm wet gluten balls [mee keen] - sliced [can you vegetarian mock pig intestines]some Â toasted sesame seedssome oil for pan fryingMarinade3 tbsp light soy sauce3 tbsp worcestershire sauce1 tbsp cooking wine1 tsp sesame oil1 tbsp sugar1 tsp each of 5 spice powder and pepperSlice mock meats about 1/2 cm thickness.Marinate with marinade for several hours or overnight in the fridge.Heat oil in non-stick pan, pan fry meat pieces without the marinade until the edges are brown and slightly crispy. Â Flip over to fry the other side.Dish out on serving platter.Add some water to marinade. Â Pour into pan to boil until it is thickened. Add some Â toasted sesame seeds [optional if you prefer some gravy].Pour over fried mock meat, sprinkle some sesame seeds over meat.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of CakeI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Vegetarian Sweet Sourish Tempe Curry
text: Another tempe curry with different flavour from my Vegetarian Tempe Curry. This curry tasted spicy, sweet sourish, quite like Indian style curry. Â  The tempe is has a nutty fragrance when you munch it. Â  A delicious vegetarian curry that is good with rice. Â It can be cooked as a semi dry spicy curry and the coconut milk can be replaced by milk. Â This one has more gravy cos' I have forgotten to pan fry the potatoes Â and cos' I'm giving some to my friend who prefers more watery curries.Ingredients[serves 10]300 gm potatoes - skinned and cut wedges [can parboiled or pre-fried]200 gm wet gluten [mee keen] - cut bite size pieces [optional]2 pieces tempe - cut and deep fried until golden100 gm tofu puffs - halved2 tomatoes - cut wedges1 stalk lemongrass - lightly bruised2-3 sprigs of curry leaves100 ml oil50 ml coconut milk1 tbsp white rice vinegar2 cups waterIngredients - Curry PasteÂ [Combine together]1 tbsp halbaÂ 25 gm meat curry powder1 tsp fennel powder1 tsp cumin powder1/2 tsp turmeric powder1 1/2 tsp salt to taste1 tbsp sugar to tasteHeat oil in wok, Â fry tempe until golden. Â Dish out.Use the oil to saute curry paste, curry leaves and lemongrass till aromatic and oil rises.Â Add in potatoes and wet gluten pieces [can replace with more tofu puffs] to cook. Â Stir fry to combine well with curry paste. Â Â Add in water.Â  Bring it to boil until potatoes are almost soft. Â  Add in tofu puffs, tomatoes andÂ Â seasoning to taste. Â Cook for several minutes.Lastly add in fried tempe to mix, off fire.Â  Dish out into bowl to serve with rice.Note: This vegetarian curry is without onions or garlic because the dish is for vegetarian diet for religious reason. Â You can pre-fried or parboiled the potatoes, then less water is required.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [Here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Stir Fry Eggplant with Miso
text: The vegetarian sambalÂ [see recipe here]Â Â which I prepared was so useful and I  could use it as a base for quite a number of dishes. This stir fry eggplant is one of them. Â Here, I added miso to the sambal and used it to fry eggplant. Â Very flavourful with rice.Ingredients[serves 5-6]600 gm eggplantÂ 3 tbsp vegetarian sambal [can replaced with chilli boh]3 tbsp miso2 tbsp chopped gingersome small chilli padi - slicedsalt and sugar to taste150 ml water2 tbsp oilsome crushed vegetarian 'kiam hu' [optional]Mix miso and sambal together into a paste.Slice eggplant and soak in water with some salt. Â Drain before frying.Add 2 tbsp oil into wok, saute ginger until aromatic.Add in the chilli padi, vegetarian sambal and miso paste. Â Stir fry until fragrant.Add in the eggplant, stir fry to mix well.Add water and seasoning to taste. Â Bring to boil, then simmer untilvegetable is cooked and soft.Dish out on serving plate and garnish with some vegetarian fried 'salted fish'.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Egg With Black Fungus
text: This dish is exactly the same asÂ Sesame Oil Ginger Vegetarian Egg.Â  For this version, I used vegetarian egg with sesame oil and lots of ginger and black fungus [bok nee] instead of mushrooms.Â Â  Simple, tasty and yet appetising with rice.Vegetarian egg is called tau pau or fresh bean curd sheet that comes in rounds or rectangular form. Â For this recipe, choose the round type.Ingredients[serves 10]10 pieces vegetarian egg - pan fried until golden brown5 florets Â of black fungus - soaked and break into small florets3 tbsp ginger - cut fine shreds [here I used more, rinse once under running water]3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tsp sugar3 tbsp sesame oila dash cooking wine100 ml water [tau pau will soakÂ  up some of the gravy]Â Heat sesame oil in wok, saute finely cut ginger until aromatic and slightlyÂ  crispy.Â  Set aside.Add in sauce ingredients and water. Â  Bring to a boil, then add in black fungus.Cook for several minutes, then put in the fried vegetarian egg pieces.Â Braised for another 5-10 minutes and add a dash cooking wine. Â Add a little more water if you want more gravy.Dish out to serve with rice.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Braised Mushrooms, Vegetables in Nam Yee Sauce
text: For this dish, ingredients are quite similar to Char Chap Chye but I think there is more fermented bean curd used. Â Full of flavours from the nam yee which also give the dish a nice colour.Ingredientsoriginal recipe from Yum Yum Magazine No. 77 with some modifications[serves 6]150 gm cabbage - washed and break into small pieces1/2 carrot - peeled and sliced5 dried mushrooms - soaked and quartered5 button mushrooms - sliced5 straw mushrooms - halved10 tofu puffs - halved2 pieces sweetened tofu skin - cut and deep friedÂ 2 pieces dried tofu skin [tau kee] - soaked and cut 1 inch length15 gm glass noodles - soaked for 5-10 minutes2 tbsp sesame oil4 pieces nam yee [fermented soya bean curd] - lightly masheda few slices gingerSeasoning1 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tsp sugar200 ml waterBlanch cabbage and carrot in boiling water for a few seconds. Â Dish out into a colander.Use the same water, blanched the mushrooms for a few seconds. Â Dish out into a colander.Heat sesame oil in wok, saute ginger slices, then add in the nam yee. Â Fry until aromatic.Add in tau kee and tofu puffs. Â Stir fry to mix ingredients, then add in all the blanched ingredients. Â Stir to mix well, add in water and seasoning. Â Bring to boil, then lower heat to simmer for a few minutes.Lastly add in glass noodles and stir well.Dish out to serve Â immediately [can Â thicken the gravy with cornstarch mixture if preferred].Â Notes: Visit this site for its' Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs Up EventÂ - Soy Beansorganised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of CakeI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Vegetarian Tempe Curry
text: Always a delicious vegetarian curry that is so good with rice at any time when you are on vegetarian diet.My family and friends' favourite curry which is a must to prepare during the annual vegetarian diet time.Ingredients[serves 10]300 gm potatoes - skinned and cut wedges300 gm cabbage - break into bite size pieces1 carrot - peeled and cut wedges150 gm tofu puffs - halved1 piece tempe - cut cubes and fried2-3 sprigs of curry leaves2 pandan leaves - knotted100 ml oil100 ml coconut milk3 cups water [more gravy]Ingredients - Curry PasteÂ [Combine together]50 gm chilli paste20 gm lemongrass paste30 gm coriander paste1 tbsp galangal paste1 tsp turmeric powder3 tbsp meat curry powder1 1/2 tsp salt2 tsp sugar1/2 tsp vegetarian msg [optional]Curry Paste and SpicesHeat oil in wok, Â fry tempe until golden. Â Dish out.Use the oil to saute curry paste, curry leaves and pandan leaves till aromatic and oil rises.Â Add in potatoes and carrots to cook. Â Stir fry to combine well with curry paste. Â Â Add in water and coconut milk.Â  Bring it to boil until potatoes are almost soft. Â  Add in cabbage, cover to cook until cabbage is soft. Â Add in seasoning to taste. Add in tofu puffs, boil for several minutes.Lastly add in fried tempe to mix, off fire.Â  Dish out into bowl to serve with rice.Note: This vegetarian curry is without onions or garlic because the dish is for vegetarian diet for religious reason.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Herbal Soup [Bak Kut Teh]
text: Vegetarian Bak Kut Teh is definitely different from the actual meaty Bak Kut Teh. Â It isn't oily at all without the meats. Â However, the soup is very aromatic with all the herbs. Â My hubby asked why I cooked 'Bak Kut Teh' when I'm on vegetarian diet. Â This is an indication that the soup is very fragrant and herbally, hehehe! Â Can drink it without the 'sinful' factor.This soup was served with Vegetarian Savoury Rice with White Beans.Ingredients[serves 8-10]original recipe from Yum Yum magazine No. 77 with some modificationsHerbal Soup Ingredients1 tsp white peppercorns - washed, lightly crushed5 gm dang gui3 gm chuan xiong2 star anise10 gm cinnamon stick12 gm yuk zhu3-4 pieces licorice roots [gan cao]2 litres waterSeasoning1 tsp salt1 tsp vegetarian msg or mushroom seasoning granules1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and vegetarian oyster sauce1/2 tbsp dark soy sauce1 piece black fungus - soaked and break into small pieces1 piece gluten roll - cut or break into bite size pieces5-6 dried mushrooms - soaked, drained and sliced [can use 1 tin button mushrooms]2 packets fresh enoki mushrooms - cut off the roots, washed2 pieces sweet bean curd - cut and fried until golden [can replaced with 10 tofu puffs]100 gm dried bean curd sticks, soaked and cut into short lengthsPlace white peppercorns, dang gui and chuan xiong in a soup bag, tied up. Place soup bag and the rest of the herbal ingredients in a soup pot. Â Add in water. Â Bring to a boil for 10-15 minutes until the soup is aromatic.Add in seasoning ingredients, black fungus, gluten roll, dried mushrooms. Â Bring to a boil, then lower heat to simmer for 20 minutes.Add in the remaining ingredients and continue to boil for a further 5-10 minutes.Taste to adjust seasoning. Â Serve soup hot with lettuce leaves and some chopped coriander leaves.Notes: You may use the ready mix bak kut teh soup bag to replace the herbal ingredients. Â  Â You may also use any kind of fresh mushrooms to replace the above mushrooms.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen FlavoursI'm also linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Savoury Rice With White Beans
text: This savoury rice recipe is actually a vegetarian rice dumpling recipe. Â Instead of cooking it with glutinous rice and wrapping up as rice dumplings, I substituted it with white rice and cooked it with several pieces of bamboo leaves so that the rice has the aroma of rice dumplings. Â You can replace 150 gm white rice with glutinous rice but here, I used all white rice as I'm cooking this for some elderly people too.A very nice savoury rice suitable as One Dish Meal for vegetarian diet. Â This rice was served withÂ Vegetarian Bak Kut TehÂ which is aromatic and light with vegetarian ingredients.Ingredients[serves 8]original recipe from Kuali.com with some changes600 gm rice - washed and drained150 gm white beans [mei tau] - washed, soaked overnight and drained2 tbsp sesame oil1 tbsp oilenough water to cook riceseveral pieces of bamboo leaves - cleaned6 dried mushrooms - soaked, drained and diced100 gm salted mui choy - soaked, drained and chopped100 gm sweet mui choy - soaked, drained and chopped100 gm chopped chai por - washed and drained30 gm dried crispy gluten - optional1 tbsp grated gingerSeasoning2 tbsp Chinese 5 spice powder1 tbsp salt3 tbsp sugar2 tsp pepper1 tbsp dark soy sauceIn a wok, fry white beans without oil for a minute, then add in chopped mui choy, fry for a few minutes until ingredients are dry. Â Push aside.Add sesame oil and oil into wok, saute ginger until aromatic. Â Add in the chai por and gluten crisps. Â Stir fry for a minute. Â Mix all the ingredients together.Add in seasoning, then the rice. Â Stir fry to mix all ingredients well or until the rice is quite dry.Transfer to a rice cooker. Â Add in the bamboo leaves and enough water to cook rice.Remove the bamboo leaves, fluff up rice before serving immediately with vegetarian sambal [see recipe here]Â or chilli sauce and a vegetable soup if preferred.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Vegetarian Stir Fry Celery with Mushrooms
text: Simple stir fry celery with mushrooms with fragrant vegetarian oyster sauce.This quick stir frying method of the celery keeps it crunchy and sweet.Ingredients[serves 4-5]3-4 stalks of celery - washed and slice slantwise1 carrot - slice slantwise3-4 florets bok nee - soaked and break into small florets100 gm small abalone mushrooms1 red chilli - seeded and slice slantwisea few slices of gingeroyster sauce, salt, pepper and vegetarian msg/mushroom granules to taste mix and mix with some cornstarch water for thickening1 tsp cooking wine1 tbsp sesame oilHeat sesame oil over low heat, saute ginger slices. Â Add in mushrooms and carrots. Â Stir fry for a few seconds.Add in celery and bok nee, give it a quick stir to mix.Pour in seasoning sauce and wine, Â bring it to boil.Dish out to serve immediately.Notes: Visit this site for its Nutritional Facts [here]

title: Vegetarian Chye Boey
text: This dish can be cooked with the leftovers of Â Vegetarian Stir Fry TurnipÂ with some additional ingredients. You can also cook this stir fry sengkuang [jicama/turnip] and use it as the base for this vegetarian chai boey.Ingredients - A1 Â turnip [sengkuang] about 1 kg - cut very fine shreds1 carrot - cut very fine shreds200 gm cabbage - slice thinly3-4 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut fine shreds2-3 florets of soaked black fungus [bok nee] - slice thinly30 gm dried crispy fine gluten [optional]10-12 french beans - finely sliced100 ml oilSalt and vegetarian msg to tasteHeat oil in wok to fry mushrooms, crispy gluten and bok nee for a minute.Fry mushrooms till fragrant then add in all the vegetables except french beans.Continue frying until the vegetables are limp and soft.Â  Add in salt and msg to taste.LastlyÂ add in the french beans. Â Â Stir fry to combine and cook till french beans are cooked.Â  Dish out to serve with rice or lettuce leaves and chilli sauce or transfer to a big pot.Add in ingredients B and bring to boil. Â Lower heat and simmer until all the vegetables are soft and has the sourish flavour of chai boey.Ingredients - B1 stalk green mustard [about 300 gm] - washed and cut chunky pieces2 stalks preserved salted vegetables [kiam chye] - washed, soaked and cut into 1-2" lengths4-5 dried chillies1 piece 5 cm size ginger - mashed2-3 salted wet plums2-3 calamansi lime1 stalk lemongrass - lightly bruisedHeat wok, fry without oil the kiam chye, lemongrass, dried chillies, ginger for several minutes. Â Add in the vegetarian stir fry yam bean and green mustard [kai choy]. Â  Stir fry to mix well.Add in enough water to cover vegetables, salted plums and calamansi limes. Â  Bring to boil for several minutes.Lower heat and simmer until vegetables are soft and dish is fragrant.Serve immediately.

title: Dual Purpose Vegetarian Stir Fry Jicama
text: This jicama/bangkwan stir fry was prepared for the purpose of making vegetarian chai boey [see this post]. Â Since the quantity is quite big, part of it can be served as Stir Fry Jicama similar to Popiah but it's vegetarian. Â Part of it can be used to prepare the ever popular Chai Boey minus the meat.Ingredients - A2 pieces firm beancurd - cut thin strips - fried until golden1 Â turnip [sengkuang] about 1 kg - cut very fine shreds1 carrot - cut very fine shreds200 gm cabbage - slice thinly3-4 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut fine shreds2-3 florets of soaked black fungus [bok nee] - slice thinly30 gm dried crispy fine gluten [optional]10-12 french beans - finely sliced100 ml oilSalt and vegetarian msg to tasteHeat oil in wok to fry mushrooms, crispy gluten and bok nee for a minute.Fry mushrooms till fragrant then add in all the vegetables except french beans.Continue frying until the vegetables are limp and soft.Â  Add in salt and msg to taste. Â Add in fried beancurd.LastlyÂ add in the french beans. Â Â Stir fry to combine and cook till french beans are cooked.Â  Dish out to serve with rice or lettuce leaves and chilli sauce or transfer to a big pot.Add in ingredients B and bring to boil. Â Lower heat and simmer until all the vegetables are soft and has the sourish flavour of chai boey.I'm linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Vegetarian Red Yeast Rice Char Siew [Ang Chow Char Siew]
text: This is actually mock char siew flavoured with red yeast rice residum, nam yee and sweetened with gula melaka. Very different from the normal store bought vegetarian char siew which I think uses some red colouring.Surprisingly good. Â My niece loved it. Â My hubby thought it was store bought, started tasting it after I told him it's not colouring but 'Ang Chow'.Ingredients[serves 5-6]300 gm wet gluten balls [mee keen] - tear or cut strips2 tsp sesame oil1/2 cup water30 gm gula melakasome toasted sesame seedsMarinade1 tbsp red yeast rice residum [ang chow]1 piece red fermented beancurd - nam yee1/2 tsp 5 spice powder1/4 tsp pepper and vegetarian msgsalt to tasteMarinate gluten shreds with marinate for several hours or overnight.Heat sesame in oil. Â Stir fry marinated gluten shreds for several minutes.Add in water, bring to boil then simmer for 10 minutes.Add in gula melaka and simmer until gravy is reduced and thicken.Taste to adjust seasoning. Â Sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds.Dish out to serve. Â Garnish with extra toasted sesame seeds.

title: Vegetarian Sambal 2
text: Another version of vegetarian sambal that has more ingredients. Â  The previous oneÂ [Vegetarian Sambal I]Â has no carrots and uses fresh red chillies with calamansi lime juice. Â  This one uses chilli paste [from dried chillies] and tamarind slices. Â Both are as good. Â You can squeeze in so lime juice for more tangy Â taste.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Kuali.com with slight modification]300 gm chilli paste75 ml oil75 gm sugar1 tsp salt15 gm tamarind slices4 slices galangal [wild ginger]extra lime juice - optionalBlend together3 red chillies6 bird eye's chillies1 stalk lemongrass10 g fresh tumeric100 gm tomato [about 1 medium Â size]70 gm carrot [1/2 a medium size carrot]Heat oil in wok and add in the blended spice paste. Â Fry until fragrant.Add in chilli paste and fry until oil separates. Â Add in tamarind slices, galangal, sugar and salt to taste. Â Stir fry until fragrant.Dish out to cool before storing in glass container.Â Add extra lime juice if preferred before serving with rice, noodles etc with raw vegetables like cucumber or four angled beans.I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Vegetarian Pickled Mixed Vegetables [Acar Awak] 2013
text: It's Nine Emperor Gods Festival [Kew Ong Yeah] which starts today 5th till 13th October for 9 days. Â I made this pickled mixed vegetables again. Â I think, I skipped this dish last year cos' the family was in mourning of our beloved father then. Â  Â This time I have replaced long beans with french beans. Â The idea came from a lady at the wet market who told me that french beans stay crunchy and taste better in this acar. Â Look up this post [here]Â for the recipe with long beans.Cut vegetables before blanchingIngredients for the Chilli PasteÂ [combine together]200 gm chilli paste100 gm grounded lemongrass50 gm grounded galangal50 gm tumeric paste [tumeric powder mix with water]30 gm grounded candlenuts [buah keras]2 kg cucumber - cut 1 inch length thin strips - season with some salt, set aside1/2 kg cabbage - break into bite size pieces1/2 kg carrots - cut 1 inch length thin strips1/2 kg french beans - cut 1 inch length pieces [replacing long beans]200 gm grounded peanuts3-4 tbsp toasted sesame seeds200 gm sugar2 tsp salt1.5 ml water and 200 ml white vinegar150Â  ml oilBlanched vegetables and chilli pasteSeason cut cucumber with some salt and set aside for 15-20 minutes. Place seasoned cucumber in a muslin bag and squeeze out the water.Â  Do this in several batches.Â  Drier cucumber will make it crunchy when cooked.Bring water to boil in a wok then add in vinegar.Â  Blanched each of the cut vegetables for about a minute and remove usingÂ  a serrated ladle into a basin. Usually, I will blanch the cucumber first, followed by carrot/long beans and cabbage.Â  Do not overcook the vegetables.Â  Discard the water after all the vegetables are blanched.Heat up oil in the wok to saute the chilli paste till aromatic and oil separates.Â  Add in half portion of sugar and salt.Â  Fry to combine then add in all the blanched vegetables.Â  Stir to combine the chilli paste and vegetables. Then add in the cut chillies, balance sugar and salt.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning [need not be too sweet, sour or salty as it tastes better after 1-2 days].Bring it to a boil, lower heat then add grounded peanuts and sesame seeds [keep a little as garnish].Â  Mix well and off fire.Â  Leave to cool before storing in containers.Â  Sprinkle with sesame seeds when serving.Â  Keep well for 4 weeks or more in refrigerator.Â  Bring out and leave it toÂ  room temperature before serving with white rice.Â  Notes:If cooking less, just adjust the quantity of the ingredients proportionately.Â Â Acar tastes better after several hours or even after several days.Chilled in the fridge in airtight container, keeps well for up to at least a monthVisit this site for its Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: Oven Baked Crispy Anchovies
text: Must thank Noob Cook [see link]Â for this lovely recipe on oven baked anchovies. Â My family loves crispy fried anchovies but I always avoid frying anchovies unless really necessary. Now with this easy and healthy way, I wouldn't mind Â preparing these crispy anchovies for many, many dishes that require fried anchovies.Ingredients100 gm anchovies - halved and remove all the innards and bonesPlace anchovies in a colander and rinse under running water several times [depends on the species, some are more salty than others].Drain dry and spread them in a baking tray line with parchment paper.Baked in preheated oven at 160-180 degrees C [depending on your own oven-temperature differs]] for 10-15 minutes. Â Halfway through baking, toss and spread anchovies evenly to ensure even baking.Increase oven temperature to 180-200 [depending on your own oven-temperature differs] degrees C and bake for a further 5-10 minutes or until anchovies are golden brown and crispy.Serve immediately or cool completely before storing in an airtight container.Some of the dishes prepared and served with theseÂ oven baked crispy anchoviesStir Fried Spinach with Fried AnchoviesMixed Salad with Oven Baked Crispy AnchoviesStir fry kailan with oven baked crispy anchoviesNotes: Visit this site for it'sNutritional Facts [here]

title: Pork Ribs in Fragrant Sweet Sauce
text: Fragrant sweet sauce pork ribs that is easy to prepare yet tasty with plain white rice. Â I just love cooking this kind of dishes cos' it can be prepared earlier which makes it taste even better and minimal oil and frying required for this dish.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum magazine No.48 with slight modificationsÂ Ingredients - serves 5600 gm meaty pork ribs [original recipe uses spare ribs]Â 1 tbsp chopped garlic1 onion - peeled and chopped finely3-4 slices ginger1 tbsp sesame oil [original recipe uses cooking oil]1 cube fermented red bean curd [nam yee]1 tbsp fermented soybean paste [taucheo]Seasoning1 tbsp each light soy sauce and oyster sauce2-3 tbsp rock sugar750 ml watersome chopped spring onions for garnishingHeat sesame oil, saute chopped garlic, onions and ginger until aromatic. Add in taucheo and nam yee. Â Fry until fragrant.Add in the pork ribs and seasoning. Â Stir fry to mix ingredients well.Add in water, bring to a boil then lower the heat and simmer for about 30-40 minutes or until pork ribs are tender and the sauce is thickened.Dish up and serve.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post to Cook Your Books #5 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen FlavoursI'm also linking this post Â toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ EventÂ - Soy BeansÂ organised by Doreen fromÂ my little favourite DIYÂ and me,Â Bake for Happy Kids, hosted by Mich fromÂ Piece of Cake

title: Sweet Buns With Chicken Serunding
text: For these buns, I used the Sweet Bun Dough recipeÂ [see this post]Â and used chicken serunding [from a Muslim friend] as filling.These buns are fluffy, soft and moist. Â Nice buns.Ingredients for the buns [Sponge Dough Method][makes Â 16Â  buns]Step 1 - Ingredients100 gm plain flour150 gm bread flourÂ [you can replace plain flour and use all 250 gm bread flour]4 tsp instant yeast [I used 3 tsp]130-150 mlÂ  cold waterMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour. Â Knead to form a smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients250 gm bread flour100 gm sugar [I used 80 gm]1 tbsp milk powder1 tsp salt1 small egg [20 gm] - can used large egg and set aside some for egg glaze130 ml cold water50 gm butterEgg glaze**Step 1 - If not using dough, store in plastic and refrigerateAdd all Step 2 ingredients Â [except butter] to dough from Step 1. Â Knead from low speed until well combined. Â Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes]. Â Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stageÂ [**Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate. Â  Thaw to room temperature before using. Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only]. ORShape dough into a ball. Â Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Â Â  Punch down and divide dough into 16 portions of equal weight.Â  Shape dough into round balls.Roll out each ball and flatten dough, place a spoonful or more of any filling in the centre.Â  Gather up the seam and seal well. Â  Place bun on paper casing, seam side down on baking tray.Â  Finish shaping all the buns.Leave to rise for 30-45 minutes or until double in size. Â Brush with egg/milk glaze. Sprinkle with sesame seeds [optional].Baked in preheated oven at 190 degrees [middle shelf]Â  for 12-15 minutes or until golden.Â Brush buns with some melted butter [can skip this step if you do not want the buns surface to be oily. Â This step is to create a soft crust]. Â Â Remove and leave to cool on rack or serve warm.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: ORANGE COTTONY CAKE I [OGURA CAKE]
text: I have been baking cottony cakes of various flavours including this one but I didn't realise that I have not posted the recipe.This cake was baked for my neighbour. Â I only get to try the cake when I trimmed off the edges. Â The cake rose beautifully but somehow did shrink a little. Â Very fragrant, tangy taste, soft and spongy cake.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg60 ml corn oilÂ 80 ml Â orange juice [from 1-2 oranges]zest of 1 orangePlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Add in eggs, corn oil and orange juice.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar70 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour the batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Â  Â Lightly shake the pan and the batter will spread out evenly.Â Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes. Â  Reduce temperature to 140 degrees C and bake for a further 20 minutes. Â [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will be dry after baking].Remove from oven and invert the cake to cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate for slicing and serving later.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: Kiam Hu Kut Gulai [Salted Fish Vegetable Curry]
text: One of the popular Nyonya style curries with slightly different ingredients for the similar kind of curry. Â Some recipes do not add shrimp paste [belacan] to the spices.Very strong flavour, spicy curry with various vegetables. Â Good serving it with plain rice. Â Sometimes, I love to spread the hot curry over blanched instant noodles. Â Wow!, reminds me of my working days in KL when my aunt used to prepare it for me. Â  One point to note - taste before adding salt cos' the salted fish bones and some types of belacan or shrimp paste may be rather salty.Ingredients[original recipe from Nyonya Flavours with slight modifications]Curry Paste Ingredients [blended and mix with other paste ingredients]1 tsp white peppercorns2 stalks lemongrass100 gm [10-15] shallots10 gm [2 pips] garlic20 gm [15] dried chillies20 gm shrimp paste/belacan2 tbsp coriander powder1 tsp tumeric powder3-4 pieces salted fish bones - rinsed and soaked for 5-10 minutes200 gm long beans1 long brinjals - cut 2x4 cm pieces100 gm cabbage - optional1 cup taufu puff/taupok - halved200 gm small prawns - head and tail removed100 ml coconut milk [I used milk]750 ml watersalt and sugar to taste100 ml oilHeat oil in pan, saute salted fish bones for 1-2 minutes. Â Dish out.Using the same oil, add in curry paste. Â Fry until aromatic and oil separates.Add in long beans and brinjals. Â Stir fry to mix ingredients. Â Add in a little water for easier stirring of ingredients.Â Add in cabbage leaves [if using] and fried salted fish bones. Â Stir fry for a minute.Â Add in remaining water, bring to boil. Â When vegetables have softened, add in the prawns and taufoo puffs. Â Let curry boils for another 1-2 minutes.Add in seasoning to taste and lastly pour in coconut milk. Â Bring to boil again.Off heat, serve curry with plain white rice.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Nyonya Prawn Sambal Curry [Sambal Udang]
text: My mum used to cook this at home quite regularly but using ready bought fresh curry paste from the wet market. Â The taste varies each time. Â I came across this recipe from the book Nyonya Flavours where the curry paste is quite simple to prepare but rather spicy and tasty. Â  So here is the recipe.The Sambal Udang was good with Nasi Lemak and freshly sliced cucumber. Hmmm..... yummy, yummy. yummy.Â  You can use shelled small prawns for this dish. This was cooked at my MIL's place and I wasn't able to take better shots of the dish cos' we were all too busy enjoying this piping hot curry.Ingredients - Sambal UdangGround Spice Paste10 dried red chillies [15 gm] - soaked and deseeded10 shallots [100 gm] - peeled and cut small pieces1 stalk lemongrass - Â slice the white part only2-3 garlic [10 gm]5 gm tumeric [I used 1 tsp tumeric powder]500 gm prawns [medium or small] - shelled5 tbsp oil1/2 tsp salt to taste3 tbsp sugar to taste [can reduce]10 gm tamarind pulp [1 tbsp]300 ml waterBlend the spice paste ingredients in a processor until fine, then add tumeric powder. Â Mix well and set aside.Dissolve tamarind pulp in water to extract the tamarind juice. Â Strain and discard the tamarind seeds and pulp.Heat oil in wok, saute ground spice paste until aromatic and oil separates [can prepare paste until this stage and store in refrigerator until later use].Add in the tamarind juice and seasoning. Â Bring to boil for several minutes, then add in the prawns. Â Continue to stir fry to coat prawns with curry paste.Taste to adjust seasoning and boil for a few minutes until prawns are cooked.Dish out to serve with plain rice or nasi lemak.Notes: Visit this site for it's nutritional factsÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4 EventÂ hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Ginger Bud Dipping Sauce For Blanched Meat
text: Torch ginger is a pink flower bud known to Malaysians as 'Bunga Kantan' and is a common herb in most Asian kitchens. Â It is a member of the ginger family. The bud when cut gives an invigorating aroma and is used to flavour tangy curries/soups [Gulai Tumis, Assam Laksa etc.] and rice [Nasi Ulam and Nasi Kerabu]. Â Here, it is use as an aromatic ingredient for a nice dipping sauce.A very easy, simple yet good dipping sauce for blanched meat fillet or steamed/boiled chicken meat.Â  Savoury, sourish and sweet taste with fragrant aroma of chopped coriander leaves and the wild ginger flower [bunga kantan] is really appetising.Â Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum magazine]1 stalk wild ginger flower [bunga kantan] - finely chopped1-2 stalks of coriander leaves - finely chopped3 red chilli padi - chopped50 ml light soy sauceJuice of 3 limes1-2 tbsp sugar1 tbsp fine preserved soya bean paste [taucheong]Â Prepare and mix all ingredients together.Serve with blanched thinly sliced meat fillets or steamed chicken - chopped.Steamed Chicken Whole Legs With Ginger Bud Dipping Sauce2 chicken whole legs [with skin] - neatly trim offÂ  sides and excess fats-marinate for 30 minutes withÂ 1/2 tsp each of salt and pepper2 tsp sesame oil - to brush on chicken skin after steamingsteamed chicken over high heat for 20-30 minutes or until cooked and brush sesame oil over chicken skin ORboil in boiling water for 5 minutes, off heat, cover and soak chicken for 15 minutes.Â  Drain and brush with sesame oil.chopped into bite size pieces and serve with dipping sauce.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ I'm also linking this post toÂ September 2013 Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and Lovage

title: Preserved Green Mustard Beancurd Soup
text: Came across this soup recipe in Agnes Chan's latest book 'Let's Eat'. Â I happened to have some roasted pork ribs from my mom and cooking this soup is a good way to clear them. Â Surprisingly the soup tastes very flavourful and appetising. Â  I think this soup is not new cos' some blogger friends have cooked this soup before.Since roasted pork ribs are quite oily, I suggest it is better to boil them with some water, drained and rinsed the ribs well before cooking with other ingredients. Â This way the soup will be clear and free of scums.Ingredients[serves 3-4][recipe slightly modified]2-3 pieces roasted meaty pork ribs3 pips garlic3 slices ginger1/4 tsp white peppercorns - crushedsome chicken meat - optional750-1000 ml water1 tomato - cut into wedges100 gm preserved green mustard [kiam chye]1 preserved wet salted plum1 piece soft bean curd - cut into 6 pieces1/4 tsp chicken stock granulessome wine and sesame oilBring water to boil. Â Add in roasted pork ribs. Â Boil for 1-2 minutes. Â  Drained and rinse to clear off the scums.Place ginger, garlic, peppercorns and cleaned roasted pork ribs in a soup pot. Add water and bring it to a boil. Â Lower heat to simmer until meat is tender [about 20 minutes] and soup is fragrant.Add in preserved green mustard, tomatoes, wet plum and chicken meat [if using] . Â Boil for several minutes.Lastly add in beancurd, wine and sesame oil. Â Add some salt and msg to taste.Garnish with cut spring onions and serve soup hot.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post to Cook Your Books #4 hosted by JoyceÂ of  Kitchen Flavours

title: Kuih Seri Muka
text: Very happy with the 'performance' of my electric steamer, I made this steamed Nyonya kuih as I have the pandan juice and blue pea flower [bunga telang] water Â left over from making of the snowskin mooncakes. Â If you don't have the indigo colour, it is alright to make it plain. Â In fact, I shouldn't have mix the blue and plain colour rice together, then I would have a more distinct tri-colour kuih [white, blue and green].Not too difficult to prepare yet the kuih is good and definitely worth the to make for the family and friends. Â  My friends told me this kuih is good.IngredientsÂ - original recipe from Home Cooking Magazine with slight modifications[I used 15x23 cm oval shape steaming tray of my electric steamer]Rice Layer100 gm glutinous rice - washed and soaked for 4 hours100 gm glutinous rice - washed and soaked with blue pea water [please refer here for preparation]150 ml thin coconut milk2-3 pandan leaves1/2 tsp salt [use 1/4 tsp for each portion]Top Pandan Layer125 ml thick coconut milk110 gm sugar1.5 tbsp cornflour50 ml pandan juice [blend 5 blades of pandan leaves with 50 ml water, strain to obtain the juice]3 eggsa drop of green colouring [optional]Drain rice and combine the rest of ingredients. Â Place in a steaming tray and steam for 40 minutes until rice is cooked. Â  Cool for a while and discard the pandan leaves.Transfer rice to a lightly greased steaming tray. Â Press rice gently to level out. Â Steam for 10 minutes over high heat.Mix all the topping ingredients well. Â Strain into a double boiler with boiling water. Â Stir mixture until it thickens.Pour mixture over the steamed rice and continue to steam for another 25 minutes over low heat.Cool thoroughly [several hours] before slicing.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up - September 2013 EventÂ Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Joceline ofÂ Butter, Flour & MeI'm also linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and LovageI'm Â also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4 EventÂ hosted byÂ JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Nourishing Chicken Soup
text: This herbal soup recipe Â is from Agnes Chan's latest book 'Let's Eat'. Â According to her, this nourishing soup is best served after menstruation and during confinement periods. Â It helps to replenish blood lost and boost up energy. Â  Â I love herbal soup cooked this way as it is less oily and I get to enjoy the nourishing soup and all the ingredients including the herbs.Looks like this soup is an all purpose soup that suits the whole family from young to old. Â For the health benefits of some of these herbs, pleaseÂ see this post.Ingredients - recipe slightly modified[serves 3-4]3 chicken thighs - skin removed and cut bite size pieces [about 600 gm]10 red dates1 tbsp Chinese wolfberries/kei chee30 gm yuk chuk/solomon's seal4 slices dang qui/angelica roots800 ml watersalt to tasteBlanch chicken pieces in boiling water for 1-2 minutes, drained Â and rinse well. Â Bring water to boil in a pot [I used a claypot]. Â Add in all the herbs [except kei chi and red dates] for 10-15 minutes until the soup has the herbs' aroma.Add in chicken and red dates. Â Bring to boil again, reduce heat to simmer for about 40 minutes.Lastly add in Chinese wolfberries/kei chee and salt to taste. Â Boil for 1-2 minutes.Serve hot.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]I'm Â linking this post toÂ September 2013 Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and LovageI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Passion Fruit Snow Skin Mooncake [2013]
text: A lovely natural yellow colour snow skin mooncake using fruit juice. Â I used passion fruits for the colour, fragrance and tangy taste. Â It's not necessary to add essence.I used this ping pei skin to wrap Apple flavour mooncake paste [store bought]. Couldn't take cross section pictures of these mooncakes cos' they are for giveaways [will try to take the pictures at my friend's place]. Â However, I got to try the taste of the ping pei skin from the smaller mooncakes which I made from leftover dough. Â It's good.Ingredients[makes 5 pieces - dough weighs 300 gm]Â 90 gm cooked glutinous flour [kao fun]75 gm icing sugar90 ml iced passion fruit juice [about 2 passion fruits, add some water]*20 gm shortening* press out the juice, discard the seeds and add more water if necessary to obtain about 90 ml liquid. Â Refrigerate until required.Sift icing sugar with kao fun into a mixing bowl.Rub in shortening with your finger tips until fine grains formed.Stir in the iced cold passion fruit juice/water. Â Mix and combine into a soft dough.Cover and leave aside to rest for about 30 minutes.Roll into a long log and cut into 5 equal portions [about 60 gm/piece].Roll each piece into a ball and flatten it slightly. Â Use it to wrap any filling of your choice.Roll into a ball, press neatly into mooncake mold. Â Knock out to dislodge the ping pei mooncake and place in a plastic casing.Chill ping pei mooncake in the refrigerator.Notes:Any excess or leftover ping pei skin can be combined and use to make smaller ping pei mooncakes.

title: Savoury Sweet Blue Snowskin Mooncake [2013]
text: Snow Skin mooncakes [Ping Pei] are always my nephews' and friends' favourite. Â There is no way that I can skip making them every year, but I don't like to make the same types every year. Â  So, I have to keep looking for new recipes and mooncake fillings as my inspiration to make them. Â Couldn't take cross section pictures of the mooncakes cos' these are for giveaways [hopefully I can get to take the pictures at my mum's place].For this mooncake paste, I used the blue colour ping pei skin. Â The natural blue colour comes from the blue pea flowers [bunga telang] boiled with some water, then refrigerate until required.This recipe is enough for 8 pieces but I did only half of it. Â The mooncake mold shouldn't be too big otherwise the mooncake skin may be too thin and difficult to wrap.Pictures taken at my mum's place when I sent them over thereIngredients[makes 8 pieces - dough weighs 400 gm]Â 100 gm cooked glutinous flour [kao fun]100 gm icing sugar80-100 ml iced cold blue pea flower water*2 tbsp shortening* boil about 10-15 blue pea flowers with about 150 ml water for 5-10 minutes until indigo colour. Â Strain to obtain the water, refrigerate until required.Sift icing sugar with kao fun into a mixing bowl.Rub in shortening with your finger tips until fine grains formed.Stir in the iced cold blue water. Â Mix and combine into a soft dough.Cover and leave aside to rest for about 30 minutes.Roll into a long log and cut into 8 equal portions [about 50 gm/piece].Roll each piece into a ball and flatten it slightly. Â Use it to wrap any filling of your choice.Roll into a ball, press neatly into mooncake mold. Â Knock out to dislodge the ping pei mooncake and place in a plastic casing.Chill ping pei mooncake in the refrigerator.Here is a brand new paste filling which is savoury sweet [not sweet at all for a mooncake paste] and matches well with the sweet snow skin. Â This paste is also good for baked Shanghai mooncakes.Savoury Sweet Mooncake FillingIngredients - Paste weighs 650 gm[recipe adapted from Amy Beh at Kuali.com with some modifications]50 gm candied winter melon strips [tung kwa] - diced60 gm mandarin peel [kaet peang] - diced, seeds removed60 gm salted egg yolk - steamed and mashed50 gm castor sugar120 gm split green beans [lok tau peen] - soaked for at least 4 hours, drained well2 pandan leaves - knotted250 gm lotus paste - store bought [can add extra 100 gm for a firm and sweeter paste]Place split green beans in a steamer with pandan leaves on top. Â Steam for 40 minutes or until cooked and soft.Transfer cooked hot beans to a food processor and add in candied melon, mandarin peel, salted egg yolk and sugar. Â Process and blend well.Remove and combine with lotus paste. Â Mix well and evenly.Divide filling into 8 portions according to requirement and form into balls. Â Refrigerate until required.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up - September 2013 EventÂ Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Joceline ofÂ Butter, Flour & MeI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted byÂ JoyceÂ of Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Savoury Cheesy Pandan Snow Skin Mooncake [2013]
text: For this mooncake filling, I used Pandan Snow Skin dough. Â The green colour from the pandan water is just nice. Â Couldn't take pictures on cross section of the mooncakes cos' these are for giveaways [but I did see it at my friend's place when she cut it, looks good like professionally made, hehehe!].Pictures were taken at my mum's placeÂ and found that the pieces with just the cheesy tau sar [mung beans paste] were given to friends and not my mum. Â This one is with the savoury sweet mung beans paste [recipe in tomorrow's post]. Â  Â Anyway, the combination was good, too.This mooncake was good, very fragrant mooncake skin without adding any essence. Â Tasted it when I used the excess and leftovers to make smaller ones.Ingredients - weighs about 350 gm[makes about 6 pieces]100 gm cooked glutinous flour [kao fun]90 gm icing sugar120-130 ml iced cold green pandan water*30 gm shortening* blend 5 blades of pandan leaves with about 150 ml boiled cool water. Â Strain to obtain the pandan water, refrigerate until required.Sift icing sugar with kao fun into a mixing bowl.Rub in shortening with your finger tips until fine grains formed.Stir in the iced cold green pandan water. Â Mix and combine into a soft dough.Cover and leave aside to rest for about 30 minutes.Roll into a long log and cut into 6 equal portions [about 60 gm/piece].Roll each piece into a ball and flatten it slightly. Â Use it to wrap any filling of your choice.Roll into a ball, press neatly into mooncake mold. Â Knock out to dislodge the ping pei mooncake and place in a plastic casing.Chill ping pei mooncake in the refrigerator.I have made Ping Pei mooncakes with this filling [see related posts]Â bought from the baking suppliers. Â This year I made my own which is just as good, healthier and more economical.IngredientsÂ - Savoury Tau Sar Paste [weighs 650 gm]200 gm split green beans - soaked for at least 4 hours and drained well2 pandan leaves - knotted125 gm castor sugar1 tsp salt2 tbsp corn oilPlace split green beans in a steamer with pandan leaves on top. Â Steam for 40 minutes or until cooked and soft.Transfer cooked hot beans to a food processor and add in sugar, salt and oil. Â Process until fine and blend well.Cool and store in plastic bag.Savoury Cheesy Paste Ingredients[weighs about 750 gm]250 gm cream cheese - room temperature500 gm savoury tau sar pasteCream cream cheese in a mixing bowl until smooth.Combine with savoury tau sar paste. Â  Mix well.Transfer to a plastic bag. Â Refrigerate until required.Divide filling into 100-110 gm portions or according to requirement [size of mold] and form into balls. Â Refrigerate until required.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up - September 2013 EventÂ Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Joceline ofÂ Butter, Flour & Me

title: Plum Fruit Snow Skin Mooncakes [2013]
text: I'm very happy this year as I have used all natural colours from fruits, plants and flowers for my snowskin mooncakes. Â  This one is a lovely natural purplish pink colour snow skin mooncake with the fragrance of the plum fruit. Â I used plum fruits for the colour and it is not necessary to add any essence.This ping pei skin is used to wrap Red Dates and Longan flavour mooncake paste [store bought]. Â  Couldn't take cross section pictures of the mooncakes cos' these are for giveaways [will update with photos of it if I can at my mum's place].Ingredients[makes 5 pieces - dough weighs 300 gm]Â 90 gm cooked glutinous flour [kao fun]75 gm icing sugar90 ml iced plum fruit juice [use 1 plum fruit]*20 gm shortening* cut up the plum fruit, discard the seed. Â Boil cut fruits with about 150 ml or more water if necessary and strain to obtain about 90 ml liquid. Â  Â Refrigerate until required.Sift icing sugar with kao fun into a mixing bowl.Rub in shortening with your finger tips until fine grains formed.Stir in the iced cold plum fruit water. Â Mix and combine into a soft dough.Cover and leave aside to rest for about 30 minutes.Roll into a long log and cut into 5 equal portions [about 60 gm/piece].Roll each piece into a ball and flatten it slightly. Â Use it to wrap any filling of your choice.Roll into a ball, press neatly into mooncake mold. Â Knock out to dislodge the ping pei mooncake and place in a plastic casing.Chill ping pei mooncake in the refrigerator.Notes: Â Any excess or leftover ping pei skin can be combined and use to make smaller ping pei mooncakes.

title: Pandan Coconut Kuih Lapis
text: The original recipe actually uses carrot juice but I changed it to pandan flavour and the recipe below is just half the portion. Â It is actually a steamed layered cake with the nice aroma of pandan and coconut which definitely blends well.This steamed kuih turns out well, chewy [QQ] and I was very happy that I can peel the layers while eating it. Â Quite simple to make if you assemble all the dry ingredients in 2 bowls then mix in the liquid ingredients. Â I used the steaming tray of my electric steamer and half this portion is enough for my family. Â The steaming part is not difficult at all with the electric steamer. Â It's light, easy and no water vapour condensation.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum Magazine No. 69 with some modifications]Ingredients - A200 gm rice flour [I used 100g]200 gm tapioca flour [I used 100g]1 tbsp sago flour [I used 1/2 tbsp]270 castor sugar [I used 135g]700 ml water [I used 350 ml]300 ml coconut milk [I used 150 ml]Ingredients - B100 gm rice flour [I used 50g]100 gm tapioca flour [I used 50g]1/2 tbsp sago flour [I used 1/4 tbsp]120 gm castor sugar [I used 60g]500 ml carrot juice [I used 250 ml pandan juice]For pandan juice - blend 5 blades of pandan leaves and add enough water, strain to obtain 250ml pandan juice. Â Add a drop of green colouring - optional.Â In a mixing bowl, combine all the dry ingredients A, then stir in the liquid ingredients until well mix. Â The mixture is about 700ml. Â Divide into 6 even portions [125ml].Put dry ingredients B into another mixing bowl, then stir in the liquid ingredients until well mix. Â The mixture measures about 350ml. Â Divide the mixture into 5 equal portions [70ml].Heat up the steaming tray [lightly greased] for 5 minutes.Pour 1 portion of the batter A into greased tray and steam over high heat for 4 minutes or until set. Â  Pour in 1 portion of the batter B over the white and steam for 4 minutes or until set.Repeat alternating the white and green layer until the last layer which is white and steam for 10 minutes.Remove and leave to cool completely. Â Cut into pieces and serve. Â [Useful tip - use a plastic serrated knife wrapped with cling film to cut the cake. Â This is to prevent the cake from sticking to the knife and to get a neat edge]I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up - September 2013 EventÂ Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Joceline ofÂ Butter, Flour & MeI'm linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and LovageI'm Â also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4 EventÂ hosted byÂ JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Figurine Mooncake with Melon Seeds [2013]
text: This is a simple figurine mooncake which I made for this year's mooncake festival. Â It's without any filling but coated with melon seeds [kuaci]. Â I didn't use any particular figurine mooncake molds but instead I used the big wooden mooncake molds. Â Not too bad looking, lol.Â Ingredients for Mooncake Skin[Recipe adapted from book on Mooncakes published by Seashore][makes 33 -36 pieces ]270 gm golden syrup75 gm corn oil1.5 tsp alkaline water380 gm plain or superfine flourenough melon seeds for coating [about 50 gm]Combine golden syrup, oil and alkaline water in a mixing bowl until well mixed. Â Cover, leave to rest for at least an hour or overnight.Sift in flour and mix into a smooth dough [DO NOT KNEAD]. Â Leave to rest for 4-5 hours or overnight before use.Divide dough into small portions [about 25-30 gm, depending on the molds used]. Â  Roll into ball and coat with melon seeds.Â Put into mooncake mold. Â Press in neatly, knock out and place on a baking tray lined with parchment paper leaving some space in between.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown [if not applying egg glaze]. Â Remove to cool on wire rack. Â These mooncakes will soften and taste better after airing them for several days.Note: Â If using egg glaze - bake for 10 minutes, remove from oven and rest for 2 minutes. Â Brush with egg glaze and return to oven to bake for another 7 minutes.I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted by JoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Fresh Herbs and Cheese Omelette
text: This dish was supposed to be prepared and share with August Little Thumbs Up Event on Eggs Theme but somehow couldn't make it. Â Anyway, I managed to prepare this for Karen's September Cooking with Herbs Blog Challenge since this recipe uses fresh herbs cooked in an omelette.I had prepared a Basil OmeletteÂ [see here]Â last month using only basil but this omelette has more herbs added which is even more aromatic. Â Moreover with Parmesan cheese added, it's awesome. Â For the nutritional information on this dish,Â please visit this site.Notes on the ingredientsBasil - a member of the mint family, used medicinally for digestive upsets, migraine, nervous tension, constipation, insomia and for treatment of coughs and sore throats. Â Its also a natural insecticide, an insect repellantMint - known for its medicinal and culinary values, believes to allay nausea and help ease colic painCoriander - known as Chinese parsley or cilantro. Â A common aid for digestion and appetite stimulant.Spring Onions - a vitamin-enriched herb supposed to reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke, has a natural antibiotic action, relieves congestion in the air passage and aids cancer resistanceIngredients[original recipe from Marshall Cavendish Cookery Books with slight modifications]3 eggs2 tbsp white wine or water1/4 tsp salt to taste1/2 tsp ground black pepper30 gm fresh mint leaves - coarsely chopped30 gm fresh basil leaves - coarsely chopped30 gm fresh coriander leaves - coarsely chopped1 stalk spring onions - coarsely chopped1 tbsp Parmesan cheese powder1-2 tbsp butter or olive oilBeat eggs with water/wine, salt, pepper and cheese. Â Add in all the herbs. Â Stir gently with a fork to mix well.Heat butter/oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat. Â Pour in the mixture, spreading it evenly, cover to cook for 1-2 minutes until the omelette is lightly browned on the underside.Â Flip omelette to cook the other side for 1-2 minutes until the egg is just set.Turn out onto plate and serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and LovageI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4 EventÂ hosted byJoyceÂ ofÂ Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Pandan Lime Jelly Cordial
text: A very nice, aromatic, cold dessert with combination of aromas from pandan leaves, lemongrass, ginger and kaffir lime leaves. Â The texture and taste is quite similar to the Taiwanese dessert called 'Ai Yu'Â [see post here and picture below]Â but this is actually jelly cooked to the same texture.Not too difficult to prepare but definitely refreshing chilled dessert for a warm afternoon.Recipe adapted from Yum Yum MagazineÂ Ingredients - A5 pandan leaves - knotted2 stalks lemongrass - lightly bruised5 cm piece ginger - lightly smashed5 kaffir lime leaves1300 ml waterIngredients - B90 gm instant jelly powder [use either plain or lime flavour jelly powder]75 gm sugarIngredients - C500 ml hot boiling water5 tbsp sugarJuice of 8 calamansi lime [limau kasturi]Â Dissolve sugar in hot boiling water. Â Add in the lime juice. Â Mix well and refrigerate before use.Bring A to boil, then reduce heat to simmer for 45 minutes. Â Strain the liquid. Â The liquid should be about 700-750 ml left.Return to heat and add in B. Â Stir until sugar and jelly powder are dissolved.Pour mixture into a container and allow it to set. Â Refrigerate it.Serve cold by scooping chilled jelly to a serving bowl and drizzle in chilled lime cordial. Â Add some crushed ice if preferred.I'm linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and LovageI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted byÂ JoyceÂ of Â Kitchen Flavours

title: 1:6 WHOLEMEAL CUSTARD STEAMED BAOS
text: Already quite awhile I haven't make wholemeal steamed buns which at a time I used to do with various ratio of wholemeal flour to plain flour. Â  This recipe has a ratio of 1:6 which means 1 portion wholemeal to 6 portions plain flour. Â I used custard filling which is not too sweet for the steamed buns. Â My MIL always commented that store-bought paste are too sweet to her liking, so this one is specially prepared for her which I hope is not that sweet for her.Â Check out these posts if you like to try these steamed buns with various ratios of wholemeal to plain/pau flour.1. Â  Wholemeal Mantou [Steamed Buns]2. Â  Wholemeal Lai Wang Bao3. Â Homemade Burgers4. Â Pandan Wholemeal Steamed Buns5. Â 1:1.5 Wholemeal Steamed Buns6. Â 1:2 Wholemeal Steamed BunsFor making these buns, I have changed the method slightly with just 1 time proofing for 45 minutes from shaping the last piece of bun before steaming. The buns are Â soft and fluffy. Â  I can say that it is perfect.Ingredients[dough weighs 600 - makes 20 pieces x 30gm]50 gm wholemeal flour300Â gmÂ plain flour [you can useÂ pau flour or low protein flour]30Â gm castor sugar1/2 tsp salt1 tsp instant yeast200-210Â ml water20 gmÂ  shorteningÂ [youÂ can useÂ butter or oil]Pau Filling - Custard Filling [recipe below]Combine all the ingredients in a mixing bowl.Â Add in the water gradually and knead at speed 3 [I'm using Kenwood stand mixer] until well mix and soft.Then add in exceptÂ shortening. Â Continue to knead into a soft, smooth and pliable dough. Â  Â The dough should leave the bowl clean and does not stick to the fingers when touch. Â  No need to proof dough at this stage.Bring dough together and roll into a log. Â Divide into 5 equal portions of 120 gm each [I'm making 20 pieces smaller buns, you can make into bigger ones according to own preference]. Â Â Shape each portion into a ball.Divide each portion into 4 equal parts to obtain a total of 20 pieces.Â  Roll the pieces into round balls. Â Flatten each ball into round circles. Â Â Wrap up filling [about 1/2 tbsp]Shape into any shapes preferredÂ [here I shaped them into round and pleated buns].Â Â  Place on parchment paper.Continue doing the same until finish. Â Leave to rest for 45 minutes. Â Â Steam the buns over rapid boiling water for 10-12 minutes. Â  I used an electric steamer to steam the buns from cold water for 12-15 minutes.Serve immediately or cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container [before serving, always reheat buns for 10 minutes cos' buns taste better while hot/warm].Custard Filling[enough for 20 paus]20 gm custard powder30 gm plain flour45 gm cornflour150 gm sugar210 ml milk1 egg - lightly beatenÂ 1 tsp vanilla essence20 gm butterCombine custard powder, cornflour and plain flour in a bowl. Â  Mix well. Â Add in sugar.Gradually stir in the milk. Â Using a hand whisk, stir mixture until sugar dissolves.Â Add in the egg. Â  Stir until mixture is smooth. Â Strain into a saucepan to remove any lumps.Add in vanilla essence and butter. Â Boil mixture over low fire, stirring continously until mixture becomes a thick Â paste.Cool then store in a covered container. Â Refrigerate until required.Notes:Wholemeal Steamed Buns Recipe [from Yum Yum Magazine]Custard Filling Recipe [from Kuali.com with slight modifications]I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted byÂ JoyceÂ of Â Kitchen Flavours

title: Pandan Nasi Lemak
text: Who can resist Nasi Lemak? Â I think many people can't but the main constraint to enjoy a plate of aromatic Nasi Lemak could be the coconut milk. Â Anyway, once in awhile it's okay to forget about that ingredient. Â Because of this negative factor, I for one will choose the best Nasi Lemak to eat.With the LTU's September theme 'Pandan', it give me the boost to cook this Pandan Nasi Lemak again for the family. Â The pandan not only enhance the flavour and aroma, it also adds a little colour for a change to the coconut rice. Â The rice will have a darker colour tone after awhile.I served the Pandan Nasi Lemak with a wide choice of condiments - Sambal Dried Prawns [given by a neighbour], Â Egg Curry [see this post], spicy chilli paste [see this post for recipe], crispy chilli anchovies with peanuts [see recipe here]Â .......etc and of course the sambal belacan to suit your own taste. Â A stir fried lady's finger is also added Â to compliment these dishes. Â There is always a never ending range of dishes that goes well with Nasi Lemak.Egg CurrySpicy chilli pasteCrispy Fried Anchovies with peanutsIngredients[recipe adapted from Amy Beh's Cookbook No.3]450 gm [3 cups] long grain rice - washed and drained2 tbsp oil10 blades screwpine leaves [pandan leaves] - blended with 100 ml water, strain to obtain 150ml pandan juice450 ml water100 ml coconut milk + 1 tsp saltSpices2 cloves garlic with skin - lightly smashed3 shallots - peeled and halved2 cm knob ginger - lightly smashed2 stalks lemongrass - smashed2.5 cm cinnamon stick1 star anise3 cloves3 pods cardamonHeat oil in wok to fry spice ingredients until aromatic. Â Add in the rice.Stir to mix. Â Transfer to rice cooker or steaming tray [if steaming the rice].Add in pandan juice, remaining water and 1/2 portion of coconut milk.Â Cook until rice is done.Add in remaining coconut milk and fork the rice well.Serve hot with any curry dish.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up - September 2013 EventÂ Â organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted by Joceline ofÂ Butter, Flour & MeI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ I'm also linking this post toÂ September 2013 Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and Lovage

title: Coconut Paste Baked Mooncake [2013]
text: This mooncake skin pastry is the same as the one which I used to bake with Pineapple Lotus paste filling [see this post for the preparation]. Â The dough is good, soft and easy to handle. As I mentioned earlier, when baked, it gives a nice colour and does not require egg glaze.Similarly as my previous mooncake, Â I baked a 'flatter' mooncake [1/2 portion] using the normal mooncake mold. Â Pastry for Baked Mooncake[makes 14 pieces - 1/2 portion of the normal size mooncake]220 gm golden syrup90 ml corn oil1.5 tsp alkaline water [kan sui]1/8 tsp bicarbonate of soda300 gm plain flour - sifted [I used superfine flour]Combine all the ingredients [except flour] in a mixing bowl. Â Stir to mix together until well combined. Cover with a cling film wrap and leave aside for at least 5-6 hours or overnight.Give the syrup mixture a good stir before adding flour. Â Mix well but DO NOT Â KNEAD the dough.Cover and set aside for an hour or more before using [I left it overnight].Divide dough into small portions of 50 gm each. Â Wrap with any mooncake filling our your choice.Press dough with filling in a dusted mooncake mold, then knock the sides of the mold gently to dislodge the mooncake. Â Place on baking tray lined with parchment paper.Baked in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown [I omit egg glaze for the mooncake skin]. Â Keep the baked mooncakes in bamboo trays with lid slightly ajar to air for a few days. Â The mooncake skin will soften and taste Â better.Coconut Paste Filling - yields 500 gm pasteIngredients20 gm toasted melon seed [kwa chee]40 gm toasted sesame seeds20 gm milk powder60 gm candied melon [tung kwa] - chopped coarsely35 gm kao fun [cooked glutinous rice flour]1/4 tsp salt250 gm grated white coconut [white portion only]Steam grated coconut for 25-30 minutes until soft. Â Remove and leave to cool completely.Mix together1 1/4 tbsp corn oil1 1/4 tsp water60 gm castor sugarCombine oil, water and sugar in a mixing bowl. Â Stir until sugar dissloves.Add cooled grated coconut and the rest of the ingredients. Â Mix well.Lastly add in kao fun and salt to mix.Divide mixture into small portions.I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted by JoyceÂ of Kitchen Flavours

title: Coconut Paste Figurine Mooncake [2013]
text: The mooncake skin dough from this recipe is soft and easy to handle. Â For more shining look, I suggest it's better to apply egg glaze. Â Here, I didn't use egg glaze, that's why the figurine mooncakes look pale.Ingredients for Mooncake Skin[Recipe adapted from Amy Beh - Kuali .com][makes 36 pieces with Minnie design]350 gm golden syrup90 gm corn oil1 tsp alkaline water400 gm superfine flourCombine golden syrup, oil and alkaline water in a mixing bowl until well mixed. Â Put into a figurine mooncake mould. Â Press in neatly, knock out and place on a baking tray lined with parchment paper leaving some space in between.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown [if not applying egg glaze]. Â Remove to cool on wire rack. Â These mooncakes will soften and taste better after airing them for several days.Note: Â If using egg glaze - bake for 10 minutes, remove from oven and rest for 2 minutes. Â Brush with egg glaze and return to oven to bake for another 7 minutes.Coconut Paste Filling - yields 500 gm pasteIngredients20 gm toasted melon seed [kwa chee]40 gm toasted sesame seeds20 gm milk powder60 gm candied melon [tung kwa] - chopped coarsely35 gm kao fun [cooked glutinous rice flour]1/4 tsp salt250 gm grated white coconut [white portion only]Steam grated coconut for 25-30 minutes until soft. Â Remove and leave to cool completely.Mix together1 1/4 tbsp corn oil1 1/4 tsp water60 gm castor sugarCombine oil, water and sugar in a mixing bowl.
