Â Stir until sugar dissloves.Add cooled grated coconut and the rest of the ingredients. Â Mix well.Lastly add in kao fun and salt to mix.Divide mixture into small portions.I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted by JoyceÂ of Kitchen Flavours

title: Pineapple Paste Mooncake [2013]
text: Time has come again for mooncake making. Â For years, I have been making Snow Skin Mooncakes and Figurine Mooncakes. Â This year, I made some baked mooncakes but only half the size of the usual mooncakes and using the normal mooncake molds.The mooncake skin pastry I use here is soft and easy to handle. Â When baked, it has a nice colour which does not require glazing with egg. Â  Â  Recipe is from Kuali.com.Pastry for Baked MooncakeÂ [makes 14 pieces - 1/2 portion of the normal size mooncake]220 gm golden syrup90 ml corn oil1.5 tsp alkaline water [kan sui]1/8 tsp bicarbonate of soda300 gm plain flour - sifted [I used superfine flour]Combine all the ingredients [except flour] in a mixing bowl. Â Stir to mix together until well combined. Cover with a cling film wrap and leave aside for at least 5-6 hours or overnight.Give the syrup mixture a good stir before adding flour. Â Mix well but DO NOT Â KNEAD the dough.Cover and set aside for an hour or more before using [I left it overnight].Divide dough into small portions of 50 gm each. Â Wrap with any mooncake filling our your choice.Press dough with filling in a dusted mooncake mold, then knock the sides of the mold gently to dislodge the mooncake. Â Place on baking tray lined with parchment paper.Baked in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown [I omit egg glaze for the mooncake skin]. Â Keep the baked mooncakes in bamboo trays with lid slightly ajar to air for a few days. Â The mooncake skin will soften and taste Â better.Pineapple Lotus Paste Filling500 gm lotus paste [store bought]400 gm grated pineapple150 gm castor sugar1/2 tsp lemon juiceCook grated pineapple and sugar in a heavy based saucepan over medium heat until it starts to boil.Reduce heat, add lemon juice, simmer the mixture until dry, thick and paste-like.Dish out to cool completely.Divide pineapple paste into small portions [20 gm], roll into balls. Â Divide lotus paste into 30 gm each.Wrap lotus paste around pineapple paste. Â Roll into a ball. Â Set aside.I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #4Â hosted by JoyceÂ of Kitchen Flavours

title: EZ Family Style Jiu Hoo Char [Stir Fried Yam Bean with Cuttlefish]
text: As I said before, Stir Fry Jicama is always our family favourite vegetable dish and as I mentioned then, the shredded cuttlefish available aren't so good as before. Â  But last weekend, I chanced upon a vendor along the roadside of the wet market selling it. Â The cuttlefish shreds look very fresh and more 'real', so I bought some to cook this dish. Â The cuttlefish does smell like cuttlefish, hehehe! Â You can smell it and tasted fragrant and sweet.The little curly strips in the photos that look like rubber bands are the cuttlefish shreds.Anyway, if you don't like cuttlefish but love Jicama or Sengkuang, perhaps you can try these:1. Â Â Vegetarian Stir Fry Sengkuang;2, Â Â Stir Fry Jicama with Dried Sole3. Â Â Pie Tee FillingIngredients800 gm Jicama [sengkuang] - peeled and finely shredded1 red carrot - peeled and finely shredded2-3 stalks Chinese leeks - finely shredded1 big onion - peeled and thinly sliced150 gm pork belly - blanched in boiling water until firm - cut thin strips100 gm dried cuttlefish shreds - rinsed several times under running water, squeezed dry4 pieces dried mushrooms - soaked, drained and cut thin strips1 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp msg to taste2 tbsp chopped garlic100 ml oilHeat oil, Â fry mushrooms for a few seconds, then add in garlic. Â Fry until aromatic.Add in meat shreds and continue to stir fry for a few seconds.Add in dried cuttlefish shreds. Fry until aromatic.Add in the shredded vegetables [onions, sengkuang and carrots]. Â Stir fry to mix all the ingredients well. Â Keep frying until the vegetables turned limp and cooked through.Add in seasoning.Add in leeks. Â Continue to stir fry vegetables until ingredients are well mixed and leeks are cooked. Â Taste to adjust seasoning.Dish up to serve with rice or wrap it with fresh lettuce leaves.

title: Stir Fry Pumpkin Beehoon [Rice Vermicelli]
text: The previous week was very hectic with much to do here and there. Â Planned to eat out on Saturday night but the thought of my MIL's leg problems and inconvenience in movement, the idea was dropped. Â I ended up cooking this noodle dish which is simple, easy and yet acceptable to my family.Ingredients[serves 4]200 gm rice vermicelli [beehoon] - soaked for 5 minutes, drained in colander200 gm pumpkin - skinned and shredded200 gm meat - cut thin strips2 tbsp Â dried prawns - rinsed and drained1 tbsp chopped garlic1 stalk Chinese celery [kin chye] or spring onions - cut 3 cm lengths [optional]some cut chillies or sambal belacan2 tbsp oil1 cut watersalt, pepper and msg to tastePrepare the ingredients above.Heat oil in wok, saute garlic until aromatic. Â Add in the dried prawns, fry until aromatic. Â Add in meat, continue to fry for a few seconds.Add in the pumpkin, water and seasoning. Â Bring to a boil. Â Put in the noodles. Â Use chopsticks to loosen up the noodles to combine with the rest of ingredients.Cover to cook for a few minutes or until the water has almost dried up and the noodles are soft. Â Add in celery or spring onions.Loosen the noodles again using the chopsticks and pan turner.Dish out to serve with cut chillies or sambal belacan.Notes: Visit this site for it's Nutritional FactsÂ [here]

title: Hoo Pioh Th'ng [Fish Maw Soup]
text: This recipe is from the book 'At Home With Amy Beh 2'. Â It is quite a common soup which my MIL used to cook during CNY. Â  Â Quite a costly soup because of the fish maw if it is a quality type. Â Here I used the ready fried fish bladder. Â It just needs to be soaked until soft, then cut into bite size pieces and it' s ready for cooking.A very clear and light soup which is not oily at all using meat and prawn balls instead of chicken.According to Amy Beh, this is a hearty and nutritious nyonya home style soup that is popular with the Hokkiens. Â This soup is served during wedding lunches on a long table [t'ng tok] together with other favourite nyonya dishes.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Amy Beh 2 with some modifications]40 gm fish maw/dried fish bladder/hoo pioh500 gm chicken - chopped chunky pieces [I used meat and prawn balls] -Â Recipe for Meatballs here100 gm gingko nuts - shelled and skinned [see post on How to prepare gingko nuts]Â 100 gm jicama - cut thick slices5-6 water chestnuts - sliced1 canned button mushrooms - halved1 small red carrot - cut thick slices [optional]2.5 litres water1 tbsp sesame oilsalt and msg to tasteTie in a muslin bag the following ingredients1 bulb garlic - with skina few slices of ginger1 tsp peppercorns - lightly crushedSoak the fish bladder in cold water until soft. Â Squeeze dry and cut into bite size pieces.Bring water to boil in a big soup pot with the muslin bag. Â Simmer the soup for 20 minutes.Add in the water chestnuts and sengkuang. Â The add in the fish maw.Bring soup to boil and add in the meat balls to cook. Â Lastly add in the gingko nuts and mushrooms.Add seasoning to taste. Â Bring soup to boil again. Â Off heat.Serve soup hot immediately.Note:If using chicken, add the chicken at Step 2. Â If using meat and prawn balls, see recipe below.Ingredients for Meat and Prawn Balls100 gm shelled prawns - finely chopped100 gm meat or chicken fillet - finely choppedmarinate with some pepper, salt, sugar, sesame oil and cornflour.Â  Mix well and refrigerate while you prepare the other ingredients.Scoop prawn and meat ball mixture into balls with a wet metal spoon into boiling soup to cook for 1-2 minutes.Â I'm Â linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #3 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Sri Lankan Curry Chicken
text: Since cooking the Sri Lankan Curry Fish [see post]Â which was yummy delicious, I thought it would be good to try the chicken curry which I saw at Veronica's Kitchen. Â  Next in line would be prawn or may be mixed vegetables...The curry is good, very aromatic, slightly spicy, sourish and the gravy is of quite thick consistency. Â Great with rice and I think should be good with bread too. Â Confirmed by my hubby's siblings, the curry is good.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Veronica's KitchenÂ with some modifications]Curry PasteÂ [mix other ingredients to blended onion and garlic together]1 onion - cut small pieces4 cloves garlic - cut small pieces4 slices ginger10 dried chillies - soaked and deseeded1 red chilli - cut small pieces [optional]blend the above ingredients in a processor until fine. Â Mix with the powdered ingredients and set aside.Powdered Spice Ingredients2 tbsp coriander powder1 tsp tumeric powder1 tbsp cumin powder1 tsp fennel powderAromatics:1 onion - sliced4 green small chillies - sliced4 sprigs curry leaves1 1/2 tsp fenugreek and mustard seeds1 kg chicken [I used meaty chicken thighs] - cut into chunks and marinate with 1 1/2 tsp tumeric powder, 2 tsp vinegar or lime juice and some blended curry paste3 tbsp oil500 ml water or thin coconut milk [Iused 400 ml water]125 ml thick coconut milk or milk [I used 50 ml]1 tsp each of salt and sugar to tasteHeat oil in pan, fry aromatics until fragrant. Â Add in curry paste.Â  Fry until oil separates and aromatic. Â Add in the marinated chicken.Continue to stir fry until the chicken is well coated with curry paste and firm.Add in water or thin coconut milk. Â Bring to boil, lower heat to simmer until is tender [about 10-15 minutes].Add in milk or thick coconut milk and seasoning to taste.Dish up to serve with rice. Â This curry is more flavourful and tasted better after some time.

title: Fried Egg With Salted Mustard Leaves [Kiam Chye]
text: Another quite unusual omelette recipe which was published in Marshall Cavendish Â table calendar years ago. Â The previous unusual egg recipe from the same calendar was posted several days agoÂ [Spicy Salted Eggs].Â Month end is coming soon and I think my egg-tion must cease too. Â I'll definitely sit back to enjoy all the wonderful recipes shared in this month's LTU event.I can say this is the first time, I'm frying omelette with preserved mustard leaves [salted leaves - kiam chye - hum choy]. Â Very simple recipe and not much ingredients but this omelette is egg-cellent.Â Ingredients[serves 2-4]100 gm preserved salted vegetables - kiam chye - julienned and soaked for 5 minutes. Â Drain and squeeze dry2 cloves garlic - chopped1 red chillies - deseeded and julienned1 sprig coriander leaves - chopped150 gm small prawns - shelled and cleaned2 - 3 tbsp oil2 large eggs - lightly beaten with 1/2 tsp salt and ground black pepper. Add in chopped corianderHeat a non stick pan on medium low heat. Â Fry julienned salted vegetables for a few second. Â Push aside, add in oil. Â Fry garlic.Add in chilli and mix with vegetables.Pour in beaten eggs, swirl pan to form a round omelette. Â Before top of egg is cooked, add prawns. Â Cook for about 2 minutes.Flip the omelette over and cook through. Â Cut up roughly with ladle and serve.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart OutI'm also Â linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #3 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Basil Omelette
text: Egg-cellent omelette with simple ingredients. Â Very fragrant and aromatic basil leaves and crispy fried garlic and ginger make this omelette, hmmm ... delicious with rice or on its own.Ingredients[recipe from Kuali.com]4 eggs - lightly beaten with 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp pepper and 1 tsp shaoxing wineA bunch of fresh basil leaves - plucked, rinsed, drained and chopped2 tbsp minced ginger1 tbsp minced garlic1-2 tbsp oil1 tsp sesame oil and 1 tsp oilHeat sesame oil and oil in a non stick pan to saute garlic and ginger until golden and crispy. Â Dish out.Mix basil leaves with beaten eggs.Heat oil in pan over medium low heat. Â Pour in egg mixture [can fry in 2 batches].Leave to fry gently until done. Â  Flip half omelette to make a half moon and fry until omelette is cooked through.Cut into triangle slices with the wok turner. Â Dish out on serving plate.Top with fried crispy ginger and garlic before serving.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart OutI'm Â also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #3 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ I'm also linking this post toÂ September 2013 Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and Lovage

title: NYONYA HONG BAK [BRAISED PORK BELLY]
text: Such a familiar name in the Peranakan cuisine, a dish which I have eaten very often during the time when my grandma was still around. Â This dish disappeared from our home after her passing, very sad isn't it? Â During the recent ancestral worship, I looked up the recipe in 'Nyonya Flavour' book and found this wonderful recipe.My hubby's siblings confirmed it is good and suggested that I should prepare this dish for family gatherings.The 'hong bak' meaning fragrant meat, I think is really fragrant and aromatic. Â The sauce is thick and very full of flavours and aroma. Â Siang, siang, siang....Phang, phang, phang...Ingredients[recipe adapted from Nyonya Flavours with some modifications]Spice Paste - Ground100 gm [10] shallots25 gm [3 cloves] garlic5 gm [2 pieces] cekur roots20 gm [3 tbsp] coriander powder1/2 tsp pepper1 tbsp fine taucheo [preserved bean paste]450 gm pork belly - cut big chunks [can use pig trotters]2 potatoes - peeled and cut wedges2 tbsp oil1 tbsp dark soy sauce2 tbsp sugar1 tsp salt to taste1- 1 1/2 cups waterHeat oil in wok, saute spice paste until aromatic.Add in the pork belly. Â Stir fry until meat is firm and well coated with paste. Â Add in the seasoning.Pour in water [enough to cover meat]. Â Bring to boil, then lower heat to simmer for 20-25 minutes until meat is tender but not soft.Add in the potatoes, stir and continue to simmer for 20 minutes until the potatoes and meat are soft.The dish can be served warm anytime with plain white rice and other nyonya dishes.I'm  linking this post to Cook Your Books #3 Event  hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: MILK TEA [TEH TARIK] COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: There were several packets of Lipton Milk Tea sachets lying in the kitchen cabinet, soon expiring. Â I remembered baking the Vietnamese Coffee Cottony CakeÂ [see posting on this cake here]Â where I used the 3 in 1 Vietnamese coffee as flavour. Â So I used the similar recipe to bake this cake with tea flavour.The cake turns out well - soft and spongy. Â Good cake.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use Â 9" square tin]65 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg60 ml corn oil1 sachet of 3 in 1 [30g/sachet] Lipton Milk Tea dissolve with 80 ml hot water - set aside to coolPlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil and milk tea mixture.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Smooth the surface with a spatula and steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be soggy after baking].Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate before slicing to serve later.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart Out

title: Palm Sugar Roasted Pork Belly
text: Shared this recipe with a neighbour and showed her how to cook it. Â It was so lovely that I was tempted to make a portion for my family. Â The method is quite similar to Wendy's recipe but I did some adjustments to suit my family's taste. They prefer stronger flavours.Gravy obtained from braising of the meat. Â Good to spread over plain white rice like the gravy from the Char Siew Rice stalls.Ingredients[original recipe from Yum Yum Magazine 72 with some changes]600 gm pork belly Â [4 inches in length and about 1/2 inch thick slices]1 tbsp grated garlic2 tsp 5 spice powder [good quality type]1/2 tsp pepper4Â tbsp soy sauce1-2 tsp dark soy sauce50-80Â gm palm sugar [2 pieces round gula melaka about 40 gm/piece]1/2 tbsp of rose wine [mei hua lou]500 ml water [or enough to cover meat]Marinate meat slices with all ingredients [except palm sugar and rose wine] for at least 1/2 an hour or several hours.Put all ingredients [except palm sugar] in a wok. Â Add in enough water to cover the meat [more if you like to have some gravy]. Â Bring it to a boil then lower heat and to simmer for 10-15 minutes. Â Turn over meat slices and boil for a further 10-15 minutes or until the meat is almost tender.Add in palm sugar and continue to boil until gravy is reduced and thick like honey.Keep stirring to prevent meat getting burnt.Dish out to cool before cutting to serve Â with sliced cucumber and white rice.I'm  linking this post to Cook Your Books #3 Event  hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Pie Tee Filling
text: I love Pie Tee and the vegetable filling but I'm too lazy to make the pie tee shells. Â Before CNY, ready fried Pie Tee shells are sold in some wet markets. Since it isn't CNY, I just prepared the vegetable filling and enjoyed it with fresh lettuce leaves. Â It's quite similar to most of the stir fried jicama recipes. Â The difference is probably the portion of the various ingredients used. Â Crab meat can also be used to substitute prawns if you like.Ingredients[recipe adapted from an article written by Ivy Soon published in the Star newspaper]200 gm prawns - shelled and coarsely chopped150 gm lean or fatty pork - blanched and cut thin strips [optional]5-6 mushrooms - soaked and sliced thinly2 pieces firm beancurd -julienned and fried until firm2-3 tbsp oil3-4 garlic - finely choppedÂ 800 gm sengkuang [yambean] - cut thin shreds1 carrot - cut thin shreds2 leeks - sliced thinly200 gm French beans - sliced thinlysalt, msg and pepper to tastePrepare ingredients as above.Heat oil in wok, saute mushrooms, add garlic. Â Saute until aromatic, add in prawns. Â Stir fry and add in meat. Â Stir to mix.Add in the sengkuang and carrot. Â Stir to mix and fry until vegetables are limp. Add in fried beancurd.Add seasoning to taste, then add in leeks and french beans. Â Continue stir frying until vegetables are cooked.Dish out to serve with pie tee shells or fresh lettuce leaves.I'm Â linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #3 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Fried Crispy Garlic Pork Belly
text: Quite similar to Fried Nam Yee Pork but with a slight adjustment to the marinade. But it tasted much better than the nam yee pork. Â Here garlic is added to marinate the meat.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum magazine 85]800 gm pork belly Â [4 inches in length and about 1/2 inch thick slices]1/2 tbsp grated garlic1 piece taucheo [fermented beancurd]1/2 tsp 5 spice powder [good quality type]1 tsp salt1 tbsp sugar1 tbsp each of sesame oil and wine3 tbsp cornfloursome oil enough to pan fry meat slicesMarinate meat slices with all the ingredients except oil for at least an hour.Heat enough oil in a non stick pan. Â Place marinated meat slices to fry until crispy on one side.Flip over to fry the other side until golden brown and crispy at the sides.Dish out. Â Cool slightly and cut thin slices before serving.I'm  linking this post to Cook Your Books #3 Event  hosted by Kitchen Flavours

title: RED BEAN COCONUT MILK COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Still having 1/2 a Â packet of dessicated coconut in my fridge and some coconut milk left from cooking the Egg Curry. Â Instead for freezing the milk for later use, I used it to bake this cake and added red bean paste too. Â See how the cake looks?Of course, this cake tasted 'lemak' with the coconut milk. Â Overall result - it is nice, soft, spongy flavourful cake. Â I increased the salt to bring out the coconut flavour.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use Â 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/2 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg45 ml corn oil80 ml coconut milk2 tbsp red bean paste [optional]2 tbsp dessicated coconut [have some extra to sprinkle on top of cake]Whisk eggs in a mixing bowl until creamy. Â Drizzle in corn oil followed by coconut milk. Â Mix in the red bean paste if using. Â Continue beating until well combined. Â Add in the flour, salt and dessicated coconut. Â Using a paddle hook, fold until batter is smooth. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar70-80 gm castor sugar Â [reduced by 1 tbsp if using sweet red bean paste]Using an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out evenly. Â Steam bake on the lower rack in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be soggy after baking].Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or chill in the refrigerator before slicing to be serves later.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up August Theme - Eggs organised by Zoe of Bake for Happy Kids and Doreen of My Little Favourite DIY and hosted by Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart Out

title: Chicken with White Fungus Soup
text: This is a very easy soup to cook which does not require specific amount of ingredients. Â You can add or reduce the amount of the ingredients according to your preference. Â For this soup, I simply mix and match the ingredients according to how many people I'm serving this soup.I cooked this soup at my MIL's place and I didn't have much time to take step by step photos on the preparations. Â Moreover, I had many other dishes to cook during that time. Â It's a light soup Â and I just love the clarity of the soup, not oily at all. Â Dipped the chicken pieces in soy sauce before eating it brings out the sweetness of the meat.Ingredients3 chicken thighs - cut big chunks [with or without skin]3-4 chicken wings - discard the end tip and cut at the joints10 gm white fungus - soaked to fluff up - break into florets1 can mushrooms - halved [use either straw or button mushrooms]a handful of red dates - rinsedsome garlic - keep whole with skin1/2 tbsp white peppercorns - lightly smashedsalt and chicken stock granules to taste1.5 litres water [adjust accordingly]Pour water into soup pot, add in f\garlic and peppercorns. Â Bring to boil, then add in white fungus, continue to boil for 15-20 minutes or until the soup is fragrant.Add in the chicken pieces and red dates. Â Continue boiling over medium heat until chicken is tender [about 10 minutes]. Â Add seasoning to taste.Cover, off heat. Â Serve soup hot.

title: Marbled 5 Spice Tea Eggs
text: This article about E-g-g [EGG] was written by Lim Hong Meng and shared with readers of Home Cooking magazine dated back to 1999. Â I have almost a complete series of these magazines since then until it cessation around 2004. Â I have kept this collection with the aim to know more about food preparation, kitchen tips and restaurant outlets. However, the main purpose is to try some of the wonderful recipes shared in these magazines when I retire from work...hehehe! Â it's a long wait.I have summarised the article and just sharing some main points about this simple word 'EGG'. Â It is probably the most loved food in the world. Â Found in every kitchen of every cuisine and ranks one of the most nutritional food known to mankind.The Healthy Egg- rich in high quality proteins [9 essential amino acids];- has significant number of vitamins [A,D,E and B12] and minerals[riboflavin, iron, zinc, folic acid and phosphorus]. Â These nutrients are important in promoting good vision, maintaining healthy skin, improving resistance to infection, building healthy red blood cells and maintaining the central nervous systems, etc.- has a very small amount of fat that helps the body to absorb fat soluble vitamins [ADEK], makes hormones and bile acids.Eggs are essential helpers in the preparation of food. Â They are use to:- thicken custards and sauces;- leaven souffles and cakes;- binds meat;- stabilise emulsions such as mayonnaise.Beyond the Dining Table [Uses of eggs]- for hair and skin care [excellent toner for oily skin];- eggshells can be used to clean the insides of glass bottles and jars, remove smell or odour from them;- water from boiling of eggs can be used to water houseplants when cooled. Â The minerals in the water is great growth booster for plants.From a simple EGG, great dishes have been born irrespective of the cooking methods - boiled, steamed, deep fried, pan fried, stir fried or baked.Anyway, this post is also about Tea Eggs, the recipe shared with this article which I prepared to share with LTU - Eggs theme. Â This dish makes an excellent cold Â or warm appetiser.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Home Cooking Magazine April 1999 with some modifications]1 dozen eggs - cleanedPlace eggs in a saucepan. Â Cover with cold water and add some salt. Â Bring the water to boil slowly. Â Stir the eggs with a pair of chopsticks in a circular motion continuously while the water comes to a boil [this is done so that the egg yolks with be in the centre of the egg white when cooked].When the water boils [stop the stirring], reduce the heat and simmer for 15 minutes. Â Drain and leave the eggs to cool.Using the back of a spoon, crack eggs all over but do not remove the shells.Place cracked eggs in a saucepan again. Â Add in the tea leaves and all Â the ingredients below. Â Pour in enough water to cover the eggs.Boil for 1 hour on medium low heat. Â Drain and serve either warm or cold.1 piece cinnamon stick2 star anise3 cloves3 pieces dong quai [optional]1 tsp 5 spice powder1 tbsp salt1 tbsp sugar3 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp dark soy saucea few slice ginger [optional]I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart OutI'm also sharing this post Â withÂ Cook Your Books #3 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Spicy Salted Eggs
text: I find this recipe a very unusual way of serving salted eggs. Â The recipe was published in a table calendar years ago. Â Have you come across eating hard boiled salted eggs with spicy sauce?You can actually prepare the chilli sauce earlier, reheat when required and pour on to hard boiled salted eggs before serving. Â This sauce is good on its own with rice as it is very tasty [spicy, sourish sweet taste].I didn't make the salted eggs Â for this recipe. Â Please refer to these posts Â [2 ways to make salted eggs]Â if you wish to prepare your own salted eggs.Ingredients[serves 5]5 hard boiled salted eggs - peeled and halved1 medium size onion - peeled and sliced into ringsspring onions - sliced slantwise for garnish2 tbsp cooking oilPaste Ingredients [blended and mix]1 onion - peeled3 shallots - peeled2 cloves garlic - peeled1 tbsp chilli paste1 tbsp fennel powderSeasoning2 tbsp each of Hoisin sauce and chilli sauce2 tsp palm sugar80-100 ml waterJuice of 1 limesalt to tasteHeat oil in wok, saute blended paste until aromatic. Â Add in hoisin and chilli sauce followed by water.Stir until gravy boils. Â Reduce heat, then add in onions, palm sugar and salt to taste.Stir for 2-3 minutes until oil rises to the top. Â Remove from heat, stir in lime juice.Place salted eggs on a serving platter. Â Pour on gravy. Â Garnish with spring onions. Â Serve with rice.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart OutI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #3 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Tamarind Curry Fish with Pineapples
text: One healthy kind of sourish curry that does not require cooking with oil. Â This dish was categorised as Perak food in the book 'Rasa Malaysia' by Betty Saw.The original recipe uses Spanish Mackerel slices but I'm using Threadfin fish/Ikan Senangin [from my hubby's fishing trip]. Â  Of course the fish tasted good being freshly caught but the curry gravy is also good with the sweet flavour from the pineapple when cooked till tender becomes sweet and flavourful.IngredientsÂ 450 gm Spanish mackerel slices - washed and seasonedÂ with 1/2 tsp salt [I used Ikan Senangin/Threadfin]2 pieces tamarind slices [assam keping]625 ml water1/2 pineapple - cut small pieces2 tsp sugar1 tsp saltBlended Ingredients4 red chillies - deseeded/cut4 small red chillies2 stalks lemongrass1 tsp tumeric powder [or 1 cm piece fresh tumeric]Season fish with salt.Boil blended ingredients with water. Â Add in the tamarind slices, lower heat to simmer for 10 minutes.Add in the pineapple, continue to simmer until pineapples are tender [about 5 minutes] and curry is aromatic.Add in the fish slices and seasoning to taste. Â Cook for 5-10 minutes until fish is cooked.Serve curry hot with rice.I'm Â submitting this to Â Malaysian Food Fest [August 2013] PerakÂ hosted byÂ Â Wendyinkk of Table for 2...or moreI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #3 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: APPLE JAM COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Made some apple jam the other day and had some extra left which couldn't be stored in the jar. Â So I used it [about 2-3 tbsp] to bake this cake. Â Since the apple jam is sweet, I reduced the sugar in the egg whites from 80 gm to 60 gm.The cake turns out perfect without any cracks, soft, light and fluffy. Â I added some poppy seeds but it's optional. Â The cakes tasted good with a slight aroma of lemon and cinnamon [the jam flavours].Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[using 8" or 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted and a pinch of cinnamon powder1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg60 ml corn oil2-3 tbsp apple jamÂ [see recipe here]60 ml milkPlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil, apple jam and milk.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar60 gm castor sugarÂ using an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Smooth the surface with a spatula or just lightly shake the baking pan [the batter will spread out evenly].Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes. Â Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate before slicing to serve later.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart Out

title: Fried Lady's Finger [Vegetarian]
text: A simple stir fry vegetarian lady's finger [Okra] which I served with egg curry [see this post]Â and rice.Ingredients300 gm lady's fingers - washed, drained and cut into diagonal slices3 shallots - peeled and sliced3 cloves garlice - skinned and sliced3 dried chillies - cut into 2 cm pieces - washed1 tbsp cooking oil1 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1 tsp light soy saucea dash of pepper1 tbsp waterHeat oil in wok, fry shallots, garlic and dried chillies until slightly crisp.Add in cut vegetables. Â Stir fry to mix. Â Add in the sauces and water.Allow to cook for 1-2 minutes until vegetables turn dark green.Season with pepper and dish out to serve.

title: Egg Curry
text: This is nice simple curry which I have cooked several times. Â The recipe was adapted from Faridah Begum shared in the local newspaper. Â The curry base is also suitable for cooking seafood [fish/prawns and squids].IngredientsEggs [any number - I cooked 4 eggs]2 tbsp fish curry powder1 tbsp kurma curry powder [I replace with 1 tsp each of cumin and fennel powder]salt to taste1 onion - sliced1 sprig curry leaves1/2 tbsp fenugreek or halba1-2 tbsp cooking oil1 cup water1 cup coconut milk or milk or yoghurt1 tomato - cut into wedges1 green chilli - halved and seededsome coriander leaves- cut into 1 inch lengthsMix both curry powders and salt with some water into a paste.Heat oil in a pot, saute onions, fenugreek and curry leaves until aromatic. Â Add in curry paste.Fry until oil separates, pour in water and milk. Â Bring to boil.Break one egg at a time into a small bowl. Â Slide each egg into the curry from the sides of the pot.Reduce heat and let the eggs cook for about 3-5 minutes before stirring the curry.Add in the tomatoes and chilli. Â Simmer for another 1-2 minutes. Â Add in the coriander leaves.Serve with rice.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart Out

title: Stir Fry Jicama with Dried Sole
text: Stir fry Jicama [sengkuang] with pnee hoo [dried sole] is now our family favourite instead of the traditional Jiu Hoo Char. Â We called it Pnee Hoo Bangkwang Char. Believe me this is delicious too. Â Nowadays, my mum and MIL prefer to use fried dried sole [pnee hoo] to fry this vegetable as we discovered that some cuttlefish shreds sold at the wet markets are not as tasty as before.Ingredients800 gm Jicama [sengkuang] - peeled and finely shredded200 gm cabbage - washed and finely shredded1 red carrot - peeled and finely shredded200 gm Chinese leeks - finely shredded [optional]250 gm pork belly - blanched in boiling water until firm - cut thin strips100 gm dried sole [pnee hoo] - rinsed and dried, cut small pieces4 pieces dried mushrooms - soaked, drained and cut thin stripssalt and msg to taste2 tbsp chopped garlic100 ml oilFry dried sole in oil until golden and crispy. Â  Dish out to cool before pounding it into fine bits. Â This can be prepared earlier and stored.Heat oil, Â fry meat until oil oozes out. Â Add mushrooms, fry for a minute, the add in garlic. Â Fry until aromatic.Add in the shredded vegetables [except leeks]. Â Stir fry to mix all the ingredients well. Â Keep frying until the vegetables turned limp and cooked through.Add in pnee hoo, seasoning and leeks [if using]. Â Continue to stir fry vegetables until ingredients are well mixed and leeks are cooked. Â Taste to adjust seasoning.Dish up to serve with rice or wrap it with fresh lettuce leaves.Note: Â The photos taken are not that good cos' this dish was cooked at my MIL's kitchen [in a hurry as there were quite a number of dishes to cook on that day].

title: Aromatic Tom Yum Omelette
text: Tasted this omelette at the super mart promoting Tom Yum paste. Â It was aromatic with kaffir lime leaves and the main seasoning is fish sauce. Â The spiciness can be adjusted according to own preference [add more tom yum paste but add just a little fish sauce as some store bought Tom Yum paste could be rather salty].Ingredients[makes 3 pieces omelette]2 eggs10 pieces kaffir lime leaves - remove center stems and finely shredded1/2 tsp tom yum paste [not spicy with this amount]fish sauce and a dash of msg to taste1/2 tsp cornflourMix all ingredients [except eggs] together. Â Then beat in the eggs.Heat up a non stick pan with some oil. Â Pour in 1/3 of the egg mixture.Fry until firm and slightly golden around the edges.Flip over to fry the other side until golden and omelette is cooked.Dish up to serve with rice or sandwich bread.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up August Theme - Eggs organised by Zoe of Bake for Happy Kids and Doreen of My Little Favourite DIY and hosted by Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart OutI'm submitting this post to Asian Food Fest - November 2013hosted by Lena of Frozen Wings

title: ALMOND COCONUT COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: There was a packet of dessicated coconut left in my pantry for months which has to be cleared. Â  So I used it Â for this cottony cake which is soft Â and moist. Â The almond flavour is not very intense with the first bite but the dessicated coconut is more noticeable. Â Overall, it is yummy cottony cake with a bite.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use Â or 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg50-60 ml corn oil80 ml almond milk [dissolve 3 tbsp almond powder with 80 ml hot water/milk] - cooled2 tbsp dessicated coconut [have some extra to sprinkle on top of cake]Whisk eggs in a mixing bowl until creamy. Â Drizzle in corn oil followed by almond liquid. Â Continue beating until well combined. Â Add in the flour and salt. Â Using a paddle hook, fold until batter is smooth. Â  Then fold in the dessicated coconut. Â Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar70-80 gm castor sugar [I used 65 gm cos' almond liquid is sweet]Â Using an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out evenly. Â Sprinkle some extra dessicated coconut evenly over batter.Steam bake on the lower rack in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be soggy after baking].Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or chill in the refrigerator before slicing to be serves later.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ August Theme - EggsÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Baby Sumo of Eat Your Heart Out

title: Dong Quai Spinach Soup
text: This soup was prepared the same time I cooked the Chicken in Special Sauce [see recipe here]. Â I used the stock from boiling of the chicken to cook this herbal soup which was good. Â  Simple, easy and at least the stock is put to use.Ingredients300 gm spinach - washed and separate leaves with stems700 ml chicken stock [from Chicken in Special Sauce]3-4 slices dong quai [angelica roots]1 tbsp kei chi [wolfberries]salt and msg to tasteBring stock from boiling chicken to boil. Â Add in the dong quai pieces and simmer until the soup is fragrant. Â Add in seasoning to taste.Add in spinach to boiling stock before serving. Â Boil until vegetables are cooked. Â Add in kei chi and serve hot with rice and chicken dish.I'm linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and Lovage

title: Long Beans Rice
text: Am I getting lazy these days? Â Preparing mostly 1 Dish Meal. Â Actually I'm not but very tired. Â I have to travel here and there to my mum and MIL's place during different days of the week. Â These visits require me either to help clean Â or cook at their places which is really tiring. Â This one pot rice is prepared at my MIL's place for Saturday dinner. Â  I Â haven't the time to prepare anything elaborate cos' I have first to clean up her place when we arrive on Saturday afternoons for the weekend stay over. Â Anyway, having this for dinner at home is much better than eating out. Â Usually, I damned tired to get out of the house after the putting her place in order. Â My MIL is recovering from a fractured wrist.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum magazine with slight modifications]Â 250 gm pork belly - skin removed, cut into small pieces [season with some light soy sauce]200 gm long beans - diced1 tbsp chopped garlic300 gm rice - washed and drained600 ml water1/2 tbsp oilsome sesame oilsome chopped spring onionsSeasoning1/2 tsp each of salt and pepper2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy saucea dash msg to tasteHeat oil in wok, pan fry seasoned pork belly until the oil oozes out and aromatic. Â Push aside, add in chopped garlic. Â Fry until fragrant.Add in the rice and seasoning. Â Stir well to mix then add in the long beans. Â Fry for several seconds to mix ingredients.Transfer to a deep steaming pot, add water. Â Place pot in another big pot and steam for 30 minutes over medium high heat until cooked. Â Off heat and leave to rest for 5-10 minutes before fluffing up to serve.Garnish with chopped spring onions and serve with cut chillies.NotesYou can cook the fried rice in a rice cooker. Â I prefer to steam the rice because it will not stick to the steaming pot. Â I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Chicken with Special Ginger Sauce
text: I can kill two birds with one stone with this chicken dish. Â Simply cook the chicken thighs in boiling water then use the stock to prepare a vegetable soup [see recipe here]. Â Chopped up the chicken thighs and serve with this special ginger/black vinegar sauce and plain white rice. Â Isn't it simple enough dinner for a family of 3 on a busy weekday?Really yummylicious boiled chicken. Â Great with this sauce.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum magazine with slight modifications]3 pieces meaty chicken thighs - fats and some skin removedÂ Dipping Sauce [mixed together]3 tbsp black vinegar1 tbsp shaoxing wine1-1/2 tbsp sugar1 tsp salt2 tbsp water2 tbsp chopped gingerÂ 1 red chilli - seeded and chopped2 stalks of coriander leaves - choppedBring a pot of water enough to cook chicken pieces to boil. Â Put in chicken thighs. Â Let the water boils again. Â Cover, off heat and leave chicken pieces in the water for 15-20 minutes.Remove and set aside. Â Put all the sauce ingredients in a small mixing bowl. Â Mix together.Cut chicken pieces into bite size pieces. Â Place on serving plate.Pour sauce ingredients over chicken and serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Vegetarian Mixed Vegetable Curry
text: The original version of this curry [from Yum Yum magazine No. 72] is without shallots [a vegetarian version for religious purpose]. Â Here, I added shallots/onions to this curry cos' it is not for religious vegetarian diet. Â By adding shallots, the curry will be thicker and more fragrant.IngredientsCurry Paste [Blended and Mix with powdered ingredients]4 red chillies10 dried chillies - soaked3 lemongrass5 candlenuts [buah keras]100 gm shallots [optional]3 tbsp meat curry powder2-3 tsp mixed halba1 tbsp coriander powder1/2 tbsp tumeric powder4-5 tbsp cooking oil250 gm cabbage - washed and break into pieces1 carrot - peeled and cut wedges1 eggplant - washed and cut thick wedges150 gm long beans - washed and cut 4 cm length200 gm tofu pok [tofu puff]2 pandan leaves - washed and knotted5-6 kaffir lime leaves - stems removed1200 ml waterSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 1/2 tsp salt1/2 tbsp sugar1200 ml water150 ml thick coconut milk [1 used 135 ml plain yoghurt]Heat up oil, saute aromatic, spices and curry paste until fragrant and oil separates.Add vegetables, seasoning and stir fry to mix ingredients well. Â Add in water.Bring to boil and cook until vegetables are tender. Â Add in tofu puffs and coconut milk or yoghurt.Bring to boil and off heat. Â Stir in the kaffir lime leaves.Dish out to serve with plain rice.I'm linking this post to Cook Your Books #2 Event  hosted by Kitchen Flavours

title: Prawns in Plum Sauce
text: There was so much of Â big prawns in my MIL's fridge which I need to clear. Â I wouldn' t want to eat Assam Prawns or Sambal Udang Â all the time, so why not give this a try. Â Moreover, I can share this recipe with 3 food events hosted by fellow food bloggers this July.Again this is another dish which I didn't know which is considered as Selangor/KL food until I saw it in this book 'Rasa Malaysia'.Ingredients500 gm big sea prawns - washed and dried3 tbsp oil5cm piece ginger - chopped4-5 cloves garlic - choppedsome chopped coriander leaves and spring onionsSeasoning Sauce [combined]1 tbsp each of dark soy sauce, light soy sauce and sugar1 tsp salt2-3 tbsp plum sauceHeat oil in wok, fry prawns until they turned red. Â Dish out and leave enough oil to fry ginger and garlic until aromatic and brown.Return the fried prawns and toss well to mix with the seasoning sauce. Â Stir well and add in the chopped coriander leaves and spring onions.Serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen FlavoursÂ Â I 'm also submitting this post toÂ Malaysian Food FestÂ Kuala Lumpur Selangor MonthÂ hosted byÂ Shannon of Just As Delish

title: Steamed Sliced Pork with Fu Yee
text: Another steamed meat dish with easily available seasoning sauce that you have in the kitchen. Â Simple and aromatic meat good to serve with plain white rice.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum magazine - slightly modified]250 gm lean pork - thinly sliced1 tbsp finely shredded ginger2-3 stalks spring onion - shreddedMarinating Sauce3 pieces fermented beancurd [fu yee]1 tsp each of sugar and sesame oil1 tbsp each of shaoxing wine and light soy sauce1 tsp cornfloura dash of pepperMix all ingredients and marinating sauce for at least an hour.Place on steaming place with some spring onion.Steam over high heat for 10 minutes or until meat is cooked.Garnish with extra spring onions and serve with rice.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: OREO BISCUIT COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Cottony cake with Oreo biscuits. Â Hope it turn out well. Â How much of it must I add? Â How to decide.....hmm guess best to do it piece by piece. Â That's what I did. Â Remove the cream from the biscuits [save it to whisk with the egg yolks and reduce the sugar Â in the egg whites]. Â Piece by piece, crushed them and 5 pieces should be enough cos' if too much the cake may have the 'dirty' look. Â Moreover, I'll be sharing the cake with my MIL who doesn't like cakes that looks 'dark'.The cake turns out perfect ..... spongy soft and the sweetness is just nice.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[use Â or 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg50 ml corn oilCream from the 5 pieces Oreo biscuits80 ml milk + 1 tsp vanilla essence5 pieces Oreo biscuit - crushedWhisk eggs and biscuit cream in a mixing bowl until creamy. Â Drizzle in corn oil followed by milk. Â Continue beating until well combined. Â Add in the flour and salt. Â Using a paddle hook, fold until batter is smooth. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar60 gm castor sugarÂ Using an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Add in the crushed biscuits. Â  Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out evenly.Â Steam bake on the lower rack in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be soggy after baking].Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate before slicing if serving later.

title: Pumpkin Kuih Ee in Brown Sugar Syrup
text: This Kuih Ee recipe was inspired by Joceline ofÂ Butter, Flour and Me. Â The pumpkin glutinous rice balls looks simple yet yummy. Â But here I have slightly modified the preparation to suit my family's preference. Â  I reduced the water in the syrup cos' kuih ee tastes better and keeps well in sweeter soup.My family will prepare this dumpling soup for prayers on mid [15th day] of the 6th lunar calender month. Â The usual Kuih Ee has several colours but this time, I thought it would be good just to make a simple one with pumpkin and brown sugar ginger syrup. Â The method to prepare the syrup was from a TV cook show which suggested that caramelising the brown sugar slightly will make the syrup more fragrant.My opinion - it is good, the rice balls are soft and chewy and the soup has the caramelised aroma of the brown sugar and ginger.Ingredients200 gm glutinous rice flour120 gm steamed mashed pumpkinÂ 2 tsp brown sugar80-100 ml water [depends on the pumpkin]Brown Sugar Syrup140 gm brown sugar [I used 50/50 of brown sugar and dark brown sugar]550 ml water6-7 slices ginger [I used Penang Air Itam ginger]a few pandan leaves [optional]Place sugar in a saucepan, turn on low heat to slightly caramelise the sugar.Add in water and ginger slices. Â Bring to boil to dissolve the sugar.Simmer syrup until fragrant. Â Set aside to cool [this syrup can be prepared in advance].Knead pumpkin paste and flour into a soft dough. Â Cover, rest for half an hour before rolling into small balls. Â  Place on a tray. Â Since this quantity is not too much, I dropped them to boil as I roll.Bring a pot of water to boil. Â Add in the kuih ee to boil until cooked [the rice balls will float up when cooked]. Â  Use a serrated ladle to scoop out the balls and place in a big bowl of water for several minutes.Use the same serrated ladle to scoop the kuih ee into the prepared syrup.Dish out onto individual bowls to serve warm or cooled.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and Sommelier

title: CARROT TAU SAR/MUA CHEE PAUS
text: Made this batch of steamed paus as praying item to my late father in-law on 11th day of 6th lunar calendar month [yesterday]. Â Quite simple to make as I used my 'sure can' pau dough and store-bought red bean [tau sar] paste. Â  However, I made some 'mua chee'Â [see recipe]Â to add to the red bean paste as filling. Â This portion is enough to make 16 paus.These steamed buns were lovely. Â Serve hot from the steamer, the mua chee is so soft and chewy, the red bean paste was molten. Â The pau skin was perfect, soft, moist and QQ.Ingredients[makes 16 pieces]350 gm pau flour sifted together with 1 tsp double action baking powderMix together - 200 mlÂ carrot juice/waterÂ [*], 40 gm caster sugar and 1/4 tsp vinegar1 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp shortening[*] 1 small carrot blended with 200 ml or more water - strained to obtained 200 ml carrot juice/waterÂ Filling - 200 gm red bean [tau sar] paste - store bought. Â Divide into 16 portions. Â Flatten each piece and wrap mua chee with it. Â Roll into a ball.How to Make Muah CheeÂ Ingredients100 gm glutinous rice flour100 to 110 ml water2 tsp sugara little oil to grease plastic bagStep 1 - Add water to flour then add sugarÂ Step 1 - stir till mixture is not lumpyStep 1 -Â  Mixture after steaming for 15 minutesStep 1.Â  Put glutinous rice flour in a steaming bowl.Â  Add in water gradually and stir to combine well with flour then add in sugar.Â  Continue to stir till mixture is smooth and not lumpy.Â Prepare a steamer with water.Â  Bring water to a boil on high heat and put in mixture to steam for 15-20 minutes or until muah chee is cooked.Â  Off heat, remove to cool for 10 minutes.Step 2Step 2.Â  Oil a plastic bag and put in cool muah chee.Â  Knead till smooth and Q. Â  Divide into 16 equal portions with a plastic cutter [to prevent sticking].Using a Dough Mixer or Hand Knead to make pau doughCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic.Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Then divide each ball into 8 equal portions. Shape each into a ball, then roll into flat circle.Wrap filling with each flatten dough. Â Gather the edges and shape into pleated paus or round balls.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray.Leave to prove for 15 - 20 minutes or until double in size.Steam over high heat for 10-12 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave paus for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].

title: Family Style Pig Trotters in  Black Vinegar
text: I was taught how to cook this family style pig trotters in black vinegar years ago and had cooked it quite a number of times, has shared the recipe with some friends too. Â But, I'm wondering, why all this while I didn't post the recipe. Â Thought, it would be good to prepare it again and share with Little Thumbs Up Event hosted by Chef and Sommelier with the Theme - Ginger.I had a story to tell on how I got to learn about this dish. Â I happened to pass by my neigbhour's house while he was cooking this dish. Â The aroma and fragrance were so nice and can't help but to ask him what is it. Â Without explanation, he scooped some into a bowl and asked me to try. Â I told him I would have it for dinner with my hubby.This was the first time my hubby and I really enjoyed Too Kar Chor. Â We were immediately addicted to it and wouldn't mind if there is a second portion to savour. Â The sourish sweet flavour, aroma of ginger and black vinegar was just perfect. Â Without hesitation, I approached my neigbhour for the recipe. Â He Â was happy to teach me how to prepare it and even giving me the useful tips of cooking it. Â He even told me which type and brand of black vinegar to use for this dish.Â  If you cannot find the exact type maybe just check the contents of any other black vinegar which is similar to the one I am using here.The meat cooks faster after frying. Â The young ginger and black fungus are nice and absorbs the sweet sourish taste of the black vinegar. Â Â The gravy can be spread over rice or just simply drink it, a spoonful at a time, it is awesome. Â I prefer this version as the gravy is a little concentrated yet still drinkable.This bottle of black vinegar Â [hei mi cu] contains:- black glutinous rice, lime skin, ginger, salt and vinegar. Â If you are using this particular brand from Swee On Woh Sauce Factory [situated at Jalan C Y Choy, Penang], it is not necessary to add sugar as it is already sweetened. Â No other seasoning is needed. Â It's available in a small bottle of 300 ml, too.Post Updated on 29 April 2015 - Checked with this soy sauce factory in Penang. Â The black vinegar is available here in Kuala Lumpur [see address below].Ingredients1 pig trotters - cut to bite size pieces50 gm black fungus [mok yee] - soak and break into big pieces150 gm young ginger - wash and sliced100-200 gm old ginger - wash and slightly smashed1 bottle [600 ml ] of black vinegar1/3 bottle of water [about 200 ml]Blanched pig trotter in boiling water for several minutes or until the scums surfaced. Â Remove and rinse to clean the meat pieces. Â Drain and set aside.Pour black vinegar and water into a cooking pot. Â Add in old ginger. Â Bring to a boil, then simmer until soup is aromatic.Heat up wok without oil to saute young ginger for several minutes. Â Dish out and add into black vinegar soup.Using the same wok, fry blanched meat [without oil] for several minutes. Â Dish out and add to the pot.Add inÂ black fungus. Â Cover and bring to boil all the ingredients.Lower heat, cover pot and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until pig trotters are cooked and just tender but not too soft.Â Leave meat to sit in the soup for sometime before serving.Note:I used Penang Air Itam old ginger for this dish. Â The ginger flavour is stronger and more aromatic.I used the post which shortens the cooking time.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs Up organised by Zoe of Bake for Happy Kids and Doreen of My Little Favourite DIY and hosted by Alvin of Chef and Sommelier

title: Steamed Red Yeast Ginger Chicken
text: An easy steamed chicken with red wine residuum [ang chow] recipe. Â Juicy chicken meat pieces with a strong flavour of 'ang chow', wine and of course ginger. Â Good with rice straight after steaming. Â Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum No. 48 magazine]3 chicken thighs - deboned and cut into bite sizes pieces [I removed certain parts of the fatty skin only]1 tbsp chopped ginger [I used Penang Air Itam ginger]some coriander leaves/spring onions - for garnishingSeasoning2 tbsp red wine yeast residuum1 tsp each of sugar and chicken stock granules1/2 tsp salt and sesame oil1 tbsp shaoxing winedash of pepperMix chicken with seasoning and marinate for at least an hour [preferably overnight].Before steaming, wrap chicken with marinade with aluminium foil and fold into a neat parcel [I placed the chicken in a aluminium foil tray, then cover it with foil or wrap up the tray with another piece of aluminium foil].Heat up a wok over high heat, pour in 400 ml water, bring it to a boil. Â Place the tray/parcel in it, cover to cook for 20 minutes or until water has dried up.Continue to cook for a further 3 minutes.Remove, garnish with coriander leaves and serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Fragrant Fried Ginger Pork Belly
text: There are many different marinades for deep fried or pan fried pork belly such as soy sauce, cekur, nam yee or foo yee and even shrimp paste [belacan] etc. Â But this fried pork belly uses ginger juice with 5 spice powder as marinade. Â  Can imagine how is the taste like?I can say, it's simple yet awesome. Â Â The fried meat is tender, fragrant and the ginger flavour is not that intense or noticeable.The original recipe is for 800 grams of pork belly [skin removed] but I bought just a thin strip of pork belly to prepare this dish as I'm only cooking for 2 persons.Ingredients[original recipe from a Yum Yum magazine]800 gm [cut into 4 thin strips] - removed skinsome shredded spring onions and coriander leavesenough oil for deep fryingMarinade4 tbsp ginger juice - pounded and extract the juice [I used Air Itam ginger]1-2 tsp 5 spice powder1-2 tsp salt2 tbsp cornstarch2 tbsp plain flourCut pork belly strips into 2 to 3 pieces [for easier frying].Marinade pork belly with marinade for at least 1 hour [preferably overnight].Heat oil to deep fry pork belly until golden brown.Dish out and drain.Leave to cool slightly then cut thin slices. Â Garnish with coriander leaves and spring onions. Â Serve with rice.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: CITRON HONEY TEA COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: My nephew bought a bottle of Korean citron honey tea that comes Â with whole limes and syrup. Â I used it to bake this cottony cake. Â See how it looks. Â Nice yellow colour, soft, cottony and spongy with bits of preserved lime. Â The sweetness is just nice and cake has the .... taste of the honey tea. Â NICE. Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[using 8" or 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted5 egg yolks1 whole egg45 ml corn oil2 preserved citron honey tea limes - seeds removed and chopped small pieces2 tbsp citron honey tea syrup mix with 60 ml waterPlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil and honey tea and lime mixture.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar60 gm castor sugarÂ Using an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Smooth the surface with a spatula or just lightly shake the baking pan [the batter will spread out evenly].Steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes. Â Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate before slicing to serve later.

title: Spicy Soy Sauce Fried Fish
text: This way of serving fried fish is my nephew's favourite. Â  Â He loves the fragrant spicy, salty taste of the sauce which is quite oily but spread over plain white rice, it is yummylicious to him. Â This was cooked at my mum's kitchen [I wouldn't cook this dish in my kitchen because it is 'hot' in every sense to one's nostrils and kitchen].Ingredients1 ikan bawal emas [kum cheong] - cleaned and pat dry[can use other types of fish like pomfret, senangin etc]season with a little salt10 small chilli - cut small piecesenough oil to fry fishsome soy sauce to tasteHeat enough oil in wok to fry fish until golden brown and crispy.Dish out on serving plate.Remove oil, leaving 2-3 tablespoons to fry cut chillies.Add soy sauce to chilli. Â Stir to mix. Â Off heat and scoop over fried fish.Serve immediately.

title: Steamed Chicken Wings
text: Never given any attention to identify which are the dishes that belongs to Selangor or Kuala Lumpur food. Â So long as the food Â at these places are good and yummy, nothing matters. Â By chance, I saw this book Rasa Malaysia by Betty Saw which categorised the recipes according to various states of Malaysia. Â This is one of the dishes which was under Selangor food category that looks good, Â yet easy to prepare. Â Just marinate the chicken wings and steam to cook.Â This steamed chicken is very aromatic, fragrant and the gravy is yummylicious. Â Nice with plain white rice.Ingredients6 chicken wings - end tip removed and cut at the joint2 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips1 red chillisome chopped coriander leaves and spring onions1 tbsp oilMarinating Sauce1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and oyster sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp salt1/4 tsp pepper2 tsp cornflour2.5 cm ginger - scrape skin and chopped finely [I juliened the ginger]Wash chicken wings and drain dry. Â Marinate with marinating sauce for at least an hour.Place marinated chicken wings, red chilli and mushrooms in a steaming plate and steam over high heat for 12 minutes.Remove and garnish with chopped coriander leaves and spring onions.Serve immediately.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierÂ I am also submitting this post toÂ Malaysian Food FestÂ Kuala Lumpur Selangor MonthÂ hosted byÂ Shannon of Just As DelishÂ I'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Sambal Ladies' Finger [Huan Cheo Kak Tau]
text: One of the popular and common vegetable dish from the Nyonya kitchens. Â My mum has her own simple sambal recipe to fry vegetablesÂ [see here for her version]Â which is good at all times. Â This version is from Nyonya Flavours [slight modifications] with more ingredients which is also worth trying. Â The sambal dried prawns tasted good and blends well with the lady's fingers [Okra].Ingredients4-5 tbsp oil300 gm lady's fingers - blanched in boiling water until cooked through2 tbsp water1/2 tsp salt1-2 tbsp sugarSambal Paste - Blended together4-5 fresh red chillies - cut small pieces5 dried red chillies [I used 1 tsp chilli boh]3-4 cloves garlic - skinned12 shallots [100gm] - skinned3-4 candlenuts1 tsp toasted belacan [5 gm]2 tbsp dried prawns [20 gm] - rinsed and drainedBlend all the paste ingredients [except dried prawns] until fine. Â Scoop out.Using the same blender, coarsely chopped the dried prawns. Â Scoop out.Heat oil in wok, saute sambal paste until aromatic. Â Add water and seasoning.Stir fry and add in dried prawns. Â Saute until aromatic. Â Dish out to spread over blanched lady's fingers.Note: My mum will pound all the sambal ingredients and dried prawns together. Â The same paste can be used for many kinds of vegetables like brinjals, spinach, sweet potato leaves, huang ti chye, kangkong [water convolvulus], long beans etc.I'm linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: Fried Ginger Minced Meat
text: This fried minced meat dish uses young ginger. Â It has the fragrance of ginger yet not too 'hot' in taste. Â Moreover with the saltiness of the preserved radish [chai por], this minced meat tasted rather unique, very Â suitable to serve with plain porridge and rice.Ingredients are simple and method is easy, just stir fry until aromatic and meat is cooked. Â Ingredients[recipe adapted from Yum Yum magazine]300 gm minced meat [lean or with some fats is alright]200 young ginger - finely chopped100 gm preserved radish [chai por] - chopped4 tbsp oil1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp salt to taste [depends on how salty is the chai por used]1 tsp sugarHeat up oil in pan [I used a claypot], saute chopped ginger until aromatic and lightly browned.Add in preserved radish, stir fry to mix and aromatic.Add in the minced meat and seasoning. Â Stir fry until minced meat is cooked and almost dry.Taste to adjust seasoning. Â Dish up to serve with plain porridge or white rice or use as toppings for steamed tofu.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierPicture of Young GingerCut Young GingerI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted byÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: GINGER MILK TEA COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: This cottony cake has the 'Teh Tarik' ginger flavour. Â For convenience, it's alright to Â  use Â Boh's 'Ginger Milk Tea' for the cake flavour. Â If you can't find this, you can concoct your own [*] by steeping 3 tea sachets in 100 ml hot water to obtain 80 ml tea. Â  Then add in 2 tbsp condensed milk and 2 teaspoons of ginger juice [or 1 tsp ginger powder]. Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[using 8" Â or 9" square tin]75 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg45 ml corn oil2 sachets 3 in 1 [26 gm/sachet] Teh Tarik Ginger [Boh brand] dissolve with 80 ml hot water - set aside to cool OR prepare as above [*]Place the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil and tea mixture.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugar [can use 80 gm for sweeter cake]Using an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 8" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Smooth the surface with a spatula and steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be soggy after baking].Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate before slicing to serve later.

title: PENANG DURIAN COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Again now, it's Durian [king of fruits] season in Penang. Â I loved using Penang durians to bake cakes because the flesh is especially pungent, the texture is fine and soft. Â  Â The fine flesh texture makes the cake texture fine and soft too as there are no coarse/fibery pieces. Â Â BTW, I got this durian 'free' with courtesy [hehehe] from the durian vendor. Â At the durian stall, I requested for a small durian. Â Told him I needed just a little to bake cakes. Â Without hesitation, he said no problem. Â He opened up a fruit and dumped 1 'pangsa' of durian [about 3-4 pieces] into a plastic container. Â He handed it to me and said 'free for you'. Â I asked 'really?, okay, thanks, I'll bake the cake and bring some for you'. Â He gave me a broad smile. Â  What a wonderful day.While the cake was baking, I could smell the aroma of durian coming from the kitchen, Â hmmm.... awesome if you are a durian lover.The next day , I brought several slices of this cake to the vendor. Â He was so happy and wanted to give me a whole fruit this time [I didn't accept but thanked him for it]. Â  He told me to see him whenever I need the fruit again to bake cakes. Â  Next time I know where to go for free durians, hehehe.......Â Ingredients[8 or 9 inch square baking tin]5 egg yolks1 egg60 ml corn oil [I used 50 ml]70 ml milk75 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside60-80 gm durian flesh - mashed into a smooth paste1/4 tsp salt5 egg whites60 gm sugar [less as the durian is already sweet]1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 9" square tin with grease proof paper. Â  I greased the sides, too and sprinkle lightly with a little flour [this way, the cake can be easily removed from pan after cooling].Preheat oven to 160 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it. Â WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg until creamy then gradually drizzle in the corn oil followed by milk. Â  Add in durian paste, beat until well combined. Â Fold in sifted flour, stir until batter is smooth.Â  Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â Pour the batter into prepared cake tin. Â Shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out nicely and evenly or tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking.Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then lower heat to 150 degrees C and continue to bake for 55-60 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up].Â Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 3-5 minutes [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking]. Â Â Remove baking tin and the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards].Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because it is low in gluten.Turn the cake over when completely cooled. Â Refrigerate before slicing if preferred.

title: Huan Chu T'ng [Sweet Potato in Ginger Syrup]
text: Air Itam morning market in Penang has several things that are popular and famous like the Penang Assam Laksa, the Kooi Sisters Curry Mee, crispy fried crullers, and many more to name that attracts locals and of course tourists and visitors from all over. Â During festive times, this place is full of activities from dawn to dusk and the traffic snarled in the area.I used to be a 'full time' resident there and I sometimes wish to have some privacy and space. Â People [visitors] visiting the market simply parked their vehicles outside my house which is situated at the vicinity of the market making the place so congested. Â  Now, I'm a 'part-time' resident so it's more or less bearable cos' I know when to get out from there.Oh, I'm going off track. Â What I would like to share here is another famous item that one can get at the market. Â Guess what? Â It's 'AIR ITAM GINGER', grown at the surrounding hills in the area. Â It has its unique quality very different from the ginger from other places. Â This ginger is especially fragrant and famed for its heat-giving properties. Â It is a must have item in almost all dishes for confinement meals and others too. Â  During the confinement month, kilos and kilos of it are used and the price is many times more than other ordinary ginger.Using it for Huan Choo T'ng [sweet potato dessert] and Kuih Ee syrup and many other dishes does makes a great difference to its taste. Â If you do visit this place, specifically ask for 'Air Itam Ginger' and find out how it differs.We usually cook this dessert in white sugar syrup but this time I used both brown and white sugars. Â The syrup was more fragrant and not too sweet. Â Goes well with the soft and sweet potatoes. Â Screwpine [pandan] leaves are not necessary for this dessert. Â It's a nice dessert or for a hot afternoon tea time.IngredientsÂ - recipe adaptÂ ed from Nyonya Flavours[serves 3-4]500 gm orange sweet potatoes - peel and cut into chunks1 litre water30 gm [thumb size] old ginger - sliced [I used Penang Air Itam ginger]50 gm dark brown sugar50 gm white sugarBring water and ginger slices to boil. Â Add in sweet potatoes and continue to simmer for about 15-20 minutes or until sweet potatoes are soft.Add in sugar to taste.Serve warm.I'm linking this post toÂ Little Thumbs UpÂ organised byÂ Zoe of Bake for Happy KidsÂ andÂ Doreen of My Little Favourite DIYÂ and hosted byÂ Alvin of Chef and SommelierI'm also linking this post toÂ Cook Your Books #2 EventÂ Â hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours

title: CHIVES AND PRAWNS PAUS/ROLLED BUNS
text: The pau skin recipe was fromÂ Jane's CornerÂ but I doubled the portion since I have enough of milk needed for the dough. Â I noticed the quantity of shortening/butter used was quite a lot than normal, so I reduced it. Â This pau is soft and moist. Â Surprisingly, the pau is not yellowish even though plain flour and butter were used to make them.For the filling, I used chives [kucai] and prawns to make a savoury filling with a sweet pau skin.I used half the dough to make them into pau shape and the other half portion in rolled buns.Ingredients for Pau Skin400 gm plain flour80 gm castor sugar1 tsp instant yeast1/4 tsp pinch of salt200-220 ml milk1 1/2 tbsp butterUsing a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic [very important step].Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 4 round balls.Â Use 2 portions to make into pau shape. Â Divide each ball into 8 equal portions. Shape each into a ball, then roll into flat circle.Wrap filling with each flatten dough. Â Gather the edges and shape into pleated paus or round balls.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray. Â Do the same for the other portion.Leave to prove for 20-30 minutes.Steam over high heat for 10 minutes in a steamer.
