title: Pad See Ew [Thai Stir Fried Rice Noodles]
text: This is a Thai style stir fried flat rice noodles [broad strips of koay teow]. Â A very simple stir fry noodle which I think any novice cook can do. Â The ingredients are quite simple and easy to cook. Â It looks plain but surprisingly it is good especially with the chilli Â vinegar sauce [Prig Nam Som]. Â The vegetables also blends well with the noodles. Â  Â Most Chinese style stir fried noodles have mustard leaves added but this Thai noodle uses kailan. Â My hubby told me 'Prig means chilli' and 'Nam Som means vinegar sauce'. Â  Hope he is correct.Ingredients[serves 2-3]450-500 gm fresh flat rice noodles [koay teow] - cut broad strips300 gm Chinese broccoli [kailan] - washed and cut broad pieces [stems and leaves separately]1 tbsp chopped garlic200 gm pork tenderlion - slice thin strips [lightly marinated with light soy sauce, pepper and cornstarch]2 eggs [I used 1 duck egg]1 tbsp oil2 tbsp light soy sauce [I used 1 tbsp each of soy sauce and fish sauce]1 tbsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp sugarÂ Heat oil in wok, saute garlic until fragrant. Â Add in meat slices, fry until meat is cooked. Â Add in the kailan stems. Â Stir to mix. Â Add in the leaves, noodles and seasoning sauces. Â Stir fry to mix well all the ingredients.Leave to cook for a few minutes, push aside and add in eggs. Â  Stir lightly to mix ingredients.Dish out noodles to serve once the egg is cooked. Â Serve with chilli sauce [prig nam som].Prig Nam Som - Chilli Vinegar Sauce for NoodlesIngredients8 Jalapeno red peppers [I used 2 red chillies and 3-4 small red chillies]2 tbsp chopped garlic1/2 cup white vinegar [I used apple cider vinegar]1 tsp saltCoarsely blend chillies and garlic. Â Mix with salt and vinegar [must be enough to cover the chillies].Serve with Pad See Ew [Stir Fried Flat Rice Noodles].Note: The chilli sauce will thicken slight left overtime. Â Can prepare earlier.I'm submitting this post toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013Â Â hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Nyonya Assam Pedas Fish [Tamarind Curry Fish]
text: Nyonya tamarind juice curry, quite a close, simplified version of Assam Laksa which enables you to enjoy this thick, tangy soup hassle-free. Â You can omit the optional ingredients, the soup is still good. Â Quite spicy, acceptable according to my hubby's taste buds [he loves 'strong' flavoured curries].Â This quantity is enough to cook 1 to 1.5 kg fish with 1.5 litre water [tamarind juice]. Â I like this kind of spicy curry cos' no oil is required and it is good to serve with blanched rice vermicelli and garnish with mint leaves or any leafy greens.The original recipe uses stingray [cut into chunks] but here I used Mahogany Snapper [from my hubby's fishing trip]. Â You can also use whole Ikan Kembong [mackerel] and medium big prawns [if serving with noodles].Ingredients[original recipe from Nyonya Flavours with slight modifications]1.5 heaped tbsp tamarind pulp1.5 litre water1.5 kg stingray - cut into chunks [I used fresh Mahogany snapper]2 stalks ginger flower - halved and sliced finely3/4 tbsp salt to taste2 tbsp sugar to tastea few stalks of Vietnamese mint [daun kesom] - optionalsome mint leaves - optionalSpice Paste - Ground Together20 gm [15-20] dried red chillies - soaked in hot water and drained2 stalks lemongrass - sliced2 cm fresh tumeric - skinned and sliced or 1 tsp tumeric powder150 gm [15-20] shallots20 gm [2 cloves] garlic20 gm belacanBlend spice ingredients in a blender until fine. Â Set aside.Mix tamarind pulp with water and strain to extract the juice.Bring tamarind juice and spice paste to a boil in a pot for 5-10 minutes until aromatic. Â Season with salt and sugar.Add the fish and daun kesum [if using] boil until cooked for about 2 minutes.Add sliced ginger flower and serve hot with mint leaves.Notes: Â You can prepare half portion of the curry paste to cook about 600 gm of fish.This post is linked to the event, Â Little Thumbs UpÂ [JuneÂ 2013 - Curry Paste/Powder] organised byÂ Zoe [Bake for Happy Kids] andÂ Mui Mui [My Little Favourite DIY]Â and hosted by Miss B ofÂ Everybody Eats Well in FlandersI'm also submitting this to Â Malaysian Food Fest [June 2013] - PenangÂ hosted by Alan of Travellingfoodie

title: VIETNAMESE COFFEE COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: I have baked the Coffee Souffle Cake with 3 eggs [see this post] which was very nice and always my favourite. Here, I tried using Vietnamese Coffee [a friend gave me a packet containing 50 sachets of '3 in 1' coffee] to bake this cake. This coffee aroma was quite strong and the cake was not disappointing - texture was fine, spongy and moist.Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[using Â 9" square tin]65 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg60 ml corn oil3 sachets 3 in 1 [16 gm/sachet] Vietnamese Coffee dissolve with 80 ml hot water - set aside to coolPlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil and coffee milk mixture.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â  Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour batter into a 9" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only].Â Smooth the surface with a spatula and steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, lower heat to 150 degrees C and bake for a further 55-60 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be soggy after baking].Invert the cake after baking on a wire rack and let it cool slightly [about 5 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper].Cool cake completely before slicing to serve or refrigerate before slicing to serve later.

title: Black Glutinous Rice Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: Already quite awhile I have not bake this bread. Â The previous bakes [see here for the straight dough method], I used the straight dough method. Â This time, I used the overnight dough or sponge dough method where I divide the ingredients into two parts. Â I also used yoghurt to replace the water and milk. Â The bread turns out soft, moist and has a slight scent of the pulut hitam [black glutinous rice].Ingredients for Overnight Dough[makes 2 loaves]200 gm bread flour100 gm black glutinous rice flour [obtained from grinding black glutinous rice]3 tsp instant yeast150 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours. Â Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour1 tbsp skimmed milk powder [omit if using plain yoghurt]2 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp Â salt1 eggÂ 120-150 ml water [I used plain yoghurt]60 gm butterÂ Add all the ingredients [except butter] to the overnight dough. Â Knead [from low speed to medium] until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Knead a further 5-10 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 20 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reach the rim of the baking tin. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make smaller loaves]. Â Remove from oven before preheating it.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.Notes - To prepare black glutinous rice flour-Â  Grind 100 gm black glutinous rice in grinder until fine.Â  Sieve and grind a few times until the rice Â flour is really fine.

title: PUMPKIN BROWN SUGAR BUNS
text: This is a very popular steamed bun dough recipe which I noticed several blogger friends have tried and shared. Â By chance, I came across the similar recipe in a food magazine [sorry, can't remember which one]. Â These buns are very soft, fluffy and light. Â I have made them into croissant shape with a sprinkle of brown sugar inside. Â I wouldn't mind making these again especially when I'm not in the mood to prepare any pau fillings... Â Fast and easy, lol.Ingredients[makes 16 buns]250 gm pau flour - sifted20 gm wheat flour50 gm icing Â sugar50 gm pumpkin puree100 ml waterÂ 1/2 tsp vinegar1/2 tbsp instant yeast1 tbsp shorteningÂ some brown sugarUsing a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic.Â Â Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Take one portion, roll into a rectangle, then cut into tall triangles. Â Sprinkle some brown sugar on each triangle.Roll up each triangle into a croissant.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray.Leave to prove for 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Steam over high heat for 10 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave paus for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].Serve immediately or reheat before serving.I'm sharing this post withÂ Aspiring Bakers#31 - Bao Ho-ChiakÂ -Â  May 2013 event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: Tauhu Tod with Spicy Sauce
text: Tauhu Tod is a Thai dish. Â It is fried firm beancurd served with a tangy sweet peanut dipping sauce. Â Simple dish yet appetising. Â  I wouldn't mind just eating this for a light meal or snack.Ingredients3 pieces firm bencurd [taukwa]enough oil for frying beancurdPeanut Dipping Sauce [Mix together]2 tsp freshly ground chilli paste1 tsp fish sauce [use salt to taste for vegetarian version]4 tbsp each of sugar and vinegar [I used calamansi juice]1 stalk fresh coriander - chopped4 tbsp ground peanutsHeat oil to fry beancurd pieces one at a time [if you do not want to use too much oil] until edges are crispy and golden. Â Remove and set aside.Mix the sauce ingredients.Cut the fried beancurd into quarters or 6 pieces.Serve immediately with dipping sauce.I'm submitting this post toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013Â Â hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Zha Jiang [Spicy Minced Meat Sauce]
text: This Zha Jiang [spicy minced meat sauce] is good served with rice or over blanched noodles dry or with soup. Â Very tasty [a little spicy, salty, sourish sweet], flavourful and appetising. Â I served it with shredded cabbage and rice. Â Kept some to serve with blanched noodles [rice vermicelli]. Â Very versatile sauce which can be prepared earlier, stored and serve anytime just by reheating. Â Ingredients200 gm minced meat1-2 tbsp oil1/2 tbsp chopped garlic2 tbsp fine preserved bean paste [taucheo]1 tbsp chilli paste [chilli boh or freshly ground chilli]1 tbsp tomato sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tbsp white vinegar [I used Apple cider vinegar]1/2 tbsp wine1 tbsp sugar4 tbsp water [more if you want some gravy]1 tsp cornflour mix with 2 tsp water for thickeningsome finely shredded cabbage - soaked in cold water and drained [optional]some chopped spring onions for garnishingHeat oil in pan, saute garlic until aromatic. Â Add in chilli paste and taucheo. Â Continue to fry until aromatic.Add in minced meat. Â Stir fry until meat is well mixed with the paste. Â Add in all the seasoning. Â Continue to fry for several minutes.Add water, bring to boil. Â Taste to adjust seasoning. Â Add thickening once meat is well cooked.Dish out to serve with shredded cabbage and rice or spread over noodles. Â Garnish with chopped spring onions.Notes:You can substitute the chopped garlic, taucheo and chilli paste with 2 tbsp store bought spicy preserved bean paste [spicy tau pan cheong] or 1 tbsp Thai Red Curry Paste.

title: PUMPKIN COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: After baking the cottony cake with purple sweet potatoes, I attempted baking another cottony cake, this time using pumpkin puree. Â The cake turned out beautiful not only in looks but texture and taste wise - thumbs up. Â  Spongy, cottony and firm to touch. Â I can say I have no complains about it. Â I brought some to share with friends at the health centre and the feedback 'it's good'.Â Lovely yellow colour comes from the pumpkin and custard powder. Â I added poppy seeds too [can omit if you don't have it].In this post, I'm sharing quite a number of photos to accompany the various steps of baking this cake. Â Hope they are of use and help to some readers who have not tried baking this cottony cake before.Ingredients[9 inch square baking tin]5 egg yolks1 egg2 tbsp castor sugar60 ml corn oil30 ml milk [depends on pumpkin puree] - can omit60 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside1 1/2 tbsp custard powder50 gm pumpkin puree1/4 tsp salt5 egg whites4 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartar1 tbsp poppy seeds [optional]Line base of a 9" square tin with grease proof paper. Â  I greased the sides, too and sprinkle lightly with a little flour [this way, the cake sides are a little crusty and can be easily removed from pan after cooling].Preheat oven to 160 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it. Â WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg until creamy then gradually drizzle in the corn oil followed by milk. Â  Â Whisk until well combined.Fold in pumpkin puree and sifted flour, stir until batter is smooth. Â Add in poppy seed [if using]. Â Set aside.Â Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â Pour the batter into prepared cake tin [smoothen with a spatula]. Â  Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking.Â Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 70 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up] OR bake at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, lower temperature to 150 degrees C, continue to bake for 50-60 minutes until cake is done.Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 5 minutes [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking]. Â Â Remove baking tin and the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards].Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Turn the cake over when cooled completely. Slice to serve or refrigerate before slicing if preferred. Â Notes:Cake keeps well in an airtight container if refrigerated [about 10-14 days].

title: Nyonya Style Meat Rolls [Lor Bak]
text: Considered a very popular snack or appetiser of Nyonya cuisine, which is also my family's favourite dish for any festive seasons. Â My mum would also prepare this whenever she has ample stock of meat in her fridge. Â This recipe is a keeper. Â As awesome as myÂ Family Style Meat Rolls [Penang Lor Bak].These meat rolls can be prepared, fried and served immediately or packed and freezed until required. Â To serve frozen meat rolls, just thaw to room temperature then reheat in the oven for 10-15 minutes at 100 - 120 degrees C. Â They will be as crispy as just fried.Ingredients[makes about Â 20 rolls]600 gm pork [tender meat] - cut strips150 gm water chestnuts [nett weight without the skin] - smashed and chopped1 big onion- chopped3 cloves garlic - choppedÂ 1 egg2 heaped tbsp tapioca flour or cornflourMarinade2 tbsp sugar3 tsp 5 spice powder1/2 tsp pepper1 1/2 - 2 tsp salt1 tsp chicken stock granules1 tbsp margarine/butter1 big piece beancurd skin [foo peh] - cut 20 equal size piecesSeason meat with marinade.Â  Add in onions, garlic, water chestnuts, egg, butter and cornflour.Â  Marinate for at least 1 hour or overnight.Wrap marinated meat into meat rolls [like spring rolls].Deep fry in medium heat till golden brown. Â [Tips: can fry meat rolls from cold oil]. Â Remove and drain on kitchen paper.Sliced and serve immediately with chilli sauce and cucumber slices or pickled radish.

title: QQ and Soft Sago Kuih
text: Anything cooked with sago [sweet or savoury] is always my favourite. Â This is one of them which I loved to buy from the kuih vendors [be it Malay or Chinese] but nowadays Â kuihs are getting expensive in terms of the costs of ingredients. Â  An easy dessert to prepare yet nice to serve as snack or dessert for gatherings. Â This QQ kuih is cut into bite size pieces, then coated with freshly grated white coconut with a little salt added to taste. Â As I say, nice and suitable for all ages. Â The kuih texture was more Q [chewy] the next day and it stays soft when chilled in the fridge.Ingredients300 gm sago soaked with 700 ml water for 5 hours60 gm castor sugar100 gm palm sugar [gula melaka] - finely chopped1 freshly grated white coconut mix with 1 tsp salt - steamed for 5 minutesDivide soaked sago in 2 equal portions.Mix castor sugar to 1 portion and gula melaka to the other portion. Â Stir until sugar dissolves.Scoop the white portion into a steaming tray [can use an 8" steaming tray] and steam for 15 minutes. Â I used the steaming tray from my electric steamer [the kuih doesn't stick to the base or sides after steaming].Pour the gula melaka portion over the steamed white portion and continue to steam for about 40 minutes or until sago is clear.Remove from steamer to cool completely before cutting into bite size piecesÂ [bestÂ Â to cool for several hours or overnight].Coat sago pieces with grated white coconut before serving.

title: PANDAN VEGETABLE PAUS
text: A very fragrant pandan steamed pau with vegetable filling [vegetarian stir fry turnip - see recipe here]. Â I didn't purposely cook this vegetable to make these paus. Â Usually this vegetable is cooked in quite a big quantity especially during festive times. Â I set aside a portion to use as filling for this pau.Â Â Â Â These paus are soft and fluffy. Â Tasted savoury sweet. Â Ingredients[makes 24 paus]500 gm pau flour - sifted100 gm caster sugarÂ 240 ml pandan juice/water [*]Â 1/2 tbsp instant yeast1.5 tbsp shortening [original uses 3 tbsp][*] 6 blades pandan leaves [screwpine leaves] - blended with 240 ml water - strained to obtained 240 ml pandan juice/water then add a drop of green colouring [optional]1 tbsp double action baking powderFilling - Vegetarian Stir Fry TurnipÂ [recipe here]Using a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic. Â [Note: double action baking powder can be added after kneading dough until soft and smooth - this I believe is to prevent yellowish looking paus]Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 15-20 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Then divide each ball into 12 equal portions. Shape each into a ball, then roll into flat circle.Wrap filling with each flatten dough. Â Gather the edges and shape into pleated paus or round balls.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray.Leave to prove for 15 - 20 minutes or until double in size.Steam over high heat for 10-12 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave paus for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].I'm sharing this post withÂ Aspiring Bakers#31 - Bao Ho-ChiakÂ -Â  May 2013 event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: Thai Fried Crab Rice [Kow Pud Pboo]
text: This is a Thai style fried rice with crab meat and the main seasoning is Fish Sauce. Â  It is served with Chilli Fish Sauce and cucumber slices [a wedge of lime - optional]. Â Here, I added some french beans, carrot and fresh corn kernels [all these are optional ingredients]. Â Â Basil leaves can also be added for fragrance.  The fried rice served with the Chilli Fish Sauce was surprisingly good if you love the sliced shallots and small chilli bits.  Hmmmm.....satisfying.Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]6 cups of cooked rice3 cloves garlic - chopped2-3 stalks of spring onions - chopped1 cup crab meat2 eggs3-5 tbsp oil1-2 tbsp fish sauce1 tsp peppersome carrot [diced], french beans [finely cut], fresh corn kernels [optional]Heat 3 tbsp oil to fry garlic until aromatic. Â Add in all the vegetables [if using, fry for a minute], then add in the rice. Â Stir to mix well. Â  Â Â Add in the crab meat. Â Push ingredients aside. Â Add in 2 tbsp oil to scramble eggs, one at a time.Add in fish sauce and pepper to taste. Â Fry until all ingredients are cooked and rice is fluffy. Â Off heat and stir in the spring onions.Dish out to serve with Chilli Fish Sauce.Ingredients for Chilli Fish Sauce [mix together]2-3 Thai red/green chillies - cut2 shallots - sliced thinelyJuice of 1 lime2 tbsp fish sauceThai Chilli Fish SauceClick here for other Fried Rice RecipesI'm submitting this post toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013Â Â hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: SESAME SWEET POTATO SAUSAGE BUNS
text: This steamed bun recipe is quite unique as it uses sesame oil instead of vegetable shortening or corn oil. Â These sausage rolls have the nice aroma of sesame oil. Â Soft, fluffy and moist buns that goes well with any fillings [maybe ham, cheese or luncheon meat].Ingredients[makes 10-12 pieces]300 gm pau flour or plain flour100 gm mashed sweet potatoes [I used purple sweet potatoes]2 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp salt120-130 ml water2 tsp yeast3 tbsp sesame oil1 tbsp white sesame seeds [optional]some toasted black sesame seeds - for garnish [optional]10 pieces chicken sausage - steamed for 10 minutes -  set aside to coolUsing a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except sesame oil and seeds] in a mixing bowl.  Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes].  Then add in the sesame oil, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic.  Add sesame seeds and knead for 1-2 minutes to mix well.Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Flatten each ball and cut into 5 equal portion. Â Shape each portion in long slender strips.Use a strip to wrap a sausage into a roll. Â  Place roll on a piece of greaseproof paper.Â  Â Place shaped dough in the steaming tray.Leave to prove for 15 - 20 minutes or until double in size.Steam over high heat for 10 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave rolls for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. Â This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin Â [sometimes they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Photos below show another way of shaping the buns.I'm sharing this post with  Aspiring Bakers #31 - Bao Ho-Chiak - May 2013 event hosted by Miss B of everybodyeatswell in Flanders.

title: Chicken with Fresh Mushroom Curry
text: Another simple curry yet flavourful if you don't mind using only curry powder for the spicy taste. Â Moreover, this curry uses fresh king oyster mushroom [erngyii mushrooms/sin pau koo] and carrots. Â So you can either add more of it and reduce the quantity of chicken or vice versa. Â  Â This curry tasted sourish sweet cos' of the tamarind juice. Â You can also cooked it as a thick or watery curry according to you preference. Â Ingredients[serves 3-4]2 big chicken thighs - skin removed and cut into bite size piecesÂ 3-4 stalks of fresh mushrooms [erngyii] - cut into wedges1/2 small carrot - sliced1 onion - peeled and cut into chunks1 tbsp chopped garlic2 tbsp curry powder -mixed with some water into a paste2 tbsp oil6 pieces kaffir lime leaves Â Seasoning1 tbsp tamarind paste mixed with 1 cup water and squeezed out the juice1 tsp each of salt and sugar to taste Â Heat oil to saute garlic and onions until aromatic. Â Add in curry powder [more if you want the curry to be spicy]. Â Fry until fragrant.Add in the chicken, mushrooms and carrots. Â Stir fry to mix well.Add in tamarind juice, bring to a boil, add seasoning. Â Lower heat to simmer for about 20 minutes or until chicken is cooked.Taste to adjust seasoning and add in kaffir lime leaves. Â Dish out to serve hot with rice. Â This post is linked to the event, Â Little Thumbs UpÂ [MayÂ 2013 - Mushrooms] organised byÂ Zoe [Bake for Happy Kids] andÂ Mui Mui [My Little Favourite DIY]Â and hosted by Joyce ofÂ Kitchen Flavours.

title: Taiwanese Chicken Rolls [Version 2]
text: The original version of Taiwanese Chicken Rolls [earlier post]Â has nothing to do with chicken. Â Since I wanted to prepare this for a gathering where we have some Muslim friends, I came up with this halal version. Â Here I used chicken breast as substitute and the fried rolls turned out well, tender and juicy.Â Ingredients[makes 18 rolls]300 gm fish paste - Â fish meat blended till fine and mix with some water into a sticky paste300 gm chicken breast - skin and bones removed - cut strips1 yellow onion - cut fine shreds1 - 2 tbsp tapioca flour or sweet potato flour1 piece bean curd skin - cut into 8"x 5" rectangular piecesSeasoningÂ - marinate chicken meat2 tsp each of light soy sauce, sugar and wine [I omit the wine]1/2 tsp each of salt, pepper and 5 spice powder1/2 tsp sesame oil [optional] - advisable to addMarinate chicken strips with seasoning. Â Add in sticky fish paste and onions. Â Use hand to mix all the ingredients together until well combined. Â Cover and leave to rest in the refrigerator for about 1/2 an hour.Place about Â a handful of mixture on centre of beancurd skin. Â Fold both side of the skin and roll up like spring roll. Â Do the same for the rest of the mixture.Place a few pieces of chicken roll in oil. Â Turn on heat to medium and deep fry the rolls until golden brown and crispy. Â Drain and leave on kitchen paper to cool.Cut rolls before serving them plain or with sweet chilli sauce or pickled zuchini or white carrot.Â This post is linked toÂ Facebook Asian Food Fest - August 2014 Taiwan FoodÂ hosted by AlanTravelling Foodie

title: PURPLE SWEET POTATO COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: This cake is supposed to be purplish in colour but I think I added too little of the mashed purple sweet potato. Â Anyway, it doesn't matter as with this quantity used, the cake texture was lovely [spongy firm] except without the purplish colour. Â I guess you can try with any colour sweet potatoes, which I will be doing........Ingredients[8 or 9 inch square baking tin][recipe from a food magazine with modifications]5 egg yolks1 egg60 ml corn oil [I used 50 ml]70 ml milk65 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside50 gm mashed sweet potato [purple sweet potato]1/4 tsp salt5 egg whites70 gm sugar [original uses 100 gm - too sweet]1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 8" square tin with grease proof paper. Â  I greased the sides, too and sprinkle lightly with a little flour [this way, the cake can be easily removed from pan after cooling].Preheat oven to 160 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it.Â WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg until creamy then gradually drizzle in the corn oil followed by milk. Â  Â Whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and sweet potato paste, stir until batter is smooth.Â  Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â Pour the batter into prepared cake tin. Â Â Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking. Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 70 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up]. Â Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 5 minutes [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking]. Â Â Remove baking tin and the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards].Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Turn the cake over when completely cooled. Â Refrigerate before slicing if preferred.

title: Hakka Loh Si Fun with Minced Meat
text: Not too sure if this falls under Sabah food but cos' it is Hakka food maybe it is. I need confirmation from Mary Chey of A Pepper's Love. Â The braised mince meat can be prepared earlier and the rest of ingredients during serving time. Â Â The original recipe used Loh Shi Fun but I also served the minced meat with rice. Â Both are as good.Â Serving with Loh Shi Fun[serves 2-3]500 gm loh shi fun [bee tai bak]200 gm beansprouts2 stalks spring onions - diced2 tbsp fried shallots1 tbsp shallot oil [optional]2 red chillies - sliced and mix with 2 tbsp light soy sauceBlanched noodles and taugeh in boiling water. Â Drain and place in serving bowl.Top with minced meat, spring onions, Â fried shallots and shallot oil.Serve with red chillies in soy sauce.HOW TO COOK THE MINCED MEATÂ Ingredients for Minced Meat250 gm minced meat [with some fats if preferred]1 tbsp each of chopped shallots and garlic3 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tbsp each of fish sauce, light soy sauce and oyster sauce1 tbsp each of sugar and wine1 tsp each sesame oil, dark soy sauce1/4 tsp of pepper120 ml waterHeat oil to fry shallots and garlic until golden and crispy. Â Dish out. Â Add in the minced meat to the oil. Â Add in all the seasoning and fry until meat is cooked.Add in the water, bring to boil and then lower heat to braise until meat is tender and gravy reduced.Taste and dish out to serve either with blanched Loh Shi Fun [Bee Tai Bak] and beansprouts or Â plain white rice, shredded cucumbers.Serving with Rice[1 serving]1 bowl of cooked hot ricesome shredded cucumbersome chopped spring onions and cut red chilliesPlace rice in a bowl. Â Top with minced meat, cucmbers, spring onions, fried shallots and some shallot oil.I'm submitting this post to Malaysian Food Fest - Sabah Month hosted byÂ Mary of A Pepper's Love

title: PURPLE SWEET POTATO SESAME STEAMED PAUS
text: This is an expansion of my 'sure can' pau dough recipe [see this post]. Â Expansion here means adding other ingredients to create another kind of paus. Â They are just as good in taste, texture and looks. Â  Here, I added purple sweet potatoes. Â I tried shaping the dough into various shapes according to my 'whims and fancies'. Â I believe you can too once you have master the art of pau making using this dough recipe. Â To make things easier for myself, I just use store bought lotus seeds filling cos' my intention here is just to play around with the dough.... hehehe! Â Sorry, I won't be giving the details on how to shape the paus [a bit lazy], so you may have to use your imagination basing on the photos which I'm sharing here. Â Â Ingredients[makes 16 pieces]350 gm pau flour sifted together with 1 tsp double action baking powderMix together - 180 ml lukewarm water, 40 gm caster sugar and 1/4 tsp vinegar **1 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp shortening100 gm mashed purple sweet potato [skinned, steamed and mashed]** water reduced to 180 ml from 200 ml cos' of the mashed potato]1 tbsp each of toasted black and white sesame seeds [optional]Using a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Add in sesame seeds and knead until well combined. Â Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Then divide each ball into 8 equal portions. Shape each into a ball, then roll into flat circle. Â  Â Wrap filling with each flatten dough. Â Gather the edges and shape into pleated paus or round balls.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray. Â Leave to prove for 15 - 20 minutes or until double in size. Â Â Steam over high heat for 10-12 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave paus for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected]. Â Â Some photos showing the shaping of the pausI'm sharing this post with Â Aspiring Bakers #31-Bao Ho-Chiak - May 2013Â event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: Carrot Black Sesame Steamed Buns
text: These steamed are without filling and the aroma comes from the black and white sesame seeds. Â Again the nice yellow tainted pau colour is derived from carrot juice/water used to knead the dough.Ingredients[makes 16 pieces]250 gm pau flour sifted together with 1 tsp double action baking powderMix together - 150 mlÂ carrot juice/waterÂ [*], 25 gm caster sugar and 1/4 tsp vinegar1 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp shortening[*] 1 small carrot blended with 100 ml water - strained to obtained 150 ml carrot juice/waterÂ 1 tbsp toasted black sesame seeds Â  Â  Â ) Â Mix both sesame seeds in a small plastic1/2 tbsp toasted white sesame seeds Â  ) Â lightly crushed to release its aromasome oil for brushingUsing a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].I'm sharing this post with Â Aspiring Bakers #31-Bao Ho-Chiak - May 2013event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: BLACK SESAME COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Like some blogger friends, I just loved to bake this kind of cakes popularly known to all as Ogura Cakes. Â  Â But, I prefer to call them Cottony cakes as they are really soft, moist and fine in texture. Â These cakes can be baked either small or big, the smallest which I have baked uses 3 eggs and the biggest using 7 eggs. Â Your choice will depend on your requirement and the size of the pans that you have. Â  Honestly, it is worthwhile to bake a bigger cake cos' it keeps well for long time in the refrigerator. Â Back to this black sesame flavour cake, it is aromatic, not bitter at all and the sweetness is just nice [original uses 100 gm castor sugar]. Â  From the photos, you would noticed that the top part is greener cos' I added a little green colouring to create a dual colour. Â This is optional, you can either omit or make the whole cake greenest black instead of the dual colour. Â  Â I added the green colour cos' I was 'haunted' by my MIL's remarks 'Don't make dark coloured cakes, they don't look nice'. Must overcome this phobia soon.....Ingredients[8 or 9 inch square baking tin][recipe from a food magazine with modifications]5 egg yolks1 egg60 ml corn oil [I used 50 ml]70 ml milk65 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside50 gm black sesame powder [I grinded toasted black sesame seeds into paste]1/4 tsp salt5 egg whites70-80 gm sugar [original uses 100 gm - too sweet]1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 8" square tin with grease proof paper. Â  I greased the sides, too and sprinkle lightly with a little flour [this way, the cake can be easily removed from pan after cooling].Preheat oven to 160 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it. Â WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg until creamy then gradually drizzle in the corn oil followed by milk. Â  Â Whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and black sesame paste, stir until batter is smooth.Â  Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â Remove 1/2 of the cake batter to another bowl.Â  Add in the a little green colouring, mix well [optional step].Pour the black sesame batter into prepared cake tin [smoothen with a spatula] then put the green portion over the black sesame batter. Â Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking. Â Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 70 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up]. Â Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 5 minutes [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking]. Â Â Remove baking tin and the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards].Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Turn the cake over when completely cooled. Â Refrigerate before slicing if preferred.

title: Char Siew Steamed Paus
text: These days, very addicted to this pau skin recipe. Â The paus turned out so niceÂ that I am quite reluctant to use another recipe. Â I must say it's good cos' some readers have came back to tell me the pau skin is really NICE.I used home-cooked char siew [see recipe posting here]Â as filling, my hubby's Â long outstanding request. Â You can make 16 paus of equal size or venture out to make even smaller paus [siew long paus]. Â I divided 3 portions into 2 each to make 6 siew long paus and another 2 portions to make the pau 'huat'. Â Got the inspiration when I saw the 'kuih seller' selling the pau 'huat'. Â Instead of buying the pau' huat', I bought 2 pieces of 'huat kuih' from him to make these 2 pau 'huat'. Â By the way, pau 'huat' means 'sure to prosper', really???Before steamingIngredients for Pau Dough[makes 16 paus]350 gm pau flour sifted together with 1 tsp double action baking powderMix together - 200 ml lukewarm water, 40 gm caster sugar and 1/4 tsp vinegar1 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp shortening1-2 tbsp some toasted black sesame seedsFilling - Char Siew [see this post]Using a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic [very important step].Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Then divide each ball into 8 equal portions. Shape each into a ball, then roll into flat circle [the number depends on the capacity of your steamer, for mine I made 8 at a time].Wrap filling with each flatten dough. Â Gather the edges and shape into pleated paus or round balls.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray.Leave to prove for 15 - 20 minutes.Steam over high heat for 10 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave paus for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].I'm sharing this post with Â Aspiring Bakers #31-Bao Ho-Chiak - May 2013Â event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: Char Siew Filling - Steamed Pau
text: The original Char Siew recipe is from WendyKK of Table for 2 or more [see link here]. Â I made a little adjustment to suit my family's taste and preference. Â Good recipe as I can kill two birds with one stone. Â Made this portion of char siew, ate some [about 200 gm] with rice* and the rest was use to make the char siew filling for my Char Siew Steamed Pau. *Didn't take any photos on making of the char siew cos' my purpose is to make char siew filling for steamed paus.Ingredients for Char Siew[slightly modified according to own taste preference]600 gm pork strips [I used pork belly]marinate with 1 soup spoon dark soy sauce, 1 soup spoon rose wine [aka mei hua loo or mui gwai lou], 2 soup spoons light soy sauce, 3 soup spoons sugar, 1 tsp salt and 1 cup watercook marinated pork over medium low heat until meat is cooked and Â gravy is thick like honey consistency. Â Cut into small cubes or diced.Ingredients for Char Siew Filling For Steamed PausAbove cooked char siew- diced2-3 tbsp sugar2 tbsp oyster sauce1-2 tbsp cornstarch1-1 1/2 cups waterAdd above seasoning [except cornstarch] to diced char siew. Â Bring it to a boil then lower heat to simmer until meat is tender and gravy reduced. Â Stir in the cornstarch and cooked Â until char siew is tender and gravy is stick and moist.Dish out to cool before adding 2-3 tbsp chopped spring onions and 2 tbsp Â toasted sesame seeds. Chill in the fridge until required.Recipe for Char Siew Steamed PausÂ [please see next post]I'm sharing this post with Â Aspiring Bakers #31-Bao Ho-Chiak - May 2013Â event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: Carrot 'Ling Yung' Paus
text: Such a nice coloured steamed pau using natural ingredients. Â No colouring was added. Â The bright yellow colour comes from the carrot juice/water. Â Using the store bought lotus seed paste [ling yung] helps making these paus so easy and hassle free. Â I wouldn't mind making them again and again when I want the paus to look this colour. Â  Really easy yet satisfactory results.Ingredients[makes 16 pieces]350 gm pau flour sifted together with 1 tsp double action baking powderMix together - 200 ml carrot juice/water [*], 40 gm caster sugar and 1/4 tsp vinegar1 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp shortening[*] 1 small carrot blended with 180 ml or more water - strained to obtained 200 ml carrot juice/waterÂ Filling - 250 gm Lotus seed paste [store bought]Using a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic.Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Then divide each ball into 8 equal portions. Shape each into a ball, then roll into flat circle.Wrap filling with each flatten dough. Â Gather the edges and shape into pleated paus or round balls.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray.Leave to prove for 15 - 20 minutes or until double in size.Steam over high heat for 10-12 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave paus for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].I'm sharing this post with Aspiring Bakers#31 - Bao Ho-ChiakÂ -Â  May 2013 event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: Black Sesame Yam Paus
text: Recently made this steamed pau again using the 'sure can' dough recipe. Â This time I added some toasted black sesame seeds to the skin dough, not so much for the taste but more for looks instead of the usual fluffy white. Â  I used a simple yam paste as filling which is sweet enough for us. Â Ingredients for Pau Dough[makes 16 paus]350 gm pau flour sifted together with 1 tsp double action baking powderMix together - 200 ml lukewarm water, 40 gm caster sugar and 1/4 tsp vinegar1 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp shortening1-2 tbsp some toasted black sesame seedsUsing a Dough Mixer or Hand KneadCombine all the ingredients [except shortening] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft [about 5-10 minutes]. Â Then add in the shortening, continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic [very important step].Shape into a ball and cover to rest for about 20-30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough and remove dough to a floured surface, divide into 2 round balls. Â  Then divide each ball into 8 equal portions. Shape each into a ball, then roll into flat circle [the number depends on the capacity of your steamer, for mine I made 8 at a time].Wrap filling with each flatten dough. Â Gather the edges and shape into pleated paus or round balls.Â  Place on parchment or greased proof Â paper in the steaming tray.Leave to prove for 15 - 20 minutes.Steam over high heat for 10 minutes in a steamer. Â Off heat and leave paus for a further 3 minutes before uncovering to cool on rack. This is to prevent wrinkle, rough skin [sometimes Â they may be a little wrinkle - probably because of proofing time but the texture is unaffected].This yam paste is very easy to prepare yet tastes good. Â  Not too sweet and no oil is added to the paste. The original recipe uses Â 250 gm yam with 130 gm sugar, 3 tbsp coconut milk. Â This quantity is only enough for making 12 paus.Yam Paste Ingredients - Pau Filling[enough for Â 16 paus]300 gm yam - cut small pieces80 gm sugar1 tbsp milk powder4 tbsp coconut milk2 tbsp toasted sesame seeds - optionalSteam yam pieces for about 25-30 minutes or Â until soft. Â Mash while still hot and mix with the rest of the ingredients.Fry over low heat in a non stick pan until a paste is formed [the paste is ready if it leaves the pan clean]. Â Add in toasted sesame seeds. Â Mix well.Dish out to cool and keep refrigerated until required.Note:Can prepare this filling earlier. I'm sharing this post with Â Aspiring Bakers #31-Bao Ho-Chiak - May 2013Â event hosted by Miss B ofÂ everybodyeatswellÂ in Flanders.

title: Japanese Ginger Braised Pork Fillet
text: I prepared this meal mainly because I was so unhappy after trying a Japanese Teppan Rice several weeks ago at a food court. Â That meal was not cheap because of the portion [Miss Phong Hong knows my story]. Â So I came up with this version where I have ginger braised pork fillet over cooked short grain rice [the kind of rice used for to cook sushi rice], lots of sliced zuchini and shredded cabbage with mayo. Â It's okay to serve it with plain white rice.The ingredients for this meal [excluding the rice] costs me less than RM 10.00.Ingredients[serves 3]450 gm tender pork meat fillet - marinate with some salt and peppersome tapioca flour for coating1-2 yellow onion - sliced1-2 tsp finely grated ginger3 cabbage leaves - washed, finely shredded and drainedsome mayo1 big zuchini - zlicedsome coriander leaves for garnishingSeasoninglight soy sauce, mirin, sesame oil to tastewaterTenderise the met fillet then marinate with some salt and pepper for at least 30 minutes. Â Coat sparingly with some tapioca flour. Â Leave for about 5 minutes.Heat a non stick pan with some oil. Â Pan fry the meat slices until golden and slightly crispy at the edges. Â Turn over to pan fry the other side until meat is cooked. Â This takes about 10-15 minutes only.Mix mayo with shredded cabbage. Â Chill in the fridge until required. Â Slice zuchini and leave in the fridge until required.Remove excess oil from frying pan. Â  Add in sliced yellow onion, seasoning and water. Â Braised for 10-15 minutes until gravy is reduced. Â Taste to adjust seasoning.Â To serve, place a bowl of cooked rice in serving dish. Â Top up with slices of meat with gravy. Â Garnish with cabbage, zuchini slices and coriander leaves. Â If preferred serve this rice with a bowl of miso seaweed soup.

title: Pork Fillet with Green Capsicum
text: This is actually a quick stir fried dish at the 'Chu Char' stalls where the pork fillets are deep fried or scalded in hot oil, drained and fried with the remaining ingredients.Here, I am enjoying this dish in a more healthier way. Instead of deep frying, I blanched the marinated pork fillets in boiling water. Â The boiling water can also be used as a soup base. Â This dish tasted good and we can eat without worrying about the fat content of it.Ingredients[serves 2-3]200 gm tender pork fillet - sliced1 green capsicum - cut wedges or diamond shape1 red chilli - seeded and cut big pieces2-3 cloves garlic - sliced1/2 tbsp oilSeasoning - Combine together1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1/2 tsp dark soy saucea dash of pepper2-3 tbsp watercornflour for thickening [optional]Marinate pork slices with some light soy sauce, pepper and cornstarch for at least 15 minutes.Bring a small pot of water to boil. Â  Put in pork slices. Â Dish out onto a place with the meat slices float to the surface.In a small pan, andÂ oil to saute garlic, capsicum and chilli.Add in the blanched meat and seasoning. Â Bring to a boil over high heat. Â Stir to coat meat with sauce. Â Thicken with cornflour mix if preferred.Dish out to serve immediately.

title: Stir Fry Sambal Spinach
text: Loved this stir fry spinach with sambal belacan. Â An easy vegetable dish to prepare yet yummy for us who always look forward to some spicy dish at the dinner table whenever there's no curry dish. Â Â Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]500 gm spinach - rinsed and separate leaves with stems, wash and drain in colander1-2 tbsp sambal belacan [home-made or store bought]salt and msg to taste1-2 tbsp coconut milk [I used thick milk]2 tbsp oilHeat oil in wok, saute sambal belacan for 1-2 seconds. Â Add in spinach.Stir well to mix the ingredients. Â Cover to cook for another few seconds.Uncover, add seasoning and milk and fry for 1-2 seconds or until vegetables are cooked.Dish out to serve immediately.

title: Steamed Can Savoury Rice
text: This is quite similar to the Taiwanese steamed savoury glutinous rice in individual stainless steel tall cans [ a hawker's delicacy of Central Taiwan]. Â With this idea, I cooked this steamed rice but using short grain rice [this rice is used for cooking sushi rice]. Â I like to use this rice instead of glutinous rice as it is not that sticky or chewy and we can have it as a One dish meal . Â The rice tasted good and fragrant quite similar to 'Chu Bee P'ng'. Â  I served it with some pickled zuchini and a Miso soup with some sweet leaves [so that there are enough vege for a meal].Ingredients[serves 3 - steamed in 3 individual aluminium cans]200 gm short grain rice - washed and drained6 [50 gm] shallots - sliced3 [50 gm] dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips2 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed200 gm shredded meat with some fats - marinate with soy sauce, pepper, sesame oil and cornflour300 ml water Â enough oil to fry shallotsSeasoning to taste2-3 tbsp light soy sauce1/4 tsp msg1/2 tsp pepper1/2 tsp 5 spice powderHeat oil in pan to fry shallots until golden. Â Dish out. Â Remove excess oil, leaving 1-2 tbsp to fry mushrooms and dried prawns. Â Fry until fragrant, then add in shredded meat. Â Fry until meat is firm.Add in rice and seasoning to taste. Â Stir in fried shallots [reserving some for garnishing].Dish out into individual cans [equal portions]. Â Add about 100 ml water to each portion.Steam for 25-30 minutes or until cooked. Â Leave for 10 minutes before turning out to serve on plate.Garnish with crispy shallots, coriander leaves Â and sweet sour chilli sauce [optional].

title: TOPO VANILLA COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: A slightly difference in the quantity of some ingredients with no increase in number of eggs. Â Custard powder is also used for this cake. Â However, the cake texture is soft, moist and cottony like other cottony cakes.Basic flavour of this cake is vanilla but I used the topo map idea to create a more 'sophisticated' look. Â Ingredients[8 inch square baking tin]5 egg yolks1 egg55 ml corn oil70 ml milk1 tbsp icing sugar [original uses 30 gm]85 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted15 gm custard powder1/4 tsp salt2 tsp vanilla essence5 egg whites70 gm sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartarsome chocolate, green and yellow colouring [can use any colour combination you like]some cocoa powder for dusting in between layersLine base of a 8" square tin with grease proof paper. Â  I greased the sides, too and sprinkle lightly with a little flour [this way, the cake can be easily removed from pan after cooling]. Â I used a 9" pan and the cake is not that tall. Â Use 8" pan if you want a taller cake.Preheat oven to 170 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it. Â WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg until creamy then gradually drizzle in the corn oil followed by milk. Â  Â Whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth. Â Stir in vanilla essence. Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in 3 portions until well combined. Â Divide batter into 4 portions.Â  Add in the colouring, mix well.Scoop the batters alternately to create the uneven layered effect of the cake into prepared cake tin. Â After putting each layer, dust some cocoa powder over it using a small sieve. Â Shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out itself].Â Â Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking.Â Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 45-50 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up]. Â  Â You can also bake the cake at 150 degrees C for 70 minutes.Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 5 minutes [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking].Â Remove baking tin and the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards].Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Turn the cake over when completely cooled. Â Refrigerate before slicing if preferred.

title: Light Cheddar Cheesecake
text: A simple cheesecake baked using cheddar cheese slices for my cousin. Â Her children loves the buttery rich taste of this cake. Â The cake should be baked in a 6 inch pan but I used a 7 inch pan, that's the cause of the cake not be taller.Ingredients[use 6 inch loose base round pan]3 slices cheddar cheese50 gm butter50 ml fresh milk3 large eggs50 gm cake flour or superfine flour3 egg whites50 gm castor sugarPreheat oven at 150 degrees C with a water bath. Â Grease and line a 6 inch loose base round baking pan.Place cheddar cheese slices, butter and milk in a saucepan. Â Over medium low heat, stir gently until all is melted. Â Mix together and set aside for 5-10 minutes to cool before using.Whisk egg yolks until creamy and drizzle in the butter and milk mixture. Â Stir well.Add sifted flour and fold until smoothWhisk egg whites in another mixing bowl until foamy. Â Add in the sugar gradually and beat until stiff peaks formed.Gently fold in 1/3 of the egg whites into the cheese mixture. Â Mix in the balance and be careful not to deflate it.Pour batter into baking tin and smooth the surface.Bake in preheated oven for 50 minutes or until the tester comes out clean.

title: Hakka Style Steamed Beehoon
text: A simple noodle that can be prepared ahead without stir frying yet it can be served hot or warm during meal time. Â Original recipe uses meat but I used prawns. Â The beehoon tasted good even without the meat. Â Initially, I wasn't thinking of posting this recipe cos' it's nothing special about it, that's the reason why I didn't have any step by step photos taken. Â But after eating it, I think it is much, much better than the economy fried beehoon...Ingredients[serves 2]200 gm fine beehoon [rice vermicelli] 100 gm lean pork - cut thin strips [I used 50 gm prawns]1 squid - cleaned and cut thin strips [I omit]100 gm beansprouts - tailed and washedsome spring onions - cut strips or chopped [I used chopped coriander leaves]1 red chilli - cut strips or chopped [I used sambal belacan]Seasoning - combine together2 tbsp sesame oil 1 tbsp soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp sugar1 tsp chicken stock granulesa dash of pepperMarinate meat and squid with 1/4 portion of seasoning [if using, not necessary with prawns].Boil a pot of water to blanch beehoon.Â  Drain dry on a colander. Â Use the same water to blanch beansprouts for a few seconds. Drain on colander.Use marinade to mix with blanched beehoon and beansprouts. Â  Stir to mix well.Put beehoon Â and beansprouts in a steaming dish, top up with marinated meat and squid.Steam over high heat for 8-10 minutes before serving.Sprinkle extra sesame oil before serving.

title: Assam  Pedas Ayam
text: My hubby keeps complaining that the curries he tried at the food outlets are not spicy hot or aromatic enough.This post was inspired by a recipe from Malaysian Food Fest - Johor shared byÂ Queenie of Semalam Berlalu Esok Menanti. Â After cooking this, I realised there were so many different versions of this curry and all looks so mouth watering and some are really spicy. Â This curry is not too spicy basing on my hubby's tastebuds, more chillies can be added [I think he swallowed the food too fast]. Â Perhaps, I'll try some others with more chillies and decide which one has that 'kick'.Anyway, this curry is not too bad, very aromatic and fragrant. Â Best of all, it requires no coconut milk. Â My brother in-law likes it, he says 'not that sinful' and he finished half a plate of it when I told him no coconut milk inÂ this curry.Ingredients[recipe adapted fromÂ Queenie of Semalam Berlalu Esok MenantiÂ with some modifications]800 gm chicken thigh - skinned removed - cut into bite size piecessome daun kesumseasoning - salt, sugar and chicken stock granules to taste2 tbsp tamarind mix with 1/2 bowl water Â 1 bowl water1 tsp fenugreek1/2 tsp tumeric powdera small piece of belacan1 cm piece galangal [lengkuas]20 dried chillies - soaked in hot water, drained and blended till fine [can increase to 30]3-4 tbsp oil Â Ingredients [Ground into Paste]5 lemongrass6 shallots5 cloves garlic2 cm piece gingerHeat oil in pan until hot, saute fenugreek until aromatic. Â Add blended paste. Â Fry until fragrant and crispy. Â  Â Â Add tumeric powder, then chilli paste and belacan. Â Fry until oil separates. Â Add in the chicken, fry to mix well with spices and until chicken pieces are firm. Â Â Add in tamarind juice and water. Â Bring to a boil. Â Add in seasoning and simmer until chicken is cooked. Â Â Lastly add in the kesum leaves. Â Serve curry hot. Â Note: Â Curry tasted even better the next day

title: Family Style Dried Oyster Porridge
text: This is the porridge I cooked for dinner when we came back from 'Cheng Beng'. Â Too tired [after a day out under the scorching sun] to cook anything much, this porridge served with Chinese cruellers [freshly fried, available in the evenings nearby my house] is more than satisfying, lol....I prepared all the ingredients until step 2 before leaving for Cheng Beng. Â Cool and kept it in the fridge. Â Before meal time, I add water to the prepare rice, bring it to boil and cook... [hassle free cooking]. Â Takes about Â 30 minutes and the porridge is ready.Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 cup rice - wash and drain100 gm pork belly [skin removed] or lean pork fillet - cut thin stripsÂ 1 tbsp dried prawns - rinsed5-6 dried oysters [big ones] - soaked to soften and cut halve2 shallots - sliced2 cloves garlic - chopped5-6 cups water [or enough to cook porridge]1-2 tbsp oilsome chopped coriander leaves and spring onions1-2 pieces Chinese cruellerÂ [yew char koay] - cut small piecesSeasoning to taste2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1/2 tsp each of salt and pepper1/4 tsp msg or chicken stock granulesHeat oil in wok, saute shallots and garlic until aromatic and brown.Add in dried prawns, dried oysters and meat to fry for 1-2 minutes or until fragrant. Â Add in the rice, stir to fry for a minute.Â  Add in seasoning to mix. Â Â Stir to combine.Â Dish out into a big pot, add in water.Â  Bring to a boil for 10-15 minutes.Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Off fire and cover pot for 5-10 minutes before serving.Garnish with spring onions and coriander leaves.Â  Serve with Chinese cruellers.

title: BLACK SESAME ZEBRA COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Came across a Japanese Cotton cake recipe using black sesame powder. Â Out of curiosity, I tried this cake but made it into a zebra pattern. Â Since I do not have the black sesame powder, I used ground toasted black sesame seed [not fine enough]. Â I find it a bit difficult to blend the paste with the batter, that's why Â certain parts have a big patch of black sesame due to uneven mixing [I was afraid to deflate the meringue due to over-mixing]. Â  Next time, I must really grind the black sesame into a fine paste or get the powder...Overall the cake tasted good and the texture is still cottony soft and moist. Â The cake doesn't shrink much.Ingredients[8 or 9 inch square baking tin]5 egg yolks1 egg45 ml corn oil70 ml milk65 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside1/4 tsp salt50 gm black sesame powder [you can grind toasted black sesame seeds into paste]5 egg whites100 gm sugar [I reduced to 80 gm]1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 8" square tin with grease proof paper. Â  I greased the sides, too and sprinkle lightly with a little flour [this way, the cake can be easily removed from pan after cooling].Preheat oven to 170 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it. Â WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg until creamy then gradually drizzle in the corn oil followed by milk. Â  Â Whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth.Â  Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â  Remove 1/3 of the cake batter to another bowl.Â  Add in the black sesame powder, mix well.Scoop the 2 batters alternately to create the zebra effect of the cake into prepared cake tin [using a small ladle, put the plain portion in the centre of tin and top with black sesame batter, shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out itself].Â Â Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking.Â Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes, then lower temperature to 140-150 degrees C and continue to bake for 50-55 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up].Â Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 5 minutes [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking]. Remove baking tin and the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards]. The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Â Turn the cake over when completely cooled. Refrigerate before slicing if preferred.

title: Black Currant Jam
text: Black grapes were sold rather cheap at the supermarket over the weekend. Â Haven't make jam with black currants and thought should make it now cos' the grapes were very sweet and they were seedless too.The jam turns out well and since the grapes were very sweet, I used very much less sugar than for my Red Plum JamÂ [see post].Ingredients[makes 1 bottle x 450 gm]600 gm seedless black grapes - washed and drained in a colander, cut into small pieces200 gm sugar [more if the grapes are not too sweet]2 tbsp lemon juice [use 1 tbsp if grapes are sourish]Place a saucer in the freezer [for testing if jam is ready].Mix sugar with cut fruits until sugar melts.Place mixture in a heavy base pot or non-stick pan. Â Add in lemon juice.Bring to a boil then simmer until jam gels up [stir the jam occasionally throughout the cooking]. Â This takes about 30 minutes.Spoon a little of jam onto cooled saucer. Â Return to freezer for about 3-5 minutes. Â If the jam wrinkles up when push with a finger, the jam is ready.Store jam in sterilised glass container. Â Refrigerate jam.

title: Chocolate Loaves
text: Oh!, has been a very hectic period before CNY and until Cheng Beng [in between busy with closing accounts for tax purposes and preparation to move office], hardly have time to bake some nice loaves until now. Â A long outstanding loaf bread to bake. Â  Instead of baking in a Pullman's tin, I made into 3 small loaves and baked them in a 7 inch greased square tin.A soft, fluffy and moist chocolate bread. Â Slightly soft dough but manageable, didn't stick to the fingers while shaping and the bread turns out slightly crusty but soft inside. Â BTW, the bread stays soft even on the third day. Â The whitish thing is actually flour. Â The recipe is a keeper.Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Ingredients[used 7 inch square tin]400 gm bread flour30 gm cocoa powder [I used chocolate powder]1/2 tsp salt1 tbsp milk powder [I used skimmed milk powder]3 tbsp sugar1.5 tsp instant yeast270 ml water2 tbsp butterSift flour and cocoa powder together. Â Add in salt, sugar and milk powder.Place sifted ingredients in a mixing bowl. Â  Add in yeast. Â Gradually add in water as you knead the dough for 5-10 minutes until soft dough is formed.Add in the butter and continue kneading for a further 10-15 minutes or until dough is soft, smooth and elastic. Â  Shape into a ball and cover to proof for 20 minutes or until double in size.Punch down the dough, divide into 3 equal portions. Â Shape in round balls. Â Roll out each portion and fold into thirds, then flatten into a rectangle and roll into a swiss roll. Â  Â Place the 3 swiss rolls in prepared baking tin. Â Leave to proof for an hour or until double in size [dough will rise over the rim of the tin].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 30 minutes.Remove and leave to cool before storing.

title: PANDAN ZEBRA COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: After baking the Cocoa Brandy Zebra Cottony CakeÂ [Ogura Cake], I thought a 'green zebra' should look good too. Â Wanted to have beige and green stripes but somehow or other I decided with this tone cos' I think this way the whole cake will be very fragrant with the pandan paste and coconut milk. Â The original recipe uses milk but here I used fresh thick coconut milk.Â The cake turns out well. Â  A very fragrant, soft, moist and fluffy cake. Â Add a little salt to bring out the flavour of coconut milk. Â  But the zebra pattern was not distinct at all. Â Perhaps, next time I should just add pandan paste to 1/2 the portion and keep the other Â 1/2 portion plain. Â  Â If you are baking this cake, please try it this way. Â  Tasted good, quite like you are eating a 'Nyonya Kuih', but it is light not heavy lol...Ingredients[9 inch square baking tin]6 egg yolks1 egg65 ml corn oil60 ml coconut milk20 ml thick pandan juice65 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside1/2 tsp salt3/4 tsp green colouring [for darker tone to create the zebra effect]6 egg whites75 gm sugar [can reduced to 65 gm]1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 9" square tin with grease proof paper. Â  I greased the sides, too and sprinkle lightly with a little flour [this way, the cake can be easily removed from pan after cooling].Preheat oven to 170 degrees C.Â Â Â Â Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water [about 1.5 cups] for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it. Â WhiskÂ egg yolks and 1 whole egg until creamy then gradually drizzle in the corn oil followed by coconut milk and pandan juice [continue whisking while you add ingredients]. Â  Â Whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth.Â  Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Beat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â  Remove 1/2 of the cake batter to another bowl.Â  Add in the green colouring to mixture, mix well.Scoop the 2 batters alternately to create the zebra effect of the cake into prepared cake tin. Â  Here, I made 4 individual portions to get 4 small zebra cakes within a cake pan. Â Shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out itself].Â Â Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking.Â Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 50 minutes [by then the water bath would have dried up]. Â  Note: the duration also depends on individual ovens, for mine 50-55 minutes is just nice.Remove cake and invert it to cool for about 5 minutes [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking].Â Â Â Remove baking tin and the paper linings immediately and leave cake to cool on a wire rack [base facing upwards].Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Turn the cake over when completely cooled. Â Refrigerate before slicing if preferred.Note:IÂ usually chill the cake in the fridge before slicing. Â This cake tastes as good when chilled.

title: Home-made Sushi Rolls - Uramaki
text: Uramaki [inside out sushi] is sushi roll made with the rice outside and with the seaweed [nori] sheet inside. Â You can make it using any ingredients you like such as crab meat stick, zuchini, fish roe and zuchini or egg omelette strips etc. Â An example of Uramaki is the California Sushi Roll. Â Sprinkled with toasted black and white sesame seeds on the outside make the sushi rollÂ more fragrant.Ingredients for Filling1 Zuchini - washed, seeds removed and cut stripssome crab meat sticks - steamed for 10 minutes - set aside to cool1-2 eggs mix with salt to taste - fried into omelette and cut thick strips1 packet Nori seaweed sheets1 portion of Sushi RiceÂ [see posting on how to prepare/cook sushi rice]sushi mat or cling film wrapMayonnaise Pastemayonnaise mix with some condensed milk and lime juice - transfer to a piping bag [tied up] refrigerate until requiredWrap the sushi mat with a zip lock plastic bag. Â Spread a layer of sushi rice over it, either into a square or rectangle [depends on how well you can manage to make a roll]. Â Sprinkle some toasted white and black sesame seeds over rice [optional].Â Â Place a piece of nori sheet [size according to the area of rice].Place a strip each of the filling ingredients [according to your preferences]over the nori sheet. Â Pipe some mayonnaise over the fillings.Roll up sushi roll with the sushi mat and press tight. Â Make sure the sushi rice is Â compact or firm. Â  Â Sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds all over roll.5. Â Do the same until the rice is used up. Â  Wrap up Uramaki rolls with cling wrap Â  for easier slicing. Â  Â Slice sushi rolls before serving.Note: Â These can be made and refrigerated. Â Cut sushi rolls just before serving.

title: Home-made Sushi Rolls - Futomaki
text: Futomaki are fat or large sushi rolls and they can have more than 2-3 different fillings such as zuchini, carrot, crab meat sticks, egg strips or tuna. Â Some are with mashed hard boiled eggs with mayonnaise. Â For this Futomaki, I didn't add any wasabi cos' I can't stand the taste. Â Instead, I just mixed a little wasabi with Japanese soy sauce as dipping sauce for my nephews. Â  Next time, I will prepare a pickled ginger to go with this sushi rolls.Ingredients for Filling1 Zuchini - washed, seeds removed and cut slender stripssome crab meat sticks - steamed for 10 minutes - set aside to cool1-2 eggs mix with salt to taste - fried into omelette and cut thick strips1 packet Nori seaweed sheets1 portion of Sushi RiceÂ [see posting on How to prepare/cook sushi rice]sushi mat or cling wrapMayonnaise Pastemayonnaise mix with some condensed milk and lime juice - transfer to a piping bag [tied up] refrigerate until required1. Place a piece of nori sheet over a sushi mat.  Spread a  layer   of sushi rice over the nori sheet.  Leave about 1/2" of the nori sheet  at the end without rice.Â 2. Place a strip each of all the ingredients.  Pipe some mayonnaise over the fillings [sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds if you like over the rice].Â 3.Roll up sushi roll using the sushi mat and press tight as you roll up. Make sure the sushi rice is well sealed into a firm roll.4. Do the same until the rice is used up. Slice sushi rolls before serving with wasabi soy sauce and pickled ginger or spread some tuna mayonnaise mix over sushi pieces.

title: Homemade Sushi Rolls - Hosomaki
text: Sushi rolls have always been my nephews' favourite and is a long outstanding request which I couldn't fulfil until now.There are various types of sushi rolls and it is impossible to make all at a time unless you want a variety. Â If Â so, the quantity required of each ingredient is very small. Â This is the simplest sushi roll even for a beginner. Â It may not be as delicate as those made by the sushi chefs but should be satisfying cos' it is really economical to make your own and you can choose the fillings you prefer.Hosomaki are thin sushi rolls with 1 or 2 fillings. Â They can be vegetarian or have some seafood fillings such as crab meat strips, canned tuna or fresh salmon. Â Most common Hosomaki are Tekkamaki [tuna filling] and Kappamaki [cucumber/zuchini strips].Ingredients for Filling1 Zuchini - washed, seeds removed and cut stripssome crab meat sticks - steamed for 10 minutes - set aside to cool1-2 eggs mix with salt to taste - fried into a thick omelette and cut thick strips1 packet Nori seaweed sheets - 10 sheets in a pack1 portion of Sushi Rice [see yesterday's post for preparation]sushi mat [if you have it] or cling wrapNotes: you can choose any combination of filling or use canned tuna [drain of the liquids]Mayonnaise Pastemayonnaise mix with some condensed milk and lime juice - transfer to a piping bag [tied up] refrigerate until requiredCut a piece of nori sheet into half. Â Place it over a sushi mat. Â Spread a very thin layer Â  of sushi rice over the nori sheet. Â Leave about 1/2" at the end of the nori sheet Â without rice. Â Place a strip of zuchini and a strip of carrot [you can omit the carrot]. Â Pipe some mayonnaise over the zuchini strip.Roll up sushi roll using the sushi mat and press tight as you roll. Â Make sure the sushi rice is well sealed into a firm roll.Do the same until the rice is used up. Â Slice sushi rolls [clean and wipe the knife dry if rice sticks to it as you cut] before serving.

title: Homemade Sushi Vinegar and Sushi Rice
text: This homemade sushi vinegar was taught to me by a friend. Â Tasted stronger than the Mizkan sushi vinegar sold at the supermarkets but definitely more economical to prepare your own if you are not going to use the remaining store bought sushi rice vinegar for other cooking purposes, moreover they costs quite a lot compared to vinegar.HOW TO PREPARE SUSHI RICE VINEGARIngredients - Advisable to prepare more if you intend to make more sushi rollsSmall Portion [makes about 75 ml]3 tbsp rice vinegar3 tbsp sugara pinch of salt to tasteBig Portion [makes about 400 ml]270 ml rice vinegar300 gm sugar1 tsp saltMix all ingredients together. Â Stir over low heat until sugar dissolves.Remove from heat and leave aside to cool completely before storing in a clean bottle until required.Notes: This rice vinegar can be used to cook other dishes that requires Mirin like this dishÂ Braised Spanish Mackerel with Soy Sauce and MirinHOW TO PREPARE/COOK SUSHI RICEIngredients400 gm [3 cups] short grain sushi rice - washed and drained600 ml [3 1/2 cups] waterVinegar Dressing For Cooked Sushi Rice [mix together until sugar dissolves]75 ml sushi rice vinegar3 tbsp sugar2 tsp saltRinse short grain sushi rice until clean. Â Drain and add water to steam for 30 minutes. Â Allow rice to stand for 15-20 minutes.Remove to a big bowl [wooden or stainless steel] and mix rice with vinegar dressing by slowly drizzling it into rice. Â The rice grains should be properly mixed with the sushi rice vinegar with a wooden rice paddle to prevent it from becoming lumpy and pasty.Use rice immediately or cover with a damp cloth to retain the moisture [use within 1-2 hours].Use prepared rice to make various sushi you wish to make such as the following:a) Â  Hosomaki Â - Â thin sushi rolls with 1 or 2 ingredientsÂ [see posting]b) Â  FutomakiÂ - fat sushi rolls with more ingredientsÂ [see posting]c) Â  UramakiÂ - Inside-out sushi rolls, eg. California Sushi RollsÂ [see posting]Refer here Â on How to make Sushi Rice

title: Mayo Choco Walnut Muffins
text: I was attracted to this muffin cos' no eggs or butter are required. Â Moreover, no creaming needed yet it is aÂ lovely soft, fluffy muffin using mayonnaise. Â  The muffins stay soft and moist even when cooled.The original recipe is fromÂ Peng's KitchenÂ but I added 50 gm chopped toasted walnuts cos' I have lots of toasted walnuts in my fridge.Â Ingredients[makes 9 muffins]120 gm plain flour20 gm cocoa powder1 tsp bicarbonate of soda [original uses 1 1/2 tsp]100 gm castor sugar100 gm mayonnaise125 ml milk1 tsp vanilla essence50 gm chopped toasted walnuts [optional]Preheat oven at 180 degrees C for 10 minutes.Place sugar, sifted flour and baking soda in a mixing bowl.Whisk mayo, vanilla essence and milk until smooth.Add mayo mixture to the flour. Â Mix until the batter is smooth. Â Add in half the walnuts. Â Mix well.Spoon batter into muffin cases, top with extra chopped walnuts.Bake at preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 20-25 minutes.Remove from tray to cool Â on wire rack or serve warm.

title: Mixed Vegetable Galore
text: My favourite kind of stir fry vegetables with colourful ingredients. Â I wouldn't mind just having this plate of vegetables with some rice for a meal.
