title: ORANGE POPPY SEED COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Another cottony, soft cake with orange flavour.Â Â Â  Nice cake which I baked for Autumn Solstice Festival which falls on 21 December 2012.Â Â  The cake shrinks a little but soft and cottony like the other cottony cakes which I have baked.Â  I like the citrus flavour of orange and slightly salty taste. Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture[using 8"Â  x 8" or 9" x 9" square tin]65 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg45 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]80 mlÂ  fresh orange juice [from 1-2 oranges]2 tsp orange zest2 tsp poppy seedÂ Â Place the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil, orange juice and zest.Â  Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined.Â  Add in poppy seeds and mix well. Set aside.Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack on the tray andÂ  preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar and whisk untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour into a 8" square tin [line base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Smooth the surface with a spatula and steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 70 minutes.Â  [Note: for the water bath, use 1 and 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will be dry after baking].Invert the cake after baking Â and let it cool slightly [about 10-15 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper [there maybe some vapour on the baking paper]. Cool cake before slicing to serve or refrigerate for serving later.Steam bake cake batter @ 160 C for 70 minutesCake after 15-20 minutes bakingCake after 40 minutes bakingCake after 60-70 minutes bakingCake is readyInvert cake immediately to cool for 10-15 minutesRemove baking tin and paper lining, base is dryOrange Poppy Seed Cottony CakeNote:Original recipe was from Min's blog [Orange Poppy Seed Xiang Xi Cake] with some modifications to the method.

title: Fried Noodles with Red Yeast Rice Residue
text: A healthy fried noodle dish using 'ang chow' [red yeast rice residue] after I cooked the Fried Rice with Red Yeast Rice Residue.Â  This is a meatless fried noodle which I believe is light and good for our body especially after days of indulging in meaty dishes.Â  Easy cooking for a weekend meal.Â  Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]200 gm dried noodles - blanched and mix with a little sesame oil8 pieces tofu puffs - cut thick shreds1 piece wood ear fungus - cut thick shreds2-3 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut thick shreds50 gm carrot - shredded100 gm cai xin or xiao bai cai - washed and cut thick shredsÂ Seasoning2 tbsp red yeast rice residue [ang chow]2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp peppersalt to taste 1 tbsp sesame oil150 ml waterÂ Â Â Â Blanched dried noodles until cooked, drain and toss with a little sesame oil.Heat frying pan with sesame oil, add in mushrooms and wood ear fungus.Â  Fry for a second, push aside and add in red yeast rice residue.Â  Fry until aromatic then add in tofu puffs and carrot.Â  Stir fry and add in seasoning.Â  Add water, bring to a boil and taste to adjust seasoning.Add in blanched noodles and vegetables.Â  Continue to stir fry until all ingredients are well mixed and the water is almost dry.Dish out to serve immediately.

title: Baked Cheddar Cheese Chocolate Cheesecake
text: Baked another cheddar cheese cheesecake again but this time with chocolate flavour.Â  The cake didn't shrink much.Ingredients[use 7" loose bottom round cake tin]50 gm cake flour - sifted3 egg yolks50 gm butter3 slices of cheddar cheese [about 30 gm]50 ml milkÂ 50 gm cooking chocolate - melted Using double boil method, dissolve cheddar cheese with butter, then add in melted chocolate and milk.Â  Mix well and set aside to cool.Sieve flour into a mixing bowl, add in egg yolks and cooled melted cheese and butter mixture.Whisk on medium high speed until creamy and ingredients are well combined.Â  Set aside while you prepare the egg white and preheat oven at 150 degrees C.3 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar50 gm sugarIn another clean bowl, whisk egg whites until frothy, add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue beating and gradually add in sugar in 3 batches.Whisk on medium high speed until soft to stiff peaks formed.Pour half [1/2] meringue into egg yolk mixture.Â  Mix well to incorporate ingredients.Then pour into balance meringue.Â  Mix well.Pour batter into a lined loose bottom 7" round cake tin. Smooth the surface with a use of spatula.Steam baked [use 1 1/2 cups water] in baking tray.Baked in preheated oven at 150 degrees for 70 minutes.Â  Remove from pan immediately to cool on rack [cake base is firm and dry].Â Â  This time I left the baked cake in the oven to cool for 1 hour before removing and standing cake on a pedestal to cool further.Â  Chill cake for several hours before slicing.

title: Braised Chicken Wings in Soy Sauce
text: Think I'm getting lazy and just will settle to prepare food the easy way out with less preparation and cleaning up. Â This chicken dish is an easy dish to prepare yet suitable for the young and old. Â For more flavour, just dip in your favourite chilli sauce and enjoy. Â The braising sauce can be stored, refrigerated and reuse to braise other meats.Â Ingredients8-10 pieces chicken wings - cleaned and end tip removedBraising Ingredients800 ml water5 pips garlic2 star anise3 cm piece cinnamon stick3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp salt to taste1 tsp brown sugar to tastebraising sauce Bring water to boil.Â  Add in all the spices and liquid ingredients.Boil for 5-10 minutes until aromatic and fragrant.Add in the chicken wings.Â  Make sure the liquid is enough to cover the chicken wings.Â  Bring to boil again, then lower heat to simmer for 10 minutes.Cover and leave until serving time.

title: Pandan Wholemeal  Steamed Buns
text: These are soft, moist, fluffy and healthy buns good for breakfast or teatime.Â  These buns can also be steamed plain without any filling and serve with meat burgers.Ingredients[makes 8 pieces]Mix togetherÂ - yeast mixture1/2 tsp instant yeast1 tbsp waterPau Ingredients100 gm wholemeal flour100Â gmÂ plain flour [you can useÂ pau flour or low protein flour]1 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt170 180Â ml pandan juice water *15 gmÂ  shorteningÂ [youÂ can useÂ butter or oil]*10 pieces pandan leaves blended with some water - strained and squeezed out juice, discard the residue]Combine and mix yeast mixture in a mixing bowl.Â  Stir well and leave aside for 10-15 minutes.Then add in pau ingredientsÂ  [exceptÂ shortening].Â  Knead into a smooth dough before adding inÂ shorteningÂ to knead until elastic [dough is soft and sticky].Â Â  Cover and leave to proof forÂ 15-20Â minutes or until double in size.Punch down and divide into 2 equal portions.Â  Shape each into a ball.Â  Then divide each portion into 4 equal parts.Â  Roll into round balls.Â Â Flatten each ball into round circles.Wrap each dough around chosen filling and shape into any shapes preferredÂ [I made them into roundÂ buns].Â Â  Place on paper casing and leave to rest for 30-40 minutesÂ or until double in sizeÂ in steaming trays.Steam the buns over rapid boiling water for 10 minutesÂ [ifÂ using normal steamer].Â Â I steamed the buns from cold water for 12-15 minutes in an electric steamer, then leave forÂ 3Â minutes beforeÂ removing from steamer.Serve immediately or cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.If freezing buns, thaw to room temperature and steam for 10 minutes before serving. Stir fry yam bean filling for bunsProof buns in steaming tray for 40-50 minutes

title: Fried Rice With Red Yeast Wine Residue
text: Looks quite a weird fried rice but the taste is good and very healthy. Â If you see the ingredients you would understand what I'm trying to say. Â This rice dish has at least 5 colour ingredients. Â Someone told me if you eat 5 coloured food daily, your body Â [5 main organs] is well taken care.Five Colours that Nourish Five OrgansÂ [read more from this website]Red - HeartBlack - KidneyGreen - LiverWhite - LungsYellow - Spleen and stomachIngredients[serves 2]2 bowls cooked rice3 dried mushrooms [soaked and diced]1 pieces Â 5 spice firm bean curd [diced]1 small carrot [diced]a few french beans [cut small pieces] or 3 tbsp mixed frozen vegetables1 tbsp sesame oil2 tbsp minced gingerSeasoning1-2 tbsp red yeast rice residue[ang chow]2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp pepperHeat sesame oil, saute ginger until fragrant. Â Add in mushrooms, beancurd and carrots.Fry for several seconds, then add in rice and all the seasoning ingredients.Toss and stir fry until well mixed.Add in the green beans or mixed vegetables. Â Continue to fry until vegetables are cookd through.Taste to adjust seasoning. Â Dish out to serve immediately.Click here for other Fried Rice Recipes

title: Sweet Sour [Zesty] Braised Pork Ribs
text: A zesty sauce pork ribs recipe that needs sometime to braise until the ribs are tender before adding sugar. Â  Â  The braising sauce can be used to cook chicken, pork, fish or prawns.Â  The only adjustmentsÂ needed are the quantity of Â water and cooking time. Ingredients300 gm meaty pork ribsBraising Sauce1/3 cup white rice vinegar [I used apple cider vinegar]1-2 tbsp tomato ketchup2 tsp light soy sauce2 cups water 4 tbsp light brown sugar2 tsp cornstarch mix with 2 tbsp water Wash and blanched pork ribs in boiling water for 5-10 minutes.Â  Drain away water and rinsed pork ribs.Marinate with vinegar, tomato ketchup and soy sauce for several hours or overnight.Bring water to boil, then add in the marinated pork ribs together with the marinade.Boil over high heat for 10-15 minutes, then reduce to lower heat and simmer until ribs are tender [may need to add more water if ribs are not tender enough].When pork ribs are tender, add in the sugar.Â  Cook over high heat to reduce the gravy or thicken with cornstarch.Garnish with spring onions and serve with steaming hot rice.

title: Sweet Potato Steamed Buns
text: A steamed bun with sweet potato dough and savoury stir fry yam bean filling.Â  Good for breakfast.Ingredients[dough weighs 600 gm - makes 16 buns]Mix togetherÂ - yeast mixture1 tsp instant yeast2 tbsp waterPau Ingredients300Â gmÂ plain flour [you can useÂ pau flour or low protein flour]150 gmÂ  steamed sweet potato [can use any colour sweet potato] 20Â gm castor sugar1/2 tsp salt80-100 mlÂ Â waterÂ 20 gmÂ  shorteningÂ [youÂ can useÂ butter or oil]Combine and mix yeast mixture in a mixing bowl.Â  Stir well and leave aside for 10-15 minutes.Then add in pau ingredientsÂ  [exceptÂ shortening].Â  Knead into a smooth dough before adding inÂ shorteningÂ to knead until elastic [dough is soft].Â Â  Cover and leave to proof forÂ 15-20Â minutes or until double in size.Punch down and divide into 4 equal portions.Â  Shape each into a ball.Â  Then divide each portion into 4 equal parts.Â  Roll into round balls.Â Â Flatten each ball into round circles.Wrap each dough around chosen filling [I used stir fried yam bean filling - recipe below] and shape into any shapes preferredÂ [here I shaped them into round, oval, triangle and pleated roundÂ buns].Â Â  Place on paper casing and leave to rest for 30-40 minutesÂ or until double in sizeÂ in steaming trays.Steam the buns over rapid boiling water for 10 minutesÂ [ifÂ using normal steamer].Â Â I steamed the buns from cold water for 12-15 minutes in an electric steamer, then leave forÂ 3Â minutes beforeÂ removing from steamer.Serve immediately or cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.Vegetable FillingÂ 300 gm yam bean [sengkuang] - shredded1 small carrot - shredded1 stalk leek - finely sliced [optional]3 dried mushrooms - soaked and shredded1 tsp chopped garlic 1 Tbsp oil2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp salt and pepper to tasteHeat oil in wok, saute garlic until aromatic.Â  Add in mushrooms.Â  Fry until fragrant. Â Â Add in shredded vegetables and seasoning waiting. Â Â Stir well to mix all ingredients well.Â  Cover to cook vegetables until soft.Uncover and add in leek [if using] to cook.Dish out to cool before use.Â  If filling is too watery strain away liquid before wrapping.

title: Orange Sweet Potato Chiffon Cake II
text: Another orange sweet potato chiffon cake which I baked using yoghurt instead of coconut milk. Â The cake is spongy soft and not sweet at all.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]1 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt3 tbsp oil1 tsp lemon juice 60 gm orange sweet potato [skinned, steamed and mashed]60 ml plain yoghurt50 gm cake flour siftedWhisk egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in yoghurt. Â Lastly stir in mashed sweet potato. Fold in the flour, combine well. Â Set aside while you whisk the eggÂ  white.Â  Preheat oven at 160 degrees C.Â Ingredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white3 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartar Whisk egg white until frothy then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking until foamy then gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Mix until well incorporated.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue, Â Mix well. Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes.Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.Slice before serving.

title: Tomyam Sauce Noodles
text: Quite a simple to prepare spicy, sourish noodles using tom yam paste. Â  The main ingredients for this dish are noodles and the gravy sauce.Â  The rest can be according to your own preference or whatever that are suitable which you can find in your fridge. I have added shredded cabbage and carrots to the noodles because I'm serving it as a 1 Dish Meal.Â  It's optional and you can use anyÂ  of your favourite vegetables.Â Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 - 200 gm noodlesÂ 1 tbsp sesame oil1-2 chicken thigh - shredded1 piece firm beancurd - optional [fried and diced]some nori seaweed - small strips or pieces1 tbsp toasted sesame seedssome chopped spring onions and coriander leavesTom Yam Gravy Sauce400 ml water2 tbsp oyster sauce1-2 tbsp tom yam paste2 tbsp sweet chilli sauce1 tbsp lime juicesalt and sugar to taste1 tsp cornstarch + 2 tsp waterÂ  Bring water to boil.Â  Add in chicken thighs to cook for several minutes or until cooked.Â  Dish out to cool and shredded.Â  Set aside.Add all the sauce ingredients to boiling water.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Thicken with cornstarch mixture.In another pot, bring enough water to boil.Â  Blanched vegetables.Â  Dish out, drain off excess water.Â  Place on individual serving plate.Using the same water, blanched noodles until cooked or al dente.Â  Remove and drain off excess water and add sesame oil and toss well.Â To serve, place noodles on top of blanched vegetables, top with shredded chicken and fried beancurd [if using].Â  Spoon hot tom yam gravy sauce over noodles.Top with some nori seaweed, sesame seeds and chopped spring onions/coriander leaves.Â Â Notes:-Â  Some tom yam paste are quite salty and spicy.Â  You may have to adjust the quantity use according to your taste.-Â  you can use fresh noodles [wantan noodles] or dried noodles according to your own preference.

title: 1:1.5 Ratio Wholemeal Steamed Buns
text: This is another steamed wholemeal buns with a different ratio of wholemeal flour to plain flour. Â The ratio here is 1 part of wholemeal flour to 1 and 1/2 parts of plain or pau flour. Â These buns are as good as the 1:2 Ratio Wholemeal Steamed BunsÂ [recipe here]. Â They are soft and fluffy. Â Â  Moreover, they are really easy to make using straight dough method. Â Ingredients[dough weighs 900 - makes 20 pieces ]Mix togetherÂ - yeast mixture1 tsp instant yeast2 tbsp waterPau Ingredients200 gm wholemeal flour300Â gmÂ pauÂ flour [you can useÂ plain flour but the buns maybe slightly yellowish]50Â gm castor sugar1/2 tsp salt260 ml water [original recipe uses 310-330 ml]30 gmÂ  shorteningÂ [youÂ can useÂ butter or oil]Filling - Meat/Fish Paste Filling [recipe below]Combine and mix yeast mixture in a mixing bowl.Â  Stir well and leave aside for 10-15 minutes.Then add in pau ingredientsÂ  [exceptÂ shortening].Â  Knead into a smooth dough before adding inÂ shorteningÂ to knead until elastic.Â Â  Cover and leave to proof forÂ 15-20Â minutes or until double in size.Punch down and divide into 5 equal portions.Â  Shape each into a ball.Â  Then divide each portion into 4 equal parts.Â  Roll into round balls.Â Â Flatten each ball into round circles.Wrap each dough around chosen filling and shape into any shapes preferredÂ [here I shaped them into roundÂ buns].Â Â  Place on paper casing and leave to rest for 30-40 minutesÂ or until double in sizeÂ in steaming trays.Steam the buns over rapid boiling water for 10 minutesÂ [ifÂ using normal steamer].Â Â I steamed the buns from cold water for 12-15 minutes in an electric steamer, then leave forÂ 3Â minutes beforeÂ removing from steamer.Serve immediately or cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.Â  Meat/Fish Paste Filling[enough forÂ  20 buns]250 gm minced meat [mix with 2-3 tbsp water]150 gm fish paste [you can use prawns or chicken]2 stalks spring onions - finely chopped1 tbsp finely chopped gingerSeasoningÂ 1 tbsp each of wine and light soy sauce1/2 tbsp sesame oil1/2 tsp each of salt and sugarÂ 1/4 tsp pepper to tasteAdd water to minced meat, stir until all the water is absorbed into the meat.Add in all other ingredients to meat.Â  Stir ingredients in one [1] direction for about 5 minutes.Lift and slap paste against side of bowl for about 15 times.Â  Paste will be sticky.Transfer to a container, cover and chill in fridge for at least an hour before use.Note- this paste can be used as filling for steamed buns or dumplings [bianshi - boiled wantans].

title: GD Buns with Egg Potato and Tuna Filling
text: GD here means gelatinised dough.Â The original recipe was from Sonia ofÂ Nasi Lemak Lover.Â Â  This is a good bun recipe which I have tried many times with various fillings. Â Here, I'm using the same bun recipe with Â  Â  another savoury filling, Egg, Potato and Tuna Filling.Ingredients for Gelatinized Dough100 gm bread flour70 ml hot boiling waterÂ Mix together into a rough dough using a pair of chopstick.Â  Cover dough with cling film [I used a plastic airtight container] and leave dough to cool in the fridge for 1 hour and up to 48 hours [2 days].To Prepare Basic Sweet Bread Dough1 portion of the gelatinized dough300 gm bread flour100 gm plain flour80 gm castor sugar20 gm milk powder [I used 1 tbsp skimmed milk powder]1 tbsp yeast1/2 tsp salt1 cold egg175 ml cold water [I used only 160 ml because I used 1 large egg]60 gm cold butter - cubed [I used 50 gm]egg glaze [I used milk]Â Mix sweet bread dough ingredients [except butter] with gelatinized dough in a mixer with dough hook.  Knead on medium speed for about 10 minutes till soft and smooth [the dough is quite wet but it is alright] then add in butter.Continue to knead for another 10 - 15 minutes until dough is soft, smooth and elastic [the dough should be ready if it does not stick to the fingers when touch].Â Shape into a round ball with floured hands, cover and leave to rest for 15 minutes or until double in size.Â Punch down dough.  Divide dough into 16 equal portions [quite big buns] or 20-24 portions [smaller buns].Â Shape into balls, then roll each ball on a floured board into circle.  Add the filling, pinch the seam to seal the edges and roll/shape into any shapes preferred.  Place bun on cupcake paper casing or parchment paper.Â Leave to rise for 45 minutes in the oven.  Remove them from the oven  after 40 minutes before preheating oven.  Brush with beaten egg glaze or milk and sprinkle with some sesame seeds.Â Bake in preheated oven at  180 degrees C [middle shelf] for 15 minutes.   Turn to top heat for another 1-2 minutes just to brown buns [buns look pale if using milk].Remove to cool on rack immediately before storing.Â NotesYou can prepare the dough until Step 2, keep in a durable plastic bag, tied up and refrigerate until later use.Â  ThawÂ  dough to room temperature before shaping for baking.Egg, Potato and Tuna Filling[enough for making 12 - 16 buns]1 can tuna in mayonnaise [if using tuna flakes in brine - drain away the liquid and add 3 tbsp mayonnaise]1 hard boiled egg - diced1 potato - steamed and mashedsome dried Italian mixed spices/herbsÂ  some pepper and salt to tastePrepare and mix all the ingredients together.Â  Refrigerate before using.

title: Wolf Berry Leaf Soup
text: A healthy soup for the family with simple ingredients.Â  This is a quick boil soup with vegetables [you can add more of the vegetable if you like] and you need not have another stir fry vegetable.Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 gmÂ  lean meat - washed and keep whole200 gm wolfberry leaves [kou gei]Â 4-5 pieces of tong sum4-5 Chinese red dates 1 tbsp wolfberries [kei chi]700 ml water salt and pepper to tastedash of pepper and chicken stock granulesBring water to boil with tong sum and red dates for several minutes.Add in the meat.Â  Boil until meat is cooked and tender.Add in seasoning to taste, kei chi and lastly the wolfberry leaves.Bring to boil forÂ  1-2 minutes until leaves are cooked.Off heat, remove the meat and cut into slices.Return meat slices to soup and serve immediately.

title: Steamed Fish With Ginger Onion Paste
text: Isn't this a simple and lovely steamed fish.Â  Fresh caught grouper weighing about 700 gm.Â  So delicious, every fleshy part of the fish was completed consumed.Â  Next time I will take a photo of the bones left, that will explain better, hahaha!Ingredients700 gm grouper [garoupa] - cleaned and marinate with some shaoxing wine and 1 tsp cornflour60 gm young ginger - finely minced4 stalks of spring onions [white part - finely minced and green part - cut shreds]1 tbsp oilSeasoning [mixed together]1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and oyster sauce1/2 tsp each of sugar andd sesame oilsalt and pepper to taste1/3 cup of waterGarnishingsome red chilli curlscoriander leavesspring onion shredssome fried garlic crispsÂ Cleaned and cut fish at the base [separating the flesh and bones] to open up the fish as above.Â  Make 2-3 slits on both sides.Â  Rub wine and cornstarch all over the fish and place on steaming plate.Heat oil, stir fry minced ginger and spring onions until aromatic.Â  Dish out and spread over fish and some at the bottom.Using the same wok, heat up mixed seasoning sauce [not necessary to boil it].Â  Remove to a bowl and pour over the base of the steaming plate.Steam fish over high heat for 15-18 minutes or until fish is cooked.Remove from heat and garnish with red chilli, spring onions, coriander leaves and fried garlic.Serve immediately.

title: Japanese Style Loaf Bread [Tangzhong Method]
text: A soft, moistÂ  and QQ loaf bread with wholemeal flour added.Â  You can use all bread flour too.Ingredients for Tangzhong [Water Roux Paste][yields about 250 gm water roux paste]50 gm bread flour250 ml [1 cup] waterMix flour and water in a small saucepan.Cook over medium-low heat, stirring continuously until it reaches 65ÂºCÂ (should thickened to a paste at this stage) and when you stir you can see the bottom of the pan.Remove from heat and place a cling film over the paste (making sure that it touches the paste) and leave until lukewarm before using.Note: This water roux can be kept in an airtight container after cooling in the refrigerator for a day if not using immediately.Â  If after several days, discard if roux already turned grey.Ingredients[makes 2 loaves x 500 gm] [original recipe from Christine's Recipe with some modifications]600 gm bread flour100 gm wholemeal flour1 1/2 tsp salt4 tbsp sugar2 tbsp milk powder [optional]4 tsp instant yeast All of the above water roux [tangzhong paste]1 large egg220-250 ml milk60 gm butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter and water] on slow speed to combine.Â  Add in water gradually as you may need less than 250 ml because of the water roux paste.Â Â  Continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky [if dough is too wet, it may prolong the kneading time].Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 30 minutes or double in size [usually is less than 1 hour depending on temperature of the day].Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 2 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â  Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tins.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour/rise to 80% of the baking tin] or in a heated oven at 40 degrees C for 45 minutes.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack.

title: Steamed Pork Ribs Wintermelon Soup
text: Steaming soups is a wholesome way of cooking which seals in the flavours and nutrients of ingredients being cooked. Â  Â Ingredients[serves 2-3] 200 gm soft bone pork ribs - cut bite size pieces150 gm winter melon - skin removed and cut bite size pieces600 ml water3 piece tong sum - rinsed3-5 Chinese red dates - rinsed1 tbsp dried longan - rinsed1/2 tsp salt to taste1/2 tbsp abalone sauce1 tbsp kei chi [wolf berries] - add last before serving1/2 tsp rock sugar to tasteÂ  Wash pork ribs, then blanched in boiling water for several minutes.Â  Drain away water and rinsed.Skin the melon, remove the seed and pith.Â  Cut bite size pieces.Boil water in saucepan and add in pork ribs and tong sum. Bring to a boil then simmer for 20 minutes.Â Add in the rest of ingredients.Â  Bring to a boil again.Pour soup in a tureen or steaming bowl big enough to hold all the ingredients.Place in a steamer and steam over medium heat for 40-50 minutes or until pork ribs are tender.Â  Add in kei chi during the last 5 minutes of steaming.Serve soup hot in a claypot if preferred or in a soup bowl.Notes:Can replace pork ribs with chicken pieces.Â  No need to simmer meat [step 4] if using chicken.Â  Steaming time can be reduced to 30 minutes.

title: 1:2 Ratio Wholemeal Steamed Buns
text: Recently, I discovered that my 2-tier electric steamer can be used to steam buns which turn out very nice Â [please see posting on Steamed Black Sesame Buns].Â  I always thought that the pau base maybe wet due to condensation if I use this kind of steamer.Â One thing I can't explain is the pau skin is a little wrinkled [I follow exactly the proofing and steaming time].But this steamer is only good if making small quantity [about 6-12 pieces] otherwise it is still advisable to use the big bamboo steamer to avoid over proofing of the paus.I have several wholemeal steamed bun recipes in hand which I will probably start to make since it is so convenient now with the use of electric steamer. Â  Â  I'll be making these buns with various ratio of wholemeal flour to plain flour. Â  This recipe uses 1 part of wholemeal flour to 2 parts of plain flour [1:2 ratio].Â Â  If you notice, the buns look a little yellowish probably because I used the unbleached all purpose flour.Â  Perhaps, I should use pau flour if I prefer whiter paus.Â  The buns were very soft and nice.Â For the filling, I used the Milky Coconut Bun filling [recipe here].Â  You can use any Â other fillings, be it sweet or savoury, it should be alright.Ingredients[dough weighs 600 - makes 12 pieces ]Mix together - yeast mixture1 tsp instant yeast2 tbsp waterPau Ingredients100 gm wholemeal flour200 gm plain flour [you can use pau flour or low protein flour]20 gm castor sugar1/2 tsp salt180-210 ml water20 gm  shortening [you can use butter or oil]Â Combine and mix yeast mixture in a mixing bowl.  Stir well and leave aside for 10-15 minutes.Â Then add in pau ingredients  [except shortening].  Knead into a smooth dough before adding in shortening to knead until elastic.   Cover and leave to proof for 15-20 minutes or until double in size.Punch down and divide into 3 equal portions.  Shape each into a ball.  Then divide each portion into 4 equal parts.  Roll into round balls.  Flatten each ball into round circles.Â Wrap each dough around chosen filling and shape into any shapes preferred [here I shaped them into round buns].   Place on paper casing and leave to rest for 30-40 minutes or until double in size in steaming trays.Steam the buns over rapid boiling water for 10 minutes [if using normal steamer].  I steamed the buns from cold water for 12-15 minutes in an electric steamer, then leave for 3 minutes before removing from steamer.Â Serve immediately or cool on wire rack before storing in airtight container.

title: Milky Coconut Bun Filling
text: I used this as filling for my 1:2 Ratio Wholemeal Steamed Buns [recipe posting tomorrow].Â  This filling can also be used for baked buns.Ingredients[makes about 350 gm filling - enough for 16 buns]60 gm castor sugar [original recipe uses 100 gm]2 tbsp condensed milk1/2 tsp salt2 tbsp water250 gm grated white coconut1 tbsp custard powder mix with 1 tbsp waterÂ Â Â Place sugar, condensed milk, salt and water in a non stick pan.Â  Turn to medium low heat to dissolve the sugar.Add in grated coconut.Â  Stir to mix the ingredients well.Add in custard solution and continue to stir and mix well.Continue to fry until coconut is almost dry but moist.Â  It should leave the sides of the pan clean.Dish out to cool and refrigerate before using.

title: Japanese Style Sweet Bun Dough
text: This is the sweet version of Japanese style [water roux/tangzhong] bun which I baked after the savoury versionÂ [recipe here] which is soft, fluffy and light. Â  As mentioned earlier, serve these warm or at room temperature, it taste equally good.Â  It can be kept for up to a week in an airtight container in the refrigerator.Â  Just reheat in the oven @ 100 degrees C for 15 minutes [best to wrap in foil] or microwave before serving.Water Roux Paste [tangzhong][yields about 150 gm tangzhong]25 gmÂ  [slightly less than 2 tbsp] bread flour125 ml [1/2 cup] waterMix flour and water in a small saucepan.Cook over medium-low heat, stirring continuously until it reaches 65ÂºCÂ (should thickened to a paste at this stage) and when you stir you can see the bottom of the pan.Remove from heat and place a cling film over the paste (making sure that it touches the paste) and leave until lukewarm before using.Note: This water roux can be kept in an airtight container after cooling in the refrigerator for a day if not using immediately.Â  If after several days, discard if roux already turned grey.Ingredients for Savoury Buns - dough weighs about 800 gm[makes 16 pieces x 50 gm] 375 gm bread flour100 gm plain flour35 gm milk powder [I used 2 tbsp]75 gm castor sugar [I used 5 tbsp]3/4 tsp saltÂ 2 1/2 tsp instant yeast1 egg150 ml lukewarm water [adjust as necessary]40 gm butterKnead all dough ingredients including all the water roux [except water and butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  Gradually add in water [don't add all, it may be too much], thenÂ  continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 25 minutes or double in size.Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 4 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball and rest for 10 minutes.Â  Divide each portion into 4 equal portions of about 50 gm each.Shape into round balls.Â  Roll into circle and wrap each portion with a tablespoon of filling.Â  Shape into any shapes preferred [round, oval or triangle].Â  Bring the edges together and seal well.Place sealed side down on paper casing.Â  Leave prepared dough on baking tray.Â  Do the same for the others.Leave in oven to proof until double in size or in heated oven at 40 degrees C for 45 minutes.Â  Brush with egg glaze, snip a small criss-cross or lines on top before baking.Bake in preheated oven at 190 degrees C for 12-15 minutes on middle shelf. Remove and cool on wire rack.Â Â Â Â Â Â Bacon Potato Mayo Filling - enough for 12 buns75 gm streaky bacon - cut small pieces1 potato - boiled or steamed then mashed while hot1 onion - chopped finely 3 tbsp mayonnaiseÂ dash of salt and pepper to tasteÂ Â Heat a non stick pan to fry bacon until brown.Â  Remove but leave the oil behind toÂ  fry the onions until soft.Add in mashed potato and seasoning.Â  Mix well and stir in the fried bacon.Dish out to cool before adding mayonnaise.Refrigerate until later use.

title: Century Egg and Meatball Porridge
text: Quite a simple yet delicious century egg porridge.Â Â  Some recipes use salted eggs too, but omit it because I just love to taste the sweet, fragrant flavour of century eggs.Â  Here I used duck century eggs which are more fragrant and taste sweeter than chicken century eggs.Ingredients[serves 2-3]Meat Balls Preparation200 gm minced pork1/2 tsp salt1 tsp light soy saucedash of pepper1 tsp cornstarchMarinate minced pork with seasoning.Â  Stir to mix well in 1 direction.Â  Keep refrigerated before use.Â  Shape into meat balls before adding to porridge.Rice Preparation125 gm rice - washed and drained1 tbsp oil1/2 tsp salt1500 ml water3-5 slices ginger2 century egg - shelled and choppedÂ Seasoning - salt, light soy sauce and pepper to tasteServe with some shredded young ginger, chopped spring onions, sesame oil and pepper Season rice with the oil and salt for 30 minutes.Â  Bring water to boil, put in ginger slices, rice mixture and 1/2 of the century egg.Â  Cook over high heat until boiling, then lower heat to simmer for about 1 hour.Stir porridge ocassionally to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pot.Â Half way through cooking, add in the meat balls and continue to cook.Once porridge is soft and thick, add in remaining century egg and seasoning to taste.Scoop the porridge into serving bowl, sprinkle with some shredded young ginger,Â  chopped spring onions, sesame oil and a dash of pepper.

title: KIWI YOGHURT COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: Was browsing through some food blogs about cottony cake sometime ago. Â By chance I came across a cake called Ogura Cake. Â After going through the recipe, I realised that it is the same as the cottony cake recipe. Â If I'm not wrong, there are at least 3 names for the similar cake. Â That is, Â Xiang Si cake, Ogura cake and maybe Souffle cake. Â  Before knowing these names, I called the cake as Cottony Cake so as not to confuse myself.So this cake can be named as Kiwi Yoghurt Ogura Cake, Kiwi Yoghurt Xiang Si Cake, Kiwi Yoghurt Souffle Cake and Kiwi Yoghurt Cottony Cake.Â  Whichever the name is, this type of cake is cottony soft, low in sugar, fats and gluten and there are so many flavours you can try.A little drop of apple green colouring and a teaspoon on poppy seeds were added to make the cake more appealing even though it is already a nice cake.Â  These can be omitted.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture65 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg45 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]80 ml kiwi yoghurtÂ 1 tsp lemon juicePlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil, lemon juice and yoghurt. Â Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â Set aside. Â Pour 1 and 1/2 cups water into baking tray, place baking rack over tray.Â  Preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar untilÂ  slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour into a 8" square tin [lined base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Smooth the surface with a spatula and steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 70 minutes.Â  For the water bath, use 1 1/2 cups water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will be dry after baking.Invert the cake after baking Â and let it cool slightly [about 10-15 minutes] before removing the pan and baking paper. Â Â Cool cake before slicing to serve or refrigerate for serving later.Notes:- can be served chilledÂ -Â must finish within 2-3 days if kept in room temperature- keeps well in an airtight container when refrigerated for more than a week

title: Steamed Black Sesame Buns
text: This is a healthy steamed bun that has the flavour of black sesame seeds which is easy to prepare.Â  Original recipe uses red bean paste as filling. Â  But,Â  I'm using the Savoury Split Green Bean Paste filling [see here for preparation]Â  leftover from the making ofÂ  Purple Rose Buns [see posting here].Â  Should look good with outer pau skin black and interior yellowÂ  [didn't expect it to be so symmetrical..] .Â  The buns were lovely, soft and moist. Â Â Ingredients[dough weighs 550 - makes 12 pieces ]Mix together - yeast mixture1 tsp instant yeast1/2 tsp sugar1 tbsp pau flour180 ml lukewarm waterPau Ingredients300 gm pau flour or low protein flour1 tsp double action baking powder40 gm castor sugar30 gm black sesame powder [I grind toasted black sesame seeds until fine]30 gm butterÂ Â Â Filling Â  savoury split green bean paste or 200 gm store bought red bean pasteÂ  Combine and mix yeast mixture in a mixing bowl.Â  Stir well and leave aside for 10-15 minutes.Then add in pau ingredientsÂ  [except butter].Â  Knead into a smooth dough before adding in butter to knead until elastic.Â Â  Cover and leave to proof for 30-40 minutes or until double in size.Punch down and divide into 3 equal portions.Â  Shape each into a ball.Â  Then divide each portion into 4 equal parts.Â  Roll into round balls.Wrap each dough around chosen filling and shape into any shapes preferred.Â  I used round, pleated and oval shapes.Â  Place on paper casing and leave to rest for 20-25 minutes.Steam the buns over rapid boiling water for 10 minutes.Â  I steamed the buns from cold water for 12-15 minutes in an electric steamer, then leave for 5-10 minutes before eating.Â Â Â Â  Notes:This is the first time I tried steaming paus/buns with my electric steamer with 2 trays. For this portion, I can only steam 6 buns at a time.

title: Thai Green Mango Fish
text: My hubby's fishing 'kakis' caught a 2 kilogram threadfin fish and shared with us 3 slices of it.Â  So far I haven't cook freshly caught fish by frying.Â  This time with some fresh green mangoes from my neighbour, I pan fried the fish for a change. Yummy, sweet, sourish mango with fried fish.......um!!!Â Â Â  Nice with plain white rice. Ingredients[serves 2-3] 3 slicesÂ  fish [I used thread fin fish] - cleaned and pat dry oil for frying fishsome toasted sesame seeds - optional Ingredients for Sauce- [A]1 small green fragrant mango [shredded]3-5 shallots - sliced thinly1 stalk coriander - minced1 red chilli padi - sliced thinlyÂ Combine Together- [B]5 tbsp limau kasturi juice [calamansi lime]2 tbsp fish sauce3 tbsp sugarÂ Â On a serving plate, put a layer of shredded mango, shallots, chilli and chopped coriander. Heat wok, add in oil.Â Â  Fry fish slices untilÂ  cooked and golden brown.Dish out on to serving plate.Garnish with balance of [A] ingredients, then pour combined sauce B over fried fish and [A].Serve immediately.Note:You can use fish fillets or even a whole fish for this dish. Â  I'm submitting this post toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013Â Â hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: Japanese Style Savoury Buns with Luncheon Meat
text: Luncheon Meat Mayo Bun FillingÂ This savoury bun uses water roux [tangzhong] which is soft, fluffy and light.  Serve warm or at room temperature, it tastes equally good.  It can be kept for up to a week in an airtight container in the refrigerator.  Just reheat in the oven @ 100 degrees C for 15 minutes [best to wrap in foil] or microwave before serving.Water Roux Paste [tangzhong][yields about 150 gm tangzhong]25 gm  [slightly less than 2 tbsp] bread flour125 ml [1/2 cup] waterÂ Mix flour and water in a small saucepan.Â Cook over medium-low heat, stirring continuously until it reaches 65ÂºC (should thickened to a paste at this stage) and when you stir you can see the bottom of the pan.Â Remove from heat and place a cling film over the paste (making sure that it touches the paste) and leave until lukewarm before using.Â Note: This water roux can be kept in an airtight container after cooling in the refrigerator for a day if not using immediately.  If after several days, discard if roux already turned grey.Ingredients for Savoury BunsÂ - dough weighs about 800 gm[makes 16 pieces x 50 gm]Â 325 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour20 gm milk powder [I used 1 tbsp]50 gm castor sugar [I used 3 tbsp]3/4 tsp saltÂ 2 1/2 tsp instant yeast2 eggs100 ml lukewarm water [adjust as necessary]75 gm butter [I used 50 gm]Knead all dough ingredients including all the water roux [except water and butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  Gradually add in water [don't add all, it may be too much], thenÂ  continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 25 minutes or double in size.Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 4 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball and rest for 10 minutes.Â  Divide each portion into 4 equal portions of about 50 gm each.Shape into round balls.Â  Roll into circle and wrap each portion with a tablespoon of filling.Â  Bring the edges together and seal well.Place sealed side down on paper casing.Â  Leave prepared dough on baking tray.Â  Do the same for the others.Leave in oven to proof until double in size or in heated oven at 40 degrees C for 45 minutes.Â  Brush with egg glaze, sprinkle with sesame seeds, then snip a small criss-cross on top before baking.Bake in preheated oven at 190 degrees C for 12-15 minutes on middle shelf. Remove and cool on wire rack. Â Proof dough until double in sizeBrush with egg glaze, sprinkle sesame seedsCut criss-cross on top before bakingFillings - Luncheon Meat With Mayo200 gm luncheon meat [diced] - can replace with ham1 onion - chopped1 tsp oil1 tsp black pepper3-4 tbsp mayonnaiseÂ Brown diced luncheon meat or ham in pan.  Push aside.Â Fry onions in oil to soften slightly, then mix with fried meat.  Add in pepper.Â Mix well.  Dish out to cool before mixing with mayonnaise.Â Refrigerate before using.

title: Savoury Brown Rice in Claypot
text: A rice dish that is not difficult to prepare yet yummy as a 1 Dish Meal for an easy lunch or dinner.Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 gm brown rice - wash and drain200 ml water or enough water1 boneless chicken thigh - skin removed - cut cubes1 Chinese sausage [lap cheong] - blanched in hot water then sliced1 small piece of salted fish - wash and diced1 spring onion - chopped1 red chilli - choppedSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp chicken stock granules1/2 tsp salt 1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp sesame oilÂ a dash of pepper some cornstarchÂ Â Â Â Marinade chicken with 1/4 of the seasoning ingredients.Cook brown rice in claypot with some oil [prevent rice from sticking to base while cooking].Â  When water boils and simmeringÂ  [just when water is just drying up], pour 1/2 of the seasoning sauce over rice then spread marinate chicken, sausage and salted fish over rice.Cover to continue cooking rice and ingredients for 5-10 minutes on low heat till the fragrance of the marinated ingredients seeped into the rice.Â  Off fire and leave rice covered for 10-15 minutes.Sprinkle spring onions and chilli before serving.When serving, give it a good stir and dish out into individual bowls or plates to serve.Note:I served this rice dish with a simple vegetable soup.

title: SWEET POTATO WHOLEMEAL LOAF [STRAIGHT DOUGH METHOD]
text: One of the many lovely bread recipe worth keeping.Â  Should be a healthy bread with sweet potato and wholemeal flour as part of the ingredients.Â  The bread is soft, moist and fluffy.Â  Too good it was finished in 2 days.Ingredients[makes 1 loaf bread -Â  800 gm]200 gm sweet potato [orange or purple] - steamed and mashed350 gm bread flour50 gm ] wholemeal flour 40 gm sugar [2 tbsp]3/4 tsp salt1 egg150 ml water [add gradually - mashed sweet potato may be wet]2 tsp instant yeast40 gm butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter and water] on slow speed to combine.Â  Add in water gradually as you may need less than 150 ml because of the sweet potato.Â  ThenÂ  continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky [if dough is too wet, it may prolong the kneading time].Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 30 minutes or double in size [usually is less than 1 hour depending on temperature of the day].Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 3 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â  Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tin.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour/rise to 80% of the baking tin] or in a heated oven at 40 degrees C for 45 minutes.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack. Â Notes:You can make it in a big loaf of 800 gm or 2 smaller loaves of 400 gm each.

title: EZ Stir Fry Mushrooms with Bok Choy
text: Bought several packets of organic fresh abalone mushrooms [reasonably priced] during a health talk.Â  They were very fresh, and sweet.Â  Just by simple stir frying with leafy greens and fish sauce as seasoning is good enough.Ingredients300 gm bok choy - washed and cut bite size pieces1 packet abalone mushrooms - small size type - keep wholeseveral dashes of fish sauce [if vegetarian - season with salt or light soy sauce]2 tsp sesame oil or 1 tbsp oilHeat wok, add sesame oil to saute mushrooms for a second.Add in bok choy stems followed by fish sauce.Stir well to mix, then add in the leafy parts.Stir for a while just to cook vegetables.Dish out and sprinkle some fried garlic crisps.Â  Serve immediately.

title: Steamed Fish Head with D.O.M.
text: This fish head [thread fin fish] is from the same fish which I used to prepare Steamed Fish Fillet with Rice VermicelliÂ  [see post].Â Here, I used a very simple sauce [including liquer] to steam the fish.Â  The sauce has a strong sweet taste of D.O.M liquer.Ingredients1 fish head - halvedsome shredded gingersome spring onions and red chilli for garnishing Steaming Sauce - mix together1-2 tbsp of D.O.M. liquer [depending on size of fish head]1/2 tbsp each of light soy sauce and oyster sauce1/2 tsp chicken stock granules or msg1 tbsp sesame oilPlace fish head in a steaming plate or flat bowl.Pour in steaming sauce and sprinkle some shredded ginger.Bring water to boil and steam fish for 8-10 minutes [depending on size of fish head] or until cooked through.Off fire and garnish with spring onions and chilli.Serve immediately.

title: Purple Rose Buns With Green Pea Filling
text: Have seen many postings by fellow bloggers on these cute little roses.Â  Here, are some of the cute little roses that I have made to satisfy my curiosity.Â  Do they look cute or awful? Â  Do visit these blogs for a better explanation on the making [Wendy, Table for 2...or more and Sherleen's Kitchen Diary ] if you wish to try.Ingredients[original recipe adapted from Sherleen's Kitchen Diary ] - I doubled the quantity and used Savoury Green Bean Paste as filling] 125 gm pau flour [can use supefine flour]80 gm mashed purple sweet potato20 gm sugar [I used 1 tbsp]1/4 tsp instant yeast1 tsp corn oil [I used vegetable shortening] Â  Pau DoughÂ Mix and knead all ingredients [except shortening] in a mixer bowl until soft.Add in shortening and continue to knead dough until soft, smooth and elastic.Shape into a ball, cover and let it proof for 1-2 hours or until 1 1/2 times in size.Punch down and knead for 1-2 minutes.Divide dough into 10 gm each.Â  Roll each piece into a flat circle of equal width. Â To form the rose, please see pictures below [I did the rose in 2 different ways].Place rose buns on paper cases and restÂ  forÂ  30-40 minutes or until double in size in a steaming tray.Steam over boiling water for 10 minutes.Â  Off fire but leave buns in steamer for a further 2-3 minutes before uncovering and remove to cool on wire rack.Â First Way Â Â Â Â Second WayÂ  Â Â Â Â Â Â Note:For the second method, the dough weighs about 50 gm [you can make it either bigger or smaller. it's okay] and filling is about 20 gm.Fillings - Savoury Green Bean Paste [see here for recipe]

title: Roasted Chicken Wings
text: There are so many versions/flavours of roast chicken wings which I have in hand. This sometimes makes it difficult to decide Â which to do first. Â Anyway, a simple one this time where the marinating ingredients are easily available in any kitchen.Â I'm making quite a number cos' it's for a family gathering over the weekend but the recipe here is for making 10 pieces chicken wings. Â Moreover, the chicken seller has offered a discount too. Ingredients10 pieces chicken wings - cleaned and pat drya few tablespoons of honeyMarinating Sauce [Mix Together] for chicken3 tbsp sweet chilli sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp BBQ sauce [Can replace with worchester sauce]1 tbsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp shaoxing wine1 tbsp sesame oil1 tbsp oildash of pepper to tastesalt to tasteMix marinating ingredients in a bowl. Â Taste to adjust seasoning.Add in cleaned and dried chicken wings. Â Mix well to coat with sauce.Transfer to a container, cover and refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours or overnight.Line baking tray with aluminium foil. Â  Grease lightly with some oil.Arrange the wings in the tray and bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 15 minutes.Turn over chicken wings, baste with balance marinating sauce and continue to bake for another 10 minutes.Turn over chicken wings again and brush with some honey. Â Baked/grill for another 5-10 minutes or until chicken wings are cooked and well glazed.Rest for 5 minutes before serving.Â I'm sharing this post with Muhibbah Malaysian Monday [November/Decemebr 2012] hosted by Suresh of 3 hungry tummies

title: Baked Cheddar Cheese Cheesecake
text: A soft, light and fluffy baked cheesecake using cheddar cheese slices.Â  Cake shrinks a little after cooling but tasted good with aÂ  nice cheesy flavour.Ingredients[recipe adapted from Min's blog with some modifications to the method]50 gm cake flour - sifted3 egg yolks50 gm butter3 slices of cheddar cheese [about 30 gm]50 ml milk Using double boil method, dissolve cheddar cheese with butter, then add in milk.Â  Set aside to cool.Sieve flour into a mixing bowl, add in egg yolks and cooled melted cheese and butter mixture.Whisk on medium high speed until creamy and ingredients are well combined.Â  Set aside while you prepare the egg white and preheat oven at 150 degrees C. 3 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar50 gm sugarÂ In another clean bowl, whisk egg whites until frothy, add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue beating and gradually add in sugar in 3 batches.Whisk on medium high speed until soft to stiff peaks formed.Pour half meringue into egg yolk mixture.Â  Mix well to incorporate ingredients.Then pour into balance meringue.Â  Mix well.Pour batter into a lined loose bottom 7" round cake tin. smooth the surface with a use of spatula.Steam baked [use 1 1/2 cups water] in baking tray.Baked in preheated oven at 150 degrees for 70 minutes.Â  Remove from pan immediately to cool on rack [cake base is firm and dry].

title: Nori Sausage Rolls [Sweet Bun Dough]
text: This sausage rolls recipe uses the basic Sweet Bun DoughÂ [recipe here]. Here is the similar bun recipe but I'm using the straight dough methodÂ  which also yields soft and fluffy buns.Ingredients for the buns [Straight Dough Method][makes Â 16 - 18 buns]100 gm plain flourÂ Â [you can replace plain flour and use all 500 gm bread flour]400 gm bread flour4 tsp instant yeast [I used 3 tsp]100 gm sugar [I used 80 gm]1 tsp salt260 - 280 Â ml water1 small egg [30 gm] - can used large egg and set aside some for egg glaze60 gm buttersome nori seaweed - break into small pieces or use nori powder 16 pieces sausage [blanched in hot water, drain and cool or steamed for 5-10 minutes]Mix all the dry ingredients and egg Â [except butter] in a mixer bowl, then slowly add in the water. Â Knead from low speed until well combined. Â Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes]. Â Add in butter, keep kneading Â until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage.Â Shape dough into a ball. Â Cover and leave to proof for 15-30 minutes or until double in size. Â  Punch down and divide dough into 16 portions of equal weight.Â  Shape dough into round balls or any shapes preferred.Place bun in baking tray [here I rolled the buns into 2 different ways]. Â See photos below.Leave to rise for 45-60 minutes or until double in size. Â Brush with egg/milk glaze. Pipe mayonnaise over the top.Baked in preheated oven at 190 degrees [middle shelf]Â  for 12-15 minutes or until golden.Â Brush buns with some melted butter [can skip this step if you do not want the buns to be oily]Â Remove and leave to cool on rack or serve.Photos below show two ways of rolling the Sausage RollsFirst Way Second Way

title: Steamed Fish Fillet with Rice Vermicelli
text: My hubby brought home a feshly caught thread fin 'senangin' fish.Â  Instead of steaming the whole fish, I decided to prepare this dish and kept the head for steaming.Â  I have prepared this steamed noodles when I have fresh meaty fish fillets after visiting Cheah's blogÂ  on Steamed Fish Fillet with Rice Vermicelli.Â Â  Several of my friends have also tried and like them very much.Â Â  Perhaps, I should post this dish here for my own record but do visit Cheah's blog [No Frills] for the original recipe. Â  BTW, she has a good collection of simple yet delicious recipes, too. It's a nutritious and healthy 1 Dish Meal for all.Ingredients[serves 2-3]120 gm rice vermicelli [thin type] - I used A1 brand - 2 1/2 piecesSoak for 5-10 minutes to soften.Â  Drain well and place on casserole dish.300 gm fish fillet - cleaned and sliced [here I used thread fin] seasoned with 2 tsp fish sauce,Â  2 tsp sesame oil, 1 tsp sugar, 1 tbsp chopped young ginger and a dash of pepper.Â  Set aside in the fridge for an hour or so.Sauce for Rice Vermicelli [Beehoon] - mix together1 cup water1 tsp each of salt and oyster sauce2 tsp fish sauceGarnishing2 tbsp shaoxing wine 1 red chilli - sliced thinly1 stalk spring onion - chopped1-2 tbsp fried garlic crisps with garlic oilArrange marinated fish fillet slices on the rice vermicelli.Â  Add in some shredded ginger.Pour sauce over the rice vermicelli just before steaming.Bring water to a rolling boil.Â  Steam noodles over rapidly boiling water for 8-10 minutes.Turn off heat, drizzle in wine, add in fried garlic crisps and oilGarnish with chopped spring onions and sliced red chilli.Serve hot with chopped garlic, chilli and light soy sauce dip.

title: Wholemeal Loaf [Tangzhong Method]
text: After baking the wholemeal yoghurt loafÂ [see here]Â using straight dough methodÂ which isn't too bad, I thought why not try another using tangzhong methodÂ [please see here]. Â With this method, it is believed that it yields fluffy bread that stays soft for many days. Â Seems not that difficult either with the help of the machine to knead the dough. Â As advised by Christine, it's very hard to knead the dough until it passes window pane test cos' wholemeal flour is added. Â So just knead until it's very elastic will do.Â Anyway, this loaf is soft and healthy bread for breakfast. Â Hopefully with regular consumption, the body's cholesterol and BP levels will never escalate and always in control.... hahaha!. Â Many people with high cholesterol avoided medication cos' it is costly.Â  Maybe with this kind of bread, it's of help to them.Ingredients200 gm bread flour150 gm wholemeal flour40 gm sugar5 gm salt6 gm instant yeast100 gm tangzhongÂ [refer here]Â *1 egg110 ml milk40 gmÂ butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  ThenÂ  continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 45 minutes or double in size [usually is less than 1 hour depending on temperature of the day].Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 3 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball and rest for 15 minutes. Â Roll and fold into thirds then roll each portion into a rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â  Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tin.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour/rise to 80% of the baking tin] or in a heated oven at 40 degrees C for 45 minutes.Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30 - 35 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack. Â * To prepare Tangzhong Paste/Water-Roux PasteÂ (æ¹¯ç¨®) [adapted from Minty's Kitchen]Â [yields about 150 gm tangzhong]25 gm bread flour125 ml waterMix flour and water in a normal saucepan.Cook over medium-low heat, stirring continuously until it reaches 65ÂºCÂ (should thickened to a paste at this stage) and when you stir you can see the bottom of the pan.Remove from heat and place a cling film over the paste (making sure that it touches the paste) and leave until lukewarm before using.

title: Wakame, Meatballs and Tofu Soup
text: A neighbour gave me a packet of wakame [seaweed with mixed vegetables] from Taiwan.Â  A tablespoon of it is more than enough to cook a pot of soup for the family of 3. Â The easiest way is to add it to boiling water, break in an egg and add seasoning to taste. Â Â See here for more information aboutÂ Wakame.Rehydrated WakameFor a change, I made some meatballs with fish paste, added tofuÂ  to the soup and that's it, a simple, tasty and hot soup for a cold raining night [has been raining almost all evenings in our area].Ingredients for Homemade Meatballs100 gm fish paste [I used Spanish Mackerel fish]100 gm minced meat2 tbsp of finely chopped carrotsalt, pepper and sesame oil to tasteMarinate with 1/2 tsp each of salt, pepper and sesame oil. Â Mix well and add 1 tsp cornstarch. Â Stir in one direction until paste is sticky thick, then slap it against the side of bowl for several times. Â Transfer to a clean container, cover and refrigerate until later use.Â Form in round balls before cooking.Other Ingredients for Soup700 ml water or soup stock1 tbsp dried wakame1 piece soft tofu - cut cubes1 spring onion - chopped1 tsp fried garlic crisps with a little oilsalt, msg and pepper to tasteÂ Â Bring water or stock to boil. Â Add in meatballs to boiling stock, then add in the wakame.Cook for a minute then add in tofu cubes. Â Let soup comes to boil again.Add seasoning to taste. Â Boil soup for another minute.Serve hot with some chopped spring onions and fried garlic crisps.Notes:Â [see here for more information on Wakame]What is Wakame?Â Wakame is a thin and stringy seaweed, deep green in color and used in making seaweed salad and miso soup. Wakame is common in Japanese and other Asian cuisines.While nori, the seaweed used for rolling sushi, is usually sold dried, wakame can be found either dried or fresh, in a refrigerated, and sealed package. When refrigerated, the wakame is preserved with sea salt and is partially dry so that itâ€™s moist to the touch, but not dehydrated and brittle like nori sheets.Along with the increased popularity of both theÂ raw food dietÂ (also called living foods) andÂ macrobiotic diets, wakame, has gained in popularity in the west. Proponents of both macrobiotic and raw foods diet extol the life-giving and healthful properties of wakame along with other seaweeds.I'm sharing this post withÂ The Spanish Wok- The TSK Butler Soup KitchenÂ Monthly Blogger Event November 2012.and also Muhibbah Malaysian Monday [November-December 2012] hosted by Suresh ofÂ 3 hungry tummies

title: Kerabu Mango
text: This mango salad [kerabu mango] is prepared for serving with authentic Kelantan Belacan Rice.Very easy salad to do but the mango must be firm and not be too ripe.Ingredients1 semi ripe green mango - skinned and cut into thin strips1 carrot - shredded5-6 shallots - slicedcalamansi lime juiceÂ salt and sugar to tastePut shredded mango, carrot and shallots in a big bowl.Mix sugar, salt and lime juice together.Toss lime mixture to shredded ingredients.Refrigerate until required.

title: STRAWBERRY YOGHURT COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: The past week was so hectic with hardly any time left to keep me in the kitchen.Â Â  Instead of baking bread, I optedÂ  to bake this cottony cake again.Â  This time using strawberry yoghurt.Â Like the previous bake [Mango Yoghurt Cottony Cake], this cake is low in sugar, fats and flour.Â  The texture is cottony soft and a little tangy taste cos' of the strawberry and lemon juice.Â  A little drop of rose pink colouring was added to make the cake more appealing even though it is already a nice cake.You need only two mixing bowls to mix the batter.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture65 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg45 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]80 ml strawberry yoghurtÂ 1 tsp lemon juicePlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil, lemon juice and yoghurt. Â Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â Set aside. Â Preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Â Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar until slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour into a 8" square tin [lined base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Smooth the surface with a spatula and steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 70 minutes.Â  For the water bath, use 1 1/2 cup water for the duration of baking.Â  This way the cake base will not be wet or too moist after baking.Invert the cake after baking Â and let it cool slightly before removing the pan and baking paper. Â Â Cool cake before slicing to serve or refrigerate for serving later.batter in baking tinbaked cake before inverting to cool on wire rackcool cake inverted before remove base paper liningÂ Notes:- can be served chilledÂ -Â must finish with 2-3 days if kept in room temperature- keeps well in an airtight container when refrigerated- I discovered that this cake is similar to Xiang Si cake and also known as Ogura cake. Â Quite the same as souffle cake too.

title: Tuna Stuffed Cornet Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Was supposed to make buns into a figure 8 shape then top with tuna fillings.Â  Drop the idea and change to make cornet bunsÂ [see here] cos' I didn't want to 'expose' the fillings [a little should be alright-lah]. Â Â  Â Ingredients for the buns-Sponge Dough Method[makesÂ  10 - 12 pieces]Step 1 - Ingredients2 tsp instant yeast160-170 mlÂ  water230 gm bread flourÂ Mix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour.Â  Knead to form a smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients60 gm sugar1/4 tsp salt1 small egg [20 gm]25 ml water100 gm bread flour 30 gm butterÂ Add all Step 2 ingredientsÂ  [except butter] to dough from Step 1.Â  Knead from low speed until well combined.Â  Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes].Â  Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage [Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate.Â Â  Thaw to room temperature before using.Â Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only].Â Shape dough into a ball.Â  Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down and divide dough in 10 - 12 pieces. Shape dough into round balls.Â  Flatten each ball, roll up and roll dough into a 12" rope.Â  Thin out at one end.Coil the dough around a lightly greased cornet shape mould.Â  Place on a lightly greased baking tray. Â  Do the same for the rest of the dough.Â  Leave to rise for 40-50 minutes or until 2 times in size.Â Before baking, brush with beaten egg.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 10-12 minutes or until golden.Leave to cool on rack, remove mould and fill cornet buns with prepared filling before serving.Ingredients for FillingÂ [Tuna with Mayonnaise]1 can tuna flakes in oil - drain away all the oil and small chilli1 big onion - chopped small pieces3 tbsp mayonaisedash of pepper and salt to taste Fry tuna flakes and onions together until onions are soft and mixture is slightly dry.Remove from pan to cool before adding mayonnaise. Â Combine well, filling is ready for use or refrigerate until required.Stuff filling into cornet buns before serving.

title: Wholemeal Yoghurt Loaf [Straight Dough Method]
text: My neighbour has high cholesterol eventhough on medication.Â  She was advised to refrain totally from white bread and switch to only wholemeal or wholegrain breads which are believed to be of help to lower cholesterol.Â  How true I don't know.Â Â  Â Â I came across Happy Home Baking's Fuss Free Wholemeal Loaf postingÂ [see here for original recipe] , so I'm giving it a go and see if it's going to help my friend lower her cholesterol. Â  Because it is a wholemeal loaf, 1 to 2 slices is already Â very filling for breakfast with a cup of hot beverage. Â No doubt the bread is soft and moist but is definitely not as light and fluffy as white breads.Ingredients[makes 1 loaf in Pullman's tin] 260 gm bread flour116 gm wholemeal flour30 gm caster sugar [2 tbsp]6 gm salt [1 tsp]100 ml natural plain yoghurt150 -170 ml water5 gm instant yeast [1 1/2 tsp]15 gm butterÂ Â Â Â Knead all dough ingredients [except butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  ThenÂ  continue kneading on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes until smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 30 minutes or double in size [usually is less than 1 hour depending on temperature of the day].Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 3 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â  Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tin.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour/rise to 80% of the baking tin] or in a heated oven at 40 degrees C for 45 minutes.Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack. Â Â Note- Â I covered the tin, baked at 190 degrees C for 35 minutes - bread base and sides were crusty but the top is soft and not crusty as the dough didn't rise to 4/5 height of the tin.Â Â  This is optional step.

title: Tuna Mayo Rolled Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Similar bun dough recipe and fillings.Â  Here, I just wanted to share idea on shaping of these buns.Ingredients for the buns-Sponge Dough Method[makesÂ  10 - 12 pieces]Step 1 - Ingredients2 tsp instant yeast160-170 mlÂ  water230 gm bread flourMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour.Â  Knead to form a smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients60 gm sugar1/4 tsp salt1 small egg [20 gm]25 ml water100 gm bread flour30 gm butterAdd all Step 2 ingredientsÂ  [except butter] to dough from Step 1.Â  Knead from low speed until well combined.Â  Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes].Â  Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stageÂ [Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate.Â Â  Thaw to room temperature before using.Â Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only].Shape dough into a ball.Â  Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down and divide dough into 10 or 12 pieces.Shape dough into round balls.Â  Flatten each ball, roll into oval shape.Â  Place some filling in the centre.Â  Seal the edges and roll into an oval shape.Fold into half along the long side, then roll up like Swiss roll.Invert dough and place on paper casing.Do the same for the rest of the dough.Â  Leave to rise for 40-50 minutes or until 2 times in size.Before baking, brush with beaten egg and sprinkle some sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C forÂ  6 minutes, then turn to bottom heat and continue baking for 9 minutes.Leave to cool on rack.Â Â Â Â Ingredients for FillingÂ [Tuna with Mayonnaise]1 can tuna flakes in oil - drain away all the oil and small chilli1 big onion - chopped small pieces3 tbsp mayonaisedash of pepper and salt to tasteFry tuna flakes and onions together until onions are soft and mixture is slightly dry.Remove from pan to cool before adding mayonnaise. Â Combine well, filling is ready for use or refrigerate until required.

title: Steamed Fish with Herbal Stock
text: One freshly caught fish [Mahogany Snapper] from my hubby's fishing trip to be steamed. Â Light and good with mild herbal flavour.This fish is different from the grouper.Â  The flesh is not as sweet but texture is softer.Â  I used herbal stock with some shredded meat to steam it to enhance the flavour.Ingredients1 fresh fish - cleaned and make a slit on the thick part for both sides30-50 gm meat - cut thin strips and marinate with soy sauce, pepper, sesame oil and cornfloursome shredded gingera tbsp of wolfberries [kei chi]Herbal StockÂ - rinse herbs and boil for 5-10 minutes orÂ until fragrant3-4 slices of dong quaia few pieces of chuen qionga few pieces of tong suma few pieces of licorice [kam cho]100 ml water [maybe less for stronger flavour]Seasoning1 tsp each of light soy sauce and oyster saucesome sugar and pepper to taste1/2 tsp sesame oilBoil herbal stock until fragrant and set aside to cool.Clean fish and place in a steaming dish.Before steaming, add kei chi to herbal stock then pour over fish. Â Spread marinated meat all over fish.Bring water to boil then steam fish over high heat for 12-15 minutes [depending on the size of fish].Garnish with coriander and serve immediately.

title: Pizza with Tuna Mayo Topping
text: An easy pizza recipe with tuna mayo topping.Â  This pizza base uses more plain flour than bread flour.Ingredients - Pizza Base[dough weighs 400 gm - makes 6 pieces]180 gm plain flour50 gm bread flour1/2 tsp salt3/4 tsp yeast140-160 ml cold water30 gm shorteningKnead all ingredients together until soft and smooth.Â  Cover and rest for 25 minutes.Shape dough in round, flatten slightly and cut in 6 pieces.Â  Roll each piece into a circle of about 5mm thick.Place dough on baking tray use a fork to poke holes all over.Rest until dough is double in size.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 15-20 minutes.Toppings - Tuna Mayo - mixed together1 can tuna in mayonnaise1 big onion - choppedsome chilli sauce and tomato sauce [or use pizza sauce]some Italian mixed herbs 1 piece cheddar cheese - cut into 6 Spread pizza base with some chilli sauce and tomato sauce [or pizza sauce], follow by tuna mayo filling.Sprinkle some mixed herbs, top with a small piece of cheddar cheese.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 10-15 minutes.

title: Coffee Choc Chip Loaf Bread [Straight Dough Method]
text: A soft and moist loaf bread with aroma of coffee and sweetness from raisins and chocolate chips.Easy bread loaf that you can baked using the straight dough method.Â  The dough can be kneaded earlier, refrigerated and thawed before shaping for baking.Â  If you are up early, the freshly baked bread can be ready for breakfast.Â Ingredients[baked in loaf pan of size 4"x3"x9"]250 gm bread flour50 gm plain flour1 tbsp skimmed milk powder1 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp salt 1 tsp instant coffee granules1 1/2 tsp instant yeast 2 tbsp condensed milk1 small egg165 ml cold water30 gm butter [1 tbsp]some chocolate chipssome raisins some oatmealÂ Knead all dough ingredients [except butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  ThenÂ  continue kneadingon medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes to get to window pane stage or soft, smooth and elastic dough which is not sticky.Â Â  Add in raisins to incorporate well into dough.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 30 minutes or double in size.Punch down rested dough.Â  Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll into a rectangle. Â  SpreadÂ  with chocolate chips.Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well.Â Â  Place the dough in greased loaf pan.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour/rise to 80% of the baking tin]. Â Â  Brush with milk glaze and sprinkle on top some oatmeal.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25-30 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack. Â Â I'm sharing this with Bake Your Own Bread October 2012 hosted by girlichef

title: EZ Braised Herbal Roast Trotter
text: A pork dish which is always a favourite of my nephews. Â Instead of the normal pig trotter used for braising, this dish uses roasted pig trotter which is easy to prepare and quick to cook. Â The crispy skin of the roasted pork when braised becomes spongy and not that fatty.Ingredients2 roasted pig trotter - chopped into chunky pieces5-6 dried red chillies - washed5-6 slices of dong quai1 piece 3 cm length cinnamon stick2 star anisesome light soy saucesome dark soy sauce for colour [optional]some palm sugar to tasteenough water to cover meat piecesChopped roasted pig trotter into chunky piecesPlace meat pieces in a heavy based pot. Â Add in dried red chillies, dongquai, cinnamon stick and star anise.Pour in water enough to cover the meat pieces. Â Bring it to a rolling boil.Add in light soy sauce, palm sugar and dark soy sauce to taste.Bring it to a boil again, turn to low heat, cover and simmer for about 30 minutes or until meat pieces are tender but chewy.Serve hot with plain white rice.Note- do not add too much light soy sauce because roasted pork is already quite salty.I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Sharon of Â Test with Skewer

title: Rolls To Buns
text: This recipe is actually for making rolled buns with various fillings but I made them into round buns because of my mum's request. Â She prefers fillings to be wrapped inside the buns rather than 'exposed'.Â Dough is not sticky, texture like pau dough. Â Dough weighs about 600 gm. Â Buns are soft, moist and fluffy immediately after baking. Â  Buns are not that soft the next day but when warmed up in the oven toaster for 5 minutes, it's soft and nice again. Â Ingredients for Dough[makes 12 buns]250 gm bread flour50 gm plain flour40-50 gm sugar [I used 3 tbsp]1/2 tsp salt1 tbsp skimmed milk powder1 3/4 tsp yeast [can used 5 gm]1 egg100-120 ml water30 gm butterAny filling of your choice [meat floss, red bean paste etc]egg or milk glazesome toasted sesame seeds - optionalsome soft butter - for brushingKnead all ingredients together [except butter] until a soft dough is formed. Â Takes about 5-10 minutes with an electric mixer.Add butter and continue to knead until dough is soft, smooth and elastic [window pane stage]. Takes about 10 minutes.Shape into a round ball and cover to rest for 30 minutes or until double in size.Punch down and divide dough into 12 portions [50 gm each]. Â Rest for 5 minutes. Â Wrap filliing with dough, seal the edges well. Â Place on a baking tray lined with parchment paper, seam side down.Cover and leave to proof for 50-60 minutes or until double in size.Before baking, brush buns with egg or milk glaze, sprinkle some sesame seed.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 12-15 minutes [middle shelf] or until golden brown. Â Remove and brush with some melted butter and serve immediately or cool on wire rack before packing.Notes- Brushing baked buns immediately after baking helps to keep the buns soft and shiny.- This bun dough is suitable for any sweet or savoury fillings [please refer my label on fillings for options].- Refer to Christine's blogÂ [here] on tips for makingÂ  fresh buns for breakfast.I'm sharing this post with Bake Your Own Bread hosted byÂ girlichef.

title: MANGO YOGHURT COTTONY CAKE [OGURA CAKE]
text: This should be a healthy cake compared to butter cakes cos' it's low in sugar, fats and flour.Â  The texture is cottony soft and a little tangy taste cos' of the mango and lemon juice.Â  A light and nice cake which I believe is not a burden to the body with a few extra slices.Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture65 gm superfine flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt5 egg yolks1 whole egg45 ml corn oil [3 tbsp]80 ml mango yoghurtÂ 1 tsp lemon juicePlace the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl and make well in the centre. Â Add in eggs, corn oil, lemon juice and yoghurt. Â Using a paddle hook, beat ingredients until creamy and well combined. Â Set aside. Â Preheat oven at 160 degrees C for 10 minutes.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture5 egg whites1/2 tsp cream of tartar65 gm castor sugarUsing an electric mixer, whisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar until slightly foamy. Â Add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Using a spatula, fold in 1/2 of the meringue into egg yolk mixture. Â Lift and fold until well combined, then add to rest of meringue. Â Fold again until well mix.Pour into a 8" square tin [lined base with baking paper at the bottom only]. Â Smooth the surface with a spatula and steam bake in oven at 160 degrees C for 70 minutes.Invert the cake after baking Â and let it cool before removing the baking paper. Â Â Cool cake before slicing to serve.Notes:- cake is quite close to 'Xiang Si' and Souffle cake [honestly not sure what's the difference between these cakes, so I better call it cottony cake, not to confuse myself]- can be served chilledÂ - keeps well in an airtight container refrigerated.

title: Pan Fried Steamed Buns [Sui Chern Pau]
