text: Tried some of these paus during my Taiwan trip.Â  They were delicious with soft and moist pau skin.Â  The meat filling was juicy, soft and fragrant.Came across this recipe from Fong's Kitchen quite awhile ago and just got the time to try it now.Â  My family could enjoy these lovely 'Sui Chern Paus' for morning breakfast as I prepared all the dough and meat fillings a day ahead.Â  Very satisfied.Â  Fong prepared this for lunch and serve them with a hot and sour soup.Â  Yummy!!!Ingredients for Meat FillingsÂ [thanks to Fong ofÂ  Fong's Kitchen Journal for sharing this lovely recipe]200 gm minced pork (with some fats)3 - 4 leaves of Chinese cabbage - blanched in boiling water for 2-3 minutes to soften.Â  Drain off excess water, squeeze dry and chopped into small piecesaÂ  handful of Chinese chives - chopped mix with 1/2 tsp each of salt and sugar, sit for 30 minutes.Â  Squeeze out excess water,2 stalks spring onion - choppeda small piece of ginger - gratedÂ 1/2 cup stock add seasoning [oyster sauce, pepper, sugar, sesame oil to taste]Place meat in a bowl, add ginger and spring onion.Â  Stir in 1 direction for several minutes.Â  Gradually add in the stock and stir to incorporate into the meat.Â  Add in the cabbage and chives.Â  Stir well to combine until a sticky paste develops.Chill in the fridge for at least an hour before use [I prepared this a day before]. Ingredients for Pau Dough[makes 12 pieces]250 gm plain flour [I used superfine flour]1 tsp instant yeast2 tbsp caster sugarA pinch of salt125 ml - 140 ml water2 tbsp cooking oil [I used 1 tbsp of shortening]Flour Solution - mix 1 tsp plain flour with 1 cup waterÂ Â Â Various stages of making pan fried steamed pausPlace the dry ingredients in a mixing bowl [except water and oil].Â  Gradually add in the water and knead into a dough.Â  Add in the oil/shortening and continue to knead until the dough is smooth and pliable.Â  Shape into a ball and cover to rest for 45 minutes or until double in size.Â  [I place the dough in plastic bag and tied up tightlyÂ  and kept it in the fridge a day ahead.Â  Thaw to room temperature then continue with Step 2].Punch down the rested dough and divide into 12 portions.Â  Round each portion and rest for 5 minutes.Â  Roll each portion into a round disc.Â  Complete rolling out all the 12 portions.Fill each portion with a tablespoon of meat mixture and pleat into a pau shape, seal the edges well into a pleated bun.Oil lightly a non-stick pan and arrange the buns from the outer circle towards the centre [see above photos].Â  Turn on the heat to medium to pan fry [brown] the buns lightly.Â  When the bottom skin is slightly browned, pour in the flour solution until it reaches about half the height of the buns.Â Â Cover and let it steam cook over medium low heat for about 15-20 minutes or until the flour solution starts to dry up. Â  Drizzle a little sesame oil around the edge of the pan and sprinkle over some toasted sesame seeds and chopped spring onions. Â Cover for another minute and serve hot immediately.Cooked Paus before invertingInverted pan fried steamed buns

title: Thai Style Garlic Steamed Salmon
text: My second thai style steamed fish . Â The original recipe was fromÂ Echo's Kitchen. Â My first Thai Style Garlic Steamed Fish was fromÂ Table for 2 ....or more. Â  The difference between the two is the latter has lemongrass added. Â Tastewise, almost similar, awesome, very tempting and appetising. Â You wouldn't mind preparing the same again and again cos' it is really simple.Ingredients[adapted from Echo's KitchenÂ some modifications for easier reference]300-400 gm fresh grouper [garoupa] - scaled and cleanedsome coriander leavesSteaming Sauce IngredientsÂ [combine together]4 big cloves of garlic - chopped3 chilli padi - slice thinly2 tbsp calamansi lime juiceÂ 1 tbsp brown sugar1/2 tbsp vegetable oil1 tsp sesame oil1 tsp fish sauce [I used anchovies fish sauce]1/2 tsp saltPlace a tablespoon of the mixed steaming ingredients on steaming plate, then place cleaned fish on top.Prepare steamer and bring water to boil. Â Place steaming tray with fish to steam over high heat for 8-10 minutes or until cooked through.Remove from steamer. Â Garnish with coriander leaves and serve immediately.I'm linking this post to Carole's Chatter Â for Food on Friday' theme on Salmon.Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â onI'm submitting this post toÂ Asian Food Fest - November 2013Â Â hosted by Lena ofÂ Frozen Wings

title: EZ Soft Steamed Pau
text: This recipe was adapted from Angel's Â Easy and Soft Steamed PauÂ [original recipe from Cook.Bake.Love]Â for the pau dough. Â I used a different filling. Â The paus are really soft and QQ like traditional steamed paus. Â  I believe the dough can be used for any fillings.Â Â  I'll definitely make it again cos' my hubby says the pau skin is much better than store bought [he just had a steamed meat pau from a popular outlet which wasn't up to his expectation].What I couldn't understand is my paus weren't whitish like those store bought ones. Â Is it because I used the unbleached all purpose flour or because of the baking powder? Â Perhaps, I should try using cake flour or even Hong Kong Flour to see the difference. Â The dough is soft and not sticky. Â Easy to handle and dough weighs about 350 gm.Ingredients[makes 8 paus]180 gm cake flour [I used all purpose flour]20 gm constarch [2 tbsp]30 gm sugar [I used 2 tbsp]5 gm double action baking powder [I used 1 tsp]4 gm yeast [I used 1 1/4 tsp]100 ml warm water18 ml corn oil [I used 1/2 tbsp shortening]Â Mix all ingredients together [except shortening/oil]. Â Knead until soft dough, then add in shortening.Continue to knead until smooth and pliable dough. Â Shape into a ball and cover to prove for 50 minutes or until double in size. Â [I kept dough in a plastic bag, tied up and refrigerate until required (next day), thaw to room temperature before shaping].Punch down dough. Â Divide into 8 portions [about 44 gm each]. Â Shape into round balls and rest for 5 minutes.Roll each ball to flatten into a circle and wrap filling [any filling about 30 gm]. Â Pleat into pau shape, place on greasedproof paper. Â Rest for 15 minutes or until double in size.Steam over high heat for 15 minutes. Â Off fire and leave for 3 minutes before uncovering steamer [this is to prevent the pau skin from wrinkles].Notes:- this steamed pau dough is suitable for both sweet and savoury fillings. Â Please refer to fillings label for selection.

title: Carrot and Zuchini Pickle
text: This is a simple yet nice pickle as appetiser that is worth making.Â  Sometimes you can see this pickle been served as appetiser at Chinese Restaurants.Â  In the home, it may be good to serve with fried meat. Â  The carrots and zuchini pieces are very crunchy and tasted sweet and sourish.Ingredients2 Japanese cucumbers [zuchini]1 carrot1 red chilli - halved and seeded5 tbsp apple cider vinegar or white rice vinegar3 tbsp castor sugara pinch of saltCut carrot and zuchini into 4 cm stripsCut chilli into thin stripsRinse in boiled cold water and drain vegetables.Place in a glass bowl.Â  Pour in the vinegar and stir in the sugar and salt.Â  Mix well.Transfer to a glass container.Â  Cover and chill for a day before serving.Serve the appetiser the next day.

title: Vegetarian Sweet Sour Chilli Sauce
text: This chilli sauce was taught to me by an elderly neighbour.Â  She says the sauce goes well with plain white rice, fried rice, noodles and even fresh vegetable salads. Â Yummy for vegetarian diet this year which falls on 15th October until 23rd of the month. Â This period is the annual 9-day Taoist festival that requires devotees to observe a strict vegetarian diet to cleanse and purify their bodies.This period also coincides with the Hindu vegetarian festival called 'Navarathi' [see here for more info]. Â  They observe a strict vegetarian diet, pray and fast. Â Navarathi is a celebration to worship the supreme goddess Sakhti in her various forms. Â Hindus also offer daily prayers, fruits, flowers and coconuts to the goddess.Here are the ingredients andÂ  preparation.Â  This sauce keeps long when refrigerated.Ingredients300 gm red chillies - desseded - cut small pieces25 gm bird's eye chilli Â - cut150 gm young ginger - cut small pieces2 piece wild ginger flower - cut small pieces100 gm vegetarian fine glutten pieces5 tbsp fine tau cheong [I used miso paste]Â 2 tbsp chilli paste100 limau kasturi juice150 - 170 gm sugar1 1/2 tsp salt to taste450 ml water1 cup oilBlend together the chillies, ginger and wild ginger flower until fine.Heat oil in wok to fry tau cheong [or miso] until aromatic. Â Add in blended ingredients and chilli paste.Fry until oil separates. Â Add in seasoning to taste [if using tau cheong, less salt is Â needed] and fine glutten pieces.Stir fry for several seconds then add in water. Â Bring to a boil then simmer until oil surfaces.Add in lime juice. Â Taste to adjust seasoning. Â Bring to a boil and dish out to cool before storing or serve.

title: Vegetarian Braised Mui Choy
text: Mui Choy [sweet and salty types] are usually cooked with fatty meat and braised till soft. Â This vegetarian mui choy of course have no meat added but peanuts. Â  It tastes good too for a vegan. Â The photo doesn't look good [cos' I didn't intend to post this recipe] but the dish tasted good especially when reheated.Ingredients300 gmÂ sweet mui choy - wash, soak and drain300 gm salty mui choy - wash, soak and drain4 dried mushrooms - soak and drain - cut strips100 gm peanuts - wash and boil till almost softa few slices ginger2 tbsp each of oyster sauce and sugarÂ to taste2 tbsp each of Â sesame oil andÂ oil1 litre waterPrepare both types mui choy as above and cut into shreds.Heat wok without oil to fry mui choy until soft and dry. Â Dish out.Heat oil in wok and fry ginger till fragrant. Â Add in mushrooms. Â  Fry for a second then add in vegetables Â and peanuts.Stir fry until well combined. Â Add in seasoning. Â Fry for a few minutes then pour in water.Bring to a boil then lower heat to simmer until vegetables are soft and gravy reduced.Dish Â out to serve with porridge.Note: There are 2 types of mui choy. The dish taste better with both types. Add more water if it is too dry.

title: Vegetarian Sambal
text: The Nine Emperor Gods Festival started on 15th October this year for 9 days. Â It's time to go strictly on a vegetarian diet. Â Those vegetarian dishes, noodles, delicacies sold at the vegetarian food outlets and makeshift stalls are so tempting and delicious. Â Sometimes I wonder how they make vegetarian pizzas and burgers and where comes the 'cheese' and 'mayonnaise'. Â Anyway, I wouldn't want to try.My family and I hardly go for processed vegetarian food but this vegetarian sambal uses only one ingredient which I'm sure is processed ingredient [vegetarian belacan]. It comes in paste or granules forms. Â I was told that these are made from mushrooms.The sambal goes well with fried noodles/rice and even noodle soups. Â Gave some to some friends who are on vegetarian diet, they told me it's good, tasted quite like Thai sambal. Â  I have used this sambal for my vegetarian Cantonese Fried Flat Rice Noodles 'Sar Hor Fun'. Â  It was good. Â Will definitely make more next round and should be good for Nasi Lemak [Coconut Milk Rice].Ingredients300 gm red chillies - seeded25 gm small chillies [chilli padi] - optional for more spicy sambal100 gm tomato [about 1 medium size] - chopped3 tbsp vegetarian concentrated mushroom granules [looks like fried belacan]60 gm castor sugar1 tsp salt100 ml calamansi lime juiceWash chillies and remove the seeds. Â Blend chillies and tomato together [not too fine].Heat a little oil and fry mushroom paste until aromatic. Â Add in the blended ingredients.Fry for several minutes then add in the seasoning. Â Continue frying on medium heat until mixture is fairly dry.Add in the lime juice. Â Bring to a boil. Â Off heat and dish out to cool before storing in glass container.

title: Gyoza [Pan Fried Japanese Dumplings]
text: Gyoza for a Sunday light snack with the family. Very simple ingredients yet yummy gyoza [meat dumplings] served with shredded fresh ginger/black vinegar sauce or teriyaki sauce [stir mix 1/4 cup teriyaki sauce with 1 tsp sesame oil].Ingredients[makes 40 pieces]350 gm minced meat1/2 cupped finely chopped blanched white cabbage1 tbsp grated ginger1 tsp chopped garlic1 tbsp light soya sauce1 tsp sesame oil1 tsp cornflour40 pieces round gyoza skin wrapper or wanton skin - store bought about 1-2 packets[I used white gyoza skin wrapper] Using a big bowl, combine all the ingredients. Â Stir in 1 direction while you mix them. Â Stir until a sticky paste develops. Â Refrigerate for 15-30 Â minutes.Arrange gyoza wrappers on a plate and a scoop a heaped teaspoon of the minced meat mixture onto one half of the wrapper.Â  Lightly brush the edge of the other half of the wrapper with water.Â  Make a few pleats on the dry side and fold to enclose the filling.Â  Press the edges together to seal well.Â Â Heat a non stick pan with a little oil over medium heat for a minute. Remove pan from heat and arrange the dumplings in the pan.Cook for 1-2 minutes or until the base is lightly browned.Â  Add 1/4-1/2 cup water, then cover the pan with a lid.Â  Cook for 3-4 minutes and add more water if necessary [to get a softer skin].Dish out the dumplings and allow to stand for 1-2 minutes or until the dumplings come away from the pan easily.Â  Repeat the cooking process for the balance uncooked dumplings.Â  Serve with dipping sauce. Tip:- to remove the cooked gyoza from pan, invert a flat plate to cover the dumplings then place your hand on the centre of plate, flip pan over and you will see the browned side of the dumplings.I'm submitting this to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday November 2012 hosted by

title: Curry Powder Chicken Curry
text: Was at a friend's place sometime back and was attracted to a very nice aroma of curry so similar to the 'Nasi Kandar' curry and asked her whether it is the neighbour cooking the curry.Â  She told me it is her husband.Â  Since I love trying hot spicy curries, I asked her for the recipe.Â  Her husband happily told me, "It's just a simply chicken curry using only curry powder and this is the brand.Â  I found it at Tesco Store".Â  He told me to add cardamons for added 'kick' to the curry.Here's the recipe and the brand that he shared with me.Ingredients[serves 2-3] Curry Paste1 big onion [or 50 gm shallots]1 tomato30 gm ginger3-4 cloves garlic3 tbsp AI brand meat curry powder [you can try other brands]Blend the first 4 ingredients together, then mix with curry powder.Â  Set aside.300 gm chicken thighs [de-skined and cut to bite size pieces] - marinate with a little tumeric powder and 1/4 tsp salt1 big russet potato - skinned and cut into wedges [can omit and replace with another chicken thigh]3cm piece cinnamon stick2 cardamons50 ml plain yoghurt [or 30ml coconut milk]200 ml water4 tbsp oil salt and sugar to tasteHeat oil in wok, saute cinnamon stick, cardamons and curry paste until aromatic.Add in the marinated chicken.Â  Stir fry for awhile to mix well with the paste.Add in potatoes.Â  Continue to stir fry until chicken is quite firm.Â  Add in water.Â  Bring to a boil then lower heat to simmer for 20-25 minutes.Add in salt and sugar to taste.Â  When potatoes and chicken are soft and tender, add in yoghurt or coconut milk.Bring it to a boil again and dish out to serve with plain white rice or steamed bread slices.Note-Â  this curry is even more flavourful after several hours or kept overnight. -Â  add 1-2 chilli padi when blending paste for hotter curryI'm sharing this post with The Spanish Wok, TSK Butler Soup Kitchen Monthly blogger event October 2012 in conjunction with World Food Day. and I'm also submitting this post to Carole's Chatter for the Friday's theme on 'Curries'Â on

title: Black Glutinous Rice Loaf Bread [Straight Dough Method]
text: Was thinking since glutinous rice flour can be used to make bread, why not black glutinous rice flour.  So here it is, my attempt to bake 2 loaves of bread using black glutinous rice flour.  The result was very satisfactory - the loaves are soft and moist with a nice crust and the purplish colour of the rice flour gives a unique colour to the bread.Ingredients[makes 2 loaves x 470 gm]500 gm bread flour100 gm black glutinous rice flour [can obtained from grinding black glutinous rice]*1 tsp salt 3 tbsp sugar [about 50 gm]1 egg250 ml milk + 50 ml water [can use all milk]3 tsp yeast2 tbsp butterÂ Â Â Â Â Â Knead all dough ingredients [except butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  ThenÂ  continue kneadingon medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes to get to window pane stage or smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 30 minutes or double in size [usually is less than 1 hour depending on temperature of the day].Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 2 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well [you can shape the loaves according to own preference]. Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tins.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour/rise to 80% of the baking tin] or in a heated oven at 40 degrees C for 45 minutes. Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack. Â *Â  Notes - To prepare black glutinous rice flour-Â  Grind 100 gm black glutinous rice in grinder until fine.Â  Sieve, then grind a few times until you get really fine rice flour. Â An ArticleÂ  AboutÂ  Black Glutinous Rice BelowBlack rice - revered in ancient China but overlooked in the West - could be the greatest 'superfoods', scientists revealed today. The cereal is low in sugar but packed with healthy fibre and plant compounds that combat heart disease and cancer, say experts.Scientists from Louisiana State University analysed samples of bran from black rice grown in the southern U.S. They found boosted levels of water-soluble anthocyanin antioxidants.Anthocyanins provide the dark colours of many fruits and vegetables, such as blueberries and red peppers. They are what makes black rice 'black'. Research suggests that the dark plant antioxidants, which mop up harmful molecules, can help protect arteries and prevent the DNA damage that leads to cancer.Â Food scientist Dr Zhimin Xu said: 'Just a spoonful of black rice bran contains more health promoting anthocyanin antioxidants than are found in a spoonful of blueberries, but with less sugar, and more fibre and vitamin E antioxidants.Â  'If berries are used to boost health, why not black rice and black rice bran? Especially, black rice bran would be a unique and economical material to increase consumption of health-promoting antioxidants.'Â Centuries ago black rice was known as 'Forbidden Rice' in ancient China because only nobles were allowed to eat it.Â  Today black rice is mainly used in Asia for food decoration, noodles, sushi and desserts. But food manufacturers could potentially use black rice bran or bran extracts to make breakfast cereals, beverages, cakes, biscuits and other foods healthier, said Dr Xu.Â When rice is processed, millers remove the outer layers of the grains to produce brown rice or more refined white rice - the kind most widely consumed in the West.Â Â  Brown rice is said to be more nutritious because it has higher levels of healthy vitamin E compounds and antioxidants.Â But according to Dr Xu's team, varieties of rice that are black or purple in colour are healthier still.Â Â  They added that black rice could also be used to provide healthier, natural colourants.Â Studies linked some artificial colourants to cancer and behavioural problems in children.Â The scientists presented their findings today at the 240th National Meeting of the American Chemical Society in Boston .Â  Victoria Taylor, senior dietician at the British Heart Foundation, said: 'In reality, it's unlikely there's a single food out there that will have a great impact on lowering your risk of heart disease. Healthy eating is about a balanced diet overall.Â 'It's great if you can eat more of some groups of healthy foods, like having five portions of fruit and vegetable a day, but there is still no conclusive evidence that 'super foods' alone make a real difference to your heart health.'I'm submitting this post toÂ  World Bread Day 2012

title: Baked Stuffed Crabs
text: My hubby brought home some flower crabs from his fishing trip.Â  I steamed them for 20 minutes and shelled the crabmeat which was quite a lot.Â  Gave some to my mum for making Popiah vegetable filling and kept some for this baked stuffed crabs.Ingredients[makes 4 pieces]4 flower crabs - steamed and shell the crabmeat.Â  Set aside.4 tbsp of potato flakes [can use mashed potato]1/2 cup milk1 big onion - diced1 tomato - diced2 pieces of cheddar cheese - quarteredsome chopped coriander leaves2 tbsp oilÂ 4 crab shells Â Seasoning [combine]1 tbsp curry powder1/2 tsp sugar1/2 tsp pepper1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and oyster sauceMix potato flakes with milk.Â Â  Set aside.Heat oil in wok, stir fry onions for 1 minute and add in tomato.Â  Fry for another minute and add in seasoning.Â  Continue to fry for 1-2 minutes until filling is well combined.Â  Off heat.Add in crabmeat, potato mix and chopped coriander.Â Â  Mix well to combine.Divide filling into 4 portions.Â  Line a quartered piece of cheddar cheese on the inside of the crab shell. Stuff each filling into crab shells.Â  Level up evenly and neatly.Â  Place another quartered cheese on top.Â  Finish stuffing the remaining crab shells.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 15-20 minutes or until the top of the filling turns golden brown.

title: Mango Tomato Jam Chiffon Cake
text: Again another flavour chiffon cake which I baked using my homemade mango and tomato jam .Â  Cake turns out well, soft, moist and spongy.Â  Rose beautifully.Â  This time I add an extra egg white and the result is satisfactory.Â  Taste wise ....has the taste of the jam.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]1-2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp oil2 - 3 tbsp water2 tbsp Mango and Tomato jamÂ Â Â 75 gm cake flour - siftedWhisk egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in water.Â  Lastly stir in jam.Â  Fold in flour until well combinedÂ [this time I mixed all these ingredients in a cake mixer using a paddle hook instead of hand whisk]. Â Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 170 degrees C.Â Ingredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg whites [can add an extra egg white]1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 tbsp sugar [40 gm]Whisk egg white until frothy, continue whisking and add in cream of tartar, when foamy, gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue till well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â TapÂ a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 35-40 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Traditional Style Pork Soup [Bak Ngee Th'ng]
text: An all time favourite soup - pork pottage [rou geng] for the dinner table which is not difficult to prepare with only 2 main ingredients [pork and vegetables]. Â It can be prepared ahead of dinner time. Â Apart from pork, fish fillets can also be used.Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 gm pork meat [muscle meat] - cut thin slices,Â  marinate with:1 tsp light soy sauce1/4 tsp each of salt, msg and pepper1 tsp sesame oil4 tbsp sweet potato flour [can use tapioca flour and wheat starch 50:50]100 gm cabbage - washed and cut shreds750 ml watersome chopped spring onionsSeasoning For Soup1 tsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp each of salt 1/4 tsp pepper and msg1 tsp sesame oilÂ Â Â Â Season meat slices with marinade for at least 20 minutes.Â  Toss marinated pork slices in flour.Â  Tip off excess flour and place on a plate.Â  Leave for 5-10 minutes.Bring water to boil in a soup pot.Â  Drop in pork slices and let it cook for about 5 minutes [need not stir].Â  The pork slices will float to the top when cooked.Â  Use a serrated ladle to dish out pork slices and spread on a plate.Â  Leave to cool in a fridge [this will make the pork slices very chewy].Add seasoning and adjust to taste.Â  Put in the cabbage to cook until soft.Return the pork slices to soup.Â  Stir and serve garnish with spring onions. Â I'm sharing this post with Muhibbah Malaysian Monday October 2012 hosted by Sharon at Test with SkewerandÂ  The Spanish Wok, TSK Butler Soup Kitchen Blogger Event October 2012.

title: Coffee Walnut Chiffon Cake
text: This is a good recipe for Coffee Walnut Chiffon Cake from Happy Flour which I am baking for the second time. Â The ingredients especially the measurements are not exactly the same because I am using the measuring spoon. Â But the cake is just lovely and good. Â I used only 30 gm of chopped walnuts to sprinkle on top of the cake [you can add it to the batter without sprinkling any on top].Â  Ingredients[recipe adapted from Happy Flour with some changes] 50 ml hot milk 2 tbsp instant coffee - Â Dissolve coffee granules in hot milk.Â  Leave to cool70 gm plain flour - sifted with 1/8 tsp baking powder1 1/2 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp saltÂ Â  Â  Â  Â  3 egg yolksÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 3 tbsp corn oilPlace all the dry ingredients [sifted flour, salt and sugar] in the mixing bowl.Â  Make a well in the centre.Â  Pour in all the liquid ingredients [egg yolks, coffee milk and oil].Â  Beat together using a paddle hook on medium to high speed until well combined and mixture is smooth [takes about 5 minutes].Â Â  Set aside.3 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 tbsp castor sugar30 gm roasted walnuts - finely choppedPreheat oven at 175 degrees Celsius.Put egg white in cake mixer bowl [make sure bowl is clean and ungreased].Â  Whisk egg whites until a little frothy, add in cream of tartar, continue whisking until foamy and add in sugar in 3 batches.Â  Keep whisking egg white mixture till soft to stiff peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 of meringue to egg yolk mixture.Â  Mix evenly until well combined. Then pour into balance egg meringue.Â  Fold until evenly combined and add in roasted walnuts [according to preference, here I didn't add to batter].Â  Pour batter into 7 inch ungreased chiffon tube pan.Â  Smooth the top with a spatula.Â Â  Sprinkle cake top with toasted walnuts.Baked in preheat oven [lower rack] for 40 - 45 minutes.Â Invert baked cake immediately to cool completely before removing from pan.Notes- It is advisable to add the walnuts to the batter instead of spreading them on top of cake.Â  Some of the walnuts will drop off when you invert the cake to cool.

title: Thai Style Garlic Steamed Grouper
text: This steamed fish dish was inspired by Wendy [Table for 2 .. or more]Â which was really good.Â  My hubby's very first reaction to this dish was, 'Wow!, this is good!', 'Much better than other ways of steaming fish'.Â  Moreover, the fish is very fresh from his fishing trip. Â I used calamansi limes [limau kasturi] juice that blends very well with the other ingredients. Very appetising... Will definitely prepare this again... Didn't bother to take more pictures cos' we wanted to savour the steamed fish steaming hot, hahaha!.Â Ingredients[adapted from Wendykk with some modifications for easier reference]300-400 gm fresh grouper [garoupa] - scaled and cleanedsome coriander leavesSteaming Sauce IngredientsÂ [combine together]4 big cloves of garlic - chopped3 chilli padi - slice thinly1 lemongrass - slice thinly [used the top portion]Â 2 tbsp calamansi lime juiceÂ 1 tbsp brown sugar1/2 tbsp vegetable oil1 tsp sesame oil1 tsp fish sauce [I used anchovies fish sauce]1/2 tsp saltPlace a tablespoon of the mixed steaming ingredients on steaming plate, then place cleaned fish on top.Prepare steamer and bring water to boil. Â Place steaming tray with fish to steam over high heat for 8-10 minutes or until cooked through.Remove from steamer. Â Garnish with coriander leaves and serve immediately.

title: Soft Rolls with Spicy Serunding [Straight Dough Method]
text: With some spicy chicken serunding [floss] left, I used it as filling for this soft, moist and fluffy rolls. Â The texture was lovely and tasted good. Â This bun recipe is a keeper. Â  If eating buns the next day, just warm them up in a small oven toaster before serving.Â  Â  Ingredients for Bun Dough[makes 16 pieces]400 gm bread flour100 gm plain flour1 tsp curry powder [I omit]50 gm castor sugar1 tsp salt3 tsp yeast1 egg240-250 ml water or milk60 gm butterFilling - spicy chicken floss [you can use any fillings or fried minced meat]Â Â Â Place all the dry dough ingredients in a mixing bowl of anÂ electric mixer. Â Mix well and add in the egg. Knead from low speed and gradually add in the water or milk. Â Continue kneading until a soft dough is formed [this takes about 5-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue to knead from low to medium high speed. Â Knead until dough is soft, smooth and elastic [window pane stage]. Â This takes about 10 minutes. Â The dough should be stretchable and doesn't stick to the fingers when touch.Shape into a round ball. Â Cover to proof for 20-25 minutes or double in size.Punch down dough, divide into 2 equal portion. Â Rest for 5 minutes.Sprinkle some flour on work surface. Â Take one portion of the dough, roll into a flat rectangle of about size 7" x 15". Â Spread filling evenly over rolled dough. Â Roll up from the long side towards the centre from the bottom and roll down from top towards the centre so that both meets in the centre of the rectangle. Â Seal the edges to form a log.Cut Â into 8 equal pieces. Â Invert each piece and place on a baking tray lined with parchment paper. Â Do the same for the other piece of dough.Leave to proof in an unheated oven for 45 minutes or until double in size.Brush with egg or milk glaze and bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 12-15 minutes.Remove to cool on wire rack.

title: Dried Lilybud Soup
text: I had this soup while I was in Taiwan last year. Â A very easy, simple and quick to prepare soup yet it is yummy to go with rice.Â  At home, this is a quick boil soup which is clear, has the sweet taste of dried lily buds [in Taiwan the lily buds have a very nice bright orange/yellow colour] and fragrant flavour of the seasoned meat.Ingredients[serves 2-3]50 gm dried lily buds - knotted and trim off the hard ends50 - 100 gm minced meat600 ml water [you can use stock]salt, msg and pepper to tasteSoak dried lilyÂ  buds for 5 minutes to soften then drain off excess water.Marinate minced meat with salt, pepper, sesame oil and cornstarch. Â Set aside.Bring water to boil in a soup pot [I used claypot]. Â When water boils, drop in minced meat Â in lumps [not necessary to make into meatballs]. Â Add in seasoning to taste.Cook for several minutes, then add in dried lily buds. Â  Bring soup to boil again.Off heat, sprinkle in some chopped spring onions.Serve immediately.Â Notes - Dried Lily Buds Â Also known as tiger lily buds, golden needles [kim chiam] and dried lily flowers is an essential brain food.Â  These are rich in protein, fats, calcium, iron and vitamin B1. All of which aids in the metabolism of your brain.I'm sharing this post withÂ The Spanish Wok- The TSK Butler Soup KitchenÂ Monthly Blogger Event October 2012.

title: English Bread Pudding with Walnuts and Crumble Toppings
text: It's unavoidable to have leftover bread slices when breakfast is most of the time bread. Â and buns. Â Over the week, I have accumulated about 4 cups of bread and it's high time I 'get rid' of them. Â Fastest way I believe is making Bread Pudding or breadcrumbs.Â Bread pudding is an old fashioned dessert [but I'm having it for breakfast] that had its humble beginnings in the 13th century England. Â It was first known as a 'poor man's pudding' as it was made from stale leftover bread that was simply moistened in water to which a little sugar, spices and other ingredients were added.Here 's the simple recipe with 2 parts to prepare, the bread cubes and custard to moisten the bread. Â I baked this quantity in 2 x 6" square baking tins [cos' I'm giving 1/2 portion to my neighbour].Â  You can use a 7" or 8" square tin, the difference is only in the thickness of the pudding.Â Ingredients[serves 4]4 cups of bread cubes [diced bread slices]1/2 cup raisins [you can use any other dried fruits]2 eggs350 ml milk [can use 1/2 cream and 1/2 milk for richer flavour]Â 40 gm sugar1 tsp vanilla essence2 tbsp melted butter1/2 cinnamon powder [optional]30 gm toasted walnuts - choppedcrumble toppings [optional]Greased baking pans with butter and sprinkle a little flour on the base and sides.Place the diced bread and raisins in the baking pans, evenly spreading them. Set aside.Whisk sugar and eggs until creamy and light [this step is for a light and fluffy textured bread pudding]. Â  Then add in vanilla essence and cinnamon powder. Â Whisk for a second to mix well. Â Add in the milk and melted butter. Â Stir to combine well all the ingredients.Gently pour egg and milk custard mixture all over bread. Â Press down a little with a spatula to cover bread with custard.Sprinkle the toasted walnuts and crumble toppings on top.Â  Leave for about 1/2 - 1 hour to allow bread to soak up the custard.Steam-bakeÂ in preheated oven at 150 degrees C for 1 hour.Â  Remove and serve warm.Crumble Toppings20 gm castor sugar25 gm butter45 gm plain flourUse your finger tips to mix the ingredients until it resembles bread crumbsKeep in a container and store it in the refrigerator for later use.I'm submitting this post to Aspiring Bakers#24 - Jellies and Puddings [October 2012] hosted by Charmaine of Mimi Bakery HouseÂ and also toÂ Bake Your Own BreadÂ hosted by girlichef

title: Super Soft Loaf Bread [Tangzhong Method]
text: This is really a super soft loaf bread. Â Actually, I baked this bread [2 loaves] before with a burnt top 'darker than the Roti Benggali' but the bread is really soft and moist. Â The reason for the burnt top was because of my oven setting. Â I accidentally turned it to top heat during the whole process of baking. Â Initially I thought it was because the bread rose very high and so near to the top heating element. Â  Thinking it was a flopped recipe, I didn't bother to take any pictures [should have took some photos to show the burnt top] and dare not share the other loaf with my neighbour.So I baked this bread again which turned out well without the burnt top but I added 1 tbsp wholemeal flour.Â  This breadÂ  is better without the wholemeal flour [please omit it].Â  Next time, I'll just use white bread flour. Ingredients[makes 1 loaf]270 gm bread flour [I added 1 tbsp wholemeal flour-optional]90 gm tangzhong paste [water roux]30 gm sugar [I used 1 tbsp]1/2 tsp salt1 egg [50-60 gm]60 ml milk1 1/2 tsp yeast30 gm butter [I used 1 tbsp]Mix all ingredients [except butter] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead until soft.Add in butter and continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic [window pane stage]. Â Dough is quite wet but still manageable with further kneading.Shape into a round ball and leave to proof until double in size.Â Punch down. Â Roll out dough into a swiss roll shape. Â Place in Pullman's tin to proof for 45 minutes or until double in size. Â You can proof it in an oven @ 40 degrees C for 45 minutes [it will rise beautifully to double in size or until 80% height of the tin].Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 30 minutes.Remove bread immediately to cool on rack.How To Prepare Tangzhong [Bread Starter/Water Roux] - Ratio of flour to water is 1:5][yields about 270 gm tangzhong paste, enough for making 3 loaves of the above bread]50 gm bread flour250 ml waterMix flour with water until well combined. Â Cooked to 65 degrees C on low heat, keep stirring into a smooth, thick paste.Store in container, cover with cling film. Â Cool and refrigerate until required.Notes- thaw to room temperature before use- leftover can be kept for 2-3 days- discard if greyishI'm sharing this post with Bake Your Own Bread hosted by girlichef.

title: Cream Cheese Chiffon Cake
text: I have baked this cream cheese chiffon cake several times but  was disappointed that the cake shrinks quite a bit using the previous method where I whisk the melted cream cheese and butter with egg.Â This time I used the method below and I'm quite happy with the result.   The cake is spongy, soft and moist chiffon with nice cheesy taste.Â Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture50 gm cream cheese20 gm butterÂ melt over hot water pan and stir to mix well. Â Set aside.65 gm cake flour2 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt4 large egg yolks50 ml milkPlace all the dry ingredients [sifted flour, salt and sugar] in the mixing bowl.Â  Make a well in the centre.Â  Pour in all the liquid ingredients [egg yolks, melted cheese and milk].Â  Beat together using a paddle hook on medium to high speed until well combined and mixture is smooth [takes about 5 minutes].Â Â  Set aside.Â Ingredients for Egg White4 large egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 tbsp caster sugarWhisk egg white in a clean mixing bowl till frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue beating for a second and add in caster sugar gradually.Â  Continue beating all the time until soft to stiff peaks formedÂ [Note - it is easier to fold in soft/stiff peak egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture].Fold in 1/3 the egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold into the balance egg white mixture.Â  Fold till mixtures are well combined.Â Â Pour into 7" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30-35 minutes on lower rack.Remove from oven and immediately invert pan to cool cake before removing from pan.I'm sharing this post withÂ BakeFest #12@fun and food cafeÂ  hosted by MansiÂ and also linking toÂ Vardhini's Page @ CooksJoy.

title: Peanut Minced Meat Claypot Rice
text: Another claypot riceÂ  suitable as One Dish Meal for a simple lunch or dinner.Â  Lovely to serve with a bowl of leafy green vegetable soup [refer here for soup recipes].Ingredients[serves 3-5]300 gm rice - wash and drain450 ml water1 can braised peanuts - drain away liquid some chopped spring onionssome cut red chillies in soy sauce [accompaniment]150 gm minced meat3 dried mushroom - soaked and cut small cubes Marinate with:2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp each of sugar, sesame oil and cornflour1/2 tsp each of dark soy sauce and pepper powderSeasoning for RiceÂ - combine together1/2 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp sesame oil 1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and oyster sauce2 tbsp hot waterMarinate meat and mushroom.Â  Leave in the refrigerator for at least an hour.Wash rice in several changes of water and place in a claypot with 450 ml water [I used basmathi rice]. Â  Leave to soak for about 30 minutes before cooking.Cook, covered over medium heat until water is almost absorbed [about 5-10 minutes].  Drizzle in the seasoning sauce.   Add in the meat and mushroom and braised peanuts all over the rice.Â Lower heat to the lowest and cover to complete cooking the rice and meat for another 10-15 minutes. Â Check rice after 10 minutes to prevent it from sticking at the base of claypot [or give it a good stir for even cooking]. Â Cover claypot to complete the cooking for a further 5 minutes on the lowest heat possible.Remove from heat, uncover and top with cut spring onions.Â  Serve immediately. Â Â I'm sharing this post with Muhibbah Malaysian Monday October 2012 hosted by Sharon ofÂ Test with Skewer

title: Herbal Fish Soup
text: A simple herbal soup with freshly caught fish [from my hubby's fishing trip].Ingredients[serves 2-3] 1 whole garoupa [about 300 gm] - clean and cut into half1 tbsp meddlar seeds [goji/wolfberries]1/2 tsp salt to taste1/2 tsp chicken stock granulesHerbs [refer here for benefits of the herbs]5 gm [1 piece] tian-ma [Rhizoma Gastrodiae Elatae]3-4 slices dong quai [angelica roots]5 pieces chuan qiong [szechuan lovage rhizome]some button mushrooms [I omit]3 bowls waterRinse herbs and place in a soup pot with water.Â  Bring to a boil and simmer for 15 minutes until aromatic.Â  Put in the fish and goji to cook [add button mushrooms if using].Â  Let is boil.Add in seasoning to taste.Serve hot.Health BenefitsTian - Ma [Rhizoma Gastrodiae Elatae] is also known as Gastrodia Tuber. The sweet and neutral herb has been used in TCM to relieve pain, treat neurasthenia and insomnia, depression, blood-vessel type of migraine, etc., as it calms internal Wind and convulsions, soothes the Liver, controls ascending Yang due to Yin Deficiency, etc., by enhancing the function of liver channels.I'm linking this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday October 2012 hosted byÂ Sharon ofÂ Test with SkewerÂ and alsoÂ  submitting this post to TSK Butler Soup Kitchen Monthly Blogger EventÂ October 2012 and also in conjunction with World Food Day hosted by The Spanish Wok.and also submitting to Carole's Chatter for Friday's theme on 'Soup Glorious Soups' Â onI'm linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and Lovage

title: EZ Plain Pancakes
text: Very easy to prepare and simple pancakes for breakfast or tea time. Â You only need 2 bowls, one for dry ingredients and the other for wet ingredients.Ingredients[makes 10-12 pieces]Dry IngredientsÂ - mix together to combine130 gm all purpose flour - sifted2 tbsp [30 gm] sugar1 1/2 tsp baking powder1/2 tsp saltWet Ingredients - whisk together to combine240 ml skimmed milk2 tbsp melted butter1 large egg1. Â  Make a well in the centre of the dry ingredients. Â Gradually pour in the wet ingredients. Â Just stir lightly to combine well but not to develop glutton. Â It's okay if there are a few lumps. Â Rest for 15 minutes [you can prepare this batter earlier, keep in covered container and leave in the refrigerator until later use.2. Â  Lightly oil a griddle or non stick pan on medium heat. Â Use a small scoop [about the size of ice cream scoop] to ladle batter onto heated pan. Â Turn over to fry the other side when the bottom is brown and edges are firm.3. Â  Remove from pan to cool separately on a tray. Â Do not stack the pancakes while still hot.4. Â  Serve pancakes warm with either whipped cream and fresh fruits or just maple syrup, Â butter and jam or plain with a hot beverage.Notes:Pancakes can be prepared ahead and Â refrigerate. Â Toast pancakes before serving.

title: EZ Oven Baked Fried Chicken
text: I haven't been cooking much in my kitchen these days except for the weekends. Occasionally, I would love to indulge in some deep fried food but was put off doing it cos' I don't want to keep the used deep fried oil.Â  Some of you may say 'Aiyoh, so simple just buy lah!'. Â Yes, I did but later regret it cos' I 'suffered' for 2 weeks because of this deep fried food which I bought. Â Maybe I've a sensitive throat but I developed a sore throat which turned into a flu and bad cough.Recently, I came across this recipe where I can have deep fried chicken using the oven. Â  The oven fried chicken isÂ full of flavour without the greasiness as deep fried. Â You can use other cuts of chicken, too.I must say that I'm quite happy with the result eventhough the crispiness can still be improved but the meat was tender, succulent and juicy. Â Probably, I'll try again with another flavour [here I used pepper/salt and curry powder]. Â Best Â thing is, my throat was okay and the chicken wasn't oily even with the skin.Ingredients[serves 3]3 piece chicken whole leg - [deboned chicken chop style]2 tsp pepper and salt mix1 tsp curry powderPat dry chicken drumstick and marinate with above pepper salt mix [I used the one I bought from Taiwan] and curry powder for several hours or overnight.1 egg lightly beaten with 30 ml milk30 ml melted butterFlour Coating - mix together2 tsp pepper and salt mix1 tsp curry powder1/2 cup all purpose flourGrease a baking rack with some melted butter or oil.Â  Place over a baking tray lined with aluminium foil [for easy cleaning].Dip marinated chicken legs with beaten egg, then coat with flour coating.Â  Shake off excess flour and place on a big plate.Â  Leave for 5-10 minutes, then put back into the flour mix to coat with more flour.Place chicken pieces on baking rack.Â  DrizzleÂ  melted oil all over coated chicken pieces [this is to get the crispy coating].Baked in preheated oven at 200 degrees C [middle shelf] for 40 minutes.Â  Then grill for another 5-10 minutes until crispy.Â  Remove from oven and rest for 5 minutes before serving [I served chicken without slicing].Note:Can coat chicken with any seasoning of your choice such as garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, black or white pepper, Cajun seasoning etc. I'm sharing this post with Muhibbah Malaysian Monday October 2012 hosted by Sharon atÂ Test with Skewers.

title: Stir Fry 5 Coloured Vege Dish
text: When coming to fry vegetables, I like to combine a few ingredients in one dish [usually with 5 colours] so that I get to eat a variety from soya to greens.Â Here is a simple stir fry vegetarian dish to serve with rice.Ingredients [quantity exactly in the photo below][For vegetarian dish, omit the minced meat] 1/2 carrot - cut stripsbeancurd stick - soak to soften and cut stripsblack fungus - soak to plump up and cut stripssome green beans - slice thin stripssome dried lily buds - knotted and soak for a few minutes - squeeze out excess watersome beansprouts - tailedsome minced meat - omit for vegetarian dishsome chopped garlic and gingervegetarian oyster sauce, salt and pepper to tastesesame oil and oilÂ Heat up wok, add in oil, saute chopped garlic and ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in meat [if using].Â  Fry until it turns pale, add in lily buds, beancurd stick, black fungus and carrot.Fry for a few seconds, add in green beans and beansprouts.Â  Stir fry to combine all ingredients.Â  Add seasoning to taste.Dish out on plate once the beans are cooked.

title: Orange Chiffon Cake
text: Baked this Orange Chiffon for my cousin sister in-law, a hairstylist who gives us [my family] free hair cut and anything from hair cream to hair spray etc... A big thank you to her.Spongy, soft and moist chiffon with nice tangy aroma of orange.Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture[recipe adapted fromÂ Happy FlourÂ with slight modifications to ingredients and method]110 gm cake flour [superfine flour]1 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt3 large egg yolks3 tbsp corn oil85 ml orange juice [from 1-2 oranges]1 tsp orange zestPlace all the dry ingredients [sifted flour, salt and sugar] in the mixing bowl.Â  Make a well in the centre.Â  Pour in all the liquid ingredients [egg yolks, orange juice, oil and zest].Â  Beat together using a paddle hook on medium to high speed until well combined and mixture is smooth [takes about 5 minutes].Â Â  Set aside.Ingredients for Egg White3 large egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 1/2 tbsp caster sugarWhisk egg white in a clean mixing bowl till frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue beating for a second and add in caster sugar gradually.Â  Continue beating all the time until soft to stiff peaks formedÂ [Note - it is easier to fold in soft/stiff peak egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture].Fold in 1/3 the egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold into the balance egg white mixture.Â  Fold till mixtures are well combined.Â Â Pour into 7" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30-35 minutes on lower rack.Remove from oven and immediately invert pan to cool cake before removing from pan.Cake shrinks a little after cooling

title: My Ping Pei 2012 [Snow Skin Mooncakes] - 2
text: These are my second batch of Ping Pei Mooncakes giveaways.Â  Since they are for giveaways, I can't slice them for pictures [will try to take some photos when we savour these mooncakes this Sunday on Mid-autumn festival day].You may be wondering why I have to wait until Sunday [mid-autumn festival], cos' I don't keep any mooncakes at home.These are photos of my second batch of Ping Pei mooncakes for my mum and mother in-law.Â Â Â Â Â Â Notes:For recipes of these mooncakes, please refer here and here.

title: Black Sesame Ping Pei Mooncake with Mixed Nuts
text: Here, I am using the Black Sesame Ping Pei Skin to wrap the mixed nuts filling [Ngoh Gin]Â  [recipe here].Â  The snow skin paste has a strong, nice aroma of sesame seeds.Ingredients for Black Sesame Ping Pei SkinÂ Â [dough weighs about 350 gm] [makes 5 x 60-70 gm pieces depending on the thickness]2 tbsp each of toasted black sesame seeds and white sesame seeds -Â  finely ground80 gm fried glutinous rice flour [kao fun] - sifted80 gm icing sugar - sifted90-100 gm shortening [too little shortening the skin will be crumbly unless you make it thicker]40-50 ml iced cold water [may not use all]green and yellow colouring [optional]mooncake mouldÂ Â Â Use a blender to finely grind both sesame seeds.Combine sifted icing sugar and kao fun, then add in ground sesame powder.Â  Mix wellUse rub-in method, add in shortening to [2] and mix until fine grains.Â  Gradually add in iced cold water until the dough binds.Knead into a soft and smooth paste.Â  Cover and rest for 15-30 minutes.Divide dough intoÂ  5 Â  equal portions.Wrap skin over mixed nuts filling, roll into a smooth ball and edges are well sealed [always dust your hands with extra kao fun to prevent dough from sticking].Place onto dusted mooncake mould, press to fill up the mould then knock out mooncake.Serve chilled.Notes:I kept 1/2 portion plain and add some yellow and green colouring to the other portion [givingÂ  some of these mooncakes to my mother in-law, she likes mixed nuts butÂ  may not like to see black and white mooncake skin].Â Â I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted byÂ Suresh ofÂ 3 hungry tummies

title: My Ping Pei 2012 [Snow Skin Mooncakes] 1
text: Some of my Ping Pei mooncake giveaways this year.Â  The fillings are quite similar as previous but with different combinations.Mooncake with the above mouldÂ Â Mooncakes using the above new moulds  Ingredients for Ping Pei SkinÂ [dough weighs about 800 gm] [makes 12 x 60-70 gm pieces depending on the thickness]200 gm fried glutinous rice flour [kao fun] - sifted150 gm icing sugar - sifted70 gm shortening1 tsp essence [lemon] - optional200 ml iced cold wateryellow, green, pink and chocolate colouring [optional] - according to own preference, you can keep it plain or a single colourIcing Sugar, Shortening and Kao FunPing Pei dough divided into various coloursMix together sifted flour and icing sugar, then add in shortening.Use rub-in method to mix flour, sugar and shortening together into fine grains.Slowly and gradually add in ice cold water.Â  Mix well and knead with hand tillÂ  smooth.Â  Cover and leave to rest for 15 - 30 minutes.Â  [Notes - If making different colours, divide into a few portions and add in colouring, knead till well combined then rest the dough for 15-30 minutes]Divide dough into 12 equal portions [about 60-70 gm each-thicker skin].Â  You may make about 14 pieces if using smaller mooncake moulds and less filling. Â Â  Roll out 1 portion thinly into a circle that is large enough to wrap a ball of filling [about 110 gm] - depends on size of mould.Â  Coat filling with kao fun and wrap with ping pei dough.Press into mould dusted with kao fun.Â  Knock mould lightly to dislodge the mooncake.Â  Place in plastic mooncake tray and mooncake container.Â  Refrigerate before serving.Notes :- Various Ping Pei Fillings [can be mix and match to suit you preference][Most of the paste can be store bought or you can make your own.Â Â  See this post for the recipe for some of the mooncake fillings.- You can make each Ping Pei in a single colour or any combination of colours according to your ownÂ  preference [please refer above photos on the combination].- The paste which I used for this year's Ping Pei are:-Savoury Sweet Mung Beans Paste with Cream CheesePandan Lotus with Melon SeedsTau Sar with Melon SeedsLotus Seed Paste with Melon SeedsPandan Lotus Paste with Salted Egg YolkÂ Â Â - These are the first batch of giveaways and second batch to come, next post [My Ping Pei 2012 [Snow Skin Mooncakes 2] with pictures only.

title: Vegetarian Fried Beehoon
text: A noodle dish I like when I thought of meatless meal.Â  Usually will serve the noodle dish with a warm/hot sweet dessert like green beans with barley sweet soup [recipe here]Â or red beans soupÂ [recipe here]. Â Looks like there are lots of ingredients for this noodle but take a closer look at it you will realise that you may have most of them in the kitchen cupboard or fridge. Â You need not follow exactly all the ingredients, just make do with what you have in hand and you will end up with at least a 'five coloured noodle', believe to be good for health [protein, fibre, carbo etc....].Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 gm beehoon [rice vermicelli] - soak 5-10 minutes and drain [I used 3 pieces of A1 rice vermicelli]2 pieces sweet beancurd sheet [tian-zhu] - cut 1/2 inch pieces and deep fried till crispy1 piece firm beancurd - cut strips 4 stalks of bok choy - cut [or sawi/choi sum]1 small carrot -cut strips1/2 can of young corns30 gm dried lily buds [kim chiam] - knotted and soak to soften 2-3 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips2-3 florets of black mushrooms [bok nee] - soaked and break into small piecessome cut red chillies 2-3 tbsp oil1/2 tsp each of salt, msg and pepper2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce [more if you prefer darker noodles]Â 1 tsp sugar1 1/2 cup waterHeat some oil in wokÂ  to fry firm beancurd until firm.Â  Dish out.Using the same wok, fry young corns, lily buds and carrots for a minute.Â  Dish out onto plate with beancurd.Add in dried mushrooms and black fungus.Â  Stir fry for a minute, pour in water and add in seasoning to taste.Â  Bring it to boil and add in beehoon.Â  Use a pair of chopstick to mix noodles with sauce.Â  Add in the bok choy, all of the other fried ingredients and deep fried sweet beancurd sheet pieces.Â Â Mix well and cover wok to let noodles and ingredients cooked through.Â  Takes about 3 minutes.Â  Uncover and stir fry noodles lightly until gravy is almost dried up and noodles are soft.Dish out to serve immediately with cut chillies.

title: Double-boiled Herbal Roast Chicken
text: Suddenly has a craving for herbal soup with chicken [the type served during Chinese wedding course dinner]. Â But instead of wrapping the ingredients with cellophane paper and steamed, I opted to use double-boiling method in a pot. Â Co-incidentally, my mum gave me a roasted chicken, this makes it easier to prepare the dish.Just need to add some other ingredients like fresh, dried or canned mushrooms of your choice and young corns, red dates, dried longan and goji [wolfberries] and most important the Chinese herbs.Â Ingredients1 roast chicken [remove the head/neck and end tip of wings]1/2 can of young cornssome dried mushrooms - soaked and cut1 tbsp each of dried longan and goji5-6 red dates4 cloves garlicSeasoning to taste2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp salt1 tsp sugarChinese Herbs [rinsed and put in a small porous bag - obtained from medical hall]a handful of yoke chok5-6 pieces tong kwai5-6 pieces chuan-qiong3 pieces wai sun2 pieces pak kei1 piece sok tei3 cups water1/2 tbsp cornflour + 2 tbsp water [for thickening]Put all the Chinese herbs in the small bag and tied up. Â Bring water to boil in the pot with herbs until fragrant. Â Off heat.Stuff as much of the other ingredients into chicken cavity [can leave balance in the soup]. Â Place chicken into herbal soup. Â Bring it to a boil again and add in seasoning to taste. Â Off heat and cover with lid.Place pot in a bigger pot with enough water to steam/double boil for 1 hour or until chicken is soft and tender. Â Turn chicken over once halfway through cooking.Discard the herbal bag. Â Bring soup to a boil and thicken the soup slightly before serving. Â Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.Â I'm linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and Lovage

title: Layered Pumpkin Bread With Spicy Chicken Floss
text: I have used this filling for buns last year.Â  The buns [recipe here]Â  were good.Â Â  With no exception this year, we received a packet ofÂ  'serunding'Â  [spicy chicken floss] a Malay Hari Raya speciality from a Malay friend.Â  This time I used it as filling for my Layered Pumpkin Bread.Â Â  IÂ  think it's alright to use other types of fillings too for this layered bread.Â For the bread dough, I used the same recipe for myÂ  Pumpkin Buns [recipe here] that uses plain flour.Ingredients - Pumpkin Bread Dough [Straight Dough Method][baked in 7" square baking tin] 300 gm plain flour1/2 tbsp skimmed milk powder1/2 tsp salt25 gm sugar [1 used 1 heaped tbsp]1 small egg100 gm pumpkin puree50 ml water [depends on size of egg and whether puree is wet]2 tsp yeast1 tbsp butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter and water] on slow speed to combine. Â Gradually add in water [may not need all otherwise the dough may be too wet and difficult to handle] and continue kneading until dough is soft and smooth [about 5-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-10 minutes to get to window pane stage.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for1 hour. Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 3 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball.Â Roll a portion into a 7" square piece to fit into the baking tin.Â  Place flattened dough on the baking tin lined with parchment paper.Â  Spread evenly a layer of chicken floss.Â  Repeat the same process for the other 2 pieces of dough.Proof until double in size [about 1 hour]. Â  Glaze with beaten egg [I used milk] and sprinkle sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 15 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack.Â Â  Sliced bread into any shapes[diamond, square or rectangle] you like before serving.Dough ready for shapingRoll dough evenly into square to fit baking tin Glaze bread with milk and sprinkle sesame seeds Layered Pumpkin Bread with Spicy Chicken FlossI'm sharing this with AlphaBakes for September's 'P' theme hosted byÂ Caroline Makes

title: Gula Melaka Chiffon Cake
text: Another chiffon cake which I have baked sometime ago but didn't post the recipe. Baked this chiffon several days ago which turns out well with the aroma of coconut milk and palm sugar.Â The chiffon cake is soft, light and moist. Â The sweetness is acceptable.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture75 gm gula melaka [palm sugar] - double boiled with a little water. Â  Strain and add to 50 ml coconut milk - set aside75 gm cake flour - sifted1/2 tsp salt3 egg yolks3 tbsp oilÂ In a mixing bowl, put in sifted cake flour and salt.Â  Make a well in the centre, pour in egg yolks, oil, and sugar/coconut milk mixture.Â  Using a paddle hook, whisk ingredientsÂ  [on medium to high speed] until egg yolk mixture is creamy and thick.Â Â Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 160 degrees C.Ingredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg whitesÂ 1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 tbsp sugar or 50 gm sugarWhisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar, continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft to stiff peaks formed [I used speed 5].Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into rest of meringue till well incorporated. Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â  Â Smooth the surface with a spatula.Â  TapÂ a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles.Â Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees for 40-45 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Homemade Mango and Tomato Jam
text: A jam that has a fruit and a vegetable [is tomato a vegetable or fruit?].Â  Doesn't matter this jam is packed with fruity flesh that goes well with home baked bread slices. Â Definitely a light [not too sweet] jam.Ingredients[makes 2 bottles x 500 gm]Â 700 gm mango flesh - chopped finely and keep the juices too300 gm tomatoes - chopped finely1 tsp vanilla essence150 ml water200 gm sugarPrepare the fruits as above. Â  Place a small saucer in the freezer [this is use to test whether jam is ready].Place cut ingredients and water in a heavy based saucepan. Â Bring to a rolling boil, then lower heat to simmer until soft [stirring occasionally to prevent sticking on base of pan].Add in sugar, stir and continue to simmer for about half an hour or more until mixture is thickened. Â Stir occasionally to mix ingredients and add in vanilla essence when jam is almost thickened. Â Simmer until it gels up. To test if jam is ready, place a teaspoon of jam on chilled saucer. Â Return to the fridge and leave for a few minutes and jam should be ready if it forms a mass.Store jam in sterilised airtight bottles. Â Always refrigerate jam as homemade jams are without preservatives.I'm submitting this post to Teatime Treats Challenge hosted byÂ What Kate Baked

title: Steamed Pumpkin Cake [Kim Kuah Kuih]
text: This is the usual recipe I used for preparing Steamed Pumpkin Cake [Kim Kuah Kuih in Hokkien dialect].Â  The steamed cake is QQ soft and has a nice blend of pureed pumpkin and pumpkin cubes.Â  Served with my homemade chilli sauceÂ [recipe here], I believe there should be no complaints.Recipe Source fromÂ Tiga Gajah Cho Heng Sdn Bhd, PenangIngredients - Batter Mixture250 gm rice flour100 gm wheat starch1 tbsp salt1 tsp pepper1/2 tsp msg1 1/2 tbsp sugar1000 ml water250 gm steamed pumpkin - mashed Mix all ingredients together, stir well and strain, then add in mashed pumpkin [pumpkin puree].Â  Set aside.Â  Ingredients - Garnishing 100 gm dried prawns - washed and pounded1 tbsp oil1 red chilli - finely chopped1 stalk spring onions - cut into small pieces50 gm fried sliced shallotsFry dried prawns in oil till fragrant, remove to cool.250 gm pumpkin -Â  cut into small cubes.1 tbsp oil 2 cloves garlic and 2 shallots - choppedGreased a 10" round or square tin.Heat oil in wok and saute garlic and shallots till fragrant.Â  Add in cubed pumpkin to fry for 5 minutes till aromatic.Â  Add in a little of fried dried prawns.Â  Stir to mix well and pour inÂ  2/3 portion of the batter.Â  Continue stirring on medium heat till batter thickens.Â  Off fire and add in the balance [1/3 portion] batter.Â  Stir to mix until batter is well combined.Pour into the greased steaming tray.Â  Smooth the surface and steam over high heat for 30 minutes.After steaming, sprinkle dried prawns evenly over pumpkin cake.Â  Cool and before serving, sprinkle spring onions, chilli and fried shallots on cake.Â Â Cut and serve with chilli sauce.

title: PASSION FRUIT SOUFFLE CAKE I [OGURA CAKE]
text: Today, I baked another SoufflÃ© Cake with passion fruit as I believe the citrus flavour of this fruit should be good since the ones with orange and lemon juices were so nice.Â I was glad the cake turn out well. Â It'sÂ  spongy, soft, light and moist.Â  I added some of the seeds which were crunchy after baking. Â Â Moreover, the cake base was dry as I removed the water bath after 50 minutes of baking and left the cake to bake for a further 5-10 minutes.Â  This time I just lined the base of baking tin cos' I read that it's okay to lightly greased the sides.Â  But I noticed the cake shrinks more even though I removed the cake from the tin immediately after baking.Â  Anyway, the shrinkage is acceptable so long as the cake turns out well.Here I followed my recent method of mixing egg yolk,Â  my chiffon cake way cos' it's workable and I can leave the cake mixer to do the mixing.IngredientsÂ 40 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set asideÂ 15 gm sugar [I used 1 1/2 tbsp] - passion fruit juice is quite sour1/4 tsp salt3 egg yolks [large eggs]1/2 egg (about 30g) [I used a small egg]35 ml vegetable oil [IÂ  used 2 1/4 tbsp]50 ml passion fruit juice1 tsp passion fruit seeds3 egg white [large eggs]55 gm sugar [used 3 tbsp]1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 7" square tin with grease proof paper and lightly greased the sides and sprinkle sparsely some flour.Â Â  Preheat oven to 150 degrees C.Â  Before preheating oven, place a baking tray with baking rack on top, fill up with some water [for steam-baking] on the lower shelf.Egg Yolk Mixture - In a mixing bowl, sift in flour and add in sugar and salt.Â  Make a well in the centre and pour in egg yolks [with the extra 1/2 egg], oil and passion fruit juice.Â  Fix mixer with a paddle hook and whisk until mixture is creamy [scrape the sides and bottom of the mixing bowl halfway through mixing to make sure that the ingredients are well combined].Â Â  Add in the passion fruit seeds.Â  Set aside.Egg White - Using a clean mixing bowl, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue to whisk until slightly foamy, add in sugar in 3 batches and whisk on medium high speed until soft to stiff peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly [lift from bottom to top with a spatula] in two portions until well combined.PourÂ  batter into prepared cake tin. Â  Smooth the top with a spatula.Place baking tin on baking rack with the water bath and steam-bake cake in the preheated oven at 150 degrees C for 50 minutes, then remove the water bath and continue to bake cake for a further 5-10 minutes [I did this way so that the cake bottom will not be too moist].Remove cake at once from tin [use a flat spatula to dislodge the sides of the cake].Â Â  Transfer the cake to cool on a wire rack. Â Invert the cake to remove the greased proof paper from the base of the cake.Slice cake when completely cool [this cake can be chilled and served directly from the refrigerator].Notes:This cake keeps well in an airtight container for about 7-10 days. I'm sharing this post with AlphaBakes for September 2012 theme with 'P' hosted by Caroline MakesÂ and also with Â Bake Fest #11 at The Mad Scientist's Kitchen hosted by Archana

title: Home Cooked Indian Style Fish And Eggs Curry
text: Another home cooked Indian style curry using curry leaves and curry powder.Â  Tasty, flavourful and easy curry.Â  Can prepare the curry stock and freezed in portions for later use.Â  Just reheat curry, add in tomatoes, onions, fried fish and eggs before serving.Fish And Eggs CurryCurry LeavesIngredients5 pieces fish blocks - pan fry in oil till golden. Set aside5 hard boiled eggs - pan fry in oil till golden. Set aside1 tomato - cut wedges1 big onion - cut wedges1-2 tbsp tamarind paste mix with 750 ml water. Strain away seeds, keep juice100 ml fresh milk [substitute with 50 ml coconut milk]salt and sugar to taste4 tbsp oil Curry Mix - Combined together the 6 ingredients2 cloves garlic - blended50 gm shallots - blended2 tbsp chilli paste/boh [either dried chillies or fresh red chillies]2 tbsp fish curry powder1/2 tsp turmeric powder1 tsp mixed halba - optional1-2 sprigs curry leaves1 lemongrass - lightly smashedPrepare all the ingredients and set aside.Â  Heat oil in pot on medium heat.Â  Before oil is hot, add in combined curry mix, lemongrass and curry leaves.Â  Saute till fragrant and oil is chilli red.Â  Add in tamarind juice.Â  Bring to boil for 5 minutes.Â Â Add in tomatoes and onions followed by milk.Â  Let it boil and add in salt and sugar to taste.Â  When curry boils, add in fried fish and eggs.Â  Off fire and dish out to serve with rice.Â  Â NotesIf storing curry, prepare only step 1.Â  When serving, follow steps 2 and 3.Â  Curry tastes good after several hours. Can substitute fish with prawns.Â  Fish, prawns and eggs need not be pan fried but must be added before adding milk, tomatoes and onions.Mint, spring onions and coriander can be added to curry.I'm sharing this post with The Soup Kitchen Monthly Bloggers' Event - September 2012 [TSK Butler] hosted byÂ The Spanish Wok.

title: Tong Chye Chicken Porridge [Hokkien Style Khay Moi]
text: This is a kind of easy to prepare simple chicken porridge yet yummy if you like the chinese celery [kin chye] and preserved salted vegetables [tong chye] taste.Â  These two must have ingredients to me is no problem, I can accept so is my other half.I'm not sure if you can remember this porridge which used to be served on the morning of Chinese wedding day [during my younger days in Penang] before the bridegroom goes to fetch the bride with his friends and relatives.Â  Nowadays, this porridge has been replaced by sumptuous buffet or array of Nyonya dishes.Â  In fact, most hosts dare not serve this porridge on such occasion probably because it maybe taken as 'cheap stuff', but frankly speaking, it is a very nice porridge.Â Usually the aunties/neighbours will come to the house and prepare this porridge using the big oil tins [we called it kerosene tins eventhough it is cooking oil tins].Â  When the bridegroom returns with the bride the guests willÂ  then be served either with Nyonya kuihs/drinks or lunch [rice with Nyonya dishes on long tables].Â  Ingredients[serves 4-5] 2 chicken whole legs [with skin] 6 cups watera few cloves of garlic - keep wholea few slices of ginger2 cups rice6 cups of water2 tsp salt1/2 tsp msg1 tsp pepper1 tsp sesame oilÂ Tong Chye, Kin Chye, Garlic Oil, Chillies and Shredded ChickenCondiments2 stalks of Chinese celery [kin chye] - sliced finely2 tbsp preserved salted vegetables [tong chye] - rinsed thoroughly, squeeze out excess water and chopped finely1-2 tbsp of fried crispy garlicChinese cruellers - Eu Char Koay - cut small pieces some cut red chilliessome pepperBring 6 cups of water to boil in a big pot with ginger and garlic, then add in the chicken whole legs.Â  Let water boils again, cover and off heat to cook chicken for 15Â  minutes.Â  Remove chicken to cool on plate.Â  Discard the ginger and garlic.Remove any scums from the stock, add in rice and another 6 cups of water.Â  Bring it to a boil and cook until rice is cooked but not thick.Â  Add in chicken shreds and seasoning to taste.Â  Cover and leave porridge for a further 15-20 minutes until it is slightly thick.While porridge is cooking, debone boiled chicken and shred the meat into strips [discard the skin if preferred].To serve, ladle porridge into a serving bowl, top with some chopped celery, tong chye, garlic crisps and cruellers with dash of pepper and cut chillies.Note: We love this porridge some much.Â  This portion was only enough for 3 of us [each had 1 1/2 bowls]. Â Make sure porridge is not too thick if adding Chinese cruellers [eu char koay].I'm sharing this with Muhibbah Malaysian Monday September 2012 hosted by Suresh ofÂ 3 hungry tummies

title: Tau Sar Figurine Mooncake 2012
text: I made this figurine mooncake with red bean paste and meat floss filling by popular requests from my nephews.Â  Personally, I prefer plain 'koong chye pneang' [recipe here]Â and for those with other fillings [please recipe here].Â  But you can also use this recipe for plain mooncake if you intend to make more, just omit the red bean paste and meat floss.This recipe here uses more golden syrup and oil compared to the recipe for Sesame Seed Figurine Mooncake [recipe here].Â  The dough is softer but more oily to the touch.Ingredients[makes 25-30 pieces with meat floss fillings and 25-30 pieces with red bean paste][moulds used - pineapple and Garfield]450 gm golden syrup170 ml corn oil1 tbsp alkaline water [kan sui]1/2 tsp bicarbonate soda600 gm plain flour [I used Rose flour]enough meat floss [store bought]enough red bean paste [store bought]Combine the first 4 ingredients in a deep container.Â  Use a wooden spatula/spoon to stir until they are well blended together.Â  Cover and leave to rest for at least 4-5 hours [I leave it overnight].Before folding in the flour, give the syrup mixture a good stir.Â  Fold in sifted flour gradually and mix evenly to form a smooth and soft dough [Do not over mix or knead dough].Â  Cover and let it rest for another 6-7 hours [I leave it overnight].After resting, the dough will be firmer but soft and easy to handle.Divide dough into small portions according to the size of the mould used.Â  Roll a little of the portion, flatten and then wrap some filling in the centre.Â  Seal the edges well and press into the figurine mould.Â  Dust with flour if dough sticks to mould or hand.Â  Knock out and place on greased baking tray.Â  Do the same for any fillings used.Bake in preheated oven on middle shelfÂ  at 180 degrees C for 20 minutes or until golden.Remove and cool completely on a wire rackÂ  before storing.NotesI don't brush the mooncakes with egg glaze.Â  If you do, bake mooncakes for 8 minutes, remove to cool for 1-2 minutes before brushing egg glaze then bake again for another 7-8 minutes or until golden.The mooncakes will be soft immediately out of the oven but will turn hard while cooling.Keep mooncakes in a tray [I used bamboo steamer trays] with lid slightly ajar for a few days or until the mooncakes are soft again before packing.I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysia MondayÂ hosted by Suresh ofÂ 3 hungry tummies

title: Sesame Seed Figurine Mooncake 2012
text: This year, I'm making these figurine mooncakes in loving memory of my late father.Â  Last year during this time he was with us enjoying most of the mooncakes that I made but it's not happening this year.Â  I remembered there was a day last year during mid-autumn festival , he had a piece each of the mooncake on both hands.Â  While he was turning around he just lost his balance and fell on the floor.Â  But the unbelievable thing was, he was still holding tightly onto the mooncakes even though he fell.Â  My sister in-law was teasing me at that time.Â  She said "Wow!, you 'ang kong ah peang' [meaning figurine mooncakes in Hokkien] must be very good.Â  You see Pa still holding onto it even though he was sitting on the floor".I'm glad that for years I have being making mooncakes which my Pa really enjoyed.Â  Last year, he tried all the varieties [figurine mooncakes and ping pei mooncakes]Â  but we never knew that it was going to be the last time he was enjoying the mooncakes. Â  He passed away about more than a month later without being seriously ill.Anyway, this is the recipe for figurine mooncake which used less golden syrup and oil [for 300 gm flour] compared to my other recipe [for 600 gm flour].Â  See here for recipe.Â  With less syrup and oil, the dough is slightly firmer than the latter which is softer and more oily to the touch.Shaping mooncakes Shaped mooncakes before bakingÂ  Baked figurine mooncakesÂ Ingredients [makes 30 pieces using the 'Angku' mould]200 gm golden syrup [recipe here]50 ml corn oil3/4 tbsp alkaline water1/4 tsp bicarbonate soda3 tbsp toasted sesame seeds300 gm plain flour - sifted [I used Rose flour]Figurine mould - I used the small 'Angku' mould Combine the first 4 ingredients in a deep container.Â  Use a wooden spatula/spoon to stir until they are well blended together.Â  Cover and leave to rest for at least 4-5 hours [I leave it overnight].Before folding in the flour, add sesame seeds and give the syrup mixture a good stir.Â  Fold in sifted flour gradually and mix evenly to form a smooth and soft dough [Do not over mix or knead dough].Â  Cover and let it rest for another 6-7 hours [I leave it overnight].After resting, the dough will be firmer but soft and easy to handle.Divide dough into small portions according to the size of the mould used.Â  Roll a little of the portion then press into the figurine mould.Â  Dust with flour if dough sticks to mould or hand.Â  Knock out and place on greased baking tray.Bake in preheated oven on middle shelfÂ  at 180 degrees C for 20 minutes or until golden.Remove and cool completely on a wire rackÂ  before storing.NotesI don't brush the mooncakes with egg glaze.Â  If you do, bake mooncakes for 8 minutes, remove to cool for 1-2 minutes before brushing egg glaze then bake again for another 7-8 minutes or until golden.The mooncakes will be soft immediately out of the oven but will turn hard while cooling.Keep mooncakes on a tray [I used bamboo steamer trays] with lid slightly ajar for a few days or until the mooncakes are soft again before packing.

title: Orange Zebra SoufflÃ© Cake
text: This is the sixth SoufflÃ© Cake which I baked using orange and cocoa for flavour and the zebra effect.Â The cake is cottony soft, light and moist with a nice aroma of orange.Ingredients3         egg yolk1/2       egg (about 30g)15 gm       sugar [I used 1 tbsp]1/4 tsp    salt50 ml       orange juice1 tsp      orange zest35 ml vegetable oil [IÂ  used 1 1/2 tbsp]1/4 tsp orange paste       [I omit as I don't have it]40 gm       cake flourÂ      - sifted - set aside2 tsp cocoa powder dissolve in 15 ml hot water - set aside to cool3         egg white55 gm       sugar [used 3-4 tbsp]1/4 tsp    cream of tartarLine base of a 7" square tin [loose bottom pan] with grease proof paper.Preheat oven to 150 degrees C.Â Â Â  Place a baking tray on the lowest rack, pour in enough water for steam baking, then place a baking rack over it.Â  This way, you need not have to wrap baking tin with foil.Mix orange juice, zest and oilÂ  together.Â  Set aside.Use a hand whisk mix egg yolks, half egg, sugar and salt together.Drizzle in liquid mixture [orange juice, zest and oil] and whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth.Â  Set aside.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites until frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  B eat until soft peaks then gradually add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until stiff peaks formed.Â  Do not over beat egg whites otherwise it may be difficult to fold in to egg yolk mixture.Fold in 1/3 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Â  Remove 1/3 of cake batter to another bowl.Â  Add in the cocoa mixture, mix well.Scoop the 2 batters alternately to create the zebra effect of the cake into prepared cake tin [using a small ladle, put the orange portion in the centre of tin and top with cocoa batter, shake the pan lightly and the batter will spread out itself].Â  Tap baking tray on work surface a few times to release trapped air bubbles before baking.Â Place it over the baking rack to steam bake cake in a preheated oven at 150 degrees C for 50 minutes. Â Remove cake at once from tin [otherwise the cake base may be moist because of vapour from steam-baking].Â Â  Remove all the paper linings immediately and cool it on a wire rack.Â  The cake may shrink a little when cooled because of less flour used [low gluten cake].Note:I usually chill the cake in the fridge before slicing. Â This cake tastes as good when chilled. Â Â I'm submitting this post to:Â Recipe Box 14 hosted by Bizzy Bakes

title: Coffee Sweet Buns - Cinnamon Rolls
text: For this cinnamon rolls, I'm using the remaining half portion [weighs 500 gm] of the Coffee Sweet Bun Dough [recipe here]Â that's enough for baking 9 cinnamon rolls using a 7 inch baking tin.Â These cinnamon rolls are lovely with soft bun texture, nice aroma of coffee blended with cinnamon and slightly sweet salty fillings. Â Perfect healthy version of cinnamon buns minus the extra fats and sugar.
