text: An easy and simple soup to prepare that goes well with rice.Â  With this soup, you can skip frying another vegetable dish.Â  Try to cook this soup with young spinach shoots or if using ordinary spinach, removed the tough stems.Â Â  Sure it's a healthy and light soup for all.Ingredients[serves 3-4]500 gm chinese spinach1 tsp each of chopped garlic and shallots30 gm silver baits, fried until crispy1 tbsp wolfberry [kei chee] - rinsed700 ml water or stock1/2 tsp each salt, pepper and chicken stock granules1/2 tbsp oil Heat oil to fry silver bait until fragrant and crispy.Â  Remove.Â  Keep about 1/2 tbsp oil to saute chopped garlic and shallots until fragrant.Â  Pour in water/stock and bring to boil for several minutes or until soft is aromatic.Add in seasoning to taste [can prepare the soup base before meal time until this step].Â Just before serving, bring soup to a rolling boil, then add in vegetables and cook for about 2-3 minutes.Â Â Â  Add in wolfberry.Sprinkle fried silver bait on top before serving soup hot.I'm submitting this post to The soup kitchen monthly blogger eventÂ @ The Spanish Wok:The Soup Kitchen by Debs.

title: Lipton Tea Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: I tried making this bread basing on the idea of Green Tea Loaf Bread.Â  Honestly, my friend and I do not prefer the green tea flavour the last time when I baked my Green Tea Loaf Bread.Â  I have baked chiffon cake using Lipton Tea and it turns out well, so perhaps it may be good for loaf bread too.Result - a good loaf bread which is soft, fluffy and moist.Â Â  The tea flavour is mild but has nice brownish colour.Ingredients for Overnight Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour3 - 3.5 tsp instant yeast200 - 250 ml water  Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof  for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing  and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before  adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour3 tbsp sugar1 tspÂ  salt1 egg 3 Lipton Tea sachets [remove tea bags] mix with 2 tbsp milk powder and 100 ml hot water - leave to cool before use60 gm butterÂ Add all the ingredients [except butter] to the overnight dough. Â Knead until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Knead a further 5-10 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reach the rim of the baking tin. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make smaller loaves].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.I'm submitting this post to Alphabakes August 2012 theme 'T' hosted byÂ The More Occasional BakeÂ andÂ Caroline Makes.

title: EZ Homemade Carrot and Orange Jam
text: Another easy homemade fruity jam with just a few ingredients.Taste like orange marmalade but definitely not that bitter. Â The brandy enhances the flavour even more.Orange and lemon rindOrange fleshIngredients[makes 2 bottles x 550 gm]Â 700 gm orange flesh - chopped and retained the juices too200 gm carrot - gratedzest and juice of 1 lemonzest of 3 oranges700 ml water400 gm sugar1 tbsp brandy [optional]Boil Â carrot, orange flesh and rind until softSimmer until water has reduced and fruits are softAdd sugar and simmer until jam gels upPrepare the fruits as above. Â Make sure the white pith is removed from the orange and lemon skin [to reduce bitterness]. Â Discard all seeds. Â Place a small saucer in the freezer [this is use to test whether jam is ready].Bring water to boil in a heavy based saucepan. Â Add in Â the grated carrot, orange flesh and lemon rind and boil for 15-20 minutes, then reduce heat to medium. Â Simmer until water is reduced and fruits are soft. Â Stir ocassionally to prevent sticking to base of pan.Add sugarÂ and continue to simmer for about half an hour or more until mixture is thickened. Â Stir occasionally to mix ingredients well and add in brandy when jam is almost okay. Â Simmer until it gels up. Â Place a teaspoon of jam on saucer. Â Leave in fridge for a few minutes and jam should be ready if it forms a mass.Store jam in sterilised airtight bottles. Â Always refrigerate jam as homemade jams are without preservatives.I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Sharon ofÂ Test with Skewerand also sharing this post with Teatime Treats Challenge hosted byÂ What Kate Bakedchiffon cake using carrot and orange jam[recipe here]

title: Dumplings in White Fungus, Dried Apricot Sweet Soup
text: During mid-year of lunar calendar [15th day of 6th lunar month], my mum will prepare glutinous rice balls in sweet, ginger soup for prayers. Â  Â This year, she didn't make this because my father passed away and it is believed that the immediate family is not supposed to do certain things [like making 'kuih ee'] before one year has passed. Â But she told me as a married daughter, I can make glutinous rice balls from my home for her. Â In fact, if according to tradition, relatives and friends will cook glutinous rice dumplings and bring them to the bereaved family during such times [first year].Instead of preparing the usual 'kuih ee', I prepared a sweet dessert and add in the glutinous rice balls Â which I made in just 2 colours. Ingredients for Sweet Soup40 gm [about 10] dried apricots - sliced15 red dates3 honey dates20 gm white fungus [2 florets] - soaked and broken into small pieces1.5 litre water100 gm rock sugar to taste2-3 screwpine [pandan] leaves - knottedBoil white fungus in water over medium heat until soft. Â Add in red dates and honey dates. Â Boil for about 10 minutes.Add in rock sugar and pandan leaves. Â Boil for about 10 minutes.Lastly add in dried apricots. Â Boil for several minutes. Â Off fire. Â Serve hot or warm with cooked glutinous rice balls [tang yuan or 'kuih ee'].Ingredients for Glutinous Rice Balls/Tang Yuan/Kuih Ee200 gm glutinous rice flour20 gm tapioca flour170 - 180 ml water20 gm shorteninga drop of yellow food colouringMix both flours with water and knead until soft. Â Add in shortening and continue to knead until soft, pliable and smooth. Â Divide into 2 equal portions. Â Keep one portion plain and add yellow colouring to the other portion. Â Knead the yellow portion until the colour is well blended. Â Set aside to rest for 15 minutes.Break dough into small bits [according to own preference] and roll into small balls. Â Place them on a tray.Meanwhile, boil a pot of water to cook rice balls. Â The rice balls will float to the surface when cooked. Â Remove rice balls with a serrated ladle into a basin of cold water for a few minutes. Â Transfer cooled rice balls with a serrated ladle into sweet soup before serving.I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian MondayÂ hosted by Sharon at Test with Skewer.

title: Mini Char Siew Paus [Sponge Dough Method]
text: The palm sugar char siew filling was simple to prepare and yet so tasty for my baked sweet buns. Â Thought it would be good for steamed paus, too. Â  I love using sponge dough method for my Â flour dough which I believe it yields bread or paus that stay soft for longer time.The original recipe is from Lily NgÂ [Tien Tsin Pau]. Â Since I was planning to make small paus, I used only half the quantity. Â With this portion I made 20 small paus. Â For the palm sugar char siew fillingÂ [please refer here].Ingredients[makes 20 paus]Ingredients for Sponge Dough200 gm all purpose flour [remove 2 tbsp and replace with 2 tbsp wheat starch/tung mein flour]3/4 tsp instant yeast120 - 150 ml water Mix all ingredients in a mixing bowl until soft and smooth. Â Cover and leave aside to rise for 40 minutes.Sponge DoughPau DoughIngredients for Pau Dough50 Â gm all purpose flour [remove 1/2 tbsp and replace with 1/2 tbsp wheat starch]3/4 tsp double action baking powder1.5 tbsp castor sugar1/2 tsp shorteningMix all the pau dough ingredients [except the shortening] to the sponge dough. Â  Knead to mix from low speed to medium speed until soft and smooth. Â Add in shortening.Knead well until dough is soft and pliable. Â Shape into a ball and cover to rise for 20 minutes or double in size.Â  Dough weighs about 400 gm.Punch out dough and roll into a log. Â Cut into equal portions [about 20 gm]. Â Roll out all portions into circles. Â Then use each circle to wrap prepared filling. Â Shape into pau and seal the edges well. Â Do the same for the remaining dough. Let rise for a further 20 minutes.Meanwhile, bring water to a rolling boil. Â Steam paus for 12-15 minutes. Â Off fire and leave paus in the steaming tray for 2-3 minutes before uncovering [this is to prevent wrinkle skin].Note:The pau skin doesn't look all that white probably because I used unbleached all purpose flour.Â  May be different if I were to use pau flour [Hong Kong flour].

title: Palm Sugar Char Siew [Version 2]
text: Told my mum about Char Siew with palm sugar which I have made.  She wasn't very convinced that it tasted good.  I shared the idea with my neigbhour who tried it [recipe from Table for 2 or more] and her family loves it.Â My mum has some pork belly in the fridge, she said she would try but will add some other char siew ingredients just in case the family members  find it different.So here is her version of marinating and I helped her to cook.  Wow!, it is a hit with the children in the house.  All finished up with no leftovers.... It was delicious and yum, yum.Ingredients600 gm pork belly Â [4 inches in length and about 1/2 inch thick slices]1 tsp 5 spice powder [good quality type]1/2 tsp pepper1 tsp salt2 tbsp soy sauce1-2 tsp dark soy sauce1 pandan leave - knotted80 gm palm sugar1/2 tbsp of rose wine [mei hua lou]enough water to cover meatMarinate meat slices with all ingredients [except palm sugar and rose wine] for at least 1/2 an hour or several hours.Put all ingredients [except palm sugar] in a wok. Â Add in enough water to cover the meat [more if you like to have some gravy]. Â Bring it to a boil then lower heat Â and cover wok to simmer for 10-15 minutes. Â Turn over meat slices and boil for a further 10-15 minutes or until the meat is almost tender.Remove lid and add in palm sugar and continue to boil until gravy is reduced and thick like honey.Keep stirring to prevent meat getting burnt.Dish out to cool before cutting to serve Â with sliced cucumber and white rice.

title: Steamed Red Skin Buns - Mi Koo [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Today, I need to make some of these buns as offering for ancestral worship [my father in-law's 4th anniversary]. Â  I was wondering how these buns will be like if I were to use the sponge dough method which usually yields very soft buns. Â The buns rose beautifully and indeed very soft even on the third day. Â I didn't manage to take photos of the inside as all were given to my hubby's siblings. Â The ingredients are exactly the same as in my previous postingÂ [mi koo recipe here]Â and the method is as below.Ingredients for Sponge Dough[makes 8 pieces]450 gm plain flour - sifted1.5 tbsp instant yeast250 ml waterÂ Mix all the ingredients into a soft dough.Â  Cover to proof for 1-2 hours.Ingredients for Bun Dough150 gm plain flour - sift together with baking powder1 heaped tsp double action baking powder150 gm castor sugar1/4 tsp salt2-3 tbsp coconut milk1 heaped tbsp vegetable shortening1 tsp rose pink colouring mix with 100 ml water for brushing bun on skin8 pieces of greased proof or parchment paper [3 inches x 5 inches]Mix bun dough ingredients [except shortening] to sponge dough until well combined. Â  Knead until soft and smooth, then add in shortening.Â  Continue to knead until dough is smooth and pliable.Â  Shape dough into a round ball. Â Cover to proof for 30 minutes or until double in size.Remove dough onto a floured board.Â  Punch down dough to release air then roll out into a long log and cut into 8 equal pieces [about 150 gm/piece]. Form each piece into a smooth round ball then press roll from the centre to form an oblong shape dough. Put dough onto a piece of paper. Complete the same for the rest. Leave to proof till double in size [about 30 minutes]. Before steaming, brush dough with rose coloured [pink] water.Heat enough water on high heat in wok. When water is boiling, put steamer [I use 2 x 14" bamboo steamer] over the water and steamed for 20 minutes. Off heat and leave steamed buns in steamer [covered] for about 3 minutes before uncovering to remove buns to cool on rack. The purpose is to get a smooth skin bun. If using other steamers be careful of water vapour that may drop onto the buns.Serve buns warm with a hot beverage.Proofed buns before steamingNote:These buns can be:stored in plastic bag and kept in the freezer for months. Â Just thaw to room temperature and steam for 10 minutes before serving orsliced and spread with butter orfried with beaten egg like french toast orwrap with sliced roast pork.

title: Herbal Chicken Soup
text: Remember all those strong smelling concoctions that mum painstakingly double-boiled from strange herbs that came in brown paper-wrapped packages? Â Some were sweet, others bitter but all were served up with the intention to keep us healthy. Â Here is one that I prepare to enjoy in the hope to gain some health benefits, lol.Ingredients[serves 2]2 large chicken thighs - skin removed and cut into 2-3 pieces each 700 ml watersalt and light soy sauce to tasteHerbal Ingredients - rinse2 pieces wai san slices3-4 pieces dong quai slices5-6 pieces dong shen [1" length]some yok choksome hoi chok3-4 pieces chuan xiong Â slices3-4 pieces red dates3-4 pieces dried longan1 tbsp wolf berries [kei chee]Blanch chicken thigh in hot water for a few seconds. Â Drain and rinse. Â Set aside.Bring water to a boil and add in Â all herbal ingredients [except chinese wolfberry]. Â Boil for a minute and then simmer for 10 minutes until fragrant and aromatic.Add in chicken thighs to cook for another 5-10 minutes or until chicken is tender. Â Add in the wolfberries.Add salt and light soy sauce to taste.Â Serve soup hot.Health benefits of the following herbs:Dong Quai [Angelica Root]Â - Â This 'heaty' herb nourishes the blood [excellent blood tonic], heart, liver and spleen. Â An excellent herb for those who are anemic [treats iron deficiency and anemia] and those with menstrual problems. Â Balances estrogen levels, reducing anxiety, combat stress and promotes relaxation. Â Generally used in savoury brews.Â [read here for more information]Kei Chee [Chinese Wolfberry] - Nourishes the lungs, kidneys and liver. Â Also good for the eyes, lower back and blood circulation. Â Mostly used in savoury soups. Â Goes well with chicken.Chuan Xiong [Szechuan Lovage Rhizome] - Activates and warms the blood and Qi. Â Good for the liver, gall bladder and heart. Â Used to treat headaches, skin problems and menstrual problems. Â Add to savoury brews.Yok Chok [Solomon's Seal] - A cooling herb for the stomach and lungs. Expels wind and has an overall calming effect. Â Relaxes stiff and cramped muscles. Â Can be used in both sweet and savoury brews.Hung Choe [Red dates] - A tonic for the stomach and spleen. Â Balances the properties of other herbs. Â  Â  Â  Recommended for those who feel tired and weak. Â Can be added to most soups and drinks.Leng Geng [Dried Longan] - Â It is added for sweetness and useful in preventing hair loss and hair greying.I'm submitting this post to The soup kitchen monthly blogger eventÂ @ The Spanish Wok:The Soup Kitchen by Debs. I'm linking this post toÂ September Cooking With Herbs Blog ChallengeÂ hosted byÂ Lavender and Lovage

title: Happy Home Baking: Chocolate Sponge Loaf
text: Here again a simple sponge cake recipe that yields moist and tender cake from Happy Home Baking.Â  It's an easy to bake cake and I don't mind baking this cake again for I like its chocolaty taste.Thanks to Happy Home Baking, for the original recipe and write up of this cake, please refer to Happy Home Baking: simplicity.Ingredients [loaf pan size 19cm x 9cm x 7cm]Dry Ingredients - sifted together 3 times - set aside80 gm cake flour20 gm cocoa powder [used good quality cocoa powder]1/2 tsp baking powder1/8 tsp baking soda1/4 tsp saltLiquid Ingredients - combine together - set aside50 ml vegetable oil50 ml natural plain yoghurt [room temperature]1 1/2 tsp vanilla essence2Â  large eggs, room temperature90 gm caster sugarLine loaf pan with foil and parchment paper.Â  Preheat oven at 170 degrees C.Whisk eggs and sugar in a mixing bowl on high speed [I used Kenwood Mixer speed 5] until the batter is triple in volume, thickens and leaves a ribbon-like trail when the paddle is lifted up [takes about 5 minutes].Â  Turn to low speed [speed 2-3] for another 1 minute to stabilise the air bubbles in the batter.Sift over the flour mixture into the batter in 3 separate additions.Â  Use a spatula to gently fold in the flour until well blended with each addition.Â Â  TAKE CARE NOT TO DEFLATE THE BATTER.Remove some batter into another mixing bowl.Â  Add in the liquid ingredients.Â  Mix with a spatula until well blended.Â  Add this mixture to the rest of egg/sugar batter.Â  Fold gently with spatula until well blended.Pour batter into loaf pan, tap the pan on tabletop a few times to release any trapped air bubbles in the batter.Bake in preheated oven for 25-30 minutes or until a skewer inserted in the centre of cake comes out fairly clean.Â  DO NOT OVER BAKE.Remove cake and unmould to cool completely on wire rack.

title: Plain Flour Carrot Loaf [Straight Dough Method]
text: You can baked this bread using all purpose flour if you happen to run short of bread flour.Â  This bread turns out well like my previous baking of pumpkin buns [recipe here].Â  The bread texture is goodÂ  - soft and moist even though I baked it as a loaf bread. Â Ingredients[bake in loaf pan size 21cm x 9cm x 7cm]300 gm plain flour1 tbsp skimmed milk powder1/2 tsp salt30 gm sugar [1 used 2 level tbsp]1 small egg150 gm grated carrot - squeezed out juice and add water to get 150 ml carrot juice2 tsp yeast1 tbsp butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter and water] on slow speed to combine. Â Gradually add in carrot juice/water [may not use all] and continue kneading until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes to get to window pane stage.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 15 minutes or until double in size. [Can prepare dough up to this stage - place dough in an airtight container or tied up plastic bag and keep in the refrigerator for 1 day before use. Â Safe time and bread can be ready in a shorter time whenever you feel like having freshly baked bread for breakfast. Â  Thaw dough to room temperature before use].Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 4 pieces of equal weight. Â Round up into a ball. Â  Roll each piece into a small rectangle, fold into thirds, then again roll flat into a rectangle.Â  Roll up tightly into a swiss roll. Â  Place on baking tin.Â  Finish doing the same for the other 3 pieces.Leave dough in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour].Â Remove from oven to preheat oven to 180 degrees C for 10 minutes.Then bake loaf bread in preheated oven for 25 minutes. Â Remove and cool onÂ wire rack.Note:This dough can be used to bake buns too.I'm sharing this post with Bake Your Own Bread viaÂ girlichef.

title: Char Siew Sweet Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: For these Char Siew Buns, I'm using the sweet dough [sponge dough method] and palm sugar char siew as filling.Â  You can also use straight dough method to make the bun dough.The bun texture is very fine and soft even on the next day. Â It is very similar to those small buns that are served with chicken chops at western food outlets.Ingredients for the buns-Sponge Dough Method[makes Â 16Â  buns]Step 1 - Ingredients100 gm plain flour150 gm bread flour [you can replace plain flour and use all 250 gm bread flour]4 tsp instant yeast [I used 3 tsp]130-150 mlÂ  cold waterMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour. Â Knead to form a smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients250 gm bread flour100 gm sugar [I used 80 gm]1 tbsp milk powder 1 tsp salt1 small egg [20 gm] - can used large egg and set aside some for egg glaze130 ml cold water50 gm butterEgg glaze and toasted sesame seedsFilling -Â  palm sugar char siewÂ [recipe here]Â  Add all Step 2 ingredients Â [except butter] to dough from Step 1. Â Knead from low speed until well combined. Â Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes]. Â Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage [Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate. Â  Thaw to room temperature before using. Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only]. ORShape dough into a ball. Â Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Â Â  Punch down and divide dough into 16 portions of equal weight.Â  Shape dough into round balls.Roll out each ball and flatten dough, place a spoonful or more of char siew filling in the centre.Â  Gather up the seam and seal well. Â  Place bun on paper casing, seam side down on baking tray.Â  Finish shaping all the buns.Leave to rise for 30-45 minutes or until double in size. Â Brush with egg/milk glaze. Sprinkle with sesame seeds.Baked in preheated oven at 190 degrees [middle shelf]Â  for 12-15 minutes or until golden.Â  Brush buns with some melted butter [can skip this step if you do not want the buns to be oily]Â Remove and leave to cool on rack or serve.I'm submitting this to Bake Your Own Bread hosted by girlichef.

title: Palm Sugar Char Siew [Version 1]
text: This char siew recipe is adapted from Wendy [recipe here].Â  I used pork tenderlion for this char siew [only made half the portion] which I will be using as filling for my Char Siew Sweet Buns.Â  Ingredients300 gm pork tenderlion [about 1/2 inch thick slices] or pork belly1/2 tsp salt1 tbsp soy sauce1 pandan leave - knotted40 gm palm sugarenough water to cover meatPut all ingredients [except palm sugar] in a heavy based sauce pot.Â  Bring it to a boil then lower heat to simmer for 10-15 minutes with lid on.Â  Turn over meat slices and boil for a further 10-15 minutes or until the meat is almost tender. Remove lid and add in palm sugar and continue to boil until gravy is reduced and thick like honey.Keep stirring to prevent meat getting burnt.Dish out to cool before cutting to serve or cut into small pieces to make char siew filling.Sauce Ingredients for Char Siew Filling for Buns2-3 shallots - flatten and chopped1/2 tbsp oil80 ml water1/2 tbsp each of tapioca flour and cornstarch1 tsp plain flour1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp rose wine [mei hua lou]2 stalks spring onion - chopped small pieces2 tbsp toasted sesame seeds Fry shallots in oil until aromatic.Â  Add in diced char siew and all the sauce ingredients [except the 3 types of flour].Â  Stir to mix ingredients well.Â  Add in water.Bring it to a boil and lower heat to simmer for 5-10 minutes.Â  Add in all the flour to thicken. Set aside to cool completely before adding chopped spring onions and sesame seeds.Refrigerate filling before use.Note:This filling can be used for steamed baos too.

title: Lemon SoufflÃ© Cake [2nd Attempt]
text: My first attempt to bake this cake was not that satisfactory but the taste was perfect. So I tried this time following the actual baking method and the cake was lovely, lovely, lovely. Â If you are interested to bake this cake, please follow this recipe and method. Â I will definitely bake this cake again and again cos' it is a low gluten cake. Â A special thanks to Happy Flour for her guidance and advice on the ingredients used. Â Happy Flour, I made it!!!!Ingredients3 egg yolk1/2 egg (about 30g)15 gm sugar [I used 1 tbsp]1/4 tsp salt25 ml lemon juice25 ml milk1 tsp lemon zest35 ml vegetable oil [IÂ  used 2 tbsp]40 gm cake flourÂ  - sifted - set aside3 egg white55 gm sugar [used 3 tbsp]1/4 tsp cream of tartarLine base of a 7" square tin with grease proof paper and wrap it with tin foil. Â  Â [This time, I used a 7" loose base round baking tin.] Â Place it in a bigger square baking tin.Â  Preheat oven to 150 degrees C.Mix lemon juice, milk, lemon zest and oilÂ  together.Use a hand whisk mix egg yolks, half egg, sugar and salt together.Add in liquid mixture and whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites and cream of tartar till frothy. Â  Add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk on medium speed until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/4 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Scoop out 1/3 of mixture, add a little [1-2 drops] of green colouring, fold until combined.Pour 1/3 of plain batter into prepared cake tin, followed by green batter then again the plain batter. Â Swirl the batter to create a marble effect [I didn't really swirl the batter]. Â Place it in the bigger cake tin filled with hot water.Steam-bake cake in a preheated oven at 150 C for 60 minutes [without covering with foil.Â Â [Note: If covering cake with foil, bake at 180 degrees C forÂ  45 minutes, after 45 minutes, remove foil and bake a further 10 minutes].**Remove cake at once from tin. cool it on a wire rack and all paper linings otherwise the cake base and sides may be moist.Note** Next time I bake this cake, I try this baking method.I'm submitting this post  to  July Tea Time Treats Challenge - Cake Stall Cakes   hosted byLavender and Lovage  and  What Kate Baked

title: Lemon SoufflÃ© Cake [1st Attempt]
text: After baking the Orange Souffle CakeÂ and Chocolate Souffle CakeÂ which I like so much, I again tried with lemon flavour.Â  The flavour of this cake is very refreshing and the texture is soft, cottony and moist.Â The only mistake I made was I covered the top with foil but forgotten to extend the baking time for another 10 minutes.Â  So the top was a little moist and difficult to handle.Â  I then grilled it for about 5-10 minutes to make it easier for slicing, the cake was saved. Â  Don't follow this way, unless you prefer a pale crust. Â  Â  Next time, I will try to bake at 180 degrees C for 45 minutes if I'm covering it with foil.Ingredients3         egg yolk1/2       egg (about 30g)15 gm       sugar [I used 1 tbsp]1/4 tsp    salt25 ml lemon juice25 ml milk1 tsp      lemon zest35 ml vegetable oil [IÂ  used 1 1/2 tbsp]40 gm       cake flourÂ      - sifted - set aside3         egg white55 gm       sugar [used 3 tbsp]1/4 tsp    cream of tartarLine base of a 7" square tin [use loose bottom pan] with grease proof paper and wrap it with tin foil.Â  Place it in a bigger square baking tin.Â Preheat oven to 150 degrees C.Mix lemon juice, milk, lemon zest and oilÂ  together.Use a hand whisk mix egg yolks, half egg, sugar and salt together.Add in liquid mixture and whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites and cream of tartar till frothy. Â  Add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk on medium speed until soft peaks formed. Fold in 1/4 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Scoop out 1/3 of mixture, add a little [1-2 drops] of green colouring, fold until combined.Pour 1/3 of plain batter into prepared cake tin, followed by green batter then again the plain batter.Â  Place it in the bigger cake tin filled with hot water.Steam-bake cake in a preheated oven at 150 C for 55-60 minutes [without covering with foil.Â  [If covering cake with foil, bake at 180 degrees C forÂ  45 minutes, after 45 minutes, remove foil and bake a further 10 minutes].Remove cake at once from tin, discard all paper linings [to prevent vapour when cooling] and cool it on a wire rack.

title: Fried Rice With Salted Fish
text: One more dish using the salted fish made by my hubby from his fishing trip.Â  This time I fried rice with the salted fish meat with smoked ham.Â  I loved to add some vegetables to my fried rice for an easy complete weekend meal.Â IngredientsÂ [serves 2]1 cup basmathi rice - steamed to cook for 25 minutes and cooled [I seldom has leftover rice at home]2-3 tbsp diced salted fish meatÂ 1-2 pieces smoked ham [or any other ham] - cut small cubes1 egg - lightly beaten with a pinch of salt and 1/2 tsp shaoxing wine [can use 2 eggs]romaine lettuces - cut shredssome carrot shredssome chopped garlic spring onion - cut small pieces2-3 tbsp oil2-3 tbsp light soy sauce to tasteÂ  dash of msg and pepper to tasteHeat 2 tbsp oil in wok on medium low fire to fry salted fish until aromatic and golden.Â  Removed.Using the same oil, saute garlic until aromatic, add in ham, carrots and rice.Â  Stir to mix well and add in seasoning to taste.Â Â Push rice aside.Â  Add in 1 tbsp oil, pour in the egg.Â  Bring the rice to mix.Â  Fry until rice is light, then add in vegetables and fried salted fish.Â  Stir fry to mix well and vegetables are cooked.Â  Lastly add in the spring onions.Off fire and dish out on serving plate, garnish with extra salted fish.Â  Serve with sambal belacan or cut red chillies.Click here for other Fried Rice Recipes

title: Cornet Shaped Carrot Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Came across this recipe sometime ago but could'nt bake these buns as I do not have the cornet moulds. On my last shopping trip, I noticed these cornet moulds among the other baking items up for sale for the Hari Raya festive season.Â  There were so many newÂ  baking/cooking utensils/items on sale at the departmental stores but I have to discipline myself not to buy too many unnecessary items no matter how tempting they are.Â  Being a rather 'disciplined person', hehe, I bought only these moulds and they were cheap for a set of 6 pieces [RM 3.90/set] and hopefully they are going to useful....in my kitchen.First I baked these buns then I filled them with some tuna mayo fillings just before serving.Â  I supposed they can be stuffed with many other types of fillings [either sweet or savoury].Â  May be my god daughter would love it with ice cream [she loves having bread with ice cream].Â  This recipe yieldsÂ  16 buns.Â  The buns were soft, fluffy and moist and can easily be dislodged from the moulds.Ingredients for the BunsStep 1 - Sponge Dough100 gm bread flour100 gm plain flour1.5 tsp instant yeast130 ml waterMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour.Â  Knead to form a soft and smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Bread Dough200 gm bread flour2 tbsp sugar1 tsp salt130 gm grated carrot40 gm butterAdd all Step 2 ingredientsÂ  [except butter] to dough from Step 1.Â  Knead from low speed until well combined.Â  Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes].Â  Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage [Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate.Â Â  Thaw to room temperature before using.Â Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only].Shape dough into a ball.Â  Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down and divide dough in 16 pieces. Shape dough into round balls.Â  Flatten each ball, roll up and roll dough into a 12" rope.Â  Thin out at one end.Coil the dough around a lightly greased cornet shape mould.Â  Place on a lightly greased baking tray. Â  Do the same for the rest of the dough.Â  Leave to rise for 40-50 minutes or until 2 times in size.Â Before baking, brush with beaten egg.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 10-12 minutes or until golden.Leave to cool on rack, remove mould and fill cornet buns with prepared filling before serving.Potato and Tuna Mayo Bun Filling Ingredients for filling1 tin tuna2 hard boiled eggs - chopped1 potato - boiled/steamed till soft - diced3 tbsp mayonnaiseMix the first 3 ingredients together then add in mayonnaise.Â  Refrigerate if not using immediately.I'm sharing this bread recipe with Bake Your Own Bread [BYOB] viaÂ girlichef

title: MY Penang Lor Mee
text: Penang Lor Mee is a hawker's food usually available at hawker's stalls that sell the popular Penang Prawn Noodles [aka Hokkien Mee or Har Mee].Basically it is blanched yellow noodles with beansprouts and water convuvolous top withÂ  soy sauce braised meat and eggs.Â  Thick brownish 5 spice flavoured gravy is scooped over the noodles and serve with plain chilli sauce and garlic/vinegar sauce.Â  Some other ingredients such as pork skin, pork small intestines,pork ribs andÂ  chicken feet, can also be added if cooking in bigger quantitiesThis is the recipe with simple ingredients for Penang Lor Mee.Ingredients[makes 3-4 bowls]200 gm yellow noodles150 gm rice vermicelli [meehoon]150 gm beansprouts150 gm of water convuvolous [kangkong] - washed and cut into 3 cm lengths [I like more vege]2 tbsp of fried shallots200 gm pork meat [keep whole]2 hard boiled eggs - shell removed2 tbsp chilli boh/paste mixed with 2 tbsp hot watergarlic and vinegar sauce *Ingredients for the stock/gravyÂ [taste to adjust seasoning]700 ml water or stock1 star anise1 heaped tsp 5 spice powder1 1/2 tsp salt2 tsp sugar 3 tsp light soy sauce1/4 tsp msg2 tsp dark soy sauce [more is colour is light]1/2 tsp pepper2 - 3 tbsp cornstarchÂ  mix with 2 tbsp water for thickening1 egg - lightly beatenBoil water is a stock pot.Â  Add in all the ingredients and bring to boil on high heat for 10-15 minutes to bring out the flavours of the 5 spice powder and star anise.Â  Add in the hard boiled eggs and meat.Â  Lower heat to simmer for 15-20 minutes or until meat is cooked.Â  Dish out the eggs and meat and set aside to cool before slicing.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Bring stock to a rolling boil, then stir in the cornflour mix to thicken the soup.Â  Let it boil for a few seconds.Â  Turn off heat immediately.Â  Pour in egg in a circular pattern and stir lightly.Â Double-boil gravy to keep warm/hot or just reheat to hot before serving noodles.How to serve noodlesSlice meat and cut eggs into wedges. Set aside.Bring a pot of water to boil.Â  Blanch yellow noodles, meehoon, beansprouts and kangkong to cook [1 bowl portion at a time].Â  Drain off water.Â  Place noodles in a serving bowl.Top noodles with some sliced meat and eggs.Â  Use a ladle to scoop gravy over ingredients.Sprinkle fried shallots and serve with a chilli sauce and garlic/vinegar sauce.How to prepare garlic and vinegar sauceÂ 75 gm garlic - remove skin1 tbsp sugar1 tbsp white vinegar2 tbsp boiling waterBlend garlic in a blender, then add in the remaining ingredients.Â  Stir to mix well.Can store leftovers in a glass container and refrigerate for other uses, too. I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Suresh ofÂ 3 hungry tummies

title: Fried Soy Bean Noodles [Tau Chiam Noodles]
text: A very Asian cuisine and a convenient one-dish meal for the family for weekend lunch or dinner.Info from Eating Pleasure on Soy Bean Noodles "Soy bean noodles is called tau chiam in Hokkien. It's made of soy bean and wheat.  Hence, the Protein value is higher than the normal noodles, and it's low in carbo too. It's good for diabetes patient who loves noodles. The texture is similar to "pan mee" ????."At home, this noodle is usually cooked into a thick soup with yam, dried prawns, meat and mushrooms.Â  The stock is boiled and the noodles added.Â  The soup becomes thick by the time the noodles are cooked and also because of the yam. Add more stock if you preferred the soup to be less thick.Â  A very traditional way [kochabi] and is quite acceptable by all in the family. I'll cook the soup version next time.Anyway, this time, I'm frying it with some other ingredients.Â  Ingredients[serves 2-3]200 gm soy bean noodles [tau chiam] - blanched in boiling water to soften50 gm meat - sliced [optional] 70 gm prawns - shelled3 dried mushrooms - soaked and shredded1 small red carrot - shredded50 gm cabbage - shredded [I used iceberg lettuce]50 gm chives or chives flower - cut 3 cm lengths2 tsp chopped garlic2 tbsp oil1 tbsp sesame oilcut red chillies in soy sauce Seasoning [combined]1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp soy saucedash of msg and pepper to taste1/2 tsp sugar1 cup waterBlanched noodles in boiling water to cook until al dente.Â  Remove and drain in colander [mix with some sesame oil].Heat oil in wok, fry garlic until aromatic.Â  Add in prawns, meat and mushrooms to fry, then add in carrots.Â  Stir fry well and add in blanched noodles and seasoning.Â  Stir fry and toss noodles to combine all ingredients.Add in water, chives and lettuce.Â  Stir fry to combine ingredients well and cooked until gravy is slightly thickened.Dish out and serve immediately with cut chillies.NoteÂ If using cabbage, add in when adding carrotsNot necessary to have all the above ingredients, any combination is alright.Â  I added crabmeat too.

title: Potato Sesame Seed Buns [Straight Dough Method]
text: This é©¬é“ƒè–¯é¢åŒ… Potato Bread recipe was from Cathy's blogÂ [details here] which was adapted and modify from 'The Second Book of Baking for Beginners' by Carol.Â  I used to bake potato buns from potato flakes and has never tried using boiled potato [mashed].Quite an easy to follow recipe but most important is, it yields really soft and moist buns.Â  However, I made them round and coat them with toasted sesame seeds which are rather similar to those sold at Adventist Hospital Bakery.Â  There, the buns were baked in a cluster of 9 buns.Â  The buns were covered with lots of sesame seeds, very soft and moist.Â  Think this is also a healthy bun cos' it isn't sweet, salty or oily.Ingredients[makes 12 buns]270 gm bread flour30 gm plain flour3 gm bread improver [I omit]150 gm mashed potato [boiled with water till soft and mashed]20 gm caster sugar [I used 1 1/2 tbsp]1 tsp instant yeast1/4 tsp salt150 ml milk30 gm butter [I used 1 tbsp]enough lightly toasted sesame seeds Butter, cut into thin stripsgranulated sugar - optionalDough - Combine all ingredients together (except butter) in a mixer and knead until a soft dough is formed [about 10-12 minutes]. Â Â  Add in butter and continue to knead until the dough is soft, smooth and elastic.Â  This takes about 10-15 minutes from low speed to medium high speed.Â  The dough should not stick to the fingers when touch or reach window pane stage.Leave to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size.Â  Punch down dough. Divide the dough into 12 equal portions. Â  Roll dough into round balls.Â  Wet them with some water, then coat it with sesame seeds.Â  Place on foil cupcake cases [buns will not stick to foil cases after baking].Proof the dough forÂ  45minutes or until double in size.Use a knife to make a slit in the middle of the doughÂ  and put one strip of the butter on top.Â  Sprinkle with some granulated sugar [for better effect, brush dough with egg glaze or milk before slitting the buns].Bake in a preheated oven at 190 degrees C for 15 minutes or until golden.Â  Remove to cool on wire rack.I'm sharing this post via BYOB [Bake Your Own Bread] hosted by Girlichef.

title: Fuchow Fish Maw Soup
text: This soup has quite a number of ingredients but preparation is not that difficult.Â  The soup tastes sourish sweet and not spicy at all even though chilli is added.Â Ingredients50 - 100 gm fried fish maw - soaked until soft, cut into bite size pieces1 tbsp chopped coriander leaves Ingredients for Meat and Prawn Balls100 gm shelled prawns - finely chopped100 gm meat or chicken fillet - finely choppedmarinate with some pepper, salt, sugar, sesame oil and cornflour.Â  Mix well and refrigerate while you prepare the other ingredients.Ingredients for Soup Stock 1 tsp each of chopped garlic, shallots and ginger1/2 tsp chilli boh/paste [optional]1/2 tbsp oil700 ml chicken stock or water3 tbsp tomato sauce2 tbsp chilli sauce1/4 tsp sugar1/2 tsp salt to taste [if using water]1 tsp chicken stock granules a dash of pepper1-2 tbsp lime juice1 tbsp cornstarch + 1 tbsp water for thickeningHeat oil in pot to saute chopped ingredients and chilli paste until aromatic.Â  Add in stock/water.Â  Bring it to a rolling boil. add in fish maw to cook.Â Â Scoop prawn and meat ball mixture into balls with a wet metal spoon into boiling soup to cook for 1-2 minutes.Â  Add in all the seasoning and simmer for a few minutes.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Stir in thickening.Â  Once it comes to a quick boil, dish out and garnish wi NoteAfter thickening the soup, you can stir in 1 beaten egg before serving.

title: Milk Bread Loaf [Straight Dough Method]
text: Milk bread slice with butter and homemade Kiwi JamThis milk loaf recipe wasÂ  from Blessed Homemaker and her original source was from Happy Home Baking.Â  Anyway, this is the recipe which I used to bake 2 loaves of bread [420gm each] using just milk.Â  As usual, I made double as I'm sharing with my neighbour.Â  Just halve the quantity if you wish to make only a loaf.This bread is soft, light and moist.Â  Nice bread.Â  The dough is not sticky, easy to handle.If I'm not wrong, this dough recipe can also be used to make buns [recipe here].Ingredients for Milk LoafÂ [makes 2 loaves x 420 gm]500 gm bread flour1/4 tsp salt 3 tbsp sugar [about 50 gm]1 small egg260 ml UHT milk2 tsp yeast1 tbsp butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  ThenÂ  continue kneadingon medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes to get to window pane stage or smooth, elastic and dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 1 hour or double in size [usually is less than 1 hour].Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 2 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â Place theÂ  loaves in greased Pullman's tins.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour]. Â Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 35-40 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack. Â I'm submitting this post to Bake Your Own Bread [BYOB] viaÂ girlichef

title: Banana Walnut Cinnamon Cake
text: I baked this all in one muffin basing on Happy Homebaker's recipe Banana Walnut Cinnamon Cake. Â From her post, I learned several things, so this cake became something special to me.You can bake them as muffins [12 ] or a cake.Making the cake is a breeze. Â  It's so fast I couldn't believe it especially when I had all the ingredients ready.The cake is really good - soft, moist and fluffly [even on the next day]I learned from her that by greasing and flouring the sides of the baking tin [I used my brand new loose base round baking tin], the finished cake will give a nice golden crust.Â  Â This is true.Anyway, I had her permission to post her recipe here but I did a little adjustment to suit my taste [less sugar and fats]. Â  Â Since I used a very sweet specie of bananas, Â I reduced the sugar. Â Her choice to use 250 gm of bananas makes the cake soft, moist and I think sweet too. Â Hopefully, it can be a healthier version for us [old folks]. Â I also used the measuring spoons to measure the ingredients instead of weighing.Ingredients[makes one 7" cake] Ingredients A - sifted together150 gm cake flour2 gm ground cinnamon [I used 1/4 tsp]4 gm baking powder [I used 3/4 tsp]2 gm baking soda [I used 1/3 tsp]1 gm salt [I used 1/6 tsp]Ingredients B - whisk to combine2 large eggs80 gm caster sugar [I used 60 gm]Â 70 ml vegetable oil [I used canola oil]Â 1 1/2 tsp vanilla extractÂ 250 gm - about 3-4 medium sized over ripe banana, mashed (original recipe uses 120g)70 gm walnuts, coarsely chopped [reserve 1 tablespoon as toppings] - can substitute with any nuts or dried fruitsÂ Toast chopped walnuts at 150 degrees C for about 8 to 10 minutes, stir in between and make sure walnuts do not get burnt.Line base of a 7" round pan with removable base with parchment paper, grease (with butter) and flour the sides.   Set aside.Â Sieve together cake flour, ground cinnamon, baking powder, baking soda and salt, set aside.Â Place eggs, caster sugar, oil and vanilla extract in a mixing bowl. With a manual whisk, whisk to combine.Â Add mashed banana, whisk to combine.Â Sieve over the flour mixture, with a spatula, fold the mixture until just incorporated. Do not over mix. The batter should appear lumpy.Â Add in chopped walnuts (set aside 1 tablespoon to use as toppings), stir just to combine.Â Pour batter into prepared pan. Tap the pan a few times on work surface to release any trapped air bubbles. Sprinkle the top with the remaining walnuts.Â Bake in pre-heated oven at 175 degrees C for 30-35 minutes or until a tooth pick inserted into the centre comes out clean.Â Remove from oven, leave to cool for 5mins.  Unmould and transfer to wire rack, let cool completely.Â Note from Â HHBRecipe source: adapted from æˆ‘çš„å¹¸ç¦æ‰‹ä½œé¢åŒ…ï¼ŒæŽæˆå®ž

title: Strawberry Yoghurt Chiffon Cake
text: Recipe adapted from Happy Home Baking.Â  Instead of using cranberries, I used dried strawberries from Cameron Highlands.Â  The strawberry aroma and flavour of this cake was very distinct even while baking in the oven.Â  Nice.Â  Only problem was the cake rose very high and cracked. Â  I should have followed Happy Flour's advice to use a bigger pan [22-23 cm].Â  Next time must do it.Here are the ingredients and method. Ingredients[for 8 inch tube pan - best to use a slightly bigger pan]3 egg yolks (use large eggs)25 gm  caster sugar [I used 1 1/2 tbsp]40 ml vegetable oil [I used 3 tbsp]80 gm plain yoghurt [I used strawberry yoghurt]1 tsp lemon juice80 gm cake flour - sifted4 egg whites (use large eggs)55 gm caster sugar [I used 3 tbsp]60 gm dried strawberries - chopped small pieces [some cake flour for dusting]Method from Happy Home Baking Sieve flour and set aside.Â Chop dried strawberries into smaller pieces.Â  Coat with flour and sieve to remove excess flour. Set aside.Place egg yolks in a mixing bowl. With a manual hand whisk, whisk the  yolks a little. Add in sugar and whisk to combine. Add in vegetable oil gradually, whisk to combine.Â Add in yoghurt and lemon juice. Whisk to combine. Sieve over the flour and whisk till the flour is fully incorporated. Do not over mix. Set aside.In a clean, dry mixing bowl, beat egg whites with a handheld electric mixer on low speed until mixture becomes frothy and foamy.Â  Add half of the sugar amount and turn to high speed and beat the mixture. Continue to add in the remaining sugar and beat until the egg whites reaches the soft peak stage.The soft peak stage is reached when the peaks of the whites curl over and droop slightly. The egg whites should appear smooth and glossy. (Do not over beat the whites until stiff, it is better to beat the whites till soft peaks for easy folding with the yolk batter.)Add the beaten egg whites into the egg yolk batter in 3 separate additions, each time folding gently with a spatula until just blended.Add in the prepared dried strawberries. Fold in until just blended Do not over mix. Pour batter into a 17cm tube pan (do not grease the pan). Tap the pan lightly on a table top to get rid of any trapped air bubbles in the batter.Bake in pre-heated oven at 180 degrees C for 30 mins [lower rack], or until a toothpick inserted into the centre comes out clean, when lightly pressed the cake will spring back. Invert the pan immediately and let cool completely before unmould. To remove the cake from the pan, run a thin-bladed knife around the inside of the pan and the center core. Release the cake and run the knife along the base of the pan to remove the cake.

title: Preserved Mustard Green and Tofu Soup [Kiam Cai Tofu Soup]
text: After my successful attempts of brining mustard greens 'kiam chai'Â [recipe here] , so it's time to cook them.Â  This is also one of our favourite soups when we visit the 'Chu Char' stall.Â  A simple version of soup quite similar in taste to the famous 'Kiam Chai Ark' but of course without the duck, pig trotter and less oily.Â  I supposed this is a healthier version and you can also add seafood [prawns, fish fillet and squids etc] according to your preference.Ingredients[serves 2-3]50 gm preserved green mustard [kiam chye] or 1-2 leaves - rinsed, cut 1 inch lengths50 gm meat - sliced thick pieces1 piece tofu - cut into 6 cubes1 tomato - cut wedgessome red carrot slices - optional3 slices ginger1 preserved wet plum [salted plum]700 ml water1 spring onion - cut into 3 cm lengths [add in before serving]Some fried crispy garlic with oil [add in before serving]Seasoning1/2 tsp sugar1/2 tbsp light soy saucea dash of pepper1/2 tsp chicken stock granules Bring water to boil.Â  Add in all ingredients [except tofu] to cook until aromatic.Â  Add in seasoning to taste.Add in tofu to cook.Â  Bring soup to boil again.Add in spring onions and dish out to serve hot with fried crispy garlic oil.Note - you can saute ginger with some oil until aromatic then add in water to boil [I skipped this step cos' I prefer my soup to be less oily] I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Suresh ofÂ 3 hungry tummies

title: Meat Floss Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: I supposed these buns are the simplest to bake even for a novice baker.Â  Just baked the sweet buns in any of the common shapes [round, oval, oblong etc] where you can make a horizontal slit in the centre.Â  Pipe in some moyannaise and fill it up with meat floss.Â  Never thought it could be so simple.Â  Wow! easy, lovely soft and fluffy homemade buns are ready to be served in a jiffy.Â  Better still, I prepared my bun dough a day earlier and refrigerate.Â  I just need to thaw to room temperature the next day, shape it up, proof and baked.Â  Makes buns making so, so easy.These buns were for my cousin's children for Saturday's afternoon tea.Ingredients for the buns-Sponge Dough Method[makes Â 10 Â buns]Step 1 - Ingredients2 tsp instant yeast160-170 ml Â water230 gm bread flourMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour. Â Knead to form a smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients60 gm sugar1/4 tsp salt1 small egg [20 gm] - can used large egg and set aside some for egg glaze25 ml water100 gm bread flour30 gm butterEgg glaze and toasted sesame seedsFilling - enough mayonnaise and meat floss Add all Step 2 ingredients Â [except butter] to dough from Step 1. Â Knead from low speed until well combined. Â Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes]. Â Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage [Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate. Â  Thaw to room temperature before using. Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only]. ORShape dough into a ball. Â Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Â Â  Punch down and divide dough into 10 portions of equal weight.Â  Shape dough into round balls.Roll out each ball and shape into oval shape.Â  Place shaped bun on paper casing on baking tray.Â  Finish shaping all the buns.Leave to rise for 30-45 minutes or until double in size. Â Brush with egg/milk glaze. Sprinkle with sesame seeds.Baked in preheated oven at 190 degrees [middle shelf]Â  for 12-15 minutes or until golden.Remove to cool on rack.Make a horizontal slit in the centre of the baked bun.Â  Pipe in or spread mayonnaise and fill it with meat floss.I'm submitting this post to Bake Your Own Bread [BYOB] viaÂ girlichef

title: EZ Homemade Kiwi Fruit Jam
text: I loved to make my own preserves whenever possible with fruits that are in season.Â  They are fresh and reasonably price too. Â There were lots of fresh Kiwi fruits selling reasonably cheap on my recent shopping trip to the supermarket.Â  Definitely, I was tempted to buy it, some for dessert and some for making jam.Â This Kiwi fruit jam is one of my favourite preserves because of Â its natural flavour, colour and fruity. Â Moreover, it is easy to prepare with just 3 ingredients [kiwi fruit, sugar and lemon juice].Ingredients[makes the quantity as shown in the photo]700 gm kiwi fruit [about 7 fruits] - skinned and chopped in smaller pieces150 ml water1 tbsp lemon juice - to taste200 gm granulated sugarsterilised bottlePlace cut kiwi fruits, lemon juice and water in a heavy based pan. Â Bring it to a boil and lower heat to cook until fruits are softened and water reduced.Add in sugar and continue to simmer. Â Stir occasionally to mix ingredients well. Â In the meantime, place a small saucer in the freezer to chill [for testing if jam is ready]. Â Simmer until it gels up. Â Place a teaspoon of jam on saucer. Â Leave in freezer compartment for a few minutes and jam is ready if it forms a mass.Store in sterilised airtight bottles. Â Always refrigerate jam as homemade jams are without preservatives. Â NoteThis preserve should keep well for at least 3 months refrigerated.Chiffon cake using homemade kiwi fruit jam

title: Oriental Style BBQ Spare Ribs
text: Finally got to try out this lovely dish, BBQ Spare Ribs shared by Cheah of No FrillsÂ [recipe here].Â  It's easy to prepare, yet tasty and good.Â  Really yummy!!! Â  My hubby's first comment was 'Oh, this is good!, even the restaurants don't serve spare ribs as good as this.Â  Can imagine how good I felt? Â  Worth the trouble cooking at home.I only bought 600 gm spare ribs and had to adjust the seasoning a little otherwise please refer to the original recipe.Ingredients600 gm spare ribs- cut into 4 inch lengths4 pips garlic- pressed4Â  tbsp light soya sauce40 gm palm sugar - break into small piecesShaoxing wine to drizzlesome cornflour water forÂ  thickeningtomato slices and lettuce leavesMarinate the spare ribs with the light soya sauce and palm sugar for at least 2 hours [I refrigerate overnight].Put the marinated spare ribs in a sauce pot andÂ  add water just enough to cover the ribs. Â Â  Bring to a boil, cover andÂ simmer on low fire until ribs are tender but still has a bite.Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Place ribs on a foil lined baking tray and grill for 2 minutes on each side [I grilled on top shelf at 250 degrees C].Meanwhile, thicken the sauce with the cornflour mixture to desired consistency, turn off heat and drizzle on some Shaoxing wine.Arrange lettuce leaves on serving plate, top with grilled spare ribs, then ladle on the thickened sauce.Â  Garnished with sliced tomatoes [or zuchini slices if preferred].Â  I served with more lettuce cos' I didn't cook any other vegetable dish.Serve immediately.Â NoteWas so eager to savour this dish that I didn't really concentrate on taking nicer shots of it.Â  Doesn't matter about the pictures, we loved this spare ribs - so tender, flavourful and not oily too.

title: TWISTED PURPLE SWEET POTATO BUNS [GDM]
text: How these buns came about?. Â I prepared the gelatinized dough [GDM] with the intention to bake buns using sardine filling. Â Then I noticed I had some mashed sweet potato left and a savoury split green bean pasteÂ [recipe here]Â which I prepared to use as filling for baking purple sweet potato buns. Â Honestly, I prefer having loaf bread for breakfast rather than buns and I have no intention to bake more buns in a week. Â So, what I did was to use the gelatinized dough ingredients, add in the mashed sweet potato and created these buns which turned out to be so soft, moist and fluffy. Â I didn't glaze them hoping that these buns will maintain its natural purplish colour.I was surprised too that the savoury split green bean pasteÂ [recipe here]Â gave these buns a totally new flavour [sought of like east meets west]. Â  As I was a bit lazy to shape the buns, I just baked them in a baking tray [top photo]. Â Of course you can shape it into any shapes you like [round, oval, cresent etc. it's okay]. Â  I didn't finish baking all the buns at one time. Â As I said I was a bit tired after my morning exercise, so I kept the remaining dough in a plastic bag [tied up] and refrigerate. Â  Maybe I'll finish my baking the next day....Â As the buns were so yummy, there wasn't any left the next day. Â Greatly motivated with the result of the first batch, I baked the rest of the buns [see second and third photos below]. Â They were as lovely and yummy!!!.. Â Noticed the quantity? Â I was able to share with my neighbours, gave some to my mum and some of course for ourselves...Ingredients for Gelatinized Dough100 gm bread flour70 ml hot boiling waterMix together into a rough dough using a pair of chopstick.Â  Cover dough with cling film [I used a plastic airtight container] and leave dough to cool in the fridge for 1 hour and up to 48 hours [2 days].To Prepare Basic Sweet Bread Dough1 portion of the gelatinized dough300 gm bread flour100 gm plain flour80 gm castor sugar20 gm milk powder [I used 1 tbsp skimmed milk powder]1 tbsp yeast1/2 tsp salt1 cold egg200 gm mashed purple sweet potato80-100 ml cold water [I used about 90 ml]60 gm cold butter - cubed [I used 50 gm]egg glaze [I used milk] - I omitMix sweet bread dough ingredients [except butter] with gelatinized dough in a mixer with dough hook.Â  Knead on medium speed for about 10 minutes till soft and smooth [the dough is quite wet but it is alright] then add in butter.Â Continue to knead for another 10 - 15 minutes until dough is soft, smooth and elastic [the dough should be ready if it does not stick to the fingers when touch].Â  Shape into a round ball with floured hands, cover and leave to rest for 15 minutes or until double in size [#].Punch down dough.Â  Divide dough into 3 equal portions [I just estimate].Shape each portion into a round ball, then take a portion, roll on a floured board into rectangular shape about 1/2 cm thickness. Â Spread the fillings all over the dough, roll up tightly like swiss roll. Â Pinch the seam to seal the edges well. Â  Divide the roll up dough into 9 equal portions by twisting it. Â Place the twisted side up on a round baking tray lined with greased proof paper.Â Leave to rise for 45 minutes or until double in size in the oven.Â  Remove them from the ovenÂ  after 45 minutes before preheating oven. Â Bake in preheated oven at Â 200 degrees C [middle shelf] for 12 - 15 minutes. Â  Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately before storing.These pictures were all the buns which I made from this portion of ingredients using the gelatinized Â dough method.Here are the pictures that showed how I shaped some of these buns. Braided  bunsÂ  Rolled slit bunsÂ These were the buns I baked the next day with the same dough, same filling but different shapes.Â  For the round buns, divide dough into equal portion [about 30-40gm each], add filling and roll into round balls, wet it and roll on toasted sesame seeds. Â Place them on paper casings and baked in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 12 minutes on middle shelf.I'm sharing this post viaÂ Â BYOB - Bake Your Own Bread atÂ Girlichef

title: Seaweed and Pork Ribs Soup
text: Not that difficult to prepare this soup and is said to be beneficial for those having constipation problems.Â  Soup is tasty and goes well with just plain white rice.Ingredients[serves 2-3]250 gm meaty pork ribs - cut in pieces, blanched in boiling water for a few minutes and rinsed1 small white carrot - skinned and cut into wedges1 small red carrot - skinned and cut into wedges1 piece seaweed [aka hai tai] - rinsed, soaked and cut into 3 cm lengths700 ml water1/2 cube of chicken stock granules1/2 tsp salt to tastepepper to tastePut both carrots and pork ribs into a pot.Â  Bring to boil, then lower fire and simmer for an hour or until pork ribs are tender. Â Add in seaweed and boil for another 10-15 minutes.Â  Add seasoning to taste.Serve soup hot with rice.

title: Milky Loaf Bread/White Loaf Bread Using Whipping Cream
text: Since Â I had some whipping cream left from making cheesecake, I used the balance to bake thisÂ loaf Â bread that uses whipping cream. Â  I have seen various versions of this bread which is soft and fluffy but frankly speaking, it is not that suitable for me and my hubby [senior citizens, a little 'kiasi'] as our daily breakfast bread. Â  I supposed, its alright for the younger people and only ocassional indulgence for me.I think it will be a long, long time before I gonna bake this bread again. Â So I'll just Â post the pictures and for the recipe please refer to HEREÂ andÂ HEREÂ for further information..

title: Gluten Free Banana Oatmeal Muffin
text: Had kept this recipe for sometime but never tempted to bake these muffins until now. Â My FIL used to say healthy food can never be delicious.Anyway, I just baked these muffins supposed to be healthy using oatmeal and bananas. Â These muffins are not sweet or oily.Ingredients[makes 12 muffins]3 cups oats [I used quick cooking oats]3/4 tbsp baking powder3 medium size ripe bananas - mashed2 eggs1 cup UHT milk [can use vanilla almond milk]1 tsp vanilla extract2 tbsp honey2 tbsp canola oil3 tbsp mini chocolate chips + 1 tbsp for toppingsMix all the dry ingredients in a big bowl.Using another bowl, beat eggs, honey and oil together. Â Add in vanilla and milk. Â Mix well and pour liquid mixture into dry ingredients. Â Lightly mix to combine ingredients. Â Set aside to rest.Preheat oven at 190 degrees C for 10 minutes.Scoop batter into baking tray lined with paper casings to 3/4 full.Baked for 20-30 minutes until golden brown. Â Test with skewer before removing muffins to cool on wire rack.I'm submitting this post toÂ Aspiring Bakers #21: Gluten-Free Bakes (July 2012)Â hosted byÂ Hankerie.

title: Mustard Leaf Porridge [Kuah Chye Moi]
text: In our family, we cook 2 versions of this porridge.Â  One version has at least 13 different main ingredients [usually served on the 9th day of CNY]. Â The other is this one which we will cook whenever Â we thought of having porridge with lots of vegetables, especially mustard leaves [aka kuah chye, kai choy].The first version has different types of meat [roasted pork, duck, chicken and innards] together with other ingredients as in this version. Â My grandma gave the first version a family name called 'chu chye moi' in Hokkien meaning to retain wealth and prosperity in the new year. Â We will cook a very big pot of this dish on this particular day because the ingredients are all leftovers from the previous day's praying to Jade Emperor [King of Heaven].Â On the 9th day of CNY [Chinese New Year] all family members, friends and relatives who know about this porridge will come over to the house for this porridge during lunch time.Â  After taking this porridge, it is hope that all Â are able to hold on to their wealth or more wealth during the year.Â  How true, I do not know.Â  Never had the chance to check it out with my grandma.Â  Perhaps, it is my grandma's 'tactic' to get everyone to the house... who doesn't want to be wealthy.....hehehe!Here is the second version. Â An easy family style porridge with lots of mustard leaves.Â  Got it cheap.Â  Bought it to cook this porridge and also make homemade preserved salted vegetables - kiam chye, hum choy [recipe from Sonia, Preserved Mustard Greens ].Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 cup rice - wash and drain100 gm pork belly [skin removed] - cut strips [can used roasted pork or mix both]1 tbsp dried prawns - rinse2 pieces firm beancurd - cut small cubes2-3 leaves kuah chye/kai choy/mustard leaves - wash and cut [add more if preferred]2 shallots - sliced2 cloves garlic - chopped4-5 cups water1-2 tbsp oilred chilli - cut shredsSeasoning2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1/2 tsp each of salt and pepper1/4 tsp msg or chicken stock granulesHeat oil in wok, fry beancurd until firm.Â  Push aside, using the remaining oil, saute shallots and garlic until aromatic and brown.Add in dried prawns and meat to fry for 1-2 minutes.Â  Stir to mix all the ingredients together.Â  Add in the rice, stir to fry for a minute.Â  Add in seasoning to mix and add vegetables.Â Â Stir to combine.Â  Dish out into a big pot, add in water.Â  Bring to a boil for 10-15 minutes.Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Off fire and cover pot for 5-10 minutes before serving.Garnish with fried shallots and coriander leaves.Â  Serve with cut chillies in soy sauce.Â I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Suresh of 3 hungry tummies

title: EZ Homemade Citrus Marmalade
text: This is one of the many homemade jams/preserves that I like.Â  Made with citrus fruits, the taste is a little sourish, slightly bitter [cos' of grapefruit and orange rind] and not too sweet as I reduced the sugar. The bitterness will not be obvious after a while.Â Â Wendy has a very detailed write up on marmalade and has shared her recipe on Sweet Orange Marmalade [Here].Â Â Â  Do check it out if you love marmalade.Â  When grapefruits are in abundance at the supermarkets, I will never miss making this jam which uses the flesh of grapefruits, oranges [with rind] and lemon [with rind].Here is the recipe adapted from Kuali.com with some minor changes especially the sugar quantity.Ingredients[makes 1 bottle about 550 gm]flesh of 1 grapefruit [about 300 gm]flesh and finely shredded rind of 2 oranges [about 350 gm]flesh and finely shredded rind of 1 lemon [about 100-120 gm]600 ml water300-350 gm sugar1 tbsp brandy - optionalPrepare the citrus fruits as above. Â Make sure the white pith is removed from the orange and lemon skin [to reduce bitterness]. Â Discard all seeds. Â Place a small sauce plate in the freezer [to test whether jam is ready].Bring water to boil in a heavy based saucepan. Â Boil the orange and lemon rind for 15-20 minutes, then add in the flesh of grapefruits, oranges and lemon. Â Bring everything to a rolling boil for 10-15 minutes, then reduce heat to medium. Â Boil until water is reduced to half and fruits are soft.Add sugarÂ and continue to simmer. Â Stir occasionally to mix ingredients well. Â In the meantime, place a small saucer in the freezer to chill [for testing if jam is ready]. Â Simmer until it gels up. Â Place a teaspoon of jam on saucer. Â Leave in fridge for a few minutes and jam should be ready if it forms a mass.Store jam in sterilised airtight bottles. Â Always refrigerate jam as homemade jams are without preservatives.

title: Stir Fry Sweet Sour Yellow Noodles
text: This Â sweet, sourish and slightly spicy stir fry noodles can be a healthy version of the Indian/Mamak Mee Goreng [Fried Yellow Noodles] Â for an EZ weekend lunch. Â Easy to prepare meatless noodles yet appetising.Ingredients[serves 2-3]400 gm yellow noodles - rinse in a colander under running water and drain.3 stalks chai sim [mustard leaves] or bok choy - washed and cut into 1 inch length100 gm beansprout - tailed1 potato - boiled or steamed to soften - skinned and cut cubes1 tomato - washed and cut cubes2 pieces firm beancurd [taukwa] - pan fried and cubed1 lime - cut wedges2-3 shallots - sliced2 cloves garlic - chopped2-3 tbsp oilSeasoning Sauce [mix together]2-3 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp chilli paste [chilli boh]1 tbsp dark soy sauce - for colour1 tsp sugar to taste1/2 tsp msg or chicken stock granulessalt to taste [I omit cos' yellow noodles are salty]1 cup hot water1 hard boiled egg - additional for garnishspring onions for garnishingPut enough oil in wok to pan fry beancurd till firm and golden. Â Dish out to cool then cut into cubes.Using the same wok and oil, saute chopped garlic and shallots till brown.Add in potato, beancurd and tomato. Â Stir to combine. Â Add in yellow noodles and seasoning. Â Stir fry to combine well. Â Add in beansprouts and vegetables. Â Stir and toss ingredients well with a wok ladle and a pair of long chopstick.Pour in hot water. Â Stir to mix and cook until gravy is reduced.Dish out to serve immediately with squeeze of lime. Â Garnish with hard boiled egg, spring onions and fried shallots if desired.

title: Apple Figs Jam Chiffon Cake
text: I have seen recipes that uses various jam/preserves to bake chiffon cakes.Â  Since I have my homemade Apple Figs Jam [recipe here], why not bake chiffon cake with it.Here's a simple recipe using this jam.Â  Of course, this chiffon cake has the taste of the preserves.Â  Just to create a pattern for the chiffon cake, I mixed some batter with a little green colouringÂ  and alternate it with the plain batter when filling up the pan.Â Â  Should have used more colouring for a better effect.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]1-2 tbsp castor sugar1/2 tsp salt3 tbsp oil60 ml milk100 gm Apple Figs Jam [used 3 tbsp]Whisk egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil. Â Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in milk. Â Lastly stir in jam until well combined.Fold in flour gently to mix well. Â Set aside while you whisk the egg white. Â Preheat oven at 170 degrees C.120 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powderIngredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar2 tbsp sugarÂ green colouring - optional Whisk egg white until frothy and add in cream of tartar. Â Continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar. Â Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined. Â Then fold mixture into rest of the Â meringue till well incorporated. Â Remove a portion and add in 1/2 tsp green colouring. Â Fold to mix well.Pour batter into 8" chiffon pan alternately with plain and green batter. Â  Knock a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 35-40 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Salted Fish Mixed Vegetable Curry
text: My hubby made some salted fish from the fishes he caught. Â Shared some with my neighbours and kept some to cook this curry. Â Cockles can also be added to it, but this time I didn't cos' we only wanted to savour the mixed vegetables and the gravy.We had this curry with Greek Olga BreadÂ [recipe here]. Â A simple meal that can be prepared earlier. Â Just warm up the bread in the oven and heat up the curry........and the meal is ready.Ingredients[serves 3-4]100 gm long beans - cut 3 cm lengths100 gm cabbage - break into small pieces1 brinjal [about 200 gm] - cut into wedges5 pieces of salted fish - rinsed and soaked for 5-10 minutes [depends on the saltiness of the salted fish]100 gm prawns - head removedSpice Ingredients [blend and combine]1 large onion2 cloves garlic1 cm piece ginger2 tbsp fish curry powder1 tbsp chilli boh1/4 tsp tumeric powder2 tbsp ground almond4 tbsp oil [more if you prefer more chilli oil for the curry]1/2 tsp saltsugar and msg to tasteenough waterBlend onion, garlic and ginger in a food processor then combine with curry powder, chilli paste, tumeric powder and ground almond.Heat oil in wok, pan fry salted fish pieces until aromatic and browned. Â Remove and set aside. Â Using the same wok saute spice ingredients until aromatic. Â Add in 1/2 tsp salt. Â Fry until oil separates.Â Pour in some water then add in the vegetables to cook. Â Stir fry for several minutes until well mixed. Â Add in salted fish.Â  Pour in enough water just to cover the vegetables. Â Bring it to a rolling boil. Â  Cover wok to cook vegetables until soft.Add in prawns Â and seasoning.Â  Bring it to boil to cook prawns.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Off fire.Dish out curry into bowl. Â  Serve hot with rice or flat bread.Greek Olga Bread [soft and spongy flat bread]

title: Greek Olga Bread
text: This the first time I have came across this bread [recipe HERE]. Â My hubby loves flat bread which can be used as a wrap for vegetables and meat or eat it with hot curry.This bread tastes of honey and has a slight sweetness that can be eaten on its own.Â  Soft and moist.Ingredients[makes 8-10 pieces]1/4 cup milk2 tbsp honey2 tbsp Â butter1/2 tsp salt1 egg1/2 tsp Â sugar280 gm all-purpose flour1 tsp instant yeastPut all ingredients into the mixer bowl [except butter]. Â Knead until soft and smooth. Â Add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic.Cover dough and leave to rise until double its size.Punch down dough, Â divide into 8-10 equal pieces. Â Roll each piece to a thin rough circle about 1/8 inch thick.Heat a large dry skillet or an electric griddle, over medium-high heat [Do Not use any oil]. Â Cook 15 seconds, flip and cook the other side for about 10-15 seconds, until mottled brown spots appear. Â  Do not over cook.Â Cool and wrap in foil.Â  Keep in a plastic bag, use them at once or refrigerate or freeze.

title: Stir Fry Sambal Sweet Leaf [Mani Cai]
text: After cooking the Sweet Leaf [Mani Cai] Soup which I liked with so much leafy greens, I thought I should cook this vege again but this time to stir fry with sambal belacan.This dish is simple yet tasty with the sambal and dried prawns which blends well with the sweet leaf.Ingredients150 gm sweet leaf [just the leaves without the stems] - rinsed and drain well in colandersalt to tastea little water 2-3 tbsp oil1 egg - optional Â Sambal Ingredients [pounded together]3 red chilliesÂ 2-3 shallotsa small piece of belacan2 tbsp dried prawns - rinsedHeat oil in wok to saute pounded ingredients until aromatic.Â  Add in sweet leaf and stir fry to mix well or until vegetables are limp [can add a little water] and cooked. Â  You can also stir in an egg to the vegetables [I didn't add the egg since I added alot of dried prawns].Add in salt to taste [be careful not to add too much cos' the belacan and dried shrimps may be salty].Dish out to serve with rice.NoteI used less oil here.Â  You can add another 1 tbsp to saute the sambal and vegetables will be more smooth and tender even without adding water.Â For more information on this vegetable, please refer toÂ Fong's Kitchen Journal. Â Â I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Suresh ofÂ 3 hungry tummies

title: Cinnamon Walnut Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: Came across Cathy's [Cinnamon Loaf]Â just after I baked my Carrot Loaf Bread where I added cinnamon powder and loved it very much. Â Her posting gave me the idea to bake a new loafÂ  bread again with cinnamon powderÂ  but I added some walnuts, wow!, I'm happy with the result. Â My hubby and myself really enjoyed this lovely bread [soft, moist, fragrant and nutty too] for breakfast.Stays good even on the third day. I marked this as one of my favourite bread.Recipe is for making 2 loaves of 500-550gm each. Just half the quantity if baking 1 loaf.Ingredients for Overnight Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour3 tsp instant yeast [actual is 3.5 tsp]250 ml waterMix all ingredients in a mixer bowl into a soft rough dough. Â Cover with a clean kitchen towel and leave to proof for several hours or overnight at room temperature.Â Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour [I used 270 gm bread flour and 30 gm wholemeal flour]2 tbsp milk powder1 tsp cinnamon powder3 tbsp sugar1 tsp Â salt80 gm chopped toasted walnuts150 ml water [keep some first, if all is used, the dough may be sticky and difficult to handle]60 gm butter [I used about 50 gm]Add all the ingredients [except butter and walnuts] to the overnight dough. Â Knead until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Knead a further 3-5 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers when touched or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll into a rectangular piece. Â Sprinkle all over with chopped walnuts then roll up Â tightly like swiss roll style into a roulade. Â Seal the edges well. Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reaching the rim of the baking tin].Â Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.NoteWhen I baked the bread at 160 C [40 minutes] or 170 C [30 minutes], the bread is much softer and moist than baking it at 180 C for 25 minutes.

title: Steamed Fish With Garlic/Ginger Paste
text: Again fresh fish from my hubby's fishing trip.Â  Two garoupa fish that weighs about 500-600 gm in Â total. Â Since it is so fresh, the best way to cook is by steaming with the least ingredients.Â  So I used garlic/ginger paste and some greens to bring out the natural sweetness of the fish.IngredientsGaroupa fish [about 500-600 gm] - scaled and cleanedGravy and Seasoning50 gm ginger - finely chopped5-6 cloves garlic - finely chopped1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp sugar to taste1/2 tsp pepper1 tbsp cooking wineÂ 1 tbsp Mei Kwai Lo [Rose Wine]1 tbsp sesame oil Garnishsome shredded carrot, young gingersome spring onion and coriander - sectionedEither chopped garlic and ginger finely or blended.Â  Mix with the rest of the seasoning ingredients in a small bowl.Pat dry cleaned fish and place on a heatproof dish.Â  Spread the gravy and seasoning mix all over the fish.Steam over high heat for 12-15 minutes [depending on the size of fish] or until fish is just cooked through.Garnish with the rest of ingredients before serving.

title: Honey Chiffon Cake
text: A simple chiffon cake, using honey.Â  The texture is soft and chewy.Â  Simple ingredients and easy to prepare.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]4 tbsp honey3 tbsp oil3 tbsp milkWhisk egg yolks with honey till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in milk.Â Â  Fold in flour until well combined. Â Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 160 degrees.125 gm cake flour - sifted Ingredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white3 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartarWhisk egg white until frothy, add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar in 2-3 batches.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into rest of meringue till well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â Knock a few times on tabletop to release trapped air. Â  Bake in lower rack of preheated oven at 160 degrees for 40-45 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Plain and Spinach Loaf Bread [Straight Dough Method]
text: Seen this bread recipe from Â somewhere but can't recall. Â So I use the Sweet Potato Loaf Bread recipe from Cathy's blog to bake this bread with some adjustment to suit the ingredients I have.
