I used plain yoghurt instead of whipping cream.This loaf bread is soft and moist but quite time consuming to make.Â  I wouldn't bake this bread if there is time constraint because you need to knead the dough separately.Â  The quantity here is to make 2 loaves and 1 loafÂ [qty in red].Ingredients - Plain DoughÂ [makes 2 loaves]280 gm bread flour [140 gm]30 gm wholemeal flour [15 gm]2 tbsp castor sugar [1 tbsp]1/4 tsp salt [1/8 tsp]1 tsp instant yeast [1/2 tsp]140 gm whipping cream [70 gm]20 gm shortening [10 gm]Ingredients - Spinach DoughÂ [makes 2 loaves]300 gm bread flour [150 gm]40 gm wholemeal flour [20 gm]100 gm spinach puree [50 gm]2 tbsp castor sugar [1 tbsp]1/4 tsp salt [1/8 tsp]1 tsp instant yeast [1/2 tsp]140 gm whipping cream [70 gm]20 gm shortening [10 gm]Knead the dough separately until smooth [may need to add a little water - about 30 ml] and add in shortening. Â Continue to knead until soft, smooth and elastic [window pane stage]. Â Shape both Â into round balls and cover to proof for 1 hour.Punch down both dough and fold into thirds. Â Then roll each dough into 1" thickness. Â Stack the 2 flattened dough together Â and roll up tightly to form a roulade.Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin], Â sprinkle some oats on bread. Â Leave in the oven to proof for 1 hour.Remove dough from oven to preheat oven to 160 degrees C for 10 minutes. Â Baked bread for 45 minutes. Â Remove from tin immediately to cool on rack before storing.

title: Spinach Buns With Meat Floss
text: A rather unique bun recipe using spinach [pui ling chye] and plain flour. Â Easy to handle dough which is not sticky or Â has a raw vegetable smell. Â I read this recipe from 100%Â Baking Corner in one of the Chinese magazines but I made some changes.Â  Instead of baking it as plain buns, I used meat floss and seaweed [nori] as savoury filling. Â The buns are soft, moist and nice even on the second day.Â  [If you still have the buns by the third day, then you can reheat in the oven for 5-10 minutes @ 100 degrees C or steamed it for 5 minutes.Â  It will be soft again].Spinach Buns Bread Dough [makes 12 buns]Â 300 gm plain flour1 tbsp skimmed milk powder1/2 tsp salt2 tbsp sugar 1 small egg100 gm spinach - washed and drain in colander [blend with 70 ml water] - should get about 170ml2 tsp yeast1 tbsp butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  ThenÂ  continue kneadingon medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes to get to window pane stage or dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 1 hour or double in size.Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 4 equal portion. Â Round up into a ball. Roll each portion into a rectangle.Â  Brush lightly with some soft butter, then sprinkle filling.Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well.Â  Roll into a long thin roll and cut into 9 pieces.Â  Place 3 pieces inverted on a greased paper casing.Â  Do the same for the rest of dough.Proof until double in size [about 1 hour]. Â Glaze with beaten egg [I used milk] and sprinkle sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 190 degrees C for 15 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack.Â  If prefered, brush lightly with some melted butter.Meat Floss, Seaweed and Sesame Seed Bun Fillingsome store bought meat flosssome seaweed [nori] - break into small piecessome toasted sesame seedsmix the ingredients together and use as filling for buns.

title: Spinach Loaf Bread [Straight Dough Method]
text: Was wondering how blended spinach [aka pui ling chye in Hokkien or poi choi in Cantonese] turn out to be in bread.Â  Will it change colour or does it have a raw vegetable smell.Â  The answer is NO.Â  No vegetable smell, the colour was natural an beautiful.The texture is soft but firm and compact.Â  I believed it is because plain flour is used instead of bread flour.Â  Has anyone tried this kind of bread before?Â  Perhaps, you would like to share some info or views on this kind of bread.Spinach [Pui LingChye/Poi Choi]Spinach Bread Dough300 gm plain flour1 tbsp skimmed milk powder1/2 tsp salt2 tbsp sugar 1 small egg100 gm spinach - washed and drain in colander [blend with 70 ml water] - should get about 170ml2 tsp yeast1 tbsp butterKnead all dough ingredients [except butter] on slow speed to combine. Â  ThenÂ  continue kneadingon medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [about 7-10 minutes].Add in butter and continue kneading on low speed from the start then turn to medium speed when butter and dough has combined. Â Knead for about 5-7 minutes to get to window pane stage or dough is not sticky.Form dough into a ball. Â Place in a bowl covered to rest for 1 hour or double in size.Punch down rested dough. Â Divide into 3 equal portions. Â Round up into a ball. Â Fold into thirds then roll each portion into a rectangle. Â  Roll up like swiss roll and seal the edges well. Â Place the 3 small loaves in greased Pullman's tin.Leave in oven to proof until double in size [about 1 hour]. Â Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30 minutes. Â Remove and cool on wire rack.

title: Spicy Nasi Ulam [Mixed Herbal Rice]
text: This herbal rice looks difficult to prepare with some many ingredients but it is not so when you have some home grown herbs such as daun kaduk, cekur leaves, tumeric leaves, kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass in your garden.Â  Lucky me, I have all these and a visit to the vegetable stall, I managed to get the rest.... You can also prepare this dish in smaller quantity.If you like these herbs and don't mind slowly chewing the mixed rice, you will enjoy the aroma and freshness of the herbs.Â  Delicious and healthy food.Â  IngredientsÂ [serves 7-8]3 mackerel [ikan kembung] - pan fried, bones removed and flaked2 tbsp dried shrimps - rinsed, chopped coarsely and pan fried without oil2-3 tbsp grated white coconut - pan fried until golden and crispy [kerisik]2 1/2 cups rice - cooked in rice cooker, cooled and fluff upHerbs [slice finely]6 shallots1 small piece fresh tumeric30 gm young ginger1 wild ginger bud2 lemon grass6 kaffir lime leaves6 cekur leaves1 tumeric leaf4 stalks daun kesum [polygonum leaves only] 4 stalks basil [leaves only]10 daun kaduk leaves [wild betel nut]Seasoning [Mix together]3 tbsp sambal belacan 1/2 - 3/4 tsp saltÂ 1 tsp pepper1 tsp ground black pepper2 tsp sugar or to taste2 tbsp sesame oilCombine seasoning ingredients in a large mixing bowl.Â  Add in the cooked rice.Â  Toss well to combine.Mix in all the finely cut vegetables, dried prawns, fish and dessicated coconut.Â  Stir to mix well and serve immediately with extra sambal belacan if preferred.NoteCan replace fried mackerel flakes with fried salted fish meat [chopped small pieces].Can add more herbs, if you have it, it's alright.I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted byShannon ofÂ Just As Delish

title: Soft Buns With Cheddar Cheese/Raisins
text: I made these buns with the basic recipe from Cathy's blogÂ 'Trying out new toy'. Â The buns turned out lovely and soft. Â But I added some cheddar cheese and raisins as filling for the buns. Â You can omit the filling if you are making plain buns.Here's the recipe for these lovely buns which remains soft for 2 days.Ingredients - Straight Dough Method[makes 9-12 buns]200 gm bread flour50 gm wholemeal flour30 gm Â shortening [I used 20 gm]8 gm milk powder [I used 1 tbsp]45 gm sugar [I used 2 tbsp]1/4 tsp salt1 eggÂ 7 gm dry yeast [I used 2 tsp]120 ml water [I used milk]egg glaze or milk Â - optional [my opinion is to use milk]Oats for toppings - optionalcheddar cheese and raisins - optionalKnead all the ingredients (except shortening) together with a dough hook until a soft dough is formed.Add in shortening and continue kneading until the dough is soft, smooth and elastic or window pane stage [I knead until the dough leaves the bowl clean and does not stick to the fingers when touched].Â Shape into a ball and cover to proof for 1 hour or double in size.Punch out air from the dough and divide into 9 - 12 equal portions. Â Shape into balls. Wrap a small piece of cheddar cheese and some plump up raisins with each piece of dough. Â  Seal the edges and shape into a round ball. Â Place dough seam side down on paper casing. Â Repeat the same for the others. Â Â Proof for 1 hour. Â Brush buns with egg glaze or milk. Â Sprinkle oats.Bake in a preheated oven @ 190Â°C for 10 - 15 minutes. Â Remove to cool on wire rack.NotesI prepared the dough until Step 2, wrap the dough in a thick plastic bag. Â Tied up with a rubber band and kept it in the fridge a day before baking these buns. Just thaw the dough to room temperature before shaping. Â  In this way, I can have my soft buns ready for late breakfast around 9.00 - 10.00 am the next day.

title: Dumpling Festival 2012
text: According to Chinese traditional beliefs, it is said that when someone passed away in the family, within a year, many things cannot be done such as making rice dumplings [tang yuen], steamed sweet glutinous rice [thnee kuih] and wrapping of dumplings [bak chang etc].So since my Pa passed away, we were advised not to do any of these for a year.Â  As it is a traditional practice, for the past few days, many of our friends, relatives and neighbours have been bringing to us the dumplings that they made.Here are some of the dumplings which we received.Â  I wish to thank them for their kind thoughts and of course their delicious DUMPLINGS of various fillings and shapes. Interesting, isn't it?Â  I appreciate the BOND between us.Each have their own flavours and tasted good with all their love and care.Â Â  I'll share mine next dumpling festival, hehehe!

title: Lor Mai Kai in Lotus Leaf
text: For this year's Dumpling 'Chang' Festival, my family won't be making any dumplings.Â Â  Since the family [especially the teenage kids] loved savoury glutinous rice so much, I decided to make Lor Mai Kai to satisfy their cravings.The recipe is actually Lor Mai Kai [Steamed Savoury Glutinous Rice] but instead of the usual steaming in Â bowls, I wrapped them with lotus leaf after checking with dear Sonia when I saw her posting on LMK. Apart from the LMK flavours, it also has the fragrance of the lotus leaf.Â  I should say it is Yum Yum [better than store bought].My first intention was to follow 3 different recipes shared by Sonia, [Nasi Lemak Lover], Ah Tze [Awayofmind] and Happy Flour [LMK].Â  On second thought, I think I can't handle 3 different recipes in one go, so I decided to use a recipe that I have which makes enough to give to my mum and her grandchildren.Â  To my dear friends, I will try each of yours when I am preparing less of it.Here are the ingredients and method.Â  I actually made 9 LMK with lotus leaf and 3 in bowls.Ingredients[makes 12 bundles]600 gm glutinous rice - washed and soaked in water for at least 4 hours or overnightSeasoning for glutinous rice [mix together in a big mixing bowl]1 tsp salt1/2 tsp each of sugar, Ajinomoto, pepper1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce2 tsp sesame oil3 tbsp oilDrain glutinous rice and steam for 45 minutes or until rice is thoroughly cooked.Â  Remove and add to seasoning.Â  Mix seasoning and rice well.Â  Roughly divide into 12 equal portions.3 chicken thighs - deboned - each cut into 4 pieces12 small dried mushrooms -Â  soaked and keep whole2 Chinese sausages - skin removed and sliced slantly to get 12 pieces100 gm char siew - store bought [cut 12 slices]150 gm pork, cut into slices [I omit]Seasoning for meat and mushrooms1 tsp salt1 1/2 tsp sugar1/2 tsp Ajinomoto1/4 tsp pepper2 tsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp each of oyster sauce, sesame oil, cooking oil2 tsp wine2 tbsp water2 tbsp cornflour1 stalk spring onion and a piece of ginger - lightly mashed [optional] Season chicken, pork and mushrooms with the seasoning for meat for at least an hour.3 pieces of lotus leafBlanched in hot water until soft.Â  Remove and rinse to clean.Â  Using a scissor, cut each leaf into 4 pieces.Â  Drain on colander to drip dry the leave.To Wrap LMK in lotus leafTake a piece of lotus leaf.Â  Place a piece of each ingredient about 2-3 inches from the edge of the broad side of the leaf.Â  Top up with 1 portion of the steamed glutinous rice.Â  Fold the leaf to cover the rice and wrap up like a parcel.Â  Tuck in the end to seal well.Place parcel on a steaming tray.Â  Do the same for the rest of the ingredients.Steam LMK over boiling water on high heat for 30-40 minutes.Serve hot.Steamed LMK in bowls The LMK rice is soft, QQ and taste is just nice.Â  The meat and mushrooms have the fragrant smellÂ  and flavours of spring onions and ginger.

title: Banana Chiffon Cake
text: This morning, a neighbour gave me these home-grown bananas. Â They are from her colleague's village home where they grow many, many types of fruits [bananas, jackfruit, rambutans, roselle etc.], herbs and tubers. Â Most times she will pass these to me whenever she gets them. Â I have received from her wild ginger flowers, jackfruits, yam, sweet potatoes, rambutans, roselle and this time bananas. Â Â Since I have a Banana Chiffon cake recipe fromÂ Â Happy Home Baking pending for sometime, I might as well bake and share it with this thoughful neighbour. Â  I adjusted some of the ingredients. Â  The cake bakes well and tasted good. Â Â  It does not shrink and no liquid is needed.Â Â  A point to note is that this cake should be finished fast as it does not keep for long unless you refrigerate it because of bananas used.Ingredients3 egg yolks [used large eggs] Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â 1-2 tbsp castor sugar1/8 tsp salt3 tbsp corn oil80 gm mashed bananas [about 2-3 medium size bananas] + 2 tsp lemon juice [or 1 tbsp]50 gm plain flour - sifted with 1/8 tsp baking powder3 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar2 tbsp castor sugarBeat together egg yolks and sugar in a mixing bowl with a hand whisk until blended. Â Slowly add in oil and Â continue whisking until well combined. Â Add in mashed bananas. Â Mix well to combine. Â  Fold in sifted plain flour. Â Set aside. Â Preheat oven at 170C while you prepare the meringue.Put egg white in cake mixer bowl [make sure bowl is clean and ungreased]. Â Whisk egg whites until a little frothy, add in cream of tartar, continue whisking until foamy and add in sugar in 3 batches. Â Keep whisking egg white mixture till soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 of meringue to egg yolk mixture. Mix evenly till well combined. Then pour into rest of the meringue. Â Fold till evenly combined. Â Pour batter into 7 inch ungreased chiffon pan. Â Smooth the top with a spatula. Â Tap pan on table top a few times to release trapped air bubbles.Baked in preheated oven [lower rack] for 35 - 40 minutes.Â Remove and invert baked cake immediately to cool completely before removing from pan.

title: Savoury Yam Cake
text: This Savoury Yam Cake recipe is from Ah Tze [Awayofmind Bakery House] which I bookmarked to try.Â  Slightly different from my earlier posting Steamed Yam Cake.Â  I realised the quantity is small and lots of yam too.Â  Also wondering how this cake taste like with 5 spice powder added.Anyway,Â  ...I like this recipe, the yam cake is soft and the yam and 5 spice powder matched well...I served it with my homecooked chilli sauce.Sorry Ah Tze, I added some extra ingredients because this Yam Cake is for my mum, so must have more 'liao' otherwise she may think I am stingy with the dried prawns, hehehe....Ingredients400g yam, peeled and cut into cube4 shallots, diced2 tbsp dried prawns, soaked [slightly pounded]1/2 tsp each of salt, 5 spice powder 1/4 tsp white pepper100g rice flour3 tbsp tapioca starch or corn starch1 tsp salt550 ml waterÂ Â Garnishes 3 tbsp of dried prawns - washed and slightly pounded - fry with a little oil until fragrant 3 tbsp crispy fried shallots3 tbsp thinly sliced spring onion1 red chilli - dicedSteam the yam cubes for 20 mins. Set aside.Â Heat the oil in a non-stick wok toÂ  fry the shallots until browned.Â Â  Add dried prawns, stir fry for 2 to 3 minutes, then add the steamed yam cubes.Â  Stir fry for another 2 mins.Â Â  Add salt, five spice powder and pepper, mix and remove from heat.Combine rice flour, tapioca flour, salt and water in a pan. Mix until mixture is smooth and free of lumps. Heat the mixture over low heat, stirring continuously withÂ  a wooden spoon until it thickens. Remove pan from heat, add yam cubes and mix well.Transfer the yam cake mixture to a oiled steaming tray.Â  Cover and steam for 25~30 mins. Allow to cool completely before cutting. Garnish before serving.

title: Cinnamon Walnuts With Choc Chip Muffins
text: From Happy Home Baking, I saw thisÂ Cinnamon Walnuts and Choc Chips MuffinsÂ recipe and told myself, must bake this muffin asap cos' it uses oil instead of butter and moreover, my hubby can have them for supper when he watches the Euro 2012 matches.Anyway, that night, he wasn't watching the matches, so we had these muffins for breakfast. Â I had to warm up the muffins in the oven [@ 100 C for 15-20 minutes]. Â The muffins tasted fragrant with the cinnamon, nutty with the Â walnuts Â and sweet from the choc chips.Â Â Easy to prepare if all the ingredients are available.Â  I believe the batter can even be prepared the night before if you planned to have them for breakfast the next day and too many chores to do.Ingredients(makes 9 regular size muffins)140 ml milk80 ml canola or corn oil [I reduced to 70 ml]1 large egg, lightly beaten1 tsp vanilla essence200 gm plain flour1 tsp baking powder1 tsp ground cinnamon100 gm castor sugar [I reduced to 80gm]1/8 tsp salt50 gm walnuts, coarsely chopped50 gm chocolate chipsIn a mixing bowl, whisk together milk, oil, egg and vanilla extract until just combined.Sieve flour, baking powder and ground cinnamon into another mixing bowl. Add sugar, salt and stir to combine.Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. With a rubber spatula, fold the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir only until the ingredients are just combined (Note: stop stirring once the flour incorporates into the batter, but do check that there is no pockets of flour at the bottom of the bowl).Reserve 1 tablespoon each of the chopped walnuts and chocolate chips. Â Gently stir in the rest of the chopped walnuts and chocolate chips into the batter. Do Not over mix the batter. The finished batter should appear thick and lumpy.Spoon batter into paper muffin cups, fill it to about 3/4 full.Sprinkle top with the reserved chopped walnuts and chocolate chips.Bake in preheated oven at 200 Degrees C for about 20 - 25mins or until a toothpick inserted in the center of a muffin comes out clean. Â  Transfer to a wire rack and let cool completely.

title: Spicy Sardine Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: To prepare my Papa's most loved dish Spicy Sardine Vege Salad,  I bought a big can of sardines in tomato sauce but only use half of it.Â  With the balance, I used it to bake buns with sardine filling which are my nephews favourite too.Using the sweet bun recipe [sponge dough method], these buns are light, fluffy and soft.  Refer HERE to view photos on how to make buns using sponge dough method.Ingredients for the buns-Sponge Dough Method[makesÂ  10Â  buns]Step 1 - Ingredients2 tsp instant yeast160-170 mlÂ  water230 gm bread flourMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour.Â  Knead to form a soft and smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients60 gm sugar1/4 tsp salt1 small egg [20 gm]25 ml water100 gm bread flour 30 gm butterAdd all Step 2 ingredientsÂ  [except butter] to dough from Step 1.Â  Knead from low speed until well combined.Â  Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes].Â  Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage [Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate.Â Â  Thaw to room temperature before using.Â Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only].Shape dough into a ball.Â  Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down and divide dough in 60 gm per portion or into any portions preferred.Shape dough into round balls.Â  Roll out each ball and fill it 1 tbsp of the sardine onion filling.Â  Gather the edges together and seal up the seam to shape into a triangular shaped bun or shape it into an oval shape.Â  Place bun on greased paper casing on a baking tray.Leave to rise for 30-45 minutes or until double in size.Â  Brush with egg/milk glaze. Sprinkle with sesame seeds.Baked in preheated oven at 190 degrees for 12-15 minutes.Â  Brush buns with melted butter if preferred.Remove to cool on rack.Ingredients for FillingÂ [Spicy Sardine Filling]250 gm sardine in tomato sauce - pour away sauce1 big onion - chopped small pieces 1.5 tbsp chilliÂ  sauce [or 1 tsp chilli paste]1/2 tsp ikan bilis [anchovies] stock granules1/4 tsp pepper1 tbsp lime juicesalt and sugar to tasteHeat 1/2 tbsp oil in pan to saute onions until soft.Â  Add in sardines and all the seasoning.Stir fry to combine and cook until mixture is slightly dry.Remove from pan to cool.Â Â Â  Filling is ready for use or refrigerate until required.Note:Filling is enough to make 10 buns.

title: Sweet Leaf [Sayur Manis] Egg Soup
text: This leafy vegetable is known as 'sweet leaf', is a shrub grown in some tropical regions. Â  In Chinese it is called mani cai (é©¬å°¼èœ), in Malay it is called cekur manis or sayur manis. Â It is one of the most popular leaf vegetables in South Asia and Southeast Asia and is notable for high yields and palatability. Â Its multiple upright stems can reach 2.5 meters high and bear dark green oval leaves 5â€“6 cm long. Â The flowers and small purplish fruits of the plant have also be eaten in Indonesia, the leaves of the plant are used to make infusion, believed to improve the flow of breast milk for breastfeeding mothers. ItÂ is a good source of vitamin K and also have high level of provita-min A carotenoids, especially in freshly picked leaves, as well as high levels of vitamins B and C, protein and minerals. The more mature leaves, the higher nutrient content of the leaves. Â Â This is the vegetable that we use in â€˜Pan Meenâ€™. Â Â In Vietnam, the locals cook it with crab meat, minced pork or dried shrimp to make soup. In Malaysia, it is commonly stir-fried with egg or dried anchovies. Â My mum cook this in soup with either ikan bilis or dried prawns and an egg. Â Sometimes, I stir fry it with sambal belacan dried prawns. Â Its crunchy and has a bite. Â Whichever way it is cooked it is full of fibre and green goodness. Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 gm sweet leaf [mani cai] - separate leaves from stems - soak to wash leaves thorough and drain in colander**1 tbsp dried prawns - washed and lightly pounded1 tsp chopped shallots1 tsp chopped garlic600 ml water or 3 rice bowls1/2 - 1 tsp salt to taste1/4 tsp peppera dash of msg to taste1 eggHeat soup pot with a little oil to saute shallots, garlic and dried prawns until fragrant. Â Add in water.Let it boil for 5-10 minutes until aromatic. Â Â  Add in the vegetable to cook through. Â Break in an egg and lightly stir to mix. Â Bring to a boil again and serve immediately.NotesÂ I was told that the type of sweet leaf that taste better are the ones with slightly curly leaves.To separate the leaves from the stem, just hold the stem at one end and push down with your thumb and index finger.To wash the leaves, crushed them with both hands then soak in water. Â Rinse several times and drain dry in a colander.Â Some people believed that diabetics should not take too much of this vegetable because it is 'sweet'.Â For more information on this vegetable, pleaseÂ refer to Fong's Kitchen Journal. I'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Shannon of Â Just As Delish

title: Spicy Sardine Vege Salad
text: Today is Father's Day and it reminds me of the many dishes my father liked.Â  This sardine salad was one of his favourites.Â  I had prepared this dish on this day just to remember the times when he would request for it especially when my mum isn't cooking any fish dish for dinner.A tasty salad which is not difficult to prepare.Â  Add more small hot chillies if you prefer it to be spicier.Ingredients1 can [250 gm] sardine in tomato sauce - bones removed1 tbsp tomato sauce salt, sugar and pepper to taste100 gm fresh letttuce leaves - cut shreds50 gm fresh mint leaves1 big onion1-2 red small chilli [cili padi] or 1 red chilli - cut small piecesJuice of 3 calamasi limes Heat up sardines and add seasoning to taste.Â  Set aside to cool.Put cut vegetables in a colander to drain off water. Mix together lettuce leaves, mint leaves, onion and chilli in a big bowl.Add in cooled sardine mixture and lime juice.Toss well and serve immediately or refrigerate until serving time.

title: Father's Day 2012
text: My dear father - Ong Kok Beng @ Ong Khit ThowThis Father's Day is no longer a day of celebration for me and Â my siblings.Â  It's the first time that our privilege to celebrate this day with our father no longer holds.Â  We can only recall memories on how we celebrated each Father's Day with him in the past.Â  The reason is that he has been called to rest 8 months ago.Â Since his passing [Passing of My Beloved Papa] we have come by my occasions that we are experiencing for the first time doing many, many things without him but memories of the past still linger on clearly. Â  We recall what he had said then and his actions, his laughters and satisfactions on how things were done. Â  Definitely we missed him alot and we never are going to have the chance to experience it again. He has been a great father to me and my siblings. Â We remembered how we planned to celebrate this day with him every year.Â  We cracked our heads to think what are the food he loves and where he would prefer to have a dinner. I would think of what cakes to bake for him. Â All these years he had never ever demand or request any kind of celebration.Â  He was always happy with whatever was planned and arranged for him.Â I remember these were some of his favourite dishes and many more. Â Sometimes when the dish was so good, he would liked to keep for his children and grandchildren, he would only savoured on the gravy.Stir Fry Sambal EggplantStir Fry Sambal Sweet Potato LeavesStingray Curry with Ladies FingersSteamed Minced Meat with EggsJava MeeChicken CurryPenang Hokkien Mee [Prawn Noodles]Fried Sago Cake [Sago Char]Stir fry Spicy Stingray with Preserved VegetablePing Pei MooncakeKoong Chye Peang [Figurine Mooncake]Steamed Meat PausMy hope to all who still have their fathers, to always truly love and care for their beloved Papa and to enjoy every moment with him for there may be a day, you may experience and feel the way I feel now.Â  Never tell your Papa you have no time for him because there will be a time when your Papa has no time for you.Â Â  To my dear father, we loved and missed you.I also hope that all fathers of the world to always truly love and care to spend time on this day with their children so that this day for the years to come will bring back good memories for all.Wishing all fathersÂ 'HAPPY FATHER'S DAY'.

title: EZ Stir Fry Homemade Kiam Chye
text: My brining of mustard greens [recipe here]Â was completed. Â Not knowing how the texture and taste would be, I just prepare a simple stir fry of the vegetable. Â Moreover, I roast pork belly [recipe here] today for my plain porridge, so why not fry preserved mustard green [aka. kiam chye] which is a dish that definitely goes well with it too.Here is the recipe.Â  Believe me the kiam chye/hum choy was good.Â  Not salty [I just rinsed and soaked for about 10 minutes].Â  It was crunchy and soft. Â  Nice!! Â Now, I'm doing my second batch of brining mustard greens for my mum and neighbours.Ingredients1 big stalk of preserved mustard green [kiam chye] - rinsed and soaked for 10 minutes - cut thin shreds1 red chilli - cut shreds1 tsp each of shredded ginger and chopped garlic1-2 tbsp oil1 tsp sesame oilsugar and pepper to tastesome watera dash of shaoxing wineÂ Put cut vegetables to fry in pan without oil for about 5 minutes or until vegetables are dry. Â Push aside and add in oil.Add ginger, garlic and red chilli. Â Saute until fragrant then mix together with vegetables. Â Add seasoning to taste. Â Add some water to simmer kiam chye for a few seconds or until vegetable is soft.A in wine and sesame oil. Â Stir to mix and dish out to serve with porridge.NoteThis dish can be prepared earlier and serve later with hot porridge.

title: Tapioca Loaf Bread [Straight Dough Method]
text: After the successful attempts baking the soft loaf bread with glutinous rice flour and cornflour, I thought I should also try with tapioca flour. Â Managed to get the basic recipe from home baking website and did some adjustments to the ingredients. Â This recipe yields 2 loaves of Â 500gm bread.The loaf bread texture is like the cornflour loaf.Â  It's soft and moist......and we tried toasting it on the 3rd day. Â  It is good with a mild tapioca smell.Ingredients45 gm tapioca flour270 ml waterCombine the tapioca starch and the water (270 ml). Â Stir until thick over low heat and cool completely. .555 gm bread flour2 tbsp skim milk powder1 - 1 1/2 tsp salt3 tbsp sugar3 tsp yeast140 ml warm water30 gm butterAdd all the ingredients [except butter] to the cooked tapioca dough. Â Knead [from low speed to medium] until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Knead a further 5-10 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Then divide each dough intoÂ half. Shape the dough into a ball lightly. Â Â Roll each dough out into a rectangle. Â Fold the dough into thirds,Â then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size or almost reaching the rim of the baking tin. Â Remove from oven before preheating it.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees for 25 minutes [uncovered] or 200 degrees C for 30 minutes [covered]. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.   NotesNext time, I try to bake it at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes. Â Just to see if the texture is like the QQ Glutinous Loaf Bread.

title: Homemade Preserved Mustard Greens [Kiam Chye]
text: This recipe Preserved Mustard Greens [Kiam Chye]Â was shared by Sonia, Nasi Lemak Lover.Tried brining the mustard greens Sonia's way. Â Must thanked her for this EZ way to make our own 'kiam chye, hum choy'.Here's the recipe adapted from Sonia.Kiam Chai / Hum Choy(Homemade Pickled Mustard Greens)(recipe source: adapted from My Little Space and flavours lifestyle magazine, with minor changes)Ingredients2 kg mustard greens (kai choy) èŠ¥èœ, rinsed & drainedÂ 145 gm coarse saltBrining solution3-4 litres water, or enough to cover4 tbsp salt40 gm ginger, sliced1/2 tsp turmeric powder1 tbsp rice flour, mixed with 4 tbsp waterEquipment- ceramic crock and heavy object (example plate), or glass jar with lid and a plastic sheet and rubber band.Cut large heads of mustard greens into half, rub salt in between the leaves and stem then set aside for about 6 hours to draw out the moisture and wilt the greens.Bring water to boil together with all other brining ingredients. Then set aside to cool before used.Squeeze moisture from the mustard greens and then pack them into jar.Â Pour cooled brining solution into the jar to keep those mustard greens covered.Â Cover the top with plastic sheet & tide it up with rubber band, then cover by lid and set aside to in a cool place to ferment for 5-7 days.Check on the greens every day and skim off the whitish bloom that appears on the surface of the brining solution.Remove the mustard green after the 7th day without squeezing out any liquid, discard brining solution.Wrap the mustard greens in cling film and store refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 2 months.Â Photos taken on my homemade preserved mustard greensNotesVegetable is crunchy, not too salty and has a mild sourish tasteJust rinse and soak preserved kiam chye for 10 minutes [or taste it before soaking] to reduce the saltiness before cooking.I cooked again this dish [Stir Fry Spicy Stingray with Preserved Mustard Greens], this time using my homemade preserved mustard greens [kiam chye].Â  It was delicious.Â  The vegetable was soft but crunchy after frying.

title: Cornflour Loaf Bread [Sponge Dough Method]
text: The recipe here makes 2 loaves weighing about 480 gm each. Â Soft loaf bread. Â  The loaf is not exactly rectangular eventhough I covered it, Â as it didn't rise to 90% height of my Pullman's tin.Â Â  Ingredients for Sponge Dough180 gm bread flour120 gm cornflour2 tsp instant yeast200 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour Â [removed 2 tablespoons]2 tbsp wholemeal flour4 tbsp sugar1 tsp Â salt1 egg100 ml water [used about 90 ml]60 gm butterÂ Add all the ingredients [except butter] to the sponge dough. Â Knead [from low speed to medium] until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Knead a further 5-10 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reach the rim of the baking tin. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make smaller loaves]. Â Remove from oven before preheating it.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees for 25 minutes [uncovered] or 200 degrees C for 30 minutes [covered].Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.NotesNever discard the loaf bread if they are not that soft or moist to your liking. Â  It's yummy, delicious [crispy outside and moist inside] when you toast and apply jam and butter to it.

title: MY Bubur Kacang [Mung Beans in Coconut Milk]
text: This is how I prepare the Bubur Kacang [mung beans in coconut milk]. Â During my grandmother's time, when cooking this dessert, coconut milk was added to the pot of sweet green beans soup.Â Â Nowadays, with some in the family members being quite health conscious, the coconut milk is added separately to individual bowls and how much to add depends on one's own preference.Â  Honestly, without coconut milk it should not be called 'bubur kacang'.Ingredients[serves 4-5] 100 gm green beans - wash and drain 2 tbsp glutinous rice2 tbsp sago [optional]2 screwpine [pandan] leaves - wash and knotted1.5 litres water [water will be reduced as you boil, add more if necessary]120-150 gm sugar [adjust according to preference]50 ml coconut milk mix with 1/2 tsp salt Prepare the above ingredients.Â Pour water in a pot to boil then add in green beans to cook.Â When green beans are soft, add in glutinous rice and sago.Â  Continue to boil for a further 10 minutes are until rice is cooked and sago turns translucent.Â Add more water if you prefer the dessert not too thick. Â  Add in sugar to taste.Â  Off fire.Â  [You can add in the coconut milk if you do not want to serve it separately].Serve bubur kacang hot or warm in individual bowls with coconut milk.I'm submitting this to Aspiring Bakers #20-Asian Dessert Buffet! [June 2012] hosted by Moon of Â Food Playground.

title: Spicy Stir Fry Pineapple
text: A simple spicy pineapple stir fry that requires only few ingredients.Â  This dish can be cooked if you have leftover pineapples that are not sweet to be eaten raw.Â  You can substitute french beans with zuchini or cucumber [my original recipe uses zuchini].Â  With french beans it is also good as the french beans remained crunchy after frying.Â  The natural flavour of the pineapple makes this dish sweet and sourish thus very appetising.Â Â  If you feel like having pickled vegetables 'acar', this can be a substitute.Ingredients[serves 2-3]1/4 of pineapple - cut strips100 gm french beans - cut slantly about 1 inch lengthsome red carrot - cut thin stripssome shredded black fungus - optional 1 tbsp dried prawns - washed and chopped/pounded1/2 tbsp oil1 tbsp hot chilli sauce* to taste1 tbsp tomato sauce* to tastesalt to tasteÂ toasted sesame seeds or grounded peanuts - optional Heat oil in wok, saute dried prawns until fragrant.Add in french beans, carrots and pineapple.Â  Stir fry to combine.Add in chilli sauce and tomato sauce.Â  Add salt to taste.Cover to steam cook vegetables for 1-2 minutes.Remove and dish out to serveÂ  with rice.Â Sprinkle sesame seeds and grounded peanuts before serving - optionalI'm submitting this post to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Shannon of Just As DelishÂ  Â  Â Note:Usually I substitute these 2 ** seasoning with my homemade sweet sour chilli sauce.Â  Please refer Here on preparation of the chilli sauce.

title: Homemade Sweet Sour Chilli Sauce
text: This homemade sweet sour chilli sauce is easy to prepare and keeps well in the fridge for months.Â  Suitable as dipping sauce for any fried food, steamboat ingredients, steamed savoury cakes or can also be used to fry vegetables.If you prefer the sauce to be less spicy, just remove the chilli seeds and do not add small chilli [cili padi].Â  However, certain red chillies are rather spicy depending on it's origin and seasons.Ingedients100 gm red chillies [about 10 pieces] - washed and cut3 small chillies [cili padi] - optional50 gm garlic - skin removed5 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp salt1/4 cup white rice vinegar [used good quality ones]1/2 cup water1 tbsp oil - heat separately until hotBlend red chillies and garlic in a food processor until fine.Put all ingredients [except oil] in a stainless steel saucepot.Â  Bring it to a boil and cook for a further 5-10 minutes.Â  Off fire.Heat up 1 tablespoon oil in a small saucepan until hot.Â  Quickly pour into cooked sauce and stir to combine well.Cool before storing in glass container.Â  Keep in the refrigerator.I'm submitting this to Muhibbah Malaysian Monday hosted by Shannon ofÂ Just As DelishNote:This chilli sauce can be used to stir fry pineapples, zuchini, french beans, black fungus and carrots instead of using store bought tomato and chilli sauces.

title: Carrot Loaf Bread [Sponge Dough Method]
text: The recipe here makes 2 loaves weighing about 500 gm each. Â Soft, light and moist loaf bread. The original recipe does not have cinnamon powder.Â  By adding it the bread has the fragrant smell of cinnamon and carrot.Â  Very nice bread .......Ingredients for Sponge Dough180 gm bread flour120 gm cornflour3 tsp instant yeast230 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft and smooth dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour 150 gm red carrot [grated finely]3 tbsp sugar1 tsp Â salt1/4 tsp cinnamon powder [optional] 40 ml water [add gradually]30 gm butterÂ Add all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the sponge dough. Â Knead [from low speed to medium] until well combined.Â  Gradually add in water [may need less as the carrots contains water] and knead dough until smooth [about 10 minutes] then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Knead a further 5-10 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reach the rim of the baking tin. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make smaller loaves]. Â Remove from oven before preheating it.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes or at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes. Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.Â Â NotesNever discard the loaf bread if they are not that soft or moist to your liking. Â  It's yummy, delicious [crispy outside and moist inside] when you toast and apply jam and butter to it.

title: Chocolate SoufflÃ© Cake
text: After baking the cottony, soft and moist Orange SoufflÃ© Cake, I was all excited to try this cake with a different flavour.Â  Promised myself, I will try to bake this cake again without any mistakes.Â  So here is my Chocolate SoufflÃ© Cake. Â Â  The cake rose beautifully but shrinks a little because it is low in gluten. Â  The cake is really soft, moist and cottony.Â Â  Probably will try to bake another such cake using lemon.Ingredients3         egg yolk1/2       egg (about 30g)15 gm       sugar [I used 1 tbsp]1/4 tsp    salt50 ml chocolate milk [I used 2 tsp cocoa powder mix with 50 ml hot water and 1 tbsp condensed milk] - cool before useÂ 35 ml vegetable oil [IÂ  used 1 1/2 tbsp]1/4 tsp chocolate paste40 gm       cake flourÂ      - sifted - set aside3         egg white55 gm       sugar [used 3-4 tbsp]1/4 tsp    cream of tartarLine base of a 7" square tin with grease proof paper and wrap it with tin foil.Â  Place it in a bigger square baking tin.Â Preheat oven to 150C.Mix chocolate milk, oil and chocolate paste together.Use a hand whisk mix egg yolks, half egg, sugar and salt together.Add in liquid mixture and whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites and cream of tartar till frothy. Â  Add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/4 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Spoon 1 Tablespoon batter and mix with 1 tsp chocolate paste.Â  Mix well. Pour batter into prepared cake tin.Â  Place it in the bigger cake tin.Â  Drop a few drops of the cocoa batter on top of cake batter.Â  Use a skewer to stir the batter to create a swirl effect pattern on cake.Steam-bake cake in a preheated oven for 55 minutes.Remove cake at once from tin and cool it on a wire rack.Â  Remove all paper linings when cooling cake to prevent vapour at the base and sides.Notes from Happy Flour"The recipe uses less flour which meant that the cake has a low gluten content to maintain it volume after it is baked. In other word the cake will shrink in height and width during cooling, so don't worry. This is a cotton soft moist cake".

title: Tuna Mayo Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: I baked these Spicy Tuna Mayo Buns using sweet bun basic dough recipe [sponge dough method - refer HERE].  These buns are light, fluffy and soft.Â Ingredients for the buns-Sponge Dough Method[makesÂ  10Â  buns]Step 1 - Ingredients2 tsp instant yeast160-170 mlÂ  water230 gm bread flourMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour.Â  Knead to form a smooth dough.Cover and leave to proof for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients60 gm sugar1/4 tsp salt1 small egg [20 gm]25 ml water100 gm bread flour 30 gm butterAdd all Step 2 ingredientsÂ  [except butter] to dough from Step 1.Â  Knead from low speed until well combined.Â  Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes].Â  Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage [Notes - if not baking buns immediately, the dough can be kept in plastic bag tied up and refrigerate.Â Â  Thaw to room temperature before using.Â Â  Advisable to keep up to 48 hours only].Shape dough into a ball.Â  Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down and divide dough in 60 gm per portion or into any portions preferred.Shape dough into round balls.Â  Roll out each ball and fill it 1 tbsp of the tuna mayo filling.Â  Gather the edges together and seal up the seam to shape into a round bun or shape it into an oval shape.Â  Place bun on greased paper casing on a baking tray.Leave to rise for 30-45 minutes or until double in size.Â  Brush with egg/milk glaze. Sprinkle with sesame seeds [Notes - make a few slits on top ofÂ  bun before baking if filling has mayonnaise otherwise the buns may burst with filling].Baked in preheated oven at 190 degrees for 12-15 minutes.Remove to cool on rack.Ingredients for FillingÂ [Spicy Tuna with Mayonnaise]1 can spicy chilli tuna flakes in oil - drain away all the oil and small chilli1 big onion - chopped small pieces3 tbsp mayonaiseFry tuna flakes and onions together until onions are soft and mixture is slightly dry.Remove from pan to cool before adding mayonnaise. Â Combine well, filling is ready for use or refrigerate until required.Note:Filling is enough for 10 buns.

title: How To Make Buns Using Sponge Dough Method
text: Here is a basic bun recipe using sponge dough method which I find good and easy to prepare.Â Â  The dough is easy to handle, the baked buns are soft and light.Â  Just be careful when adding the liquid.Â  Too much liquid [especially when large egg is used] may result in dough being too wet and sticky.Â You can use the bun dough recipe with any fillings and make into any shapes you prefer.Â  Yields about 10-12 buns depending on the shapes.Step 1 - Ingredients2 tsp instant yeast160-170 mlÂ  water230 gm bread flourMix yeast with water in mixing bowl, then add in flour.Â  Knead to form a smooth dough.Cover and leave to proofÂ  for 1-1 1/2 hours or double in size.Step 2 - Ingredients60 gm sugar1/4 tsp salt1/2 tsp yeast 1 small egg25 ml water100 gm bread flour 30 gm butterAdd all Step 2 ingredientsÂ  [except butter] to dough from Step 1.Â  Knead from low speed until well combined.Â  Continue to knead on medium speed until dough is soft and smooth [takes about 7-10 minutes].Â  Add in butter, continue to knead until dough is soft and elastic or window pane stage.Shape dough into a ball.Â  Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutesPunch down and divide into 60gm per portion orÂ  into any portions required.Shape dough into any shapes with fillings.Â  Leave to rise for 30-45 minutes or until double in size.Â  Brush with egg/milk glaze.Baked in preheated oven at 190 degrees for 12-15 minutes.

title: EZ Stir Fry Yee Meen
text: A very simple EZ stir fry yee meen [deep fried yellow noodles] that you can cook at home with some of the ingredients you would have most times in the refrigerator.Ingredients[serves 2]120 gm yee meen [2 pcs] - blanched with hot water to soften - drain in colander50 gm meat - sliced [can replace with chicken meat]100 gm shelled prawns2 stalks choy sum [mustard leaves] - cut [use cabbage if you don't have choy sum]1-2 tsp chopped garlic 2 tbsp oilred chilli shreds and fried shallots - garnishingsambal belacanSeasoning 2 tbsp light soy sauce1-2 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp salt to taste1/4 tsp pepper dash of msg to taste1 cup hot water or stockHeat oil in wok, saute garlic until fragrant.Â  Add in the meat and prawns.Â  Stir fry until prawns are firm.Â Add in vegetables, yee meen and all the seasoning.Â  Stir fry on medium high heat to combine well.Pour in hot water/stock. Stir to combine and bring it to a boil.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Dish out to serve when noodles are cooked and gravy is slightly reduced.Garnish with fried shallots and shredded red chilli.Â  Serve with sambal belacan if prefered.

title: Matcha Spiral Buns [Straight Dough Method]
text: This is a lovely green tea bun recipe from Cheah, [No-Frills Recipes: Red Bean Buns].I used my brown bean sweet paste as filling for the buns. Â  The bun dough was prepared the previous day [kept in the refrigerator] and I was able to bake them the next morning for breakfast - Â served warm, they were soft and moist. Â  Why, I baked it in the early morning - cos' it was raining heavily and I couldn't go for my regular morning exercise. Â So what best to do ...... bake bread.. lol. Â Anyway, the buns were all finished by 8.30 am. Â Some in our tummies and some at my neighbours... Â So I can't tell whether they are soft and moist later..... next time, to update.Oh yes, must be wondering why the shape of the buns are so odd. Â Actually, I tried the spiral way.Ingredients for Matcha Buns[makes 12 buns x 60 gm]300 gm high protein flour - sifted100 gm plain flour - sifted2 tsp green tea powder [beautiful green colour]30 gm caster sugar [I used 2 tbsp]1/2 Â tsp salt1 Â tsp yeast260 ml milk [I used 250 ml]30 gm butter [I used 1 tbsp]Filling - sweet brown bean pastewhite sesame seeds1 egg lightly beaten for egg wash [I used milk]Put all dough ingredients [except butter] in a mixing bowl. Â Knead from low speed until until a soft dough is formed. Â Add in butter. Â Continue to knead from low speed Â for about 5 minutes, then knead on medium high speed for a Â further 5-10 minutes. Â Knead until dough is soft, smooth and elastic [does not stick to fingers when touch or window pane stage].Cover with a piece of damp cloth to prove in a warm place for Â 15 minutes or till dough doubles in size [dough is ready for shaping when an indentation of a finger remains and the dough does not sink].Punch down dough, transfer onto a slightly floured surface and divide dough into 6 portions of 120gm each. Â Shape into balls.Â Roll out a portion into rectangular shape, brush with some melted butter. Â Roll up swiss roll into a log. Â Cut into half. Â Invert one half , flatten it Â and wrap with 1/2 tbsp of filling in the centre. Â Bring the edges together to seal, Â Place seam side down on a lightly greased paper casing in a baking tray. Â Do the same for the remaining portions. Â Leave buns in the oven shelf to rest for 30-35 minutes or until double in size.Brush with egg wash or milk and sprinkle on some sesame seeds if desired.Bake in a preheated oven @ 190 degrees C for about 15 mins. Â Remove from oven to let cool on a wire rack. Â Brush buns with some melted butter.Recipe for brown bean paste, please refer toÂ Sweet Brown Bean Paste.

title: Brown Beans, Black Glutinous Rice Dessert
text: Recipe from a neighbour who loves black glutinous rice dessert but for health reasons came up with this dessert where she adds red beans and gingko nuts.Â  Although a little different from traditional recipe it is still acceptable for a change.Â  Anyway, I used brown beans instead of red beans.Â  The dessert was yummy especially with black glutinous rice, the dessert is slightly thick and creamy when coconut milk is added. Â  She omits the coconut milk but I added it.Ingredients[serves 4-5]150 gm brown beans or red beans - washed and soaked 2-3 hours25 gm glutinous rice - washed and soaked for an houra handful of dried longan Â [optional] - rinsed2 screwpine leaves [pandan leaves] - knotted1.2 litres water80 gm rock sugar to taste100 gm gingko nuts - shelled removed1 tbsp sugar50 ml coconut milk mix with 1/4 tsp salt [refrigerate]Boil water with screwpine leaves.Â  Add in brown beans/red beans and glutinous rice to cook.Bring to a rolling boil for 5-10 minutes.Â  Turn to low heat and simmer until beans and rice are soft and slightly thick.Use another small saucepot, boil gingko nuts with some water for 5-10 minutes.Â  Drain away water and add enough fresh water and 1 tbsp sugar to gingko nuts.Â  Bring it to a boil, cook until gingkoÂ  nuts are soft and sweet [water reduced to thick].Add rock sugar and dried longans to the softened beans and rice.Â  Boil till rock sugar dissolves. Â Taste to adjust the sweetness. Â Â Off heat, cover pot immediately [this is just to plump up the longans, so that they are firm and sweet]. Â Add in gingko nuts to individual bowls when serving. Â Serve hot/warm with coconut milk.I am submitting this post to Aspiring Bakers #20: Asian dessert buffet! (June 2012)Â hosted by Moon of Food Playground

title: Potato Buns [Straight Dough Method]
text: This recipe makes 9 pieces of buns in a 9"x9" square tin.Â Â Â  However, I doubled the quantity to make 25 buns using a 24cm square tin to bake them as I am sharing with my neighbour. Â  The dough is very soft. Â  The next time I will bake just this quantity using the 9" tin as it is easier to handle.These buns are soft and moist. Â  Â Worth tryingRecipe Source - One Publisher - Koleksi RotiIngredients A70 gm castor sugar1/4 tsp salt1 egg40 gm potato flourIngredients B1 1/2 tsp instant yeast150 ml cold waterIngredients C260 gm bread flour1 tbsp skim milk powder60 gm butter egg glaze [I used milk]Custard mix [use instant custard powder mix with some water into a smooth paste]Combine ingredients A and B together, then add in ingredients C.Â  Knead until a soft, smooth dough is formed [about 7-10 minutes]. Â Add in butter.Â  Continue to knead from low speed to combine butter and dough.Then continue to knead dough on medium high speed until it is soft, smooth and elastic.Flour hands and shape dough into a round ball.Â  Cover to let dough rest for 30 minutes or rise to double in size.Punch down, divide dough into 9 equal portions [about 50gm each].Shape into round balls and place in a greased baking tray.Leave dough to rise until double in size.Â  Brush egg glaze/milk on bread dough.Â  Put custard paste in a piping bag.Â  Press custard mix on the surface of each bun in a cross pattern.Bake on middle rack of preheated oven at 180 degrees for 25-30 minutes.

title: MY Belacan Fried Rice
text: Served salad with fried riceThere are various types of fried rice and most are all delicious whichever way they are fried.Â  It's all ones' own preference.Â  It's no exception for the Belacan Fried Rice which comes in many versions and served with various garnishing such as mangoes, cucumber and sometimes fried crackers. Here is my version which to some may not be the best but it can fill our stomachs for an anticipated 'lazy day' dinner. Â I cooked the rice and prepared the ingredients beforehand. Â  Served the rice with my lemony taste vegetable salad.Ingredients[serves 2-3] 150 gm Basmathi rice3 tsp of belacan stock granules [or 2 cm piece prawn paste, toasted]1 tbsp fried shallots1 tbsp each of chopped shallots, garlic,Â chilli paste [cili boh],Â oyster sauce1/2 tsp each of salt1/4 tsp msg and pepper2-3 eggs150 gm shelled prawns1 stalk spring onion, cut small piecesfried shallots and shredded red chilli - garnishing3 tbsp oilÂ Cook rice with belacan and fried shallots in a rice cooker.Â  Allow to cool, fluff up rice, remove and keep rice in the refrigerator overnight if possible.Heat 1 tbsp oil in wok.Â  Add in eggs to fry until slightly firm.Â  Remove.Add in 2 tbsp of oil to saute shallots and garlic until fragrant.Â  Add in chilli paste/boh.Â  Fry until fragrant, add in prawns.Â  Fry till prawns are firm about 2 minutes, then add in the flavoured rice.Stir fry until ingredients are well mixed. Lower heat and add in all the seasoning.Â  Turn back to medium high heat, toss to mix well.Add in the eggs and spring onion.Â  Stir to mix well.Off fire.Â  Dish out to serve.Â  Garnish with fried shallots and red chilli.Click here for other Fried Rice Recipes

title: Lemony Taste Vegetable Salad
text: It's middle of the year, the hot season is around the corner.Â  Despite the current unpredictable weather with ocassional heavy downpours at anytime of the day, the weather is still humid, warm and sometimes unbearable too even in the evenings.So it's time to enjoy a light refreshing salad once in a while instead of stir fry vegetables for lunch or dinner. Â Since I have most of the ingredients in my pantry, this is an easy salad suitable to serve with fried rice.Â  Trying not to sweat it out in a hot kitchen wheneverÂ  possible.. ha..hah.Â  I think it's a healthy salad [cos' it consists of 5 colours].Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 zuchini [about 250 gm] - washed - smashed with a cleaver, remove the seeds and break into smaller bits1 red carrot - cut thin strips1 piece black fungus - soaked and blanched in hot water - cut thin strips100 gm chicken breast/fillet - season with a little salt/pepper - steam or roast to cook - then tear into shredsa handful of agar-agar strips - soaked in cool boiled water - drain and cut into 3 cm lengths some toasted sesame seedsSalad Dressing - Mix together in a bowlJuice of 1 lemon2-3 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp salt1 tsp sesame oil1 tsp white rice vinegar [optional]Put zuchini, carrot, black fungus, agar-agar strips in a big bowl [make sure they are well drained].Â Â  Add in chicken meat.Â  Toss to mix well all the ingredients.Pour salad dressing over vegetables.Â Â  Toss to mix well.Transfer salad to a serving bowl, cover with cling film and refrigerate until serving time.Sprinkle some toasted sesame seeds before serving.

title: Sweet Corn Buns [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Another lovely bun recipe, soft and moist with sweet corn kernels.Â  However, the dough is quite soft and sticky which cannot be rolled.Â Â  It can only be cut and shape into small round balls and baked in round tin foil casings or in paper casings.This quantity yields about 18 buns.Recipe Source - One Publisher - Koleksi Roti [double portion of original recipe]Ingredients for Sponge Dough240 gm bread flour1.5 tsp yeast170 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours.Ingredients for Bread Dough160 gm bread flour40 gm plain flour1 egg [keep 1/2 for egg glaze]4-5 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp salt1/2 tsp yeast30 ml water60 gm butter150 gm sweet corn kernels [drain away water]some mayonnaise and cheddar cheeseÂ Add all the ingredients [except butter] to the sponge dough. Â Knead until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Add in sweet corn kernels. Â Knead a further 5-7 minutes.Shape into a ball [very soft and quite sticky] and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Divide dough into 15gm portions. Â Roll each portion into balls and place 3 in each greased foil casing or paper casings.Â Â  Leave to proof in oven for 1/2 an hour or until double in size.Brush egg glaze, put extra sweet corn kernels or small pieces of cheddar cheese on the surface and press mayonnaise along the joints. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 190-200 degrees C for 15 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Pandan Coconut Chiffon Cake
text: Again I'm saying I liked to follow the chiffon cake recipes in Happy Flour's blog.Â  I also like the quantity of the ingredients used.Â  Even if I failed in my attempt, the loss is worth the try [trying not to waste food ingredients].Â  This is another successful chiffon cake I baked on my first attempt.Â  Very happy and satisfied with it. Â I used my homemade pandan paste. Â The aroma of the cake Â was lovely.Ingredients3 egg yolksÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1-2 tbsp castor sugar1-2 tbsp corn oil1/4 tsp salt2 tbsp pandan juice [I omit]2 tsp pandan paste 70 ml coconut milkÂ Note: Can substitute these 3 ingredients with pandan essence, coconut mix and colouring90 gm plain flour - sifted with 1/8 tsp baking powder3 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 tbsp castor sugarBeat  together egg yolks and sugar in a mixing bowl with a hand whisk until  blended.Â  Slowly add in oil andÂ  continue whisking until well combined.Â   Slowly drizzle in pandan juice, pandan paste and coconut milk.Â  Continue to whisk until light and creamy.Â  Fold  in sifted plain flour until well incorporated.Â  Set aside.Put egg white in cake mixer bowl [make sure bowl  is clean and ungreased].Â  Whisk egg whites until a little frothy, add in  cream of tartar, continue whisking until foamy and add in sugar in 3  batches.Â  Keep whisking egg white mixture till soft peaks formed.Preheat oven at 175 degrees Celsius.Â  Fold in 1/3  of meringue to egg yolk mixture. Mix evenly until well combined. Then  pour into rest of egg meringue.Â  Fold until evenly combined.Â  Pour batter  into 7 inch ungreased chiffon pan.Â  Smooth the top with a spatula. Tap pan on table top several times to release trapped air.Baked in preheated oven [lower rack] for 35 - 40 minutes.Â Invert baked cake immediately to cool completely before removing from pan.Note:For the Homemade Pandan Paste, blend 10-15 pieces pandan leaves with 1/2 cup water. Â Strain over sieve twice and discard the blended leaves after pressing out the pandan juice. Â Store pandan juice in container for 5 days in the fridge.Â  The residue at the bottom is the pandan paste and the light colour water on top can be used as pandan juice. Â  Keeps up to 2 weeks.

title: Orange SoufflÃ© Cake
text: Must thank Happy Flour for sharing this lovely feather light Orange SoufflÃ© Cake.Â  The cake is really soft, moist and cottony.Â  Never expect that it is quite easy to prepare [almost similar to chiffon cake but less gluten].Â  Shrinks a little after cooling as advised by Happy Flour.Â  I'm quite satisfied with the result being the first time.Â  The only problem was my timer failed to work this time and I wasn't sure whether I had baked the cake for the 55 minutes. Â Could have baked less then 55 minutes as the sides of the cake weren't brownish.Â  My other mistake was I forgot to wrap baking tin with tin foil. Â  Â Probably will bake this lovely cake again. Â Was wondering if I can use lemon instead of orange.For more details on this cake, please check it out at Happy Flour: Orange SoufflÃ© Cake.Ingredients3         egg yolk1/2       egg (about 30g)15 gm       sugar [I used 1 tbsp]1/4 tsp    salt50 ml       orange juice1 tsp      orange zest35 ml vegetable oil [IÂ  used 1 1/2 tbsp]1/4 tsp orange paste       [I omit as I don't have it]40 gm       cake flourÂ      - sifted - set aside3         egg white55 gm       sugar [used 3-4 tbsp]1/4 tsp    cream of tartarLine base of a 7" square tin with grease proof paper and wrap it with tin foil.Â  Place it in a bigger square baking tin.Â Preheat oven to 150C.Mix orange juice, zest, oil and orange paste together.Use a hand whisk mix egg yolks, half egg, sugar and salt together.Add in liquid mixture and whisk until well combined.Fold in sifted flour and stir until batter is smooth.Use a cake mixer, whisk egg whites and cream of tartar till frothy. Â  Add in the sugar in 3 batches and whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/4 of the meringue into the egg yolk mixture until combined.Â Â  Then fold in the rest of the meringue lightly in two portions until well combined.Pour batter into prepared cake tin.Â  Place it in the bigger cake tin.Steam-bake cake in a preheated oven for 50-55mins.Remove cake at once from tin and cool it on a wire rack.Notes from Happy Flour"The recipe uses less flour which meant that the cake has a low gluten content to maintain it volume after it is baked. In other word the cake will shrink in height and width during cooling, so don't worry. This is a cotton soft moist cake".

title: Pumpkin Loaf Bread II [Sponge Dough Method]
text: This is another version of pumpkin loaf bread which is also good and worth a keeper. Â I still prefer the sponge dough method as it yields loaf bread which remains soft for 2-3 days if kneaded to window pane stage.Â Added some wholemeal flour to this recipe, too.Â Â Â  Pumpkin can also be substituted with orange sweet potato. Â The recipe yields 2 loaves of bread weighing 550gm each.IngredientsÂ for Sponge Dough300 gm bread flour2 tsp instant yeast230 - 250 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours. Â Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough250 gm bread flour50 gm wholemeal flour3 tbsp sugar1 tsp Â salt1 egg200 gm pumpkin puree50 ml water [I did not add water]50 gm butter [2 tbsp]Add all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the sponge dough. Â Knead until well combined, then gradually add in water [if necessary] while kneading until a soft dough is formed. Â Knead for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth, elastic and dough does not stick to the fingers [about 15 minutes on high speed] or to window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double in size. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Bubur Pulut Hitam With Durian
text: Normally, Bubur Pulut Hitam sweet dessertÂ  [black glutinous rice sweet dessert] is served with thick coconut milk.Â  Sometime ago,Â  a colleague of mine from Singapore told me that this dessert taste good with durian instead of coconut milk.Â  I cooked this before but did not post the recipe and was planning to do soÂ  when the king of fruits is back.Â Â  Myself, I like it both ways.The local durian season is now on in Penang.Â  My hubby bought a few fruits and it's quite costly at the moment because it's just the beginning.Â  I reserved some to cook this dessert again.Â  Just to enjoy..lol.Â  The durian smell wasn't that strong when you are savouring it.Â  It is stronger when someone else is eating it nearby... Unbelievable.Ingredients[serves 4-5]100 gm black glutinous rice - washed2 pieces screwpine leaves [pandan leaves] - washed and knotted6 cups of water100 - 120 gm sugar 100 - 150 gm durian flesh - mashed slightly into a rough pastePut rice, pandan leaves and water in a pot.Â  Bring to boil and cook until rice is soften and cooked [when cooked, the water is reduced and the rice is thick and sticky].Â  Then add in sugar to taste.Â  Add in durian flesh.Â  Stir to mix well.Â  Off fire.Serve dessert warm or hot.Notes:The black glutinous rice is from Kelantan.Â  Very good quality, not husky and cooks fast.Â  Naturally sticky when soft and cooked.

title: QQ Glutinous Flour Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: Thanks to Vivian Pang for sharing this recipe.Â  Really a good loaf bread recipe and an additional flour option.Â  I used the overnight dough method to bake this bread. Â The loaf was still soft on the second day but slightly dry. Â We toasted it, it was lovely with butter and jam and a cup of hot beverage.The recipe here makes 2 loaves.Â  The ingredients and method is slightly different from Vivian's.Ingredients for Overnight Dough200 gm bread flour100 gm glutinous rice flour1 tsp instant yeast [first time trying, I used 1.5 tsp]150 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours. Â Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour1 tbsp skimmed milk powder2 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp Â salt1 egg120-150 ml water60 gm butterÂ Add all the ingredients [except butter] to the overnight dough. Â Knead [from low speed to medium] until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Knead a further 5-10 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reach the rim of the baking tin. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make smaller loaves]. Â Remove from oven before preheating it.Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees C for 40 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Claypot Braised Fried Yee Meen
text: Sunday is usually a 'Noodle' day for me especially when I have several household chores to do or when I am doing some baking.Â  It is a One Dish Meal with least preparation, cooking and cleaning up.Â  Since I am baking a cake and making the glutinous rice wrap and roll, preparing noodles for dinner will be just nice for me.Â  I may still have time to 'look see, look see' at the shopping mall or do some blogging, lol...Ingredients[serves 2-3]2-3 pieces fried yee meen [store bought - either fine or broad type]* or enough for 2-3 persons* blanched in hot water to remove excess oil, drain in colander, set aside 100 gm shelled prawns *100 gm pork slices **marinate separately with a dash of salt, pepper and sesame oilsome crabmeat - optional [I added crabmeat as I have them in my fridge]1 tbsp chopped garlic3 dried Chinese mushrooms - soaked till soft and sliced thinly2 stalks of mustard leaves [choy sum] washed and cut into 3cm lengthssome sliced red chilli in soy sauce or ready sambal belacan1 tbsp oilGravy700 mlÂ  hot water1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 - 3/4 tsp salt to taste1/2 tsp sugar [optional]1/4 tsp each of msg* and pepper* I used original Ajinomoto 19091-2 tbsp cornflour + 2 tbsp water for thickening Heat oil in a pan [I used claypot] over medium fire.Â  Saute garlic until fragrant, add in meat and cook for a few seconds.Â  Add in prawns and cook until prawns are firm.Pour in hot water and add in all seasoning to taste.Â Â  Bring to a boil again before adding yee meen and mustard leaves.Â  Thicken gravy with cornflour mix when it boils again.Â  Scoop up prawns and meat to the top.Serve immediately with chillies or sambal belacan.

title: Sweet Brown Bean Buns [Gelatinized Dough]
text: I made some sweet bean paste using brown beans instead of red beans. Preparation is not that difficult.  With this portion of ingredients, I can get about 350gm of the sweet bean paste which is enough for the portion gelatinized dough.  Please refer to this post for the dough recipe Pandan Coconut Buns [Gelatinized Dough Method.Brown BeansÂ Ingredients for Brown Bean Paste100 gm brown beans2 pandan leaves - knotted 100 gm dark brown sugar400 ml water or enough to cook beans until tender1 tbsp butterBoil brown beans with pandan leaves in a pot with water until very tender. Â Cool and discard pandan leaves .Â  Blend the soft beans in a processor until fine. Â Add a little water if necessary.Â  Blended them in several batches for easier handling.Place blended ingredients in a heavy based pan. Â Stir continuously to reduce the Â water. Â Cooked until Â paste still slightly dry but moist.Â  Add in sugar.Â  Continue to stir and paste is almost dry again.Add in butter. Â Continue to stir fry until paste is Â smooth and shiny but not dry.Dish out and cool before storing.Â Â Use paste as filling for buns.Note:Filling enough to makes about 22-24 buns. Â  How to shape these buns [See above 3 photos]Â Â Verdict - these buns are soft and moist.Â  With the homemade sweet brown bean paste, it is not that sweet.

title: Steamed Fish With Miso
text: There is a tub of Japanese miso in my fridge. Â  Since I haven't bought a new bottle of preserved soya bean paste [taucheong] to steam fish, I used it as a substitute. Â It turned out good as it is not too salty and the colour is lighter than taucheong. Â Guess I can try to use miso in other recipes that require taucheong.I used this steaming sauce to steam fish [this fish is from my hubby's fishing trip a week ago and its still very fresh].Â Â  A really tasty dish.Â Â  I do not know the name of this fish.Â  Can anyone tell me what is the name of this fish? Â My hubby found the name is Mahogany Snapper [he called it dark spot fish].Â Ingredients for Steaming Sauce1 tbsp each of chopped garlic and ginger1 red chilli - seeded and chopped [keep some for garnishing]Â 1 stalk spring onion - cut small pieces [keep some for garnishing]1 tbsp miso paste1 tsp oyster sauce1 tsp sugara dash of pepper 1 tsp oil1/2 tsp sesame oilHeat pan with oil to saute garlic, ginger, spring onion and chilli until aromatic. Â Add in miso paste. Â Stir fry for a few seconds on low heat. Â Add in seasoning to taste. Â  Dish out.1 fish - cleaned and keep whole -about 300 gm1 cabbage leave - washed, break into smaller piecesand blanched to soften [use to line steaming plate]Place cabbage leave on steaming plate. Â Put a little steaming sauce on top of cabbage leave followed by the fish. Spread rest of steaming sauce on top of fish.Steam fish over boiling water on high heat for 10-12 minutes [depending on size of fish] or until cooked through. Â Garnish with spring onions and chilli. Â Serve immediately.

title: Seaweed, Tofu and Minced Meat Soup
text: It may not be the best soup but it can still be tasty to our taste buds. Â Moreover, it is simple, healthy, quick to cook and cheap [not more than Ringgit 2.00].Â  So much better when served steaming hot in a claypot with rice.Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 piece tofu - cut into 6 or 8 cubes50 gm minced meat - marinate with light soy sauce, sesame oil, pepper and cornflour1/4 piece of seaweed - wash and drain of water in a colander500 ml water or 3 rice bowls1 tsp tung choy - rinse1/4 tsp saltmsg and pepper to tastesome spring onion - choppedsome garlic crisps [optional]Bring water and tung choy [preserved salted vegetable] to boil in soup pot [I used claypot].Â  When boiling, drop in the minced meat [not necessary meatballs] using a spoon. Â Boil soup for a few minutes or until aromatic.Add in tofu cubes.Â  Let the soup comes to a boil again while you add in seasoning to taste.Â  Lastly add in seaweed.Â  Give it a stir.Â  Off fire once the soup boils again.Before serving, add in spring onions and fried garlic crisps [if preferred].Serve soup immediately.Note:Add seaweed just before serving otherwise you may get 'purplish' coloured soup.

title: Cappuccino Vanilla Yoghurt Chiffon Cake
text: Was planning to bake this chiffon cake when I bought this yoghurt. Â Then I saw Wendy's Topo Map Love cake pattern which looks so unique and interesting. Â I know it won't be that soon I will bake the Topo Map Love cake. Â So without hesitation, I used part of her idea to create those dark lines in this cake too. Â  Can't compare with Wendy's but at least I know the effect, haha! Â Â The cake texture is good. Â  Light, moist and taste yummy.Â  My hubby asked to reserve the last 2 slices for him.Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture4 large egg yolks2 tbsp castor sugar4 tbsp corn oil1/2 tsp salt100 ml capuccino vanilla yoghurt with Nata Coco 120 gm plain flour + 1/2 tsp baking powder - siftedWhisk egg yolks with castor sugar till creamy and add in corn oil [1 tbsp at a time]. Â Mix well after each addition. Â Then add in yoghurt. Â Mix well, fold in flour until well combined. Â Set aside. Â Preheat oven at 170 degrees C for 10 minutes. Meanwhile prepare the meringue.Ingredients - Egg White Mixture4 large egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 tbsp caster sugarSome chocolate powder - optional - to form thin lines in the cakeWhisk egg white in a clean mixing bowl till frothy, then add in cream of tartar. Continue beating for a second and add in caster sugar gradually. Â Continue beating all the time till soft peaks formed [Note - it is easier to fold in soft peak egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture. Â Do not overbeat meringue]Fold in 1/3 the egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture until well combined. Â Then fold into the rest of egg white mixture. Â Fold until mixtures are well combined.Â Â Pour 1/3 portion into 7" chiffon pan, sieve in unevenly a layer of cocoa powder.Â  Top with another 1/3 portion of mixture and sieve in another layer of cocoa powder and pour in balance mixture.Â  Smooth the surface with a spatula.Â  Tap pan several times on table top to release trapped air bubbles.Â Bake in preheated oven for 40 minutes on lower rack. Â Remove from oven and immediately invert pan to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Glutinous Rice Wrap Rolls
text: Is this consideredÂ  'Dim Sum', rice roll or dumplings, I do not know. Â  Anyway, it is edible 'wrap and roll' that are filled with delicious treasures.The rolls are very flavourful.Â  When fried the glutinous rice is soft and QQ.Â Â  Nice.Ingredients[makes 20-22 rolls]300 gm glutinous rice - wash and soak in water overnight1 tsp salt1 tbsp oil1 piece beancurd skin [cut into rectangular pieces of about 10cm x 15cm]enough oil for deep frying [fry in several batches to reduce the quantity of oil required] Filling100 gm char siew - store bought - diced100 gm tender lean pork - diced100 gm chicken breast - diced4 shitake mushrooms - soaked and diced1 small carrot - diced1 tsp each of oyster sauce, sugar, light soy sauce and wine1/4 tsp each of salt and pepper to taste1/2 cup water or stockDrain soaked rice. Â Line a steaming tray withe muslin cloth. Â Pour in rice and steam for about an hour or until rice is soft and cooked. Â Remove from heat and add in salt and oil. Â Mix well and set aside.Heat 1/2 tbsp oil in a wok. Â Stir fry the lean pork, chicken meat, mushroom and carrot. Â Fry for a few seconds. Â Add in seasoning and water. Â Simmer until the filling is almost dry, then add in the char siew. Â Fry for a few seconds to combine ingredients.Mix the filling with glutinous rice. Â Combine well.Place some filling in the middle of each beancurd skin. Â Fold in the sides and roll up. Â Do the same until the ingredients are all used up.Heat enough oil in wok and deep fry dumplings/rolls until golden brown [I shallow fry the rolls in batches on medium heat].Drain well on kitchen paper and serve hot [plain or with mayonnaise/chilli sauce].I'm submitting submitting this post toÂ Small Small Baker: Aspiring Bakers #19: Dim Sum Affair (May 2012)Â Â  hosted by SSB of Small Small Baker.                document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src=http://www.inlinkz.com/cs.php?id=148181&' + new Date().getTime() + '"><\/script>');

title: Makeover Roast Duck Meat Rice
