text: With some roast duck meat left in the refrigerator, I thought it would be good to add some tasty sauce to it.Â  Then steam it with cooked rice to make a 'One Dish Meal'.Â  To me, this steamed duck rice tasted better than the duck rice sold at the hawker's stall.Â Â  Definitely more duck meat, lol....Ingredients[serves 2-3] 1/2 roast duck breast - chopped bite size pieces [deboned - optional]1 roast duck drumstick - chopped bite size pieces [deboned - optional]1 tsp each chopped garlic and ginger1 tbsp sesame oil some shredded carrot and spring onions Seasoning Sauce [mix together]1 tbsp Hoisin Sauce [Sweet Sauce]1 -2 tbsp sugar to taste2 tbsp apple cider vinegar1 tbsp dark soy sauce salt to taste1/2 - 3/4 cup water 1 tsp cornflour + 2 tsp water - for thickening Cooked rice enough for 2-3 personsHeat sesame oil in wok to saute garlic and ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in duck meat.Â  Stir fry for a few seconds.Â  Add in seasoning sauce.Â Â  Quickly stir fry to combine well.Pour in water.Â  Bring to a boil and lower heat to simmer for 5 minutes.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Add cornflour mix to thicken the gravy.Â  Dish out to serve, garnishing with shredded carrot and spring onions.Â  Serve with rice or as One Dish Meal.For One Dish Meal - Steamed Roast Duck Meat RicePut enough rice in individual serving dish [best with cover].Â Â  Arrange duck meat pieces over rice with enough gravy.Â  Before serving, cover serving dish and steam rice over boiling water on high heat for about 20 minutes or until rice is hot.Â  Remove from steamer, garnish with spring onions and carrot.Â  Serve immediately.Note:I served this One Dish Meal with a vegetable dish - Stir fry Cabbage with tomatoes.

title: Home Baked Soft Buns [Straight Dough Method]
text: This bun recipe is from Kitchen Corner [I tried before and has kept the recipe for sometime] is suitable for plain buns or other buns with any fillings you like.Â Â  The buns are soft, light and fluffy for 1-3 days.I doubled the quantity to make 18 small buns in 2 trays.Â  The dough was not sticky and easy to handle.Â  Best of all I can prepare the dough a day ahead of baking by keeping it in an airtight container. Thaw it to room temperature [about 10-15 minutes] and I can make the buns. Ingredients[makes 8-9 small buns] 200 gm bread flour1 tbsp skimmed milk powder1.5 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt2/3 tsp instant yeast120-125 ml water [add gradually]1 tbsp butteregg glazetoasted sesame seeds [optional] Â Mix all ingredients [except butter] together and knead [from low speed to medium high speed]Â  into a soft dough [about 7-10 minutes].Â  Add in butter and continue to knead until smooth and elastic.Â  This takes about 7-10 minutes.Â  Form dough into a round ball, cover dough and leave to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough to release air and divide into 9 portions [about 35-40 gm].Â  Roll into a smooth ball [or add fillings and make into any shapes] and place in baking tray [7"x7"x3"].Â  Leave to proof for about 1 hour or double in size.Â  Brush buns with beaten egg or milk and sprinkle toasted sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees Celsius for 15-20 minutes.Â  Cool on rack before storing in airtight container or plastic wrap.Note:I doubled the portion but baked on 2 different days in 2 different shapes - round and oblong.Â Â Â  For the fillings, I use up some of my leftover fillings from earlier bakings.Â  These buns have various fillings - sambal dried prawns, coconut, cheddar cheese withÂ  raisins and meat floss.Â Â  The dough can also be used to bake buns with various toppings like Mexico buns, milk crisps buns and cheese/parsley etc.

title: Yudane Bread
text: This  is a good loaf bread recipe worth baking for the family. Soft, moist and  light bread.Â  Bread texture is good, very similar to 'Roti Benggali'.Â  You can add other ingredients like raisins, linseed, walnut etc.Â  Or slit the top after proofing and top with grated cheddar cheese and granulated sugar.Â  Thanks to Hidehide for sharing this recipe. Â IngredientsÂ [makes 2 loaves]Prepare Yudane180 gm bread flour150 ml hot waterÂ Mix ingredients into a dough with a pair of chopstick.Â  Leave covered for 1 hour [must be cooled].Bread Ingredients420 gm bread flourÂ  9 tsp skimmed milk powder3 tbsp castor sugarÂ 1.5 tsp saltÂ 3.5 tsp instant yeastÂ  260 ml warm water2 tbsp [30 gm] butterAdd prepared yudane to bread ingredients [except butter].Â  Knead together into a soft and smooth dough [takes about 10 minutes], then add in butter.Â Â  Continue to knead for another 10 minutes, until dough is soft, smooth and elastic.Form dough into a ball and coat lightly with flour. Â  Cover to proof for  about 15 minutes or until double in size.Punch  down dough and roll into a ball.Â  Divide dough into 2 portions [for 2  loaves]. Take 1 portion, roll flat in rectangular shape, fold to centre  from left and right, then roll flat into a long rectangular shape.Â  Roll  up swiss roll, seal the edges and put into a greased Pullman's tin.Â   Leave to proof for 1 - 1 1/2 hours [or until it rises to 80% of the tin].Â   Do the same for the other portion.Preheat  oven at 180 degrees C and bake bread on lower rack for about 25-30  minutes.Â  Remove bread from oven and baking tin immediately to cool on  rack before storing.

title: Apple and Figs Jam
text: Another tasty jam [sweet sourish flavour] from Amy Beh's collection that I have prepared sometime ago.Â  I made this jam again and would like to share with those interested to make their own preserves.Â  Probably, I will use some to bake a chiffon cake like the one with Red Plums Jam.Ingredients[makes aÂ  bottle and a half x 400 gm]450 gm Granny's Smith green apples [about 5 apples] - remove skin and chopped finely50 gm figs - soaked and chopped small piecesRind of 1 orange250 ml water 200 gm sugarPlace all ingredients [except sugar] in a pan. Â Bring it to a boil and lower heat to cook until fruits are soften [I blend it a little to get a finer texture] and water reduced.Add in sugar and continue to simmer. Â Stir occasionally to mix ingredients well. Â In the meantime, place a small saucer in the freezer to chilled [for testing if jam is ready]. Â Simmer until it gels up. Â Place a teaspoon of jam on saucer. Â Leave in fridge for a few minutes and jam should be ready if it forms a mass.Store in sterilised airtight bottles.Â  Always refrigerate jam as homemade jams are without preservatives.Chiffon cake using homemade apple figs jam

title: EZ Kelantan's Nasi Dagang
text: Whenever we travelled to Kelantan, Malaysia, the one local food which we will never miss is their 'Nasi Dagang'.Â  A rice served most commonly with fish curry [Curry Ikan Tongkol], fresh vegetables [ulam] and fish crackers [keropok ikan].Â  My hubby will buy this special rice called 'beras lembut' [soft rice] which has a brownish tinge that is the original rice used to cook Nasi Dagang.My pantry always has this special rice and I can cook it whenever I want to.Â  There are of course many versions of cooking this aromatic rice but I try to stick to the easiest without coconut milk being use.Â  This time, I am cooking it with natural yoghurt.Â  The one main ingredient is the fenugreek.Â  Without it, it is not Nasi Dagang. Â  The rice is aromatic and flavourful.Â  I am cooking a prawn curry with some vegetables [Prawn Curry With Vegetables]Â  to serve with this rice.Fry rice with shallots, ginger and fenugreekIngredients150 gm Kelantan Nasi Dagang - beras lembut - washed and drain.Â  Set aside2 shallots - sliced thinly1 cm piece ginger - shredded1 tsp fenugreek1cup water or enough to cook rice [rice may need less water]2 tbsp yoghurt1/2 tsp saltHeat oil in wok to saute shallots and ginger until aromatic.Â  Add in fenugreek and rice.Â  Stir fry to mix well.Â  Add in salt.Transfer fried rice to rice cooker and water together with yoghurt to cook or steam rice in steaming tray for 25-30 minutes.Â  Leave for 10 minutes before fluffing up to serve with curry and any vegetables preferred.Keep rice warm until serving time.

title: Prawn Curry With Vegetables
text: This prawn curry with some vegetables is cooked to serve with Kelantan's Nasi Dagang [EZ Kelantan's Nasi Dagang]Â  as a complete meal.Â Â  If you are a curry lover, the rice and curry should be able to satisfy your appetite.Â  Eat with your fingers, it should leave a nice aroma for awhile.Ingredients[serves 2-3]7-8 medium to large prawns - shell intact5-6 ladies' fingers - cut half7-8 french beans -Â  break into 3 pieces1 big onion - cut wedges1 tomato - cut wedges4-5 tofu puffs 1 red chilli and 1 green chilli - cut wedges [optional]1 lemongrass - optional 1 sprig curry leaves - optional3 tbsp oil1 cup waterÂ 2 tbsp yoghurtSpice Ingredients [blend and combine]1 large onion2 cloves garlic1 cm piece ginger2 tbsp fish curry powder1 tbsp chilli boh1/4 tsp tumeric powder1 tbsp ground almondsalt and sugar to tasteÂ Â Saute spices until oil risesAdd water, bring to boil before adding vegetables and prawnsHeat oil in wok, saute spice ingredients, lemongrass and curry leaves until aromatic.Â  Add in 1 tsp salt and sugar.Â  Fry until oil rises.Pour in water.Â  Bring it to a boil, then add in the vegetables to cook for a minute.Add in prawns and tofu puffs.Â  Let it boil until prawns are cooked.Â  Add in yoghurt.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Dish out curry once the prawns and vegetables are cooked.Â  Garnish with fresh mint leaves.Â Â  Serve hot with rice.

title: Happy Flour: Raisins Bread Pudding with Crumble Topping
text: While browsing through Happy Flour blog, I was attracted to her bread pudding recipe that uses only 1 egg and moreover with crumble topping. Â  Since I have several slices of my Walnut Loaf left, I set my mind to finish off the bread by making it into a pudding.Â Â  This portion is enough for 2-3 persons.I like it Â because the quantity is small, the ingredients are easily available and theÂ methodÂ is simple. Â Best of all, I can prepare it ahead of serving time and the freshly baked, warm bread pudding is ready within 20 minutes. Â My hubby loves it.Â  I reduced the sugar a little as I added more raisins and sultanas.Â  Afraid it maybe too sweet.For the recipe, please hop over toÂ Happy Flour: Raisins Bread Pudding with Crumble Topping

title: Pumpkin Paste for Buns/Paus
text: An easy way to prepare the pumpkin paste for either steamed paus or baked buns. This quantity is enough for the 12-14 pumpkin buns [300 gm flour].  Please refer to the Pumpkin Buns [Straight Dough Method]  for the Pumpkin Buns recipe.Ingredients300 gm pumpkin puree50 gm brown sugar1/2 tbsp butter Steamed pumpkin wedges [more than 300 gm] for 30 minutes or until soft. Cool for awhile. Scrap out the pumpkin flesh into bowl and mash till smooth. Discard the skin.Â Put 300 gm puree and sugar in a non stick pan. Cook on low heat until sugar dissolves [about 5-7 minutes].Â Continue stirring the paste until almost dry but moist, then add in butter [about 5-7 minutes].Â Continue stirring until paste is smooth, almost dry and shiny.Â Cool before storing for use. Note:Pumpkin paste must be cooked thoroughly otherwise it may not keep long.

title: Family Style Sesame Oil Ginger Meatballs
text: This is our family recipe since my Grandma's time. Â A very simple pork recipe with only 2 main ingredients - shredded ginger and minced meat [even better if you minced your own].Â A dish suitable for confinement ladies and all who loves the aroma of sesame oil and ginger.Â  In Penang, with the Ghee Hiang Sesame Oil, this dish is even more flavourful Â together with good quality soy sauce.Update: Another quite similar dish using eggs too.Â  Refer this post.Ingredients300 gm minced meat [with some fats]4-5 tbsp of finely shredded ginger4-5 tbsp sesame oil4 tbsp light soy sauce2 tsp dark soy sauce3/4 cup water1 tsp sugar to tasteHeat sesame oil in wok to saute ginger until aromatic and slightly crispy.  Remove a little, set aside as garnishing.Add in light soy sauce, dark soy sauce, sugar and water.  Bring it to a boil.  Taste to adjust seasoning.Form minced meat into a tablespoon size meatballs and drop them into boiling sauce.  Leave to cook for awhile before stirring [to avoid meatballs from breaking apart].Dish out cooked  meatballs and gravy onto a bowl.  Garnish with fried ginger.  Serves well with rice or porridge.

title: Mah Lai Koh - Dark Coloured Version
text: This is a lovely Mah Lai Koh recipe which I have kept for umpteen years [about 15-20 years].Â  If I remembered correctly this is one of Amy Beh's recipe in the newspaper.Â  I purposely bought my first bamboo basket because of this cake.Â  Have been using it so often until finally it 'died' of old age.Â  Then, I bought a replacement but of different quality [cheaper type] which I did not like so I stopped making this cake.Â Since making the Ma Lai Koh [light coloured version] which I don't really fancy.Â  I have this urge to make this dark version cake to share eventhough I know there are many who may have this similar recipe.Â  I make use of a smaller bamboo steaming tray and steamed the balance batter using jelly moulds.Â Ingredients - A150 gm plain flour - sifted2 tbsp sugar1 tsp instant yeast75 ml lukewarm waterMix all ingredients well until smooth. Â Keep in a container with tight lid for at least 12 hours or overnight [My opinion, this step is very important, the texture of the steamed cake depends on how well this yeast dough rises].Ingredients - B180 - 200 gm castor sugar35 gm custard powder - sifted to with35 gm high protein flour/strong flour2 tbsp milk powderIngredients - C5 eggs beaten lightly with a fork150 ml corn oil2 tsp alkaline waterIngredients - C1 1/2 tsp baking powder1/2 - 3/4 tsp bicarbonate of sodaa 20 cm bamboo basket or 20 jelly mouldsLine bamboo basket with parchment paper or line jelly moulds with paper casings.Place risen dough in the mixing bowl of a food processor. Â Using a dough blade, blend well with sugar then add in sifted dry ingredients [custard powder, flour and milk powder]. Â Continue to mix until well combined.Change dough blade to a balloon whisk. Â Add in beaten eggs gradually while beating. Â Whisk till batter is creamy and light [about 10 minutes on high speed]. Â  Â Batter must not be lumpy at this stage. Â Drizzle in oil, then alkaline water. Â Continue to mix well. Â Lastly sift in baking powder and bicarbonate of soda. Â Mix well.Cover and leave batter to rise for at least 2 hours.Pour batter into prepared basket or moulds. Â Steam over rapid boiling water on high heat for 40 minutes Â [bamboo basket] and 20-25 minutes [for small moulds].Note:I used a 18 cm bamboo basket and 10 jelly moulds.Â  I think it is best to steam in a 20 cm bamboo basket for 40-45 minutes.Steamed food/kuihs do not keep long in humid temperatures/warm weather.Â  Best to finish within 1-2 days otherwise keep in airtight container and refrigerate.Â  Thaw to room temperature before serving.

title: EZ Home Style Siew Mai
text: Siew Mai is my favourite Dim Sum item which I will definitely go for when I am at the Dim Sum outlets. One portion is never enough. Â I did make siew mai once in awhile when I have available 2 main ingredients [water chestnuts and suitable wantan skin]. The wantan skin sold at the wet market nearby my house is rather thick and at times uneven. Â Here I tried using the Japanese Gyoza pastry skin for a change. Â  Meat and prawns are not a problem.Â I'm submitting submitting this post toÂ Small Small Baker: Aspiring Bakers #19: Dim Sum Affair (May 2012)Â Â  hosted by SSB of Small Small Baker.Ingredients[makes about 22 - 24 pieces]150 gm prawns - shelled and minced coarsely350 gm minced meat with some fats [minced coarsely]70 gm water chestnuts - chopped finely1 tbsp each of chopped spring onionsÂ 22-24 pieces of round wantan skin [I used Japanese Gyoza skin - store bought]Seasoning1/2 tsp each of salt and sugar1 tsp pepperÂ 1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp sesame oil1 egg white 1 tsp cooking wine [optional]Â  1 tbsp water2 tbsp tapioca flour1/3 carrot - finely grated or scrap using a spoon - toppingMix prawns and meat with all seasoning ingredients [except carrot] in a bowl. Stir in one direction until gluten develops.Â  Add in water chestnuts and spring onions.Â  Continue stirring until all ingredients are well combined.Â Â Take the mixture and slap it against the side of the bowl for 10-15 times until the mixture looks slightly shiny [ this process will make the meat firmer].For easy wrapping, setÂ  aside the mixture in the fridge for at least 1 hour.Place a wrapper in your palm and heap 1 tablespoon of mixture in the centre.Squeeze a section of the wrapper gently between your forefinger and thumb to shape the siew mai.Using a palette knife, add some meat to the hole between the forefinger and thumb until it covers the top of the siew mai.Â  Then lightly pat the bottom so that it fills up nicely.Place the siew mai in a tray lined with parchment paper [prevent sticking].Â  Place some grated carrot on each siew mai as garnishing.Steam siew mai over boiling water for 10-15 minutes.Â  Serve immediately.                document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src=http://www.inlinkz.com/cs.php?id=148181&' + new Date().getTime() + '"><\/script>');

title: Walnut Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: Another of my regular loaf bread recipe which I would like to keep in this blog for reference and making. Â Verdict - Soft, moist and has the flavour of walnut.Â  Stays good even on the third day.Ingredients for Overnight Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour3 tsp instant yeast [actual is 3.5 tsp]250 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours. Â Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour [I used 270 gm bread flour and 30 gm wholemeal flour]2 tbsp milk powder3 tbsp sugar1 tsp Â salt150 gm chopped walnuts150 ml water [keep some first, if all is used, the dough may be sticky and difficult to handle]60 gm butter [I used about 50 gm]Add all the ingredients [except butter and walnuts] to the overnight dough. Â Knead until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Add in Â walnuts. Â Knead a further 3-5 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers or window pane stage.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reach the rim of the baking tin]. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves]. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: EZ Fragrant Sauce Pork Belly
text: The original recipe [which I copied years ago] uses pork ribs that has to be deep fried and and then braised.Â  I followed the recipe 100% when I was not that 'health conscious', but now, I prefer not to deep fry meat before cooking with sauce.Â  When I need to deep fry, I will do it in batches so that not much oil is needed. Â Of course, it will be time consuming and put you off from cooking the dish.Anyway, instead of deep frying pork ribs, I used pork belly and Â pan fry method before braising in fragrant sauce. Â This way, I can keep my kitchen clean too. Â The end result of the makeover- yummy, delicious that goes well with steaming hot white riceIngredientsÂ 500 gm pork belly - washed and cut into bite size pieces - marinade with 1 piece fermented red beancurd [nam yee] and 1 tbsp Shaoxing wine for at least 1/2 hour [overnight in the fridge is alright]Braising Sauce Ingredients - Combine together1 1/2 tbsp sugar [can reduce a little]1/2 tsp pepper1/4 tsp msg1 tsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tsp Shaoxing wine250 ml water [enough to cover meat]Heat up wok with a little oil [optional]. Â Spread out pork belly pieces in wok to pan fry till slightly brown.Â Â Â  Turn over once to pan fry the other side.Pour in combined sauce ingredients. Â Stir fry to combine meat and sauce ingredients well for a minutes. Â Then add in enough water to cook meat.Bring it to a rolling boil, reduce heat, cover and simmer for 40-45 minutes or until meat is just tender and gravy is slightly thick.Note:I set aside half portion to use for steaming rice for my One Dish Meal.Â  I just need to prepare a salad or simple vegetable stir fry or soup to go with it.I'm submitting this to Red Meats Feast hosted by MySpicyKitchen.

title: Pumpkin Yoghurt Chiffon Cake
text: Seen the Pumpkin Chiffon Cake recipe sometime back in Small Small Baker's blog but did not try to bake it when I saw coconut milk is required.Â  Anyway, today with pumpkin puree in my pantry, I ventured out to bake this cake but used natural yoghurt to replace the coconut milk.Â Â  Bought a few tubs of natural yoghurt [special offers].Â  Taste wise I cannot tell the difference because I have not tried a pumpkin chiffon cake using coconut milk before.Â  I saw the cake rising well and covers the whole 7" chiffon cake pan.Â  IÂ  should have use the 9" pan instead.Â  Maybe next time, must remember.Â Â  Very soft but firm cake texture and taste good too.Â  Very confident, gave the cake to my mother in-law.Â  She loves it very much.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture4 egg yolks2 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt4 tbsp oil80 gm pumpkin puree60 ml coconut milk or fresh milk with 1/4 tsp cinnamon powder/ground nutmeg [I used natural yoghurt]Whisk egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in coconut milk/fresh milk/yoghurt.Â  Lastly stir in pumpkin puree until well combined. Fold in flour in batches until well incorporated. Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 170 degrees.120 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powderÂ   Ingredients for Egg White Mixture 4 egg white 5 tbsp sugar1/8 tsp cream of tartarWhisk egg white till frothy then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking till foamy then gradually add in sugar [in 3 batches].Â  Whisk till soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue till well incorporated.Â  Pour batter into 7" or 9" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 40 - 45 minutes.Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: EZ Home Style Birthday Noodles [Lam Mee]
text: This portion serves 3-4Â I have heard not many people like this noodle basically the soup looks plain, without the sambal it is quite flat in taste; not filling for the tummy etc.Â  Personally, I like this noodle which is a perfect One Dish Meal [because of the combination of ingredients].Â The taste depends on the cook and the eater.Â  You can prepare delicious good food and yet there are people who do not know how to enjoy the food [most times it is ones taste/preference and attitude problem].Â  Have you heard of people who are lazy to eat, do not what to eat and some who says 'why so troublesome to prepare the food?' Â  Of course, there are the people who eat to live and people who live to eat.For most Hokkien people [older generations] celebrating their birthdays, this noodle is a must.Â Â  I remembered during my younger days, when the older generations celebrate their 60th, 70th and 80th birthdays, they will prepare this birthday noodle for prayers and distribution to close friends and relatives together with a big red 'tortoise' bun.Â  In return, the receivers will either give a red packet 'Angpow' and a box of flour vermicelli 'Mee Suah' signifying long life.Nowadays, I hardly see this practice anymore, probably because people think it is too troublesome.Â  Just ask the restaurant to prepare this dish if they are holding a birthday dinner for friends and relatives [some restaurants do not serve this type, they serve the Cantonese 'Sang Meen'].Â  That's it, practices/things changed and the bond changes too.Popularly known as Lam Mee in Penang [aka Seh Jit Mee] it is sold at the hawker's stalls but they are different from the ones prepared at home. Â  I love this noodle, so I am cooking it to enjoy even though it is not my birthday today.Â  Looking at the ingredients, it does seem troublesome but when you do it, it is not.Â  Best of all, most of the ingredients are boiled Â and can be prepared long before meal time.Ingredients[serves 3-4]500 - 600 gm yellow noodles300 gm beansprouts - tailed, washed and drain50 gm chives [kucai] - washed and cut 4 cm length1 red chilli - seeded and cut fine strips -garnishingsome coriander leaves - garnishingsambal belacan - store bought or prepare your own *fried crispy shallots- store bought or prepare your own*some dried sole [pnee hoo] - toastedÂ  or fried and pounded - optional*200 gm pork belly or lean meatÂ  [or any part of meat with a little fat] - keep whole200 gm medium sized prawns with shells - washedÂ 1 egg - beaten with a pinch of salt [optional - a little pink coloring - birthday purpose]Â some cooked crab meat- optional1 litre water1 tsp salt1 tsp chicken stock granules1/4 tspÂ  pepper to taste2 tbsp cornflour combine with 3 tbsp water for thickening For the soup - bring water to boil in a pot.Â  Put in prawns, cook till prawns change colour.Â  Remove and set aside to cool.Â Â  Remove shells then slice prawns lengthwise into 2-3 pieces.Put in meat to boil and cook for 10-15 minutes or until almost tender but has a bite.Â  Remove and set aside to cool and cut strips.Add seasoning to soup.Â  Bring it to a boil and thicken with cornflour mix.Â  Keep stock boiling over a gentle low heat in a simmer.Fry beaten egg in a non stick pan into a thin omelette and cut thin strips.To Serve Birthday Noodles [Lam Mee][either serve the whole portion in a big deep plate to share or in individual plate]Â Boil a pot of water enough to blanch yellow noodles, beansprouts and chives [together or individually depending on the amount required].Â  Drain dry and lay on serving plate.Â Â  Top all over with prepared prawns and meat.Â  Pour enough boiling soup stock over.Â  Add omelette and crab meat.Â  Sprinkle fried shallots and dried sole [dried sole can be added to soup even before serving].Â  Garnish with coriander leaves and red chilli.Serve with sambal belacan sauce.Â  Note [these can prepare earlier and store]* Sambal belacan - Pound or blend together 4 fresh red chillies and 1-2 cm square toasted belacan, then add juice of 1 lime [calamasi lime]* 5-6 shallots - finely sliced and fry in oil till golden.Â  Strain and leave to cool before storing in airtight container* 1 piece dried sole [pnee hoo] - wash and break into pieces.Â  Fry in oil until crispy and golden.Â  Cool and pound till fine.* I cooked the soup stock in a claypot and served the noodles in the claypot itself.Â  Less washing to doÂ  and claypot retains heat longer.

title: Chilli Sauce [Dipping Sauce]
text: This is a thick and nice chilli sauce [not too spicy because I removed the chilli seeds].Â  Easy to prepare for use as dipping sauce for any fried snacks such as spring rolls, fried wantan, dumplings and fritters. Ingredients3 red chillies - seeded3 cili padi2-3 cloves garlic1 tbsp each of chilli sauce, tomato sauce and lime juice1-2 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp salt to tasteBlend chillies and garlic in an electric processor.Â  Spoon out into a small container and add in all other ingredients.Â  Stir to combine well.Â  Refrigerate if not using immediately.Note:I use the sauce to serve with Fried Round Wantans

title: Sui Kow Wantan Mee Soup
text: Simple yet complete and delicious too.Â  Please refer to my posting on MY Prawn/Meat Dumplings [Sui Kow] for the ingredients for the dumplings and soup stock.For the noodle soup you just need the following ingredients.Ingredients[per serving]1 bundle of store bought wantan noodles [or any noodles preferred]some mustard leaves [choy sum] - washed and cut into small pieces or any leafy vegetable available - lettuce/spinach/baby bok choy etcsome spring onions - choppedsome garlic crispsa dash of pepper and sesame oilsome cut chillies, pickled chillies or sambal belacan Bring a pot of water to boil.Â  Blanched vegetables, remover and set aside.Cook noodles inÂ  boiling water.Â  Drain and place on serving bowl.Â  Top up with blanched vegetables, dumplings and scoop hot soup over noodles.Â  Add garlic crisps, spring onions, pepper and sesame oil.Â  Serve with chillies and soy sauce.

title: Stir Fry Spicy Crab
text: A fragrant, really spicy and a little sourish crab dish that has the 'kick'.Â  Taste different from the usual sweet and sour crabs.Â  The grounded spices makes the gravy thick instead ofÂ  using cornstarch and egg as thickening.Â  Goes well with plain rice.Ingredients[serves 3-4]600 gm mud crabs - cleaned and cut into halves2 lemon grass lightly smashed1 sprig curry leaves - washed and wipe dry1 cup waterÂ  or enough to cook crabs1/2 cup oilSpice Ingredients [Grounded]100 gm shallots3 cloves garlic20 gm ginger6 red chillies1 tbsp chilli boh -omit if you do not want it too spicy 1 tsp tumeric powder1/2 tbsp belacan stock granulesSeasoning2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp oyster saucesalt and sugar to tasteHeat oil in wok.Â  Fry curry leaves and lemongrass until fragrant.Â  Add in the grounded spices.Â  Fry on low heat until aromatic and oil rises.Put in the crabs and stir fry for several minutes [add some water if too dry] until ingredients are well combined and crabs turning red.Â  Pour in water.Â  Add seasoning and bring crab to a boil.Â  Cover to cook through crabs.Simmer for 5-10 minutes or until crabs are cooked.Â  Taste too adjust seasoning and continue to cook until gravy is slightly thick.

title: MY Prawn/Meat Dumplings [Sui Kow]
text: Recently we had Dim Sum at a newly opened Dim Sum Tea House in our housing estate.Â  Apart from the usual Dim Sum items, this outlet also serves many different boiled soup.Â  One of them is Sui Kow Soup [Prawn/Meat Dumplings Soup].Â  Three pieces in a bowl costs RM 4.00.Sui Kow is one of the many dumplings that I liked.Â  In conjunction with SSB's Dim Sum Affair, I thought probably it is time to prepare this again.I'm submitting  submitting this post to Small Small Baker: Aspiring Bakers #19: Dim Sum Affair (May 2012)Â Â  hosted by SSB of Small Small Baker.Â Â Â Ingredients[makes about 20 pieces]20 small-medium size prawns - marinate with a pinch of salt and some cooking wine100 gm minced meat with some fats [I used lean meat]50 gm water chestnuts - chopped finely2 dried Chinese mushrooms - soaked and chopped20 pieces of round wantan skin [I used Japanese Gyoza skin - store bought] garlic oil, shredded spring onions [optional]shredded ginger in black vinegar sauceSeasoning 1/2 tsp each of salt, sugar and pepper to taste1 tsp chicken stock granules or 1/4 tsp msg1 tsp each ofÂ  light soy sauce and sesame oil1 tbsp water 1 tsp cornflourCombine meat with seasoning.Â  Stir in direction to mix well into a sticky paste.Â  Then add in mushrooms and water chestnuts.Â  Continue stir for a few more seconds until mixture is well combined into a thick paste.Â  Rest in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes.To prepare the dumplings, place about 1 tablespoon filling on the wantan skin.Â  Top up with a prawn.Â  Apply a little water around the edges of the skin with your finger.Â  Fold into half moon, first pressing the centre of the edge then the sides to seal well.Â  Repeat the same until all the filling is used up.Bring a pot of water to boil.Â  Cook several pieces at a time.Â  The dumplings are cooked when it floats up to the surface of the boiling water.Â  Dish out onto plate using a serrated ladle.Serve hot with garlic oil, shredded spring onions and shredded ginger in black vinegar sauce.For sui kow soup - put cooked sui kow in a bowl, scoop enough soup over sui kow.Â  Garnish with chopped spring onion, sesame oil and a dash of pepper.Soup Stock for Sui Kow I prepared a healthy soup stock for the sui kow using my steamboat stock recipe which is very aromatic but not oily.Ingredients[serves 3-4]2 lemongrass - lightly smashed2 stalks of spring onions4-5 cloves garlic1/2 a cube of ikan bilis stock [anchovies]salt and pepper to taste1 litre waterPut all ingredients in a saucepot.Â  Let it boil for about 5-10 minutes.Â  Add salt and pepper to taste.Â  Simmer stock for another 5-10 minutes.Â Â  Remove all the ingredients.Â  The soup is ready.Â  When serving add garlic crisps and sesame oil if preferred.Note:I used Japanese Gyoza skin wrap for my dumplings because I found the yellow wantan skin sometimes has a very strong alkaline taste.                 document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src=http://www.inlinkz.com/cs.php?id=148181&' + new Date().getTime() + '"><\/script>');

title: Mango Yoghurt Chiffon Cake
text: Mango Yoghurt Chiffon CakeMy neighbour gave me quite a lot of mangoes from Ipoh. Â With mango yoghurt in my pantry, I tried baking a Mango Yoghurt Chiffon cake for her. Â Turns out well. Â Soft, Â moist and not too sweet.Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture3 large egg yolks2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp corn oil80 ml mango flavoured yoghurt80 gm plain flour60 gm fresh mango - diced or cut small cubes [optional] Whisk egg yolks with castor sugar till creamy and add in corn oil [1 tbsp at a time]. Â Mix well after each addition. Â Then add in yoghurt. Â Mix well, fold in flour with mango until well combined. Â Set aside. Â Preheat oven at 180 degrees C for 10 minutes. Â Meanwhile prepare the meringue.Ingredients - Egg White Mixture3 large egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar3 tbsp caster sugarWhisk egg white in a clean mixing bowl on high speed until frothy, then add in cream of tartar. Â Continue beating for a second and add in caster sugar gradually. Â Continue beating all the time till soft peaks formed [Note - it is easier to fold in soft peak egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture. Â Do not over beat meringue]Fold in 1/2 the egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture till well combined. Â Then fold into the balance egg white mixture. Â Fold till mixtures are well combined. Â Pour into 7" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven for 30-40 minutes on lower rack.Remove from oven and immediately invert pan to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Vegetarian Curry
text: This is a good vegetarian curry recipe from Amy Beh which I have cooked before.Â  I substituted some of the ingredients [thin coconut milk with water and thick coconut milk with yoghurt or 2 tbsp ground almond].Â My dear friends, Marieta and Garth of Ibiza, I especially like to share this slightly sourish vegetable curry with both of you.Â Â  Is your lemongrass from Penang growing well in Ibiza?Ingredients100 gm each of the following vegetablescarrots - cut wedgeslong beans - cut 3 cm lengthscabbage - break into small piecesbrinjal - cut into wedges8 pieces taufu puffs - halved1 piece tempeh [fermented bean cake] - cut into 2 cm square pieces [substitute with 2 pieces firm beancurd if unavailable] - quartered and pan fry in oil until golden brown - set aside or use more taufu puffsSpice Ingredients A2 stalks lemongrass - lightly smashed2 sprigs curry leaves1 star anise3 cloves3 cm cinnamon stick3 cardamons - split and use seeds onlySpice Ingredients BÂ [blend and mix together]4 candlenuts [buah keras]1 tsp tumeric powder3 tbsp chilli boh [chilli paste]3 tbsp meat curry powder250 ml water [enough to cover ingredients]135 ml natural yoghurt [can substitute with 2 tbsp ground almond]1 tbsp tamarind paste mixed with 100 ml water - squeezed for tamarind juice5 tbsp oilSeasoning1 tsp each of salt and sugar to taste1/2 tsp msg [Ajinomoto]Heat oil in wok/pot and saute ingredients [A] until fragrant.Â  Add in [B] and continue to fry until oil rises.Add in the carrots, long beans and brinjals.Â  Fry well to combine.Â  Pour in water and tamarind juice.Â  Bring to a simmering boil for about 5 minutes.Â  Add cabbage and cook until vegetables are soft.Add in taufu puffs and tempeh.Â  Pour in yoghurt [or ground almond] and add in seasoning to taste.Cook to a brief boil.Â  Cover the wok/pot forÂ  about 5 minutes before dishing out to serve. Â  [Usually I will dish out curry into a claypot and reheat it when serving].Note:This time, I served the curry with an EZ tomato rice [meatless day].Â  The curry gravy is reduced because of the taufu puffs that soaked up the water.Â  Add more waterÂ  and seasoning if you prefer the curry to be slightly watery.Â  The vegetable quantity must be accurate otherwise you need more liquid to cook the vegetables.In Penang, to cook curry is not troublesome as most of the fresh curry paste ingredients [many varieties] can be bought at the wet market.Â  You just need to tell the vendor what curry and the quantity you are cooking, he will mix them for you.

title: EZ Tomato Rice
text: There any many variations to cooking Tomato Rice with a variety of ingredients.Â  This is a very basic, easy Tomato Rice recipe which is full of flavour and goes well with most curries.Â Â  I believed it is also a healthy version as no coconut milk is used.Â  Most time, when the recipe uses coconut milk, I try to substitute with milk or yoghurt.Â  I really do not know the difference of the taste because I hardly eat this rice at the stalls.Â  The flavours maybe from the spices used.Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 gm Basmathi rice - washed and drain300 ml water1 tbsp oil2 shallots - sliced thinly2 cm piece cinnamon stick1 star anise 2 cardamon pods - use the seeds only2 cloves2 tbsp tomato puree1/2 tsp salt to tasteÂ chicken stock granules to tastea handful of sultanasHeat oil in wok, saute onions and spices until fragrant.Â  Add in tomato puree and fry to combine well.Add in the rice and seasoning.Â  Stir to mix well.Â  Transfer fried rice to rice cooker or steaming tray.Add in water to cook rice in rice cooker or steam over boiling water for 25-30 minutes.Â  Add in sultanas.Â  Give it a stir.Â  Off heat and leave for 5-10 minutes before fluffing rice to serve.Serve tomato rice with cucumber slices and any curry.Note:Serving Tomato Rice with Vegetarian Curry [light and easy] .

title: Pandan Coconut Buns [Gelatinized Dough Method]
text: Came across this bun recipe of Sonia from Nasi Lemak Lover.Â  Thanks to her for sharing this really 'workable' recipe and easy method.Â  I made these buns with the two different fillings in hand [pandan coconut [recipe here]Â and sambal dried prawns ].Â  Very happy with the results.Â  Shared half with my neighbour and she loves it very much.Â  Even her daughter in-law who does not eat bread, commented that the buns were yummy, better than store bought.I prepared the sweet bread dough, kept it in a airtight container in the refrigerator for several hours [#] while I went shopping.Â  When I came back from my shopping spree, I brought out the dough and thaw it for about 30 minutes, then started making these buns.Â  The dough is so easy to handle.Â  I like it and will definitely used this recipe [makes 22 buns x 50 gm] next time when making buns with other types of fillings.Ingredients for Gelatinized Dough100 gm bread flour70 ml hot boiling waterMix together into a rough dough using a pair of chopstick.Â  Cover dough with cling film [I used a plastic airtight container] and leave dough to cool in the fridge for 1 hour and up to 48 hours [2 days].To Prepare Basic Sweet Bread Dough1 portion of the gelatinized dough above300 gm bread flour100 gm plain flour80 gm castor sugar20 gm milk powder [I used 1 tbsp skimmed milk powder]1 tbsp yeast1/2 tsp salt1 cold egg175 ml cold water [I used only 160 ml because I used 1 large egg]60 gm cold butter - cubed [I used 50 gm]egg glaze [I used milk]Â Mix sweet bread dough ingredients [except butter] with gelatinized dough in a mixer with dough hook.Â  Knead on medium speed for about 10 minutes till soft and smooth [the dough is quite wet but it is alright] then add in butter.Â Continue to knead for another 10 - 15 minutes until dough is soft, smooth and elastic [the dough should be ready if it does not stick to the fingers when touch].Â  Shape into a round ball with floured hands, cover and leave to rest for 15 minutes or until double in size [#].Punch down dough.Â  Divide dough into 22 - 24 equal portions [I just estimate].Shape into balls, then roll each ball on a floured board into circle.Â  Add the fillings, pinch the seam to seal the edges and roll/shape into any shapes preferred.Â  Place the seam side down on cupcake paper casing or parchment paper.Â  Leave to rise for 45 minutes in the oven.Â  Remove them from the ovenÂ  after 40 minutes before preheating oven.Â  Brush with beaten egg glaze or milk and sprinkle with some sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven atÂ  180 degrees C [middle shelf] for 15 minutes. Â  Turn to top heat for another 1-2 minutes just to brown buns [buns look pale if using milk]. Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately before storing.

title: EZ Pandan Coconut Filling
text: This is an EZ pandan flavoured coconut filling that can be used for buns and paus. Â I prepared this filling using my recipe for Brown Sugar Coconut filling by substituting brown sugar with white sugar and adding pandan paste. Â It is easy, simple and fast to prepare but mostÂ important, it is tasty [really has the pandan flavour] too.Ingredients200 gm freshly grated white coconut [available at the wet market]100 gm white sugar [sweetness is just nice] - health conscious50 ml fresh milk [I used 1 tbsp skimmed milk powder mix with water/pandan water]1 tsp pandan paste1 tbsp butter1/4 tsp salta drop of green colouring [optional]Melt butter in non stick pan on low fire. Â Add in sugar, salt and milk. Â Stir until the sugar dissolves.Add in pandan paste and grated coconut.Continue stirring until the mixture is almost dry.Off fire and leave to cool [can prepare and keep in fridge before using].Step 1 and 2Step 3EZ way to prepare pandan pasteÂ [Refer to Nasi Lemak Lover Blog]25 pieces screwpine [pandan] leaves - cleaned and cut small pieces300 ml waterBlend together pandan leaves and water until fine. Â Strain and squeezed for the juice. Â Discard the residue. Â Strain again and store in a plastic container.Leave in fridge for about 3-5 days before use.Â Pour away the pandan water and scoop out the pandan paste for use.Note:Did not take any pictures before using the pandan paste.Â  Will remember the next time.Click here Â - Gelatinized Dough Buns with Pandan Coconut Filling

title: Prawn Rolls With Beancurd Skin
text: I am submitting this post to Small Small Baker: Aspiring Bakers #19: Dim Sum Affair (May 2012) hosted by SSB of Small Small BakerPrawn Rolls With Beancurd SkinRemember the small, sweet white shell prawns for the prawn fritters.Â  Since my Ma have some of these prawns and also some leftover beancurd skin [foo peh], I suggested to make them into these prawns rolls [quite similar to those sold at dim sum outlets].Â  Very simple ingredients and method to prepare these prawn rolls.Ingredients[makes 10 rolls]300 gm small white prawns - remove shells, wash and drain dryMarinade1/2 tsp pepper1/2 tsp salta dash of msg1 tsp sesame oil3 tbsp cornflour10 pieces of beancurd skin [foo peh] - size 3" x 4" piecePrawn Rolls Before FryingMix marinade to prawns.Â  Stir to combine well and set aside for 15 - 20 minutes in the fridge.Use a piece of beancurd skin, put in about 1 spoonful of prawn mixture in the centre.Â  Roll up and press both sides to seal rolls [see photo].Â  Keep in container to store in fridge if not frying immediately.Â Fry in wok with oil [turn on to medium heat after putting in the prawn rolls] like frying meat rolls until golden and crispy. Â Complete frying the rolls in batches. Drain on kitchen paper before serving with chilli sauce or mayonnaise.                 document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src=http://www.inlinkz.com/cs.php?id=148181&' + new Date().getTime() + '"><\/script>');

title: Raisin Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: Raisin Loaf Bread is one of the many loaf breads that I have made before but did not post the recipe. Â Today, I made this bread again as I have some raisins left in my pantry to clear. Â This recipe yields lovely, softÂ bread. Â The ingredients here makes 2 loaves of bread [550 gm each]. Â It is more economical to bake this quantity [just keep a loaf in the refrigerator if 1 loaf last you for 2 days].Ingredients for Overnight Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour3 tsp instant yeast [actual is 3.9 tsp]250 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough. Â Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours. Â Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour [I used 270 gm bread flour and 30 gm wholemeal flour]2 tbsp milk powder3 tbsp sugar1 tsp Â salt150 gm raisins - soaked in 1 tbsp rum or cool boiled water [just enough to plump up raisins]150 ml water [or less]60 gm butter [I used about 50 gm]Add all the ingredients [except butter and raisins] to the overnight dough. Â Knead until well combined and dough is soft for about 10 minutes then add in butter. Â Continue kneading until soft, smooth and elastic. Â Add in Â raisins. Â Knead a further 3-5 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log. Â Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for an hour or until double in size [almost reach the rim of the baking tin. Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves]. Â  Here, I divide the dough into 4 portions and plaited the dough.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes. Â Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Kung Pao Fish Fillet
text: A common 'kung pao' sauce that can be used to cook fried fish fillet, fried chicken, fried prawns or anything when you feel like having 'kung pao' flavoured food. Â Served with white rice on a plate with some vegetables makes a complete tasty One Dish Meal for lunch or dinner.Ingredients500 gm fish fillet - cut bit size slicesMarinate with 1 tsp each of salt and sesame oil, 1/2 tsp pepper, 1 egg and 2 tbsp of cornflourenough oil to fry fish fillet6-8 dried chillies - soaked and cut into 21 big onion Â - cut wedges1 inch piece young ginger - sliced1-2 stalks spring onion - cut 1" lengthKung Pao Sauce [Mix all together] - taste to adjust seasoning3 tbsp white vinegar3 tbsp tomato sauce 3 tbsp dark soy sauce5 tbsp sugar100 - 150 ml water2 tsp constarchHeat enough oil in wok and fry fish fillet in batches until golden and crispy at the edges. Â Dish out on plate.Remove oil and only leave a tablespoon of it to saute dried chillies and ginger untill aromatic. Â Add in onion.Pour in combined kung pao sauce mixture. Â Allow it to boil then add in fried fish fillet and spring onion.Stir fry to combine all ingredients and fish slices are well coated with kung pao sauce.Serve immediately.Note:This dish was prepared at my mum's place for a family of 10.

title: Vegetarian Loufah Soup
text: Sometimes, I have a strong urge to go meatless for a meal or two.Â  Here is a very simple soup which I prepared and served with my Steamed Garoupa. Â Ingredients[serves 2]1 loufah - remove the skin and cut wedgessome black fungus - soaked and break into small piecessome carrots - slicedany dried mushrooms - soaked and cut smaller piecesa handful of taufu puffs - cut half 1 cup water or vegetarian soup stocksome light soy sauce, salt, msg and pepper to taste1 tsp sesame oil Heat sesame oil in a claypot.Â  Saute mushrooms until aromatic.Â  Add in black fungus and carrot.Â  Stir fry to mix ingredients.Â Â Pour in water or stock and add in seasoning.Â  Bring it to a boil, then add in taufu puffs.Â  Boil for 1-2 minutes.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Lastly add in the loufah to cook.Â  Off fire once the loufah is soft.Serve immediately.Note:Can add a few slices of ginger, fried garlic crisps and steamboat stock for more aromatic soup

title: Steamed Garoupa With Soy Sauce
text: My hubby's 'second job' - fishing.Â  No, it is his hobby after he was 'banned' from playing badminton by his cardiologist after surviving a heart attack while playing the game. This is his catch of the day - a 1 kg Garoupa.Â  Very fresh fish that requires little 'dressing', so steaming it with a simple soy sauce mix and ginger with lots of spring onion/coriander should be awesome.Ingredients1 Garoupa fish [600 gm] - scaled and cleaned1" piece ginger - shredded finely1 stalk spring onions - cut fine shreds1 stalk coriander - cut 1" length1-2 tsp fried chopped garlicÂ  some oil [heated till hot] - optionalSauce Ingredients2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tsp sugar5 tbsp water1/2 tsp sesame oila dash of pepperSteam fish over boiling water for 15 - 20 minutes or until fish is cooked.Bring sauce ingredientsÂ  to a boil in a saucepan.Â Â Remove fish from steamer, drain away the stock if any.Â  Quickly pour sauce over steamed fish.Garnish with shredded ginger, spring onions, coriander leaves and garlic crisps.Lastly pour some hot oil over fish [optional] before serving immediately.Note:Definitely taste better with the extra hot oil but healthwise it is better to omit it after all this fish is very fresh.

title: Mocha Loaf Bread [Sponge Dough Method]
text: After making the lovely Coffee Loaf Bread [better than store bought] and enjoying it, I thought of trying another flavour.Â  So here it is, my Mocha Loaf Bread.Â  Soft and moist and smells good.Â  On the second day, for breakfast we toasted the bread slices, spread it with a little butter and my homemade jam.Â  Wow!Â  It's good, you will love bread from now on. Ingredients for Sponge Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour3.5 tsp instant yeast [I used 3 tsp]200 ml water   Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof   for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing   and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before   adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough270 gm bread flour30 gm cocoa powderÂ 1 tbsp skimmed milk powder3 tbsp sugar1.5 tspÂ  salt1 large egg 3 tsp instant coffee granules dissolved in 130 ml hot water60 gm butterÂ Add   all the ingredients [except butter] to the sponge dough.Â    Knead until well combined and dough isÂ soft  for  about 10  minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until  soft,  smooth and elastic.Â Â  Knead a further 10Â   minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size.Â Â Â  Punch down dough.Divide   dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and  fold each portion into thirds,   then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â   Place in baking tin [Pullman's   tin] and leave to proof in oven for  more than an hour or until double  in  size.Â  [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make smaller loaves within 1 Pullman's tin ].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: 'Ang Chow' Chicken
text: My neighbour's friend gave him 2 bottles of homemade red rice wine residue [ang chow in hokkien dialect].Â  Not knowing what to do with it, he gave me a bottle.Â  SoÂ  I cooked this simple dish and shared half with him. Â  If he likes the taste, I will probably prepare another dish 'Ang Chow Char Siew' to share with him.Â Â Â 'Ang Chow' [aka Hong Chow] is the residue from fermented red rice wine. It is believed to be good for health especially beneficial in lowering triglycerides and cholesterol.Cooking this dish only requires 3 main ingredients.Â  It can be served with rice or cook into a soup with flour vermicelli [mee suah] as a One Dish Meal.Â  The chicken tastes even better after several hours.Â  It can be freezed and reheated before serving . Â Â Ingredients[serves 3-4] 6 pieces chicken thigh - skin removed and cut into bite size pieces50 gm ginger - sliced2 tbsp red rice wine dregs [residue from fermented red rice wine]1 tbsp sesame oil 150 ml waterSeasoning1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp salt1 tbsp rock sugar to tasteHeat sesame oil in wok, saute ginger slices until aromatic.Â  Add in the red rice wine dregs followed by chicken.Â  Stir fry for 5 minutes or until all ingredients are well combined and fragrant.Add water and seasoning to taste.Â  Bring it to a boil.Â  Cover and lower heat to simmer for about 20 minutes or until chicken is tender and gravy is reduced.Dish out to serve with rice.

title: Sambal Dried Prawns Bun [Sponge Method]
text: This is actually a plain loaf bread recipe from Kitchen Corner which I have tried and found it very good.Â  I used it to make buns, it is also very good with good texture.Â  The buns remains soft for 2-3 days. Â I used some of the sambal dried prawns [see recipe]Â which I cooked earlier as filling for these buns.Â  Really yummy! Makes 12 buns.This bun has less fillings, stingy.. lolIngredients - Sponge Dough220 gm bread flour 3/4 tsp instant yeast dissolve in 130 ml waterAdd flour into the yeast mixture and mix into a sticky dough. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and leave for 1-2 hours or till it becomes about 2-3 times in size.Â  [Usually, I will mix ingredients in an airtight container, leave it to proof for 30 minutes in room temperature, then cover the container and kept in the fridge until later use.Â  Thaw to room temperature before mixing with bread dough ingredients].Ingredients - Bread Dough60 gm bread flour1/2 tbsp milk powder 1/2 tsp salt 1 tbsp sugar  40 ml water1 tbsp butterMix bread dough ingredients with sponge dough in a mixer with dough hook.Â  Knead on medium speed for about 5-10 minutes till soft then add in butter.Â  Continue to knead for another 10 minutes till dough is soft, smooth and elastic. Cover and leave to rest for 15 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough.Â  Divide dough into 12 equal portions.Shape into balls, then roll on a floured board into circle.Â  Add the sambal fillings, pinch the seam to seal the edges and shape into round buns or any shape preferred.Â  Place the seam side down on paper casing or parchment paper.Â Leave to rise for 30 - 40 minutes.Â  Brush with beaten egg or milk and sprinkle with some sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 15-20 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately.

title: Sambal Dried Prawns [Sambal Hae Bee]
text: I love sambal dried prawns sandwiches with sliced cucumber or fresh mint leaves.Â  I also love sambal dried prawns with plain white rice and cucumber/mint leaves.Â  Recently, my neigbhour [the one for whom I baked the extra loaf ofÂ  bread] gave me a packet of dried prawns [good quality one].Â  So why not, make the sambal, serve it with rice, use it as my buns' filling?Search all over and found this recipe from Amy Beh's collection, but I change some ingredients for my own convenience.Â  This is a good recipe, the sambal dried prawnÂ  is not salty.Â  Should be good as bun filling.Ingredients200 gm dried prawns - soaked, cleaned and lightly pounded [I use the blender]2 tbsp tamarind paste mixed with 100 - 150 ml water, strain to obtain juice4 kaffir lime leaves, finely sliced [I omit]1/2 cup oilSpice Ingredients [Ground to a paste] 5 dried chillies, soaked [I substitute with 1 tbsp chilli boh]7 red chillies10 shallots2 cloves garlic2 stalks lemongrass1/2 tsp tumeric powderSeasoning3 tbsp sugar or to taste1/2 - 3/4 tsp salt or to taste [depends on the dried prawns]1/2 tsp chicken stock granules [I used msg - Ajinomoto]Prepare the ingredients as above.Heat oil in a wok and fry the spice ingredients over medium low heat until aromatic.Add in the tamarind juice.Â  Bring it to a boil.Â  Add in the dried prawns.Â  Stir fry until well combined.Add in seasoning and kaffir lime leaves [if using].Â  Reduce the heat and keep frying until mixture is almost dry and crumbly [to the desired texture].Â  Drier if using as bun filling.Dish out and leave to cool.Â  Serve with sliced cucumber or fresh mint leaves.

title: Honey, Lemon Chiffon Cake
text: Another lovely chiffon cake from Baking Friends Unite which I have tried earlier and has kept the recipe. Â I baked this cake again and I am very satisfied with it.Â  Since I have some poppy seeds, I sprinkled some before baking this cake.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]4 tbsp honey3 tbsp oil1 tbsp water + 2 tsp lemon juicezest of 1 lemonWhisk egg yolks with honey till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in water and lemon juice.Â Â  Fold in flour and zest until well combined. Â Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 170 degrees.85 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powder + a pinch of saltIngredients for Egg White Mixture4 egg white1/8 tsp cream of tartar4 tbsp sugar Whisk egg white until frothy, continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue till well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â Knock a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 35-40 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Coffee Loaf Bread [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Really lovely and yummy loaves of coffee flavoured bread. Â Soft and moist. Â Took several good shots of the bread but accidentally erased them. Â Used a new hand phone Â and not too familiar with it's functions. Â But believe me, the bread is good. Ingredients for Sponge Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour3.5 tsp instant yeast200 ml water   Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof   for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing   and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before   adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour3 tbsp sugar1.5 tspÂ  salt1 large egg 6 tsp instant coffee granules dissolved in 130 ml hot water60 gm butterÂ Add   all the ingredients [except butter] to the sponge dough.Â    Knead until well combined and dough isÂ soft  for  about 10  minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until  soft,  smooth and elastic.Â Â  Knead a further 10Â   minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size.Â Â Â  Punch down dough.Divide   dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and  fold each portion into thirds,   then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â   Place in baking tin [Pullman's   tin] and leave to proof in oven for  more than an hour or until double  in  size.Â  [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Ma Lai Koh - Light Coloured Version
text: I used to steam the darker version of Ma Lai Koh and love the cake very much for its texture and taste. Â But it requires a longer preparation time and yeast is used. Some Ma Lai Koh uses coconut milk, which I do not really like [healthwise not advisable - family history of heart problem]. Â  When I came across this light colour version, the procedure seems to be simpler.Â  I gave it a try because it is faster to make. Â The cake turns out well [soft and moist] but I should have rested the batter for about 15-20 minutes before steaming. Â This way, the texture may be even better [probably better honeycomb effect]. Â Perhaps, I will do it next time and should you be trying, maybe you can add in this step.Â  But take note to finish this steamed cake within 1-2 days.Â  Ingredients5 eggs180 gm castor sugar100 ml corn oil130 ml fresh milkSifted together280 gm superfine flour4 tbsp custard powder2 tsp baking powder1/2 tsp bicarbonate soda1/4 tsp saltLine a 7" Â square tin with greased proof paper.Prepare a steamer with enough water. Â Bring to a boil while you prepare the batter.Whisk eggs and sugar in an electric mixer on medium high speed till light and creamy.Â Slowly drizzle in oil on medium low speed to combine. Â Then drizzle in milk.Gradually add in sifted flour and fold on low speed until well incorporated and mixture is smooth.Rest batter for 15-20 minutes [advisable step].Then pour batter into prepared steaming tray. Â Steam cake over high heat for 30 minutes or until cake comes out clean when tested with a skewer.Remove to cool in rack before slicing.Note:Steamed kuihs do not last long in humid/warm temperatures.Â  Best to finish within 1-2 days, otherwise keep in airtight container and refrigerate.Â  Thaw to room temperature before serving.

title: Pickled White Carrot
text: After making the zuchini and cabbage pickles, this time I tried pickling white carrots. Pickled white carrot goes well with Penang Lor Bak, Meat Rolls, Taiwanese 'chicken' rolls and and other fried meat or even prawn and fish fritters.It is very simple but the steps to do it must be followed especially with the seasoning of the vegetable with salt. Â It Â must be left for at least 1-2 hours to draw out the liquid. Â This is very important as to get a crunchy pickle. Â For white carrots, it is important if do not want your pickle to have the bitter taste of it.Ingredients300 gm white carrot - scrape the skin, wash and sliced thinly2 tsp salt1/4 cup white rice vinegar4 tbsp sugarMix salt to sliced carrots well. Â Leave for 1-2 hours to drain out liquid [Must follow strictly this step].Rinse carrot and squeeze out as much liquid/moisture as possible. Â Mix sugar and vinegar together.Place carrot in a glass container. Â Pour in the vinegar and sugar solution. Â Mix well. Â Cover the container and leave for at least 2 hours before it is ready to serve.Chill in the refrigerator and enjoy this refreshing pickle to any fried meat.

title: Taiwanese Chicken Roll [Version 1]
text: Taiwanese 'chicken' roll has nothing to do with chicken. Â Pork and fish paste is used to make these rolls. Â I have no idea why it is called chicken roll. Â  Perhaps, it looks like the chicken neck when you make them long. Â I have tried it while in Taoyuan, Taiwan. Â It is about 1 foot long. Â  Anyway, this is a delicious meat roll worth making. Â The texture is soft and moist but firm.Taiwanese Chicken RollHere, I made these rolls shorter for easy frying. Â Not much oil is required by frying in several batches.Ingredients[makes 18 pieces]300 gm fish paste - Â fish meat blended till fine and mix with some water into a sticky paste300 gm tender lean pork [I used 'li chi rou'] - cut strips1 yellow onion - cut fine shreds1 - 2 tbsp tapioca flour or sweet potato flour1 piece bean curd skin - cut into 8"x 5" rectangular piecesSeasoningÂ - marinate meat2 tsp each of light soy sauce, wine and sugar1/2 tsp each of salt, pepper and 5 spice powder1/2 tsp sesame oil [optional]Marinate pork strips with seasoning. Â Add in sticky fish paste and onions. Â Use hand to mix all the ingredients together until well combined. Â Cover and leave to rest in the refrigerator for about 1/2 an hour.Place about Â a handful of mixture on centre of beancurd skin. Â Fold both side of the skin and roll up like spring roll. Â Do the same for the rest of the mixture.Place a few pieces of chicken roll in oil. Â Turn on heat to medium and deep fry the rolls until golden brown and crispy. Â Drain and leave on kitchen paper to cool.Cut rolls before serving them plain or with sweet chilli sauce or pickled zuchini or white carrot.Â Note:I was told that these 'chicken rolls' are served with Taiwanese porridge called 'kiam moi' or 'yam porridge'. Â The ingredients for cooking 'kiam moi' are quite similar to the ingredients for my Kocha [traditional] Flavour Noodle Soup. Â Just substitute noodles with rice to cook porridge.This post is linked toÂ Facebook Asian Food Fest - August 2014 Taiwan FoodÂ hosted by Alan Travelling Foodie

title: Blueberry Cinnamon Rolls [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Very soft, moist buns that are not too oily or sweet.Â  A cinnamon roll recipe worth keeping and repeating.Ingredients[makes 16 pieces in a square baking tin]Sponge Dough 200 gm bread flour2.5 tsp instant yeast120 ml waterÂ Mix  all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for  at least 1-2 hours. Ingredients for Bread Dough120 gm bread flour60 gm superfine flour 2 tbsp milk powder5 tbsp sugar1/4 tspÂ  salt100 ml water or just enough to make a soft but not wet dough30 gm butter Topping1 tbsp melted buttersome cinnamon powder combined with icing sugar4 tbsp of blueberry pie fillingÂ Glaze - 1/2 egg yolk with 1 tbsp milk - mixedÂ Add   all the bread dough ingredients [except water and butter] to the sponge dough.Â    Knead for awhile until well combined, then gradually add in water while  kneading.Â  Continue to knead  until a soft dough is formed.Â  Takes about 10 minutes then  add in  butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft, smooth, elastic and dough  does  not stick to the fingers [about 10 minutes on medium speed].Shape into a ball, coat with some flour and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 4 equal portions.Â  Roll each portion into a square.Â  Brush lightly with melted butter, then spread a tablespoon of blueberry pie filling, sprinkle cinnamon and icing sugar.Â  Roll up tightly and cut into 4 pieces. Â Arrange the rolled dough in a square baking tray line with parchment paper.Â  Repeat the same for the 3 portions.Â Â  Leave to proof in oven for about 30 minutes or until double in size.Â Â Â Remove from oven and preheat oven at 190 degrees C.Â  Before baking, brush with egg glaze and sprinkle some sugar [if prefered].Bake in preheated oven for 20 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Steamed Pumpkin Buns
text: I had this very good recipe for steamed buns using pumpkin sometime ago from Amy's [cooking crave] blog.Â  That time, I wasn't into posting recipe in my blog.Â  The buns were very soft, light and moist. The colour of the buns were very lovely orange.Â  This time, the colour was light orange, I believed it could be the quality of the pumpkin.Â  The last time, I bought the pumpkin that was from Indonesia.Â  This time, it is the pear shaped time and I have no idea where it is from.Anyway, I am sharing this lovely recipe of Amy Ong with you.Â  The only doubt I have about this recipe is the quantity of oil used [it is quite a lot].Â  Never mind, the buns are good.Ingredients[makes 18 pieces] - can make up to 24 if you prefer smaller buns]1 tbsp yeast1 tsp sugar125 - 150 ml warm waterMix all together and leave to rest for 10-15 minutes or until frothy500 gm plain flour - sifted1/4 tsp salt150 gm mashed steamed pumpkinÂ  100 gm [8 tbsp] sugar100 ml [8 tbsp] oilMix all the above ingredients [except oil] with yeast mixture and knead on medium speed for about 10 minutes or until soft and smooth.Add in oil, continue to knead for another 10 minutes or until dough is soft, smooth and elastic.Â  Shape into a ball and coat with some flour.Â  Cover to proof for 10-15 minutes.Divide dough into 18 equal portions [or more if making smaller buns].Â  Roll into balls and then into circles.Wrap each portion with any fillings prefered or shape into any desired shapes [croissant, swiss roll, round, spiral or flower etc]Â  if making plain steamed buns and place on baking paper.Proof for 10-15 minutes or until double in size.Â Â Steam buns over boiling water on high heat for 12-15 minutes.Â  Off fire, leave buns in steamer for a minute before uncovering lid.Remove to cool on wire rack or serve immediately.Note:Here I used Stir Fry Turnip [Popiah Chai] as fillings for the buns.Â  Next time, I will just make them into various shapes without fillings.

title: Tofu, Leafy Green Thick Soup
text: I love preparing food that can be cooked earlier [best in the morning] and only require reheating before meal time. Â It will be hassle free to get dinner ready especially during hot weather season or when get home later than expected.Â  This is a quick to cook soup to serve with rice and the ingredients can be prepared earlier.Â Â Â  This soup is suitable for the old and young.Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 piece soft tofu - dicedA handful of prawns without shells - lightly smashed and halvedA bunch of leafy green vegetable [I used 'A' Chai] - wash and cut thinly1 egg - lightly beaten600 ml water or soup stockÂ salt, chicken stock granules ormsg and pepper to tastecornflour mix to thicken soup slightly1 stalk spring onion, a few slices ginger and some cooking wine [if not using soup stock] - Saute spring onion and ginger until slightly brown. Â Add wine, then water. Bring it to a boil for a few minutes. Â Discard spring onions and ginger. Â Use stock for soup.Bring stock to boil, then add in tofu and prawns. Â When soup is boiling add in vegetables and seasoning. Â Give it a stir, thicken soup then pour in beaten egg in a circular manner. Â Stir once after a few second when the egg has firmed up.Â  Add pepper to taste and garlic crisps [I did not add to soup because my hubby does not like garlic crisps in soup].Dish out to serve hot with rice.Â  Note:I served this thick soup with my Kocha Flavour Steamed Pumpkin Rice.

title: Kocha Flavour Steamed Pumpkin Rice
text: After a busy week, simple cooking over the weekend is something that you can do if you feel like having a meal at home.Â Â  This recipe is simple enough with most of the ingredients available in the house.A 'kocha' flavour steamed pumpkin rice which is easy to prepare as One Dish Meal and perhaps serve with a simple easy to cook thick soup if you feel like it. Â  If cooking a bigger portion, you can cook the rice in the rice cooker.Ingredients[serves 2]120 gm [1 cup]Â  rice - wash and drain [IÂ  used Basmathi rice]150 gm pumpkin - removed the hard skin and either diced or cut thick strips1-2 tbsp dried prawns - rinse with water for several times - drain1-2 dried mushrooms - soaked to plump up - cut strips100 gm meat - cut strips or diced - season with soy sauce, pepper and a little cornflour2 shallots - sliced1 tsp chopped garlicsome spring onions shredded for garnishing1 tbsp light soy sauce,Â  1/4 tsp each of salt and pepper to taste1 tbsp oilenough water to cook ricePrepare the ingredients as above. Â Heat oil in wok to saute shallots and garlic until golden brown. Â Push aside, add in meat, mushrooms and dried prawns to fry for a few seconds. Â Add in rice and seasoning. Â Stir to mix all ingredients well.Lastly add in pumpkin to mix. Â Off fire. Â Dish out rice into a steaming tray [Can prepare up to this step and keep rice mixture in the refrigerator and steam before meal time].Add enough water to cook rice. Â Steam rice for 25-30 minutes. Â Leave rice for another 5 - 10 minutes before fluffing up to serve or you can cook rice earlier - before serving, just fluff up rice and steam for 10 minutes. Â Garnish with spring onions and fried crispy shallots.Serve rice with cut chilli in soy sauce, or any soup.Note:I served the Pumpkin Rice with Tofu, Green Vege Thick Soup.

title: My Cola Chicken
text: EZ to prepare and tasty to serve with rice.Ingredients[serves 3-4]800 gm chicken [I used 3 chicken wings and 3 pieces chicken thigh - cut to bite size pieces]Â Marinade1-2 tsp light soy sauce1 tsp sesame oil1-2 tsp dark soy sauce325 ml regular Coca Cola2 tbsp light soy saucesalt to taste 4-5 slices ginger6-8 cloves garlic - skinned and keep whole1 small red chilli1 tbsp oilÂ 1 tsp lemon juice - optionalClean chicken and drain.Â  Marinate for 15 minutes.Heat pan with oil.Â  Pan fry chicken pieces to brown on both sides.Add in ginger slices.Â  Fry till aromatic.Â  Mix well with chicken, pour in Coca Cola and remaining marinade sauce.Bring it to a boil add in chilli, garlic and light soy sauce to taste.Â  Cook on low medium heat to simmer chicken for 15-20 minutes until sauce is reduced and slightly thick and sticky. Â Stir in lemon juice if using. Turn chicken once through the cooking.Serve chicken with salad leaves and rice.Note:I served this Cola chicken with plain white rice and pickled cabbage/carrot as a One Dish Meal.

title: Pickled Cabbage & Carrots
text: Another simple pickled cabbage and carrot that goes well with rice and meat dish either braised, baked or grilled.Â  Can be prepared ahead of meal time and save the trouble to stir fry a vegetable or preparing a fresh salad. Ingredients [serves 3-4] 300  - 350 gm round cabbage - washed and cut broad strips or break into small piecesÂ 100 gm red carrot - shredded1 tbsp salt sprinkle cabbage and carrot with some salt.Â  Mix  and leave for about 2 hours to sweat out the liquid.Â  Drain, rinse and and  squeezed out as much liquid as possible.Â  This is to make the vegetables  crunchy.Mix together70 ml white rice vinegar4 - 5 tbsp sugara pinch of saltAdd mixture to cabage.Â  Mix well and leave to stand in glass container, covered for 24 hours before serving.Refrigerate leftovers [covered and it can keep for a few more days]Note:I served this pickled with My Cola chicken.

title: Pickled Zuchini
text: A simple pickled zuchini, very crunchy that should goes well with rice and fried meat.Ingredients[serves 2] 200 - 250 gm zuchini - washed and sliced - sprinkle with some salt.Â  Mix and leave for awhile for the liquid to drain.Â  Rinse zuchini and squeezed out as much liquid as possible.Â  This is to make the zuchini crunchy.Mix together2 tbsp apple cider vinegar2 tbsp sugara pinch of saltAdd mixture to zuchini.Â  Mix well and refrigerate for at least an hour before serving.Â Â  Discard the liquid before serving.Add a small red chilli if you prefer a little spicy taste - optional. This post is linked toÂ Facebook Asian Food Fest - August 2014 Taiwan FoodÂ hosted by AlanTravelling Foodie

title: EZ Kocha Flavour Prawn Rice
text: An EZ prawn rice as One Dish Meal that can be served with a pickled vegetable and simple vegetable soup. Â  See this recipe in one of the Taiwanese Cook Show featuring this traditional dish.The rice has a very nice aroma from the cooked fresh prawns with a sprinkle of spring onions.Ingredients[serves 2-3] 2 cups rice - wash and cooked in a rice cooker using hot water Â [I steamed my rice until just cooked and very fluffly]. Â The rice has to be fluffy and dry.200 gm fresh medium size prawns - wash and shelled [keep the shells for frying]. Marinate the prawns with a pinch of salt, a dash of pepper and sesame oil1 - 2 stalks spring onion - cut small pieces [keep some for garnishing]50 ml water100 ml cooking winesalt and pepper to taste1/2 tbsp oilCook rice as normal using hot water.Heat oil in a pan to saute part of the spring onions until aromatic and onions are slightly browned.Â  Add in the prawn shells.Â  Fry until shells turned pinkish and aromatic.Â  Pour in 1/2 portion of Â wine, then water. Â Bring it to a boil for a minute.Â  Off heat, remove the shells and spring onions.Â  Discard and retain the stock in the pan. Â  Bring stock to a boil again, add in Â balance wine and prawns to cook. Â Stir for a few seconds until just firm. Â Off fire.Add in seasoning to taste. Â Dish out and add toÂ cooked rice that is still hot. Â Fluff up rice and Â stir to mix well [gravy must not be too much otherwise the rice will be too wet]. Â Â Reheat the rice for a few minutes before serving.Â  If using steamer, steam for 2-3 minutes or until rice is hot and prawns are fully cooked. Â  Serve with pickled zuchini or carrot and any soup prefered.This post is linked toÂ Facebook Asian Food Fest - August 2014 Taiwan FoodÂ hosted by AlanTravelling Foodie

title: Red Plums Jam Chiffon Cake
text: I baked this chiffon cake using the recipe for Mango and Passion Fruit Jam Chiffon cake.Â  I substituted the mango and passion fruit jam with red plums jam and the passion fruit juice with 20 ml honey/apple cider vinegar mixed with 20 ml water.Â I supposed it is possible to use any jam to bake chiffon cakes.Â  Probably, in future when I make any different preserves/jam, I will try to use it to bake different flavoured chiffon cakes.The cake turns out well, smells good and of course the jam flavour. Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]1-2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp oil20 ml honey/apple cider vinegar juice + 20 ml water3 tbsp red plums jam [recipe here]Whisk  egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â   Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in liquid.Â  Lastly stir  in jam.Â  Fold in flour until well combined. Â Set aside while  you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 170 degrees C.100 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powderIngredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white3 tbsp sugar [40 gm]Whisk egg white until frothy, continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk  mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue  till well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â Knock a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 40-45 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.Note:Forgotten to take a picture of the cut cake.

title: Strawberry Flavoured Oreo Cookie Chiffon Cake
text: I tried baking this Oreo Cookie chiffon cake using the Lemon  chiffon cake recipe.Â  I added 60 gm of Oreo biscuits [crushed]  and used milk instead of lemon juice and water.The cake was very satisfactory.Â  A little of saltiness and slightly sweet taste from the Oreo biscuits.Â Â  I reduced the sugar and the cake was lovely. Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp oil75 ml milk60 gm Oreo biscuits [crushed finely] - I used biscuits with cream and strawberry flavoured jam [any type of Oreo biscuit is okay]Whisk   egg yolks with sugar until creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â    Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in milk.Â Â   Fold in flour and Oreo biscuits until well combined. Â Set aside while  you whisk  the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 160 degrees C.100 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powder1/2 tsp salt [can omit] Ingredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar 3 tbsp sugarWhisk egg white until frothy, continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk   mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue   till well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â Knock a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees for 45 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.Note:I have tried baking Oreo biscuits with chocolate flavoured cream.Â  This time IÂ  am using Oreo biscuits with cream and strawberry flavoured jam.

title: Home Style Pork Porridge - 'Bak Moi'
