text: This is a very traditional family dish.Â  Simple 1 Dish Meal using only a few ingredients and easy to prepare.Â  Suitable for the young and old.Â  I prepared this porridge because my hubby and myself are coughing badly.Â  Thought this porridge is less troublesome.Ingredients[serves 2-3]1 cup rice - washed6 cups water200 gm minced pork [meat/fat ratio 80:20] - marinate with 2 tsp soy sauce, 1/2 tsp pepper, 1 tsp sesame oil, 1/2 tbsp cornflour and 1/2 tbsp finely chopped garlic for 30 minutes - form into meatballsblanched pork liver - optional Garnishing - chopped tong choy [preserved vegetable], coriander leaves/spring onions and fried garlic crispSeasoningÂ 1 tsp salt1 tsp light soy sauce 1/2 tsp pepper - extra when serving1 tsp msg/chicken stock granules From top - garlic crisps, tong choy and chopped coriander/spring onionsBoil rice in claypot to cook porridge for 20-25 minutes.Â  When porridge is ready, drop in meatballs to cook for 5 minutes or until meatballs are cooked.Â  Add in seasoning to taste.To serve, place some shredded lettuce in bowl [optional], scoop porridge and meatballs over it.Â  Garnish with chopped tong chye, coriander/spring onions, fried garlic and a dash of pepper.Note:If adding pork liver - sliced liver in thin broad piecesÂ  and blanched in hot boiling water to cook.Â  Drain and rinse pork liver.Â  Add to porridge before serving.

title: Fragrant Braised Pork Belly [Hong Sao Rou]
text: Another easy way to cook fragrant braised pork belly, all in a pot.Â Ingredients600 gm pork belly - cut bite size pieces3-4 slices ginger2 stalks spring onion - cut long stripsSeasoning3 tbsp oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce 1 tbsp rock sugar to taste3 tbsp Shao Hsing wine - more for stronger flavour if preferredenough water to cover pork piecesfried firm beancurd - optionalhard boiled eggs - optionalHeat up a heavy based saucepan.Â  Put in the pork pieces in the heated pan [choose those more fatty parts] to pan fry for awhile or until slightly browned.Â  Put in the balance pork, pan fry for another 5 minutes.Push pork pieces aside and using the oil in the pan, fry ginger and spring onions until fragrant.Â  Then add in oyster sauce and light soy sauce.Â  Stir to coat pork pieces with seasoning, then pour in the wine.Â  Add in rock sugar.Â  Bring it to a boil, then pour in enough water to cover meat.Â  Let it boil for a few minutes. Taste to adjust seasoning.Cover and lower heat to simmer for about 40 - 45 minutes until meat is tender and sauce is reduced [if good saucepan is used, the simmering time may be about 20 minutes].Â  Remove spring onion and ginger slices.Serve braised meat with blanched leafy vegetables [brussel sprouts, kailan, salad leaves] or broccoli.Â Can serve this dish with plain white rice on a plate as a 1 Dish Meal.

title: EZ Homemade Red Plums Jam
text: Came across red plums on offer [RM 8.50/kg] at the supermart, so I bought extra to prepare this jam. Â It is not difficult to make this bread spread or preserves. Â I probably will use it to bake chiffon cake like I used Mango and Passion fruit jam. Â Think it should be lovely.Â  If it turns out well, I will share the recipe with you.Ingredients[makes 2 bottles x 400 gm]500 gm red plums - seeded and chopped finely1 Royal Gala apple - peeled and chopped finely [I use a grater]Rind of 1 lemonJuice of 1/2 lemon250 gm sugar150 ml waterSimmering jamPlace all ingredients [except sugar] in a pan. Â Bring it to a boil and lower heat to cook until fruits are softened and water reduced.Add in sugar and continue to simmer. Â Stir occasionally to mix ingredients well. Â In the meantime, place a small saucer in the freezer to chill [for testing if jam is ready]. Â Simmer until it gels up. Â Place a teaspoon of jam on saucer. Â Leave in fridge for a few minutes and jam should be ready if it forms a mass.Store in sterilised airtight bottles.Â  Always refrigerate jam as homemade jams are without preservatives.Chiffon cake using homemade Red Plum Jam

title: Stir Fried Minced Pork For Noodles
text: A simple stir fry minced pork dish that can be prepared and kept for later use.Â  Serve well with noodles or rice and a simple vegetable soup as a meal.Ingredients[serve 3-4] 300 gm minced pork [I used tender part of pork - 'wu hua rou'] - marinate for 30 minutes with:3 tsp each ofÂ  light soy sauce,Shaoxing wine2 tsp each sugar, pepper and dark soy sauce1 tbsp cornflour1 tbsp chopped garlic2 tsp chilli paste1 tbsp sesame oil1-2 tbsp oil [depends on the fat content of the meat]3 dried mushrooms - soaked until soft and dicedHeat oil in wok, saute chilli paste for a few seconds, then add in chopped garlic.Â  Fry until fragrant, add in mushrooms.Â Â  Continue to fry until aromatic.Â Add in minced pork. Continue to stir fry ingredients until cooked through.Â  Add in 3 tbsp water.Â  Continue to fry until meat is almost dry but moist.Dish out and set aside to serve with blanched noodles or rice together with seasoning sauce for noodles/rice.To serve noodles, boil a pot of water, add in a pinch of salt and a few drops of oil.Â  Put in noodles and scald for a few minutes until cooked.Â  Drain well.Â  Place noodles in serving plate.Â  Mix in 1-2 tbsp of seasoning sauce and toss to combine.Â  Top with prepared minced pork mixture and garnish with chopped spring onions and chilli.Â  Serve with a bowl of soup/vegetables.Seasoning Sauce for Noodles/Rice[enough for 3 serving] 3 bundles of 'Wang Di Mein' or any dried noodles preferred1 tbsp fine tau cheong [I used miso paste]3 tbsp light soy sauce2 tsp dark soy sauce3 tsp sugar1/2 tsp pepper1 tsp sesame oil1 ladle of soup stock/water [optional]Boil ingredients in a small saucepan for a minute.Â  Set aside to mix with blanched noodles/rice when serving.Note:Â Leftovers can be kept for later use.Â  Reheat, use as topping for blanched vegetables etc.'Wang Di Mein' can be bought [according to bundles] from most of the grocery stalls at the wet market. Â One bundle is equivalent to 1 serving. Â It is easy to cook and can be Â  blanched and then steamed before serving.

title: Lotus Seeds with Lily Bulbs Dessert
text: Another of Soup Queen'sÂ  light and sweet dessert to drink before you turn in for the nightÂ recipe for women which I tried and like. Â  Taste better if it is sweeter.Â  This simple dessert is for beautiful skin.Excerpt from Soup Queen's blog:Â Â "Drinking this regularly - say once a week - is touted to improve your skin texture and promote cell regeneration".Â "Lotus seeds benefits the spleen, heart and kidneys. It also calms because it helps with restlessness and insomnia. It clears heat and therefore highly nutritious to people prone to heatiness".The portion of the ingredients are according to the minimum quantity which the vendor is willing to sell. Â I try not to buy more the the quantity required to prepare the dessert.IngredientsÂ [3 bowls]50 gm lotus seed - soaked to soften and remove the pith20 gm dried lily bulbs [pak hup] - RM 12 tbsp rock sugar to taste [more if you prefer it sweet]500 ml waterPlace all ingredients into a slow cooker or crockpot. Simmer for an hour. Serve warm.

title: Lemon Chiffon Cake
text: This  is another very good chiffon cake recipe from Happy Home Baking which I have tried once before. Â  I like this cake because it is soft, light and moist.Â  The sourish taste and aroma from lemon can make you go for more than a slice. Â Thanks to Happy Home Baking for Â sharing the recipe and giving me the confidence to try baking more chiffon cakes.Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]2.5 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp oil50 ml water + 25 ml lemon juicezest of 1 lemonWhisk  egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â   Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in water and lemon juice.Â Â  Fold in flour and zest until well combined. Â Set aside while  you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 160 degrees.100 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powder + 1/2 tsp saltIngredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar 3 tbsp sugar [40 gm]Whisk egg white until frothy, continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk  mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue  till well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â Knock a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 160 degrees for 45 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Mixed Fresh Vegetables With Garlic Sauce
text: Serving this salad with Devil's Chicken and Tumeric Rice.Â  This salad can be prepared and kept in the fridge until ready to eat.Â  Refreshingly fresh and light.Ingredients2 zuchini - wash and shreddedsome salad leaves - wash and cut thin shreds1 tomato - seeded and cut stripsCut all the vegetables and place in a colander to drip dry while you prepare the garlic sauce.Garlic Sauce - Mix togetherÂ 2 tbsp minced garlic3 tbsp mirin3 tsp light soy sauce2 tsp sesame oiljuice of 2 calamasi lime or 1 tbsp vinegarsalt and pepper to tastesome toasted sesame seed In a mixing bowl, mix together all the garlic sauce ingredients.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Garnish with a sprinkle of toasted sesame seeds.Pour over prepared vegetables.Â  Toss to mix well and refrigerate until later use.

title: Devil's Chicken
text: Easy to prepare very fragrant and flavourful Devil's Chicken which goes well with rice or bread.Â  Basic recipe from The Waitakere Redneck's Kitchen but I adjusted some of the spices because I prefer it to be more spicy. Â  Can consider as a healthy dish as it is not oily. Â It's yummy.Ingredients Â [serves 3]500gm whole chicken leg - skin removed and cut bit size pieces [marinated with 1/2 tbsp tumeric and 1/2 tsp salt for at least 2 hours]1 tomato - quartered1 onion - quartered2 tbsp oilGrind together5 shallots, 3 cloves garlic, 2 red chilli, 1/2" piece ginger then mix in 2 tsp each of meat curry powder and chilli pasteSeasoning2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp each of sugar and lemon juice1/2 tbsp each of light soy sauce and worchester sauce1/2 tsp salt to taste1/2 cup waterHeat oil, fry ground ingredients until fragrant.Â  Add in chicken pieces.Â  Fry until chicken pieces are almost firm.Â Add in seasoning.Â  Fry for a few minutes and add in water.Â  Bring it to a rolling boil.Cover and simmer on low heat to cook chicken for about 20 minutes.Â  Add in tomatoes and onion.Â  Cook for another 5 minutes and sauce is thickened.Dish out to serve with rice or bread.Â Note:I served the Devil's Chicken with Tumeric Rice and Mixed Fresh Vegetables with Garlic Sauce.

title: Tumeric Rice
text: Fried crispy shallots andspring onions enhance the taste of the riceThis Tumeric Rice is cooked using Basmathi rice which I am serving with Devil's Chicken and Mixed Fresh Vegetables with Garlic Sauce.Â  Initially planned to cook a middle-eastern chicken curry 'Bamia Chicken' which is very spicy to go with the rice, but since I didn't have some of the spices in hand, I can only cook it some other time.A very simple yet fragrant rice which goes well with any curry or fried chicken, prawns and fish.Ingredients[serves 3-4] 2 cups basmathi rice - washed and drain2 shallots - sliced1/2 inch piece ginger - sliced1/3 tsp tumeric powder 1/2 tsp salt1/2 tsp chicken stock granules 1-2 pandan leaves600 ml or enough water to cook the rice1/2 tbsp oilHeat oil in wok to saute shallots and ginger until fragrant.Add in the rice and seasoning.Â  Quickly mix together and transfer to a rice cooker to cook or steam with enough water to cook rice with pandan leaves.Sprinkle with some shallot crisps.Â Â Serve with Devil's Chicken.

title: Salting Chicken Eggs in Brine Solution
text: Previously, I tried salting eggs with salt and wine for several times but each time did not manage to get the same expected results.Â  Sometime this February, I came across this recipe from Redneck's Kitchen which is quite simple to follow.Â  So I gave it a try using 6 chicken eggs and 2 duck eggs. Â After the 20th day, I took out an egg and shake it, a traditional way to check whether the salted egg is ready. Â Didn't really hear any obvious sound 'which is like something hard in solution', so I put it back. Â On the 25th day, I did the same thing and this time I heard what was expected and knew the salted eggs are ready for use. Â  I boiled 2 eggs [1 each of the duck and chicken eggs] but found it a bit too salty serving them with rice. Â  I gave the balance to my Ma. Â She served a few with porridge and an egg to steam minced meat, the saltiness is acceptable.Â Â Ingredients - eggs, container and brineHere are the ingredients I used.Â 6 chicken eggs2 duck eggs1 cup salt [can reduce to 3/4 cup]4 cups water2 tbsp Shaoxing wine [for added flavour] - optionalThe ingredients and method are according to Redneck's Kitchen.5 largest chicken eggs1/4 cup saltÂ  to 1 cup water [salt:water ratio] - can reduce the saltÂ plastic or glass containerbrine must cover eggs - submergedTo work out how much liquid you need, place eggs in your chosen container.Â  Pour cold water into the container. Drain the water to a measuring jar to work out the salt ratio.Dissolve salt in hot water. Leave to cool.Pour the salt water into the container to completely cover the eggs.Label and keep in a cool place for at least 1 month [Mine was ready by the 25th day].Remove eggs and store in the fridge.Â  Use as required.

title: Mango & Passion Fruit Chiffon Cake
text: The passion fruit seeds are very crunchyThis is a good chiffon cake recipe from Happy Home Baking. Â I like to follow the recipe from Happy Home Baking because most of the chiffon cake recipes here only require 3 eggs. Â I prefer to bake a smaller cake so that it can be finished sooner rather than a bigger cake which cannot be finished by my small family.Â Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]1-2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp oil40 ml passion fruit juice [from 1-2 passion fruit] - keep the seeds3 tbsp Mango and Passion fruit jam [recipe here]Whisk egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in fruit juice.Â  Lastly stir in jam and seeds. Â Fold in flour until well combined. Â Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 170 degrees C.100 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powderIngredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white3 tbsp sugar [40 gm]Whisk egg white until frothy, continue whisking, when foamy, gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue till well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan. Â Knock a few times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â  Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 45 minutes.Â Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Black Sesame Seed Chiffon
text: I tried this chiffon cake recipe from Blessed Homemaker sometime in July 2010. Â That time, I wasn't really into posting recipes in my blog. Â I kept the recipe because the cake was really good. Â So here again, I baked this cake since I have some grounded black sesame paste [leftover from my bread making].Â  This time, I am trying it out with 3 eggs [Small Small Baker's recipe]. The cake has good texture, soft, light and moist.Â  Ingredients for Egg Mixture4 egg yolks [large] [3 eggs]2.5 tbsp castor sugar [2 tbsp]1/4 tsp salt [same]4 tbsp corn oil [2 tbsp]130 ml milk [70 ml water]20 gm black sesame seed paste [40 gm black sesame powder]Beat egg yolks and sugar together, then continue beating while adding oil, followed by milk.Â  Then fold in the black sesame seed paste until well incorporated.Â  Fold in sifted flour until well combined and set aside while you prepare the egg white mixture.Preheat oven at 160 degrees for 10 minutes.150 gm cake flour + 1 tsp baking powder [or 150 gm self raising flour] - sifted [80 gm + 1 tsp baking powder]Ingredients for Egg White Mixture4 egg whites [3 egg whites]1/2 tsp cream of tartar [1/4 tsp]4 level tbsp of castor sugar [30 gm sugar]Whisk egg white until frothy then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking and gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until foamy and soft peaks formed.Fold 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture until well combined.Â  Pour into the balance meringue and fold until well mixed.Pour mixture into 7" chiffon pan.Â  Tap on table top several times to expel out trapped air.Baked in preheated oven for 40-45 minutes on lower rack.Â  Remove and invert pan immediately after baking.Â  Cool and then remove from pan before slicing.Note:You can even try the quantity in red which uses only 3 eggs [if you happened to have large eggs or only 3 eggs, ha ha]. Â I got the recipe from Small Small Baker's blog.Â  There were some white spots in the cake.Â  This is because I have whisked the egg white until stiff and egg yolk and meringue not too well incorporated.

title: Japanese Cream Buns
text: Came across this bun recipe from Lena's blog [frozen wings]. Â I have tried her English Cottage Bread Loaf which was good and I believe this recipe must also be good. Â Today, I baked them and the quantity is enough for me to share with my neighbour.The buns are really soft and moist even on the third day. Â The texture is good too. Â Since I do not have whipping cream I replaced it with plain yoghurt. Â Lovely buns which I believe can be used with any type of fillings.Ingredients[makes 20-24 buns] Ingredients A Â Â 120 gm bread flour + 85 ml boiling waterAdd boiling water to flour.Â  Stir well to form a dough.Â  Cover and set aside to cool before keeping in refrigerator for at least 12 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before use.Ingredients B380 gm bread flour [I added some wholemeal flour]5 tbsp [75 gm] sugar1 tsp salt 2.6 tsp [8gm] yeastIngredients C120 ml cold milk100 ml whipping cream [I used plain yoghurt]1 cold eggIngredients D - 40 gm butterMix ingredients well and add in C.Â  Knead to form a rough dough.Â  Add in A.Â  Knead until well blended [after about 10 minutes kneading].Add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until dough is soft, smooth and elastic.Â  Let proof until double.Â  Punch down dough and divide into portions [to fit the baking tray] or 60 gm each.Â  Roll round and rest for 10 minutes.Place in baking tray and let proof for 50 minutes to an hour.Bake in preheated oven at 190 degrees C for 15 minutes.Remove to cool on rack.Note:Can use Mexico topping by the 2nd proofing.Mexico topping [Mix together all ingredients]60 gm butter + 50 gm sugar - cream and add in 1 egg.Â  Cream until smooth and add in 65gm flour + 1/4 tsp baking powder.Â  Mix well.Â  Pipe topping on top of buns before baking.

title: Sticky Vermicelli Broth [Mee Suah Kor]
text: Another noodle dish from Amy Beh's collection of recipes. Â The recipe uses quite basic ingredients.Â  This broth looks quite similar to one of our Penang's traditional noodles Â  called 'Mee Suah Kor' in Hokkien which is cooked in a big pot for the blue collar workers [coolies and construction workers] in the olden days.Â  I remember, when I was very young, I have seen hawkers preparing this noodle and the yellow noodles into very thick soupy broth with dried prawns and sometimes meat.I think these type of noodles are still sold at the Cecil Street Market, Penang in the afternoons but no more for the 'coolies' and labourers.Ingredients[serves 2-3]Â A handful of prawns - shelled and diced100 gm minced pork meat - marinate with 1/4 tsp pepper, 1/8 tsp sugar, 1 tsp oyster sauce, 1/2 tsp light soy sauce and 1 tbsp cornflour for 15Â  minutes2 dried mushrooms - soaked and shredded1/2 tsp each chopped shallots and garlic1 litre chicken stock1 tbsp sesame oilSeasoning for soup1 tbsp each of light soy sauce and Shao Hsing wine1/2 tsp fish sauce1/4 tsp pepper dash of msg 20 gm potato starch + 5 tbsp water for thickeningÂ 180 gm flour vermicelli - scald in boiling water for a minute.Â  Drain and toss in a little sesame oilGarnishing - chopped spring onions and coriander2-3 tbsp black vinegar [chit choe]Heat sesame oil in a wok. Fry chopped shallots and garlic until fragrant and lightly browned.Â  Push aside and add in meat, prawns and mushrooms to fry briskly with a few tablespoons of chicken stock.Â  Fry for a minute until cooked through.Â  Dish out and set aside.Bring the chicken stock to boil in a large saucepan or claypot.Â  Add in seasoning and flour vermicelli.Â  Give a quick stir to loosen noodles.Â  Drizzle in thickening and stir well to mix.Turn off heat and add in pre-cooked meat, prawns and mushroom mixture.Â  Garnish with spring onions and dish out into individual serving bowls and serve hot with black vinegar for added flavour.

title: English Cottage Loaf Bread [Sponge Dough Method]
text: Saw this bread recipe in Lena's [frozen wings] food blog which looks good.Â  So I tried baking it today but I used the sponge dough method with the same ingredients because I am leaving the house for my regular morning exercise.Â  I just mix half portion of the bread flour and water with the yeast into a rough dough.Â  Cover and leave it to rest for 1-2 hours and finish off doing the dough when I came back.Â  In a way it helps to save time while I do other things [going for exercise and nearby morning market].A good bread recipe to keep. Â Bread is soft, moist, light and texture is lovely.IngredientsÂ [makes 2 loaves x 400 gm]Overnight Dough 150 gm bread flourÂ 100 gm plain flour3.5 Â tsp instant yeast180 ml waterMix  all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for  at least 1-2 hours. Ingredients for Bread Dough250 gm bread flour2 tbsp milk powder3 tbsp sugar1 tspÂ  salt1 egg80 ml water or just enough to make a soft but not wet dough50 gm butter [2 tbsp]Topping [optional] - butter and sugar - after proofing, use a knife to cut slits and spread butter, then sprinkle sugar Add  all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the overnight dough.Â   Knead until well combined, then gradually add in water while  kneading until a soft dough is formed.Â  Knead for about 10 minutes then  add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft, smooth, elastic and dough  does not stick to the fingers [about 15 minutes on high speed].Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and fold  each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place  in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than  an hour or until double in size.Â Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 - 30 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.Â Â Note:This bread makes lovely bread toast with Â butter and jam

title: EZ Braised Pork Belly
text: This is an EZ braised meat recipe worth keeping. Â The basic recipe is from Amy Beh's website but I did not follow all the procedures especially on the deep frying of the pork pieces. Â Instead, I make sure the pork skin is well dried and I pan fried them. Â The result is satisfactory and best of all this dish can be prepared way ahead of meal time or even one day ahead. Â I kept the whole pot in the refrigerator. Â Before serving, I removed the fats that have coagulated on the surface [more healthy] then reheat the dish. Â Viola! Just slice the meat and enjoy with white rice, some vegetables and chilli sauce if preferred.Ingredients1 kg pork belly - cleaned and cut into 2 portions1 tsp dark soy sauceBoil enough water in a wok.Â  Place pork bell in boiling water to blanch for about 5 minutes.Â  Remove and rinse well.Â  Use a fork to prick holes on the skin as much as possible.Â  Rub skin with dark soy sauce.Â  Place pork pieces skin side up in a container.Â  Leave it in the refrigerator to dry the skin [can prepare this a day earlier].Â  Heat a non stick wok with a little oil on medium heat.Â  Place pork belly skin side down in to pan fry until 'blisters' all over.Â  The sear the sides until slighty golden.Â  Remove and soak pork in a basin of iced cold water for about 15 minutes.Â  Drain and set aside.8 dried mushrooms - soaked [ I used dried mushroom and 1 packet 'king mushroom] - cut half or keep whole50 gm ginger - cut into a few thick slices1 tbsp chopped garlic4cm piece cinnamon stick3 star anise5 cloves1 tsp cumin seeds1-2 stalks of spring onion700 ml water [enough to cover pork pieces]200 gm broccoli - cut into florets and blanched [optional]coriander leaves for garnishing 1 tbsp potato starch mix with 2 tbsp waterSauce Ingredients2 tbsp fish sauce2 tbsp soy sauce2 tbsp sesame oil 2 tbsp Shao Hsing Hua Tiau wine2 tbsp rock sugar1 tsp chicken stock granules2 tsp pepperPlace ginger slices, chopped garlic, spring onions, cinnamon stick, star anise, cloves, cumin seeds in a based of heavy based pot.Â  Then place pork belly skin side up on top of the spice ingredients.Â Â Place the mushrooms around the pork belly and add in the sauce ingredients.Â  Pour in water.Â  Bring water to a rolling boil for about 5 minutes.Â Â Lower heat and braise meatÂ  for 45-50 minutes or until just tender.Â  Do not overcook meat, the texture of the meat should have a bite.Â Â To serve, remove and cut slices.Â  Place on serving plate.Strain the gravy to remove the impurities and thicken with potato starch mix.Â  Pour gravy over cut meat and garnish with coriander leaves or blanched broccoli.

title: Prawns and White Fungus Salad
text: Salad is always an appetising dish to serve for dinner especially during hot weather season. Some salads can also be prepared and kept in the refrigerator until serving time, thus reducing the things to do before meal. Â I love to cook dishes that can be prepared earlier, way ahead of meal times. Â At least there won't be much cleaning to do after meal time. Â Ingredients[serves 2] 1 whole white fungus - soaked until plumped up, remove the hard centre and cut into small pieces150 gm prawns - boiled/steamed to cook and shelleda handful of cherry tomatoes - cut half 1 big onion - sliced thinly1 red chilli - sliced thinly or 2 red small chillies1/2 cup mint leavessome coriander leavessome roasted sesame seeds Salad Dressing [Mix together]1.5 tbsp sugar or to taste1/8 tsp salt1/2 tsp chicken stock powder3 tbsp lime juice1 tbsp fish sauce1/8 tsp pepper or to tastea dash of sesame oilÂ Scald white fungus pieces in hot water for 1-2 minutes.Â  Drain and soak in icy cold water for 10 minutes.Â  Drain in colander.Sliced shelled prawns into half and prepare the rest of the salad ingredients as above.Mix all salad ingredients in a big bowl.Â  Add in salad dressing.Â  Toss well and transfer to a serving dish.Â  Cover with cling wrap and refrigerate until serving time.Before serving, garnish with some toasted sesame seeds.Here are some information obtained from Chinese Soup Pot about white fungus [aka snow fungus].Â  White Fungus Uses and Health Benefits:In Chinese medicine, white fungus nourishes and moistens the lungs, as well as improves skin complexion.It removes what Chinese medicine calls dryness and heat  in the body by moistening and increasing body fluids. White fungus  eases physical symptoms like dry skin, chapped lips, thirst, dry nose  and throat, constipation, and dry coughs.Some clinical data have shown that white fungus has the potential of  lowering elevated blood sugar, and an inhibitory effect on cholesterol  levels.According to a report by Cancer Research UK, white fungus is also  used as an immune tonic and for treating debility and exhaustion.

title: Watercress Chicken Soup
text: I loved cooking soup with vegetables and less meat.Â  This is a simple but nutritious soup which can be prepared earlier before meal time.Â  The portion here is enough for 2-3 people depending on how many other dishes you are preparing for lunch or dinner.Â Ingredients2 chicken thighs - skin removed, clean and cut into bite size pieces200 gm watercress - washed, cut and blanch inÂ  boiling water, rinse and drain [reduces the bitterness in soup]3-4 red dates1 dried honey dates [mat choe]1 tbsp bitter almonds [pak hung]1 tbsp sweet almonds [lam hung]1/2 tsp chicken stock granulessalt to taste600 ml hot waterPrepare the ingredients as stated above.Â  Put watercress, chicken pieces and other ingredients in a serving claypot.Â  Pour in hot water.Bring soup to a rolling boil for 2-3 minutes.Â  Off fire.Â Â Prepare a steaming pot with enough water and a steaming tray.Â  Put claypot on a steaming tray and steam soup for 30 - 40 minutes.Â Â  Reheat soup before serving and add salt to taste.Note:Cooking soup by double boiling or steaming will give a clear soup.Â  Convenient and clean way if cooking in small quantity and you can serve the soup in the claypot.the cardinal rule of making 'sai yeong choi' or watercress soup [without the bitter taste] is the pot of water MUST BE BOILING before you add watercress. Â Â If you add watercress into water which is warming up or even cold water, your soup will turn out bitter [from the Soup Queen].

title: Bouncy Pork Meatballs
text: This recipe is from The Waitakere Redneck's Kitchen.Â  I have been searching for good meatball recipes which are simple, can be prepared and stored for later use.Â  So when I saw that these meatballs can be kept frozen until required, I did not hesitate to try it out.I think I am quite happy with the result and it's a keeper.Â  Maybe, I will make these meatballs for steamboat instead of buying the ready-made ones.Here are the ingredients and method from Redneck's Kitchen.Â IngredientsÂ Makes 48 pieces [1/2 tablespoon size]500 gm pork - cut into small pieces [I used Kak Sim meat]1/2 cup [125 ml] icy cold water1/2 - 3/4 tsp salt1/2 - 3/4 tbsp sugar1Â  1/4 tsp baking powder1/2 tbsp oil [I used 1 tsp each of oil and sesame oil]1 tbsp fish sauce2 tbsp cornflour1/4 tsp pepperÂ  [ I used 1/2 tsp]In a separate cup, mix all the seasoning [except pepper] together.Â  Set aside in the refrigerator.Minced pork in a food processor into a paste.Â  Add 5 tbsp of water [from the 125 ml water], 1 tbsp at a time to make a smooth paste.Remove paste into a big bowl.Â  Pour in mixed seasoning.Â  Stir well slowly using several chopsticks or hand in one direction until liquid is absorbed into the paste.Â Â Transfer paste to a smaller container, cover and keep in freezer for 30 minutes.Boil a pot of water.Â  Once water is boiling, remove from heat.Add pepper to paste.Â  Stir to combine.Â  Scoop paste into wet hand.Â  Push paste up through the thumb and second finger by making a fist.Â  Use a wet spoon [a tablespoon] to scoop and drop it into the pot of hot water.Â  [To prevent paste from sticking to hand, wet hand and spoon in water].Continue until pork balls form a layer in the water.Â  Now, turn on the heat but 'Do Not Let It Boil', just simmer slowly without bubbling [otherwise pork balls will not 'Bounce'].Â  Any leftovers can be kept in the freezer.Fill a basin with icy cold water.Â  When pork balls start to float, leave for a few seconds more.Â  Remove one and cut into half to see if it is cooked.Â  The inside should not be 'pink'.Â  Scoop out the pork balls and letÂ  them cool in the cold water.After pork balls have cooled, use as required or freeze to keep.Note from Redneck's KitchenFor Chicken meatballs - pepper is optional.Â  The meatball texture is softer than pork balls.For Beef meatballs - must add 1/2 tsp alkaline water to seasoning mix.

title: Homemade PlainTortillas
text: My hubby has been asking for flat bread something like chapati where you can eat with curry or roll up with fillings and fresh vegetables.Â  But I wasn't keen to buy ready made ones from the stores because I believe it contains much fats.Â  So when I saw this recipe from Lena of Frozen Wing's blog, I thought it is time to try them.Â  Just wondering whether the oil quantity can be reduced.I prepared the 12345 Chicken Fillet as fillings for these tortillas.Ingredients[makes 10 pieces]250 gm [2 cups] all purpose flour1/4 cup vegetable oil1 tsp salt2/3 cup warm waterSift flour and salt into a medium size bowl.Â  Add oil and warm water.Â  Use a pair of chopstick to stir to combine all the ingredients into a dough.Transfer dough onto a lightly floured smooth surface.Â  Knead for 2-3 minutes until dough is smooth [not difficult to work out dough].Divide dough into 10 pieces.Â  Roll each piece into a ball.Â  Cover and allow to rest for 30 minutes.Preheat a cast iron skillet or a heavy based non-stick pan.Â  Roll each ball into a circle of 6" in diameter.Â  Cook one at a time, flipping halfway through cooking, when it starts to puff and a few spots appear.Stack up tortillas and serve them with any fillings or curry.Note:If serving later, stack tortillas and wrap in foil to enclose.Â  Bake for 3-4 minutes or until hot in a preheated oven at 180 degrees Celsius.Â  To assemble, place some salad leaves, chicken, onions on tortilla.Â  Squeezed any preferred sauce [bbq, chilli, yoghurt or mayonnaise] on top.Â  Wrap and roll.Â  Cut into sections and serve at once.

title: 12345 Chicken Fillet
text: I came across the recipe '12345 Pork Ribs or Lean Meat' on The Waitakere Redneck's Kitchen and tried it using whole chicken at my Ma's place.Â  The sauce combination was good and very easy to prepare.Â  But I prefer either to use chicken thighs or lean meat.Â  So back to my home, I used chicken breast fillet to cook this dish because I can pan fry the fillet and I intend to serve it with homemade tortillas.Â  I think it should be alright with any choice of meat depending on your own preference.Here are the ingredients.Â  I marinate the chicken fillet before pan frying them.Ingredients1 chicken breast - skin and bones removed - cut thick slices[marinate with 1/2 tsp each of pepper, sesame oil and salt and 1 tbsp cornflour]Â Pan fry chicken fillet in non stick wok with 1 tbsp oil until golden brown on both sides.Â  Finish fry them in batches to reduce the quantity of oil needed.Sauce Ingredients1 tbsp oil2 tbsp sugar3 tbsp light soy sauce4 tbsp Chin Kiang black vinegar [I used Chit Choe]Using the same wok, add oil if it is less than 1 tbsp [remaining from pan frying chicken fillet].Â  Add in sugar.Â  When sugar melts and caramelise, add in the light soy sauce and vinegar.Â  Stir until caramelised sugar dissolves.Then stir in the fried chicken meat.Â  Stir to mix sauce and meat slices.Â  Cook very quickly until sauce is reduced and thick.Dish out to serve with rice.Â Â Note:Should be good idea to garnish this dish with fresh vegetables [sliced zuchini, salad leaves, tomatoes or blanched broccoli].Â Â  Maybe I will try preparing this dish again using other cuts of meat to serve as a 'One Dish Meal' with white rice, some fresh vegetables or vegetable soup.

title: Cranberry, Coffee Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: Came across this recipe 'cranberry coffee loaf' is the local newspaper sometime back.Â  Since I have all the ingredients ready, I decided to prepare this bread but I added yoghurt as I know yoghurt makes the bread lovely and deliciously good.Â  The aroma of the freshly baked bread was really satisfying.Here is my version and method.Â   Ingredients for Overnight Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour4 tsp instant yeast200 - 250 ml water   Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof   for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing   and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before   adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour2 tbsp milk powder 4 tbsp sugar1 tspÂ  salt60 gm dried cranberry3 tsp instant coffee granules dissolved in 50 ml water1 small tub [135 gm] yoghurt [natural or cranberry type] 2 tbsp butterÂ Add   all the ingredients [except butter and cranberries] to the overnight dough.Â    Knead until well combined and dough isÂ soft.Â   Knead for  about 10  minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading  until soft,  smooth and elastic. Â Add inÂ  dried cranberries. Â Knead a further 3-5  minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide   dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and  fold each portion into thirds,   then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â   Place in baking tin [Pullman's   tin] and leave to proof in oven for  more than an hour or until double  in  size.Â  [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Steamed Buns With Chinese Sausage [Starter Dough Method]
text: First time making this pattern pau, practice will make perfectDuring the Chinese New Year, most Chinese families will buy chinese sausages [lap cheong] as CNY gifts for friends and relatives.Â  However, not all people will eat chinese sausages as it is a preserved food and rather fatty.Â  This is so with some of my friends who received them as part of their CNY gifts and just do not know what to do with it.Â  So, when they gave them to me, I will usually used them as fillings to make Steamed Buns. Â These buns are really tasty and of course they just love it.How to prepare the Chinese sausages [lap cheong] for wrapping?Enough number of Chinese sausage - skin removed and cut into 4 pieces.some oyster sauce, water and Â a little cornflour mix.Pan fry the prepared sausages in a non stick pan [without oil] for a few minutes. Â Add in oyster sauce then some water to combine with sausages. Â Stir in cornflour mix [just enough to coat the sausages]. Â Dish out on plate to cool before using. Â Can prepare ahead and refrigerate until required.This is how the sausages look after fryingIngredients for Starter DoughÂ 175 gm plain flour/pau flour1 tsp yeast100 ml warm waterMix all ingredients into a sticky, rough dough. Â Cover dough and leave for 1-2 hours or until 2-3 times in size.Ingredients for Bun Dough175 gm plain flour/pau flour1.5 tbsp [40 gm] castor sugar1 tsp double action baking powder100 ml warm water1/4 tsp vinegar 1 tbsp oil or vegetable shorteningMix all ingredients [except water and oil] with starter dough. Â Knead to combine ingredients well, then gradually add in water as you knead the dough until soft and smooth. Â If using electric mixer, it takes about 10 minutes. Â Then add in vegetable shortening/oil. Â Continue kneading for another 10-15 minutes until dough is soft, smooth and elastic [does not stick to fingers]. Â Cover dough and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down and divide into 2 portions. Â Roll each portion and fold in thirds. Â Then roll into a log and divide into 8 pieces. Â Do the same for the other portion. Â [After this step, you can roll out the dough into any shape to suit the fillings used]. Â Roll each small piece into an oval shape. Â Â Place a piece of sausage in the centre, then make equal number of slits on both sides and fold criss-cross to cover the sausage. Â Pinch the end and place it on a steaming tray lined with greased proof paper. Â See photos below.Leave to rise for at least 1/2 hour or until double in size.Steam over boiling water on high heat for 12-13 minutes. Â Off fire and leave buns in steamer [covered] for another 1 minutes. Â Then remove the cover and place buns on rack to cool or serve immediately.Note:Please refer to Steamed Meat Pau [Tua Pau] recipe for straight dough method.Â  This is a really good pau skin recipe to keep.

title: Braised Spanish Mackerel With Soy Sauce and Mirin
text: This is a simple and healthy 3 dish meal for 2 that costs less than Ringgit 10.00. Â Not too bad idea of simple dishes if you are looking for some non-spicy food for dinner.The above picture shows the 3 dishes that goes well with plain white rice:Â Braised Spanish Mackerel with Soy Sauce and MirinMiso Tofu and Seaweed SoupSalad leaves, cherry tomato Yoghurt SaladBRAISED SPANISH MACKEREL WITH SOY SAUCE AND MIRIN 2 pieces Spanish mackerel - clean and pat dry3-5 spices ginger [more if you love ginger]1 stalk spring onions - cut slantwise about 1 inch lengths [keep some for garnishing]2 tbsp soy sauce3 tbsp mirindash of pepper1-2 tbsp oilPan fry Spanish mackerel with oil in non-stick pan until both sides are golden brown. Â Push aside.Use the remaining oil to saute ginger slices and part of the spring onions until fragrant [maybe slightly brown].Add in soy sauce from around the wok followed by mirin and pepper. Â Bring it to a bubbly boil. Â Push the fried fish slices back into the sauce to braise until sauce is slightly thickened [1-2 seconds]. Â Flip over fish slices for 1 time so that it is well coated with sauce. Â  Very quick process.Dish out to serve with garnishing [spring onions].Serve with rice.Note: Â Can also use Salmon slices but reduce the oil quantity.JAPANESE MISO TOFU SOUP400 ml water1 piece soft tofu - cut big cubes1 small piece seaweed [hai tai] - wash and soak in water for a few minutes - cut wide strips2 tbsp Japanese Miso pasteMix miso paste with some of the water until well mixed. Â Set asideBring water to boil in a soup pot. Â Add in miso paste mix and seaweed 'hai tai' and tofu cubes. Â Let it boil again, then lower heat to simmer for another 5-10 minutes.Serve hot with rice.SALAD LEAVES, CHERRY TOMATO WITH YOGHURT SALADSome salad leaves - washed and break into small piecessome cherry tomatoes - cut half1 small tub plain yoghurt [about 135 gm]1/2 tsp fish saucejuice of 1 calamasi lime1 tsp sugar [optional]Mix all ingredients together and refrigerate until serving time.

title: Steamed Noodles With Clams and Meat
text: Extra vegetable to serve with noodlesClams used to be cheap but now getting expensive these days.Â  But cooking clams at home is still worth it and there are various ways to prepare them for the family.Â  You can fry, boil or steam and it still taste good whichever way you treat it, only not to overcook it.Â  Came across some lovely recipes from Amy Beh's collection.Â  I prefer the boiling or steaming methods.Here I tried preparing Steamed Clams with Pork Belly by also adding rice vermicelli [beehoon] to make it into a '1 Dish Meal' for two.Â  Simple and easy but delicious without frying and the kitchen is 'clean'.Â  I will try toÂ  prepare the original recipe some other time [please check out the recipe in Kuali.com if you wish to try it out].Ingredients[serves 2]120 gm rice vermicelli [beehoon] - soaked in water for 15 minutes or till almost softcoriander and spring onions - cut for garnishing30 gm ginger - finely shredded1 red chilli - sliced300 gm clams - rinse thoroughly, soaked 15 minutes.Â  Wash and rinse again. Drain off water150 gm meat fillet - sliced thinly - marinate with 1-2 tbsp of marinade/seasoning sauceMarinade [Mix together]1/2 tsp each of pepper, sugar, salt, chicken stock granules and sesame oil1 tbsp each of fish sauce, Shao Hsing wine, fried garlic oil and cornflour150 - 200 ml waterÂ  Prepare the ingredients above.Place soaked rice vermicelli on a casserole dish.Â  Top up with marinated meat slices and shredded ginger and some spring onions.Â  Top up with clams, pour remaining marinade sauce, Â ginger and sliced chilli/chilli padi.Prepare steamer or wok for steaming.Â  Bring water to boil on high heat. Steam dish over high heat for 12-15 minutes or until clams open up.Â  Serve at once with garnishing and extra garlic crisps [optional].Serve noodles with a plate of simple stir fried yaw mak with fish sauce.Note:If you prefer more soupy noodles, you can add more water and seasoning sauce. to noodles

title: Red Beans With Longan Sweet Dessert
text: I prefer this type of red beans to the usual darker coloured red beans.Â  This type is more 'fleshy' after boiling and the beans are soft without skin breaking.Â  It can be boiled with dried longan or even gingko nuts, the soup taste good.Here is a version with only small portion of ingredients enough for 2-3 persons.Â  Many people usually will prefer to buy ready cooked red bean soup because they think it takes a long time to cook and in big quantity.Â  This is not so.Â  By cooking it in your own kitchen, you can 'control' the sweetness of the soup.Ingredients[2-3 bowls]100 gm red beans [see picture]3-4 pieces screwpine leaves [pandan leaves]1 litres water 2-3 tbsp rock sugara handful of dried longan  Pick the rotten beans and discard them.Â  Wash the beans under running water several times.Â  You can soak beans with some water and leave it in the refrigerator for a few hours or overnight.Â  Throw away the water before boiling [some believe this way, it will reduce flatulence effect of beans].Put  all ingredients except rock sugar and longan in a pot.Â  Bring it to a rolling boil  for about 10 minutes.Â  Then lower heat, cover and simmer for 1 hour or until beans are soft.Add rock sugar to taste.Â  Off fire and serve hot or warm.Note:Â I store leftover dessert in the refrigerator, eating them cold or reheat if I want it hot.Useful information from The Soup Queen on 'Why eat red beans?'I am not sure whether the above beans which I used to cook this dessert is considered the actual red beans but here are some information you may not know about red beans to share.known for their 'strengthening' qualities and 'yang' energy.good for blood building, full of iron especially beneficial for women.support kidney and bladder function.good source of magnesium, potassium, zinc copper, manganese and B vitamins. Â High potassium and low sodium can help reduce blood pressure and acts as a natural diuretic.good protein substitute and lots of soluble fibre that helps to eliminate toxins and cholesterol.

title: Coffee Raisin Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough]
text: This recipe is for 2 loaves of bread weighing 550 gm each. Â   Ingredients for Overnight Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour4 tsp instant yeast200 - 250 ml water  Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof  for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing  and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before  adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour2 tbsp milk powder 3 tbsp sugar1 tspÂ  salt1 egg 150 gm raisins - soaked in rum or cool boiled water [just enough to plump up raisins]3 tsp instant coffee granules dissolved in 100 ml hot water60 gm butterÂ Add   all the ingredients [except butter and raisins] to the overnight dough.Â    Knead until well combined and dough isÂ soft for  about 10  minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft,  smooth and elastic. Â Add in Â raisins. Â Knead a further 3-5 minutes and dough does not stick to the fingers.Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide   dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and fold each portion into thirds,   then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's   tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double  in  size.Â  [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Longan, Red Date & Goji Sweet Dessert
text: Thanks to Soup Queen for sharing this wonderful dessert which I tried and like.Â  The dessert is not too sweet and the quantity is just nice for my small family.Â  Apart from this, Soup Queen has advised that this dessert has the following benefits which I think is good for all.These are the benefits: helps replenishing vital energy or Qi; promotes blood and improves eye sight.Ingredients[makes about 4 bowls]A handful of dried longan flesh8 dried red dates - remove seeds - cut small pieces1 tbsp goji berry [kei chee] - soaked in water for a bit1 liter water 2 tbsp rock sugar to taste - depending on how sweet you prefer the dessertPut all ingredients in a pot.Â  Bring to a rolling boil.Â  Then cover and lower fire to simmer for 30 minutes.Serve warm, best before bedtime.Note:Since I love gingko nuts, I boiled separately about 10 -15 gingko nuts in some water until soft withÂ  1 tbsp of rock sugar from above.Â  I served this dessert with a scoop of gingko nuts.Benefits of Gingko Nuts [refer to www.tastehongkong.com/ingredients/gingko-nuts].Â  Aka silver apricots and believed to have these benefits but not to be taken in excess as it is potentially toxic [5-10 nuts a day should be okay]keep skin younglives longerbenefits respiratory system [related illness - asthma, bronchitis and cough etc]

title: Yoghurt Loaf Bread [Overnight Dough Method]
text: Soft bread slices with homemade Mango/Passion fruit jamMy first time baking this lovely bread was in July 2011.Â Â  This time I baked the same bread but using the overnight dough method.Â  Really good.Â  You should try it and keep this recipe.Â  By the way, original recipe was from Hidehide.Fresh from the oven - Yoghurt Loaf BreadIngredientsÂ [makes 2 loaves]Overnight Dough 150 gm bread flourÂ 150 gm plain flour3.5 Â tsp instant yeast250 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour2 tbsp milk powder3 tbsp sugar1 tspÂ  salt1 small tub [135 gm] yoghurt [natural plain or fruity is okay]enough water to make a soft dough or not necessary50 gm butter [2 tbsp]Add all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the overnight dough.Â  Knead until well combined, then gradually add in water [when necessary if the dough is too dry] while kneading until a soft dough is formed.Â  Knead for about 10 minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft, smooth, elastic and dough does not stick to the fingers [about 15 minutes on high speed].Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double in size.Â Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.Note:Always remember that you can toast the homemade bread if it is no longer soft as on the first day of baking. Â It still taste good with butter and jam with a cup of hot beverage. See posting on Mango and Passion Fruit Jam for recipe.

title: Mango and Passion Fruit Jam
text: This is a lovely jam which goes well with bread and can be used to bake Mango and Passion Fruit Chiffon Cake.Ingredients [makes about 2 x 450 gm bottle]500 gm mango flesh - cut small cubes and mashed50 gm passion fruit pulp - remove seeds by pressing fruit pulp through sieve. Â Can keep seeds to bake chiffon cake200 gm granulated sugarPut all ingredients together in a heavy based pot or pan. Â Boil over medium heat.Stir continuously until almost sticky and thick.Cool a plate in the freezer for 5-10 minutes. Â Put a teaspoon of cooked jam on plate. Â Leave in freezer for 1-2 minutes to test if jam is ready. Â If jam is still watery, continue to cook until slightly thicker.Â Â When jam is ready, I add about 1/2 tbsp brandy for fragrance.Note:This jam can be use to bake Mango and Passion Fruit Chiffon Cake. Â Add in the passion fruit seeds when Â baking cake. Â The seeds will be crispy and crunchy.Chiffon cake using homemade mango and passion fruit jam

title: Mandarin Orange Chiffon Cake
text: Came across this recipe at Small Small Baker's and referred to Bernice 's Kitchen. Â Faced the same situation as Small Small Baker, that is, lots of Mandarin oranges left after the CNY celebration in my mum's place. Â  Of course, many has gone rotten too. Â Grateful Small Small Baker came up with the idea to substitute oranges with Mandarin oranges.The Mandarin orange chiffon cake turns out well. Â Soft, light, moist and a nice colour. Â Great idea to clear off the oranges.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]1-2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp oil40 ml fresh Mandarin orange juiceZest of 1 Mandarin orangeÂ Whisk egg yolks with sugar and salt until creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in juice and add in the zest. Â Fold in the flour and combine well. Â Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 175 degrees.50 gm cake flour - Â siftedÂ Ingredients for Egg White Mixture3 egg white3-4 tbsp sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartar or 5 gm cornflourWhisk egg white until frothy then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking until foamy then gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft/stiff peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture until well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue until well incorporated.Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan and knock several times on tabletop to release air bubbles. Â Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 40 minutes.Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: CHOCOLATE MARBLE BREAD LOAF [OVERNIGHT DOUGH METHOD]
text: You must be wondering why I am posting quite a number of loaf bread recipes. Â My hubby loves having bread for breakfast. Â Sometimes, he even has bread for supper especially when he stays up late to watch football. Â That's the reason why I am baking so much bread. Â I don't like baking the same thing all the time eventhough my hubby doesn't mind eating the same kind of bread. Â I get tired baking and eating the same type, so I have to bake a variety otherwise, I will be bored having bread for breakfast with him almost 7 days a week. Â  Having bread at home is also a blessing especially Â when it rains in the early morning and you do not feel like having breakfast outside.Occasionally, I will bake some buns but I tried not to do so too often because my hubby will finish them very fast. Â Buns are not too good for us because I feel the sugar and fat content are much higher. Â Moreover the fillings for the buns are not too healthy especially for us 'senior citizens'.Today, I baked the Chocolate Marble Loaf Bread. Â This is a good bread which I have baked before but did not post the recipe. Â The recipe here is for 2 loaves of 500 gm bread [use half the quantity if baking only 1 loaf]. Â As usual, the 1 loaf is for my friendly neighbour.Ingredients for Overnight Dough100 gm bread flour200 gm plain flour3.5 tsp instant yeast250 ml waterMix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour2 tbsp milk powder3 tbsp sugar1.5 tspÂ  salt1 large egg6 tsp Â cocoa powder [dissolve in hot water to make a thick paste] *50 ml water [more or less] Â 60 gm butter [2 tbsp]* I used 60 gm cooking chocolate - melted and keep warmAdd all the ingredients [except water, butter and cocoa paste] to the sponge dough.Â  Knead until well combined, then gradually add in water [if necessary] while kneading until a soft dough is formed.Â  Knead for about 10 minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft, smooth, elastic and dough does not stick to the fingers [about 15 minutes on high speed].Divide dough into 2 equal portions. Â Add cocoa paste to 1 portion and knead until Â paste is well incorporated to bread dough.Shape into balls separately and cover each with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide both plain and cocoa dough into 3 equal portions of 200 gm each.Â  Roll each portion flat and stack up alternating the plain and cocoa dough. Â Flatten and Â fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double in size.Â Â [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves or braid it by twisting].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Steamed Crabs with Liquor
text: My hubby brought home his catch of 4 crabs today.Â  As I have a recipe for steamed crabs in my 'to try' list of recipes, I just follow it.Â  The steamed crabs have a strong flavour of brandy and ginger garlic aroma.Â  Simple dish that goes well with steamed flavoured rice.Steamed Crabs with LiquorIngredients[serves 2-3]4 mud crabs - medium size [cleaned and cut into half]1 tbsp chopped ginger1 tbsp chopped garlic1 tbsp sesame oil1 egg1 stalk coriander and spring onion - chopped2-3 tbsp brandya pinch of saltHeat wok with sesame oil to saute ginger and garlic.Â  Dish out into a bowl to cool a little.Add in egg, brandy and salt.Â  Mix well and add in the chopped coriander and spring onion [keep some for garnishing].Place crabs in a casserole dish [I used a bamboo steamer and lined it with foil].Â  Pour mixture over crabs.Â  Cover the crabs and steam over boiling water for 30 minutes or until crabs are cooked or changed colour.Serve with plain rice [I served the crabs with a steamed flavoured rice and zuchini relish].Steamed Flavoured Rice1 cup rice - washed and drain [I used Basmathi rice] or quantity enough for two1 tsp sesame oil2 cloves garlic - chopped3 slices ginger1 tsp each oyster sauce, light soy sauce, dark soy sauce and salt, pepper to tasteenough water to cook riceSaute garlic and ginger in sesame oil until fragrant.Â  Add in the rice and all the seasoning.Â  Stir fry to mix well and dish out into a steaming tray.Â  Pour in enough water to cook rice.Steam rice over boiling water for 25 minutes or until rice is cooked.Â  Off fire. Â I fluffed up the rice, transfer to a casserole dish lined with foil.Â  Fold up the foil and set aside for reheating when I steam the crabs [all can be prepared ahead of meal time - less preparation and cleaning].Â  Before serving, I steamed both the crabs and rice together.Zuchini Relish2 - 3 zuchini - cleaned and sliced1 small red chilli - sliced [optional]4 tbsp lime juice2 - 3 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp saltPut sliced zuchini in icy cold water for 5 minutes.Â  Drain off water in a colander.Â  Transfer to a bowl.Mix sugar and salt with lime juice, then pour over zuchini.Â  Mix well and cover.Â  Keep in fridge until serving time.

title: Pineapple, Zuchini Salsa
text: When cooking for dinner, I sometimes prefer not to fry vegetables but instead will prepare a salad or salsa.Â  With salsa, I can use a variety of vegetables and even fruits in it.Here is a simple Salsa recipe which I came across in some food blogs sometime ago.Â  Appetising, refreshing and light.Ingredients [mix all together][serves 2-3] 1/4 pineapple - cut1/2 zuchini - cut fine strips1 big red onion - sliced thinly1 small red chilli or chilli padi - cut1/2 cup mint leaves - shreddedSeasoning [combine together]3 tbsp lime juice1 tbsp fish sauce2 tbsp sugar1/8 tsp saltPrepare vegetables and fruits as above.Â  Mix all in a big bowl.Pour in combined seasoning ingredients.Â  Toss well and transfer to a serving dish.Â  Cover with cling wrap and refrigerate until serving time.

title: SWEET POTATO BRAIDED BREAD LOAF[OVERNIGHT DOUGH METHOD]
text: This is actually a Nastar bun recipe with cheddar cheese filling but I used it to bake the braided loaf as I was short of time.Â  It turns out well, the texture is soft and moist.Â You can make 10 Nastar buns from this quantity. Just divide dough into 10 portions.Â  Roll each portion into a rectangle, fill with a piece of cheddar cheese.Â  Then roll up into a swiss roll, seal the edges, cut across the buns.Â  Place bun in a paper cup to proof until double in size.Â  Before baking, brush with egg glaze and top up with small bits of cheese.Â  Baked at 180 degrees C for 20 minutes.Â  I will try to bake these buns when I have enough time to spare.The quantity in bracket [in red ink] is for 1 loaf of bread.Ingredients forÂ  Overnight Dough130 gm bread flour [65 gm]130 gm plain flourÂ Â  [65 gm]3 tsp instant yeastÂ  [1.5 tsp]140 ml water [70 ml] Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or keep in airtight container and refrigerate for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 10-15 minutes before use.Ingredients for Bread Dough260 gm bread flour [130 gm]2 tbsp milk powder [1 tbsp]3 tbsp sugarÂ  [1.5 tbsp]1/2 tspÂ  saltÂ  [1/4 tsp]130 gm orange sweet potato paste [65 gm]70 ml water/ more or less [35 ml]2 tbsp butter [1 tbsp]Add   all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the sponge dough.Â    Knead until well combined, then gradually add in water while kneading   until a soft dough is formed [you may not need all the water].Â  Knead for   about 10 minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft,   smooth and dough is not sticky [about 10 minutes on high speed].Â  Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide   dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and fold each portion into thirds,   then roll into a log. Â  Flatten and cut into 3 strips and braid.Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's   tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double  in  size. [Best to proof for 1-2 hours].Â  Remove from oven when you preheat the oven.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Kocha Flavour Noodle Soup
text: This is a family style/way of cooking a variety of noodles [beehoon, instant noodles, soybean noodles and fat rice vermicelli].Â  Most times, yam or pumpkin are used to cook the noodle soup but you can omit these if cooking for 1 or 2 people.Â  Of course, if yam is added the soup will be thicker when it turns soft and more aromatic because of the yam.Â  Here I am not adding yam because I am cooking it for a light lunch.Â In Taiwan, this noodle is served together with Taiwanese Chicken RollsÂ [see posting]Ingredients for noodle soupIngredients[serves 1]1 bundle of rice vermicelli [beehoon] - soak for 5 minutes and drain1 dried mushroom - soaked and cut stripssome dried prawns - wash and drainsome meat slices - marinate with light soy sauce and cornfloursome cut shallots and garlic1 stalk mustard leaves [chai sim] - wash and cutsome cut chilli [optional]seasoning - salt, chicken stock granules and pepper to taste1/2 tbsp oil300 ml waterÂ Â Blanched noodles in boiling water to cook and drain [cook noodles as per instructions - depending on what noodles used].Â  Set aside.Heat oil in a saucepan, saute shallots and garlic until aromatic and golden.Â  Add in mushrooms and dried prawns, fry for a second.Â  Then add in the meat slices.Â  Fry until aromatic, add in water and seasoning.Â  Let it boil for 5-10 minutes.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Off fire.Â  Can prepare until this stage and keep aside until meal time.When serving noodles, bring soup to boil again, add in noodles and vegetables.Â  When vegetables are cooked, dish out into a bowl to serve.Â  Add pepper and red chilli.Â  [When cooking for 1, I used a claypot to cook the soup and serve noodles in claypot - less cleaning up to do].Note:You can use any type of leafy vegetables you prefer.Â  I usually add more vegetables and try to cut down on meat.

title: Stir Fry Di Wang Chai With Fresh Mushrooms
text: A simple and healthy dish that you can prepare in any quantity.Â  Seen this recipe on one of the TV cook shows.Â  The mushrooms are very fragrant and sweet. Â IngredientsEmperor vegetables [di wang chai] - washed and cut to 1 inch length [drain in colander]some oil and saltAssorted fresh mushrooms [abalone, shimeji or king etc] available - remove root portions, wash and drain.oyster sauce, light soy sauce, salt, sugar and winepepper and sesame oilcornflour mixÂ Step 1Â Heat wok with oil until hot add salt, then the vegetables.Â  Stir fry on high heat until cooked.Â  Dish out on serving plate.Using the same wok, add in fresh mushrooms.Â  Stir fry for 2-3 seconds, then add in wine, oyster sauce, light soy sauce, salt and sugar to taste.Â  Braise mushrooms for a few seconds then thicken lightly with cornflour mix.Â  Dish out on top of fried emperor vegetable [aka hong thay chye].

title: Homecooked Noodles - Java Mee [Revisited]
text: This is a  smaller quantity of home-cooked version of Java Mee which I prepared over the weekend enough for 3 - 4 people [depending on whether they are great eaters].Â  The first posting on May 30, 2011 was prepared by my sister in-law [following my Ma's recipe] which was good.This is my own version which my hubby likes and enjoyed very much. Ingredients for Soup[serves 3-4]100 gm sweet potato paste [orange colour type]750 ml water3 - 4 tbsp tomato sauce1.5 tbsp sugar 1.5 tsp salt1/4 tsp msg2 tbsp cornflour mix with 2 tbsp water [for thickening] Remove  skin of sweet potatoes.  Wash and cut into big chunks and steam for  about 25 minutes till soft [I usually will prepare more and use it to bake bread or steamed buns].Â Â   While hot, mash sweet potatoes quickly into  a fine paste.Â Mix paste with about 1/2 the water and strain stock into  a boiling pot.Â  Â   Discard the rough and fibrous part of sweet potato which is left on the sieve.Â  This step is necessary to get a smooth thick stock for the soup.Â  You will notice the different stock texture here and in the earlier posting.Add remaining water to stock.Â  Bring the stock to boil then add in salt, sugar, msg and tomato sauce. Â    Boil stock for 10 minutes and tasteÂ  soup to adjusting seasoning [the soup  should taste sweet and slightly sourish] .Â Â   Then thicken with cornstarch mix.Â Â  Bring to a boil and  off fire. Â  Double boil soup to keep the soup hot and prevent the bottom of the soup from being burnt because it is thick.Â  Or just reheat soup after preparing the noodles for serving.Ingredients To Serve Noodles 500 gm yellow noodles200 gm beansprouts - wash and drain [I tailed them]1 potato - boiled/skinned and sliced1 piece firm beancurd - fried and sliced1 hard boiled eggs - sliced1 tomato - sliced [I used some cherry tomatoes - halved]100 gm char siew - sliced [store bought]Lettuce leaves - cut shreds3-4Â  calamasi limes [or more] - 1 for each servingsome fried shallotschilli paste fried with some oil and salt [for spiciness]To  serve noodles, prepare a pot of boiling water, cook noodles and  beansprouts together [quantity depends on own appetite].Â   Drip dry the noodles after Â boiling and place on serving plate. Top up with all the condiements [slicedÂ Â potato, beancurd,  tomato, eggs and char siew].Â  Put 2-3 scoops  of hot soup [quantity enough to cover noodles] over noodles,Â   top with lettuce, fried shallots and lime wedges.Â   Add in fried chilli  paste to serve [if you want spicy noodles].Very appetising and delicious noodleÂ Note:  Can add more tomato sauce or any of the above ingredients according to  own preference.  Some people prefer to mix yellow noodles and rice  vermicelli.  All depends on own preference.

title: Salted Fish with Tofu Soup
text: During our younger days, my Ma used to cook this dish for the family. Â Nowadays, she does not cook this soup probably because salted fish is getting expensive and not that 'healthy' too. Â Usually, pork belly meat is use to cook the soup but here I am using lean meat. Â Once in awhile, I think it is alright to prepare this for the family because it is really a tasty soup.Ingredients[serves 2-3]2-3 pieces salted fish bones - cleaned and soaked for 5 minutes, drain1 piece firm tofu - cut into 6 pieces150 gm lean meat or pork belly - cut 1 cm thick slices3-4 slices ginger2 cloves garlic - cut thick slices1 tbsp oilsalt to taste [if salted fish is not that salty]some peppercorn - crushed 600 ml waterPrepare the above ingredients as stated.Â  Heat wok with oil to pan fry tofu pieces until firm and golden on both sides [wait until the tofu is golden before flipping over to prevent them from breaking].Â  Dish out and set aside.Â  Using the remaining oil, put in salted fish pieces to fry until fragrant.Â  Then add in sliced ginger, garlic and peppercorns.Â  Fry until aromatic then add in the meat slices to fry for a second.Bring the water to boil in a pot.Â  Put all the fried ingredients into the pot.Â  Let it boil for 5-10 minutes on medium heat.Â  Turn to low heat and simmer for another 15 minutes.Â  Add salt and a dash of msg to taste.Sprinkle on some spring onions before serving.Â  The soup taste better when hot.

title: PUMPKIN BREAD LOAF I [SPONGE DOUGH METHOD]
text: This  recipe is for 2 loaves of bread.Â  Measure half the quantity if you are  making only 1 loaf [550 gm].Â This bread is very soft and moist even on  the third day.Â  But I realised the texture is also fine which I believed could be due to longer kneading time.Â  I kneaded a little bit longer and on faster speed because the dough was a sticky.Â  I did not add any water to the bread dough.Â  Good recipe to keep.Ingredients for Sponge Dough150 gm bread flour150 gm plain flour3.5 tsp instant yeast250 ml water Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours or put in plastic bag, tied up without proofing and keep in fridge for at least 4 hours.Â  Thaw for 15 minutes before adding bread dough ingredients.Ingredients for Bread Dough300 gm bread flour2 tbsp milk powder3 tbsp sugar1 tspÂ  salt200 gm pumpkin puree 50 ml water or omit50 gm butter [2 tbsp]Add  all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the sponge dough.Â   Knead until well combined, then gradually add in water [if necessary] while kneading until a soft dough is formed.Â  Knead for  about 10 minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft,  smooth, elastic and dough does not stick to the fingers [about 15 minutes on high speed].Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide  dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and fold each portion into thirds,  then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's  tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double in  size.Â  [You can divide dough into any number of equal portions to make small loaves or braid it as I did this time].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Vegetarian Stir Fry Brussel Sprouts
text: This is a simple dish but with a variety of ingredients in small quantities. Â A dish that can help you clear off some of the leftover items in the kitchen cupboard or refrigerator. Â Here I will not provide the exact quantity of each item, it all depends on what you have on hand but of course you must have a vegetable. Â Here, I used brussel sprouts. Â You can Â replace the brussel sprouts with cabbage, beansprouts, garlic sprouts and loufah. Â Just cut all ingredients either in strips or Â cubes. Â I added chai por which was given to me by a friend. Â Not that salty but crunchy.I am cooking this dish to go with porridge.Ingredientsblack fungus - soaked and cutkim chiam - washed and knottedfirm beancurd - cuttaufu puffs [taupok] - cutcarrot - cutchai por strip - soaked and cut [I used the chai por from Hatyai]brussel sprouts or cabbage, beansprouts and loufah1-2 tbsp oilseasoning - light soy sauce, cooking wine and pepper to tastesome watersome chopped garlic [can omit if vegetarian for religious purpose]Heat oil in wok to fry beancurd till firm. Â Push aside, then add in garlic and chai por strips. Â Fry till fragrant. Â Then add in kim chiam, black fungus, carrots, taufu puffs and beancurd. Â Stir to mix all ingredients well for a second.Add in seasoning, brussel sprouts. Â Stir and add in some water.Fry till vegetables are cooked. Â Only takes a second or two. Â  Dish out to serve.

title: EZ Fried Rice With Chai Sim
text: Usually, when cooking fried rice, we do not add much vegetables except for some mixed vege [carrots, green peas and corn]. Â But I love to fry rice with other vegetables such as bok choy. Â  For this easy fried rice, I tried adding chai sim stems [choy sum/sawi] and use the leafy part to cook a vegetable soup [I add them to my Japanese Miso Soup]. Â  So here is a simple One Dish Meal with a soup for the family. Â Hassle free meal for dinner. Â Ingredients[serves 2-3]3 bowls cooked rice [I used Basmathi rice] or enough quantity for 3Â 250 gm chai sim [choy sum]1 chinese sausage - remove the skin and cut slices10 - 12 prawns - shelled2 eggssome spring onions or fried shallot crisps - garnishing2-3 tbsp oilsome chopped garlicsome light soy sauce, a dash of msg and pepper to tastesambal belacan - optionalWash chai sim, separate the leaves from the stems. Â Cut the stems into fine cubes and break the leaves into smaller pieces for the Miso Soup or any other soup preferred.Heat 2 tbsp oil in wok to saute garlic until fragrant, then add in the prawns. Â Fry until prawns are firm, then add in the rice, turn heat to low. Â Stir to mix rice well with seasoning. Â Then turn to medium heat, continue frying the rice for 1-2 seconds then add in the chai sim stems. Â Stir fry to mix all ingredients well.Push rice aside and add in the remaining oil . Â  Pour in the egg. Â Cover the egg with the rice and continue to stir fry until egg is cooked and rice is light, then add in the sliced sausage.Â Stir fry for another second and dish out to serve with sambal belacan or cut chillies. Â Garnish with spring onions or fried shallot crisps.Click here for other Fried Rice Recipes

title: CREAM CHEESE BISCUIT BREAD LOAF [SPONGE DOUGH METHOD]
text: After baking the Oreo CookieÂ Loaf Bread several times, I really loved this bread. Â It stays soft and moist for 2-3 days and taste good too.Since I have some cream cheese biscuits, I decided to substitute Oreo Biscuit with it. Â The dough is easy to handle. Â The bread is soft and not salty. Â  Lovely bread worth making for the family and friends.Â  This recipe makes 2 loaves of bread.Ingredients for Sponge Dough300 gm bread flour200 ml water2 tsp instant yeastMix all ingredients into a soft, rough dough.Â  Cover with a clean cloth to proof for 1-2 hours or until double in size.Ingredients for Bread Dough200 gm bread flour2 tbsp sugar1 tsp saltÂ 1 egg50 ml water [may need less]110 gm cream cheese biscuit [crushed]. Â I bought Julie's brand1-2 tbsp butterMix all ingredients [except water and butter] to prepared sponge dough.Â  Then gradually add in water.Â  Knead until a soft dough is formed. Â  Takes about 10 minutes, then add butter.Â  Continue kneading until dough is soft and smooth [another 10 minutes].Â  Remove dough and shape into a ball.Â  Cover with a clean cloth and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down dough, then divide into 2 portions.Â  Roll out each portion and fold into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in loaf tin.Â  Cover to proof for at least 1-2 hours or until double in size.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees for 25 minutes.Remove from pan to coolÂ  on rack immediately after baking.

title: ALMOND BREAD LOAF [OVERNIGHT DOUGH METHOD]
text: I baked this bread because I have some ground almond in the fridge.Â  I followed the Black Sesame Loaf Bread recipe and just substituted the black sesame paste with ground almond.Â Â  Here I increased the quantity because I wanted to make 2Â  bigger loaves of bread.Â Overnight Dough [about 660gm]3 cups plain flour - sifted2 tbsp sugar1.5 tsp instant yeast1 cup waterMix all ingredients into a dough.Â  Divide into 2 equal  portions.Â  Keep in plastic bags.Â  Tie up and keep in the fridge [I kept  the 2ortions in an airtight container in the fridge].Â  Can be kept for  up to 7 days.Â  Thaw for 10-15 minutes before using.Bread Dough [makes 2 loaves ofÂ  550gm bread] 300 - 330 gm overnight dough [1 portion of the overnight dough]1 large egg200 ml water [less if using a large egg] or milk 30 gm ground almond [I ground roasted almonds for this]1.5 tbsp sugar3/4 tsp yeast1 tsp salt375 gm bread flour2 tbsp margarineTear the overnight dough into smaller pieces in the mixing  bowl.Â  Add in all the ingredients except the water, bread flour and  margarine.Â  Mix well.Add in bread flour.Â  Knead and gradually add in water [may need  less].Â  Continue kneading into a soft dough [about 10 minutes] then add  in margarine.Â  Knead for another 10 minutes on medium speed until a  soft and smooth dough is formed.Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes before shaping dough.Punch down dough and divide into 2 portions [if baking 2  loaves].Â  Fold into thirds and roll out swiss roll style.Â  Roll into a  log and place on Pullman's tin.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least  1-2 hours or double in size.Baked in a preheated oven at 180 degrees for 25 minutes. Remove and cool before storing.Note:When bread is not so soft after 2 days, toast them, they taste good with butter and jam.

title: Stir Fry Garlic Flower Sprouts with Beancurd
text: Garlic flower sprout looks quite similar to chives [kucai] flower but when fried it has a stronger garlic taste.Â  It is crispy and you can enjoy them only when you have strong teeth and gums to chew on them.Â  I think it is a high fibre vegetable.Ingredients1 bunch of garlic flower sprouts - cut about 1 inch length - discard the ends2 pieces of firm beancurd [taukwa] - cut broad strips1 small red chilli - cut stripslight soy sauce to tastesome water2 tbsp oil Put 2 tbsp oil in wok to fry beancurd strips to slightly crispy at the edges.Â  Dish out.Â  Remove excess oil.While wok is still hot, add in the garlic sprouts and red chilli.Â  Fry on high heat for a second then return the beancurd into wok.Â  Stir to mix ingredients well.Â  Drizzle in enough light soy sauce to taste around the wok followed by a little water.Stir for another second and dish out to serve with porridge or rice.

title: Fried Rice With Fresh Herbs
text: This  is another aromatic fried rice with daun kadok [wild betel  leaves], cekur leaves [sand ginger leaves], kaffir lime leaves and fish sauce. More ingredients such as lemongrass, indian curry leaves,  mint leaves and wild ginger flower 'bunga kantan' can also be added if  available.Â  You can mix and match any of these ingredients, it is still  okay. Â  These ingredients have to be finely cut for frying this fried  rice.Â  Since, I am only frying for 2, I just used daun kadok, cekur  leaves, lemongrass and kaffir lime leaves from my garden.IngredientsÂ [serves 2]3 bowls of cooked rice3 calamasi lime juice3 tbsp fish sauce to taste sugar to taste1 Chinese sausage - cut small cubesÂ 1 small lemongrass - sliced finely2 tbsp dried prawns - soaked and drained2 eggs [beat with a little salt] - fry egg omelette and cut shreds [optional]1 small Bombay onion - sliced for garnishing10 or more daun kaduk leaves - shreddedsome cekur leaves - shreddedsome kaffir lime leaves - keep whole orÂ  shreddedÂ  2 tbsp oilClockwise - Top cekur leaves, lime, dried prawns, daun kaduk, sausagePrepare  all the ingredients above.Â  Heat up oil, saute sausage until fragrant.Â  Dish out and set aside.Â  Saute lemongrass and dried prawns until fragrant. Â Push aside and add in rice [fry on low heat]. Â Stir to combine rice and other ingredients well, Â add in seasoning [fish sauce, salt and sugar].
