Â Stir fry to mix.Add in all the shredded ingredients. Continue stir frying to combine all the  ingredients well and cooked through. Â  Rice should be light and fluffy.Â  Off  fire and dish out to serve with garnishing - spring onions, cili padi, big Bombay onions and eggs.Squeeze in the lime juice before serving.Â  Can serve rice with Thai sambal belacan.Different from the usual fried riceNote:Â This time, I did not add in eggs [for health reason - cutting down on eggs inÂ  diet].Click here for other Fried Rice Recipes

title: BLACK SESAME BREAD LOAF [OVERNIGHT DOUGH METHOD]
text: Black Sesame Bread SlicesI have been following Vivian Pang's blog on bread making and sometimes wondering whether 'overnight dough' and 'starter dough' are actually the same.Â  Most times, I used starter dough method to make my bread and I found the bread good [soft and moist even on the third day].Â So this time, I tried Vivian's method.Â  It is simpler as I just need to mix the ingredients and portioned out the quantity ready for use anytime.Â  The only problem is that I need to double the quantity if I wanted to make bigger loaves of bread [2 loaves of 550 gm bread].Â  With Vivian's quantity, I can only make 2 loaves of 330 gm bread.Next time, I will try to divide the overnight dough to 2 portions only and increase the bread dough ingredients by 1.5 times.Â  Perhaps, this way I should be able to get a bigger bread [enough for 3 days breakfast].Â  Less frequent breadmaking.Here is Vivian's original recipe.Overnight Dough [about 660gm]3 cups plain flour - sifted2 tbsp sugar1.5 tsp instant yeast1 cup waterMix all ingredients into a dough.Â  Divide into 3 equal portions.Â  Keep in plastic bags.Â  Tie up and keep in the fridge [I kept the 3 portions in an airtight container in the fridge].Â  Can be kept for up to 7 days.Â  Thaw for 10-15 minutes before using.Bread Dough [makes 2 loaves of 330 gm bread] 200 - 220 gm overnight dough [1 portion of the overnight dough]1 egg130 ml water [less if using a large egg] or milk 20 gm black sesame seed paste [I used ground toasted black sesame seeds]1 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp yeast1/2 tsp salt250 gm bread flour1 tbsp margarineTear the overnight dough into smaller pieces in the mixing bowl.Â  Add in all the ingredients except the water, bread flour and margarine.Â  Mix well.Add in bread flour.Â  Knead and gradually add in water [may need less].Â  Continue kneading into a soft dough [about 10 minutes] then add in margarine.Â  Knead for another 10 minutes on medium speed until a soft and smooth dough is formed.Cover and leave to proof for 15 minutes before shaping dough.Punch down dough and divide into 2 portions [if baking 2 loaves].Â  Fold into thirds and roll out swiss roll style.Â  Roll into a log and place on Pullman's tin.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours.Baked in a preheated oven at 180 degrees for 25 minutes. Remove and cool before storing.A soft and fluffy loaf bread that goes well with sliced cheddar cheese or butter spread. Loaf bread with toasted almondÂ Note:I tried baking the bread but substituted black sesame with toasted almond [grounded] using the above quantity into only 1 loaf.Â  The bread weighs about 750gm.Â  Here's how the bread turns out to be.

title: Orange Sweet Potato Chiffon Cake
text: With some orange sweet potato puree left after baking the Orange Sweet Potato Loaf Bread, I used it to bake this chiffon cake.Â Â I followed the basic ingredients from Happy Flour's recipe but I reduced the sugar because I think sweet potatoes are sweet.Â  I prefer chiffon cakes that are not too sweet.Â  The cake turns out well and I think the texture should be better if large eggs were used.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [used large eggs]1-2 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt2 tbsp oil70 gm orange sweet potato [skinned, steamed and mashed]60 ml coconut milk or fresh milk [I used fresh milk]Whisk  egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â   Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in coconut milk/fresh milk.Â   Lastly stir in mashed sweet potato. Â Fold in the flour, combine well. Â Set aside while you whisk the egg  white.Â  Preheat oven at 175 degrees C.70 gm cake flour siftedIngredients for Egg White Mixture 3 egg white 3 tbsp sugar 1/4 tsp cream of tartarWhisk  egg white until frothy then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking until foamy then gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk until soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk  mixture. Â Mix until well incorporated.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue, Â Mix well. Â Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven at 175 degrees C for 40 minutes.Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Stir Fry Crab Noodles with Tom Yam Paste
text: My hubby's new interest and hobby now is fishing.Â  These crabs were his catch for the day.Â  Very fresh and sweet.Â  For this dish, 2 crabs is enough for 2 persons, but since he managed to catch 4 [various sizes], I just cooked them all and enjoy.Â  The crabs really tasted different from those you get at the wet market.Â  Hard to explain the taste but it has a unique sweetness and you know it is because of the freshness.Fresh crabs from my hubby's fishing tripThe part of crab which I like most [the shell]Ingredients[serves 2]2 pieces of rice vermicelli [beehoon] - soaked for 5-10 minutes, drain in colander [or quantity enough for 2 persons]100 gm round cabbage - cut strips2 crabs - cleaned and halved [here I used 4] - see picture on how the crabs were cut.5-6 pieces kaffir lime leaves - wash keep whole1-2 tbsp Tom Yam chilli paste [used good quality type] 1-2 tbsp oil Seasoning3 tbsp fish sauce1-2 tbsp sugar to tastesalt to taste [optional]200 ml waterLime juice from 3-4 calamasi limesClockwise - beehoon, mint leaves, cabbage leaves, lime, kaffir leaves and tomyam pasteHeat  wok with oil, add in tom yam paste and cabbage to fry for a second.Â  Add water, bring  to a boil, then add in the crabs and seasoningÂ  to taste.Â  Cover for 3-5 minutes to cook the crabs.Remove cover then add in rice vermicelli [beehoon].Â  Use a pair of chopstick to  loosen noodles and mix ingredients well.Â  Cover  wok for 3-5 minutes or leave to cook noodles and water has almost dried  up.Â  Remove cover, toss again till ingredients are well combined and  noodles are soft. Throw in lime leaves and pour in lime juice.Â  Off fire, toss  again and dish out on plate to serve. Garnish with mint leaves.Fry tomyam paste with oil add in cabbage, water and seasoningWhen water boils add in crabs, stir, cover to cook for 3 minutesAddÂ  beehoon, stir, cover to cook till water is almost drydelicious crab noodlesNoteCan add more tom yam paste if you prefer more spicy noodles.Be careful with salt and lime juice as some tomÂ  yam paste taste salty and sourishFish sauce, kaffir leaves and lime juice are moist important ingredients to fry Tom Yam Noodles

title: ORANGE SWEET POTATO BREAD LOAF [OVERNIGHT DOUGH METHOD]
text: This  recipe is for 2 loaves of bread.Â  Measure half the quantity if you are  making only 1 loaf [550 gm].Â  This bread is very soft and moist even on  the third day.Â  I have used purple sweet potato before [refer posting January 2012 - Purple Sweet Potato Bread Loaf.Â  Remember to reduce or omit the water if puree is too wet.Â  I did not add any water when kneading the overnight dough with sweet potato puree and bread dough ingredients.Ingredients forÂ  Overnight Dough240 gm bread flour40 gm plain flour2 tsp instant yeast100 ml water Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours.Ingredients for Bread Dough240 gm bread flour40 gm plain flour1 tbsp milk powder2 tbsp honey1/4 tspÂ  salt300 gm orange sweet potato - skinned, steamed and mashed 50 ml water or slightly more [adjust accordingly]60 gm butter Shaped dough before proofingAfter proofing for 1-2 hoursAdd  all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the sponge dough.Â   Knead until well combined, then gradually add in water while kneading, until a soft dough is formed [you may not need all the water].Â  Knead for  about 10 minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading until soft,  smooth and elastic.Â  Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide  dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and fold each portion into thirds,  then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's  tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double in  size. [Best to proof for 1-2 hours].Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Grated Cheddar Cheese Chiffon
text: Came across this chiffon cake at Sonia's blog [not exactly the ingredients].Â  The original recipe uses Parmesan Cheese.Â  Since I have a block of cheddar cheese in the fridge, I just gave it a try.Â  The cake was light, soft, fluffy and not too sweet with some changes to the measurement.Â  As like always, I prefer to use a tablespoon to measure some the ingredients since the quantity required is small.Â  Really lovely cake.Â  Its a keeper. Thanks to Sonia for sharing this recipe.Â  Ingredients for Egg Mixture4 egg yolks [large]2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp corn oil70 ml milk or water 70 gm grated cheddar cheese [can use Parmesan cheese]Beat egg yolks and sugar together, then continue beating while adding oil, follow by milk.Â  Then fold in the grated cheese.Â  Fold in sifted flour till well combined and set aside while you prepare the egg white mixture.Preheat oven at 160 degrees for 10 minutes. 70 gm cake flour + 1/2 tsp baking powder [or 70 gm self raising flour] - sifted Ingredients for Egg White Mixture4 egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar [or 1 tbsp cornflour]5 level tbsp of castor sugar [70 gm sugar]Whisk egg white till frothy then add in cream of tartar [or cornflour].Â  Continue whisking and gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk till foamy and soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Pour into the balance meringue and fold till well combined.Pour mixture into 7" chiffon pan.Â  Tap on table top several times to expel out trapped air.Baked in preheated oven for 40-45 minutes on lower rack.Â  Remove and invert pan immediately after baking.Â  Cool and then remove from pan before slicing.

title: Smoked Whole Chicken
text: Steamed whole chicken can also be smoked for added flavour.Ingredients1 whole chicken - properly cleaned and innards removedA few ginger slices1 stalk spring onions - cleaned and knottedsome salt and winesome pepper and 5 spice powder Put ginger and sping onion on a steaming tray.Â Rub chicken with wine, salt , pepper and 5 spice powder and place on steaming tray Steam chicken over boiling water for 25 minutes.Â  Off fire and  leave for 15 minutes before removing cover.Â Â Â  Leave to cool.How to smoke chicken using the wok Place 2 pieces of aluminium foil on a wok.Â  Sprinkle 1-2 tbsp tea leaves followed by 1-2 tbsp flour and 1-2 tbsp sugar.Â  Place a tray over the above.Â  Put boiled chicken on tray [skin side up].Cover wok and turn on to medium fire for 10-12 minutes [you should be able to see white smoke and then yellow smoke].Â  Off fire and leave covered for another minute.Remove cover and brush sesame oil over skin.Chopped and serve with shredded spring onion, cucumber and chilli sauce.

title: Steamed Whole Chicken
text: This is a simple way to prepare 'Pak Cham Khai' instead of the usual boiling method. Ingredients need are spring onions and ginger, salt and wine.Â  The chicken should be ready by 40 - 45 minutes.Ingredients1 whole chicken - properly cleaned and innards removeA few ginger slices1 stalk spring onions - cleaned and knottedsome salt and winePut ginger and sping onion on a steaming tray.Â Rub chicken with wine and salt and place on steaming tray Steam chicken over boiling water for 25 minutes.Â  Off fire and leave for 15 minutes before removing cover.Â  Keep the chicken stock for chilli sauce.Brush with sesame oil while hot. Cut into smaller pieces before serving with chilli sauce.Â Â Note:The same method can be used to steam just a drumstick or half chicken.Â  Reduce steaming time to 15 minutes, off fire and leave for 15 minutes.Â  I didn't cut the chicken because I am keeping the chicken to be smoked [please refer posting on smoked whole chicken].Chilli Sauce for ChickenThis is a simple chilli sauce that goes well with the steamed chicken or smoked chicken.Ingredients [blend and combine together]5 red chilli3-4 cloves garlic20 g ginger4 tbsp vinegar or lessJuice of 2 limessalt and sugar to tastechicken stockBlend all ingredients together then pour hot boiling chicken stock over blended ingredients.

title: Steamed Waxed Meat Rice in Casserole [CNY 2012]
text: This is a very easy delicious dish to prepare for CNY lunch or dinner.Â  Usually, I will prepare this dish for dinner with hubby when we are back to our own home after spending many days at my in-law's place.Â  This is usually our most enjoyable CNY dish because it is easy to prepare.Â  Most time, we never really enjoy a good meal at my in-law's place since CNY eve until we are back home [that is for several days].Â  This is because I have so much cooking to do and we usually have to rush through our meal because there are so many people eating [about 30 people] in the house.Anyway, this dish no doubt a bit 'sinful' [healthwise] but it is a consolation after so many days of hard work and never mind I prepare this only once a year.Cooked riceChinese sausages, waxed duck meat and chickenShredded ginger, spring onions and cucumberIngredients[serve 2-3]500 gm cooked rice [cooked rice enough for 2 pax]1 drumstick [or 150 gm boneless chicken meat] - sliced and marinated with 1/4 tsp of sesame oil and cornflour1 Chinese sausage [any type - meat or liver] - sliced1 pc waxed duck [drumstick or duck breast] - sliced * * boiled whole piece in boiling water for 5 minutes to reduce the saltiness and fatsa few slices of ginger - cut fine stripsspring onions - cut fine stripsSauce ingredients in saucepan to be boiledSauce Ingredients [Combined and boiled]1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp cooking wine2 tbsp chicken stock1/4 tsp each of chicken stock granules, sesame oil and thick soy sauceDish before steamingAfter steaming with sauce added Place cooked rice in a casserole or pyrex dish.Â  Lay the chicken pieces all over the rice, followed by sausages and waxed duck slices.Â  Top the ingredients with shredded ginger.Steamed the dish over boiling water for about 15 minutes or until chicken is cooked.Meanwhile, bring the sauce ingredients to a boil.Â  When rice is ready, pour sauce over dish and garnish with spring onions before serving.Â  Serve immediately.Â  To serve, mix rice and meat well before scooping onto serving bowl/plate.Doesn't look delicious [It tastes good also]Note:Â  This time, I served this dish with sliced cucumber, chilli sauce and simple Miso Soup.Â  My neighbour's daugther gave me a tub of Miso [from Japan].Â  I used it to prepare a simple Miso soup stock with romaine lettuce.

title: Chinese New Year 2012 - Dragon Year [II]
text: I know my MIL will never keep to her words.Â  It is not steamboat for ancestral worship on CNY eve.Â  Steamboat is for CNY eve dinner for her childrens' families.Â  Got to know that only when I reached her house a day before CNY eve.For ancestral worship prayers, these were the items that I have to get ready for cooking on CNY eve morning.Â  Most of the items were bought by my MIL because she loves to buy.Â  Myself, I bought the ingredients for Chicken Curry Kapitan, Meat Rolls, Penang Prawn Noodles [recipe posted before] and bake a Chocolate Marble Chiffon.Food for CNY Eve Pig Tripe's SoupChicken Curry KapitanStir Fry Turnip [Jiu Hoo Char]Stir Fry Cauliflower and BrocolliStir Fry Teow Chew NoodlesFry Fish [Senangin]Lor Bak [Family Style Meat Rolls] - recipe posted beforePak Cham Kai [Boiled Whole Chicken - 2 birds]Â Chocolate Marble Chiffon [recipe posted before]  Braised Duck Teow Chew Style [prepared by my MIL]Braised Bamboo Shoots with Pig Trotter [prepared partially by my MIL]Apart from the above, I have to prepare steamboat for dinner and also Prawn Noodle Stock for CNY first day lunch [taste better to cook the stock earlier before serving]. Â  Moreover, I cannot cook this on CNY day because I am on vegetarian diet.Â  Mind you, the quantity is not small [about 40 pax].Â Apart from all of the above, my MIL bought more items below to add to the above for ancestral worship.Roast Duck and Pork [Siew Yoke]Angku and Huat KuihFruitsThnee Kuih [Sweet Glutinous Rice Cake]I think it is too excessive but they are great eaters, the food were all finished up.Â  Is it because of one's character or too much money? Â  With so many things prepared, the saddest thing is that none of her other children [my hubby's siblings] turned up for the prayers. Â Â  I think they must have forgotten the meaning of ancestral worship on such ocassions.Â  Some came later for dinner.Â  Myself, have been in the kitchen the day before to prepare the ingredients and cooking since 6 am in the morning on CNY eve and busy till late afternoon and again in the kitchen from 5.30 pm to get the steamboat ready for my hubby's siblings and families.Â  You must be wondering why I have to slave myself, my problem is I can't bare to see an old lady doing all these things for her grown up children.Â  It should be the other way round.Â  I would find it hard to sit downÂ  and enjoy these food.There are still many, many more things to prepare such as Kwang Cheang, drinks and sweet dessert.Â  My MIL didn't manage to prepare the Kwang Cheang before the second day of CNY because of her knee problem.Â  I could not help her with this because my hands are tight with so much to handle single-handedly and of course she has her own recipe [different from mine].Don't forget the cleaning up of the kitchen, dining hall, living room and house compound when all have left late in the evening.Â  My legs are aching by then.Â  It is really very tiring and you can't even complain or make a comment.Â  You may be branded as 'calculative'.Â  Even a maid has the right to make face when overworked but not me. Â  My hubby wanted to comment on this when his siblings arrived but I stopped him because they may blamed the wife.Â Â  Best to do more and zip up the mouth.So what's the meaning of CNY forÂ  me especially when my hubby and me do not have any children.Â  Just take it that we are doing charity work for people.Food for First day of CNYÂ  Lunch -Â  Penang Prawn Noodle Soup [40 pax] , Chai Boey and reheat the CNY eve leftover dishes/soup.Dinner [30 pax] - Steamed Fish, Vegetarian Curry, Chai Boey and the CNY eve dishes etc.[managed to take pictures of only a few dishes - too busy with the serving].Â Â Cooked according to my MIL's instructionLuckily for today, I did have 2-3 of my sisters in-law to help with the serving and washing.Food for Second day of CNY [no pictures taken - really busy with the food preparation and also have to visit my mother before lunch and has to rush back to cook dinner [35 pax].Â  The following were the food for the whole day.Braised Sea Cucumber with Roasted PorkChicken Soup with Straw/Button MushroomsStir Fry Boiled Chicken with Soy SauceStir Fry Beansprouts and Tau Mui Stir Fry Leafy Greens with Fish SauceSteamed Fish with Ginger/spring onions in soy sauceSpicy Sweet Sour Big PrawnsStir Fry Vegetarian Dish [Snow Peas, Mushrooms and vegetarian gluten balls etc]Stir Fry Vegetarian Mutton with Sesame Oil and shredded gingerSteamed Braised Duck with braising stock* The vegetarian dishes were prepared for one my hubby'sÂ  sibling [the couple are vegans]For 3 consecutive nights, I have to wait till almost midnight before I could clean up the hall after all the people has left otherwise I would not have the time to do it the next morning when there are more chores waiting to be done.Â  Imagine how can one enjoy this kind of CNY with lack of sleep/rest and especially when there is not even a word of appreciation from the people. But I felt happy because I have done something good for the CNY [this I have being doing yearly since I got married in the 1990s]. Lucky for this CNY, most have left earlier because the the official off day was till Tuesday.

title: Meatballs for Steamboat
text: Meatballs for steamboatThis steamboat meatball recipe is my Ma's very own and very popular among the family and friends whom we have shared the recipe.Â  These are very tasty and flavourful meatball very different from the store bought meatballs.Â  It is worthwhile to make more because the leftovers can be coated with flour and deep fried to eat as a snack or to cook any noodle soup.Ingredients for meatballsMeatball paste Ingredients[makes about 100 meatballs]800 gm lean meat with 50 gm pork fat [minced/grounded]300 gm prawn pasteSeasoning A2 - 2 1/2 tsp salt2 tsp pepper1/2 tsp msg [optional]2 tbsp oyster sauce2 tbsp sesame oil2 tbsp cooking wine200 gm cabbage [chopped] 1 small carrot [chopped]100 gm bombay onion [chopped]50 gm garlic [chopped]4-5 pcs dried mushrooms [soaked, drained and chopped]some spring onions [chopped]4 tbsp cornflour2 tbsp plain flourMeatballs before steamingMeatballs after steaming for 15-20 minutesMix minced meat and prawn paste together with seasoning A.Â  Stir in one direction till paste is sticky.Add in the rest of the ingredients.Â  Mix well and stir in one direction.Â  Slap paste against the mixing bowl for about 5 minutes. Leave to rest for about an hour in the fridge.Grease a few steaming trays and shape meatballs about the size of a ping pong ball.Â  Place on greased tray and steam over boiling water for 15 - 20 minutes.Cool meatballs before storing in containers and keep in the fridge before serving.Meatball stockÂ Note:Â  The stock from the steaming of the meatballs can be added to steamboat stock.

title: Chinese New Year 2012 - Dragon Year [I]
text: This CNY falls on 23rd January. My Ma's side will not be celebrating the new year because of my Pa's passing in October 2011.Â  By CNY it is not even 100 days after his passing.Â  Myself, eventhough my hubby's parent's side is celebrating the CNY, I am not in the mood because I really miss my Pa.Â  Even while writing this post, I couldn't control my tears with the thought that this is the first CNY that I no longer have a 'Papa' to say 'KEONG HEE HUAT CHYE" [one of the chinese new year greetings in the Hokkien dialect] which I will usually say to him when I returned to his home on the second day of CNY.Â Â For years, I have always baked various types of cookies, grilled meat 'bak kwa' and fried potato chips for my parents and parents in-law but this year I just don't feel like doing anything because for most years, my Pa will always remind me that I have to bake more of certain cookies for his visitors, such as peanut cookies for my cousins, butter cookies, potato chips and grilled meat for his grandsons and the sweet glutinous rice cake 'thnee kuih'Â  for his Malay friends etc.Hopefully, by next CNY 2013, I will be able to make the various CNY delicacies and share the recipes with you all.Â Â Although, I am not in the mood to celebrate the CNY, I still have to carry out my duties as a responsible daughter in-law at my mother in-law's place.Â  This year she has requested to prepare steamboat for CNY eve prayers [I think this will include several CNY traditional dishes], Penang Prawn Mee [Hokkien Mee] for CNY day lunch and many, many more lunches and dinners [I usually will get to know what to cook until almost near meal time] that I have to prepare for all her children, grandchildren and visitors. The cooking will go on for several days. Guess I just have to follow her orders to make things easier.Â  I will not be posting the recipes for the dishes that will be prepared because what ingredients used will depend on what my mother in-law has in her kitchen.Â  I would not have the time to take pictures of the ingredients and the dishes because I am cooking for several families and I have no say of what to cook.Â  It will be very stressful to cope with all these in one go and with the house full of people.Some of the CNY decorations in the Penang Heritage ZoneAnyway, I hope the CNY 2012 will be a good and happy year for all of us. Wishing my Chinese readers aÂ 'HAPPY, HEALTHY AND PROSPEROUSÂ CHINESE NEW YEAR 2012'

title: OREO BISCUIT BREAD LOAF [SPONGE DOUGH METHOD]
text: I love making bread using the sponge dough or overnight dough methods because these 2 methods yield very soft and moist bread which stays fresh even on the third day.Â  Lovely bread worth making for the family and friends.Â  This recipe makes 2 loaves of bread.Ingredients for Sponge Dough300 gm bread flour200 ml water2 tsp instant yeastMix all ingredients into a soft, rough dough.Â  Cover with a clean cloth to proof for 1-2 hours or until double in size. Ingredients for Bread Dough 200 gm bread flour2 tbsp sugar1 tsp salt1 egg50 ml water [may need less] 110 gm Oreo biscuits [crushed]1-2 tbsp butterMix all ingredients [except water, Oreo cookies and butter] to prepared sponge dough.Â  Then gradually add in water.Â  Knead till a soft dough is formed. Â  Takes about 10 minutes.Â  Add in crushed cookies and butter.Â  Continue kneading till dough is soft and smooth [another 10 minutes].Â  Remove dough and shape into a ball.Â  Cover with a clean cloth and leave to proof for 15 minutes.Punch down dough, then divide into 2 portions.Â  Roll out each portion and fold into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in loaf tin.Â  Cover to proof for at least 1-2 hours or until double in size.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees for 25 minutes.Remove from pan to coolÂ  on rack immediately after baking.

title: Purple Sweet Potato Chiffon Cake
text: Came across this chiffon cake on several blogs and managed to find a Pumpkin Chiffon Cake recipe using 3 eggs.Â  I substituted the pumpkin with purple sweet potato [can use any other coloured sweet potatoes].Â  Here are the ingredients.Ingredients for Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks1-2 tbsp castor sugar1/4 tsp salt2 tbsp oil60 gm purple sweet potato [skinned, steamed and mashed]60 ml coconut milk or fresh milkWhisk egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy, then drizzle in oil.Â  Continue whisking for awhile then drizzle in coconut milk/fresh milk.Â  Lastly stir in mashed sweet potato. Â  Fold in the flour and diced potatoes until well combined.Â  Set aside while you whisk the egg white.Â  Preheat oven at 170 degrees.70 gm cake flour sifted together with 1/2 tsp baking powder 100 gm purple sweet potato cubes [diced and steam for 15 minutes] - set aside to cool Ingredients for Egg White Mixture 3 egg white 3 tbsp sugar or 50 gm1/4 tsp cream of tartarWhisk egg white till frothy then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking till foamy then gradually add in sugar.Â  Whisk till soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion of meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold mixture into balance meringue till well incorporated.Â  Add in sweet potato cubes.Â Pour batter into 7" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees for 40 minutes.Invert pan immediately after baking to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: PURPLE SWEET POTATO BREAD LOAF [SPONGE DOUGH METHOD]
text: This recipe is for 2 loaves of bread.Â  Measure half the quantity if you are making only 1 loaf [550 gm].Â  This bread is very soft and moist even on the third day.Â  Can substitute purple sweet potato with other coloured sweet potatoes or pumpkin [reduce water if puree is too wet]. Ingredients for Sponge Dough230 gm bread flour20 gm plain flour2 tsp instant yeast100 ml water Mix all ingredients into a soft rough dough.Â  Cover and leave to proof for at least 1-2 hours.Ingredients for Bread Dough230 gm bread flour20 gm plain flour1 tbsp milk powder2 tbsp sugar1 tspÂ  salt260 gm purple sweet potato - skinned, steamed and mashed 50 ml water or slightly more40 gm butter Dough ready for proofingÂ Dough ready for shapingLoaf bread ready for proofing for 1 hour or double in sizeBread ready for baking for 25 minutes @ 180 degreesPurple sweet potato loaf breadAdd all the ingredients [except water and butter] to the sponge dough.Â  Knead till well combined, then gradually add in water while kneading till a soft dough is formed [you may not need all the water].Â  Knead for about 10 minutes then add in butter.Â  Continue kneading till soft, smooth and elastic.Â Shape into a ball and cover with a clean cloth to proof for 15 minutes or until double in size. Punch down dough.Divide dough into 2 equal portions.Â  Roll and fold each portion into thirds, then roll swiss roll style into a log.Â  Place in baking tin [Pullman's tin] and leave to proof in oven for more than an hour or until double in size.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately after baking.

title: Year 2011
text: Year 2011 was a very eventful year with many things happening.Â  Sad to say the many things that happened were not that happy things.Â  But the most satisfying thing was I managed to start off this blog where I could record down almost all of my mother's home cooked family food which I hope will be shared, viewed and kept as a reference in future for all, especially for her younger generations whom may missed their grandmother's cooking.What happened throughout the year 2011.Â My mother in-law was immobile [could not walk] for 2 months due to 'a crack in the pelvic bone'.Â  I was grounded to take care of her till full recovery.My husband had a heart attack during his badminton game.Â  Thank God he was saved and now on lifetime medication and completely abstain from the game. Then myself facing menopausal problems. Thank God I am now almost over the problem and realised that to be happyÂ  the body has to be healthy.Â  Eventhough I followed a healthy lifestyle from young, I am not totally immuned from some of these health problems but it does help to speed up the recovery.My father - old age problems and finally his passing in October. Thank God, he was not bedridden during his last days. Â  But I am happy that throughout his golden years, I have given him much time, care and comfort especially during the last 3 years of his life.Â  I have no regrets putting him as my top priority in planning my schedule.Â  I hope readers will give some thoughts to spending more time with their elders especially if they are over 70's.Â  Always make them your top priority.Â  You will not regret it.WISHING ALL DEAR READERSHAPPY NEW YEAR 2012 BE STRONG TO FACE THE CHALLENGES OF THE NEW YEAR,Â  STAY HAPPY AND HEALTHY ALWAYS

title: 5 Star Black Pepper Chicken Rice
text: An easy dish to prepare for lunch or dinner if you have some vegetables, carrot, chicken meat [I have 5 Star brand black pepper chicken steak in the fridge] and cooked rice.Ingredients[serves 2]2 bowls of cooked rice [hot or warm]1 piece of chicken steak [ready bought from any departmental store]200 gm brocolli - cut into florets1 small carrot - cut design and sliced2 piece mushrooms - soaked and slicedA few cloves garlic - keep whole1 tbsp oil 400 ml waterSeasoning to taste - oyster sauce, msg, sesame oil, pepper,Â  wine, salt and pepper1 tbsp cornflour mix with 2-3 tbsp water5 Star brand - black pepper flavour chicken steakHeat up cooked rice and set aside.Heat chicken steak [both side] on medium heat in non-stick pan for 5-10 minutes.Â  Remove and sliced.Heat oil in non stick pan and fry whole garlic till brown.Â  Remove.Using the same wok, add in mushrooms.Â  Fry till aromatic, then add in carrot and seasoning.Pour in water and bring to a boil.Â  Taste to adjust seasoning.Â  Add in brocolli and fried garlic.Â  Continue to boil till brocolli is cooked.Â  Then add in cornflour to thicken sauce.Scoop 1 bowl of rice onto serving plate.Â  Scoop vegetable sauce over rice and top up with chicken steak slices.Â  Serve with sambal belacan or sliced chilli.

title: 'Beras Pulut Hitam' Chiffon Cake
text: Came across the Black Glutinous Rice Chiffon Cake quite often and was wondering where to get this type of rice. Finally, I decided to give it a try byÂ  grinding the black glutinous rice to bake the cake. The cake turn out very well [soft, fluffy and tasty].  How to grind the black glutinous rice?Â  I measured 45 gm of black glutinous rice [in Malaysia, black glutinous rice is called Beras Pulut Hitam].Â  Grind it using the small grinder till fine.Â  Then sift it and grind again the coarser grain a few more times until you get the quantity needed.Â  Discard the coarser grains.Â  I suggest that you grind more and store it for later use.Â Â Â This recipe is adapted from Happy Flour blog.Ingredients for Egg Mixture4 egg yolks20 gm caster sugar [I used 1.5 tbsp]1/4 tsp salt2 tbsp oil50 ml coconut milk [substitute with fresh milk]Whisk egg yolks with sugar and salt till creamy.Â  Drizzle in oil and whisk continously, then drizzle in coconut milk.Â  Continue whisking while adding till creamy, then fold in sifted flour till well combined.Â  Set aside while you prepare the egg white.Ingredients for Flour - sifted together35 gm cake flour45 gm black glutinous rice flour1/4 tsp baking powderIngredients for Egg White Mixture4 egg white60 gm castor sugar [I used 4 tbsp]1/4 tsp cream of tartarWhisk egg white till frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue beating till foamy, then add in sugar in 2-3 batches.Â  Whisk till soft peaks formed.Â  Fold in 1/3 portion to egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold in to the balance meringue.Â  Fold till well combined then pour into 7" chiffon cake pan.Â  Tap pan on table top several times to release trapped air.Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 35 - 40 minutes. Invert pan immediately to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Chicken Floss Buns [Starter Dough Method]
text: Various shaped bunsIt's Sunday morning, woke up at 6.00 am and was preparing to go for my morning exercise. Suddenly, it started to rain and it's still dark outside.Â  Too early to go marketing, so I decided to make these buns with Chicken Meat Floss [I think it is Chicken Serunding - a Malay dish].Â  My sister's Malay colleague gave her a packet of this meat floss for Hari Raya celebrations and not knowing what to do with it, my Ma gave it to me.The easiest and fastest way to finish it is by wrapping them up in the buns.Â  The buns turned out well and the meat floss was a real good match.Â  It tasted like anchovies in sambal tumis, a little spicy and sweet. GOOD.Here is the recipe for the buns.Â  Makes about 24 buns, if you prefer a small quantity then just half theingredients, it is still okay.Â  I mix the starter dough and measured the rest of the ingredients and went back to sleep till 8.00 am.Â  By then the starter dough is ready for use.Ingredients - Starter Dough250 gm bread flour [I used 200 gm bread flour and 50 gm plain flour]3.25 tsp instant yeast dissolve in 200 ml warm waterAdd flour into the yeast mixture and mix into a sticky dough. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and leave for 1-2 hours or till it becomes about 2-3 times in size.Â  [Usually, I will mix ingredients in an airtight container, leave it to proof for 30 minutes in room temperature, then cover the container and kept in the fridge overnight].Ingredients - Bread Dough250 gm bread flour [I used 200 gm bread flour and 50 gm plain flour]1.25 tsp salt 50 gm sugar [I used 3 tbsp] 50 ml warm water1 [50 gm] egg - lightly beaten [keep 1 tbsp for brushing buns]50 gm butterMix bread dough ingredients with starter dough in a mixer with dough hook.Â  Knead on medium speed for about 5-10 minutes till soft then add in butter.Â  Continue to knead for another 10 minutes till dough is soft, smooth and elastic. Cover and leave to rest for 15 minutes or until double in size.Punch down dough.Â  Divide dough into 2 equal portions for easier handling.Form into a ball, then roll on a floured board and fold into third.Â  Then roll into a log and cut into 12 equal portions [10 if you prefer bigger buns].Â  Shape each portion into a ball.Â  Then roll each ball into a flat round piece.Add filling [chicken meat floss], pinch the seam to seal.Â  Place the seam side down on paper casing or parchment paper.Â  Do the same for the other portion.Leave to rise for 30 - 40 minutes.Â  Brush with beaten egg and sprinkle with some black sesame seeds.Bake in preheated oven at 200 degrees C for 10-15 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack immediately.Â Â Â Â Note You can shape the buns into any shape you prefer [round, triangle, oval, oblong, swiss roll or nastar style].Â  Here, I made them into round buns and also swiss roll and nastar roll style].Â Â  But I think it is better not to expose the filling as it gets dried up when baking.the pictures do not look good but the buns are really good, soft and tasty even on the third day.

title: Sesame Oil Young Ginger Chicken
text: Came across this dish on TV and wanted to try it out because the preparation is slightly different from the usual. Shredded young ginger is used and not fried in sesame oil before adding to the chicken pieces.For the recipe here, I am giving the actual ingredients [but I substituted mushrooms with black fungus and spring onions with coriander leaves because I have not these 2 ingredients when cooking this dish].Â  I will definitely cook this dish again with the actual ingredients as it tasted good even even with black fungus and coriander leaves.Â  I think with mushrooms and spring onions it will be more aromatic and fragrant served with plain white rice. Later for my lunch with my hubby, I added more water [400 ml] to make this dish into a soup and serve it with blanched Mee Suah and vegetables as a 'One dish meal'.Basic ingredientsÂ - ginger/chicken/black fungus or mushrooms Ingredients[serves 2-3] 400 gm deboned chicken whole leg [with skin] - cut bite size pieces - marinate with salt and pepper3 - 6 dried mushrooms [depend on size] - soaked and cut broad strips100 gm young ginger - cut thin strips3 tbsp sesame oil2 tbsp cooking wine1 tbsp light soy sauce + 1/2 tsp dark soy sauce1 tsp sugarenough water to cover chicken ingredients1 stalk sping onions - cut 2 inch length [separate the white and green part]Â Step by step pictures of cooking this dishHeat up wok without oil.Â  When hot, pan fry chicken pieces [skin side down] till golden.Â  Turn over to fry the other side till firm.Â Â Add in sesame oil and white part of spring onion.Â  Stir fry till aromatic, then add in wine from the side of wok followed by water.Â  When water has boiled, add in seasoning to taste, then add ginger and mushrooms.Continue to fry and simmer till gravy is slightly reduced and chicken is tender.Â  Add in spring onions as garnishing.Â  Dish out on plate to serve with rice.

title: VANILLA BREAD LOAF [STARTER DOUGH METHOD]
text: Came across this bread recipe at Cosy Bake blog and I doubled the quantity because I am making 2 loaves at one time.Â  Also used the starter dough method and the loaf bread turns out well.Â  Soft and fluffy for 2 - 3 days.Ingredients - Starter Dough240 g bread flour60 g plain flour 2.6 tsp instant yeast200 ml milkMix all the ingredients together into a soft but rough dough.Â  Cover and set aside to proof for 1-2 hours or till double in size.Ingredients - Bread Dough240 g bread flour60 g plain flour1.5 tsp salt90 g condensed milk4 tsp vanilla essence 100 ml milk [add gradually otherwise the dough maybe too wet]60 g butterAdd all bread dough ingredients [except butter and milk] to starter dough in an electric mixer fixed with dough hook.Â  Knead on low speed to blend ingredients well, then gradually add in milk.Â  Do not add all the milk if dough is already wet.Â  Continue kneading till dough is smooth and soft [about 10 minutes] then add in butter.Continue to knead for another 10 minutes until the dough is smooth and soft again.Â  Remove dough from hook and roll into a ball.Â  Cover to proof for 15 minutes or until the dough has doubled in size.Punch down dough to release the air.Â  Transfer the dough to a floured board.Â  Divide dough into two equal portion.Â  Fold into third for each portion. Set aside.Roll out each portion into a rectangular shape and roll up swiss roll style, seal the edges.Â  Place in baking tin, cover and leave to proof for 1 hour or until the dough has doubled in size.Â  Do the same for the other portion.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees C for 25-30 minutes.Remove from tin immediately to cool on rack after baking.Note:Â  I add some chocolate chips when rolling bread just to finish off the leftover chocolate chips.Â  No sugar is added

title: Chocolate Raisin Chiffon Cake
text: This is the second time I baked this chiffon cake.Â  Lovely/good cake.Â  Got the recipe from Baking Mum blog.Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture3 egg yolks [I used 3 large eggs]30 gm [2 tbsp] castor sugar 3 tbsp oil 2 tbsp milk [30 ml]Whisk  egg yolks with sugar till creamy, then drizzle in oil and milk.Â  Continue to  whisk till well combined, then fold in sifted flour.Â  Lastly add in raisins and chocolate chips. Set aside.90 gm plain flour + 1 tsp baking powder [sifted] or 90 gm self raising flour1 tbsp chocolate powderIngredients - Egg White Mixture3 egg white [from 3 large eggs]4 tbsp castor sugar 1/4 tsp cream of tartar Whisk  egg white till frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking  andÂ  gradually add in sugar.Â  Beat till soft peaks formed.Fold about 1/3 portion into egg yolk mixture till well combined,  then fold into balance meringue. Â  Pour into a clean and ungreased 7" chiffon pan.Baked in preheated oven at 170 degrees C on lower rack for 30 - 40 minutes.Â  Invert pan immediately after baking.Â  Cool before removing from pan.

title: Banana Chiffon Cupcakes
text: Came across this recipe in Small, Small Baker blog.Â  Since I have some bananas at home, I decided to give it a try.Â  Not too please with the result probably because of the cup cases used and the baking time.Â Â Â Should baked it for at least 30 minutes at 175 degrees C on middle rack. Makes about 20 pieces.Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture40 gm egg yolks [from 2 large eggs]40 ml oil [2 tbsp]20 ml water [1.5 tbsp]60 gm bananas [mashed]Whisk egg yolks with oil till creamy, then drizzle in water.Â  Continue to whisk till well combined and add in mashed banana.Â  Whisk to combine ingredients well, then fold in sifted flour.Â  Lastly add in diced bananas. Set aside.55 gm flour + 1/2 tsp baking powder [sifted]85 gm banana - diced [keep some to cut slices]Ingredients - Egg White Mixture110 gm egg white [from 3 large eggs]55 gm castor sugar [3 tbsp]1/4 tsp cream of tartar or 5 gm cornflourWhisk egg white till frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking andÂ  gradually add in sugar.Â  Beat till soft peaks formed.Fold about 1/3 portion into egg yolk mixture till well combined, then fold into balance meringue. Combined well then scoop into cup cases.Â  Top with sliced banana as garnish.Baked in preheated oven at 175 degrees C on middle rack for 30 minutes.Â  Remove to cool on rack.Note: Can bake in 7" chiffon pan at 170 degrees C for 35-40 minutes on lower rack.

title: Blueberry Chiffon Cake
text: Bought a small tub of blueberry fillings but did not have any recipe in hand to make use of it.Â  Came across this chiffon cake recipe in 'Peng's Kitchen' so just gave it a try. Â  Really simple but not too happy with the colour of the chiffon cake.Â  Just wondering why such a dull colour.Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture3 large egg yolks30 ml corn oil [approx. 3 tbsp]30 g castor sugar [approx. 2 tbsp]75 g blueberry fillings1.5 tbsp milkWhisk egg yolks and sugar till creamy then add in oil, 1 tablespoon at a time.Â  Continue whisking after each addition.Â  Drizzle in the milk and whisk till well combined.Â  Fold in the blueberry fillings and flour.Â  Set aside.60 g self raising flour - sifted [I used 60 g plain flour + 1 tsp baking powder]Ingredients for Egg White Mixture3 large egg whites1/4 tsp cream of tartar30 g castor sugar [approx. 2 tbsp]Whisk egg whites till frothy and add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking then add in sugar in 2-3 batches.Â  Whisk egg white till soft peaks formed.Fold in 1/3 portion to egg yolk mixture till well combined, then fold in the rest of the meringue.Â  Fold till batter is smooth.Pour into a 7" chiffon pan.Â  Tap a few times to release trapped air.Â Â Bake in preheated oven at 170 degrees C for 30-40 minutes.Â  Invert pan immediately after baking.Â  Cool before removing from pan.

title: Dual Coffee Chiffon Cake
text: Quite an easy chiffon cake recipe with ingredients available from a simple kitchen yet worth keeping.Â  Recipe adapted from Cuisine Paradise but used tablespoon to measure some of the ingredients .Â  Gave this cake to my Ma, so did not manage to get a picture of the sliced cake.A.Â  Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture3 large egg yolks30 g [2 tbsp] castor sugar40 ml [3 tbsp] corn oil1 packet [20g] 3 in 1 instant coffee2 tsp instant coffee granules45 ml boiling water to blend both instant coffee granules1 tbsp rumB.Â  Flour Ingredients - sifted together80 g cake flour + 1/2 tsp baking powderC.Â  Ingredients - Egg white/Meringue3 large egg whites50 g [4 tbsp] caster sugar1/4 tsp cream of tartarMix 3 in 1 coffee with instant coffee granules with boiling water.Â  Set aside to cool.Whisk egg yolks with sugar, then add in corn oil, a tablespoon at a time.Â  Continue whisking after each addition till well combined.Â  Then add in coffee gradually, whisking as you add to egg mixture.Â  Then stir in rum.Â  Fold in flour to egg mixture till well combined.Â  Set aside.Whisk egg white in a clean bowl till frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue whisking for a second and gradually add in the sugar.Â  Continue whisking till soft peaks formed.Fold 1/3 portion of the meringue into egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold in the balance meringue till well combined.Â  Pour into a clean 7" chiffon pan.Â  Tap a few times on the table top to release trapped air.Bake in preheated oven at 180 degrees for 30-35 minutes.Â  Invert pan immediately after removing from oven.Cool before removing cake from pan.Â Note: I added some chocolate chips to cake mixture before baking.

title: Cranberry Yoghurt Chiffon Cake
text: Cranberry Yoghurt ChiffonThis recipe is adapted from Happy Home Baking but there are some changes to the ingredients to make it easier to bake the cake.Ingredients - Egg Yolk Mixture3 large egg yolks1.5 to 2 tbsp castor sugar3 tbsp corn oil80 gm cranberry yoghurt or plain yoghurt80 gm plain flour + 1/2 tsp baking powder [sifted and add in dried cranberries]60 gm dried cranberries - chopped coarselyWhisk egg yolks with castor sugar till creamy and add in corn oil [1 tbsp at a time].Â  Mix well after each addition.Â  Then add in yoghurt.Â  Mix well, fold in flour with cranberries till well combined.Â  Set aside.Â  Preheat oven at 180 degrees C for 10 minutes.Â  Meanwhile prepare the meringue.Ingredients - Egg White Mixture 3 large egg white1/4 tsp cream of tartar 3.5 tbsp caster sugarInvert pan immediately after bakingWhisk egg white in a clean mixing bowl till frothy, then add in cream of tartar.Â  Continue beating for a second and add in caster sugar gradually.Â  Continue beating all the time till soft peaks formed [Note - it is easier to fold in soft peak egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture.Â  Do not overbeat meringue]Fold in 1/2 the egg white mixture to egg yolk mixture till well combined.Â  Then fold into the balance egg white mixture.Â  Fold till mixtures are well combined.Â Â Pour into 7" chiffon pan and bake in preheated oven for 30-40 minutes on lower rack.Remove from oven and immediately invert pan to cool cake before removing from pan.

title: Steamed Yam Cake [Orh Kuih]
text: Steamed yam cake [orh kuih] is a very common steamed cake usually available at hawker stalls selling Chee Cheong Fun, Chai Kuih or some food stalls selling ready cooked dishes and Nyonya kuihs.This is a good and easy recipe for Yam Cake which I like very much.Yam cake with garmishing Recipe Source fromÂ Tiga Gajah Cho Heng Sdn Bhd, PenangIngredients - Batter Mixture270 gm rice flour100 gm wheat starch1 tbsp salt1 tsp pepper1/2 tsp msg1 1/2 tbsp sugar1000 ml waterMix all ingredients together, stir well and strain.Â  Set aside.Â  Stir again before adding to fried yam.Ingredients for BatterIngredients - Garnishing 100 gm dried prawns - washed and pounded1 tbsp oil1 red chilli - finely chopped1 stalk spring onions - cut into small pieces75 gm fried sliced shallotsFry dried prawns in oil till fragrant, remove to cool.400 gm yam - either steam half portion and mashed and add to batter mixture or cut whole portion into small cubes.3 tsp oil 2 cloves garlic - choppedHeat oil in wok and saute garlic till fragrant.Â  Add in cubed yam to fry for 5-10 minutes till aromatic.Â  Add in a little of fried dried prawns.Â  Stir to mix well and pour inÂ  2/3 portion of the batter.Â  Continue stirring on medium heat till batter thickens.Â  Off fire and add in the balance [1/3 portion] batter.Â  Stir to mix well.Pour into a greased 10" steaming tray.Â  Smooth the surface and steam over high heat for 30 minutes.After steaming, sprinkle dried prawns evenly over yam cake.Â  Cool and before serving, sprinkle spring onions, chilli and fried shallots on yam cake.Â Â Cut and serve with chilli sauceÂ [recipe here for homemade chilli sauce].Fry dried prawns and yam cubesBefore steamingAfter steaming for 30 minutes before adding garnishing

title: Taiwan Food
text: Taiwan Fried Oyster - TWD 50Taoyuan Split Bun with braised pork - TWD 35Taoyuan Siew Loong Pau - 6 for TWD 50Taoyuan Tofu Fah with Yam Balls - TWD 30/bowlTaichung Mango Shaved Ice - TWD 70/bowlTaichung Braised Pig Trotter - TWD 70/portionTaichung - Dinner for 2 - TWD 255Kaohsiung -Â  Taiwan Bento Rice Set - TWD 65 Taipei - Bento Rice set - TWD 80 [it's good]Changhua - Taiwan Meat Ball - TWD 35/pieceÂ My husband and I spent 2 weeks in Taiwan.Â Â  We travelled to various parts of the island [Taipei, Chiu-fen, Hualien, Kaohsiung, Cijin Island, Tainan, Anping, Taichung, Changhua, Lukang, Sanxia, Taoyuan and Daxi] and savoured much of their local delicacies.Â  I took plenty of photos of the food, scenery, morning and night markets to share with all my dear readers.Â  I think I can only do it gradually now as I am not in the mood since my Pa has passed away so soon after we were back.Â  Sorry for that.Â Â I am posting my Taiwan Travel and Food in my other blog - Cooking Pleasure - Travel & Food.

title: Passing of My Beloved Papa
text: My Pa was hospitalised for skin treatment a few days before I left for Taiwan.Â  He was supposed to spend about 2 weeks in hospital. For more than a decade, I was always with him whenever he was in hospital for heart problem and other ailments.Â  This time, I happened to be away and I believed he wished for his other children to take care of him. He recovered from his skin problem and was about to be discharged but then he was suddenly coughing 2 days before discharge.Â  I arrived home late on Sunday 23, October 2011 night because my flight was delayed for 2 and 1/2 hours.Â  I went to hospital the next morning to take care of him and to show him all the photos I took while in Taiwan [please refer my other blog - Cooking Pleasure - Travel & Food].Â  I didn't have the chance to show them to him.Â  He was still alert when I arrived at the hospital and only said to me "I thought I won't be able to see you again, you must come early morning tomorrow to take care of me".Â  I saw tears flowing down his cheek.Â  I know this is bad omen.Â  I changed his pampers and cleaned his body.Â  Then, he had difficulty in breathing which we thought is asthma.Â  The nurses attended to him and later the doctors came.Â  After 20 minutes, the doctor told us my Pa's heart stopped beating and has passed away [due to massive haemoptysis] after they failed to rescue him.Â  He passed away very peacefully, eyes closed and mouth smiling like in deep sleep.Â  He was 82 years old.Â  My brothers and sisters were at his bedside. I am glad he waited for me and my husband to be back.Â  I always believed he will do that for me.Â  While I was away, my siblings and sisters in-law took care of him very well.Â  He ate the food he loves to eat during his stay in hospital. My Pa should be very happy that all his children cared for him and were at his bedside till his last moment in this world.My Dearest PapaNot only myself and my siblingsÂ  are glad to have him as our Pa but my Ma is also the luckiest lady to have him as a loving and caring husband for sixty [60] years.Â  Their marriage is through match making and yet it has lasted 6 decades.Â  Their marriage is a model marriage to us all as we remembered there has never been a time of misunderstanding all these years.Â  Even till the time before he left for the hospital, he had asked my nephews to look after my Ma.My Pa was not only a caring, loving husband and father, he was also a 'commendable' grandfather to all his grandchildren and a great elder to all that are related to him.Â  One who had cared for all that came to him for help and guidance.Â  He had brought up his 4 young siblings, 6 children and cared for his mother and wife for more than half a century since the age of 30 when my grandfather passed away at the age of 51.Â  My Pa was the sole bread winner of the family.Â  Imagined during his younger days as the eldest child, life was so difficult especially during and after the Japanese Occupation.Â  He had never ever complained and always forgive other peoples misdeed throughout his life.Â  He led a very simple life [without smoking, gambling, drinking] and took care of other peoples' needs before his.I thanked God for giving me a very GOOD father for more than half a century.Â  A father whom I would like to have for my next life and thereafter.Â  Long before, I have been using this song as my handphone's ringtone and here I dedicate this song to my dear Pa "DANCE WITH MY FATHER" by Luther Vandross.Â  May his soul rest in peace and the sweet memories be with us forever and ever.Dance With My Father [Mr Ong Kok Beng @ Ong Khit Thow]Back when I was a childBefore life removed all the innocence My Father would lift me highAnd dance with my mother and meAnd then spin me around till I fell asleepThen up the stairs he would carry meAnd I knew for sure I was lovedIf I could get another chanceAnother walk, another dance with himI'd play a song that would never ever endHow I'd love love loveTo Dance with my father againWhen I and my mother would disagreeTo get my way I would run from her to himHe'd make me laugh just to comfort me, yeah yeahThen finally make me do just what my mama saidLater that night when I was asleepHe left a dollar under my sheetNever dreamed that he would be gone from meIf I could steal one final glance, one final stepOne final dance with himI'd play a song that would never ever endCause I'd love love love to Dance with my father againSometimes I'd listen outside her doorAnd I'd hear how mama would cry for himI'd pray for her even more than meI'd pray for her even more than me I know I'm praying for much too muchBut could you send her the only man she lovedI know you don't do it usually, but dear LordShe's dying to Dance with my father againEvery night I fall asleep, and this is all I ever dream.

title: Taiwan Trip 2011
text: Hi, I am on holiday in Taiwan for 2 weeks.Â  My hubby loves food and we planned to look and eat around in the island.Â  Hopefully my camera is faithful enough for me to bring back the delicacies in pictures to share with all my dear readers.My hubby will share with you our holiday travel tips and experiences in the island if you wish to travel there on your own.Â  Visit the virtualtourist.com for details.Ciao until we meet again.

title: Vegetarian Stir Fry Turnip [Sengkuang]
text: Vegetarian Stir Fry Turnip [sengkuang]My Pa was in hospital due to old age skin problems.Â  Since I have to take care of him, there will be no more vegetarian cooking for the time being.Â Â  My Ma will cook her own vegetarian dishes.Â  So here I will post all the vegetarian recipes that I have prepared so far which may be of interest to dear readers.The non-vegetarian stir fry turnip is a popular dish among Malaysian Chinese especially the Peranakan people and sometimes a must have dish during festive season a.k.a Popiah Chai and Jiu Hu Char.Here, I prepared this vegetarian version of Popiah Chai that is minus the non-vegetarian ingredients such as pork, shredded dried cuttlefish, crab meat or prawns etc.Ingredients1 big turnip [sengkuang] about 1.5 kg - cut very fine shreds1 carrot - cut very fine shreds3-4 dried mushrooms - soaked and cut fine shreds2 piece beancurd - cut thin strips10-12 french beans - finely sliced50 ml oilSalt and vegetarian msg to tasteHeat oil in wok to fry beancurd.Â  Stir fry continously till slightly crispy.Â  Remove and set aside.Using the same wok and add a little more oil if necessary.Â  Fry mushrooms till fragrant then add in turnip and carrot.Â  Continue frying until the vegetables are limp and soft.Â  Add in salt and msg to taste.Then add in fried beancurd and french beans.Â  Stir fry to combine and cook till french beans are cooked.Â  Dish out to serve with rice or lettuce leaves and chilli sauce.Note: This vegetable dish can be used as fillings for vegetable Chinese paus. Â Just make sure it is not too watery otherwise, it is difficult for wrapping.

title: Vegetarian Fried Tofu With Tau Cheong
text: This dish goes well with either rice or plain porridge.Â  Very economical dish, only costs Ringgit 2.00.Ingredients3 piece tofu - cut 4 pieces each2 tbsp chopped ginger [I used young ginger]1 red chilli - chopped1 stalk coriander leaves - chopped2 tbsp tau cheong [preserved soya bean]some waterenough oil to fry tofu piecesHeat oil in wok until hot, put in tofu pieces to fry till golden brown.Â  Fry in batches. Set aside.Remove excess oil, leave 1 tbsp in wok to saute ginger and chillies until aromatic.Â  Add in tau cheong and fry for a second.Â  The pour in some water.Â When water boils, add in the fried tofu.Â  Simmer for 1-2 minutes.Â  Add in chopped coriander.Dish out to serve.I'm linking this post toÂ Dish it Out - Tofu-Paneer & Bell Peppers AnnouncementÂ hosted byÂ My Spicy Kitchen

title: Stir Fry Bok Choy With Mock Char Siew
text: A friend of mine gave me some mock char siew supposedly imported from Hongkong.Â  I used it to fry bok choy and also fry rice.Â  Very simple stir fry dish for a vegetarian meal. Just wondering how the manufacturers can produce such look alike and taste alike food product, I really do not know.Â  Anyway, not a problem as I do not fancy using these processed food products when preparing vegetarian dishes.Ingredients300 gm bok choy - cut 1 inch length1 small piece mock char siew - slicedlight soy sauce to taste1 tbsp oildash of pepperHeat oil in wok, saute mock char siew for a second.Â  Add in bok choy and stir fry on high heat for a minute.Â  Drizzle some light soy sauce and a dash of pepper to taste.Dish out to serve.

title: Stir Fry Loofah with Assorted Ingredients
text: A very complete vegetarian dish with at least 5 colours [white, green, yellow, red and black] of ingredients which is supposed to be good for healthy living.Ingredients300 gm loofah [kak kwa] - skinned and cut into wedges100 gm mee kin [fresh gluten] - sliced 1 tin canned button mushrooms - halved5 - 6 black fungus - soaked and break into smaller pieces 2 - 3 beancurd stick [tau kee] - soaked and cut 1 inch length100 gm carrot - cut into desired shapes10 gm tunghoon - soaked in water for 5 minutes a few slices of ginger2 tbsp oilSeasoning [combine together]2-3 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp sesame oil salt to tastedash of pepper100 ml waterHeat oil in wok, saute ginger till fragrant.Â  Add in gluten pieces, mushrooms, tau kee, carrots and black fungus.Â  Stir fry to mix ingredients well.Â  Add in seasoning.Â  Stir for a few seconds and add in water.Â  Bring to a boil till all ingredients are soft.Â Then add in loofah.Â  Continue to fry to cook loofah until soft and add in tunghoon.Â  Cook till tunghoon is clear [very fast - 1 second]. Dish out to serve.

title: Sweet and Sour Vegetarian Tau Pau
text: This is an appetising dish with canned pineapples [can also used canned lychee, longan or mixed fruit cocktail] and tau pau.Â  I have forgotten to take a picture of the 'Tau Pau' which is a.k.a. vegetarian egg but is in rectangle shape.Ingredients10 pieces of tau pau - pan fried till golden brown - cut half1 cucumber - diced or cut any desired shape1 small green capsicum - cut diamond shape1 small red capsicum - cut diamond shape [I usedÂ  1 red chilli]1 canned pineapple cubes - drain and keep the syrup for sauceSeasoning sauce [combine with canned pineapple syrup]2 tbsp tomato sauce1 tbsp oyster sauce1 tbsp plum sauce1/2 tbsp light soy sauce100 ml water1 tbsp cornflour mix with 2 tbsp waterPut 1 tbsp oil in wok, saute all the cut vegetables.Â  Stir fry for 5 seconds and add in seasoning sauce.Bring to boil and add in pan fried tau pau [vegetarian egg].Â  Stir and let it cook to absorb the flavours for about a minute.Then thicken with cornflour mix.Â  Dish out to serve with rice.

title: Sesame Oil Ginger Vegetarian Egg
text: This dish is like the Mua Eu Khay [Sesame Oil Chicken].Â  For the vegetarian version, I used vegetarian egg with sesame oil and lots of ginger.Â Â  Simple yet appetising.Pan fried vegetarian eggIngredients10 pieces vegetarian egg - pan fried until golden brown5 dried mushrooms - soaked and halved [can substitute with bok nee]3 tbsp ginger - cut fine shreds3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1 tsp sugar3 tbsp sesame oila dash cooking wine100 ml water [tau pau will soakÂ  up some of the gravy]Â  Â Â Heat sesame oil in wok, saute finely cut ginger until aromatic and slightlyÂ  crispy.Â  Set aside.Add in dried mushrooms fry till aromatic.Â  Then add in sauce ingredrients and water.Bring it to a boil for 1 - 2 minutes, then put in the fried vegetarian egg pieces.Â Â  Braised for another 5-10 minutes and add a dash cooking wine.Â  Dish out to serve with rice.

title: Stir Fried Instant Noodles with Assorted Ingredients
text: My earlier postings on Stir Fried Noodles are 'no frills' with just the very basic ingredients.Â  This time, when fryingÂ  another vegetarian noodle, I added some extra ingredients like fresh gluten pieces, carrot and black fungus [boknee] for a change.Â Ingredients[serves 3] 3 pieces instant noodles [no flavourings] - blanched in boiling water to loosen and drain2 stalks bok choy - cut2 tbsp shredded carrot2 tbsp fresh gluten shreds2 bok nee - soaked and cut shreds a handful of beansprouts2 tbsp oilExtra ingredients - boknee, carrot, gluten shredsSeasoning 2 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tsp dark soy saucedash of pepperdash of sesame oildash of vegetarian msg1/2 cup waterHeat oil in wok on medium heat, add in gluten shreds, carrot and bok nee to fry.Â  Then add in bok choy and beansprouts.Â  Stir fry to combine and add in blanched noodles.Turn to low fire, add in seasoning sauce. Stir to mix seasoning evenly with noodles.Â  Then turn to high heat.Â  Continue stir frying noodles and pour in water.Â Â Cover to cook for 1-2 minutes.Â  Remove cover,Â  stir noodles until water is almost dry, off fire and dish out to serve.

title: Vegetarian  Duck [Vegetarian Siew Ngoh]
text: Fried vegetarian duck before slicingVery tasty, tender vegetarian duckIngredients for this dish is simple but the steaming is quite tedious.Â  I made 20 pieces in one go.Â  My advice is not to make too many as I have to steam them in batches.Â  The recipe here is only for making 4 pieces.Â  This dish can be prepared ahead and kept for weeks in the refrigerator before deep frying to serve.Ingredients for vegetarian gooseIngredients1 sheet [dried beancurd sheet - used for cooking tong sui] - soak in water for 5-10 minutes and drain.2 sheets of big size beancurd skin [foo peh]Marinade ingredients [combine together]1 tsp 5 spice powder1 tsp castor1/2 tsp vegetarian msg1 tsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp sesame oil 1 cube nam yee 'tau choo' [red fermented beancurd]a dash of pepper110 ml water8 satay sticksBefore steamingAfter steaming for 20 minutesCombine marinade ingredients in a bowl and set aside.Cut each beancurd skin into 4 equal size pieces.Spread 1-2 tablespoon of marinade ingredients all over a sheet of beancurd skin [foo peh], place another sheet on top and spread again 1-2 tbsp marinade.Â  Place a piece of the soaked beancurd sheet in the centre and fold into a rectangle.Â  Prick the top with a satay stick so that the seasoning can seep through the holes.Â  Use toothpicks to pin both ends to hold the pieces in place.Â  Do the same for the balance ingredients.Put vegetarian goose on a lightly greased plate and steam for 20 minutes.Â  In between steaming, open the lid for a second and continue steaming.Â  Remove and leave to cool before storing.To serve, deep fry each piece till golden brown.Â  Cut into 2 cm slices and serve plain or with chilli sauce.

title: Orange Sweet Potato Ginger Soup
text: Since half of the family members are on vegetarian diet today, we had Stir Fried Flat Noodles and Yellow Noodles for lunch together with Sweet Potato Ginger Soup.It is simple, economical and fast to cook.Â  Here are the ingredients.Sweet Potato Soup in 50 years old bowl Ingredients[serves 4-5]350 - 400 gm orange colour sweet potatoes - skinned and cut wedges3-4 screwpine [pandan] leaves - knotted1.2 litres water75 gm sugar1 knob of old ginger - lightly bruisedPut all ingredients except sugar in a pot.Â  Boil on medium high heat until the sweet potatoes are soft and has the fragrance of ginger [about 1/2 an hour].Add sugar to taste.Off fire, serve hot or warm with Stir Fried Noodles.NoteThe soup bowl is one of my grandma's collection used only during this 'Kew Ong Yeah' festival.

title: Stir Fried Flat Rice and Yellow  Noodles
text: When we are on vegetarian diet, a simple dish always taste appetising.Â  This is another simple stir fried noodle using fresh noodles, the yellow noodles and koay teow [flat rice noodles].Â  This combination of stir fried noodle is also common in the wet market food stalls or vegetarian food stalls. Here, I added fried sweet beancurd sticks as garnish and condiment.Ingredients[serves 3-4]300 gm yellow noodles300 gm koay teow2 stalks chai sim [mustard leaves]100 gm beansprout2 tbsp oil3 pieces sweet beancurd sticks - cut thin strips Sweet beancurd sticks [teik ah kee in hokkien]Â Seasoning Sauce [mix together]2 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp dark soy sauce - for colour1 tsp sugar1 tsp vegetarian msg100 ml hot waterPut enough oil in wok and add in sweet beancurd stick.Â  Turn on heat to medium and stir fry continuously to fry beancurd stick to golden brown [fry from cold oil to prevent beancurd sticks from being over browned before getting crispy].Â  Dish out on to absorbent kitchen paper.Â  Set aside.Â  Remove excess oil, leave about 2-3 tbsp in the wok to fry noodles.Reheat oil.Â  Add in yellow noodles and vegetables. Stir fry to mix well and add in koay teow together with seasoning ingredients.Â  Stir with ladle and chopstick.Â  Sprinkle water around the wok to cook the noodles well.Continue to fry till water has reduced and noodles are cooked.Â  Dish out to serve.Â  Garnish with fried beancurd sticks and chilli sauce/pickled green chillies.

title: Vegetarian Galangal Chilli Sauce
text: This is my Grandma's special fried vegetarian chilli sauce that goes well with plain white rice.Â  It is spicy, taste a bit sweet and sourish.Â  I do not have her exact recipe but I tried making it.Â  Taste is slightly different as I add wild torch ginger flower to make it more aromatic. You can omit it, still has it's unique taste.Ingredients for the chilli sauce Blended ingredients and lime juiceÂ Ingredients100 gm [6] red chillies - washed and cut small pieces3 small chillies [cili padi] -washed and cut1 knob galangal - scrape off the skin and diced1 wild torch ginger [bunga kantan] - chopped [optional]1 sprig coriander leaves8 limau kasturi juice3 tbsp fine tau cheong 1 tsp saltÂ 3-4 tbsp sugar to taste100 ml oilBlend chillies, galangal, torch ginger and coriander leaves till fine.Heat oil in wok and saute grounded ingredients till fragrant , aromatic then add in tau cheong.Â  Continue to fry till fragrant and oil separates.Â  Add sugar and salt to taste.Lastly add in lime juice and simmer till chilli paste is thick but not dry and oil is clear chilli oil.Â  Cool and store in glass jar.Â  Serve with noodles or plain rice.

title: Fried Teochew Beancurd With Chinese Celery [Kin Chye]
text: Soya products [tofu, taukwa, tofu puff, beancurd sheets etc] are probably the most essential ingredients when preparing vegetarian dishes.Â  A soya product like tofu can be a main ingredient to a dish.Â  For this dish, I used Teochew taukwa [semi soft beancurd] with chinese celery [kin chye in hokkien dialect].Â  Ingredients3 pieces Teochew beancurd - cut into 4 cubes2 stalks of kin chye - cut 1" lengthsenough oil for frying2 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp oyster saucea dash of peppera dash of sesame oila dash of cooking wineFry tofu pieces in hot oil till golden brown.Â  Dish out and set aside.Remove all the oil.Â  Using the same wok, add in chinese celery.Â  Stir fry and add in seasoning with a little water.Â  Bring it to a boil and return the fried taukwa.Â  Stir to mix sauce and taukwa.Dish out on plate to serve with rice.

title: Braised Taufu Pok and Peanuts
text: A simple vegetarian dish with few ingredients but goes well with porridge or even plain rice.Basic ingredients for this dishIngredients200 gm taufu pok [tofu puffs] - soaked, squeeze off excess water and halved3 big dried mushrooms - soaked and cut cubes1 small can braised peanuts - rinsed with boiled water1 tbsp oil1 star aniseSeasoning Sauce3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp cooking wine 1 tsp dark soy sauce for colour1 tbsp sugar1 tsp salt1 cup water 1/4 tsp pepper 1 tsp sesame oil When cold the puffs will release some gravyHeat oil in wok on medium heat, saute mushrooms till aromatic.Â  Add in soy sauce, sugar, cooking wine and water.Â  Bring it to a boil and add tofu puffs.Â  Stir to mix.Â  Cover to braise for 5 - 10 minutes.Then add in braised peanuts and pepper.Â  Stir and cover.Â  Continue to braise till gravy is almost dry and puffs are soft.Â  Add in sesame oil before dishing out to serve with rice or porridge.

title: Stir Fried Five Coloured Vegetables
text: A healthy, colourful and nutritious vegetarian dish.Ingredients100 gm carrot - cut into desired shapes150 gm cabbage - cleaned and break into bite size pieces 150 gm broccoli - cut into florets6 pieces black fungus - soaked and break into smaller pieces 50 gm dried golden lilies [kim chiam] - knot tied in the middle, cut off the ends and soak for 1 minute50 gm tofu puffs [taufu pok] - halvedsome fatt choy - soaked and squeezed out excess watera few slices of ginger 2 tbsp oil Seasoning Sauce [Mix together]1-2 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tsp mushroom stock granules or vegetarian msg1 tsp sesame oil1/2 tsp salta dash of pepper100 ml waterCombine 1 tsp cornflour with 1 tbsp water for thickeningHeat oil in wok to saute ginger, dried golden lilies [kim chiam] till aromatic. Add in black fungus, cabbage and carrot.Â  Continue to fry till cabbage is soft, meanwhile add in seasoning sauce.Â  Add in water and bring to a boil.Add in tofu puffs.Â  Stir to mix well and add in broccoli and fatt choy.Â  Cover to cook all ingredients.Thicken gravy slightly.Â  Dish out to serve with rice.

title: Braised Dual Mui Choy With Mushrooms
text: Another vegetarian dish that can be prepared ahead and warm up just before serving with rice or porridge.Two types of mui choy and mee keen Ingredients200 gm salted mui choy - rinsed, soaked and chopped200 gm sweet mui choy - rinsed, soaked and chopped100 gm fresh gluten balls [mee kin ] - cut shreds50 gm dried mushrooms - soaked and cut strips [I used dried enoki mushrooms]1 small can braised peanuts5 tbsp oil + 1 tsp sesame oilSeasoning 3 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1/2 tbsp dark soy sauce2 tbsp sugar to taste1 tsp pepper2-3 cups waterHeat oil in a wok and saute mushrooms till fragrant.Â  Then add in gluten strips.Â  Fry for a minute and add in both types of mui choy.Â  Stir fry for 5-10 minutes over medium heat.Â  Add in seasoning.Continue to fry till fragrant and add in enough water to cover ingredients.Â  Bring it to a boil and reduce heat to simmer vegetables until soft and gravy is reduced. Add in braised peanuts.Â  Stir to mix all ingredients. Serve with plain rice or porridge.

title: Brown Bean Soup
text: These red beans are not the usual type like the Tien Chin red beans. Â The colour is slightly brownish but after boiling and when cooked, it changes to a very nice orangy red.Â  The skin of the beans do not separate from the flesh even when the beans are soft.Â  A very tasty red bean soup that can be served with stir fry noodles.Â  Be careful when adding sugar because the beans have a natural sweetness.IngredientsÂ 300 gm brown beans [see picture]3-4 pieces screwpine leaves [pandan leaves]1.5 litres water 100 gm sugar or lessPick the rotten beans and discard them.Â  Wash the beans under running water several times.Put all ingredients except sugar in a big sauce pot.Â  Bring it to a boil for about 10 minutes.Â  Then lower heat, cover and simmer for 1 1/2 hours or till beans are soft.Add sugar to taste.Â  Off fire and serve hot or warm.

title: Stir Fried Rice Vermicelli [Economy Fried Bee Hoon ]
text: I believe this is the simplest stir fry beehoon [no frills] which can be found usually in the wet market areas all year round and most of the temporary vegetarian food stalls.Â  But the appearance should look slightly different because most of the stalls will add very little greens. This noodle usually enjoy brisk business on the 1st and 15th day of the lunar month because many of the Taoists andÂ  Buddhists will go vegetarian on these 2 days of the month.Usually, I would prefer to add more beansprouts and mustard leaves when frying the noodles.Ingredients[serves 2-3]150 gm beehoon - soak in water for 5 - 10 minutes100 gm beansprouts - tailed2 stalks chai sim [mustard leaves] 2 tbsp oilSeasoning3 tbsp light soy sauce1 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce1 tsp dark soy sauce1/2 tsp sugar1/4 tsp vegetarian msg150 ml waterÂ  Dried sweet beancurd sticksÂ Â Fried in oil till golden brownÂ Heat oil in wok, add in carrot and chai sim.Â  Fry and add in water.Â  When water boils, lower fire, put in the beehoon and all the seasoning.Â  Stir to mix well and add in beansprout.Â  Turn heat to medium high, stir and cover wok for 2 minutes.Remove cover and use chopsticks and ladle to loosen noodles, fry till beehoon is moist and water is almost dry.Â Â Dish out on plate to serve with fried sweet beancurd strips and chilli sauce.Â  Enjoy with a bowl of red bean soupÂ Brown Bean Soup.

title: Stir Fried Instant Flat Noodles
text: Two types of chillies for fried noodlesI bought a packet of instant flat noodles with pumpkin as one of the ingredients.Â  Since it is vegetarian, I used it to cook a simple stir fry noodles with beansprouts and chai sim [mustard leaves] and serve it with the chilli sauce and pickled green chillies which I have prepared earlier.Â  Simple but definitely taste good too.Blanched flat noodles, beansprouts and chai simBasic seasoning ingredients for vegetarian dishÂ  Ingredients[serves 2]2-3 bundles of instant flat noodles2 stalks chai sim - clean and cutÂ a handful of beansprouts - washed2 tbsp oil and 1 tsp sesame oilSeasoning Sauce [mix together]2 tbsp vegetarian oyster sauce2 tbsp light soy sauce1/2 tbsp dark soy sauce - for colour1/4 tsp pepper1/2 tsp vegetarian msg150 ml hot waterÂ Blanched noodles in boiling water till al dente.Â  Drain dry and mix in some oil to prevent noodles from sticking.Â  Set aside.Heat oil in wok.Â  Add in vegetables and beansprouts to fry for a second then add in blanched noodles.Â  Use a wok ladle and a pair of chopsticks to combine ingredients well.Â  Add in seasoning, stir fry to mix well.Â  Then add in water.Â  Stir and cover to cook noodles for a minute or until the water has almost dried up.Stir and dish on to serve withÂ  prepared chilli sauce or pickled green chillies.NoteFried noodles also goes well with a bowl of red bean soup.

title: Simple Chilli Sauce for Stir Fry Noodles
text: This is a simple chilli sauce suitable for vegetarian stir fry noodles [beehoon, kuay teow, yellow noodles etc].Ingredients50 gm chilli paste100 ml water1 tbsp vinegar1 tbsp sugar1/2 tsp saltBring all ingredients to a quick boil.Â  Cool and store in glass container.

title: Pickled Green Chillies
text: Pickled Green ChilliesThis is a simple but good version of pickled green chillies worth to make.Â  Suitable to serve with vegetarian stir fry noodles [rice vermicelli, rice noodles, yellow or instant noodles etc].Ingredients - Mix togetherÂ 120 ml boiling water60 ml white rice vinegar 2 tsp sugar1/2 tsp salt100 gm [6-8] green chillies - sliced [can add some chilli padi]Sliced Green ChilliesGreen chillies blanched in boiling waterMix together the water, vinegar, sugar and salt.Wash and slice green chillies and blanched in hot boilingÂ  water for a minute.Â  Drain dry and add to the vinegar solution.Cool and store in glass container.Â  Stand for 24 hours prior to serving.

title: Vegetarian Pickled Vegetables [Acar Awak]
text: Vegetarian Pickled Vegetables [Acar]This is a vegetarian Acar [pickled vegetables] without garlic or onions.Â  For the Nine Emperor Gods Festival [Kew Ong Yeah] whereby devotees observe a strict vegetarian diet for a duration of 9-10 days, certain vegetables cannot be consumed or use to cook the vegetarian dishes eventhough they are in the vegetables category.Â  Some of these exceptional vegetables which I know are onions, spring onions, garlic, leeks and kailan.Â However, even without onions added, this dish tastes as good.Cut vegetables before blanching Ingredients for the Chilli Paste [combine together]200 gm chilli paste100 gm grounded lemongrass50 gm grounded galangal 50 gm tumeric paste [tumeric powder mix with water]30 gm grounded candlenuts [buah keras]Other Ingredients2 kg cucumber - cut 1 inch length thin strips - season with some salt, set aside 1/2 kg cabbage - break into bite size pieces1/2 kg carrots - cut 1 inch length thin strips1/2 kg long beans - cut 1 inch length pieces200 gm grounded peanuts 3-4 tbsp toasted sesame seeds200 gm sugar2 tsp salt150 ml oil1.5 ml water and 200 ml white vinegar - for blanching vegetablesFrying sesame seeds till golden brownBlanching vegetables in boiling water and vinegarBlanched vegetables and chilli pasteSeason cut cucumber with some salt and set aside for15-20 minutes. Place seasoned cucumber in a muslin bag and squeeze out the water.Â  Do this in several batches.Â  Drier cucumber will make it crunchy when cooked.Bring 1.5 litres water to boil in a wok then add in 200 ml vinegar.Â  Blanched each of the cut vegetables for about a minute and remove usingÂ  a serrated ladle into a basin.
